webTitle: Is this a shagger I see before me?

fields.headline: Is this a shagger I see before me?
fields.standfirst:
As a fully paid-up public transport anorak, Steven Norris says he knows more about London bus routes than any person alive. So, asks Tim Adams, how come he's so successful with women?
The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: As a fully paid-up public transport anorak, Steven Norris says he knows more about London bus routes than any person alive. So, asks  Tim Adams, how come he's so successful with women?
fields.body:
Key 'London mayor' into your internet search engine and you discover that two car salesman are running for the capital's new office. One is Steven Norris, who made his first million selling Volkswagens in Wiltshire and bought a pea-green Rolls Royce to celebrate. The other is Frank Butcher of Albert Square, diamond geezer and unlovable rogue. The 'Frankly, we'd rather have Frank' site was set up in response to the fact that there is no real independent mayoral alternative to the established party candidates.

'Frank', as Frank's 'frank-talking' supporters would have it, 'is not a politician, he's one of us.' The Norris site wants us to believe something similar. Their man, though he now has the somewhat grudging backing of his party, is not concerned with ideology, he's just impatient to get things done. 'Action not politics', his slogan says.

The rivals have a few other things in common: both men have a bit of romantic hinterland; both wear their hearts on the sleeve of a flash suit; neither is afraid to call a spade a spade, or get his hands dirty (or employ a populist cliché ). And both are, you suspect, essentially fictional characters.

The Tories' unembarrassable first reserve has long been at pains to present himself as a maverick. He's the champion of civil liberties who firmly believes in capital punishment; he was instrumental in the great railway sell-off, yet sympathised with the road protesters at Newbury; he's a campaigner for freedom of information and a subject of tabloid intrusions; he's a Conservative anti-hunt protester who cries at Broadway tunes.

'But hell,' he says, ever the bloke's bloke, 'I've never been afraid of being the only fella in the regiment marching out of step...'

Steven Norris likes to admit he may irritate some people but he is equally fond of suggesting those same people could trust him to get the trains running on time, make things happen. 'Y'know, ruffle some feathers, if that's what it takes...'

The first thing he has to make happen when I arrive to meet him is solving the problem of how to get into his campaign office in Victoria. 'We're locked out,' his PR man explains, and sends me over the road for breakfast. Eventually the key to the Norris nerve centre is located, the public transport guru's full-time chauffeur comes to find me, and I'm ushered inside where a jolly (but fundamentally serious) Norris leads me through a corridor decked with his jolly (but fundamentally serious) posters. There is then a little debate as to who will get coffee; several orders for our three cups are placed with different campaign staff; two coffees eventually arrive.

By which time Norris is doing what you imagine is his second-favourite thing: talking about transport. 'I'm standing for mayor because I'm an appalling anorak who happens to know more about London's bus and Tube network than almost anyone else alive,' he says, and over the course of the next hour goes out of his way to prove the fact, explaining how he is patron of Susstrans bike initiative and of the 'ultra-green' Transport 2000 group (this in addition to his lucrative non-executive chairmanship of one of London's bus operators, and former directorship of the Road Haulage Association).

There is something mesmerising in listening to Norris talk about the city's traffic. He gets an evangelical glint in his eye. His voice goes up half an octave. He's the Billy Graham of bus lanes; the Jimmy Swaggart of the Central Line. It feels like we've been round the North Circular a couple of times before I get to ask a question.

And when Norris is not talking about his own transport policies he's rubbishing those of Ken Livingstone. Though Norris is, according to the latest poll, lying a distant third in the campaign with 11 per cent of the projected vote, he is making every attempt to convince anyone who'll listen that 'of course it's essentially a two-horse race'. He dismisses Frank Dobson loftily as a party placeman and he does not deign even to mention Susan Kramer, who he bullied and patronised on last week's Question Time. In his wilfully narrowed view it's either himself or Ken. 'When we heard Livingstone was in,' he says in his bullish way, 'this place really got a buzz - at last you know who your enemy is, what the battle is.

'Our job is a simple one,' he goes on, never a man to get mired in petty politicking. 'The dinner party conversation may be that voting for Ken is a good way to poke Blair in the eye with a stick; but in fact, of course, the best way to poke him in the eye with a stick is to vote for me.'

Norris is keen to characterise himself in this sense as the London equivalent of New York Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, the unashamed pragmatist in a city of political correctness: 'I make that comparison unhesitatingly,' he says. 'The reality is that Giuliani is a Republican in a city of Democrats. New Yorkers don't like him much but they respect him. I don't see why you need to be disliked as such, but people always respect someone who can deliver.'

There are those in Norris's own party who might be just as likely to draw a comparison between Norris and another celebrated American mayor. Not since Marion Barry was re-elected in Washington DC in 1994 after having been filmed in room 727 of the Vista International Hotel trying to persuade a former glamour model into his bed while taking drags on a pipe full of crack cocaine can a mayoral candidate have enjoyed such a special relationship with tabloid newspapers. Though Norris now talks of the week in 1993 when every day produced another unlikely front page Norris lover 'as a long, long, long time ago', it has come back to haunt him in this campaign.

Initially his candidature was blocked when a small group of his former constituency members in Epping Forest sent a letter to the London selection committee. The letter raked over Norris's infidelities and suggested him unfit for public office. There was an extra edge to it in that one of its signatories was the mother of Tim Collins, now William Hague's press secretary and in 1993 the 'brains' behind John Major's doomed 'Back to Basics' campaign, which Norris did so much to promote. Norris, 'for once allowing myself to be ungenerous', dismissed those responsible for the letter as a 'monstrous regiment' of 'harpies'. Meanwhile, the day his original candidature was announced was marked by a letter to the Times from his father-in-law, a retired rear-admiral, expressing astonishment at Norris's public plans to marry the fourth of his famous five mistresses - Lucy Clayton graduate Emma Courtney, the mother of Norris's third son - since as far as the rear-admiral knew, Norris was still married to his daughter.

Norris's reaction to these stories has always been to build them into his personal mythology. 'He makes a great virtue of his amorality,' says Sheila Gunn, the political journalist. And she should know: she was in the odd position of being the mistress who discovered she was being cheated on by Norris when she read Nigel Dempster's column. Certainly the 'Rolex Romeo' is fond of a lowest common denominator defence: I may be a serial adulterer, he has always suggested, but, hey, aren't we all (and anyway who else is going to get the trains running on time, ruffle a few feathers etc). Parliamentary insiders say he rather enjoys his tea room soubriquet 'shagger'. I wonder if he thinks his very public private life is something that enhances his appeal?

He looks a little pained, shakes his head. 'Oh, no, no, no, Tim,' he says, suddenly grave. 'Not proud of it, no. That's not me at all...'

The thing that saved Norris's political life back in 1993 was the fact that, unlike some of his colleagues in the Major administration, he had never preached on lifestyle choices. He continues to annoy the right of his party and Telegraph leader writers by supporting the abolition of Clause 28, and suggesting the Metropolitan Police should have more important concerns than rounding up gay men cruising in the dead of night on Hampstead Heath. (Norris is fond of responding to the question 'what will you do for the gay lobby?' with the reply 'gays use the Tube, too.')

Unsurprisingly for a man with his track record, Norris does not see any link between public and private morality. 'I will run my campaign on the basis of Who I Am,' he says. 'And I won't fit into any identikit pictures if they clearly don't fit.'

Who Norris is, however, is almost anyone's guess: reading his autobiography Changing Trains , you have the sense of a man who has come to believe his own myths; talking to him, you feel he finds it hard to separate the stories from the reality (he describes his days running a car dealership in Salisbury, for example, as his 'Guys-and-Dolls-Damon-Runyon kind of life').

The son of a civil servant father and a teacher mother, he grew up in Liverpool, attending the same school as Paul McCartney (who used to play skiffle in free periods) and George Harrison. He says he still sees himself as a scouser and is as quick as ever to suggest how that makes him attractive: 'I have the huge advantage now of sounding and looking reasonably classless; I'm comfortable - after a good grammar school and Oxford - at any intellectual level, and at the same time I have the advantage of knowing that if I ended up back in a two-up-two-down in Liverpool I'd be fine. He smiles, and then corrects himself. 'Actually my mum will be on the phone: we also had a box bedroom in the front.'

Though the closest he apparently got to free love back then was a famous fumble with Edwina Currie behind the school bike sheds, does he see himself a child of the Sixties? He winces a little. 'I wouldn't go that far,' he says of his party's least favourite decade.

He believes his life is 'absolutely settled now with Emma'. She describes their relationship as 'extremely tactile' and displays a great capacity for trust. 'When someone says "I want your child", you tend to believe them,' she says of Norris.

Now 54, her jowly partner is enjoying his life as a new dad and suggests he has got his bed-hopping out of his system. Still, the closest he gets to introspection is to say that he 'internalises things too much, buries things too deeply, although I often cry in the car, which helps'.

Apart from a blocked nearside bus lane, what exactly opens the floodgates? 'Oh probably just a Cole Porter song or something,' he says. 'I am simply a hopeless sentimentalist and that might even mask a less attractive side of my character. Emma would say that I have an ability to cut myself off that is quite terrifying on occasions. It's the way some people respond to a challenge or to danger or whatever.

'I wouldn't say I was particularly brave physically - not,' he hastens to add, 'that I've ever had any problems in that line. I think we're all... you know ... I'm trying to find a thread. I'm a sentimentalist who might therefore not actually be prone to great swings of emotional depth.'

That superficiality is perhaps what allows Steven Norris to come across as having such an uncomplicated agenda. He has no problem, for example, in believing that though he walked from his job at the Ministry of Transport into extremely well-paid directorships with transport companies no one 'has ever once hired me for my contacts book'. Similarly he does not labour under the slightest Prescott-style guilt-trip when he discusses the problems of the 77a while his chauffeur idles outside.

But it is presumably this same relaxed conscience that prompted Sheila Gunn to say 'she fell in love with a man who didn't exist'. Norris's other one time amour, Edwina Currie, remarked in reviewing Changing Trains that Norris and his ilk, who grew up politically in the Thatcher years, 'just didn't get it': didn't understand that 'integrity and probity are not partial qualities... but must shine though every facet.'

Norris, typically, would rather let himself off more lightly. He once remarked that his epitaph would read 'Here lies Steven Norris. This is the first place he has taken seriously.' He has long proved the virtue of being able to laugh at himself; the difficulty he faces now, you sense, is persuading Londoners they don't have to share the joke.

fields.headline: Waugh attacks pitch
fields.trailText: Fourteen wickets on the opening day left Australia, who were bowled out for 214 after winning the toss, in control of the first Test against New Zealand at Eden Park. Shane Warne and Brett Lee both took wickets with their second balls to reduce New Zealand's reply from 25 for one to 26 for four in the space of four overs.
fields.body:
Fourteen wickets on the opening day left Australia, who were bowled out for 214 after winning the toss, in control of the first Test against New Zealand at Eden Park. Shane Warne and Brett Lee both took wickets with their second balls to reduce New Zealand's reply from 25 for one to 26 for four in the space of four overs.

After Glenn McGrath, unerringly straight and fast, broke through with Matt Horne's dismissal, Warne's leg-spin removed No 3 Mathew Sinclair for eight, leg before wicket without playing a shot. Quick bowler Lee had Craig Spearman brilliantly caught at third slip by Damien Martyn, before bowling nightwatchman Paul Wiseman with the day's last ball.

The flat, brown pitch had more of a third or fourth-day look about it, providing considerable assistance for the spinners and some seam movement for the pace bowlers. New Zealand's spin duo of Daniel Vettori, orthodox left-arm, and the finger spinner Wiseman earlier did the job for their team in just 71 overs as they combined to skittle Australia. Vettori took his fourth bag of five wickets in Tests with his five for 62 off 25 overs, while Wiseman had his second-best Test total of four for 49.

After the early loss of Michael Slater, who was bowled by Chris Cairns for five without offering a shot, Greg Blewett and Justin Langer raced along at a run a minute. At drinks, Australia were 64 for one, but then the collapse started. Langer, who made 46 off 47 balls, took a risk too many against Wiseman and was stumped by Adam Parore.

Blewett followed soon after with the total on 78 and only No 4, Mark Waugh, stayed around for any length of time as the wickets tumbled at the other end. Steve Waugh and Damien Martyn both fell to Vettori for 17 to leave Australia on 138 for five before Mark Waugh pressed on to his thirty-eighth Test half-century in 132 minutes off 96 balls.

At drinks, Australia were 64 for one, but then the collapse started. Langer, who made 46 off 47 balls, took a risk too many against Wiseman and was stumped by Adam Parore.

Blewett followed soon after with the total on 78 and only No 4, Mark Waugh, stayed around for any length of time as the wickets tumbled at the other end. Steve Waugh and Damien Martyn both fell to Vettori for 17 to leave Australia on 138 for five before Mark Waugh pressed on to his thirty-eighth Test half-century in 132 minutes off 96 balls.

Vettori, after having no wicket for 25 off three overs, cleaned up three of the last four wickets as Mark Waugh was stranded at the other end on 72, scored in 197 minutes.

Steve Waugh said 250 to 300 runs would have been a good total in the conditions, which he wasn't 100 per cent happy with. 'It wasn't unexpected that 14 wickets fell,' he said. 'When you produce a pitch that's like the fourth day of a normal Test match it's going to produce wickets.'

Waugh added that he couldn't see the game lasting more than three days and believed his team had a 70-to-30 advantage after day one.

New Zealand coach David Trist also raised concerns over the pitch, but said some poor shots by his batsmen helped turn the situation later in the day.

'It's been an amazing turn of events. Certainly you wouldn't expect the pitch to be of that type on day one,' Trist said. 'One or two of our batsmen could have tightened up in those last few overs and seen through the day.'

fields.headline: Dublin the indestructible
fields.trailText: The upbeat Villa striker is making a fast recovery from a broken neck.
fields.body:
'Tis but a scratch.' - Monty Python's Black Knight upon having an arm chopped off by King Arthur.

Dion Dublin saw it coming. Sheffield Wednesday's Gerald Sibon, a mountain of a man, an immovable object, was suddenly blocking his stampede towards a loose ball. Too late for a diversion, nothing for it but to hunch his shoulders, tuck his head in, slam on the brakes and hope to cushion the impact. Ouch.

A moment later the Aston Villa striker hauled himself up and wandered over to the dugout for a dose of the magic sponge. His neck was a bit painful but nothing out of the ordinary. So he told the physio, Jim Walker, to give him a couple of minutes to catch his breath and he'd get back in the fray. 'Tis but a bruise, thought Dublin to himself.

'Can you move your neck all right?' asked Walker.

'Not really,' Dublin replied, 'but it's just a bruise.'

'Precaution, precaution, precaution,' countered Walker.

A dozen medics and St John Ambulance staff were soon fussing around Dublin, working with the utmost caution as they tried to strap his head securely onto a stretcher. He was slightly concerned but mostly baffled to have caused this commotion while the game was still going on - it was only a bruised neck after all. How bad could it be? 'I couldn't feel anything, it was all numb, sort of out of my control,' he recalls. Next thing he remembers is waiting. Inexplicable waiting in a little medical room at Villa Park while the club doctor, Barry Smith, was hooked to the phone trying to track down a particular surgeon, the best in the Midlands, to check him over. Only a precaution of course.

Dublin just wanted to get to hospital, get sorted, and get home - and an hour later they were finally on their way to hospital: 'The Doctor insisted that the ambulance went no faster then 30 mph, and later he told me that any bumps could have moved my neck half an inch and I would have been paralysed. I went straight into intensive care. They cut my kit off me and I must have had about 10 x-rays. Then the surgeon came in with his diagnosis. He's quite a confident man, bordering on arrogant because he's so good at his job. He waltzed in and said: "Right Dion, you've broken your neck."'

This one phrase smashed through his world like the single blow of a sledgehammer. 'That's when I broke down crying. My wife Louise broke down crying. I don't think I've ever felt as low as that. When he actually said those words I had nothing but an empty feeling. Every thing came to an abrupt end in my career and my life. I thought I'd lost everything.

'The first thing I said was "What about my football? I need to play football." He said: "To be honest, Dion, you could be looking at a wheelchair you were so close to being paralysed." Then he explained the procedure. Frightening. Very, very scary position to be in. Very humbling. Most definitely.' Reflecting over it three months on he pauses, before a deep breath dissolves into a relieved, slightly self-conscious laugh, shaking his head at the madness of it all.

The operation involved taking a graft from his hip to replace the crushed bone in his neck with a new piece of bone and knitting it into place with a plate and four screws. Now, he can't feel it at all. The scar has almost gone, blended into the natural creases where the neck bends. 'He went in through the front because it was easier to get to. I damaged the area on the inside, not the bones you can feel at the back of your neck. The surgeon is an amazing man. I'm indebted to him for a long, long time. I know I'm very, very lucky. I think I approach life in a different way now. I love every day. The majority of my life now will be spent with a smile on my face.' Dion Dublin, blessed with one of the sunniest natures in football even before he reassessed his lot, smiles broader than ever.

Dublin, like most footballers, likes his routines. With a chunk ripped out of his professional life, and a huge contraption of a neck brace intruding on normal life, the whole football package had to be shut away: 'It was hard, not being able to turn around, to drive, even to pick up my kids to give them a kiss. But we overcome and become stronger.' As soon as the brace came off and he had enjoyed the benefits of a family holiday he was itching to get back to work.

He'd been in contact with most of his team-mates on the phone and had gone to all Villa's home games, but had kept his distance. 'I was envious,' he admits. 'And I didn't want to go in there and make anyone think, "Dion's broken his neck - bloody hell, that might happen to me." A bit of doubt can affect your game and I wanted to let the boys get on with it. Which they did, very well.'

Last week he was back in the thick of the banter, ribbing Ian Taylor about his jumper and mocking Mark Draper about his car. But the most significant pointer that he is inching his way back into squad life took place out on the field in his first session with the first team. He was given permission to take part in a training game, and responded with relish. 'DIONNN!' screeched the flustered physio as he watched his convalescing patient dive into a challenge.

It looks like he won't have much of a mental block to hurdle when the body is fully fit. 'I know I'll just go in where I left off to be honest. It will be the normal Dion Dublin where, if there's a challenge to be made, I'll make it. If I've got to put my head in when there are six studs coming at me to score a goal I'll do it. You can't hold back if that's the way you play. I want those challenges. That's why Jim Walker has let me back in with the first team, to get a little physical bumping around. When you're playing against big Ugo [Ehiogu] and Colin Calderwood and the Skipper [Gareth Southgate] you're going to get knocked about and that's what I need.

'I'VE STILL GOT to do a lot of running to get the strength back in my legs, and build up my shoulders to help my neck, so there's a lot of work to be done. We'll wait and see how the rehab goes but I'd love to play again this season. I wouldn't say no to a Cup Final. If I'm right and fit and I feel strong enough I'll be having a quiet word with the physio and the doctor and saying please, please, please.

'My goals are still basically the same. I want to get back in the England squad. I want to play in Euro 2000 and in the next World Cup. Walking around in the Number Nine England shirt, singing the anthem at Wembley was an amazing experience. I enjoyed it so much I want more. I know it's not going to be easy, it will take time, and I might not make 2000 or 2002. But I'm going to have a bloody good go.' If his recovery continues in the bionic manner he has managed so far he could be back in contention for his club in around a month's time.

'I'd better lap up all sympathy at the moment because when I start knocking heads around people aren't going to like me so much,' he adds, shaking his head on that reconstructed neck of his and grinning for England.

fields.headline: Straight-talking Lawrence wins respect
fields.trailText: This Bradford midfielder is thriving in an alien environment.
fields.body:
It is not difficult to spot Jamie Lawrence among the quietly purposeful professionals of Valley Parade. It's not just the green hair either. No, what really sets the Londoner apart from his team-mates is that while everyone else is talking in hushed tones of today's derby opponents' mightily impressive defeat of Roma in midweek, Lawrence is telling radio reporters how he failed to watch Leeds United because it would have meant missing EastEnders .

Subtlety is not Lawrence's style. Nor is Lawrence much impressed with the parts of the North and Midlands his four-club career has taken him to. He unwisely tried to commute between the capital and Leicester City, and though he now has a home in a reasonably lively part of West Yorkshire - 'Leeds is OK. Not London, but not bad for up here' - he has no intention of sticking around in the provinces when he finishes playing football.

Refreshing as it is to talk to someone blunter than a stereotypical Yorkshireman, half of Lawrence's bravado is just an act. And if there is a reason why Lawrence comes over as loud and brash at first, it is almost certainly connected with the reason he ended up playing in the North while pining for the South. Although he had trials with Wimbledon, Millwall and Southend, clubs were not exactly beating a path to Lawrence's door once he was sent down for robbery.

'I did three years and two months, I was 23 when I came out of my sentence and nobody wanted to know me,' he said. 'That's how I ended up at Sunderland, because I knew Terry Butcher and Ian Atkins. I went on the Monday, trained on the Tuesday, played against Leeds reserves on the Wednesday and I was in. Not that it was quite that easy. I ended up going to Doncaster to play first-team football. I didn't mind.

'I always thought I was good enough to go higher, but particularly at that level it's hard when everybody knows you've been inside. They don't let you forget.'

Lawrence doesn't mind talking about it now, partly because 'it's not exactly a secret', and partly because if there is anyone else out there struggling to overcome the same thing he would like to offer encouragement by example. 'I'm quite proud of putting it behind me,' he said. 'People might say I had it easy because I could play football, but football isn't really that different from anything else. Getting to the top involves a lot of belief in yourself despite people telling you you won't make it.'

With so much to prove Lawrence might seem a typical Martin O'Neill signing, except that it was Mark McGhee who took him to Leicester, with O'Neill inheriting him shortly afterwards. 'I never thought Martin O'Neill liked me, he was always fining me,' he said. 'So Lawrence was surprised when O'Neill offered to renew his contract, but at 27 he had to be wary of the warning that a first-team place could not be guaranteed. 'I'd had a late start, I couldn't afford an early finish, so when I heard of Bradford's interest I went for it and the gaffer didn't stand in my way,' he explained.

That was three years ago, Lawrence has been a virtual ever-present for Bradford since, and by his and the supporters' own estimation is enjoying his best ever season as he turns 30. Obviously relegation at the end of the season would put a considerable dampener on his and his club's mood, but that's not the way anyone at Valley Parade is thinking.

'I don't think we'll go down, I honestly don't,' he said. 'We've got too much bottle. I think Sheffield Wednesday and Watford have gone, but the last place is between Wimbledon, Derby, Southampton and ourselves. The question we are asking is whether those three teams have more bottle than us, and I don't think they have.'

You read it here first. Wimbledon's bottle is being questioned by a green-haired midfielder from South London. There's only one Jamie Lawrence.

fields.headline: Beware the asides of March
fields.trailText: The woes of the Premiership's modest 'also-rans'.
fields.body:
You wonder why David O'Leary is turning up with his Leeds United side at Bradford City today, or why Arséne Wenger is bothering to take Arsenal to Middlesbrough. According to both managers, they have no chance of the championship. The same with Gianluca Vialli's Chelsea and the Liverpool of Gérard Houllier.

They have merely Champions League places to contest, they insist, though it seems they don't even deem themselves worthy to be in that. Vialli thinks it should be for champions only, and you suspect Wenger agrees, though accepts the realities of the modern game for the big clubs in describing it as 'an important excitement to keep everybody happy'.

Imagine the four of them in a room together, a bit like Monty Python's four Yorkshiremen, all trying to outdo each other in self-effacement.

'Who'd have thought we'd be sitting here drinking Chateau de Chatelet,' Wenger and Houllier might muse, though Vialli would doubtless prefer a nice Chianti and O'Leary a half of Guinness, as they contemplate their humility.

'Well, it's Man United for me,' says O'Leary. 'My babies are too inexperienced.'

'Luxury,' says Wenger. 'We'd love to be young. We're too old to win it.'

'Scusi,' Vialli chips in. 'We have even less chance than you two. But you try telling that to kids these days.'

'Pardon,' Houllier interrupts. 'We have to work so hard to catch up you and Manchester United that we have to be on the training ground half an hour before we even arrive. In fact, we're the worst team in the country and I think you should show more disrespect.'

And what does Sir Alex Ferguson think when he hears all the competitive non-competitiveness going on behind him? 'If I was in their position,' he said with a smile after the draw with Liverpool last weekend, 'I'd be saying exactly the same things.'

This is the age of canny psychology in managerspeak. So wary have they become, knowing that remarks will be interpreted instead of just presented, that they have learned how to say much without saying anything, or how to say the opposite of what they really believe. Banner headlines, needed to convey something different to what can be simply seen or heard on TV and radio, can mean FA disrepute charges or, more seriously, can inspire rivals.

Managers have always known how to use the press but it has now become an art form, with fibbing an accepted tactic. Take the agenda of transfer stories. Is an agent planting the tale, the manager happy for him to do so? Does the manager talk up a player's ability because he wants to sell him at a better price? Are clubs happy to be linked with players simply to show supporters that they are doing something?

Then there are injuries. Sometimes they are covered up, to put the opposition off the scent. Other times, they are highlighted by a manager because results are bad and he needs mitigation. Usually, a manager is happy to talk about the opposition because it deflects criticism from his own team. Then again, sometimes he doesn't want to for fear of riling them into greater effort next time.

Sir Alex is the master of manipulation at whose feet they all learn. Remember, after a game against Leeds, him saying that he hoped they put in as much effort against other title rivals, Newcastle, thus provoking the 'luv it' Kevin Keegan response that revealed the extent to which he was feeling the pressure?

Or recently, that Ferguson was worried by a refereeing 'vendetta' against United, his attempt to head it off?

Wenger, who quickly assimilated the phrase 'I did not see the incident' when he arrived (which begs the question: why managers sit where they do if the view is so bad), is a worthy rival. He can respond with the clever statement that if United are selling David Beckham, they have a duty to shareholders to sell him for the best price, rather than keep him away from a domestic rival. Often Wenger will smirk having said suchlike. Sunderland's Peter Reid, after perhaps remarking that the referee did well, will sometimes wink in irony.

These days, the more worldly fan can see through all the bluff and blarney, just as they can with the 'I'll moider da bum,' talk in boxing designed to sell tickets. They know the managers' 'we can't win it' stuff is designed to keep their own team's feet on the ground as well as heaping the stress of expectation elsewhere.

The problem is if the players start believing it and think that next year, rather than this, will be their season. 'In the years to come, I believe we'll succeed and win trophies,' says O'Leary. Houllier also believes that his team are a season away from challenging for honours.

No time like the present, though; never put off today_

Such opportunities as Leeds and Liverpool have do not always repeat themselves. The last decade should tell them that it is still possible. United took only one point from their last four games to let in Leeds in '92; in '96, United clawed back 12 points to pip Newcastle, something Arsenal did to United in '98.

Their own lofty circumstances should tell them something. Chelsea seem set for the Champions League quarter-finals, Arsenal and a vibrant Leeds, after an inspiring win over Roma, are in the last eight of the Uefa Cup. Emile Heskey's arrival should fortify Liverpool. Meanwhile, United do not look at their best.

So beware the sides and asides of March; rest assured that Sir Alex Ferguson will. He won't believe the self-abasement of the quartet below him and nor should we.

'Well, it's Man United for me,' says O'Leary. 'My babies are too inexperienced.' 'Luxury,' says Wenger. 'We'd love to be young. We're too old to win it.' 'Scusi,' Vialli chips in. 'We have even less chance than you two. But you try telling that to kids these days.' 'Pardon,' Houllier interrupts. 'We have to work so hard to catch up you and Manchester United that we have to be on the training ground half an hour before we even arrive. In fact, we're the worst team in the country and I think you should show more disrespect.' And what does Sir Alex Ferguson think when he hears all the competitive non-competitiveness going on behind him? 'If I was in their position,' he said with a smile after the draw with Liverpool last weekend, 'I'd be saying exactly the same things.' This is the age of canny psychology in managerspeak. So wary have they become, knowing that remarks will be interpreted instead of just presented, that they have learned how to say much without saying anything, or how to say the opposite of what they really believe. Banner headlines, needed to convey something different to what can be simply seen or heard on TV and radio, can mean FA disrepute charges or, more seriously, can inspire rivals. Managers have always known how to use the press but it has now become an art form, with fibbing an accepted tactic. Take the agenda of transfer stories. Is an agent planting the tale, the manager happy for him to do so? Does the manager talk up a player's ability because he wants to sell him at a better price? Are clubs happy to be linked with players simply to show supporters that they are doing something? Then there are injuries. Sometimes they are covered up, to put the opposition off the scent. Other times, they are highlighted by a manager because results are bad and he needs mitigation. Usually, a manager is happy to talk about the opposition because it deflects criticism from his own team. Then again, sometimes he doesn't want to for fear of riling them into greater effort next time. Sir Alex is the master of manipulation at whose feet they all learn. Remember, after a game against Leeds, him saying that he hoped they put in as much effort against other title rivals, Newcastle, thus provoking the 'luv it' Kevin Keegan response that revealed the extent to which he was feeling the pressure? Or recently, that Ferguson was worried by a refereeing 'vendetta' against United, his attempt to head it off? Wenger, who quickly assimilated the phrase 'I did not see the incident' when he arrived (which begs the question: why managers sit where they do if the view is so bad), is a worthy rival. He can respond with the clever statement that if United are selling David Beckham, they have a duty to shareholders to sell him for the best price, rather than keep him away from a domestic rival. Often Wenger will smirk having said suchlike. Sunderland's Peter Reid, after perhaps remarking that the referee did well, will sometimes wink in irony. These days, the more worldly fan can see through all the bluff and blarney, just as they can with the 'I'll moider da bum,' talk in boxing designed to sell tickets. They know the managers' 'we can't win it' stuff is designed to keep their own team's feet on the ground as well as heaping the stress of expectation elsewhere. The problem is if the players start believing it and think that next year, rather than this, will be their season. 'In the years to come, I believe we'll succeed and win trophies,' says O'Leary. Houllier also believes that his team are a season away from challenging for honours. No time like the present, though; never put off today_ Such opportunities as Leeds and Liverpool have do not always repeat themselves. The last decade should tell them that it is still possible. United took only one point from their last four games to let in Leeds in '92; in '96, United clawed back 12 points to pip Newcastle, something Arsenal did to United in '98. Their own lofty circumstances should tell them something. Chelsea seem set for the Champions League quarter-finals, Arsenal and a vibrant Leeds, after an inspiring win over Roma, are in the last eight of the Uefa Cup. Emile Heskey's arrival should fortify Liverpool. Meanwhile, United do not look at their best. So beware the sides and asides of March; rest assured that Sir Alex Ferguson will. He won't believe the self-abasement of the quartet below him and nor should we.

fields.headline: Said & Done
fields.trailText:
England in Charleroi: Belgium braced
The Belgian government are considering turning garages into prison cells to cope with the possibility of hundreds of arrests at this summer's Euro 2000 tie between England and Germany.
fields.body:
England in Charleroi: Belgium braced
The Belgian government are considering turning garages into prison cells to cope with the possibility of hundreds of arrests at this summer's Euro 2000 tie between England and Germany.

Speaking in De Morgen newspaper, Gendarmerie Michel Rompen said that at least 20,000 England fans were expected in Charleroi on 17 June - and he plans to lock up 5 per cent of them.

'We anticipate that we may have to arrest more than a thousand hooligans,' Rompen was quoted as saying. Other Belgian cities hosting Euro 2000 matches - Bruges, Liege and Brussels - are also carrying out an inventory of their available cells.

Rompen said Charleroi faced the particular problem of thousands of fans being unable to get into the 30,000-capacity stadium and wandering around the town instead. 'Only 16 per cent of seats have been reserved for the two teams' supporters,' De Morgen said.

'They are not all hooligans but they will probably all run around the streets,' he explained. 'The mayor has said that there will be no alcohol ban in the town, so we have based our strategy on zero tolerance instead.' One strike, it seems, and you're in the garage.

Anguilla win...
Anguilla - Fifa's smallest member nation and bottom of the world rankings - have won their first match. The island nation first featured in this column in March last year after they scored a rare goal against Grenada in a 14-1 defeat. At the time, government spokesman Elkin Rogers told us he was concerned about the nation's footballing future. 'Yes, it's indistinct,' said Rogers. 'We really do have very few prospects.' They also had no manager: after a 6-0 defeat to St Lucia, and subsequent 14-0, 7-0 and 9-0 defeats to the likes of Gaudeloupe, Les Strong, the former Fulham defender, disappeared. A year on, though, and Anguilla have turned the corner. Despite having only 75 registered players from a population of 9,000, the team lost just 3-1 to the Bahamas last month, and then sparkled as they've never sparkled before against the British Virgin Islands. Despite three key players - Kevin Hawley, Tyrone Benjamin, and Andre 'Sour' Griffith - missing the bus and not arriving until half-time, the side took a four-goal lead, and held out for a 4-3 win - the first in Anguilla's footballing history. The return leg wasn't so good: after seven of the 11 starters picked up injuries they lost 5-0 - but still, congratulations boys.

Upset ref calls it quits
Experienced Belgian referee Amand Ancion quit his job in tears last week after disallowing a valid goal in a First Division game between Mouscron and Charleroi. The 45-year-old, on Uefa's list for Euro 2000, told Belgian television immediately after the game that he was 'distraught'. 'I really don't know what will become of me without refereeing.' The goal was scored when Charleroi's Enzo Biondo was lying on the ground injured. Instead of sportingly kicking the ball into touch, Mouscron's Axel Lawaree scored - only for Ancion to rule it out on moral grounds. It seems to have been the final straw for Ancion, who is still suffering the repercussions of his performance in a league game between Westerlo and Genk last August. In the 6-6 draw, he issued 12 yellow cards, four reds and five penalities. He'll be missed.

More on Mellor: end in sight?BR>Last week we questioned the purpose of David Mellor. A week on, no one seems any closer to an answer. Given the chance on Wednesday to withdraw his controversial dismissal of the government-backed Crystal Palace Supporters Trust, Mellor, apparently unprepared for his 5 Live phone-in, picked up where he left off. 'You lot just don't want it enough,' Mellor told another caller. 'I don't know why I let you guys on the show.' Two days later he carried on in the London Evening Standard. 'For the past two weeks I've had leading lights from the Crystal Palace fans' buy-out campaign on my Radio 5 Live phone-in, and each time I've ended up deeply fed up with them ... You must be joking, fellows.' Crystal Palace and the Trust, Mellor explained, are 'finished', and 'what's more, they deserve to be'.

Bosses at 5 Live now admit to being confused by Mellor's recent form - and, having already shunted him out of the prime-time 606 Saturday slot, are said to be 'concerned' by his increasing unpredictability. So does the 'voice of the fans' have a long-term future at 5 Live? BBC insiders, we're pleased to report, think not.

Said & Done : david.hills@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Explain...
fields.trailText:
European qualification
Despite Manchester United's European heroics last season, England's representation in Uefa's club competitions will not grow next season. If you're looking for a someone to blame, try Blackburn.
fields.body:
European qualification
Despite Manchester United's European heroics last season, England's representation in Uefa's club competitions will not grow next season. If you're looking for a someone to blame, try Blackburn.

That's because Uefa use a country's record over the previous five years to decide its ranking, which means that England are still hindered by the 1995-96 campaign, when David Batty and Graeme Le Saux traded punches as their team finished bottom of their Champions League group. Everton didn't help, losing in the second round of the Cup Winners Cup, while only Forest got farther than the same stage of the Uefa Cup.

So England lie below Italy, Spain, Germany, France and Holland, and must be content with two automatic Champions League berths, another team having to qualify, and three places in the Uefa Cup. Of course there's always the Intertoto Cup or the fair play table - through which England and Scotland both look like qualifying for an end-of-season draw, with another two Uefa Cup places at stake.

The only other realistic hope is that Chelsea win the European Cup, or Arsenal or Leeds the Uefa Cup, while finishing outside the League's top three this season, any of which would secure one bonus place.

The first year for which 1995-96 will not count will be the 2002-03 season. Holland and France both did very well four years ago, but England have outperformed them since, so if English clubs maintain or improve their form next year they should hit fourth spot at worst. England are also set to outperform Germany for the second successive season this year. Spain and Italy still look out of reach though, despite the latter's disastrous showing this season. Still, England could soon boast the third best league in Europe.

So while English clubs are yet to reap the benefits of their improved European form, the future looks bright. And Blackburn are unlikely to be embarrassing themselves in Europe again for some time.

Champions League Two places (Premiership top two) 3rd qualifying round: One place (third in Premiership) Plus: Reigning champions Uefa Cup Three places (one via League, two cup winners) Plus: Reigning champions (if not already in Champ League) Intertoto Cup One place

fields.headline: Hearts beat anew
fields.trailText: Sunday's Scottish Cup quarter-final preview
fields.body:
Heart's meeting with Rangers tonight in the quarter-final of the Tennents Scottish Cup may be viewed as a reprise of the 1998 final only because it involves the same two clubs. As far as all but a small percentage of the players are concerned, however, that 2-1 victory for the Tynecastle side 22 months ago might just as well never have taken place.

It is a reminder of the organic nature of modern football that, after less than two seasons, the two teams will have only four survivors from that previous joust - three with Hearts, the other with Rangers - likely to start tonight's game. The reasons for the dismantling and reconstruction of the respective combatants in such a short time are themselves indicators of the difficulties encountered by clubs outside the Old Firm in sustaining a credible challenge to the Glasgow giants.

At Rangers, the changes have been effected entirely by design, at Hearts largely by the rapacious activities of predators. While Dick Advocaat succeeded Walter Smith as manager at Ibrox less than a month after that cup final and began jettisoning the old and spending the £30 million that would bring in the new, Jim Jefferies at Tynecastle faced the prospect of losing many of his players without his consent.

Rangers themselves took winger Neil McCann and seem certain to add defender Paul Ritchie when the latter's loan period at Bolton is up at the end of this season, Everton removed David Weir and others such as Dave McPherson, Stefano Salvatori and Jim Hamilton left the club for a variety of reasons. 'What a lot of people don't understand and don't take into account,' said Jefferies, 'is that, when teams outside the Old Firm do have a little success, our players become targets for the bigger clubs. Rangers and Celtic don't have this problem to the same degree. So it means rebuilding a squad and that doesn't happen overnight.

'The team who won the cup for us and who challenged for the league championship until the last couple of weeks of the season in 1998 had itself taken a good two years to assemble and it's only now that we are beginning to see the rebuilt side coming together. Since the winter break in January, we've only had one poor performance in eight games, when we lost to Kilmarnock in the League Cup quarter-finals.

'But we've won four and drawn the other of our five league matches, we've won two Scottish Cup ties and we've had four clean sheets in a row. We're probably better defensively now than we have been for a while, maybe even better than the '98 team. I think, too, that this present side is capable of playing better football than the one from two years ago, but they've still to prove that consistently.'

Much of the credit for Hearts' recent resurgence - as well as the last eight of the cup, they have climbed to fourth in the Premier League, with a chance of making Europe - has been given to Robert Tomascheck, the midfielder signed from Slovan Bratislava for just £380,000. The 27-year-old Slovakian is another example of Jefferies' astuteness in the market, joining Antti Niemi, the goalkeeper from Rangers, and Gordan Petric, the former Dundee United and Rangers defender, to make up a trio who cost a total of only £1 million.

Jefferies had been under a certain pressure to spend, spectacularly from support ers who had been misled into believing he had £4 million at his disposal following the deal that brought £8 million into the club when Scottish Media Group bought a stake.

Much of the new money helped to clear debt, but the £4 million said to have been allocated to the manager was to be spread 'over the next two or three seasons'. 'What I was actually told,' said Jefferies, 'was that I could have £1 million to £1.5 million this season, so it had to be spent wisely. I've always been used to looking for bargains, but what having a little money does is it slightly broadens your horizon. We had to strengthen various departments and we've done that with a goalkeeper, a defender and a midfielder. Now we're looking to bring in a different type of striker from the guys already here, to give us variation.'

Jefferies was also criticised, during a lean spell earlier in the season, for not fielding Tomascheck, but he was giving the Slovakian time to settle. 'When it came to playing Celtic at Parkhead, we knew he would be all right for that,' said the manager. 'He has 53 caps for Slovakia, so we knew he wouldn't be fazed by the occasion and that's how it turned out. He's doing really well. In fact, he's a much different player from the one we thought we were buying.

'Having seen him and watched videos, we thought he was purely a defensive midfielder, but he is much more. He's not just a "sitter", but has great mobility around the pitch. He doesn't just break things up in deep position, but can set things off in forward areas. Niemi has done well, too, and Petric is settling in much better now and giving good performances.'

All of Hearts' improvement and all the self-belief Jefferies can impart will surely be required tonight against a Rangers team whose appetite for trophies remains undiminished.

fields.headline: Swindon stunner for Curbishley
fields.trailText: Charlton 0 - 1 Swindon
fields.body:
What a turn up for the book. After 12 successive league wins - two short of equalling the all-time record - Charlton were nobbled by the First Division's no-hopers, who profited from a goalkeeping bloomer then held on to their lead for dear life.

At times, Swindon's penalty box resembled a pinball machine. To their credit, they never wavered and for that alone no one could begrudge them the points.

Charlton cast a nostalgic look back before their team set about trying to consolidate a bright future in this game. A bronze bust of Jimmy Seed, the club's longest-serving manager, was unveiled by his family before kick-off. While Alan Curbishley, the present manager, has some way to go to match Seed's success, he is carving his own permanent niche by guiding Charlton back to the Premiership in some style.

It looked harmless enough and the Charlton goalkeeper Dean Kiely was under no pressure as he moved to collect the ball. Inexplicably, he allowed it to squirm under his body and trickle over the line.

As Charlton's frustration grew, penalty appeals for what looked like an over- zealous challenge by Alan Reeves on Svensson were turned down, and shortly before half time Hunt was wide with a header from Shaun Newton's cross.

Defensive indecision almost cost Charlton a second goal, the ball rebounding from Rufus to Wayne Gray, who should have done much better from six yards than place his shot too near Kiely.

When Talia made his first mistake, fortune smiled on him as the clearance went to his own defender, Reeves, who was able to clear the danger.

It was all hands to the deck in the Swindon penalty box. Although Gray had another chance at the other end after good work by Hay, this time the centre-forward forced Kiely to turn his effort around the post.

fields.headline: Scottish review
fields.trailText: Lucky breaklifts Ayr to semi spot
fields.body:
Ayr United clinched a place in the Scottish Cup semi- finals for the first time since 1973, but not without a slice of luck.

That good fortune came with the bizarre goal with which Neil Duffy gave them the lead. At that stage, Partick, with Quinto Jacobs outstanding, appeared to have the edge. But they struggled to deal with a Jens Hansen corner, and when midfielder Danny Lennon attempted a clearance, the ball ricocheted into the net off Neil Duffy.

But no one could quibble with the quality of Ayr's second goal, by Neil Tarrant. He beat Partick's offside - from a long Duffy pass - and hit the ball in from 20 yards.

Celtic's damaged morale after their latest defeat by Rangers underwent a measure of repair - thanks to the finishing of Mark Burchill and Mark Viduka, who each scored twice in the 4-1 win over St Johnstone.

That Celtic gave themselves a lift for Sunday's CIS Cup Final against Aberdeen, against a team who clearly set out with a goalless draw in their sights, was particularly down to Viduka. It was from his cross that Burchill put an edgy-looking Celtic ahead after 18 minutes. Then, after St Johnstone had made it 1-1 through Paddy Connolly - a goal that emphasised the defensive crisis that had prompted Celtic to give their Brazilian international, Rafael, his full debut - the irrepressible Viduka struck twice in four minutes.

Viduka's second strike provided a particularly vivid illustration of his ability. He played a big part in the build-up, by using his strength to hold the ball up and bring Eyal Berkovic into the play, and it was from the Iraeli's return pass that he brought his total for the season to 27.

As if all this did not represent a sufficiently good afternoon's work, he also set up Burchill for the youngster's second goal.

Hamilton's players, having been persuaded to call off their threatened strike yesterday morning, went on to produce one of the most stirring performances in twice coming from behind to get a 2-2 draw at Stranraer.

That the strike did not materialise was due to a four-hour meeting led by the Hamilton secretary, Scott Struthers, who brokered an agreement - with a local businessmen - to ensure that the players received all the wages owed to them. It is not difficult to appreciate why Hamilton were in such a spin over the situation. If they had not been able to fulfil their league fixtures, the subsequent publicity could have led to a number of backers for their new stadium pulling out of the venture. Without that new stadium, it is on the cards that the club would fold.

There was a good example of teams folding on the field, with Clydebank - languishing at the bottom of the First Division with only one win - being hammered 8-0 by St Mirren. Barry Lavety was their destroyer-in-chief, with a hat-trick.

In the English First Division, George Burley's Ipswich suffered another setback - a 2-1 defeat at Wolves. Both Wolves' goals were scored by Haavard Flo. But how he must have wished he'd had the number of chances that Ipswich created.

fields.headline: Latapy shows the way
fields.standfirst: Hibernian 3 - 1 Falkirk
fields.trailText: If Hibs could persuade the SFA to stage the climactic stages of the Tennents Scottish Cup at Easter Road, they would have a chance, second to none, of lifting the old trophy for the first time in 98 years.
fields.body:
If Hibs could persuade the SFA to stage the climactic stages of the Tennents Scottish Cup at Easter Road, they would have a chance, second to none, of lifting the old trophy for the first time in 98 years.

In handicap terms, the Edinburgh side appear to be at least a stone better on their own ground than they are on the road, a factor which helped to end First Division Falkirk's marvellous attempt to reach their third semi-final in four years. Yet, Hibs still needed the individual virtuosity of Russel Latapy to enure their place in the last four. Like a boiler that takes some time to achieve a full head of steam, some matches require a proficient stoker; Latapy took the job and demonstrated his capabilities with the goal that galvanised both sides into a proper, throbbing cup tie after a largely bland opening 20 minutes.

The Trinidadian's contribution was to become even greater later, but he was owed substantial gratitude for his opener, not least for its effect on the course the match would follow thereafter. His tormenting of the visiting defence was the more remarkable for the demands made on him in the days that preceded it.

Latapy had disembarked in Edinburgh less than 48 hours earlier from the flight carrying him back from international duty and there was talk of the manager, Alex McLeish, leaving him out of what seemed certain to be a punishing afternoon.

McLeish is astute enough, however, to realise that if your truly skilful players are limited and one of them is available, it is wise to give him the opportunity to inflict some damage before any possible fatigue begins to take its toll. Latapy vindicated the decision spectacularly.

The midfielder made his first impact when he received a short pass from Stuart Lovell on the right and began to carry the ball across the field, just outside the 18-yard line. Rather than looking for an unmarked team-mate, Latapy turned and sent the ball low and hard with his left foot to the left of Myles Hogarth.

It was, at the time, the least Hibs deserved. Even if they had not been inspired, they had at least done much more than Falkirk to merit the lead. Indeed, it seemed cruel luck on the home side when the visitors were level soon after. Perhaps the lack of threat from the First Division side in outfield play had induced a certain complacency in the home defence, causing them to ignore the danger of a set piece.

They did appear to be almost comatose when Dave Nicholls delivered a free-kick from the right, allowing Andy Lawrie to rise without challenge and score with a simple header past Nick Colgan from six yards.

Hibs managed to re-impose themselves and were once again in control when Latapy scored his second just before the interval. It was a tempting centre from the Trinidadian on the left that Pat McGinlay was attacking when he was barged from behind by David Hagen. Latapy took the penalty kick and gave Hogarth not a prayer as he slotted the ball far to the goalkeeper's left.

But Falkirk are nothing if not game and any notions the home support entertained of a coast towards the finish would not have lingered too long in their minds as the visitors summoned the kind of effort that has made them the most consistent fellers of giants in recent Scottish Cup history.

Their imperishable tenacity, strengthened by shooting down the Easter Road slope in the second half, carried them into threatening areas often enough to cause palpable alarm in the home defence and, with a little fortune, at least one of the low, venomous crosses driven across the Hibs goal area could have ricocheted into the net. In the event, they bounced off defenders to safety.

Hibs, contrastingly, made more profitable use of the set piece they were given in the third minute of stoppage time. A short corner kick on the right offered Latapy the chance to deliver another precise cross that McGinlay, with another impeccably-timed run, sent the header to the right of Hogarth and in off the upright. It confirmed Hibs' place in the semi-final for the first time in five years.

fields.headline: Cheltenham show true pedigree
fields.standfirst: Cheltenham 3- 0 Halifax
fields.trailText: Cheltenham made a decent start at reminding the world that the town also possess a thoroughbred football team as they came out comfortably on top in this contest between the last two Conference champions.
fields.body:
Cheltenham made a decent start at reminding the world that the town also possess a thoroughbred football team as they came out comfortably on top in this contest between the last two Conference champions.

Runners-up and FA Trophy winners in the 1997/98 season, Cheltenham have been continually gathering momentum, even, quietly, in this inaugural season as a full-time club. Not that many outside the Cotswold town have noticed. Average gates at Whaddon Road have increased from around 3,100 last season to a tad under 4,000 this but, despite losing at home only once in over five months since a difficult start to the season, and moving to within five points of the top seven, Steve Cotterill's side are still not perceived as dark horses for promotion.

There. Got almost 200 words into the report before mentioning the gee-gees. The National Hunt Festival will this week attract sell-out 50,000 crowds for three successive days at the nearby racecourse, where on Wednesday afternoon Cheltenham's footballers will be the guests of Edward Gillespie, the managing director at the home of Steeplechasing.

Gillespie was a busy man yesterday, warming up for his biggest week of the year by hot-footing it from Gloucester's top-of-the-table clash with Northampton in the Allied Dunbar Premiership One down to Whaddon Road.

Not that Town resent the rival sporting attractions which hog the spotlight. 'The Festival will get 50,000 a day and we'll hopefully get 4,000 for Halifax's visit,' said Paddy Wood, the football club's horse-loving director. 'But you've got to have a perspective on it. The Gold Cup is the World Cup of National Hunt racing, whereas in the structure of professional football, we're in the lower echelons. But we're proud of the progress we're making at this club, on and off the field.'

Cheltenham dominated all except the latter half of the first period. Halifax had Jamie Paterson twice go close with finely judged long range efforts, Steve Book - nephew of former Manchester City captain and manager Tony - pulling off a spell-binding save after 20 minutes.

But Neil Grayson, last season's Conference player of the year, has like the majority of Cheltenham's non-Leaguers-made-good adapted well to the new level of football. Ten of yesterday's starting line-up were playing last season.

So it was Grayson two minutes into first-half stoppage time who turned in a rebound after Neil Howarth's header from Russell Milton's free-kick routine thudded against the crossbar.

That was his thirteenth goal of the season and 21 minutes from time Milton, an artful midfielder who learned his trade at Arsenal, headed his eighth, from a deflected cross by Chris Freestone.

Freestone, playing his last game on loan from Hartlepool and the sole interloper, rounded off the victory after 79 minutes. Lee Howells played a one-two with Milton and crossed from the right for Freestone who, squeezed home his satisfying parting shot.

fields.headline: Barnsley punish poor City
fields.trailText: Barnsley 2 - 1 Manchester City
fields.body:
A classy Barnsley beat promotion rivals Manchester City to strengthen their claims for an automatic promotion spot from Division One, but City have now failed to win in five games, severely denting their own hopes of avoiding the play-offs and going up automatically.

City arrived having won just three points from the last 12, manager Joe Royle highlighting lack of goals as the main problem in recent weeks. To that end, out-of-favour Bradford striker Lee Mills, who made his debut here alongside top scorer Shaun Goater, has been brought in on loan until the end of the season. Mills has only scored five times in the Premiership this season, but he scored 24 times to help the Bantams secure promotion from Division One last season and Royle clearly feels Goater is not yet receiving consistent enough support from Robert Taylor, who has scored just three times since his move from Gillingham. Craig Hignett was back in place of Georgi Hristov for Barnsley, as manager Dave Bassett tried to break a run of three straight draws at home.

Bassett's decision paid immediate dividends when Hignett broke clear down the right hand side and won a corner off Jeff Whitley after just four minutes. Darren Barnard's clever ball to the edge of the box deceived the City defence and John Curtis, the England Under-21 defender on loan from Manchester United until the end of the season, stroked a 20-yard drive through a crowded box into the bottom corner.

City could have equalised almost immediately when Barnsley keeper Kevin Miller dropped a Mark Kennedy corner, but the ball was scrambled clear. Barnsley might have extended their lead when Richard Jobson fouled Neil Shipperley on the edge of the box, Barnard's free-kick whistling narrowly over.

But Barnsley did score again, Hignett racing clear from Mark Tinkler's pass, and slotting the ball home under Weaver's body. The closest Mills came to scoring before the break came when he found a yard of space in the box, but his shot was deflected for a corner.

Ian Bishop came on for Danny Granville at half-time as City came back strongly. They enjoyed a sustained spell of pressure, but failed to create anything clear-cut. Their best efforts came when Kennedy pulled a shot across the face of goal, and Jamie Pollock shot high over.

Barnsley soaked up the pressure and begun threaten ing on the break. A goal-mouth scramble saw a Neil Shipperley effort blocked and Tinkler's follow up well saved by Weaver. Hignett should have made absolutely sure of the points when he found himself one on one with Miller again, but he seemed to hesitate, and Miller stuck out a leg to parry the shot.

City did hit the post when Pollock fired in from five yards, but it was an isolated attack, Barnsley creating by far the most chances. Shipperley seemed certain to score before Danny Tiatto deflected his shot, while Weaver dived acrobatically to keep out Hignett from 20 yards.

Goater gave City hope when he managed to squeeze between two defenders and bundle home after Miller failed to gather Kennedy's chip with four minutes to go. Although City poured forward in a tense last few minutes, Barnsley held firm to claim the points.

fields.body:
On the night of 22 December, Ian and Jules went to the Galley Inn, in Schull. It was just before Christmas and the village was glittering with lights and with the restive energy of the holiday, as distant family members came home from the Bronx or north London, cargoed with duty-free booze and cigarettes. They stayed at the pub until around midnight. (The gardaí are more lenient about closing times over the holidays.) When they left, Bailey bought a Guinness to take with him.

It was a splendid night, frosty and clear, with a winter-solstice moon overhead, lighting that numinous landscape of ocean and stone. Their old car bounced home towards the Prairie. When they arrived, Bailey, a little drunk and inspired by the hallucinatory beauty of the winter stars, decided to walk over to his studio cottage, some 200 yards away, and write, while Jules went to bed. This much Bailey told police during the course of his first questioning, in February 1997.

But the gardaí have had to struggle to figure out what happened next, and why. There are no witnesses. According to Bailey, when he finished writing, at one o'clock in the morning, he went home to bed. Someone might have wanted to seduce, to rape her. She refuses, resists, and it all goes wrong.'

The man from whom we bought our farmhouse, for example, had been busted for growing marijuana in the garden, and there is the odd instance of after-hours drinking, drunk driving, or bootleg spirits. But local police had yet to encounter a murder investigation, let alone one that might involve nationals of three countries. Long before the state pathologist arrived at the scene of the crime, Ian Bailey had already spent time there, alerted, it seems, by the Cork Examiner. Soon, other reporters and photographers arrived, walking around the house, trudging across the grass, leaving fibres of their clothing and strands of their hair everywhere, and the story of Sophie's murder made it to French television before Irish police had even managed to contact her husband.

It was the housekeeper who answered and said, "I can't talk to you." Right away, we were treated with suspicion... Finally, it was the [French] Minister of Foreign Affairs, Hervé de Charette, who informed me officially that Sophie had been murdered.'

A few days later, police were contacted by a mystery caller who seemed to have privileged information about the murder. Then, typically, the line was disconnected. (West Cork, at the time, did not have a modern telephone service - it was only recently made digital.) The chief superintendent appeared on television to ask the caller to call back.

Then the gardaí arrested Bailey, telling Sophie's husband, 'We've got him. He is in the car.' Whatever they had, he was released after 12 hours of questioning. 'Rarely have police been so sure of their suspicions and at the same time so incapable of finding the evidence,' du Plantier said. 'I criticise them for throwing out his name with such incredible recklessness. Because if there is one chance in a hundred that he is innocent, it is terrifying.'

Bailey continued to cover the murder for the tabloids, at times supplying 'breaking news' and displaying an unexpected intimacy with the details of the crime. (This was not so surprising, perhaps, since he had also worked as a gardener for Sophie's next-door neighbour.) For certain articles, he withheld his byline. In one paper, Bailey reported that Sophie had had 'a tangled love life' and had been planning to remarry her first husband. Partly at his suggestion, the investigation turned to France: 'Sur La Piste De L'amant Français' ('On The Trail Of The French Lover'), as one French daily announced.

Suspicion fell briefly on a volatile former lover, with whom Sophie had already had a run-in: he had allegedly tried to strangle her in the Paris Metro. But an inquiry established that he had not been in Ireland at the time of the murder. The gardaí also looked into the possibility that it had been a contract killing. Christmas in Ireland is not an easy time to keep track of incoming visitors, and a professional could easily have evaded airport video cameras by arriving on the car ferry into Cork or Rosslare, and then driving west. But West Cork is a complicated landscape and there are few detailed maps and even fewer signposts. A stranger asking for directions to Sophie's house would have stood out.

In the weeks following the murder, the gardaí interviewed more than a thousand people, unearthing any number of wife- beaters, dole-exploiters, drug traffickers, and illegal residents. But they seemed convinced that Bailey was their man. There were his strangely knowledgeable newspaper reports and interviews about the crime. And there were those scratches on his head and hands, as well as his history of domestic violence.

That April, the chief superintendent submitted a 2,000-page file to the director of public prosecutions, in Dublin - '2,000 pages of rumours,' according to Bailey. Since then, the gardaí have not been allowed to speak about the case, and, despite increasingly aggravated pleas, authorities in France, who had initiated their own investigation into the murder, were denied access to this file. The Irish minister of justice claimed that releasing the documents would compromise the ongoing investigation - which by that time had kept 60 gardaí employed for four months, but had not resulted in any charges.

Locals continued to discuss the crime in low voices. Why couldn't the police either charge Bailey or exonerate him? they asked. Surely Sophie would have had foreign DNA on her body, since she had fought off her attacker. Had it been made unreadable by the delay in examining the body? One fact that did slip out was that the blood found under Sophie's fingernails and the hair she was clutching were her own: she must have tried to protect her head against her attacker's hammering blows.

In December 1997, Sophie's family came to West Cork to attend a memorial service at the local church. It was a typically raw and misty morning, and we were a subdued crowd of 60 or so. The choir sang in Irish and many wept as Sophie's aunt, Marie Madeleine Opalka, made a pleasantly accented plea from the altar. Sophie 'fully loved your country and its beauty and the kindness of the people,' she said. 'We want to ask you something from the depths of our hearts. Someone among you may have information or know something - please, please, give it to the police.' It was uncannily like the church scene in The Field, John B Keane's violent play about a stranger bludgeoned to death in the west of Ireland.

Afterwards, we dodged the rain and bundled into the priest's house for coffee with the family, as a garda car and a few taut men in black coats waited at the gate. Opalka told me that her niece had invited her to come with her to Ireland the previous December and that she would forever regret having declined. 'Thank God Monsieur Bailey has not come today,' she added.

Bailey has not hidden from the publicity surrounding his possible role in Sophie's murder. And, if he doesn't actually enjoy his notoriety, he at least remains unruffled by it. In fact, he seems to have found inspiration in his plight. In one poem, entitled 'The Prisoner' he even compares his trials to those of Jesus: 'a man who slept peacefully/while his disciples panicked'.

When Brighid McLaughlin, a reporter for Ireland's Sunday Independent, travelled to Schull for an interview with Bailey in July 1997, he was initially brusque on the phone, announcing that his lawyer had instructed him not to speak about the crime. The same day, however, he appeared in the foyer of her hotel. According to McLaughlin, he had become an expert on the case and discussed theories and counter-theories with excitement. Despite his lawyer's admonition, she said, 'Bailey does talk. He simply can't stop.' The casual way he referred to the murdered woman as 'Sophie', as though he had become intimate with her in the aftermath of the crime, was troubling, she said. When McLaughlin asked how he had survived 12 hours of questioning, he replied: 'The gardaí lost their temper, not me. In Le Figaro, Daniel du Plantier also expressed his surprise at Bailey's behaviour: 'The OJ Simpson story is having babies... Bailey has chosen to court the media... And now he has an amazing new profession: "I am not the killer of Sophie Toscan du Plantier." If I were in his place and I were innocent, I would have run away and changed my name and my life.'

But Bailey's behaviour after the murder seemed to fit his general pattern. From the beginning of his time in West Cork he had been outspoken and flamboyant and had failed to display the tact of a newcomer. His neighbours were often irritated by him, and considered his adoption of 'Irish ways' a kind of masquerade.

It is highly possible that a great many locals, including, perhaps, the gardaí, would have been pleased to put him away for this murder simply because they did not approve of him.

On 27 January 1998, Bailey's 42nd birthday, he was arrested for the second time - this time by the Dublin-based National Bureau for Criminal Investigation - and some of his belongings were seized. Again, he was released after 12 hours for lack of evidence. According to Irish law, Bailey can be arrested a third time, but only if charges are brought against him.
