Sophie's family returned to Cork for the second and third anniversaries of her death to attend memorial services. A small Celtic cross, with Sophie's name, now stands on the ground where she was murdered, and locals often leave flowers there. The house itself remains empty, and is already a source of fearful legend.

Since Sophie's death, Daniel Toscan du Plantier has not visited the house that he bought for her.

He married for the fourth time, in June 1998, after declaring that 'one must respond to death with life', and his new wife gave birth to their child shortly afterwards. But he continues to harry the Irish authorities through his Paris lawyer.

Those authorities have not done much to mend their reputation. Although they appointed an assistant state pathologist soon after Sophie's death, when another French couple was found dead last year, this time in North Cork, there was again a delay - this time of 30 hours - before the pathologist arrived on the scene.

Bailey maintains his extraordinary sang-froid. He was recently hauled in for drunk driving, fined heavily, and banned from the road for four years. This was perhaps part of an attempt to make him crack, but he and his lawyer are mounting a counter-campaign, contending that the gardaí deliberately released his name to the press when such information should have been confidential. His lawyer has also made it clear that Bailey is in financial difficulty, 'finding it hard to find work as a landscape gardener'.

Since the murder, he has continued to phone me from time to time. On one occasion, he wanted to discuss 'The Battle of the Trees' in Robert Graves's The White Goddess, which has been adopted by New Agers as a holy book. Knowing that I had been friendly with the old wizard Graves, Ian asked me about the lines: 'The holly, dark green/Made a resolute stand;/He is armed with many spear-points/Wounding the hand.' The image reminded me of the Christmas tree Ian had said caused the scratches on his face and hands the night of the murder.

When Elizabeth and I called to tell him we were writing about him, he was helpful, giving us the name of his lawyer and of a French journalist he thought had handled the case well.

He had recited a poem of mine the night before and wondered how I would do as a crime reporter. As we were about to say goodbye, he interrupted abruptly: 'I'd better go. If I don't put the parsnips in the oven, Jules will kill me.'

Then, in early summer, we attended a benefit for Kosovo refugees at the Galley Inn. Night after night, we had been gazing at news images of sorrow and terror, so the cheerful, smoky pub was at once incongruous and soothing. As Elizabeth and I were moving through the crush toward the front door, Ian and Jules walked in. We were immediately struck by how much Ian had changed. He seemed heavier, with a slower walk. His face was pallid, and he had cropped his long black hair. Jules, however, looked poised and polished. But there was a wary look in her eyes. She talked briefly with Elizabeth about her involvement with the local benefits for Kosovo.

As Ian was working his way to the back of the pub, we stopped him to discuss this article. He told us that he didn't want his photograph taken. 'The matter is closed,' he explained. 'It's in the past now, and I want to put it behind me.'

As he announced this, people in the bar around us stared at him and murmured to one another. It was clear that the matter was not closed as far as they were concerned. And the gardaí is sustaining its investigation, despite the frustrating absence of forensic evidence, hoping for a breakthrough.

What must it feel like to be surrounded by such implacable suspicion if one is not guilty - to be the classic scapegoat?

And how will it all end? Another former gardener of mine, Kevin O'Mahoney, had a theory about what one Irish prime minister referred to as 'blow-ins' - foreign settlers in Ireland. 'Mental dwarfs we are for them,' he said; they see the Irish as simple-minded and easily managed. Bailey has run rings around his interlocutors and he has summed up the case succinctly: 'No witnesses, no murder weapon, no forensic evidence, no motive. It will take a long time.'

Perhaps there will be no real conclusion, and the cloud that settled over West Cork in the aftermath of the murder will gradually dissipate, leaving only the faint impression of fear and foreboding it brought to a place that had not been similarly sullied for decades. Yet there is something too distilled and concentrated about this story for it to disappear quickly. It seems to be part of a particularly European drama - for which West Cork is only one of many stages.

The village of Schull is certainly not the only remote town to have become the unexpected focus of a much criticised international murder investigation over the past few years. When a 13-year-old English girl was raped and smothered in a hostel in the village of Pleine-Fougères, in Brittany, in 1996, the local French police came under fire for not releasing details and for not immediately ordering DNA tests on local men. Like the West Cork gardaí, they probably knew little about DNA evidence, apart from what they had seen on television. The girl's parents, who managed to get the chief investigator on the case removed, called for a Europe-wide DNA database that could prevent murderers from escaping by slipping across borders.

In this story, and others, the problems of national identity and the absence of any pan-European police force have become obvious: clashes of legal systems and cultural practices, the tensions within small rural communities that are suddenly flooded with foreigners. When we asked an English friend whether he felt that his Irish neighbours were more hostile now, in the wake of this crime involving outsiders, he replied sadly that the locals were too polite to speak of it, but 'their silence is deafening'.

Not long ago, I glanced out the window of our farmhouse to see a man in a bulldozer barrelling down our road, the teeth of his machine tearing the flowering hedge. When I hurried out to stop him, he cried, 'What do you know, you're just a blow-in!' I had never experienced such xenophobic rancour in tolerant West Cork. I quashed him by rebuking him in Irish - which he didn't understand - but my satisfaction was short-lived. There was a new tension in the air.

John Montague's latest book is Smashing the Piano. Elizabeth Wassell is the author of The Honey Plain and Sleight of Hand, both published by Wolfhound Press, Dublin. She has just finished her third novel, The Thing He Loves

fields.headline: Time to downsize
fields.trailText: Overplayed and overpaid - why a tired England won't win Euro 2000 - and what can be done in the future.
fields.body:
England will not win the European Championship this summer because our top players will be exhausted after too many games from an oversize Premier League overloaded with ageing foreigners and too much money.

That may seem a bold and sweeping statement, but it was the general consensus of 240 or so of Europe's leading coaches who gathered in Munich last week for a seminar.

I was there - the only Englishman - and it was fascinating to discover what our counterparts on the Continent think of English football. Most of the leading clubs in Europe were represented, apart from ours, and yet one of the main topics of debate was the state of our game.

Opinion could be summarised thus; too many teams in the Premier League, too many games for the top players. The Europeans also think we need to have a midwinter break, that there are too many foreigners in England, especially those coming to the ends of their careers, and that players are paid far too much.

On the plus side, they think we have come a long way in a short time in terms of youth development, that our players' technique is gradually catching up with the rest of the world, and the facilities at our academies are first-class.

The overwhelming feeling was that we place too much emphasis on quantity rather than quality, and I would agree with that assessment.

Fifa, the game's governing body, have proposed a major change in the football calendar, with two breaks of two months each, the idea being to coordinate domestic and international competitions and to reduce the wear and tear on players.

One major requirement from England is that we reduce the Premiership from 20 teams to 18, and none of the foreign coaches in Munich could understand our reluctance to do this - and nor do I.

One coach from Barcelona told me he understood that Manchester City and Ipswich were big clubs in comparison to those in the Spanish second division, but suggested having two premier league divisions of 18 teams each. The old argument against reducing the number of teams here was that some clubs could not afford to lose the income from those extra two home games, but surely that is spurious now there is so much money in the Premiership, from television, merchandising and sponsorship.

Once we have reduced the number of teams, our leading players will not be playing so many games. It is almost impossible for any player to keep pushing himself to the limit for 11 months of the year, playing 60 to 70 games in a season without feeling the strain, both physically and mentally.

There was much talk about fitness, with the Germans particularly worried about the condition of the players they were producing. The new buzz word in European coaching in terms of physical development is balance. The thinking is that fitness coaches can only do so much to develop a player's physique, but it is equally important for players to have the sort of balance and rhythm that dancers and skiers, for example, have.

I remember a pioneer in this field was Len Hepple, who used to work with a lot of footballers and athletes. Nobody in England seems to do it now, which is why European coaches think our players lack the ability to change direction. That is also a metaphorical charge you can lay at the feet of English football in general.

One shining exception, it was agreed, is the youth academy system we implemented a couple of years ago, and which is fast catching up with the rest of Europe. But they all think we have too many academies - at 38, this is more than double the numbers in Italy, France or Germany, and it was thought that 28 would be a more realistic number. But the need for indoor areas for five-a-sides seems to have been overlooked.

All the coaches agreed that high wages in England cause problems, and they were staggered when I told them that many journeymen in the lower divisions earn in excess of £100,000 per year. The coaches also think we have too many foreign players cashing in on their twilight years. One coach from Milan said: 'Alan, you take them at the end of their careers whereas in Italy we have them at the beginning.'

All of these thoughts came out of a frank and fascinating exchange of ideas, and it is just a shame that there were not more influential figures from English football there to hear them.

fields.headline: Message in a bottle
fields.trailText: Brian Madley says George Best is adamant: he will have no regrets
fields.body:
The vanity of having one's photograph taken with any famous person who happens to be passing has always been abhorrent to me. But I have succumbed on two occasions, which is why there are two special photographs on my bookcase. In one I am with Sir Stanley Matthews, in the other it's George Best.

And I wanted those photographs not because of their fame but to remind me of our friendships over many years. So the news that Best had been rushed to hospital only a week after Sir Stanley's funeral left me praying for his full recovery.

It still amazes me that two men who possessed such identical soccer genius could be so completely different off the field. On the right wing a great knight, on the left a great night-out.

I never saw Sir Stanley with an alcoholic drink in his hand and I seldom saw George without one. My photograph with the mighty Matthews was taken when he lived in Malta and had chauffeured me around the island for two days. I don't even know if George can drive but there is no way I'd get into a car if he was behind the wheel.

But, although there are many stories told about the effects drink sometimes has on Best, I have only ever seen the lovable side of the man when he's had a few too many, a man who is only too happy to be his own biggest critic.

'I went to Toronto and saw a sign saying "Drink Canada Dry" so that's what I did,' is a line he was happy to borrow from Brendan Behan.

And he still delights in telling the Seventies story of the night a hotel room-service waiter delivered champagne after Best had won handsomely in a casino while escorting Marjorie Wallace, the reigning Miss World. Pound notes and his date littered the bed and as George prepared to pop the bubbly the waiter shook his head and asked: 'George, where did it all go wrong?'

But there is a harder, underlying message to that story, because Best tells it not to impress the listener or even to deride himself. He uses it to prove that he didn't throw away a career, he deliberately walked away from it, even though it wasn't always in a straight line.

'People are upset that I finished playing at Manchester United when I did, not for my sake but for their own,' he once told me. 'They don't really care what happened to me, all they worry about is that they couldn't see me play any more. If I'd wanted to I would have, but I didn't so what's the problem?'

I went to Edinburgh to see George after a famous drinking spree soon after he joined Hibs on a short-term contract.

Unfortunately for George, the French rugby team were also staying in his hotel and he ran into them as they were celebrating their victory at Murrayfield. He was still at it the following day when he should have been playing for Hibs.

'Why did you do it, George?' I asked.

'Well, they were very hospitable people and it seemed churlish not to have a drink with them,' he replied.

'But why go on for so long?'

'Don't forget there were 15 of them and only one of me,' said George.

Best can no more explain why he drinks so hard at times any more than he can tell you why or how he once performed such outrageous acts of magic on the pitch. 'It seemed a good idea at the time' is his answer to both questions.

I first got to know George well when we did a series together for the Sunday People. It involved some long sessions together, but he was then engaged to his first wife, Angie, who kept trying to drag him away from the person she described as 'that boring little man who only wants to talk about football'.

She was to be just the first lady in George's life I would meet. The second was because of a most extraordinary coincidence while I was in Australia covering a British Lions rugby tour.

We arrived in Canberra and I walked into my hotel bar to find George in the corner accompanied by his then girlfriend, Mary. He was on one of his after-dinner speaking jaunts and invited me to join him the following evening. As he answered questions from the floor, he introduced me to the audience as 'one of the pressmen I can trust' and suddenly I was in the firing line as well.

'Is George the best player you ever saw, if not who is?' I was asked. I answered honestly: 'No, he's the second best. Pele is number one on my list.' On the way back to the hotel, George was very quiet in the car before saying: 'I thought you were a friend of mine.'

'What makes you think I'm not?'

'You said Pele was better than me.'

I realised he wasn't joking and I tried to explain. He listened, then said: 'Do you think if I had played for Brazil and Pele played for Northern Ireland, you'd still be saying the same thing?' It's a question I still find difficult to answer.

The other memorable moment that night came as we sat in the bar with the two men who had organised his tour. Mary, looking like a vision, suggested to George it was time for bed. Needless to say, he didn't argue and as they left the bar one of the men turned to me and said: 'Now why would he want to go to bed with her when he could sit all night with us and talk football?' And he was serious.

Now george is with second wife, Alex, and also has his excellent agent, Philip Hughes, to help him, which is just as well because most of the problems in his life have come when he's tried to run his own affairs. About six years ago, he agreed to meet me in a wine bar he then owned in London to do an article about the forthcoming football season. I sat for two hours with no sign of George before being summoned to the telephone.

'Sorry Brian, but I've been tied up with someone slightly more important than you but if you care to join us we're in a pub just down the road.'

I was not best pleased until I realised George was in fact paying me a compliment because the person I was only slightly-less-important than was cricket legend Denis Compton, with whom he had already consumed three bottles of champagne. By the time we'd seen off six it was obvious the interview was off.

But that was the only time he's ever let me down. He once even agreed to have his beard shaved off to help a charity with which I was involved. And for me to now start lecturing him about giving up the booze, the worst case in history of black pots and kettles.

All I will say is that when our prayers are answered and he is back in good health George might in future try to make a very special effort to live as long as Sir Stanley did - which will give him at least another 30 years.

webTitle: Chelsea hit Rotterdam but don't go Dutch

fields.headline: Chelsea hit Rotterdam but don't go Dutch
fields.standfirst: Champions League details
fields.trailText: 'Techniek' and 'tactiek' await Chelsea at Feyennord on Tuesday
fields.body:
Dutch football, as most people know it, is a measured and aesthetic pursuit, like figure skating or the Japanese tea-ceremony. The Dutch tend to watch it in near-silence, as if it were a particularly solemn funeral.

Instead of cheering, spectators spend the match debating subtleties ('Who would have thought it? Zonal marking in the centre of defence!'). To the Dutch, what counts in football is 'techniek' and 'tactiek', and not such bagatelles as the final score. More important than the match itself, in any case, is Johan Cruyff's subsequent appearance on TV to explain its meaning ('I just know an enormous amount about football'). Dutch football, in short, is a complicated business.

But not the Dutch football played by Feyenoord, the Rotterdam club who find themselves joint top of their Champions League group and on Tuesday receive Chelsea.

The moment you arrive in Rotterdam you feel that you have left the Netherlands. One of the few Dutch cities to be bombed in the war (first by the Germans, then, curiously, by the Allies), its downtown district today could be in the American Midwest. Skyscrapers, big rivers, tough people. This city has none of the dinky seventeenth-century houses and little canals you find in Amsterdam.

The Rotterdammers consider themselves a hard-working lot ('We make the money, and in Amsterdam they spend it') and they seek that virtue in their football team. And so Feyenoord players tend to be bigger than Ajax players, to have heavier beard growth, longer hair, and, occasionally, earrings and tattoos. Most of the current side come from the provinces. Some, like Bert Konterman and Patrick Paauwe, are so rural they still believe in God. Peter van Vossen is one of 15 children of a pious family that disapproves of football.

The most cursory scan of the team sheet tells you that Feyenoord lack the gifts of certain other Dutch football teams. The local heroes include such refugees from British football as Ulrich van Gobbel (failed at Southampton), Jon Dahl Tomasson (ditto at Newcastle) and Van Vossen (erstwhile Rangers reserve). When Konterman was picked for Holland, and was run ragged by Gabriel Batistuta, he explained disarmingly: 'He was too quick for me.'

There is little Dutch arrogance at Feyenoord. Paul Bosvelt, the team captain (long hair, earring, from the provinces) says of their visit to Chelsea in November: 'It was really a disaster. We saw every spot on the pitch, but we didn't get the ball. It was 3-1, but it could have been six or seven.'

Yet Feyenoord do have their virtues. In the past fortnight they have beaten Lazio 2-1 away (a result that prompted double-takes even in Rotterdam) and then held them 0-0 at home. Chubby Jean Paul van Gastel, in central midfield, can barely move but has a pass like Platini's. Men like Bosvelt and Kees van Wonderen will not go down in footballing history but seldom make mistakes. The team even possess a secret weapon in the thin Polish goalkeeper Jurek Dudek, who is regarded in Rotterdam as the best keeper in the world ('or definitely the second best') and has understandably attracted Manchester United. Dudek has eclipsed Ed de Goey, who, since leaving Feyenoord for Chelsea, has been reviled by Rotterdammers as fat and lazy.

Feyenoord are no joke. But their main virtues are emphatically not Dutch: they are tough, and they are a collective. 'I'm glad I don't have to play against us,' says Bosvelt.

Even more frightening than the players are the fans. A company, Tattoo Bob, has put up a huge advert just outside the ground, and it has clearly pulled in business. One of the tough-looking fans hanging around the training pitch this week had brought with him a bulldog, which met its match only when one of the players bent down to scratch its ears.

The Legion, as the fans are known, are so wild they even make noise at football matches. At the Lazio game on Wednesday, there were moments when 45,000 people were stamping their feet on the ground and you imagined yourself in one of those mythical English stadiums before the era of all-seaters and bagel bars. The club song of 'Hand in hand, comrades' is sung without embarrassment.

It all sounds rather cute. In fact much about Feyenoord is odious. Their fans have decided that the main difference between them and Ajax is that they are honest, working-class Dutchmen while Ajax are a club of Jews. When Feyenoord play Ajax - the biggest sporting event in the Netherlands - thousands of Rotterdammers, from skinheads to office workers with their children, sing 'Hamas, Hamas, Jews to the gas chamber' and imitate the sound of escaping gas. Last April, when the team won the Dutch title, both Van Gobbel and Van Gastel chanted from the balcony of the town hall: 'Whoever doesn't jump is a Jew.'

The Feyenoord motto is 'No words but deeds'. If only they stuck to it.

fields.headline: Call it the Sky League
fields.trailText: How far will Sky go to gain an advantage in TV rights negotiations?
fields.body:
BBC bosses in Scotland were in a celebratory mood last week as they crowed about their coup in winning the live TV rights for the Celtic-Rangers game on Wednesday night. As the game effectively killed off the League Championship they had every right to be happy, as Sky would be left to cover loads of meaningless matches. But the sad fact is that this will be the only live British League game to be shown on the BBC this year and probably the last one ever unless someone stops Sky's backdoor bid to take over football.

Last week we saw Sky take a 9.9 per cent stake in Chelsea with little fuss. Even Chelsea's most famous supporter, ex-Sports Minister Tony Banks, seemed to be taken in by Sky's claim that this was good for Chelsea because they would give Vialli an extra £50 million to spend. That's about as likely as Ken Bates winning a good diplomacy award.

Having failed to take over Manchester United for a knockdown £623 million, Sky have moved to take a share in as many big clubs as it will take to win the broadcasting rights. The Premier League's reaction to this has, until the Chelsea deal, been to close their eyes and pretend it's not happening. The current rules of the Premier League allow for any one company to have a stake of up to 9.9 per cent in more than one club. When the rule was drawn up, no one reckoned on Rupert Murdoch's ruthless determination not to lose out on the exclusive rights to live football.

The BBC long ago gave up hope of competing for live football and will be left with the crumbs of highlights for the increasingly patronising Match of the Day. Murdoch has left the skirmish with the BBC to his part-owned Talksport Radio and the battleground has been cricket not football.

The idea that because Murdoch has been limited to just a 9.9 per cent stake does not necessarily mean that the club will vote for Sky's bid is laughable and an insult to our intelligence. The vote for the rights to Premiership football is already becoming a foregone conclusion and the only man who knew Sky inside out, Sam Chisholm, has been sacked by the Premier League and given a multi-million pound payoff. It's as if the Premier League want to give away the rights for nothing.

The Chelsea deal follows similar shareholdings at Manchester United, Manchester City, Leeds and Sunderland. It means that if City are promoted Murdoch will have control of five votes in the crucial TV rights negotiations. You can also add to that the vote of Spurs, who are so certain to support Murdoch that he hasn't even bothered to waste any of his money on buying shares in them - he doesn't need to. It is Spurs chairman Alan Sugar's company, Amstrad, that makes Sky dishes. If anyone has any doubt about which way Tottenham will cast their vote then they should look at the announcement that they made last week on their new internet site. None other than Sky are setting up the new site. So that's six votes guaranteed.

The Premier League, having woken up to the dangers of a Murdoch takeover, have now been making very low-key noises about the fact that they may act to change the rules of ownership if Murdoch has a stake in six clubs. The League have finally cottoned on to the fact that a change in rules requires a two-thirds majority and that if Murdoch controlled seven votes he could effectively block any rule change and be free to buy into other clubs. The Premier League are now saying that they will 'draw a line in the sand' at Sky having a stake in six clubs, but if Murdoch buys into just one more club it could be too late.

The problem is that the Premier League don't seem to have the will to take Murdoch on. If they won't act then what about the FA? The ownership rule is also an FA rule and the odds are that they are more likely to take action than the Premier League, though that would require real guts from the new FA boss. It is more likely that action will come not from the football authorities but from the Government - after all, they outlawed Murdoch's takeover of Manchester United. The problem is that Tony Blair may not want to upset Murdoch twice and his Sports Minister, Kate Hoey, hasn't the power to act on her own.

If someone doesn't act then we are effectively handing over our Premier League to Murdoch. Some people may not care if this happens, but just look what Murdoch has done to rugby league.

Charlie Whelan will host Radio 5's 6-0-6 for three weeks from next Saturday
fields.bodyText: BBC bosses in Scotland were in a celebratory mood last week as they crowed about their coup in winning the live TV rights for the Celtic-Rangers game on Wednesday night. As the game effectively killed off the League Championship they had every right to be happy, as Sky would be left to cover loads of meaningless matches. But the sad fact is that this will be the only live British League game to be shown on the BBC this year and probably the last one ever unless someone stops Sky's backdoor bid to take over football. Last week we saw Sky take a 9.9 per cent stake in Chelsea with little fuss. Even Chelsea's most famous supporter, ex-Sports Minister Tony Banks, seemed to be taken in by Sky's claim that this was good for Chelsea because they would give Vialli an extra £50 million to spend. That's about as likely as Ken Bates winning a good diplomacy award. Having failed to take over Manchester United for a knockdown £623 million, Sky have moved to take a share in as many big clubs as it will take to win the broadcasting rights. The Premier League's reaction to this has, until the Chelsea deal, been to close their eyes and pretend it's not happening. The current rules of the Premier League allow for any one company to have a stake of up to 9.9 per cent in more than one club. When the rule was drawn up, no one reckoned on Rupert Murdoch's ruthless determination not to lose out on the exclusive rights to live football. The BBC long ago gave up hope of competing for live football and will be left with the crumbs of highlights for the increasingly patronising Match of the Day. Murdoch has left the skirmish with the BBC to his part-owned Talksport Radio and the battleground has been cricket not football. The idea that because Murdoch has been limited to just a 9.9 per cent stake does not necessarily mean that the club will vote for Sky's bid is laughable and an insult to our intelligence. The vote for the rights to Premiership football is already becoming a foregone conclusion and the only man who knew Sky inside out, Sam Chisholm, has been sacked by the Premier League and given a multi-million pound payoff. It's as if the Premier League want to give away the rights for nothing. The Chelsea deal follows similar shareholdings at Manchester United, Manchester City, Leeds and Sunderland. It means that if City are promoted Murdoch will have control of five votes in the crucial TV rights negotiations. You can also add to that the vote of Spurs, who are so certain to support Murdoch that he hasn't even bothered to waste any of his money on buying shares in them - he doesn't need to. It is Spurs chairman Alan Sugar's company, Amstrad, that makes Sky dishes. If anyone has any doubt about which way Tottenham will cast their vote then they should look at the announcement that they made last week on their new internet site. None other than Sky are setting up the new site. So that's six votes guaranteed. The Premier League, having woken up to the dangers of a Murdoch takeover, have now been making very low-key noises about the fact that they may act to change the rules of ownership if Murdoch has a stake in six clubs. The League have finally cottoned on to the fact that a change in rules requires a two-thirds majority and that if Murdoch controlled seven votes he could effectively block any rule change and be free to buy into other clubs. The Premier League are now saying that they will 'draw a line in the sand' at Sky having a stake in six clubs, but if Murdoch buys into just one more club it could be too late. The problem is that the Premier League don't seem to have the will to take Murdoch on. If they won't act then what about the FA? The ownership rule is also an FA rule and the odds are that they are more likely to take action than the Premier League, though that would require real guts from the new FA boss. It is more likely that action will come not from the football authorities but from the Government - after all, they outlawed Murdoch's takeover of Manchester United. The problem is that Tony Blair may not want to upset Murdoch twice and his Sports Minister, Kate Hoey, hasn't the power to act on her own. If someone doesn't act then we are effectively handing over our Premier League to Murdoch. Some people may not care if this happens, but just look what Murdoch has done to rugby league. webTitle: Ipswich go down against the Flo

fields.headline: Ipswich go down against the Flo
fields.standfirst: League review Jason Tomas
fields.trailText: Ipswich were another team at the top who failed to justify their position yesterday. But in their case, the result - a 2-1 defeat at Wolves - was misleading.
fields.body:
Ipswich were another team at the top who failed to justify their position yesterday. But in their case, the result - a 2-1 defeat at Wolves - was misleading.

Nobody acould accuse them of not being determined to wipe out the memory of their stunning defeat by Queens Park Rangers in midweek. They completely dominaterd the first half, when they had no fewer than 12 goal attempts. In contrast, the goal with which Haavard Flo put Wolves ahead in the fourth minute proved their only shot on target during this period. Suitably inspired, the Norwegian, brought his total for the season to five in the second half. Even then, Ipswich never stopped battling and they were unlucky to have only a 75th-minute James Scowcroft goal to show for it.

It was another great afternoon for Portsmouth's 33-year-old striker, Steve Claridge, who scored the 89th- minute winner in their 2-1 victory against Nottingham Forest. As Portsmouth's manager, Tony Pulis, pointed out: 'Without Steve, we would have been in real trouble.'

Of Portmouth's partners in distress, Port Vale lost 3-2 at home to Sheffield United, but Walsall got a surprise 1-1 draw at Huddersfield. The home team wasted excellent chances in the first half and were eventually forced to come from behind for their point.

In addition to Huddersfield, Birmingham's promotion hopes took a knock. They lost 2-1 at Tranmere through a late Gary Jones goal.

West Bromwich Albion's new manager, Gary Megson, could hardly have failed to enjoy himself at Stockport, the club who sacked him nine months ago. Lee Hughes gave West Brom a 1-0 win.

Goalscorers said, are born, not made. So what can one make of the case of Reading's Darren Caskey?

His total of 18 goals from 46 matches this season, which have made him the highest scoring midfielder in the country, contrasts sharply with his record in this department in previous years. He scored no more than 12 in his previous 127 first-team games for the club and six in 43 for Tottenham. Hence the fact that Reading, who paid a club record fee of £700,000 for Caskey three years ago, have received a similar big-money offer for him from Wolves.

Reading's manager, Alan Pardew, has no doubts that Caskey is a better striker of the ball than most other lower division players. 'He is just sheer quality when he is in possession,' he says. 'I do not think I have known anyone to be as good with both feet as he is. In terms of free kicks around the box, he is our David Beckham.'

As for the improvement in Caskey's scoring ability in open play, Pardew explains: 'I have moved him slightly towards the right of the midfield, from the central midfield area.

'In this division, most of the central midfielders are second-ball winners - the so-called dogs-of-war types - and it's real hurl-burly stuff in there. Where he is now means that he has a bit more time and that his defensive responsibilities are minimised.

'Also, he has become muh more disciplined. He used to want to be on the ball all the time - the ball was like a magnet to him - and tended to end up being drawn farther and farther from the opposing goal.'

Though some of Caskey's goals this season have come from penalties, Pardew points out: 'This should not be allowed to detract from his record.

'It's a pity that the record books do now show the number of chances he has created for other players. If there was a table of goal-assists, I reckon he would be at the top of that as well.'

fields.headline: Yorke makes his points
fields.trailText: Manchester United 1 - 1 Derby County
fields.body:
There were ominous signs for pretenders to the crown with Manchester United making seven changes from their Champions League line-up, still dominating a game without playing well and Dwight Yorke rediscovering his radar for goal.

This was far from vintage United, but a vital result given their decision to rest so many players ahead of Wednesday's Champions League meeting with Fiorentina and the fact that a Yorke hat-trick will renew faith in his goalscoring talents at this, the most vital stage of the season.

A game that resounded with importance for both parties did not disappoint in the early, wind-affected going as Malcolm Christie, former United fan and parks footballer par excellence, missed a glorious opportunity to write his name into Derby folklore.

Seventeen seconds had gone when Rory Delap's right-wing cross arrived invitingly at the feet of Christie, signed from Nuneaton Borough 17 months ago, six yards from goal. Unfortunately for the former United supporter, Mark Bosnich's reactions were superb.

United's response was swift, Gary Neville's wind-assisted cross being misjudged by Delap as Quinton Fortune connected with a shot that flew inches beyond the far post.

Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, revelling in a precious starting place, slipped away from Steve Elliott and narrowly chipped over the bar before a superb pass from Paul Scholes on the halfway line sent the Norwegian striker scurrying towards goal.

Solskjaer looked to be clearly brought down by keeper Mart Poom outside the area but well-positioned referee Jeff Winter instantly disagreed - a non-decision that provoked predictable response.

Solskjaer sprinted after Winter while play continued, David Beckham stood on the wing spitting invective at the linesman and Sir Alex Ferguson left his perch in the raised dugout, and the marked managers' touchline area, to similarly harangue the officials.

It mattered not. Justice, and Poom, would be done. After 12 minutes, the Estonian keeper gathered a harmless backpass, elected to dribble out of his area and succeeded only in running into Dwight Yorke, the resulting rebound falling kindly for the United striker to tap into an open goal.

Lucky United? Yes, but no more than their pressure and the earlier Solskjaer incident merited. The goal was probably of more relevance and significance to Yorke himself as Poom kindly gifted him his first domestic goal since Boxing Day.

With Solskjaer flavour of the moment and Teddy Sheringham seemingly content with his permanent place on the bench, the competition is currently between Yorke and Andy Cole for the second striker position.

The contest became ever more absorbing as Georgi Kinkladze, revered still by half of Manchester, added a few cameo splashes to the Old Trafford canvas, twisting this way and that in an attempt to penetrate a defence that has looked suspect on more than one occasion of late.

Unfortunately for the Georgian, Christie had become more interested in a petty feud with Gary Neville, which commenced when he accused the Manchester defender of elbowing him while waiting for a 26th minute throw-in.

Seconds later, Christie inexcusably pushed Neville over in the area, presenting Scholes with the penalty and Poom with the chance of retribution. How the keeper took it, diving high to the right to push away the kick.

Yorke and Scholes had long-range shots, respectively saved and misdirected, that might have given United a cushion that it was becoming increasingly apparent they would need.

The Derby equaliser had been threatened from the 57th minute when Mickael Silvestre played a cross straight into the path of Christie who should have scored, instead of hitting Bosnich's legs, from eight yards. Then in the 66th minute Branko Strupar superbly lobbed a Kinkladze pass beyond Bosnich in the 66th minute.

But within three minutes Yorke rose superbly to head in an impressively accurate left-wing cross from Quinton Fortune and, two minutes on, a piercing through ball from Roy Keane allowed the Trinidadian to advance and curl the ball beyond Mart Poom.

fields.headline: Wise guys lacking staying power
fields.trailText: Chelsea 1 - 1 Everton
fields.body:
The Champions' League looms large in Chelsea's conciousness. When a contest against a spirited Everton side is sandwiched between Marseille and Feyenoord, it's a rich menu on offer at Stamford Bridge these days.

Enjoying participation in Europe while ensuring they get there again is an alluring quest, compared by Gianluca Vialli to champagne and caviar every three days. The result might not have been of superior quality but much of the credit for that goes to Everton, who deserved to raise a celebratory glass on the journey home.

These are halcyon days for Dennis Wise, who enjoyed another afternoon filling the role of inspired and inspiring. His capacity to inject some urgency into a team with a tendency to drift is a very useful asset indeed to Chelsea.

The Chelsea captain, who earns increasingly rave reviews with every game, is performing with relish. Just before the half-hour mark he was rewarded. Roberto Di Matteo's turn and give on the edge of the box was helped on by Chris Sutton, and Wise was perfectly poised to arrow the ball home from a narrow angle. It was reminiscent of the strike which sealed Marseille's fate in the Champions League here last week. Good times for the recently recalled England midfielder who wields mighty influence at Stamford Bridge.

How Everton must have rued the chance which had fallen to the recalled youngster Danny Cadamarteri not long before. Having bustled through to find himself in a one-on-one with the goalkeeper, he was thwarted by the commanding figure of Ed De Goey.

Everton, who had scored four on their last visit to London in what was probably their most accomplished display of the season, never looked like mustering such potent attacking thrust here. The Cadamarteri-Joe-Max Moore combination seldom looked capable of causing too many tantrums from Frank Leboeuf and company.

Walter Smith's team were so weakened that John Collins was called upon to fill in as an emergency left-back - which he did with calm aplomb - but they missed his guile further forward. They performed with plenty of purpose but lacked sufficient penetration to topple Chelsea. It was a challenging test for Stephen Hughes, making his Everton debut in the centre of midfield days after signing from Arsenal.

Chelsea were bright, pushing and probing to work openings. It proved another frustrating afternoon for the goal-shy Gianfranco Zola: three times the spark of a chance disappeared like fading embers. At half time he was replaced by Tore Andre Flo, Gianluca Vialli tinkering once more with his front line in the hope of finding an effective balance.

Flo caused a fluttering 'ooh' in the Matthew Harding Stand when his poke into the side-netting deceived a section of fans into heralding a second. Next Emerson Thome came close after a cavalier burst from the centre of defence but his venemous half-volley was always rising.

Chelsea's profligacy was punished in the 68th minute. Mark Pembridge's meaty throw-in caused confusion in the Chelsea rearguard and the enthusiastic Cadamarteri gobbled up the chance, slotting past De Goey on the half-turn.

Chelsea almost retrieved the lead thanks to a particularly generous gift from Everton. Paul Gerrard needlessly picked up Hughes's back pass, the referee awarded an indirect free-kick just to the right of the penalty spot, and Leboeuf's thump was repelled by Everton's wall.

Chastened, the visitors suddenly broke with menace, Moore rifling a powerful drive from long range to sting De goey's palms. When Jody Morris's diving header in injury time was smothered by Gerrard, it seemed nothing would settle this one.

webTitle: Villa savour life in the fast lane

fields.headline: Villa savour life in the fast lane
fields.trailText: Aston Villa 1 - 0 Coventry City
fields.body:
What a difference a few weeks can make. Just over three months ago John Gregory looked the odds-on favourite to win the seasonal sack race after Villa lost to Coventry at Highfield Road.

Now, after Ugo Ehiogu's first goal in 15 months had condemned Coventry to their fourth successive defeat, Villa are seventh in the table and looking realistically at a place in Europe, with a forthcoming FA Cup semi-final to boot.

This was not a great game, nor a particularly convincing win against a woefully out-of- form Coventry, who have now lost six of their last seven games.

But Villa's fans will not be too concerned, especially after their side laid to rest the humiliation of Coventry's 4-1 win here just over a year ago, their first ever league victory at Villa Park.

Colin Hendry, newly arrived at Coventry, had his work cut out against a lively Villa attack prompted by the busy Paul Merson.

Merson's running, passing and crossing created most of Villa's chances. The game was barely 90 seconds old when his short corner resulted in Alan Wright picking out Ehiogu unmarked at the far post, but the Villa defender tried to play the ball inside rather than go for goal and the chance went begging.

Undaunted, Merson continued to ferret away for openings and crossed for Ian Taylor to head over the bar. It was one of many openings for the home side. Magnus Hedman was forced to save smartly from both Taylor and Julian Joachim, while Hendry blocked a fierce effort from Benito Carbone..

Hedman was by far the busier goalkeeper, and his best save came in the 23rd minute when he tipped over a thundering 25-yard half-volley from his former team-mate George Boateng.

By that stage, Coventry had not had a sniff of goal, but in the 31st minute Robbie Keane had a great chance to open the scoring, only to mis-hit John Eustace's cross from 10 yards.

Villa finally broke the deadlock in stoppage time when Mustapha Hadji fouled Delaney wide on the right. When Merson swung in the resulting free-kick, Ehiogu rose above Hendry at the far post to power home a header.

Coventry manager Gordon Strachan replaced Keane with Noel Whelan at half-time, but his side still struggled to make headway against a defence superbly organised by the consistently excellent Southgate.

At the other end Julian Joachim was given a simple chance to increase Villa's lead when Eustace's attempted back-pass fell woefully short of Hedman. The Swedish goalkeeper saved his team-mate's blushes, though, by coming out quickly to get a foot to Joachim's stabbed shot and turn the ball away for a corner.

The game slowly petered out as a spectacle, although Whelan went close to snatching a barely-deserved equaliser in the closing minutes when his snap-shot on the turn flew just over the bar from close range.

fields.headline: Phillips hits Kop so hard
fields.trailText: Liverpool 1- 1 Sunderland
fields.body:
What do you get for £11million? Not the most devastating debut, it has to be said, for although Emile Heskey was his usual honest self he never threatened a goal against the team he helped bury last week, even though Sunderland were reduced to fielding their second string central defence.

But anyone expecting instant fireworks from Liverpool's new striker has not been paying attention to the Heskey career to date. He earned the biggest England rave review since Michael Owen for his performance against Argentina, yet instead of punishing Tranmere in the Worthington Cup final four days, he later managed to be upstaged by his own centre half. Instead, England rival Kevin Phillips of Sunderland had the last laugh with a late penalty equaliser.

Manager Gérard Houllier's decision to start with Heskey, just 24 hours after sealing his move from Leicester, capped a remarkable week for the big striker_ one that started so well with a valedictory contribution in his former club's 5-2 romp against yesterday's opponents last Sunday.

The 22-year-old Heskey partnered Erik Meijer in the front line against the Wearsiders while Michael Owen, who played 90 minutes in midweek for the reserves following his hamstring injury, was again nursed back on the bench with Titi Camara.

Sunderland began anxious to put their recent poor record behind them. They have not won in nine league games and defensive lapses - witness that collapse at Leicester - have recently cost them dearly.

They would have been urged by manager Peter Reid to keep tight at the back and weather any early storm. No doubt they listened but they apparently did not take heed - and Heskey was to the fore as Liverpool grabbed a second-minute lead.

He won a penalty after turning quickly in the box and was brought down by Darren Williams after Rigobert Song had played the ball forward. Patrik Berger stepped up and rattled an unstoppable penalty beyond keeper Thomas Sorensen and into the corner of the net.

Liverpool, who have conceded only nine goals at home in the Premiership, had their noses in front with the pedigree that suggested they could keep Sunderland in check. Peter Reid's side, indeed, endured a very rocky opening 10-minute period but escaped without further punishment.

The Kop had quickly warmed to Heskey and the name Bruno reverberated around the ground. But Sunderland broke away in the 12th minute and Niall Quinn seemed to get a nudge from Stephane Henchoz in the penalty area as he was about to shoot. But referee Graham Poll waved play on.

Heskey was seeing plenty of the ball and went on a marvellous run down the right in the 14th minute. He delivered a precise cross into the centre but Meijer's effort went narrowly over the top.

Heskey was proving a constant irritation to Sunderland and dragged a shot wide of the post after Meijer had played a cross fromskipper Hyypia back into his path. Hyppia was showing no effects from his recent ankle injury and almost extended their lead in the 27th minute. Berger floated in a corner from the left and Hyypia's header beat keeper Sorensen only to drift wide of the post.

Liverpool, stepping up the pace, saw Dietmar Hamann thundere a shot from 25 yards narrowly off target after Heskey steered the ball into his path. Hamann was again out of luck for Liverpool in the 31st minute when another 25-yard thunderbolt was superbly tipped over the top by Sorensen.

Sunderland were being restricted to the occasional breakaways and rarely tested keeper Westerveld. Liverpool poured forward in numbers five minutes before the break and their overall confidence was emphasised by Jamie Carragher. He was prepared to test Sorensen from 25 yards out but his effort did not match his optimism.

Sunderland were finding it difficult to carve out any real chances, but gave the home supporters a scare in the 58th minute. Republic of Ireland striker Quinn flicked the ball on to Phillips only for his effort to be superbly turned away by keeper Westerveld.

Liverpool's Carragher and Sunderland's Paul Thirwell were both booked by referee Poll with the official jumping in to separate the feuding pair.

Owen got another run-out when he replaced Meijer in the 73rd minute but four minutes later Sunderland drew level and salvaged a point.

Phillips scored his 25th goal of the season from the spot after he had been brought down by the keeper.

fields.headline: Owls show their mettle
fields.trailText: Sheffield Wed 3 - 1 West Ham United
fields.body:
Sheffield Wednesday fans remain convinced that their club started to implode that day 18 months ago when Paolo di Canio pushed over the referee Paul Alcock here, earning an 11-match ban. For all his promises that he would come back, the Italian never pulled on a blue-and-white shirt again and departed amid so much acrimony that the supporter's club threatened to sue him for the return of his £85 player of the year trophy.

So how they celebrated as their side launched a great fightback against Di Canio's new club West Ham on his first visit to Hillsborough, to keep alive their hopes of avoiding relegation with their first win in seven matches.

From the moment he stepped off the team bus until the time he boarded it back to London, Di Canio was subjected to the most hostile of receptions, the fans booing his every touch. So, amid this cacophony of hate it was inevitable that he should play a key role in West Ham taking the lead on 11 minutes by brushing aside two challenges to squeeze a pass through for the overlapping John Moncur.

The Wednesday keeper Pavel Srnicek could only flap at the cross, it fell to Steve Lomas whose shot rebounded to Frank Lampard to score. As for Wednesday, the negative energy of the fans seemed to affect them more. Even Wim Jonk, normally their most influential player, appeared lethargic and uninterested.

The only time the Owls threatened during the first period was when the Dutchman emerged from his stupor. First, in the 19th minute, when he fired a 20-yard shot that Craig Forrest pushed over the bar and then 12 minutes later when he drove in a low cross that Alan Quinn wasted.

It made what happened in the second half all the more amazing when three Wednesday goals in 10 frantic minutes turned the match on its head. The catalyst for the fight back was the introduction of Richard Cresswell, who in the 55th minute got on the end of Quinn's cross to force a shot past Forrest for the equaliser.

The focus switched from Di Canio and seven minutes later the home side were ahead when Andy Hinchcliffe unleashed a left-foot special from 30-yards - his first goal of the season. 'Paolo, Paolo, what's the score?' was still echoing around the ground when Niclas Alexandersson wrapped up the points in the 66th minute, a low shot that squirmed through Forrest's hands to show that when push came to shove, Wednesday were up to the task.

fields.headline: Graham in seventh heaven
fields.trailText: Tottenham Hotspur 7 - 2 Southampton
fields.byline: Ian Ridley at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
If you need a team to play yourself back into form against, it just has to be Southampton. Two weeks ago their north London neighbours Arsenal did it; yesterday Tottenham Hotspur disarmed the growing number of critics within their own support with a comprehensive demolition of poor and porous opposition.

Glenn Hoddle must have expected better coming back as a manager to the ground he graced as a player, especially as Southampton were twice ahead, but his subsiding side looked every inch relegation candidates. Steffen Iversen scored a hat-trick and Chris Armstrong, scoring twice, even looked a clinical finisher.

There was a flat atmosphere in and around the ground as kick-off approached, such is the air of gloom among Tottenham fans these days as they see clubs with whom they should be equals playing more attractive football and growing bigger and more successful as a result.

Hoddle's return did not help matters, serving to fuel nostalgia for more creative times when Spurs boasted a midfield artistry that the fans currently crave. What happened in the first, astonishing, 45 minutes, though, was surely enough to keep the dis illusioned critics at bay for a while, though.

Dubiously, Hoddle chose to give a debut at right-back to the new signing from Benfica, the Moroccan Tahar El Kalej, and his welcome to the Premiership from David Ginola was instant and unforgiving as the Frenchman danced past him and got in a low shot which Paul Jones did well to turn round his near post.

It seemed only a matter of time before the home side took the lead, with Darren Anderton probing from midfield, but the groans growing familiar were heard again when Chris Armstrong missed a gilt-edged chance. Francis Benali stepped on the ball to let in Steffen Iversen and he squared for Armstong, who - almost comically - pulled the ball wide from 10 yards with only a scrambling Jones to beat.

Then, wouldn't you know it, Southampton broke out to forge ahead. Hassan Kachloul split the Spurs defence with an incisive through ball and Jo Tessem strode on to drill a shot across Ian Walker and into the net. Fortunately for Spurs, they got a break just two minutes later. Sol Campbell challenged for Anderton's corner from the right but Dean Richards beat him to it, only to head into his own net. Relief was short-lived, however. Marian Pahars crossed from the left and El Khalej eluded Armstrong to head home.

Southampton are always likely to concede, however, and in what was developing into a remarkable game, Tottenham struck twice in two minutes and three times in 10, for a half-time lead. First, from Ginola's low cross, Benali failed to clear and Anderton stepped in to stab home from close range. Soon after, Steffen Freund clipped a pass through to Armstrong and this time he made amends with a cracking half-volley into the net at Jones's near post.

Then Jones put Benali in trouble with a poor clearance and Iversen seized on his hur ried pass before steering the ball into an empty net from some 20 yards. For the first time in a while, Spurs left the field for the interval with cheers instead of jeers in their ears.

Tottenham continued where they left off after the break. And it came as no surprise when they increased their lead. Ginola sent Stephen Carr away on the right and Armstrong, his confidence returning, neatly clipped the ball over Jones from close range.

Ginola was again the instigator of Tottenham's sixth. His ball sent Taricco to the byline and Iversen was at the near post to steer home . He completed his hat-trick by tucking home Ginola's deflected shot . After the famine of five goals in eight games came a feast.

fields.headline: Gallacher sinks Watford
fields.trailText: Newcastle United 1 - 0 Watford
fields.byline: John Wardle at St James's Park
fields.body:
Watford can stop humming the theme tune from The Great Escape. Keeper Alec Chamberlain insisted before this latest defeat that they were capable of staying in the Premiership, but even he must now accept the inevitable.

Chamberlain did his utmost to justify his optimism with half a dozen fine saves, but was eventually beaten in the second-half by Kevin Gallacher - a Scotsman settling a confrontation between two former England managers. But the outcome could have been different if Newcastle's keeper Shay Given had not produced two world-class saves at crucial moments.

Newcastle's first-half performance was strangely lethargic. Chamberlain com fortably fielded optimistic efforts from Robert Lee, Duncan Ferguson and Kevin Gallacher in the opening stages of the match.

Chamberlain's only other moment of concern in the opening 45 minutes came when Warren Barton angled a shot narrowly wide of the far post on the half-hour. By then, Watford had started to believe their second away win of the season was a realistic target.

Given was a notable exception to Newcastle's general mediocrity, twice demonstrating why rival Steve Harper must satisfy himself with a place on the bench.

He reacted smartly to clutch a close-range header from Icelandic striker Heidar Helguson in the 21st minute, then made an even better save to beat out a shot from Allan Smart after 32 minutes, with Wooter wastefully lofting the loose ball high over the bar.

There was more to come from Given seven minutes into the second half, when Peter Kennedy headed Wooter's cross to the feet of Smart inside the six-yard box at the end of Watford's best move of the match. The striker's shot was unconvincing, but Given's reaction save was still a remarkable one and undeniably the turning point of the game.

An astonishing miss by Alan Shearer, who hit the post when the failure of Watford's offside trap left Chamberlain exposed, suggested this wasn't to be Newcastle's day. But, with 59 minutes gone, Watford's resistance ended. Domi overlapped down the left, accepted Shearer's well-timed pass and drilled in a low cross to present Gallacher with his third goal for Newcastle.

Only Chamberlain prevented Newcastle building on that breakthrough, with three magnificent saves from Gary Speed, Dabizas and Ferguson.

fields.headline: Foxes caught late by Cort
fields.trailText: Wimbledon 2 - 1 Leicester City
fields.body:
This was a better advert for Saturday-afternoon shopping with a hangover from hell than watching football at one of the worst but most expensive grounds. Yet the significance of this Wimbledon win cannot be underplayed.

Wimbledon are in serious danger of dropping out of the Premiership for the first time in their remarkable 14-year run at the top, but Carl Cort's late winner leaves them just two wins away from manager Egil Olsen's survival target.

Cort struck with three minutes to go when the game seemed destined to end in a bore draw. Wimbledon have won only once away all season, but with four home games to come they just might beat the drop after all.

Leicester showed first. Andy Impey let fly with the first shot of the game when a third-minute effort from 20 yards was fisted away by Wimbledon goalkeeper Paul Heald, making a rare appearance for the injured Neil Sullivan.

But Wimbledon dominated and they seemed set to take the lead when a Jason Euell flick found Cort, unmarked in the penalty area. England Under-21 forward Cort took a touch too many before shooting and Tim Flowers came off his line to block.

Neither side looked that bothered, though, as the game took on the air of a pre-season friendly on a balmy afternoon in south London.

And there was only a brief sense of excitement when a 32nd-minute Impey error gave Euell possession and he was bundled to the ground by Gerry Taggart as he tried to get past the Leicester defender.

Neal Ardley calmly sent Flowers the wrong way to score with a sidefooted shot from the penalty spot and the Wimbledon sound system blasted out celebratory sounds which were a touch louder than the cheers from the crowd.

Leicester suffered a further potential set-back when they lost Robbie Savage through injury, just six minutes into the second half.

But they had little cause for concern as Taggart made amends for his penalty error by equalising four minutes later. Guppy's corner was flicked to the far post by Stan Collymore and the unmarked Taggart belted the ball in from close range.

Anybody's game now, but, in the next attack, Cort could have shifted the balance Wimbledon's way - and impressed the scout from Leeds United watching him - had he not badly mistimed his jump when presented with a free header on the edge of the six-yard area. No matter, with his late goal he did just that.

webTitle: How denials crash landed as truth

fields.headline: How denials crash landed as truth
fields.trailText: Emily Bell
fields.body:
Financial journalism has been much in the spotlight recently, courtesy of a spot of bother at the Mirror . The paper's financial tipsters, the City Slickers, have been dismissed for ramping shares they wrote about, which breaks the Press Complaints Commission guidelines and perhaps the law, too.

Then, with the impeccable timing of a man who knows how to kick a paper when it's down, razor tycoon Victor Kiam stings the Mirror for a £105,000 in a successful libel action - again against the now departed Slickers.

'I liked the outcome so much... I wanted to buy the jury!' beamed Kiam, in an unintentionally ironic statement

Our probity has never been under closer scrutiny; and quite right too. If, for instance, we print a story which we absolutely know to be wrong, we can be dragged in front of the PCC and admonished by our peers - very distressing. If errors of fact occur we can even be expensively sued. All this is as it should be. We must be accountable, and responsible.

But just occasionally a real ethical bind raises its head. Take, for instance, the departure on Friday of Bob Ayling, chief executive of British Airways - a story our correspondent thoroughly investigated and believed to be true more than a week ago. Nail up the bunting, here comes a big one, we thought. But the ethical thing to do, and indeed the professional thing, was to run it past BA. Which meant eliciting a response. One would expect either a 'no comment on market rumour', or possibly a terse 'totally untrue'.

Instead there was a river of adjectives: our story was 'ludicrous', 'inconceivable', 'laughable' and other less printable rebuttals. Then the level of damage limitation escalated: 'You are being used,' and 'Bob is absolutely in command of the company. He calls all the shots.'

The chairman would deny our story, and he did (though more of that later). And so on. Oh dear, two sets of evidence. What should we do? The 'irresponsible' thing: print the BA denial, thus airing what we strongly believed was a true story, while putting the company line. Shoddy, isn't it?

The pressure increased on Monday, when other newspapers were briefed that BA directors were 'livid' about the story and, in that rather snide way other papers have, they printed that BA was considering taking The Observer to the PCC. Ouch.

On Monday Ayling was summoned to see Lord Marshall, BA's chairman, and told the firm was letting him go.

Now this might look like an extended gloat, which it is not meant to be. We got things wrong; apparently BA has not briefed any headhunter to fill the post, let alone Spencer Stuart, named in our story. We apologise - unreservedly - for getting this wrong.

Yet BA through its battery of advisers was still fulminating on Friday that Lord Marshall's own denial 'only related to the appointment of a headhunter', so he had every reason to be 'livid'.

But there is clearly a problem here. When companies either employ numerous expensive and skilled PR advisers but do not keep them in the loop, or they choose to - and I would like to believe, with BA, that it was the former rather than the latter - it utterly undermines the money the airlines spend on burnishing its corporate image, it also makes life impossible for the battalions of extremely honest PR professionals and directors.

It also encourages 'irresponsible journalism'. If one accepts that companies mislead the press routinely - and a 'not true' when you don't know is almost as misleading as a 'not true' when something is true - what are we supposed to do?

Does any of this really matter to the reader, who after all ought to be our highest priority? Yes, if it means that verifying stories becomes a lottery and we are tempted to guess the truth more often than we should.

The truth is, we won't always get things right. But like most of our competitors, we try our hardest. And if we don't, we are at least accountable for our mistakes.

fields.bodyText: Financial journalism has been much in the spotlight recently, courtesy of a spot of bother at the Mirror . The paper's financial tipsters, the City Slickers, have been dismissed for ramping shares they wrote about, which breaks the Press Complaints Commission guidelines and perhaps the law, too. Then, with the impeccable timing of a man who knows how to kick a paper when it's down, razor tycoon Victor Kiam stings the Mirror for a £105,000 in a successful libel action - again against the now departed Slickers. 'I liked the outcome so much... I wanted to buy the jury!' beamed Kiam, in an unintentionally ironic statement Our probity has never been under closer scrutiny; and quite right too. If, for instance, we print a story which we absolutely know to be wrong, we can be dragged in front of the PCC and admonished by our peers - very distressing. If errors of fact occur we can even be expensively sued. All this is as it should be. We must be accountable, and responsible. But just occasionally a real ethical bind raises its head. Take, for instance, the departure on Friday of Bob Ayling, chief executive of British Airways - a story our correspondent thoroughly investigated and believed to be true more than a week ago. Nail up the bunting, here comes a big one, we thought. But the ethical thing to do, and indeed the professional thing, was to run it past BA. Which meant eliciting a response. One would expect either a 'no comment on market rumour', or possibly a terse 'totally untrue'. Instead there was a river of adjectives: our story was 'ludicrous', 'inconceivable', 'laughable' and other less printable rebuttals. Then the level of damage limitation escalated: 'You are being used,' and 'Bob is absolutely in command of the company. He calls all the shots.' The chairman would deny our story, and he did (though more of that later). And so on. Oh dear, two sets of evidence. What should we do? The 'irresponsible' thing: print the BA denial, thus airing what we strongly believed was a true story, while putting the company line. Shoddy, isn't it? The pressure increased on Monday, when other newspapers were briefed that BA directors were 'livid' about the story and, in that rather snide way other papers have, they printed that BA was considering taking The Observer to the PCC. Ouch. On Monday Ayling was summoned to see Lord Marshall, BA's chairman, and told the firm was letting him go. Now this might look like an extended gloat, which it is not meant to be. We got things wrong; apparently BA has not briefed any headhunter to fill the post, let alone Spencer Stuart, named in our story. We apologise - unreservedly - for getting this wrong. Yet BA through its battery of advisers was still fulminating on Friday that Lord Marshall's own denial 'only related to the appointment of a headhunter', so he had every reason to be 'livid'. But there is clearly a problem here. When companies either employ numerous expensive and skilled PR advisers but do not keep them in the loop, or they choose to - and I would like to believe, with BA, that it was the former rather than the latter - it utterly undermines the money the airlines spend on burnishing its corporate image, it also makes life impossible for the battalions of extremely honest PR professionals and directors. It also encourages 'irresponsible journalism'. If one accepts that companies mislead the press routinely - and a 'not true' when you don't know is almost as misleading as a 'not true' when something is true - what are we supposed to do? Does any of this really matter to the reader, who after all ought to be our highest priority? Yes, if it means that verifying stories becomes a lottery and we are tempted to guess the truth more often than we should. The truth is, we won't always get things right. But like most of our competitors, we try our hardest. And if we don't, we are at least accountable for our mistakes. emily.bell@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Eclipse of the boy  wonder
fields.standfirst: Everyone wanted a piece of Quentin Tarantino after his electrifying debut. But lately the motormouth has gone quiet, holed up in his Hollywood mansion, with projects left in limbo. Have we seen the end of his comic-book brutality, asks  Mark Morris,  or is he planning a second coming?
fields.trailText: Everyone wanted a piece of Quentin Tarantino after his electrifying debut. But lately the motormouth has gone quiet, holed up in his Hollywood mansion, with projects left in limbo. Have we seen the end of his comic-book brutality, asks Mark Morris, or is he planning a second coming?
fields.body:
There's something special about the idea of a dark, sprawling house in Los Angeles, filled with the ghosts of a glorious past, the sun shining relentless outside, but a firmly shuttered murk within. Think of Sunset Boulevard, or Phil Spector and Brian Wilson. These are the images conjured up by reports of an apparently increasingly reclusive Quentin Tarantino, lurking in his vast house in the Hollywood Hills and battling with script after script that doesn't work. One is about his father, a strikingly personal choice for a man accused of making movies about movies. Tarantino, they say, doesn't leave his grounds much. He doesn't have to: he has his own screening room, with a proper 35mm projector. What more could he need?

The question of what has happened to Tarantino started to crop up when lists of the best films of the Nineties appeared at the end of last year. Working on The Observer's Top 10, I was almost surprised when I remembered Tarantino. It is only two years since Jackie Brown was released here, but he seemed to have been gone for much longer. He just disappeared. Not only because he didn't seem to be doing anything, but because no one talked about him any more.

Somehow, he had gone from being the biggest thing since the movie brats of the Seventies, to the guy whose last film was the second best Elmore Leonard adaptation of 1998, utterly eclipsed by Steven Soderbergh's Out Of Sight . He wrote the introduction to a book about blaxploitation, he put his name to the re-release of a couple of terrible Seventies films and broke up with Mira Sorvino.

The rather romantic vision of Tarantino going mad in his mansion is deflated when you learn the one bit of work he has finished recently is playing a blind preacher in Little Nicky, Adam Sandler's latest. That's right, in two years the most famous director of his generation has done a bit part in an Adam Sandler movie. It starts you thinking: what was all the fuss about in the first place?

It was all an accident, anyway. Reservoir Dogs was originally planned as a tiny $35,000 film until Harvey Keitel got involved. You can see that it was designed to be a micro-budget film: most of it takes place in a big bare warehouse, and you never get to see the heist. In the end, it still only cost $1.5 million. But it didn't look cheap, it wasn't arty; it was clever but not weird, clearly aimed at people who never have considered watching a Jim Jarmusch or even David Lynch film. Consciously or not, Tarantino had created a third way between the Hollywood of the high concept Top Gun years and its arthouse polar opposite.

Strangely, Reservoir Dogs flopped at the US box office, although it did well here. But it made an impact regardless. The slow-motion walking sequence became instantly famous, as did the ear-slicing scene. The film helped put the Sundance festival on the map. It brought John Woo to the attention of Western audiences. The soundtrack was perfect for a time when exploring record piles in charity shops suddenly seemed like a good idea. And it was a man's film, three years before Loaded and all that followed. Quentin Tarantino was 29. Everything snowballed. Old scripts he had written were dusted down for True Romance, and Natural Born Killers. He directed a quarter of the vilified Four Rooms. His co-writer Roger Avary directed the widely disliked Killing Zoe. Tarantino was invited to inflict his acting on other people's films, and did some dialogue about Silver Surfer comics for Tony Scott's submarine movie Crimson Tide. And when Pulp Fiction emerged, the hype seemed instantly justified.

Here's Time magazine at Cannes in 1995: 'Then BLAM!, the Wild Bunch hit town. On the festival's final Saturday, John Travolta, Bruce Willis, Samuel L. Jackson, Uma Thurman and other performers from the American thriller Pulp Fiction brought some big-time, macho-and-mayhem, Uzi-in-your-gut star quality to Cannes.'

And the Washington Post on the film: 'Pulp Fiction is everything it's said to be: brilliant and brutal, funny and exhilarating, jaw-droppingly cruel and disarmingly sweet. Quentin Tarantino, the postmodern Boy Wonder of American crass culture, for whom the only thing to fear is boredom itself, has produced a work of mesmerising entertainment.To watch this movie (whose 2 hours speed by unnoticed) is to experience a near-assault of creativity.'

Pulp Fiction cost $8m to make. It won the Palme d'Or and made more than $200m. It was hip and mass market. It brought back Travolta and made Jackson a star. Aging surf guitar hero Dick Dale was suddenly playing Europe to big crowds. And Tarantino was on the verge of being the most famous director since Hitchcock.

What followed wasn't a spectacular self-destruction; there was no act of ego-driven madness like Dennis Hopper's The Last Movie, or Peter Bogdanovich's At Long Last Love or Michael Cimino's Heaven's Gate. People just got tired of films in which hitmen talked about old TV shows. From Things To Do In Denver When You're Dead down to 8 Heads In A Duffel Bag, the schtick grew wearier and wearier. Kevin Williamson picked up the postmodern/pop cult riffs and used them for Scream. That has exhausted itself too, as anyone who has had the misfortune of seeing Williamson's directorial debut Teaching Mrs Tingle knows.

The gang discussing Madonna over breakfast at the start of Reservoir Dogs had seemed so fresh, but staleness set in alarmingly. I remember seeing Heat and appreciating the lack of ostentatious cleverness in the dialogue.

Tarantino's insistence on appearing on screen didn't help either: he's an immensely gifted writer, a pretty fair director and one of the worst actors the world has ever seen. Only a year after the impossible heights of Pulp Fiction, From Dusk Till Dawn, scripted by and starring Tarantino, was described by one critic as 'indefensible trash'.

So Tarantino made Jackie Brown: cutting down on the violence, concentrating on a middle-aged love story. And the world shrugged and walked on by. In theory, the film was a step in the right direction, Tarantino's shot at growing up. In practice, nobody cared. Two years on from Jackie Brown, there is no Tarantino-shaped hole at the heart of Hollywood. Guy Ritchie nicked the whole Tarantino bag of tricks for Lock, Stock And Two Smoking Barrels, and ended up on Madonna's arm. Others have raced ahead.

Some mistook Paul Thomas Anderson for the new Tarantino when Boogie Nights first came out - ah, the Seventies!, they shouted. Burt Reynolds! Tacky songs on the soundtrack! But the scope and depth of Anderson's Magnolia is far beyond anything Tarantino has even hinted at. Tarantino has talked a lot about making a men-on-a-mission movie, his Dirty Dozen. But why wait when you can see Three Kings, which has all the elements you can imagine in Tarantino's film - the deliberate juxtaposition of violence and humour - plus a political complexity that would surely elude Quentin.

Why miss him when you can have a hip-hop soundtracked hitman movie paying homage to both Kurosawa and Tarantino's beloved Jean-Pierre Melville like Jim Jarmusch's fabulous Ghost Dog: The Way Of The Samurai , due out here in April? Or a hitman movie that stars Terence Stamp and Peter Fonda, exploiting every Sixties resonance they possess, like Soderbergh's The Limey? In fact, the way Soderbergh overcame the albatross of Sex, Lies and Videotape via a retreat into impenetrable artiness to a commercial resurrection as George Clooney's favourite collaborator could be a lesson to Tarantino.

Meanwhile, one of the stalled Tarantino scripts focuses on World War II, written by another burnt-out one-time wonderboy, Peter Bogdanovich. Bogdanovich, like Tarantino, is a feverish film buff, a man who went to Hollywood to worship at the feet of the great directors. Like Tarantino, he's an intensely geeky character who struck gold early: The Last Picture Show was his second movie. Like Tarantino, there was a period when he seemed unable to do any wrong: What's Up Doc? starred Ryan O'Neal and Barbra Streisand and still managed to be a good film. There is one lesson Bogdanovich can give Tarantino: don't grow up to be like me.

Whether he has the humility to say it is another matter. There's a strange story that appeared in the Philadelphia Inquirer recently. The paper reported that Tarantino has made another film, in secret. It's a nice idea, but an impossible one. Unless, of course, Tarantino has turned the camera on himself, and made a harrowing film about a once dominant director adrift in his vast estate above LA. In which case, he really was smarter than us all along.
