fields.headline: Big business is watching you
fields.standfirst: In Michael Mann's impressive paranoid thriller, Al Pacino has a fight on his hands - against the Seven Dwarfs
fields.trailText: Philip French: A movie of the first rank, less flamboyant than Mann's earlier films, but as sombre and realised on the same grand scale and with the same feeling for space. ...[It] avoids triumphalism and the choices that confront Wigand and Bergman are never simplified
fields.body:
For the best part of a century, the most desirable heroes of American cinema have carried two lethal props - the handgun and the cigarette. Generations of moviegoers have emulated them.

For a year in the Army, I went out each morning with a loaded pistol strapped to my hip, feeling like a gunfighter or a private eye, and for 21 years my self-image as a confident adult was largely achieved by having a cigarette between my lips during most daylight hours.

The murderous and suicidal implications of both actions were not lost on me. But they gave me immense pleasure and I got out of the Army without firing a shot in anger and gave up smoking before my health was permanently impaired.

As a result, I feel a certain ambivalence when invited to join attacks on manufacturers of arms or tobacco. Arms manufacturers tend to use versions of the persuasive speeches Shaw put into the mouths of the munitions tycoon Undershaft in Major Barbara and thus are out in the open.

But there can be no forgiving the hypocrisy with which the cigarette bosses defend their product or the ruthlessness with which they deploy their formidable power against critics. This is one of the key subjects of Michael Mann's engrossing political thriller The Insider , which pits a troubled scientist against his former employers, one of the top tobacco companies, whose chief executive officers are known as the Seven Dwarfs.

The movie resembles All the President's Men and The China Syndrome in the way it involves the media manipulating whistle-blowers. Vulnerable people are persuaded to threaten the welfare of themselves and their families by making public evidence that will discredit the forces of the entrenched and powerful.

The contrast between the private citizen and the professional investigator is cleverly spelt out in the opening sequences that crosscut between the lives of two men of probity involved with large corporations - Jeffrey Wigand (Russell Crowe), a chemist with the Brown & Williamson tobacco company, and Lowell Bergman (Al Pacino), a producer for CBS's 60 Minutes, America's most prestigious TV current affairs show.

Wigand is an apparently happy husband and father of two, living a quiet, golf-playing corporate life of comfort in Louisville, Kentucky. But prompted by professional scruples, he has offended his smooth employers and been fired, though on generous terms that depend on his respecting professional confidentiality. Bergman is a volatile journalist, a creation of the radical Sixties, who constantly has big, dangerous stories on his stove.

Currently on the front-burner is an interview between his show's veteran frontman, the 78-year-old Mike Wallace (Christopher Plummer), and the head of Hezbollah, which we see him risking his life to set up. On the back-burners are investigations of a drug-laundering outfit, the Unabomber, and a technical aspect of the tobacco industry on which he needs expert advice.

The latter brings Bergman into contact with Wigand and he rightly smells a story about the malfeasance of the tobacco business and the lies about nicotine addiction told on oath before a Congressional committee by the Seven Dwarfs. Bergman believes that in persuading Wigand to testify on the programme he is serving the public and getting the scientist to do what his conscience dictates.

The result is an upheaval that changes the lives of both men. Significantly, on the day when the die is incautiously cast, the New York Times lead story is of O.J. Simpson's acquittal, a case of how in America the ruthless, consciousless rich can get away with murder.

The Insider is a dark paranoid thriller, lit by Mann's regular photographer Dante Spinotti in the penumbrous style Gordon Willis developed in The Godfather and All the President's Men. Danger, real and imagined, lurks everywhere as the tobacco companies seek to silence Wigand. His pension is cut off; the family moves to a smaller house; he finds a job teaching chemistry in a high school. Obscene threats appear on his e-mail, his phone is bugged and he's followed by menacing agents.

When the FBI are called in, they treat Wigand with suspicion, taking away his guns and his computer. It's suggested that the FBI men, expecting to get lucrative security jobs on retirement, are in league with big business. The final straw comes when the tobacco companies set out to destroy Wigand's character by feeding discreditable stories to the media.

Wigand finds himself deserted by his wife and left, like Gary Cooper in High Noon, to face his enemies alone. Moreover, back at CBS headquarters in New York, the corporate lawyers are forcing Bergman's bosses to dilute the programme and to omit Wigand's testimony on the grounds that it could involve the network in 'tortious interference' in a contract between others.

Bergman suspects that the real reason is that a high-profile legal action could affect the value of CBS shares on the eve of a lucrative merger. In an electrifying scene, an affronted Wallace turns on an unprincipled, power-dressing lawyer (an icy Gina Gershon) who seeks to mollify him. But by then, Wallace has capitulated, if only temporarily, and left Lowell as isolated as Wigand.

The Insider is a movie of the first rank, less flamboyant than Mann's earlier films, but as sombre and realised on the same grand scale and with the same feeling for space. Conflations and fictionalisations have necessarily occurred, but the film avoids triumphalism and the choices that confront Wigand and Bergman are never simplified.

What makes them complex figures (and they are impressively embodied by the ambling Crowe and the balletic Pacino) is that they engage in inner moral debates that their employers dexterously avoid. Yet compromise of a decent sort is given its due in Plummer's formidable, humane and deeply moving performance as Mike Wallace. He has half-a-dozen terrific scenes showing Wallace variously as confident, arrogant, dignified, insecure and contrite.

In one of them, he confronts the implacable Bergman with a New York Times editorial accusing CBS of 'betraying the legacy of Edward R. Murrow' and you can see his wrinkled face and self-esteem collapse before the camera's relentless gaze. It's at this point that we remember that Murrow never appeared on air without a cigarette in his hand and died of cancer at the age of 57 after one lung had been removed.

The Insider is a movie of the first rank, less flamboyant than Mann's earlier films, but as sombre and realised on the same grand scale and with the same feeling for space. Conflations and fictionalisations have necessarily occurred, but the film avoids triumphalism and the choices that confront Wigand and Bergman are never simplified. What makes them complex figures (and they are impressively embodied by the ambling Crowe and the balletic Pacino) is that they engage in inner moral debates that their employers dexterously avoid. Yet compromise of a decent sort is given its due in Plummer's formidable, humane and deeply moving performance as Mike Wallace. He has half-a-dozen terrific scenes showing Wallace variously as confident, arrogant, dignified, insecure and contrite. In one of them, he confronts the implacable Bergman with a New York Times editorial accusing CBS of 'betraying the legacy of Edward R. Murrow' and you can see his wrinkled face and self-esteem collapse before the camera's relentless gaze. It's at this point that we remember that Murrow never appeared on air without a cigarette in his hand and died of cancer at the age of 57 after one lung had been removed.

fields.headline: Couch potatoes
fields.standfirst: Paul Solotaroff's Group: Six People in Search of a Life is excellent reportage, but fails to ask serious questions of psychotherapy
fields.trailText: Paul Solotaroff's Group: Six People in Search of a Life is excellent reportage, but fails to ask serious questions of psychotherapy
fields.body:
Group: Six People in Search of a Life
by Paul Solotaroff
Allen Lane, £18.99, pp339

In Ethan Coen's book of short stories, Gates of Eden, a private investigator with a pressing problem resorts to an intensive course of therapy. As he lies on the couch and obediently rummages through his earliest memories, the analyst, much to his frustration, does nothing other than lend an ear. Isn't this guy, marvels the PI, supposed to do something besides sit back and draw pay?

Charles Lathon, the therapist at the centre of Paul Solotaroff's Group: Six People in Search of a Life, could hardly be accused of sitting back and drawing pay. The Lathon plan is nothing if not exacting: under his tutelage and over the course of 10 months, six New York professionals are asked to take to take a "three-step" route back to happiness through group counselling.

Working together and "under no constraint to mind their manners", they are charged with nailing down their problems, making a start on transforming their lives and proceeding to what Lathon promises is "serious fun". What brings these people to group therapy are "the quotidian problems and concerns of affluent, midlife adulthood": Sara has a mental block around men; Peter is terminally lacking in confidence; Lina is going through a difficult divorce; Dylan is a drinker recovering from a string of tragedies; Jack is a spendthrift and Rex just wants to stop living the high life and settle down.

Solotaroff has worked all of this up into a compelling period piece. His is a suggestive piece of reportage, skilfully capturing the dynamic of group activity and measuring its pace against the unique rhythms of contemporary New York: its noise, its banter, the abruptness of the way its seasons change.

The problem with his account is that, lacking any critical distance from proceedings, it takes too much at face value. It never occurs to Solotaroff - a satisfied former patient of Lathon's - to question the assumptions behind group discussion, nor to wonder at the way in which these six, seemingly bereft of any intimacy in their private life, can find it so easily within the enclosure of a therapeutic relationship.

Lathon is enigmatic and a smooth talker, but much of what he dispenses is nothing more than homespun wisdom. When Lathon assures one client: "You are who you are and you do the best you can", the reader wishes him to reply: "Thanks for the tip."

A more serious criticism which might be levelled at Lathon's method is his peculiar and unarticulated understanding of human nature. The claim made here is that each patient has a right to be freed from "hijacked narratives", that recovering distant memories has the potential to solve problems in the here and now, and that each can achieve happiness by remaking the jigsaw of their own life story.

Nowhere is there any appreciation of the complexity of memory and the role which it plays within human consciousness. Lathon's approach threatens to make biography and accumulated experience more of a burden than an asset. Worse, its suggestion that wading through the murky backwaters of memory can solve complex life problems risks obscuring more promising avenues for individual development.

One of the most dramatic episodes of the book has Rex, whose lack of emotion has made him the black sheep of the group, suddenly lose patience with his colleagues: "You can't accept that there's other ways to do this - to reap the gain, without grovelling in the pain...obviously, there's a code of what's acceptable here, and I fall outside it."

Rex might be on to something, but Solotaroff does little to follow it up. When, in an epilogue, he recounts Lathon's subsequent fall from grace and his dispatch to see a therapist of his own, it comes as no surprise that the ironic possibilities are lost on him. Instead, it merely reinforces him in his pat belief that "It's good to talk."

Despite all its flaws, Group deserves to be read. In years to come, anthropologists may come to view the counselling ritual as a curiosity of turn-of-the-century etiquette. This book, whatever its evasions, looks likely to feature as a primary source.

fields.headline: The young rich entrepreneurs 11-20
fields.trailText: Adam Twiss and Damien Reeves | Charles Cohen | Marcus Lauder | James Page | Stephen Short | Andrew Foyle | Emma Edelson and Robert Jenkin
fields.body:
11. Adam Twiss, 24 and Damien Reeves, 25

Co-founders, Zeus Technology. £13 million each.

Zeus, like most internet companies, considers modest growth a sin against nature. In the last year the company has tripled its staff, moved to offices eight times larger than the last, and opened in the US. To top it off, last September Tony Blair chose its offices to launch his vision of a web-friendly Britain.

'The Prime Minister's visit was exciting,' says Twiss. 'It is a sign that we are beginning to get there as a company.' Zeus was set up in 1995, which makes it one of the more established web companies around. It develops internet software which other web companies use to run their sites. They claim one site in 50 around the world runs on its technology.

Adam Twiss and Damien Reeves ran their own chat and fan-based website in their final year at Cambridge where they both studied computer science. The site started to become so popular that it kept crashing under sheer weight of numbers. So they developed more sophisticated software to keep it working. They realised others who ran sites had the same problems and decided to set up a business offering their software. In September they secured more venture capital funding, though the pair had to cut their joint stake from 84 per cent of the company to 53 per cent. However, the company's value has risen from £30m to £50m, which means the value of their shares remain at £13m each. The company plans to float in the next 12 months.

Twiss says: 'A lot of people want to build up a company and sell it off before the perceived internet bubble bursts. I would not even describe many of these companies as internet businesses. Amazon is not an internet company, it is a book company. The web is just its medium. In just the same way, Direct Line is an insurance business. But we are an internet company. We make tools that make the web work better, and we are here to build a long-term business.'

12. Charles Cohen, 30

Co-founder, online loyalty scheme Beenz. £12.5 million.

Cohen says the best book he has read recently is a biography of Karl Marx. 'A lot of the terms the new economy uses are originally his, although a lot of internet businesspeople might not want to admit that.'

Rather than not want to admit it, many would probably not have heard of the founding father of Communism. But Cohen is a bit of a rarity among the e-millionaires in that his early passion was politics - he studied for the 'politician's degree', politics, philosophy and economics, at Oxford - rather than getting involved in money-making ventures. A former Liberal Democrat speechwriter, he worked at the House of Commons but turned his back on politics to set up his first Internet venture in 1995.

Over time, that enthusiasm developed into Beenz.com (after 'been there, done that'). In simple terms it is an online version of a supermarket loyalty scheme - points are earned when you buy things online, or simply by visiting websites, and can be spent with participating online traders. It was set up in December 1998 with £300,000 from a mixture of friends, family and small private investors. Cohen brought in Philip Letts of the Letts diaries family as chief executive, and in the space of 15 months the duo have raised £20m of funding from a variety of sources including venture capitalist Apax Partners, Japanese cell phone distributor Hikari Tsushin, plus a personal stake from Larry Ellison, the chief executive of Oracle, the world's second largest software manufacturer. They employ 100 people in Tokyo, London and New York. Market analysts value the company at £62m. Cohen remains coy about his wealth. 'I've got no idea how the papers come up with these figures.' But basic maths dictates that 20 per cent of a company valued at £62m means his stake is worth £12.5m.

He lives modestly in Crouch End, London, with his partner, and recently bought an A-class Mercedes - but before we could suggest that was a sign of his spending some of his virtual cash, he countered by explaining that it was bought to ferry around his baby daughter, Cecily.

13. Marcus Lauder, 23

Co-founder, Magic Moments. £12.5 million.

Marcus Lauder says he left his computer and electronics course at King's College London after only 18 months 'because I was distracted'. By what? 'By money.' 'You go to college in order to get a good job. But I was already doing a lot of consultancy work on the side. And I thought the course didn't concentrate on the most interesting work being done at the time, so I left.'

Lauder developed his interest in computers at 13, when he developed and sold software packages from his Watford home. After quitting college, he set himself up as a consultant. He met two other consultants Abby Hardoon, 36, and Victor Gareh, 35, and in 1995, with £8,000 put up by the two older men, they started Magic Moments offering internet services to business.

Hardoon and Gareh handle business deals and administration, while Lauder takes care of technical matters. The real leap in value came last August when the company was floated on the Alternative Investment Market - for young companies - partly backed by PR man Matthew Freud and Manchester United director Michael Edelson. The business is currently valued at £125m, of which Lauder has a 10 per cent stake. Lauder's interest in computers is his own; his parents are publicans and still do not have a computer. He is about to move into a flat in Chiswick with his girlfriend. But in his spare time he builds and flies model rockets from scratch. 'That takes up a lot of my time and money,' he says. He holds the UK altitude record for flying a one-metre rocket 3,000 feet. You can buy a lot of Airfix rockets for £12.5m.

15. James Page, 29

Co-founder, deckchair.com. £12 million.

This is the story of an internet fortune built on money which originally came from the Soviet dictator Joseph Stalin. If that is not exotic enough it also involves the Vietnam war, an Irish pop star, and cheap air tickets.

James Page's parents met as journalists covering the war in Vietnam but they divorced when Page was very young. He spent his childhood travelling between England, America, the Caribbean and the Scottish Highlands to spend time with both his mother and father - which was also the start of his software obsession. 'I started programming when I was 12. It was a way I could escape from the world. I could just concentrate on the machine,' says Page, who paints a lonely picture of that time.

Now, with Sir Bob Geldof, he is the co-founder of travel site deckchair.com which scans the web for cut-price airfares. Since its launch 11 months ago the company has received funding from private individuals including concert promoter Harvey Goldsmith and the Seiff family, which founded Marks and Spencer, valuing the company at £30m - Page owns 40 per cent.

A restless character, he quit college through 'boredom' after just six months, and in 1991 took his self-taught programming skills to computer games company Eidos - the inventor of the phenomenally successful Lara Croft character and the Tomb Raider series. When he quit Eidos, he bought shares in the company with money left to him by his great-aunt Monica Selton, a communist in the Fifties, who made anti-Allied broadcasts during the Korean War. Questions were asked about her treasonable behaviour in the House of Commons. Around the same time Selton decided to emigrate to the Soviet Union where Stalin himself gave her a peace prize - including cash. Selton left the money, a few thousand pounds, to her great-nephew. 'That money was my business stake,' laughs Page.

Page lives with his wife, the Australian writer Justine Etler, in London's Covent Garden.

16. Stephen Short, 28

Property developer. £11.75 million.

Ask Welsh business journalists about one of the principality's richest personalities, Stephen Short, and you draw a blank. This ruddy-faced businessman is intensely shy and shuns all publicity. His secretary dismisses all pleas for an interview saying 'he never talks to the press'. The only thing she lets slip is that he rents a box at the new Millennium Stadium in Cardiff from where he indulges his passion for rugby.

But the Cardiff construction and property communities do know him. They paint a picture of a family dynasty. These days his father, Gabriel Short, is considered to be its head. The family originally made its money from supplying contract-based industrial services to the British Steel industry. From there, they diversified into construction and they also have considerable commercial property interests in South Wales.

The younger Short owned 35 per cent of the family's main business, Short Bros, which last year had a turnover of £60m. Last November, Short Bros was sold to Australian industrial giant Brambles Industries for £25 million. This alone provided Short with an £8.75m windfall. The family created a second company, Short Developments, last year after the Brambles sale, presumably to house their growing property interests.

Stephen Short also owns property in his own right particularly in the Cardiff Bay area. He bought a 13-acre plot there four years ago for £750,000. Since then, the area has boomed and the value of this investment is likely to have at least doubled. With other properties, it is possible that his wealth could be boosted by £150,000 per year in rent. If he were to sell all his assets today they could add a further £3m to his value.

Those who have met Short describe him as a soberly dressed man of 5ft 7ins with mousy blond hair parted to one side. 'To look at him, you'd never consider him rich,' one source said. Although polite and considered 'a bit of a thinker', in meetings he is known to have temper tantrums if things don't go according to plan.

17. Andrew Foyle, 28

Software developer. £10 million.

If you have read any of the millions of words written about how in the future you will use your mobile phone to connect to the internet then you will understand why Andrew Foyle's Argo Interactive has been valued by a consortium of venture capitalists at £50m.

It is developing the software that will link the phone to cyberspace. And that is valuable to the mobile phone companies and almost every other internet venture in the world. It is the current technology Holy Grail - there are 20 million people in the UK with mobile phones as opposed to only five million with PCs at home - to get more people to use the net. In the overheated world of the internet, Foyle is right when he says, 'we are a hot company in a hot space'.

Like others on this list, Foyle never made it to college. A year off between school and university became permanent. 'Business just took over.' He set up Argo four years ago and last month hired an experienced chief executive to take over from him while he became president of the firm. He has also reduced his stake in the company from 50 to 10 per cent to get a cash injection from investors 3i and Apax Partners. But he is philosophical: 'I'd rather have a small piece in a very big company than a big part in a small company.'

His new job as president - it is his role to 'evangelise on behalf of the company' - means he is looking for a flat in London. But he will spend most of his time commuting from the home in Chichester he shares with girlfriend Susan, a TV production assistant.

19 and 20. Emma Edelson, 25 and Robert Jenkin, 22

Internet investors. £9 million each.

Emma Edelson typifies many of the new breed of entrepreneurs blending youthful enthusiasm with the ability to secure access to money and contacts, often gained through familial ties. Edelson, 25, is one of four twentysomethings who founded Oxygen. It's an internet incubator fund which buys a chunk in a start-up company, develops it and then floats it on the stock market, thus capitalising on the original investment.

If the Edelson name sounds familiar, it will be because of her father Michael, the Manchester United director and City deal-maker, who hit the headlines last year when one of the companies he chairs, Knutsford, saw its share price soar from 2p to 232p in one day.

He masterminded a similarly dramatic flotation for his daughter's company and provided her with access to financial backing, thanks to his well-developed network of City contacts. But it will be Edelson junior and her three co-fund managers - Robert Jenkin, 22, Paul Harris, 24, and Kirsti Pinnell, 25 - who call the shots. Emma Edelson and Jenkin, who previously worked for a venture capital firm, got the idea to launch Oxygen while at university together. 'We knew how difficult it was to find funding for good ideas,' she says.

Emma Edelson, along with Jenkin, has a 6.5 per cent stake in Oxygen, giving both a paper fortune of £9m. Harris and Pinnel have smaller stakes and so are not featured on the list. The company floated on the Alternative Investment Market last month when its shares were worth 2p. The share price rose as high as 65p during February although settled down around 37p.

So far Oxygen has taken stakes in five companies including Toyzone, the online toy store, and Yellow Turtle, an investors information company, but it is currently looking at more than 30 other opportunities. Notable backers of the company include Manchester United Chief Executive Martin Edwards and football pundit Alan Hansen.

Edelson previously worked for the sports marketing company International Management Group. Ironically one of her responsibilities was to help sell sponsorship for the Millennium Dome. She will be hoping that buying stakes in start-up companies will not be so difficult.

But he will spend most of his time commuting from the home in Chichester he shares with girlfriend Susan, a TV production assistant. 19 and 20. Emma Edelson, 25 and Robert Jenkin, 22 Internet investors. £9 million each. Emma Edelson typifies many of the new breed of entrepreneurs blending youthful enthusiasm with the ability to secure access to money and contacts, often gained through familial ties. Edelson, 25, is one of four twentysomethings who founded Oxygen. It's an internet incubator fund which buys a chunk in a start-up company, develops it and then floats it on the stock market, thus capitalising on the original investment. If the Edelson name sounds familiar, it will be because of her father Michael, the Manchester United director and City deal-maker, who hit the headlines last year when one of the companies he chairs, Knutsford, saw its share price soar from 2p to 232p in one day. He masterminded a similarly dramatic flotation for his daughter's company and provided her with access to financial backing, thanks to his well-developed network of City contacts. But it will be Edelson junior and her three co-fund managers - Robert Jenkin, 22, Paul Harris, 24, and Kirsti Pinnell, 25 - who call the shots. Emma Edelson and Jenkin, who previously worked for a venture capital firm, got the idea to launch Oxygen while at university together. 'We knew how difficult it was to find funding for good ideas,' she says. Emma Edelson, along with Jenkin, has a 6.5 per cent stake in Oxygen, giving both a paper fortune of £9m. Harris and Pinnel have smaller stakes and so are not featured on the list. The company floated on the Alternative Investment Market last month when its shares were worth 2p. The share price rose as high as 65p during February although settled down around 37p. So far Oxygen has taken stakes in five companies including Toyzone, the online toy store, and Yellow Turtle, an investors information company, but it is currently looking at more than 30 other opportunities. Notable backers of the company include Manchester United Chief Executive Martin Edwards and football pundit Alan Hansen. Edelson previously worked for the sports marketing company International Management Group. Ironically one of her responsibilities was to help sell sponsorship for the Millennium Dome. She will be hoping that buying stakes in start-up companies will not be so difficult.

webTitle: First the rains and now the famine as food lorries sink into quagmire

fields.headline: First the rains and now the famine as food lorries sink into quagmire
fields.standfirst: Burhan Wazir  in Beira rides shotgun in a relief lorry as it battles through mud and the musky stench of decay in Mozambique
fields.trailText: Burhan Wazir  in Beira rides shotgun in a relief lorry as it battles through mud and the musky stench of decay in Mozambique
fields.body:
A convoy only goes as fast as its slowest ship. Faqir is chin-deep in water, horizontal below the chassis of his aged aid lorry.

He crawls out, his face streaked with oil and dries himself with a rag. Rising water starts to flood his cabin. He shrugs. 'We will be stuck here. You have blanket?'

This is the daily reality of aid in Mozambique. An army of old vehicles has been hired locally to deliver growing stocks of aid flown by international armed forces from airports in Maputo and Beira to the stricken countryside. But the distribution of the supplies involves a tortuous journey and an agonising delay.

Faqir spends another half-hour trying to revive the engine. Finally, in desperation, he strikes a hammer against the fuel line. The engine rumbles into life. He sets off again - on the road from Vilangulu to Save, where around 20,000 refugees are gathered in makeshift camps.

The journey from Maputo so far hasn't been easy. The small tourist haven for visiting South Africans is a mere 400 miles away from Maputo. But supplies obtained by Save the Children languished there in a storeroom last weekend. Last Monday, the Belgian plane scheduled to deliver the goods was re-routed to Pretoria; on Tuesday, the pilots complained of exhaustion.

'It's very difficult getting supplies around the countryside,' says Roy Trivedi, Save the Children's representative in Mozambique. 'There's isn't enough transportation to begin with - and there's no point in dropping food off at a remote point if there aren't any lorries. Sometimes, the whole thing seems to work against you.'

Last Thursday afternoon, the US military machine flew into Beira Airport, two weeks overdue. Three Black Hawk helicopters rolled across the skies. Below on the tarmac Major-General Joe Wehrle towered over the huddled cameramen and pronounced, with almost religious zeal: 'This is a fight against Mother Nature, and sometimes nature wins. But we are here now - as soon as Mozambique's government asked us. Now it's time to get to work.'

But the helicopters are only the first link in the chain. Most of the roads this far from the capital are impassable. And none of the international armed forces operating in the country - the Americans, British, French, South Africans and Germans - has thought to bring with them engineers who might have helped keep the spatchcock trucks on the road.

In Save, planeloads of food remain undistributed - and a small army of lorries struggles to cover the still flooded terrain. The road from Vilangulu is dotted with potholes; large sections of the concrete have been washed away. And while the water has receded in recent days, some sections of the road remain flooded. Faqir slowly navigates the lorry through neighbouring fields to avoid being stranded.

By mid-afternoon, it has started to rain heavily and visibility is down to five metres. The supplies - exposed in the open-top back - are starting to get wet. Faqir stops by a local farm where he procures a waterproof sheet to protect them. Three hours into the journey from Vilangulu, only five miles have been covered.

The lorry has no windows, and the rain begins to seep through into the cab and onto the floor. Down below the doorway on the passenger's side, water from the road rises through a gash on the floor. All three rear view mirrors are missing, and the speedometer permanently reads 70mph. 'This is my lorry,' says Faqir proudly. 'Only one in town.'

On the outskirts of Eseve, a small township, he stops the lorry in the middle of the street. Ahead, a lioness and three cubs are zigzagging across the concrete. Half an hour passes before the animals saunter off into the trees on the left.

There are no telephone lines between Vilangulu and Save and no way for a driver to alert relief workers of delays. Last week, Faqir's lorry tumbled into a ditch and he spent the night in the driver's seat. Villagers helped him rescue his vehicle the next morning. 'This road is very dangerous,' he says. But he has a wide-eyed confidence in his vehicle. 'Truck is 30 years old,' he says. 'Always gets there.'

The afternoon passes to early evening. At a little past 6pm the road ahead disappears below the waterline. It's still raining heavily and people run for higher ground.

A clutch of houses on the right is still flooded from a week ago and only the conical straw roofs are visible above the water. A cow lies dead on the grassy embankment, its legs pointing skywards. A musky stench of decaying carcasses and rotting crops fills the air.

After midnight, the truck slows outside Save; Faqir glides it down a small hillside into a clearing. As a Portuguese rescue team starts unloading the tents and medical equipment with the help of local missionaries, Faqir stands wringing his clothes. He accepts coffee from a local mission, 'Jesus Alive!', and watches his truck being emptied.

The refugees view the supplies with caution. For the past week, they have survived almost solely on military rations left behind by British boat crews. And cholera is on the rise: 12 deaths were recorded yesterday, 10 the day before. They cannot understand why the aid takes so long to come. Every day they watch helicopters flying over their heads on their way to Beira.

It has taken Faqir three days to travel 500 miles. The amenities at Save are threadbare - a tree provides us with the only shelter for the night. Huddles of refugees sleep in similar circumstances: and the volunteers of 'Jesus Alive!' battle against the prospect of more rain to keep the villagers dry. The missionaries distribute what little food they have. Back in Vilangulu, they own a factory that can produce up to 1,000 meals a day. But, as yet, the food hasn't reached Save because there are no lorries.

Next morning, some South African helicopters land at a field nearby. The villagers rush to the pilots, scanning the opened bulk doors for food and medicines. But the Orex choppers are empty of provisions, and the pilots are only on rescue detail.

Tomorrow Faqir will return to Vilangulu as another Belgian carrier lands with more supplies. The journey back to Vilangulu will take him another 10 hours; tomorrow he will return to Save - but even later.

fields.headline: World Wine Web
fields.trailText: Premières Côtes de Bordeaux
fields.body:
Premières Côtes de Bordeaux

What's the bottle? 1997 Château Sauvage, Premières Côtes de Bordeaux

Price and stockist? £5.99, Wine Rack, Bottoms Up, Martha's Vineyard and selected branches of Victoria Wine and Thresher. Call 01707 385000 for nearest stockist.

What's interesting about the wine? Hallelujah! I've finally discovered a really good claret under £6. Fabrice and Anne Néel's delightful red is produced from vineyards overlooking the Garonne river. The Premières Côtes, where Merlot is the dominant grape variety, is often overlooked by claret lovers in favour of fancier appellations in the Médoc and Libournais, especially in lesser years such as 1997. Given the silly prices charged for some top 1997s, this is really good value, too.

What does the wine smell and taste like? Like the best clarets this wine achieves its effect through subtlety and balance. On the nose, it has notes of autumn leaves, lead pencils and fresh blackcurrants, with no oak to get in the way. On the palate, the wine is medium-bodied with excellent harmony between fruit, tannin and acidity. It finishes with a refreshing lift of acidity and medium-weight tannins. It should appeal to lovers of Old and New World wines.

What does it go with? Meat, especially roasts, and cheese. This is a perfect Sunday-lunch wine

Serving temperature? 16-18 C. You can afford to chill this slightly.

Will it keep? Fine for a year or two, and possibly longer, but it's really good now.

What are we tasting next? 1999 35 Sur Sauvignon Blanc, Vina San Pedro (£4.49, Sainsbury's; Safeway; Asda; Morrison's; Waitrose)

fields.headline: Better by half
fields.standfirst: The Midi has long been known as France's source of cheap and potent 'petits vins', but planting better grapes means that other regions can now expect the headaches
fields.trailText: The Midi has long been known as France's source of cheap and potent 'petits vins', but planting better grapes means that other regions can now expect the headaches
fields.body:
Will the south of France ever produce great wines? To a producer in Bordeaux, Burgundy or Champagne, the question would seem absurd - like asking a Brit if Chris Evans would make a good director general of the BBC (don't bet against it, folks). The Languedoc-Roussillon, otherwise known as the Midi, is the largest wine region in France. It is responsible for 7 per cent of the world's vino, but is usually dismissed by the French as a source of 'petits vins'.

Such a patronising attitude is understandable in one sense. As you'd expect from an area dominated by traditional co-operatives, the Midi churns out a lot of high-octane dross. The stuff you buy in plastic bottles from French supermarkets, which leaves your head feeling as if it's been thumped with a baseball bat, is nearly all produced here. The co-ops in Fitou, Saint Chinian, Rieux, Carcassonne and Limoux are brilliant operations, but they are the exceptions. Nearly all the best wines are made by individual producers.

Laziness and a sense of inferiority continue to undermine the Midi's potential. But that's only part of the story. The past 10 years have seen a transformation that's every bit as impressive as Clark Kent's cape-and-underpants switch in a phone box. The region has always produced a few good wines, most notably in Banyuls and the winningly named La Clape, but the number has multiplied tenfold since the early 1990s. Finally, you can understand why the Greeks and Romans rated the place so highly.

The Midi's resurrection has taken two forms. The first is a new generation of varietal wines - that is wines labelled with the name of grape, such as Chardonnay and Cabernet Sauvignon - and sold as Vins de Pays d'Oc. The second is a massive improvement in the quality of its appellation wines. The local authorities have encouraged the planting of better grapes, especially Syrah, and sought to eliminate the ones that make plonk, particularly Cinsault and younger vineyards of Carignan.

I used to think that varietal wines were the Midi's best bet. These would enable France to compete with the New World on its own simplified terms. But after a visit to Vinisud, a huge fair dedicated to the wines of the southern Europe, I've changed my mind. There are some very good Chardonnays, Merlots and Viogniers being produced in the Midi, but the really exciting wines are blended reds from the top appellations.

The names to look out for are Corbières, Faugères, Saint Chinian, Costières de Nîmes, Collioure, Coteaux du Languedoc and especially its sub-appellation Pic Saint Loup. This area to the north of Montpellier is doubly appealing. I know of few places that are wilder or more beautiful. And when it comes to the wines, I find it hard to tether my enthusiasm. The 1998 vintage was outstanding in the south of France, but notably so in Pic Saint Loup. The complexity of these wines is remarkable; at £8 or less they are incredibly cheap.

If you're looking to buy wines that will give you enormous pleasure and keep for another decade or more, forget about Bordeaux and Burgundy in 1998. Unlike the Midi, both these areas had no more than average harvests. If I were a producer in either region, I'd keep quiet about 'petits vins' from now on.

fields.headline: Eat your greens
fields.standfirst: Mother was right, purple sprouting and spring leaves are good for you and good to eat
fields.trailText: Mother was right, purple sprouting and spring leaves are good for you and good to eat
fields.body:
The wait for the asparagus season is interminable. As much as I love a jumble of woody parsnips, frozen leeks and carrots as fat as your arm in a winter soup, I cannot help but bemoan the cook's lot at this time of year. I am sick of cauliflower, have had my fill of roast onions, and let's face it, artichoke soup is only funny once or twice a year, even when the charming honey-coloured tubers are peeled and simmered with chicken stock then whizzed to a velvet purée with Jersey cream and a whole handful of emerald parsley. It is enough to make a man eat mangetout.

I cannot pretend I enjoy vegetable shopping so early in the spring. But it has to be done, otherwise it's frozen peas again or some of Holland's insipid offerings. (I once asked a Dutch cook why none of her countryfolk ever wrote to me berating my attacks on Dutch fruit and vegetables. 'Because most of us agree with you,' came the reply). So let us say my heart wasn't exactly racing on my way to the market yesterday. In fact, I dawdled all the way, taking in every book shop and estate agent's window and even stopping for a cup of coffee en route. I suspect this is not how anyone should go shopping for food, least of all someone who actually sees greed as a good thing.

There, in among the beige and grey so typical of any food market in March, was an entire stall of glorious greens. A trestle table piled high with vivid, punchy cabbages and rich, sea-green spring leaves. There were metre-long stalks of sprouts for you to snap off your own Brussels one by one. A mound of cabbages as tight as a clenched fist. A small mountain of elegant purple leaves. There were frilly Savoys with their bloom of dusky blue, and boxes of round white cabbage almost hard enough to be considered an offensive weapon.

Best of all, there was purple spouting with long blue-green leaves and tight heads of deepest purple. I do regard this as poor man's asparagus, but only just. The long spears, some measuring almost a foot long, are both tender and juicy and cooked in a couple of minutes. I dunk mine into hollandaise, just as I will the asparagus when it comes. It is good, blissfully good, to eat purple sprouting this way, but there is more than pure pleasure here. Everyone from Popeye to the hottest nutritionist in town will tell you how good greens are for you. So much do they bang on about the goodness of broccoli I cannot help but wonder if they have shares in the stuff.

Back in the kitchen, I would be happy enough with my greens lightly steamed and quickly buttered, but I really cannot see why anything so good should stay at the side of the plate. Thin-leaved cabbages can be almost as tender as spinach, so I roll up the washed leaves and shred them as fine as angel hair then dunk them into hot, clear soup, perhaps with a few little stars of pasta. Anything thicker, or leaves that take easier to coarse chopping, get steamed first for a minute or two then stirred into rich bean soup-stews. Hard white cabbage can take quite a bit of cooking, and I tend to stick it in earlier than I would any of the dark-green varieties. It is marvellous in one of those slow-cooked soups with beans and ham hocks.

Bacon and pork have an almost mythical affinity with greens, even something as straight forward as a stir-fry with bacon gets my vote, but I think we can do even better than that. Last night I threw some purple sprouting into my pasta to make a supper that managed to marry the healthy veg to a rather obscene amount of cream. And for lunch today I folded some dressed Cromer crab into fine strands of steamed cabbage to give an admittedly spartan but clean-tasting lunch.

The best part of a Chinese meal is when I remember to order the greens in oyster sauce. Likewise the Sunday roast, which can seem almost pointless without its neat pile of buttered cabbage. A side order of greens somehow brings the whole meal together. The clincher. And while no one could ever accuse me of believing in the British system of meat and two veg, I would feel cheated without something leafy next to meat and gravy.

I see nothing wrong with the old-fashioned mum's way of cooking greens, then squeezing them between two plates to get rid of any excess water then tossing them in melted butter. I would add an almost invisible grating of nutmeg and some black pepper, too, but I do think this method produces wonderfully silky, buttery greens. A squirt of lemon juice in there wouldn't hurt, either.

Could I make a plea for Brussels sprout tops, too? They look, for those who have never come across them, like miniature Savoy cabbages and are pure melt-in-the-mouth vegetables when steamed and buttered. I cannot recommend steaming greens too highly. Just dump the shredded greens in a colander over a pot of boiling water and they are ready in minutes. A shake of soy sauce is as much embellishment as they need. There is something about a cabbage leaf or stem of sprouting that hasn't seen water that makes you think it is even better for you.

But we are in search of pleasure rather than health here, so yes, it is lush and perky greens for supper, but hopefully not without a little hollandaise sauce to tide us through till the asparagus is ready.

Penne with purple sprouting and cream

I have done this recipe with workaday green broccoli, too, and it was fine. A great quick weekday supper. Serves two.

275g penne or similar shaped dried pasta

250g purple sprouting broccoli

30g butter

2 cloves of garlic, peeled and thinly sliced

4 anchovy fillets, rinsed and chopped

150ml double cream

50g freshly grated Parmesan

Put two deep pans of water on to boil. Trim the purple sprouting, keeping the leaves intact and trimming any dry ends or tough stalks. Salt the water heavily in one of the pans and drop in the pasta, turning the heat down slightly once it has come back to the boil.

Salt the water in the other pan and add the purple sprouting. As soon as the sprouting is tender, a matter of four or five minutes, drain it and wipe out the pan, returning it to the heat with the butter, garlic and anchovies. Let the garlic and anchovies cook slowly for a minute or two then pour in the cream and bring to the boil, immediately turning it down to a slow bubble. Chop the purple sprouting roughly then add it to the cream and season with black pepper.

Drain the pasta and tip it into the broccoli sauce. Fold in the Parmesan cheese.

Spring cabbage with garlic and soy

Straightforward, sassy greens to serve on the side. Serves two as a side dish.

200g spring greens

groundnut or vegetable oil

2 plump, juicy garlic cloves

dark soy sauce

Wash the leaves then tear them up, or shred them with a large knife into manageable pieces.

Heat a couple of tablespoons of oil in a wok or large pan, just enough to cover the bottom of the pan. When it is hot and slightly shimmering, squash the garlic cloves then add them to the oil. Their job is to scent the oil, nothing more.

When the oil is crackling and bubbling around the garlic, toss in the greens. There will be an almighty spit and crackle. The smell of garlic will rise up. Cook them for about four minutes, moving them round with chopsticks (it makes not the slightest difference what you use, but chopsticks will make you feel the part), until they have wilted and their colour is bright.

1 tsp groundnut oil

As much as I love a jumble of woody parsnips, frozen leeks and carrots as fat as your arm in a winter soup, I cannot help but bemoan the cook's lot at this time of year. I am sick of cauliflower, have had my fill of roast onions, and let's face it, artichoke soup is only funny once or twice a year, even when the charming honey-coloured tubers are peeled and simmered with chicken stock then whizzed to a velvet purée with Jersey cream and a whole handful of emerald parsley. It is enough to make a man eat mangetout. I cannot pretend I enjoy vegetable shopping so early in the spring. But it has to be done, otherwise it's frozen peas again or some of Holland's insipid offerings. (I once asked a Dutch cook why none of her countryfolk ever wrote to me berating my attacks on Dutch fruit and vegetables. 'Because most of us agree with you,' came the reply). So let us say my heart wasn't exactly racing on my way to the market yesterday. In fact, I dawdled all the way, taking in every book shop and estate agent's window and even stopping for a cup of coffee en route. I suspect this is not how anyone should go shopping for food, least of all someone who actually sees greed as a good thing. There, in among the beige and grey so typical of any food market in March, was an entire stall of glorious greens. A trestle table piled high with vivid, punchy cabbages and rich, sea-green spring leaves. There were metre-long stalks of sprouts for you to snap off your own Brussels one by one. A mound of cabbages as tight as a clenched fist. A small mountain of elegant purple leaves. There were frilly Savoys with their bloom of dusky blue, and boxes of round white cabbage almost hard enough to be considered an offensive weapon. Best of all, there was purple spouting with long blue-green leaves and tight heads of deepest purple. I do regard this as poor man's asparagus, but only just. The long spears, some measuring almost a foot long, are both tender and juicy and cooked in a couple of minutes. I dunk mine into hollandaise, just as I will the asparagus when it comes. It is good, blissfully good, to eat purple sprouting this way, but there is more than pure pleasure here. Everyone from Popeye to the hottest nutritionist in town will tell you how good greens are for you. So much do they bang on about the goodness of broccoli I cannot help but wonder if they have shares in the stuff. Back in the kitchen, I would be happy enough with my greens lightly steamed and quickly buttered, but I really cannot see why anything so good should stay at the side of the plate. Thin-leaved cabbages can be almost as tender as spinach, so I roll up the washed leaves and shred them as fine as angel hair then dunk them into hot, clear soup, perhaps with a few little stars of pasta. Anything thicker, or leaves that take easier to coarse chopping, get steamed first for a minute or two then stirred into rich bean soup-stews. Hard white cabbage can take quite a bit of cooking, and I tend to stick it in earlier than I would any of the dark-green varieties. It is marvellous in one of those slow-cooked soups with beans and ham hocks. Bacon and pork have an almost mythical affinity with greens, even something as straight forward as a stir-fry with bacon gets my vote, but I think we can do even better than that. Last night I threw some purple sprouting into my pasta to make a supper that managed to marry the healthy veg to a rather obscene amount of cream. And for lunch today I folded some dressed Cromer crab into fine strands of steamed cabbage to give an admittedly spartan but clean-tasting lunch. The best part of a Chinese meal is when I remember to order the greens in oyster sauce. Likewise the Sunday roast, which can seem almost pointless without its neat pile of buttered cabbage. A side order of greens somehow brings the whole meal together. The clincher. And while no one could ever accuse me of believing in the British system of meat and two veg, I would feel cheated without something leafy next to meat and gravy. I see nothing wrong with the old-fashioned mum's way of cooking greens, then squeezing them between two plates to get rid of any excess water then tossing them in melted butter. I would add an almost invisible grating of nutmeg and some black pepper, too, but I do think this method produces wonderfully silky, buttery greens. A squirt of lemon juice in there wouldn't hurt, either. Could I make a plea for Brussels sprout tops, too? Just dump the shredded greens in a colander over a pot of boiling water and they are ready in minutes. A shake of soy sauce is as much embellishment as they need. There is something about a cabbage leaf or stem of sprouting that hasn't seen water that makes you think it is even better for you. webTitle: Cruelty case leads to call for new law

fields.headline: Cruelty case leads to call for new law
fields.trailText: Paul Whitehouse, the Chief Constable of Sussex Police, has called for a change in the law after a Brighton couple escaped conviction for the deaths of three children in their care. The couple, who cannot be named for legal reasons, were tried for murder in July of last year.
fields.body:
Paul Whitehouse, the Chief Constable of Sussex Police, has called for a change in the law after a Brighton couple escaped conviction for the deaths of three children in their care. The couple, who cannot be named for legal reasons, were tried for murder in July of last year.

The case was abandoned when the judge, Mr Justice Moses, ruled that as the prosecution could not prove which of them had been responsible for the killings, or whether they had acted together, neither could be convicted. Proceedings against the couple for cruelty and neglect of one of the dead babies, and four surviving children concluded last week with guilty verdicts. It is regarded by experts as one of the worst cases of child neglect they have ever come across.

'The existing state of the law appears to be unsatisfactory,' said Whitehouse. 'We have three people in a room. Two adults come out alive and a child is dead. How can it be right that you cannot convict either of them if they stay silent or blame each other?'

One proposal is that the burden of proof in such trials falls to the defendant, as it does now in cases of receiving stolen property, where the suspect must explain how they came by the goods. Under the plan it would be up to the defendants in a murder trial, where a baby died and there were no witnesses, to explain what happened.

Whitehouse's call is being supported by local MP Des Turner, the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children and the Association of Chief Police Officers.

fields.headline: King's highway
fields.standfirst:
After his horrifying road accident, the world's most prolific author was written off. Now he's back and his new book is being launched on the internet

www.stephenking.com
fields.trailText: After his horrifying road accident, the world's most prolific author was written off. Now he's back and his new book is being launched on the internet
fields.body:
Following Stephen King's car accident in June 1999, the publishing world was understandably concerned about the output of the 'world's best-selling novelist'. Between August last year, when he returned to writing after an intense period of surgery and recuperation, and January of this year, King had only managed to complete a novella, some short stories, a memoir-cum-how-to-write book and the early stages of a TV mini-series. Clearly, by his own standards of performance, he was in the paralysing grip of writer's block.

The affliction has cropped up periodically in King's fiction - most notably in The Shining (which, paradoxically, he wrote in a month) and Bag of Bones - but a difficulty with writing words is not something the author has had much experience of in reality. This week sees his 30th novel, Riding the Bullet , which, in a possible foretaste of the future, will be published solely on the Internet. He has also produced six novels under his pseudonym, Richard Bachman, as well as 14 other books including short-story collections and non-fiction. Then there are the 27 movie adaptations, nine of which he has scripted, and the eight TV films and mini-series. For some time, he even replied personally to his fan mail.

The novels, it should be mentioned, are infrequently slim volumes. It , for example, weighed in at 1,138 pages, and more often than not his macabre tomes can double as exercise aids. As he once put it: 'I write like fat ladies diet.' He types away at a rate of 750,000 words a year, every year since 1974, when Carrie , his debut, unleashed the geysers of blood and gore that have filled King's distinctive vision of American suburbia.

But that's enough critical analysis. His is the kind of literary success that requires discussion in terms of numbers rather than words. He has, after all, sold 300 million books. His publishers, Simon and Schuster, could be forgiven, then, for beginning to wonder if the well has run dry. Especially as they recently signed a £30 million three-book deal with King. Riding the Bullet is apparently part of the package. It is also just 69 pages long - the kind of entertainment that the master of horror formerly took all of a fortnight to knock out.

Even before the accident, King was suggesting that he was running out of words, prompting speculation that he might be down to his last million. 'A writer has only a finite number of stories to write,' he said in 1998. 'I think I'm very near the end of publishing my work.'

In the wake of the crash, he has sounded still more pessimistic about his literary future. 'Maybe there'll be another book, maybe there won't. I'm more concerned with walking again without crutches.'

Of the accident itself, commentators and fans were quick to point out its uncanny resemblance to King's own fiction: car crashes feature in Misery , in which a writer is crippled, and Pet Sematry . But the real-life outcome was more reminiscent of JG Ballard's work. King suffered a shattered hip and pelvis, broken ribs and a fractured thigh bone, all of which needed six operations. 'My entire waist was turned around sideways and I could see this bulge in the side of my jeans,' he later deadpanned. 'And I thought to myself, "If that's a bone, I'm in trouble here."'

The injuries were the result of a collision with a Dodge Caravan. King was walking close to his summer home in North Lovell, Maine, when the car came off the road and hit him. The driver turned out to be wrestling with his rottweiller, named Bullet, at the time of impact. Incredibly, despite a long record of driving offences, the motorist had his license revoked for just one year.

Embittered, King did a very Ballardian thing. He bought the Dodge for $1,600 and announced that he intended to 'beat the hell out of it' with a sledgehammer, if and when he regained his fitness. He had originally taken up his daily walk to lose weight. Since the accident, his 6ft 3in frame has shrunk by three stone.

Now 52, King had for many years retained an almost teenage geekiness, enhanced by a mop-top haircut, conspicuous front-teeth and thick glasses, as well as a weakness for jeans and hard rock music. Suddenly, however, frail and wearied, he looks his age, if not older. 'He genuinely thought he was going to die,' said his friend, the humourist Dave Barry.

Perhaps lucky to be alive, King has not always enjoyed the most auspicious of breaks. When he was two, his father stepped out to buy a packet of cigarettes and was never heard from again (although his mother thought she spotted him in a Sixties newsreel about white mercenaries in the Congo). He was a sickly child, once bedridden for a year, and his mother struggled to look after him and his brother, as she travelled around the country looking for work and family support.

A bright student, he gained a degree in English from the University of Maine, in whose library he met his wife, Tabitha. After college, he subsidised teaching work with a job as a labourer in a laundry. He and Tabitha lived in a trailer in a town called called Hermon, Maine. King once described it as 'if not the asshole of the universe, then at least within farting distance of it'.

It was here, with two children to look after, that he had four novels turned down by publishers. His fifth, he consigned to the waste bin, after further refusals, only for his wife to retrieve it and encourage him to persevere. Eventually, in 1973, Doubleday sent him a $2,500 acceptance cheque for Carrie . Two months later, still living in his trailer, he learned that the paperback rights had been bought for $420,000. He was so stunned that he went straight out and bought his wife a present: a $29 hairdryer. Shortly afterwards, his mother died of cancer, never really getting to see, still less benefit from, her son's phenomenal success.

In 1988, King joined Alcoholics Anonymous. 'I have a totally addictive personality,' he admitted. 'I've never met a drink or a drug I don't like.' In particular, he had developed an intensely fond relationship with cocaine. Seemingly, it was not enough that he was he getting through three quarter of a million words a year, he also found time to nurture not one but two debilitating dependencies.

Far more of his vast fortune - he was estimated to have earned £53 million in 1997 alone - has gone on philanthropy, however, than pharmaceuticals. He has donated large sums to his alma mater, runs a number of libraries, bought two local radio stations that were in jeopardy, and built a baseball park for kids, among an impressive number of other charitable causes he supports. Exactly why King has been so productive he has never been able to explain. Occasionally he hints that writing channels the demons that otherwise could grow sociopathically destructive. But the suspicion remains that he simply loves telling stories. The ideas, he says, come 'like phone calls from nowhere'.

What is clear is that the sheer mass of words has served to crush critical appreciation. Unlike, say, Thomas Harris, a populist whose three novels have won literary acclaim, the prolific King is not seen in smart circles as an innovator, so much as an industry.

Yet it is King who has taken the first steps into the electronic age, just as he helped pioneer audio books (his short story collection Blood and Smoke was only released on tape) and revived the serialised novel with The Green Mile (published in instalments). The media conglomerates that nowadays control publishing houses will be studying the response to Riding The Bullet , which will be available to download from midnight on Monday at a cost of $2.50. At the same time, King's obsessive army of fans will be hoping that Bullet - the restless rottweiller - has not left their hero with nothing more to say.

Stephen Edwin King

Born: Portland, Maine, 1947

AKA: Richard Bachman

Family: Wife Tabitha Spruce; one daughter (Naomi Rachel), two sons (Joe Hill, Owen Phillip)

Studied: University of Maine (English)

Latest work: Riding the Bullet (published on the Internet)

Other works: Carrie , The Green Mile , Misery, Pet Sematary , The Shining

Website: www.stephenking.com

webTitle: Encryption bill has to be last straw

fields.headline: Encryption bill has to be last straw
fields.trailText: The Networker
fields.body:
Imagine: it's a dark night, and you are trying to get some cash from an ATM machine. Suddenly you notice a large figure in uniform behind you. Distracted, you mistype your PIN number. The machine demands you type it again, so you do - and collect your money.

Then the figure puts his hand on your shoulder and you discover he's a policeman. A large, unfriendly policeman. He says he has reason to suspect you are up to no good and demands that you tell him your PIN number. You refuse or, in the confusion, you can't remember it.

Before you know what's happening you've been arrested and are standing before a judge. The charge? Failing to disclose your PIN number to a duly authorised person. The fact that you cannot remember it is no defence. It is assumed that you were up to no good - unless you can prove to the contrary. You are sent down for two years.

Unbelievable? Couldn't happen in a liberal democracy? Well, I have news for you.

Last week Jack Straw, New Labour's avuncular Interior Minister, introduced a Bill into the Commons which aims to create an analogous situation in relation to data encryption. A PIN number is analogous to a cryptographic key such as you might use to protect your email - or confidential files on your hard disk - from prying eyes. The Regulation of Investigatory Powers Bill gives Mr Straw the power to demand you decrypt data on demand. Failing to provide the key will be a criminal offence, with a maximum penalty of two years in jail, and carries with it the presumption of guilt. You must somehow prove you do not have the key. That you may have mislaid or forgotten it will not be a defence.

And if, having suffered a miscarriage of justice under this statute, you decide to complain in public, 'Liberal Jack' has another ace up his sleeve - you can be sent down for a further five years!

Meanwhile, paedophiles and criminals, who really do have appalling stuff on their disks and in their emails, will keep their mouths shut and take the two years for refusing to decrypt on demand. After all, it's a better deal than doing five to 10 years for a really serious offence.

There is more.

The Bill requires UK Internet Service Providers to install systems which will allow Secretary Straw and his duly authorised goons to track subscribers' communications traffic. That means every email you send - and every reply you receive, plus information on every website you've visited, every book you've bought from Amazon, every air-ticket you've purchased, every piece of software you've ever downloaded. And if you have encrypted your communications - well, see the last paragraph, but one above.

On what grounds might the Interior Ministry justify such an invasion of your privacy? Here's a list from Section 20 of the Bill: national security (not defined, of course); preventing or detecting crime; preventing disorder; public safety; protecting public health.

Oh, and Mr Straw can lawfully authorise electronic snooping 'in the interests of the economic well-being of the United Kingdom'.

Imagine how that last justification will play with foreign businesses wondering whether to set up in e-commerce in the UK. And then ponder the fact that the official line is to make the UK the most e-friendly state in Europe by 2002. Joined-up government, my eye.

Meanwhile, the Irish government is legislating to make it illegal even for it to snoop on Internet traffic, so if this Bill makes it to the Statute book we can all move to Irish ISPs.

I wonder what Secretary Straw will do about that?

john.naughton@observer.co.uk

Couldn't happen in a liberal democracy? Well, I have news for you. Last week Jack Straw, New Labour's avuncular Interior Minister, introduced a Bill into the Commons which aims to create an analogous situation in relation to data encryption. A PIN number is analogous to a cryptographic key such as you might use to protect your email - or confidential files on your hard disk - from prying eyes. The Regulation of Investigatory Powers Bill gives Mr Straw the power to demand you decrypt data on demand. Failing to provide the key will be a criminal offence, with a maximum penalty of two years in jail, and carries with it the presumption of guilt. You must somehow prove you do not have the key. That you may have mislaid or forgotten it will not be a defence. And if, having suffered a miscarriage of justice under this statute, you decide to complain in public, 'Liberal Jack' has another ace up his sleeve - you can be sent down for a further five years! Meanwhile, paedophiles and criminals, who really do have appalling stuff on their disks and in their emails, will keep their mouths shut and take the two years for refusing to decrypt on demand. After all, it's a better deal than doing five to 10 years for a really serious offence. There is more. The Bill requires UK Internet Service Providers to install systems which will allow Secretary Straw and his duly authorised goons to track subscribers' communications traffic. That means every email you send - and every reply you receive, plus information on every website you've visited, every book you've bought from Amazon, every air-ticket you've purchased, every piece of software you've ever downloaded. And if you have encrypted your communications - well, see the last paragraph, but one above. On what grounds might the Interior Ministry justify such an invasion of your privacy? Here's a list from Section 20 of the Bill: national security (not defined, of course); preventing or detecting crime; preventing disorder; public safety; protecting public health. Oh, and Mr Straw can lawfully authorise electronic snooping 'in the interests of the economic well-being of the United Kingdom'. Imagine how that last justification will play with foreign businesses wondering whether to set up in e-commerce in the UK. And then ponder the fact that the official line is to make the UK the most e-friendly state in Europe by 2002. Joined-up government, my eye. Meanwhile, the Irish government is legislating to make it illegal even for it to snoop on Internet traffic, so if this Bill makes it to the Statute book we can all move to Irish ISPs. I wonder what Secretary Straw will do about that? john.naughton@observer.co.uk  For links and background see www.briefhistory.com/footnotes

fields.headline: Sweden
fields.standfirst: The most wired country in Europe is making heroes of its net entrepreneurs. Sandra Jordon and Tom O'Sullivan look at the impact of the e-commerce boom
fields.trailText: The most wired country in Europe is making heroes of its net entrepreneurs. Sandra Jordon and Tom O'Sullivan look at the impact of the e-commerce boom
fields.body:
Jonas Birgersson is the new Bjorn Borg. He will never play at Wimbledon but for the Swedish public he is as big a hero - and as high profile - as the former tennis champion. Along with other e-commerce entrepreneurs, Birgersson, the founder of the internet consultancy Framfab, is shaping a new identity for Sweden as the internet capital of Europe and the Swedes are enjoying the title.

Sweden is the most wired country in Europe - 64 per cent of people have access to a PC at home compared to just 37 per cent of Brits; 60 per cent of Swedes have internet access compared to 22 per cent in the UK. Sweden"s economic growth rate is 4 per cent, more than double the EU average. Unemployment is down. E-commerce companies such as Framfab go public, as it did last August, and more than 100 employees become millionaires overnight.

"Birgersson and the others are standing for something new," says Mats Anderson of the Dagens Nyheter newspaper, "for the first time, it is the entrepreneurs who are the heroes. Every other day the tabloids are talking about this stock or that company - everybody is so proud of their Swedishness."

But there is a wider debate bubbling under the surface. In liberal Sweden, people are starting to ask whether this is such a good thing. Half the population own shares, and many are doing very well financially. But the other half of the population are not.

"Traditionally in Swedish society everybody earned the same wages but now with the rise of the internet millionaires, society is changing very quickly. The growing debate is about whether we are a more greedy society - one that is losing the solidarity that has always been part of Swedish life," says Anderson.

The debate on the social impact, for the moment at least, is low-key. But the media, until now carried along by the success stories, is starting to ask questions. A television debate last month looked at the impact of the internet boom on the art world and found that galleries are closing.

During the Eighties, art galleries sprang up all over Sweden and the nouveau riche invested heavily in art. The e-commerce revolution has reversed that trend. "Money is going into technology instead of art at the moment," says artist Maria Lindeberg de Geer. "Some galleries are closing. I sell more than I ever did, but I see in my students in the art school that they are going through hell, they don't have galleries and they don't know what to do. We had very many galleries, perhaps too many."

It's not that the entrepreneurs are philistines, more that they don't have the time to invest in art. Ola Ahlvarsson, the founder of Result Venture Knowledge, bears this out. "My table broke and it took me nine months to replace it because I just didn't have the time. So shopping for art would be far-fetched." He believes the artists shouldn't lose heart.

"Instead of complaining that money goes elsewhere, I would work very hard in using internet tools to sell my art to people around the world. If you could go somewhere and see the most interesting art, read about it, contact the artist and ask questions, it would be much easier for stressed modern people (to invest in art)." The surprising thing in Sweden is that nobody has launched such a service already.

Sweden's young rich list

1. Jonas Birgersson, 29

Founder of the internet consultancy Framfab - the largest in Europe -which has an astonishing market capitalisation of £2.5bn only five years after it was launched. Valued at £1.1 billion

2. Jesper Jos Olsson, 26

Original member of the team which launched Icon Medialab which has a market capitalisation of £865m. Valued at £15 million

3,4 and 5. Kajsa Leander, 29 Ernst Malmstein, 28 and Patrik Hedelin, 30

A bit of a cheat because the trio came to the UK to launch boo.com - the online consumer shopping site - but they originally came together to launch a Swedish online bookstore which they sold to fund boo. Valued at £12 million each

6. Ola Ahlvarsson, 29

Founder, Result Venture Knowledge, which invests in e-companies. Valued at £6.6million

fields.headline: Fathers, lovers and family silver
fields.standfirst: Robin Barton explains why some famous names didn't make the list
fields.trailText: Robin Barton explains why some famous names didn't make the list
fields.body:
We have an aristocratic Rothschild. we even have a couple of Rowlands plus another couple of Gestetners. But there is not a single Goldsmith on this list. And there is no Lucas White who inherited from his father - the late co-founder of the Hanson industrial empire - the bulk of a £70m estate. Or Vicky Jaramillo who inherited £25m from her lover, the former Chelsea chairman Matthew Harding, who died in a helicopter crash in 1996.

All are below the age of 30. But while they have inherited pots of money they have not - like the Rowlands and Gestetners - started to use it to re-create the family business empires built up by the likes of Sir James Goldsmith, Lord White or even the much younger Harding, which would have allowed them to gatecrash on to the entrepreneur list. Instead they seem content to get on with spending it.

Zac and Jemima Goldsmith, two of the financier's eight heirs, have fortunes that would be the envy of any self-respecting entrepreneur. The settlement after his death in 1997 divided an estimated £1.5bn fortune among his family. Goldsmith maximised the pot by flying out of France - on his deathbed - to avoid paying inheritance tax. Yet both seem to have rejected their father's corporate legacy. Zac Goldsmith, 24, left Eton before his A-levels and now edits The Ecologist magazine, campaigning, for example, against GM food. "There remains virtually no patch of our country which has been spared the varied horrors of so-called progress," he said recently. Like his sister he has already married and his wife, Sheherazade Ventura, is expecting their first child.

His older and more famous sister, Jemima, married the former Pakistani cricketer Imran Khan, converting to Islam and taking a new name, Haiqa Khan, in the process. Her most notable recent investment was the purchase of a £1m Fulham property - not in itself a minor thing, but hardly in her father's spending league. Equally their friend, the polo-playing Bermudan-resident Lucas White, does not yet show any sign of moving from the newspaper gossip columns, in which he regularly features, into the business pages. There may also appear to be omissions on the elite list. But the list identifies those aristocrats who will inherit money.

There are a handful of aristos who have already inherited by the time they reach 30. The Earl of Iveagh, aged 29, is valued at £2.2bn and Jonathan Harmsworth, head of the Daily Mail Trust, inherited a £1.5bn fortune from his father, aged just 27. But the case of Fred and Victoria Hervey, 20 and 23, who inherited an estimated £30m fortune from their step-brother last year, offers a cautionary note. Their step-brother John Hervey became the seventh Marquess of Bristol in 1985. By the age of 21 he had inherited the family fortune, along with an alcohol problem. However, if he was fond of a drink, then he was passionate about cocaine and devoted to heroin.

By his own estimate, the price of such love was around £7m and a debilitated physique. He was twice arrested for possessing heroin and was jailed for nine months for attempting to smuggle £1,000 worth of cocaine into Jersey. He then became the first peer to be deported from Australia, and later faced more drug charges and driving bans. He died in January 1999 at the age of 44 from a flu virus, complicated by Hepatitis B. The title, minus property, passed to Victoria Hervey's younger brother. Victoria has become classic gossip-column fodder: model, It Girl, girlfriend of restaurateur Mogens Tholstrup. She is now launching a clothes shop in Knightsbridge.
