But the more accurate Inland Revenue Valuation Office figures for land in those counties, plus 30 or so acres in London, yields a figure closer to £700m. He also inherits many millions from Princess Diana, as well as being likely to inherit from his grandmother and his great-grandmother. Highgrove, Prince Charles's country house and estate, will also go to his eldest son, although the organic farming activities probably won't add much in terms of cash income. The experience of his father suggests that the son could have a long wait. 3 Hon Nathaniel Philip Victor Rothschild, 29 Head of family: Lord Rothschild Will inherit £500 million Described by his PR man as a 'shrinking violet', Rothschild junior is the place where old money meets new media. The eldest son of Lord Rothschild has inherited the family's financial acumen and has been made responsible for the family's increasing investment in everything 'net'. Along with the land and art trappings of most aristocrats, the Rothschilds are adding the internet and e-commerce to their empire. In the past four months the Rothschild family has bought an undisclosed stake in New Media Investors, a venture capital company which has pumped money into new media start-ups including lastminute.com. When New Media Investors floated on the Alternative Investment Market in November - after the Rothschilds had bought their stake - the company was valued at £88m. There have been further investments: £3m into the natural health website Clickmango (in conjunction with another venture capitalist); and, with Lord Weinstock, £10m was poured into Star Technology. These investments have propelled Nathaniel Rothschild on to the boards of both New Media Investors and Star Technology to protect his family's interest. The link with New Media Investors came via a mutual friend - at a point when the company was expanding. 'He brings a wealth of contacts,' says a spokesman for NMI, who adds that the Rothschilds definitely 'intend to increase their exposure in this area'. But this is where he displayed his shrinking violet tendencies by declining to discuss the family's e-business interests with The Observer. After schooling at Eton and a history degree at Wadham College - where he was fined £20 for driving a car without an MOT - he joined fund manager Lazard's, then went to work at Gleacher, the corporate finance firm now owned by NatWest. He currently occupies a variety of positions - and holds a 50 per cent stake - in NR Atticus, Atticus Management and Atticus Capital, a hedge fund, which controls funds approaching £312m. During his period in the City he found the time to meet and secretly marry Annabelle Neilson in Las Vegas in a rare show of impetuousness which ended in divorce. His father now describes him as 'an eligible bachelor'. But not a 'shrinking violet'. The Rothschild inheritance is difficult to quantify - not just because of the value of their internet interests. Nathaniel Rothschild will have to share his father's enormous wealth with his three older sisters. However his direct inheritance will include art, land, family companies and institutions plus his father's stake in Rothschild Continuation, the Swiss-based holding company for the Rothschild interests which has stakes in many of the family enterprises, including the bank NM Rothschild. His father has further stakes in three quoted companies: RIT Capital Partners, Value Realisation Trust and St James Place Capital. But behind this wealth there is the actual Rothschild family fortune hidden in a series of trusts in Switzerland and rumoured to be worth £40bn. This will prove to be a conservative valuation of what Nathaniel Rothschild inherits, especially if some of the family's new media investments start to pay off. 4 Hon William Guy Vestey, 17 Head of family: Lord Vestey Will inherit £340 million It was once said of the Vesteys that they lived 'not on the interest built up by their estate but on the interest of the interest'. In those terms life has come unstuck for the family since the collapse of the Vestey empire and the liquidation of the Dewhurst butchers' chain in 1995. But don't shed too many tears - the Vesteys were still left with an estimated £650m, at least half of which belongs to the father of William Guy Vestey. Additionally, they own the 5,000 acres of Stowell Park in Gloucestershire, which, at £3,000 per acre, is valued at £15m. In stark contrast to Vestey (who was Page of Honour to the Queen from 1995 to 1998 - which means he stood around and looked pretty), Mark Brown, his anarchist cousin, and the grandson of Sir Derek Vestey, was charged with masterminding the anti-capitalism march that turned violent in the City of London on June 18 last year. 5 Earl Compton, 27 Head of family: Marquess of Northampton Will inherit £200 million Daniel Bingham, as he is known, has had more stepmothers than most, his father having married five times so far. But that will have little effect on his inheritance. Of more significance could be a legal judgment over ownership of the Sevso hoard of ancient Roman silver which is valued at £40m. When the collection was put up for sale in New York in 1990 the authorities impounded it, and while the family won the legal battle over ownership, buyers have been discouraged as they might be hit later with a further legal challenge. The family owns 5,000 acres of Surrey, plus 25,000 acres in the Midlands, giving a total wealth of £100m in land alone. Aside from the Sevso hoard, Bingham's family has art treasures in both his stately homes, conservatively valued at £100m. But the huge legal costs in establishing ownership of the Sevso treasure - the Hungarian, Lebanese and Yugoslavian governments were among those contesting ownership - and the question over any future sale have lead us to reduce his valuation to £200m. 6 Hon Robert Gascoyne-Cecil, 30 Head of family: Marquess of Salisbury Will inherit £200 million The Cecil family (pronounced like 'thistle', not 'vessel') has been a venerable Tory institution for centuries - during Queen Victoria's reign, one ancestor was three times a prime minister. Last year Robert Gascoyne-Cecil's father - Viscount Cranbourne, one of the more dynamic parents in this list - was sacked as Tory leader in the House of Lords after going over William Hague's head and negotiating the abolition of the hereditary peers directly with Tony Blair. Cranbourne is also a member of a group of Premier Oil shareholders attempting to oust the current management team due to Premier's floundering share price. Their proposals acknowledge the ethical issue of Premier's business in Burma but they propose to sell off the Burmese assets (as well as interests in Pakistan and Indonesia) for financial reasons and because they fear retribution if the Burmese regime falls. The family fortune consists of 3,000 acres in Dorset valued at £9m, 10,000 acres in Hertfordshire worth a further £28.6m plus an unknown quantity of land in London. Some of the Hertfordshire land is development land, worth, according to the Inland Revenue, £850,000 per acre. Treasures going back to Elizabethan times at Hatfield House, the family home, are valued at £100m and there are investments in various trusts. Cranbourne retains his seat in the House of Lords under the life peerage of Lord Gascoyne-Cecil. 7 Viscount Macmillan, 26 Head of family: Earl of Stockton Will inherit £200 million Dan Macmillan is the great-grandson of former Tory prime minister Harold Macmillan but is perhaps better known as Jade Jagger's intermittent boyfriend of two years. She last split up with him on New Year's Eve, citing his incessant nocturnal partying, which, for a Jagger to find excessive, must have been truly heroic. He has had a stab at modelling, acting, art and fashion design, establishing a clothing label, and is now pursuing an interest in photography. But he will not be following his father Alexander Stockton into the family publishing business. Stockton was quietly removed from the chairmanship in 1990 and is currently president - the family sold its majority stake (71 per cent) to German publisher Holtzbrinck back in 1995. Dan Macmillan grew up at Birch Grove, the family home in Sussex (house guests have included John F Kennedy and de Gaulle, but not in the younger Macmillan's memory). Rather, his global social life now revolves around Ibiza and Notting Hill. The family fortune comes in the form of cash from the remaining stake in the Macmillan Group plus a small estate in Devon and property in London. 8 Viscount Lymington, 19 Head of family: Earl of Portsmouth Will inherit £190 million Oliver Wallop's father is better known as one of those who bankrolled Neil Hamilton's failed libel action against Mohamed Al Fayed last December. In a move which suggests he enjoys giving away money to lawyers, Wallop senior also previously supported Count Nikolai Tolstoy's failed legal action in the Eighties. But it will be comforting to his son Oliver Henry Rufus, whose mother is the author Candia McWilliam, that there is plenty of money where the Hamilton and Tolstoy funds came from. The Earl is now married to Annabel Fergusson. The 19-year-old Wallop stands to inherit the family mansion and 3,000 acres near Basingstoke, as well as a stake in the Grainger Trust, his father's property company, and some very valuable art treasures. Based on his previous sales for development, we calculate that five per cent of the estate has development potential, fetching £143m, while the remaining 2,850 acres are worth £8m. The family stake in the Grainger Trust is valued at £12m, while their art treasures are valued in excess of £30m. 9 Hon Jesse David Suenson-Taylor, 23 Head of family: Lord Grantchester Will inherit £176 million Suenson-Taylor's father is the third Lord Grantchester, a rare Labour peer who describes himself as a dairy farmer in Crewe, Cheshire, and is also chairman of a small milk producer, the South West Cheshire Dairy Association. His grandmother, the dowager Lady Grantchester, steered the Littlewoods organisation back on to an even keel after turbulence in the late Eighties and early Nineties. Suenson-Taylor, who maintains a low profile, will inherit an 11 per cent share of the £1.6bn Littlewoods fortune - the basis for this year's valuation. His inheritance has not shrunk by £64m since last year; we have just cleared up confusion over his stake in the Littlewoods family pot. 10 Hon William Boscawen, 21 Head of family: Viscount Falmouth Will inherit £150 million The history of the Boscawens goes back to 1264 and reaches the present via a string of beheadings and rebellions. Now the family are the largest landowners in Cornwall with an estate almost twice the size of Prince Charles's Cornish holdings, with 40,000 acres worth £117m. If just one per cent of the estate is development land (fetching £175,000 in the region), the value shoots up by a further £70m - and the head of the family is well known for the number of planning applications he submits. There is also an estate in Kent. Grandfather, father and son are Etonians and live on, and manage, the estate. The Boscawens still appoint priests of the Church of England in five parishes around the family mansion near Truro.

fields.headline: The young rich entrepreneurs 33-40
fields.trailText: Riath Hamed | Richard Russell | Robert Norton and Tiny Rowland | Peter Atalla, Alan Edmondson and Michael Haycock
fields.body:
33. Riath Hamed, 30

Manager of Prince Naseem Hamed. £3 million.

Riath Hamed has come under increasing scrutiny in the past two years. His brother's skills in the boxing ring have made the Hameds secure for the rest of their lives. But there is a growing impression that Prince Naseem has been sitting on his talent for several years and that he needs to be fighting better opponents - in some quarters Riath has been blamed for not exposing him to those riskier, but long-term, more lucrative fights.

In his defence Riath has said: 'We won't be railroaded into wars.' He says he reluctantly took over control of his brother's business affairs in 1995 - his father had hopes of him becoming a lawyer or doctor - and became manager in 1998. Over the past five years he has been at the centre of negotiations, and fallen out, with most of boxing's big names and also been involved in the jettisoning from the Hamed camp of anyone who was not 'family'. First to go in 1998 was Brendan Ingle, his manager and trainer for 17 years, followed by Frank Warren a year later. The older Hamed is married with two children and lives on the outskirts of Sheffield near his more famous brother and their other seven brothers and sisters, most of whom work in the businesses which have grown out of Naseem's fame. Riath takes less than the traditional manager's 25 per cent. His valuation remains unchanged since last year largely because of the increasingly opaque nature of the Hamed family dealings.

34. Richard Russell, 28

Director, XL Recordings. £3 million.

Richard Russell remained resolutely silent when approached by The Observer. And indeed people within the dance music industry were equally reticent about talking about the 28-year old who has a 24 per cent stake in XL Recordings. Over the past five years XL has grown into the most successful independent dance-music label around. Its early success was built on the phenomenal worldwide success of the Prodigy.

The success story was continued by Basement Jaxx who sold over 200,000 copies of their debut album last year. XL relies on the muscle of the Beggars Banquet Group - its ultimate holding company - for distribution and marketing. 1997 was an exceptionally successful year for XL with huge sales of the Prodigy's Fat of the Land.

The label's most recent financial accounts, to the end of 1997, show that it posted a very healthy pre-tax profit of £5.7m, and paid dividends of £2m, of which Russell would have received about £500,000. The company's assets totalled £6m. The Prodigy have a new album to be released this year - although there is speculation that it may be delayed -- but that will be a further boon to XL and Russell's earnings. On this basis we believe that XL has maintained momentum and profitability and, taking into account his stake in the company, we value Russell at £3m. He clearly feels financially secure, having bought an undisclosed stake in a fellow entrepreneur's label, 25-year old James Lavelle's Mo' Wax.

35 and 36. Robert Norton, 27 and Toby Rowland, 30

Founders, Clickmango. £2.5 million each.

His father, who once owned The Observer, was described as 'the unacceptable face of capitalism' and that was by a former Tory prime minister. But Toby Rowland claims that the ease with which he and Robert Norton secured private funding - they raised £3m within one week - had nothing to do with his famous late father, Tiny Rowland.

If the story sounds unbelievable, it is a line supported by one of the investors in the company which hasn't even launched yet. 'I didn't know who Toby's father was when we first met,' says Rob Zegelaar of Atlas Venture. 'I am Dutch and after we had invested in them he told me about his father. I still didn't know who he was.'

Norton and Rowland met at Oxford university but the business grew out of a telephone conversation last June. Norton, in Paris, was talking to Rowland in London. They both agreed to quit their jobs - Norton as development director of French internet company Nomad, and Rowland as a research director at Disneyand - to set up an online natural health business, Clickmango.

By the end of their first day of meetings with venture capitalists they were offered £1m. By the end of the week they accepted an offer from venture capitalists Atlas Venture and some family money from Lord Rothschild - a package worth £3m. Atlas values the company at £8m and Norton and Rowland hold 62 per cent - valuing their holding at £5m. Norton came up with the idea and says he has 'slightly' more shares.

We have included Rowland on the basis of his business interests. His overall wealth will be far in excess of £2.5m because he is a major beneficiary of his father's £200m estate.

37-40. Peter Atalla, 21 Alan Edmondson, 23 John Boardman, 22 and Michael Haycock, 23

Founders, studentnet.com. £2.2million each.

It reads a little like a Young Ones sketch. Our four student heroes come up with an idea, sell the idea making millions of pounds, and within weeks are plastered all over The Sun because of their newfound wealth.

Only in the case of these four it's true, and Alexei Sayle doesn't come in at the end, batter them, pinching both the idea and the money.

Peter Atalla, a final-year Nottingham Trent university student, was brushing his teeth last summer - and rather than wondering who had left the top off the toothpaste - he started to think about the mechanics of moving house.

He couldn't understand why there was no student website to provide information on available accommodation, as well as filling you in on what bands were in town, and other student news and gossip. After a talk with three of his closest friends at Trent - Haycock, Edmondson, and Boardman - they decided to set up a site of their own. The company studentnet.com was only incorporated last July. So while most people nurse a hangover the day after graduating, these four began building the site.

Edmonson, who does the talking for the group says, 'Mike and I had planned to take a few months off to go to the west coast of America. But when we heard Peter's idea we cancelled it. We thought it was good and wanted to get on with it right away.'

Nine months after Atalla came up with the idea - it is understood that he has a slightly larger stake than the others - the quartet share a paper worth of just under £9m. In January the US-based media company International Media Products Group (IMPG) bought a 70 per cent stake in the company, ploughing experience, resources and £1m in cash into the group. In return, the four ex-students picked up a five per cent stake in IMPG which is set to float on the American technology exchange Nasdaq this spring at an expected £150m.

IMPG expects quick returns on its money. Its corporate development director Tunch Kashif explains: 'We look to invest in companies that can increase tenfold in the space of a year. This company made revenues of £25,000 in their first three weeks. This is the sort of company we are interested in.' IMPG expects to reap a return of at least £10m on its initial investment within the first year.

Although all four men are in their early twenties, none are new to business. Haycock and Atalla both sold computer hardware before going to college. In his teens Boardman ran a mobile disco. At 14 Edmondson started a gardening service, cutting lawns, planting bulbs and trimming borders in his hometown, Doncaster, South Yorkshire.

Studentnet.com is planning to cover around 60 major British student towns and cities before the end of the year. The company will then look to expand into Europe and the US. Without the IMPG money this would not be possible but the four directors may one day regret having had to sell so much of their company to get backing. This kind of growth means long hours and they usually work a seven-day week. This sort of schedule must be particularly gruelling for Atalla and Boardman who also live together.

'Some people wonder whether we are happy working this hard,' says Edmondson. 'But there is plenty of time to do other things later. The bottom line is if we weren't happy we wouldn't be doing this.' Now that is something you would never have heard in the Young Ones.

fields.headline: Spain
fields.standfirst: Once a 'poor' man of Europe, Spain now has a dynamic economy and a new generation of entrepreneurs. Sandra Jones reports
fields.trailText: Once a 'poor' man of Europe, Spain now has a dynamic economy and a new generation of entrepreneurs. Sandra Jones reports
fields.body:
When Marcos Enriquez, 29, co-founded Spanish internet portal Ozu in 1996 he had to use his credit cards to raise some of the capital. As with any internet start-up worth its salt, Ozu's first office was someone's sitting room.

When no one came to their ski-mountainwear shop in the Pyrenees, the Barrabes brothers went to a ski station car park, jotted down the registration numbers and checked if the same cars were to be found in their village. To attract customers, the brothers blagged their way into international trade fairs and stocked up on equipment unavailable elsewhere which they now sell through barrabes.com.

Marcos Guillen of Red Internauta, a fresh-faced 28, has to endure being called "Marquitos", or "little Marcos", by some of his clients. That hasn't handicapped his internet empire building - Marcos already has a six-year-old success story under his belt: Ran Internet, Spain's leading hosting domain. Red Internauta is just his latest baby. And when one of the Torrado brothers, Juan, 31, decided to set up Arrakis, an online newspaper and internet provider, it wasn't easy to sacrifice his well-paid job and his own flat to move back home to his parents. But his gamble paid off - last year British Telecom paid £9.5m for Arrakis.

All of them have pioneered lucrative companies in an industry new to Spain. In the process they have become millionaires. Only 15 years ago Spain was regarded as a "poor country". Today it has the fifth most dynamic economy in Europe. Having previously been dogged by chronic unemployment, reaching 27 per cent in 1995/96, government reforms have turned the economy around. "Spain's economy is doing very well, it's got very strong growth of well over 3.5 per cent over the last few years and unemployment has come down tremendously," says David Thwaites, European economist at the BNP-Paribas bank.

"There's a bit of a problem with inflation, it's currently running at 3 per cent as opposed to an EU average of 1.7 percent. But as e-commerce and employment rates grow, that should sort out the inflation."

In the past, making your fortune in Spain often involved extreme measures - for example, in the bullring. This classic route to riches, and glory on the pages of !Hola!, is still going strong - just witness the superstardom of 17-year-old Julian Lopez, "El Juli", a youth whose claim to fame is nearly 200 ears (cut from vanquished bulls) in a short career.

But in increasingly "wired" Spain, a more accessible - and less dangerous - fortune beckons. Terra Networks, a collection of internet service providers, went public last October and the whole of Spain jumped to attention. At its highest point, Terra had a £20bn valuation, making the newcomer the fourth-biggest company on the Spanish stock market. "Spain hasn't been very entrepreneurial until recently," says David del Val, 31. "There were no role models of young people taking a risk and becoming successful. But that has started to happen in Spain in the last year." Del Val became one of those role models by launching Vxtreme, a company developing internet video technology in 1995. Two years later Bill Gates snapped up the company for a reported £47m.

The Spanish hope to colonise the South American and Hispanic North American markets - if they can move quickly enough. In 1999, an estimated 16.2m Spanish speakers logged on to the internet - that figure is predicted to rise to 134m by 2005. And Spanish-language internet providers, like Terra Networks, are already battling the likes of Yahoo! and AOL to capture the emerging market.

Make way for the internet conquistadors.

Spain's Young Rich

1. Marcos Guillen, 28

Director of Red Internauta.Valued at £29.6 million

2. Marcos Enriquez, 29

Co-founder of Ozu, a Spanish language web search engine. Valued at £18.3 million

3. Carlos Barrabes, 29

Co-owner of Barrabes.com, specialist in ski/climbing gear. Valued at £3 million

4 and 5. German Torrado, 23, and Juan-Ignacio Rodriguez, 29

Co-founders of Arrakis, an online newspaper and internet service provider bought by BT for £9.5m. Valued at £2.4 million each

"Spain's economy is doing very well, it's got very strong growth of well over 3.5 per cent over the last few years and unemployment has come down tremendously," says David Thwaites, European economist at the BNP-Paribas bank. "There's a bit of a problem with inflation, it's currently running at 3 per cent as opposed to an EU average of 1.7 percent. But as e-commerce and employment rates grow, that should sort out the inflation." In the past, making your fortune in Spain often involved extreme measures - for example, in the bullring. This classic route to riches, and glory on the pages of !Hola!, is still going strong - just witness the superstardom of 17-year-old Julian Lopez, "El Juli", a youth whose claim to fame is nearly 200 ears (cut from vanquished bulls) in a short career. But in increasingly "wired" Spain, a more accessible - and less dangerous - fortune beckons. Terra Networks, a collection of internet service providers, went public last October and the whole of Spain jumped to attention. At its highest point, Terra had a £20bn valuation, making the newcomer the fourth-biggest company on the Spanish stock market. "Spain hasn't been very entrepreneurial until recently," says David del Val, 31. "There were no role models of young people taking a risk and becoming successful. But that has started to happen in Spain in the last year." Del Val became one of those role models by launching Vxtreme, a company developing internet video technology in 1995. Two years later Bill Gates snapped up the company for a reported £47m. The Spanish hope to colonise the South American and Hispanic North American markets - if they can move quickly enough. In 1999, an estimated 16.2m Spanish speakers logged on to the internet - that figure is predicted to rise to 134m by 2005. And Spanish-language internet providers, like Terra Networks, are already battling the likes of Yahoo! and AOL to capture the emerging market. Make way for the internet conquistadors. Carlos Barrabes, 29 Co-owner of Barrabes.com, specialist in ski/climbing gear. Valued at £3 million 4 and 5. German Torrado, 23, and Juan-Ignacio Rodriguez, 29 Co-founders of Arrakis, an online newspaper and internet service provider bought by BT for £9.5m. Valued at £2.4 million each

fields.headline: Spice Girls plc
fields.trailText: Perhaps the strongest testament to the enduring profitability of the Spice Girls is how, despite not having released a record as a band in over a year, the money continues to roll in. The valuations of Posh and the other Spice Girls is based upon the recorded earnings from a string of Spice Girls companies: Spice Girls Productions; Spice Girls Merchandising; Spice Girls Perfumes; Spice Girls Touring and Octopus Direct.

The valuations of Posh and the other Spice Girls is based upon the recorded earnings from a string of Spice Girls companies: Spice Girls Productions; Spice Girls Merchandising; Spice Girls Perfumes; Spice Girls Touring and Octopus Direct.

The main holding company, Spice Girls Limited, had a turnover of £41.4m in the year to August 1998 - the most recently filed records - recording pre-tax profits of £567,500 and total assets of £7.5m. "Posh" has seven company directorships - all relating to the Spice Girls, including her own ironically named Moody Productions, through which she was paid £6.2m as "wages" in the year to the end of August 1998.

Each member of the band simultaneously received £6.2m in "wages" plus other payments for promotional activities. The income for the 12 months to August 1999 will be considerably larger because of the success of the Spice World movie, US tour and worldwide record sales. For the new album, expected in September, each Spice has received a £1.5m advance.

fields.headline: Ask my agent
fields.standfirst: Will Buckley takes a sideways look at the world of the sports agent and explains how to in on the action
fields.trailText: Will Buckley takes a sideways look at the world of the sports agent and explains how to in on the action
fields.body:
It is a job which requires you to watch a lot of sport, talk a lot of sport and, crucially, can be done sitting down. But the real attraction of being an agent is the mathematics. Say you charge your client a somewhat punitive but obviously non-negotiable 20 per cent of his or her earnings, you only need to represent five sports stars in order to be as rich as your average client. If you have 20 clients then you'll be taking home four times as much as your mid-ranking sports star - say, £20m a year. And so on.

The other boon to being an agent is that it doesn't require any qualifications. No sweating through law school or wasting time with accountancy exams; all you need is a phone and a handful of business cards. You can get registered with the Football Association and FIFA to represent football's top earners. But you don't have to.

To make a go of being a sports agent, the first thing you'll need is clients. These can be acquired in a number of ways. One: poaching. Tony Stephens handles Beckham, Shearer and Owen so it might be worth approaching him to ask how he sees his business going in the future. Two: playgrounds. Get 'em young, get 'em cheap; Michael Owen and West Ham's Joe Cole had signed contracts with Umbro and Adidas before they were legally allowed to smoke. Three: Africa. It is possible to purchase job-lots of African footballers at a knock-down price and then sell them on at a massive mark-up to European clubs.

Four: family and friends. A surprising number of sports stars entrust the management of their financial affairs to a relative or the bloke from next door - Snooker's Steve Davis, Chelsea's Chris Sutton and, most famously, the petulant former Arsenal striker Nicolas Anelka have all handed control to family members. The important thing is that once you've got one client you can use his contacts to snap up another.

Representing them couldn't be easier. All you need to decide is whether your football client, for instance, is going to be a one-club man who will make a tax-free £250,000 from his testimonial (Chelsea's Dennis Wise), or a midfielder for hire who will rake off 10 per cent every time he is transferred (the much-travelled David Platt). If a long-termer, advise him to sign three-year contracts until he reaches his peak, aged 29, and then hold out for a six-year contract at £50,000 per week. This will ensure that he is paid £2.5m a year for the occasional run out as a substitute as his career unwinds.

If the latter, cut some kind of a deal with a manager. It surprises many observers how often certain players are signed by certain managers despite them rarely performing well on the pitch. The skill of the job lies not in representing your clients but in building your own career and business on the back of theirs. To this end, it is vital to establish early on that, for no extra charge, you will offer, gratis, skilled financial advice and judiciously invest their money for them. From their million-pound-share portfolios, to the smallest gas bill, you will take care of everything. They won't even have to open an envelope. Which is just how you want it.

fields.headline: When the bubble bursts
fields.standfirst: Every year at least 150,000 business stop trading. Tom O'Sullivan looks at one high profile success story which ended in failure
fields.trailText: Every year at least 150,000 business stop trading. Tom O'Sullivan looks at one high profile success story which ended in failure
fields.body:
He had it all. The £99,000 Lamborghini. The smart suits. A home in Italy. A PR man to raise his profile. Even a BBC camera crew which came to film him for a piece on high flying entrepreneurs.

Wasim Akhter, 28, was a picture of success in late 20th century Britain. But even before the camera crew, from the programme Urban Money, had started filming Rochdale-born Akhter's business empire was in trouble. His Barneys Department Stores group, which sold discounted designer clothes from a shop in Manchester, was wound up voluntarily in August, owing creditors almost £750,000.

The department of Inland Revenue and the company's bank are at the head of a queue of creditors which also includes Manchester City Council, British Gas and another 30 individuals and smaller companies. The Urban Money programme was broadcast in the northwest in December - four months after the company had been wound up. It infuriated creditors and led to a story about the collapse in the Manchester Evening News. The programme - in which Akhter talked about setting up a chain of fashion stores in the UK - was partly prompted by his inclusion, last May, in Eastern Eye magazine's list of the 200 richest Asians in the UK. It claimed his personal wealth stood at £5m.

"We are still investigating matters," says Alex Kachani, the liquidator appointed to deal with the company's collapse. "Given what has happened, we are looking into it fully." Kachani is compiling a statutory report for the Department of Trade and Industry. The report should have been sent at the end of February - six months after the winding up - but has been delayed. Kachani has written to both Akhter and his brother, and co-director, Aleem Khan asking to interview them about the company"s collapse.

The Urban Money programme will now form part of Kachani's inquiry into the business failure. The brothers - they both had a 20 per cent stake in Barneys Department Stores and were the only directors - originally built their business on what is known as the "grey market" or "parallel importing". The system works when a company imports designer clothes or sportswear, bought cheaply in Europe, into the UK where they are then sold at prices which undercut those dictated by manufacturers such as Calvin Klein, Levi's and Adidas. In recent years supermarket chains Asda and Tesco have both fought legal actions with manufacturers for the right to sell such merchandise. Akhter and his brother ran a company, Whisper Distribution, supplying designer clothes to the likes of Tesco. The supermarkets were making a loud and public point about restrictive and anti-competitive trading while Akhter and his brother were making a healthy profit. From distribution they moved into retail, which seems to have been their undoing. In 1997 the Manchester Evening News reported that Akhter had spent £500,000 on a building in Salford which he wanted to open as a store selling designer clothes. Planning permission was withheld; instead the brothers opened the first and only Barneys store in Manchester, near Strangeways prison in 1998.

In a move, also being investigated by the liquidator, the Manchester store is now trading under a new name, Barneys Department Stores Mail Order Ltd, run by Akhter"s father Walayat Khan. Meanwhile Akhter has been dividing his time between Florence - where He is understood to be continuing his distribution business - and Manchester. Barneys Department Stores Group is just one of an average 150,000 business" which stop trading each year. Some go bankrupt, others go into liquidation or are made insolvent. Vat registration figures show that in 1998 186,000 companies were launched, while 156,000 fell by the wayside. Figures that show a net gain of 30,000 companies, including some of those on the Young Rich list.

DTI minister Helen Liddell said last August: "We want to encourage a culture in which those who are prepared to take risks to exploit new business opportunities will be rewarded." But it is a sobering thought that 3,000 companies are closing or stop trading every week in the UK.

The Observer wrote to Wasim Akhter and tried to contact him in both Italy and Manchester but he was unavailable for comment. However, he is quoted in the Manchester Evening News just before Christmas as saying: "Things go wrong. If running a business was easy, everyone would be doing it. Things happen. I am a success and I am still working hard to achieve what I set out to achieve and that is running a successful business and making a lot of money."

But, as if to heap indignity upon indignity, the last name on the list of creditors for Barneys Department Stores Group is Lamborghini Great Britain, which claims it is owed £1,090.27p.

fields.headline: The young rich entertainers
fields.trailText:
The people on this list have several things in common. Most 
are household names, some are or have been friends and all 
of them have more money and fame than they could ever 
have dreamed possible.
fields.body:
The people on this list have several things in common. Most are household names, some are or have been friends and all of them have more money and fame than they could ever have dreamed possible.

They also have a further distinction - previously most sports and pop stars (who form a majority on the entertainers list) have had to live with the prospect that their careers would be short and followed by a long period of no money and anonymity. But the people on this list are more business-like than any previous generation of celebrities.

If you trawl through Companies House you come up with some very familiar-sounding businesses. There is Ryan Giggs Limited, Robbie Fowler Sports Promotions, Zeta Enterprises Limited - the list goes on. They are becoming mini-corporations or, in the case of David Beckham, a major corporation (see left). But along with creating companies, these wealthy individuals have also discovered other valuable 'financial products', such as offshore accounts and investment trusts which mean you can earn £2m per year without having to become a tax exile. They can also blur the true earnings of an individual.

These valuations have been arrived at by investigating company accounts; talking to the people doing the transfer and sponsorship deals and their rivals, to confirm the value of contracts; speaking to specialist accountants in the UK and US. And if we couldn't get a definitive figure, we have not included the deal or payment in an individual's final valuation. Many of these people will go on to earn far more money in the future, as will the teams of accountants, financial advisers and business consultants hired to 'protect their interests'.

fields.headline: The young rich entrepreneurs 1-10
fields.standfirst:
Jason Drummond is richer than all of the Spice Girls put together and virtually unknown. At 30 he is a relative old-tomer - the youngest on the list is just 21. Many have set up companies in the past 12 months and are now millionaires. Welcome to a new generation of Young Rich Entrepreneurs

Special report: the young rich
fields.trailText: Jason Drummond | Robert Bonnier | Jonathan Rowland | Martha Lane Fox | Tahir Mohsan | Rob Lewis | Charlie Muirhead |  Mark Slater | Dylan Wilk | Ernesto Schmitt
fields.body:
Accounting for the entrepreneurs

'There has been a lot of hard work along the way. There have been some late nights, and lots of tears and sweat. But when I look back on it I do think that it has been surprisingly easy. I could do it all again.'

The voice of an entrepreneur who didn't make it on to this list because his claimed £20m valuation was unverifiable. Most of the companies owned by the entrepreneurs - the list is dominated by the internet - have never made a profit. And yet the combined value of the 40 business people on this list is £610m.

In the past 12 months the scale of wealth has increased massively as the e-commerce boom has distorted the value of the stock market. For most of the business people on this list, their main financial value comes from the stake they hold in their own firm. Where a company has been floated we have calculated the market value of an individual's stake in that business. Where the businesses are not floated, we have interviewed the investors and market analysts. And where valuations have not been possible - for instance when a company is registered in Jersey or the investors are publicity shy - the individual has not been included. These are the most accurate figures available at the end of February but in most cases they are stock market valuations, which means they can go down as well as up.

1 Jason Drummond, 30
Founder, Virtual Internet
£123 million

Jason Drummond gives the impression of being in a hurry. When he listens his foot taps impatiently, and he constantly fiddles with his keys or a couple of pens on his desk in his cramped and featureless office in a large Georgian building in Fulham - around the corner from where he grew up. His eyes are cobalt blue, and he carries a little too much weight for his 5ft 8in frame. Although he doesn't play any sport, he looks like a rugby player in need of a few weeks' pre-season training.

But aged 30 he is worth more than the Spice Girls put together and is about to get a whole lot richer when his Virtual Internet company floats on the full Stock Market later this month. He claims that when he was a child he told his mother that he wanted to be a shopkeeper. Indeed his mum, who was divorced from his father when Drummond was just four, crops up regularly in his conversation.

His mother, he says, is where he gets his drive. She didn't remarry, and struggled to bring up Drummond and his brothers: Justin, who was then 12 months, and six-year-old Nigel. 'It was a middle-class upbringing without the money,' remembers Drummond. 'My mother gave us our values. Not to be too English, not to accept that there were any positions that we couldn't achieve or aspire to. She gave us the confidence that with hard work anything is possible.' Drummond's father remains estranged from the family.

While still at his Fulham comprehensive, Drummond began selling mail-order computers. He left school after his A-levels and worked as a salesman for Reed Business Publishing where he first saw a fax machine - it didn't exactly change his life but it did make an immediate impact. 'It took me five minutes to decide to leave the company and set up my own fax business.'

He went on to set up and sell a number of computer and technology firms before founding Virtual Internet in 1996. It has carved a lucrative business out of registering domain names for companies on the internet to protect their copyright and brand names. In essence it provides security to any business operating on the internet.

The company, which for the moment is floated on the Alternative Investment Market, has a market capitalisation of £179m. It is more highly valued by the City than household retail names like House of Fraser, Storehouse, French Connection and Harvey Nichols. Drummond owns 69 per cent.

'It's not about the cash, otherwise I would have retired,' Drummond says, as he drops the pen he has been fiddling with. 'It's about making this company a dominant force in Europe, and being big enough to challenge the largest American companies.' He says he wants to be a 'leader' in the new business order but gives little clue as to where that ambition comes from. These are grand plans from a company which only turned in profits of £2.1m last year, even if this is £2.1m more than most internet companies make.

At home, Drummond is determined to be the father he never had. He met his wife Jackie, who was then an airline stewardess, when he was 20. They have been married for eight years, and have two children: three-year-old Mathew and Phoebe, who is 15 months. There is nothing on his messy desk to remind him of his family.

But uniquely among these entrepreneurs, he never works at weekends. They are reserved for his family. 'Jackie stopped working a couple of years ago, and she's in charge of what we do at home. I'm happy to go along with that.'

Ironically it is the family which is now forcing its way into Drummond's business activities. Last November Drummond quietly set up a new 'family' business - a web TV venture called onthebox.com. He is the sole director and his wife is company secretary. Its purpose is unclear but if it is as successful as his day job the family will never have to worry about a pension. It may even stop Drummond being in such a hurry.

2 Robert Bonnier, 30
Chief executive, Scoot.com
£72 million

The freephone service Scoot.com offers a clear example of the bizarre logic and mathematics involved in technology-related companies. Bonnier's personal fortune - based on his nine per cent stake in Scoot - has shot up from £11m last year to a paper worth of £72m today. At the same time the company made losses of £16m to the end of last September, adding to its losses of £26m the year before.

So the value of a loss-making company has increased over 700 per cent - it is valued today at £780m on the Alternative Investment Market - in the past 12 months. Obviously the value is based on potential future earnings but even so it is an astonishing statistic.

It has been a year in which Bonnier had to hire a private detective to track down what was thought to be a disgruntled former employee circulating damaging information about him and his interactive 'yellow pages' company.

The document printed the results of an anonymous 'survey' claiming to show that 70 per cent of those who had used Scoot were unhappy with the service. It also dredged up an incident from Bonnier's past when he worked as a financier for the Swiss Bank Corporation. He was investigated, and cleared of any involvement, in an insider-dealing scam in the mid-Nineties. The 'disgruntled one' has not been found; Bonnier says the investigation is 'ongoing'. He was further embarrassed when a former business associate, Ronal Zimet, came under a Serious Fraud Office investigation over his business dealings. Bonnier was not under investigation but fielded awkward questions from the press about his relationship with Zimet, then a Scoot shareholder. But backers believe Bonnier has the Midas touch. In January French multinational Vivendi bought a 10 per cent stake in Scoot for £100m. Vivendi said: 'We wouldn't be making such a commitment if we hadn't looked very closely at the Scoot business model.' And in August, Vodafone beat a path to its door for exclusive use of its information service on its phones.

3 Jonathan Rowland, 24
Founder, Jellyworks
£40 million

There was a debate about including Jonathan Rowland - the son of property developer David Rowland - on this list. He is undoubtedly wealthy but pinning down an absolute value is like trying to pin jelly to a wall. Although his company Jellyworks is valued at £150m on the Alternative Investment Market, the size of his stake is in doubt. It is held in a family trust.

Much of the money used to set up Jellyworks and provide it with a cash pool to make acquisitions came from Rowland family trusts. It is believed the Rowland family now owns around 70 per cent of the company which was chaired by Edward Guinan, a former Wall Street trader and close friend of Rowland senior who quit last month. Our inquiries have concluded that there are at least three other interested parties - family members - with a stake in the trust and that Rowland's stake is valued at £40m. At the time of the float, Jellyworks was worth £10m; afterwards it went as high as £200m. The reason for this soar in value? Jellyworks is an internet investment vehicle, which has, among other things, taken stakes in EPO.com, a Swedish internet bank and Antfactory, an incubator company which nurtures fledgling online businesses.

But the thing to remember is that Rowland's fortune - like that of many on this list is a paper one - built on share ownership. Because only 10 per cent of Jellyworks' shares are available to investors, the laws of supply and demand have sent the company's share price soaring. But if Rowland were to start offloading his stake, it could soon end up having a very different value Rowland left Bedales after his GCSEs, tried his hand at a 'couple of jobs' and ended up working for the family's property business in Norwich.

Eighteen months ago he started working directly for his father, learning how business works. Soon it was Rowland junior who was identifying the investment opportunities of the future. 'I understood the internet. I started to source deals, ring people up, meet people,' Rowland says proudly. However, he still has a long way to go in convincing the City of his longevity.

4 Martha Lane Fox, 27
Co-founder, lastminute.com
£32 million

The lift that carries you toward the offices of lastminute.com is full of grubby youths in hooded tops, and the penetrating smell of burgers. 'Oh, McDonald's! Yum!' says Martha Lane Fox, whose two-year-old internet company is due to lay the golden egg when floated on the stock market later this month. It is valued at £400m, and Lane Fox's shares will be worth £32m. Not that she will discuss this: far too embarrassing. 'I am embarrassed. I've never thought of myself as somebody who would make a lot of money. It wasn't a goal of mine. It's not bad to make loads of money, I don't care if people earn money or not, but in my naive, bourgeois ideology, everyone would share everybody's money and we'd all have the same amount.'

There's nowhere to sit in the crowded open-plan office, where none of the trainer-wearing burger-eaters is playing the table football since they're all far too busy toiling away on the website (listing last-minute deals on flights, holidays and entertainments). We adjourn to a grubby corner of the unheated corridor by the lift shaft with a view over central London. Martha is wearing webutante mufti: purple satin-trimmed cardigan and khaki oxford bags and trainers that look like beans. (Her light touch is evident everywhere except with the mascara wand: her eyelashes, already long, resemble Rorschach inkblots.) When she and lastminute.com's co-founder Brent Hoberman, 31, first took their brainchild to prospective investors, they strove to look respectable, but now, 'I think this is what they expect. Initially we went to meet these backers wearing suits and looking completely silly, and gradually we realised they didn't want to see us pretending to be them.'

Lane Fox speaks incredibly softly and incredibly fast. People have bitched to the press about how, in her previous incarnation (Westminster school and Oxford university), she was 'mousy' and, worst of all, 'normal', but I can't imagine how she ever passed unnoticed.

The daughter of a gardener/classicist and a businesswoman, and the great-niece of the 6th Marquess of Anglesey, she plainly has a terrific entitlement complex, having walked into a series of well-paid consultancy jobs after graduating. 'Yes, of course I had a huge head start because I had an amazing education, which meant I could get a very good job, which taught me how to write business plans, which gave me a web of contacts, and of course it's much harder if you come from a comprehensive school in Glasgow, even if you have a neat e-commerce idea but I don't think that means it's insurmountable.'

I ask her if the last two years seem quite real. She says she is too busy working to indulge in such thoughts. 'I very rarely stop to reflect on what's happened, to be honest.' Then she relents: 'I'm sure on some deep psychological level I'm in a deep state of shock about it.' The money - she doesn't want to talk about it, but after all, that's why we're here - has yet to make an impact on her life, she says, but that will change after the flotation, when she intends to pay herself the salary 'of someone running a proper public company'. Her flat in Notting Hill was bought before lastminute.com was launched, and she still hasn't replaced the car which she wrote off two years ago. She is 'an obsessive clothes shopper', but then again her favourite store is Top Shop.

Rumours about her flying 30 of her best friends out to a villa in the South of France for Millennium Eve are nonsense - 'Yeah, right!' - since they all paid their own fares and stayed in a cottage (I say it must have been some cottage, but she insists it was 'very higgledy-piggledy'). Her last birthday party was not, as reported, top-secret and swanky, but held in a pub in west London.

She first worked with Hoberman at Spectrum, advising big companies on new technology. I wonder why he, having had the idea, wanted her on board, but she says it didn't happen like that: 'I think I just forced myself on him.' Hoberman is the visionary, she the facilitator. 'I think I'm a good salesperson,' she says finally. 'I think I can sell the concept to anybody. And certainly there's the advantage of being young, blond and female; I'm realistic about that. But I'm also quite good at doing deals in very difficult circumstances: that's nothing to do with my age or my sex. I am not afraid to be myself.'

5 Tahir Mohsan, 28
Computer retailer
£35 million

When Time Computers won a recent business award in the northwest as the 'best emerging company' there was a rumour in Manchester that Tahir Mohsan would attend the ceremony to pick up the prize. But, true to form, Time Computer's managing director was nowhere to be seen. Nobody has ever published a photograph of Mohsan and it is claimed that local newspapers in Blackburn and Burnley have an unspoken agreement not to print his picture - Time is both a major employer and advertiser in the area. The most vivid description is from a former Time employee who paints him as a 'slight, thin, shortish bloke'.

His parents came to Blackburn from Pakistan and the only story to emerge about him is that the company was originally set up by his brother Dr Tariq Mohammed to keep young Tahir 'out of trouble'. In 12 years that is it about this man who works 18 hours per day, six or seven days per week. He topped last year's Young Rich list, but has been outpaced by the virtual millions of others. However, his millions are real - he has a 30 per cent stake in Time and it made £4.5m profit on a turnover of £105.4m in 1998. And in the past 12 months he has been busy collecting another 11 directorships - most in what appear to be new 'family' ventures including Supanet which suggests that Mohsan and Dr Mohammed - probably with the help of their other three brothers - might be getting involved in net ventures.

6 Rob Lewis, 30
Founder, Silicon.com
£28 million

If, like me, you thought that the only person who bumped into Swiss nuclear physicists at London parties was James Bond, think again. The start of Rob Lewis's fascination with the internet can be traced to such a chance meeting in 1996. The scientists from Cern in Switzerland convinced him of the power of the net and he was hooked.

The following day Lewis - who up until that point had been involved in traditional magazine publishing - concluded that print was dead. At least when it came to communicating with the IT industry and he set about launching Silicom.com - a web TV company reaching just under 300,000 high-spending IT professionals. There are plans to extend the service into Germany, France and Scandinavia later this year.

'Four years ago it was virtually impossible to get venture capitalists to invest in the web, because they thought it was so untried,' says Lewis with a smile on his face. 'It was all private money. But now they are so scared of being left out of the revolution they are falling over themselves to lend money.'

Last November a consortium of venture capital firms headed by Amadeus Capital Partners invested £11m in Silicon.com. The company has been extravagantly valued at £800m in some quarters, but through conversations with a number of those who have invested - and market analysts - we believe £100m is a more accurate figure. Lewis holds 15 per cent. He also owns a third of the software company Cromwell Media which has been valued at £40m.

The path to millionaire status started at 17 for the hyperactive Lewis, when he took a year off before sitting his A-levels to answer the phones at a small publishing firm. Within 12 months he was editing one of its technology titles. At Cambridge, where he studied economics, he set up a rival to Varsity - the college student newspaper - called The Cambridge Weekly Review. This attracted the attention of Independent Newspapers owner Tony O'Reilly and it briefly became a national student newspaper called The Weekly Review in the early Nineties.

After college Lewis spent two years as the researcher for Huddersfield Labour MP Barry Sheerman in the run-up to the 1992 election, a low point in his life. 'We really thought we could win. I spent election night at a "victory" party in Huddersfield. That was the most depressing thing I have ever done.' Lewis left politics and in 1993 started a computer title, Business and Technology Magazine, in a friend's flat in Notting Hill. It was bought by Dennis Publishing for a claimed £1m in 1996.

That is when he bumped into those nuclear physicists. A meeting that changed his life.

7 Charlie Muirhead, 24
Founder, Orchestream
£21 million

Orchestream manages and secures internet network systems - in layman's terms it is the maintenance company which sorts out problems. He owns a majority share in the company which has already attracted more than £40m of backing from venture capitalists such as Atlas Ventures and Deutsche Bank and other interested businesses, notably the chip maker Intel. However if, as expected, the company floats, Muirhead's value will soar - possibly as high as £200m. Muirhead is coy about any flotation: 'We're going through a huge growth spurt at the moment. A float is not the first thing on our minds. It is something we're considering.' Muirhead's earliest backer was record producer Hugh Padgham - he lent Muirhead £20,000 to set up an internet service provider. The two met when Muirhead, who was educated at Bedales (where he became mates with Jonathan Rowland; see number three) and Westminster schools, was taking a year out before going to university. His enthusiasm for technology was sparked while working as a glorified roadie for a company which supplied musical equipment and instruments to bands. While working for the company, Muirhead helped initiate a £350,000 management buyout, giving him his first taste of the entrepreneurial life. The ISP scheme folded but, having studied computer science at Imperial College, London, Muirhead, a skiing and diving nut, was able 'to understand how a microprocessor worked'. Orchestream was formed out of his frustration that the internet was too slow.

The company is now three years old and employs 75 people, all of whom have share options. Securing funding in the first place, however, was not the easiest thing but backers' curiosity got the better of them. 'People would giggle and then listen to what we had to say.'

The firm's soaring success - clients include Toys R Us and the US defence department - belies its once-humble origins. Orchestream's original London HQ was based above a funeral parlour. Muirhead recalls: 'We would all go down into the basement below to smoke and potential investors would have to walk through. What on earth they must have been thinking, I don't know.'

8 Mark Slater, 30
Internet financier
£19.5 million

It took Mark Slater 10 years to make his first £2.5m and 10 months to make the next £17m, transforming him from being very wealthy to enormously wealthy in the past four months.

Like several people on this list, he has had a massive helping hand via his family's wealth. Aged 16, Slater was given money to invest by his father, the legendary financier Jim Slater - a contemporary of James Goldsmith and Tiny Rowland - whose own finance company spectacularly failed in the Seventies.

A similar fate is unlikely to befall his son. Slater junior has used the money he has made in the past decade from his finance company, Slater Investments, to launch Internet Indirect which invests in small start-up companies designing software to make the net work better. When it floated on the Alternative Investment Market last December it was valued at £100m. Slater junior holds a 17 per cent stake and his father 10 per cent.

'I am sceptical about selling goods over the internet to consumers,' he says. 'I prefer the business-to-business route. Businesses expect to pay for services. But on the internet, consumers expect to get things for free or very cheap.'

Even though his father's business failed, there has always been plenty of money to provide for his four children - two sons and two daughters. Mark Slater went to Arundel public school and then read history at Cambridge. Between college and starting his investment company in 1994 he mixed careers, working as a bond dealer and a business reporter for the Investors Chronicle, among other titles.

9 Dylan Wilk, 25
Computer games supplier
£18.6 million

This was the deal year for Wilk. It is the dilemma every successful company owner faces - whether to stay independent or sell to a bigger business in order to compete on a larger stage. That Wilk had to make this decision at 25 shows the pace of his progress.

Last July he sold his mail-order computer games business, Interactive Commercial Enterprises, to AIM-listed internet games business Gameplay.com. The deal gave Wilk £2.6m in cash, a seat on the Gameplay board, and 5 per cent of the enlarged company. Gameplay.com is currently capitalised at £328m, which values Wilk's shares at £16m.

Wilk's rags-to-riches tale is such a classic one that it should come with violin accompaniment. He was raised by his mother on a council estate in Leeds and won a scholarship to Bradford grammar school. There he saw the wealth of his classmates and decided to make some money for himself.

He left school at 16 and worked for a mail-order fish food firm, but it was always in his mind to work for himself. A year later he decided on a mail-order computer software business because customers couldn't tell how young he was, and thousands of games packages were small enough to fit into his bedroom.

He borrowed £2,500 from the Prince's Trust in 1994 and he was off. By the time he sold the company last year, it was one of the largest mail-order computer games outfits in the UK, with 275,000 regular customers. When not working hard, he likes to travel fast. In fact he was banned from driving for speeding, and had to sell his convertible Ferrari 355 and his BMW M3. However, the ban ended last summer and he was last seen in a private session at Brands Hatch.

10 Ernesto Schmitt, 28
Founder, peoplesound.com
£17 million

If Ernesto Schmitt stepped in a cow pat, it would smell of roses. Tall, good-looking, cosmopolitan, bright and rich too. We love him. Schmitt is one of the first new-age music publishers. Last December, his company peoplesound.com was valued by US investment bank, Merrill Lynch, at £47m. Schmitt has a stake of 35 per cent which equates to £17m. His founding partner, Paul Levett, holds a five per cent stake which means that at the age of 29, he is also sitting on a £2.35m fortune.

Peoplesound.com - spot the social democratic, egalitarian credentials - showcases new bands on the web and allows the record-buying public to buy CDs. Visitors to the site download two million tracks per month. Backed by French businessman Bernard Arnault, who owns luxury goods company LVMH, peoplesound.com will float some time this year at an expected market value of £80m. But it is the prospect of peoplesound being bought out which will really propel the art-loving Schmitt into the financial stratosphere. Peoplesound.com is an obvious content fit for a 'technology distributor' such as Yahoo! or an established music label.

Schmitt's life so far is a catalogue of high-achievement. Son of a globe-trotting Proctor & Gamble engineer father and Uruguayan mother, he was born in the US and his early days were spent mainly in Belgium and Mexico. He studied at Cambridge, went to the Insead business school in France before doing a stint at Boston Consulting, one of the world's premier management consultancies.

But when it comes to the business he is more reticent. He refuses to give any turnover figures but concedes that the site does not make money. In the crazy economics of the internet that does not matter. What does is first entry into virgin territory and cashing your chips before the bubble bursts. So the next year is make or break for Schmitt.

But when I look back on it I do think that it has been surprisingly easy. I could do it all again.' The voice of an entrepreneur who didn't make it on to this list because his claimed £20m valuation was unverifiable. Most of the companies owned by the entrepreneurs - the list is dominated by the internet - have never made a profit. And yet the combined value of the 40 business people on this list is £610m. In the past 12 months the scale of wealth has increased massively as the e-commerce boom has distorted the value of the stock market. For most of the business people on this list, their main financial value comes from the stake they hold in their own firm. Where a company has been floated we have calculated the market value of an individual's stake in that business. Where the businesses are not floated, we have interviewed the investors and market analysts. And where valuations have not been possible - for instance when a company is registered in Jersey or the investors are publicity shy - the individual has not been included. These are the most accurate figures available at the end of February but in most cases they are stock market valuations, which means they can go down as well as up. 1 Jason Drummond, 30 Founder, Virtual Internet £123 million Jason Drummond gives the impression of being in a hurry. When he listens his foot taps impatiently, and he constantly fiddles with his keys or a couple of pens on his desk in his cramped and featureless office in a large Georgian building in Fulham - around the corner from where he grew up. His eyes are cobalt blue, and he carries a little too much weight for his 5ft 8in frame. Although he doesn't play any sport, he looks like a rugby player in need of a few weeks' pre-season training. But aged 30 he is worth more than the Spice Girls put together and is about to get a whole lot richer when his Virtual Internet company floats on the full Stock Market later this month. He claims that when he was a child he told his mother that he wanted to be a shopkeeper. Indeed his mum, who was divorced from his father when Drummond was just four, crops up regularly in his conversation. His mother, he says, is where he gets his drive. She didn't remarry, and struggled to bring up Drummond and his brothers: Justin, who was then 12 months, and six-year-old Nigel. 'It was a middle-class upbringing without the money,' remembers Drummond. 'My mother gave us our values. Not to be too English, not to accept that there were any positions that we couldn't achieve or aspire to. She gave us the confidence that with hard work anything is possible.' Drummond's father remains estranged from the family. While still at his Fulham comprehensive, Drummond began selling mail-order computers. He left school after his A-levels and worked as a salesman for Reed Business Publishing where he first saw a fax machine - it didn't exactly change his life but it did make an immediate impact. 'It took me five minutes to decide to leave the company and set up my own fax business.' He went on to set up and sell a number of computer and technology firms before founding Virtual Internet in 1996. It has carved a lucrative business out of registering domain names for companies on the internet to protect their copyright and brand names. In essence it provides security to any business operating on the internet. The company, which for the moment is floated on the Alternative Investment Market, has a market capitalisation of £179m. It is more highly valued by the City than household retail names like House of Fraser, Storehouse, French Connection and Harvey Nichols. Drummond owns 69 per cent. 'It's not about the cash, otherwise I would have retired,' Drummond says, as he drops the pen he has been fiddling with. 'It's about making this company a dominant force in Europe, and being big enough to challenge the largest American companies.' He says he wants to be a 'leader' in the new business order but gives little clue as to where that ambition comes from. These are grand plans from a company which only turned in profits of £2.1m last year, even if this is £2.1m more than most internet companies make. At home, Drummond is determined to be the father he never had. He met his wife Jackie, who was then an airline stewardess, when he was 20. They have been married for eight years, and have two children: three-year-old Mathew and Phoebe, who is 15 months. There is nothing on his messy desk to remind him of his family. But uniquely among these entrepreneurs, he never works at weekends. They are reserved for his family. 'Jackie stopped working a couple of years ago, and she's in charge of what we do at home. I'm happy to go along with that.' Ironically it is the family which is now forcing its way into Drummond's business activities. Last November Drummond quietly set up a new 'family' business - a web TV venture called onthebox.com. He is the sole director and his wife is company secretary. Its purpose is unclear but if it is as successful as his day job the family will never have to worry about a pension. It may even stop Drummond being in such a hurry. 2 Robert Bonnier, 30 Chief executive, Scoot.com £72 million The freephone service Scoot.com offers a clear example of the bizarre logic and mathematics involved in technology-related companies. Bonnier's personal fortune - based on his nine per cent stake in Scoot - has shot up from £11m last year to a paper worth of £72m today. At the same time the company made losses of £16m to the end of last September, adding to its losses of £26m the year before. So the value of a loss-making company has increased over 700 per cent - it is valued today at £780m on the Alternative Investment Market - in the past 12 months. Obviously the value is based on potential future earnings but even so it is an astonishing statistic. It has been a year in which Bonnier had to hire a private detective to track down what was thought to be a disgruntled former employee circulating damaging information about him and his interactive 'yellow pages' company. The document printed the results of an anonymous 'survey' claiming to show that 70 per cent of those who had used Scoot were unhappy with the service. It also dredged up an incident from Bonnier's past when he worked as a financier for the Swiss Bank Corporation. He was investigated, and cleared of any involvement, in an insider-dealing scam in the mid-Nineties. The 'disgruntled one' has not been found; Bonnier says the investigation is 'ongoing'. He was further embarrassed when a former business associate, Ronal Zimet, came under a Serious Fraud Office investigation over his business dealings. Bonnier was not under investigation but fielded awkward questions from the press about his relationship with Zimet, then a Scoot shareholder. But backers believe Bonnier has the Midas touch. In January French multinational Vivendi bought a 10 per cent stake in Scoot for £100m. Vivendi said: 'We wouldn't be making such a commitment if we hadn't looked very closely at the Scoot business model.' And in August, Vodafone beat a path to its door for exclusive use of its information service on its phones. 3 Jonathan Rowland, 24 Founder, Jellyworks £40 million There was a debate about including Jonathan Rowland - the son of property developer David Rowland - on this list. He is undoubtedly wealthy but pinning down an absolute value is like trying to pin jelly to a wall. Although his company Jellyworks is valued at £150m on the Alternative Investment Market, the size of his stake is in doubt. It is held in a family trust. Much of the money used to set up Jellyworks and provide it with a cash pool to make acquisitions came from Rowland family trusts. It is believed the Rowland family now owns around 70 per cent of the company which was chaired by Edward Guinan, a former Wall Street trader and close friend of Rowland senior who quit last month.
