After college Lewis spent two years as the researcher for Huddersfield Labour MP Barry Sheerman in the run-up to the 1992 election, a low point in his life. 'We really thought we could win. I spent election night at a "victory" party in Huddersfield. That was the most depressing thing I have ever done.' Lewis left politics and in 1993 started a computer title, Business and Technology Magazine, in a friend's flat in Notting Hill. It was bought by Dennis Publishing for a claimed £1m in 1996. That is when he bumped into those nuclear physicists. A meeting that changed his life. 7 Charlie Muirhead, 24 Founder, Orchestream £21 million Orchestream manages and secures internet network systems - in layman's terms it is the maintenance company which sorts out problems. He owns a majority share in the company which has already attracted more than £40m of backing from venture capitalists such as Atlas Ventures and Deutsche Bank and other interested businesses, notably the chip maker Intel. However if, as expected, the company floats, Muirhead's value will soar - possibly as high as £200m. Muirhead is coy about any flotation: 'We're going through a huge growth spurt at the moment. A float is not the first thing on our minds. It is something we're considering.' Muirhead's earliest backer was record producer Hugh Padgham - he lent Muirhead £20,000 to set up an internet service provider. The two met when Muirhead, who was educated at Bedales (where he became mates with Jonathan Rowland; see number three) and Westminster schools, was taking a year out before going to university. His enthusiasm for technology was sparked while working as a glorified roadie for a company which supplied musical equipment and instruments to bands. While working for the company, Muirhead helped initiate a £350,000 management buyout, giving him his first taste of the entrepreneurial life. The ISP scheme folded but, having studied computer science at Imperial College, London, Muirhead, a skiing and diving nut, was able 'to understand how a microprocessor worked'. Orchestream was formed out of his frustration that the internet was too slow. The company is now three years old and employs 75 people, all of whom have share options. Securing funding in the first place, however, was not the easiest thing but backers' curiosity got the better of them. 'People would giggle and then listen to what we had to say.' The firm's soaring success - clients include Toys R Us and the US defence department - belies its once-humble origins. Orchestream's original London HQ was based above a funeral parlour. Muirhead recalls: 'We would all go down into the basement below to smoke and potential investors would have to walk through. What on earth they must have been thinking, I don't know.' 8 Mark Slater, 30 Internet financier £19.5 million It took Mark Slater 10 years to make his first £2.5m and 10 months to make the next £17m, transforming him from being very wealthy to enormously wealthy in the past four months. Like several people on this list, he has had a massive helping hand via his family's wealth. Aged 16, Slater was given money to invest by his father, the legendary financier Jim Slater - a contemporary of James Goldsmith and Tiny Rowland - whose own finance company spectacularly failed in the Seventies. A similar fate is unlikely to befall his son. Slater junior has used the money he has made in the past decade from his finance company, Slater Investments, to launch Internet Indirect which invests in small start-up companies designing software to make the net work better. When it floated on the Alternative Investment Market last December it was valued at £100m. Slater junior holds a 17 per cent stake and his father 10 per cent. 'I am sceptical about selling goods over the internet to consumers,' he says. 'I prefer the business-to-business route. Businesses expect to pay for services. But on the internet, consumers expect to get things for free or very cheap.' Even though his father's business failed, there has always been plenty of money to provide for his four children - two sons and two daughters. Mark Slater went to Arundel public school and then read history at Cambridge. Between college and starting his investment company in 1994 he mixed careers, working as a bond dealer and a business reporter for the Investors Chronicle, among other titles. 9 Dylan Wilk, 25 Computer games supplier £18.6 million This was the deal year for Wilk. It is the dilemma every successful company owner faces - whether to stay independent or sell to a bigger business in order to compete on a larger stage. That Wilk had to make this decision at 25 shows the pace of his progress. Last July he sold his mail-order computer games business, Interactive Commercial Enterprises, to AIM-listed internet games business Gameplay.com. The deal gave Wilk £2.6m in cash, a seat on the Gameplay board, and 5 per cent of the enlarged company. Gameplay.com is currently capitalised at £328m, which values Wilk's shares at £16m. Wilk's rags-to-riches tale is such a classic one that it should come with violin accompaniment. He was raised by his mother on a council estate in Leeds and won a scholarship to Bradford grammar school. There he saw the wealth of his classmates and decided to make some money for himself. He left school at 16 and worked for a mail-order fish food firm, but it was always in his mind to work for himself. A year later he decided on a mail-order computer software business because customers couldn't tell how young he was, and thousands of games packages were small enough to fit into his bedroom. He borrowed £2,500 from the Prince's Trust in 1994 and he was off. By the time he sold the company last year, it was one of the largest mail-order computer games outfits in the UK, with 275,000 regular customers. When not working hard, he likes to travel fast. In fact he was banned from driving for speeding, and had to sell his convertible Ferrari 355 and his BMW M3. However, the ban ended last summer and he was last seen in a private session at Brands Hatch. 10 Ernesto Schmitt, 28 Founder, peoplesound.com £17 million If Ernesto Schmitt stepped in a cow pat, it would smell of roses. Tall, good-looking, cosmopolitan, bright and rich too. We love him. Schmitt is one of the first new-age music publishers. Last December, his company peoplesound.com was valued by US investment bank, Merrill Lynch, at £47m. Schmitt has a stake of 35 per cent which equates to £17m. His founding partner, Paul Levett, holds a five per cent stake which means that at the age of 29, he is also sitting on a £2.35m fortune. Peoplesound.com - spot the social democratic, egalitarian credentials - showcases new bands on the web and allows the record-buying public to buy CDs. Visitors to the site download two million tracks per month. Backed by French businessman Bernard Arnault, who owns luxury goods company LVMH, peoplesound.com will float some time this year at an expected market value of £80m. But it is the prospect of peoplesound being bought out which will really propel the art-loving Schmitt into the financial stratosphere. Peoplesound.com is an obvious content fit for a 'technology distributor' such as Yahoo! or an established music label. Schmitt's life so far is a catalogue of high-achievement. Son of a globe-trotting Proctor & Gamble engineer father and Uruguayan mother, he was born in the US and his early days were spent mainly in Belgium and Mexico. He studied at Cambridge, went to the Insead business school in France before doing a stint at Boston Consulting, one of the world's premier management consultancies. But when it comes to the business he is more reticent. He refuses to give any turnover figures but concedes that the site does not make money. In the crazy economics of the internet that does not matter. What does is first entry into virgin territory and cashing your chips before the bubble bursts. So the next year is make or break for Schmitt.

fields.headline: Germany
fields.standfirst: Denis Staunton in Berlin investigates why it is former East Germans who are exploiting the new media opportunities in unified Germany
fields.trailText: Denis Staunton in Berlin investigates why it is former East Germans who are exploiting the new media opportunities in unified Germany
fields.body:
When Stephen Schambach founded his first computer firm in the German town of Jena 10 years ago, his biggest problem was finding a phone. A local pastor came to the rescue, allowing the 19-year-old former physics student to move into his rectory, one of the few buildings with a functioning telephone line.

Schambach's company, Intershop, which makes software for internet retailers, is now worth £3.7bn and outperforms all other stocks on Frankfurt's Neuer Markt technology index. The firm's name is borrowed from a chain of hard currency shops in communist East Germany but the spirit that drives Schambach and his peers could not be further from that of former leader Erich Honecker.

"You find an increasing number of easterners between the ages of 20 and 24 who are starting new firms and often faring much better than their western counterparts. They are tougher and determined to have a different kind of life from that of their parents," according to Jens Reverchon of IMH, a venture capital firm based in Berlin and Hanover.

Until recently, Germany was the last place on earth to look for young entrepreneurs, not least because most Germans were almost 30 before they finished third level education. Bright teenagers stay in school until they are almost 20 and, if they want to avoid 10 months in military service, have to spend almost two years doing community work before going to university. Degree courses last at least five years, producing graduates looking for their first job when they are in their late twenties.

Germany's politicians have long been promising to reform the university system but a new generation is circumventing it by avoiding the universities in favour of technical colleges and business schools. "A lot of new firms are being set up by 22 or 23-year-olds who are still students. They'll often find a more experienced person to lead the company but they are not prepared to wait until they finish their studies before they go into business," says Reverchon.

A booming venture capital market means that, unlike their predecessors, today's young German entrepreneurs have no difficulty attracting investors. And Chancellor Gerhard Schröeder"s centre-left government is introducing a new tax regime that will transform Germany from one of the developed world's most highly taxed business environments into one of the lowest.

Big, established firms, such as Daimler Chrysler and Siemens, have started investing in young companies, and the soaring value of technology stocks in the US has persuaded many German firms to look for new acquisitions closer to home.

Many of the new millionaires produced by Germany's entrepreneurial renaissance come from modest backgrounds and they are more likely to invest their wealth in new businesses than to set up charitable foundations. As the economic recovery gains strength, Reverchon claims that Germany is fast becoming as fertile a territory for new business as Britain or the US and that, right now, conditions could not be better for the ambitious, creative young capitalist. "At the moment, there's too much money and too few ideas. Anyone with an interesting idea has an excellent chance in Germany right now."

 Denis Staunton writes for The Irish Times

Germany's young rich

1. Stephan Schambach, 28

East Germany's first home-grown multi-millionaire. Co-founder of Intershop Communications, valued at £3.7bn on the Neuer Markt technology exchange. Valued at £312 million

2. Marco Boerries, 30

Set up his first company in his father's garage aged 16 and went on to sell his Star Division internet services company to Sun Microsystems for stock now worth £94.3m . Valued at £94.3 million

3. Julian Riedlbauer, 23

Has a 27.5 per cent stake in the merged Riedlbauer Connect Service/Osnabrueker NT firm. Valued at £27.5 million

4. Jaye Muller, 26

East German musician and co-founder of Jfax.com which converts spoken language into electronic messages Valued at £15.7 million

5. Alexander Samwer, 24 Oliver Samwer 26 Marc Samwer, 28 Karel Doerner, 25 Max Finger, 29 Jorerg Rheinboldt, 27

Co-founders of Alando.de sold to the US group e-Bay for £31.4m. Valued at £5 million each

fields.headline: The young rich entertainers 11-20
fields.trailText: Catherine Zeta Jones | Robbie Williams | Naomi Campbell | Kate Moss | Liam Gallagher | Ewan McGregor | David Coulthard | Robbie Fowler | Shaznay Lewis | Kate Winslet |
fields.body:
11. Catherine Zeta Jones, 30

Actress. £13 million.

Since her starring role alongside Sean Connery in Entrapment, Zeta Jones is slowly beginning to match on screen the high profile which her relationship with Michael Douglas has guaranteed her off screen. She can now command between £5m and £6m per film, and has already signed up to three new projects, The Haunting, Ace in the Hole and a film version of Nick Hornby's book High Fidelity which should net her a minimum £15m. In an attempt to cement her future earning potential, Zeta Jones has also started to create her own dynasty through Zeta Films, a subsidiary of the Los Angeles based Initial Entertainment Group.

Her brother, Lyndon, will partner her in the two year, 12-film deal with IEG, with whom Zeta Jones's other brother, David, is a senior executive. There is speculation that the new venture is receiving £250m of backing to invest in the films but Zeta Jones will see very little of that money. 'Zeta Jones will add her name to the production credits, lending the films greater publicity, and might even offer her acting services to boost its box office,' says one senior Hollywood source.

Zeta Films will receive a percentage for each of the films, budgeted at between £3m and £30m. Her UK company Zeta Enterprise Limited was created in 1991 at the start of her career and her parents remain as directors. Since falling pregnant, Zeta Jones has dropped out of the Oliver Stone film, Beyond Borders. Her next project, High Fidelity, is unaffected - the filmmakers have agreed to only shoot her from the waist up. This is a conservative valuation because, although the Welsh actress has hit the big time, she is only now reaping the dividends.

12. Robbie Williams, 26

All-round entertainer. £11.25 million.

In the UK, Williams's first album, Life Thru a Lens has turned seven times platinum - selling 2.1m copies. The subsequent I've Been Expecting You has sold even better - more than 2.4m albums to date. In total, as a solo artist, Williams has sold over seven million records worldwide, suggesting that his home turf still proves to be the most lucrative for the former Take That star. Williams walked away from the group after a rift with songwriter Gary Barlow, having earned £5m.

And although he lags behind Barlow in the money stakes, his well-publicised problems with drugs and drink are not hindering his attempts to catch his former friend. This year, earnings from tours, record sales and sponsorships, including Pepsi have topped £5m. He has still to conquer the US but recent tours have paved the way. Still, his decision to buy a £4m house in Notting Hill suggests he is staying on this side of the Atlantic.

13. Naomi Campbell, 29

Model. £11 million.

Having escaped a possible prison sentence, when a court in Canada downgraded an assault charge brought against Campbell, she can now look forward to a better year. After a 16-year career, Campbell can earn up to £1.5m per year, but she has recently made it clear that she will be making fewer appearances - blaming stress for her decision to pull out of London and New York shows. However, she did a u-turn over her decision not to take part in London Fashion Week.

14. Kate Moss, 26

Model. £11 million.

For the last three years the waif with the estuary vowels has made an estimated £2.4m a year, and £1m for the three years prior to that. Her exclusive contract with Calvin Klein expired in January 1999, leaving her free to work elsewhere, but still receiving payment for its use of her image. A recent L'Oreal deal will rake in £3m over its lifetime, and Yves Saint Laurent and Bradbury advertising deals are likely to earn her £2m a time - her earnings soaring now she is free of the CK exclusivity clause. Moss can command £300,000 each time she takes to the catwalk, but now often does shows in the UK for free if she likes the designer.

15. Liam Gallagher, 27

Singer, Oasis. £8 million.

Gallagher is fast being aged by his lifestyle, child and wife, but remains the youngest member of an £18m band. From the outset, Oasis split the money equally, but since only Noel and Liam remain of the original line-up, it is likely that the new recruits have a lesser share. The band has just released its new album on the Big Brother label - the successor to Creation Records. It will doubtless prove even more lucrative than its predecessor Be Here Now which, despite lacklustre critical reaction, sold 6m copies in the UK alone, and considerably more worldwide.

As money from previous tours and the new record deal will now be in the Gallagher coffers, Liam's wealth is estimated at £8m. A sell-out world tour, plus a chunk of the £2.5m offered to perform at the Reading and Leeds festivals this summer, will further enhance the younger Gallagher's bank balance over the coming 12 months.

16. Ewan McGregor, 28

Actor. £8 million.

Although McGregor was paid just £1m for playing Obi Wan Kenobi in the third biggest-grossing film of all time, Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace, the prominence it earned him has begun to pay dividends. The Phantom Menace is expected to generate £2.5bn in merchandising. As his face will be on many of these products, it is likely that he was paid a fee at the outset. McGregor was contracted into the next two Star Wars films before he filmed The Phantom Menace, and can expect to earn little more than th £1m he received for the first prequel.

Before he met Lucas, McGregor was making smaller amounts on low-budget films such as Little Voice, South from Hell's Kitchen and the Nick Leeson biopic, Rogue Trader. But he has entered the big league and is set to play the lead alongside Nicole Kidman in Baz Luhrmann's Le Moulin Rouge. His post-Star Wars celebrity will prove rewarding, netting a reported £4m. He also holds a five per cent stake in the production company Natural Nylon Entertainment.

17. David Coulthard, 28

Formula One driver. £8 million.

As Coulthard lines up on the grid for today's Melbourne grand prix he will know that this is his make-or-break season. His wealth is enormous but as a driver he has never quite lived up to expectations. Although he finished third last year - bringing him £3m - observers are looking to him to challenge for top slot this season. If he doesn't, he could lose his seat in the McLaren car next year. As with other formula one drivers, Coulthard is barred from carrying non-McLaren sponsors, but sources say that the Scotsman still commands £1.5m per season from non-racing activities.

18. Robbie Fowler, 24

Footballer, Liverpool & England. £7 million.

Even if he was only paid by the game, Robbie Fowler would still be a wealthy man. His seven games since the start of the season would have raked in at least £378,000 before tax. Fortunately for the injury-ravaged striker, he gets £54,000 a week regardless. As the highest-paid footballer in the country, it was not surprising that a rumoured transfer to Arsenal came to nothing. His long-standing ankle problem was also a factor. He also picks up £500,000 per year from his boot deal with Nike. Dogged for several years by drugs rumours, which he has always denied, Fowler has recently become a father and started to settle down.

19. Shaznay Lewis, 24

Singer/songwriter, All Saints. £7 million.

All Saints have amassed 1.8m album sales in the UK, and a total of eight million worldwide. Lewis, as the band's songwriter, has seen the majority of the royalties from these sales. The new single, 'Pure Shores', appears on the soundtrack to The Beach. And although they did not receive an advance for the single, the film's high profile will pay dividends for the new album's summer release. It is likely that the other All Saints will have seen little more than £2m each from the band's success and that will not be boosted too much by the acting debut of the Appleton sisters - Nicole and Natalie - in the film Honest.

20. Kate Winslet, 25

Actress. £6 million.

Despite breaking into the Hollywood mainstream of late, Winslet has seen her fair share of bad deals. Titanic, her last appearance as an unknown, netted her a £200,000 fee plus a rumoured £600,000 bonus. Hideous Kinky was propped up by Winslet's own cash and proved something of a commercial failure, but that has not prevented her being able to command £3m a film. Winslet plays the title role in the forthcoming remake of Emile Zola's novel, Thérèse Raquin and symbolic of her desire to get more involved behind the scenes, she also works as an executive producer.

The executive role will provide her with a fee, and she will benefit from the kudos of being seen to be active behind the scenes. She is also starring alongside Harvey Keitel as Ruth in Jane Campion's Holy Smoke, and Quills, a film about erotic literature - two films which will increase her bankability.

Titanic, her last appearance as an unknown, netted her a £200,000 fee plus a rumoured £600,000 bonus. Hideous Kinky was propped up by Winslet's own cash and proved something of a commercial failure, but that has not prevented her being able to command £3m a film. Winslet plays the title role in the forthcoming remake of Emile Zola's novel, Thérèse Raquin and symbolic of her desire to get more involved behind the scenes, she also works as an executive producer. The executive role will provide her with a fee, and she will benefit from the kudos of being seen to be active behind the scenes. She is also starring alongside Harvey Keitel as Ruth in Jane Campion's Holy Smoke, and Quills, a film about erotic literature - two films which will increase her bankability.

fields.headline: The rich young entertainers 21-30
fields.trailText: Greg Rusedski | Ryan Giggs | Liam Howlett | Duncan Ferguson | Steve McManaman | Tim Henman | Michael Owen | Stan Collymore | Chris Sutton | Jude Law
fields.body:
21. Greg Rusedski, 26

Tennis player. £6 million.

One blazing month, during which he won close to £1m, turned 1999 into a more lucrative year than at one stage seemed possible. The man with a smokin' serve had failed to win a title all year, and had suffered a humiliating defeat in the US Open after he led Todd Martin by two sets to love, and served for the match in the third. But on a pacy court in Munich, he thundered aside all opposition to win the Grand Slam Cup and more than £800,000 in prize money. He spent the rest of October picking up further fat cheques in Basle, Vienna and Stuttgart, so that his year's winnings were more than £1.3m (taking his career total to £4.1m).

On the commercial front, he traded in an international contract with Nike and another with Wilson, for a 10-year clothing and racket association with Donnay that could on a good year - a grand slam victory - earn him £1m. The basic deal pays a retainer of £200,000 per season, with a guarantee of $1m for a grand slam win, or more if he ever became world number one. He has other sponsorship deals with Austin Reed, Jaguar and the internet provider Freeserve, which top up his annual income by close to £1m. Like rival Tim Henman, he too got married in December to a Lucy, drama student Lucy Connor.

22. Ryan Giggs, 26

Footballer, Manchester United & Wales. £6 million.

One of the old men of the United dressing room, Giggs turned 26 last November. A regular in the team since he was 17, he has won everything at United. He is under contract until 2003, but will be among the stars beating a path to Sir Alex Ferguson's door at the end of the season, looking for an improvement on his basic £1m salary in light of the decision to double his team mate Roy Keane's wages to £52,000 per week from next season.

A £300,000 bonus for winning the treble last season will have satisfied his passion for fast cars. But his main off-field wealth comes via Reebok which struck a six-year deal with Giggs valued at £6.5m in 1996 - he receives £475,000 per season for wearing the boots and the rest of the money comes from personal appearances and advertising.

Wherever that money goes, it is not being paid into Ryan Giggs Limited, the company created by the footballer in 1993 - an investigation of its accounts to the end of 1998 reveals assets of £861,000 but no sign of his salary or off-field payments. Already wealthy beyond his dreams the Cardiff-born Giggs would have to leave Old Trafford to secure a really big pay day - and he shows no sign of wanting to move on.

23. Liam Howlett, 28

Singer/songwriter, the Prodigy. £6 million.

Howlett, as the creative force behind dance act the Prodigy, has netted an estimated £6m from the band's worldwide sales. He receives a larger proportion of the sale value than the rest of the band and also reaps publishing royalties. Historically, the band's most lucrative deal came from an arrangement with the Allied Domecq-owned drinks brand Ballantine, which sponsored the band's tour from 1996 to spring 1998. The deal, it transpires, was worth less than the £3m initially reported, and is partly why Howlett's value has been reduced. His income has not been helped by the Prodigy's Bulgarian tour, which saw little profit and poor sales for his own solo remix collection, The Dirt Chamber Sessions.

24. Duncan Ferguson, 28

Footballer, Newcastle United. £5 million.

Ferguson has followed, almost to the letter, the caricature career of a professional footballer. He showed amazing promise at Dundee before his first big transfer - a £4m move to Glasgow Rangers. A second major transfer - a £4.3m move to Everton - was followed by a brief spell in prison for assault. He then prematurely retired as a Scottish international, settled down and started training homing pigeons. Twelve months ago he was on the move again to help balance the Everton books. This time the transfer fee was £8m and the buyer was Newcastle. Having never asked for a transfer but been involved in deals worth £16.3m, Ferguson would have picked up signing-on fees of around £2m during his career. A four-and-a-half year contract at Newcastle will pay £9m before tax - £2m per season. 3 entertainers continue on page 50

25. Steve Mcmanaman, 28

Footballer, Real Madrid & England. £5 million.

The former Liverpool striker has already picked up the first £3m tranche of his £15m, five-year, Real Madrid contract plus the new home and all the trappings of superstardom. His £60,000 per week deal puts the English league pay scale in the shade - not least because he will be paying substantially less tax than his former Liverpool colleagues. He has won over the Madrid fans with a string of good performances in an underperforming side and may form part of England's Euro 2000 squad if he stays free of injury.

26. Tim Henman, 25

Tennis player. £5 million.

No rags-to-riches story here, the gently nurtured son of a country solicitor and his dress-designer wife was never going to be short of a wad or two. His marriage last December to Lucy Heald, also from a comfortably off family from the home counties, gave him added security. But he has made the most of his great natural talent as an athlete to earn far more from whacking a tennis ball about than he would ever have done had he gone, say, into his father's business. For the first time in his career, his world ranking dropped in 1999 as he slipped from seventh to 12th, but his winnings for the year still came to just under £1m, taking his career total to more than £3m. He is now midway through a five-year, performance-related contract with Adidas that is expected to gross him £4.5m.

There are also tie-ups with Slazenger, Mercedes, HSBC and Robinson's, which boost his annual income by at least another £1.2m.

27. Michael Owen, 20

Footballer, Liverpool & England. £4.5 million.

Although he has had an injury-wrecked season - he has played only 60 minutes with strike partner Robbie Fowler all season, has had five hamstring injuries in 15 months and may miss Euro 2000 - it has not affected the earning power of the golden boy of English football.

He has ongoing deals with Walkers crisps, Pepsi, publisher HarperCollins, Jaguar cars and computer games manufacturer Eidos. His exclusive agreement with Umbro to be a 'brand endorser' runs until 2004 although there has already been speculation that it will be renegotiated and doubled to pay Owen £1m per season before too long. Last year we were conservative in our valuation of Owen and we continue to be so. He doubles his £1m basic salary with off -field endorsements but his agents, the SFX Sports Group, seem determined to ensure that his earning potential is not exploited to the extent that he suffers the sort of burn-out his hamstrings are currently experiencing.

28. Stan Collymore, 29

Footballer, Leicester. £4 million.

Treatment for depression at the Priory Clinic was probably the most expensive thing in the life of Stanley Victor Collymore in the past 12 months and even then Aston Villa picked up part of the bill. His stop-start career - he has attracted £15m in transfer fees - stalled at Villa and the troubled striker has been off limits to any commercial deals since attacking his then girlfriend Ulrika Jonsson in a Paris bar during the 1998 World Cup. But Stanley's contract at Villa guaranteed that he would be the highest-paid player and before his departure to Midlands rivals Leicester in February he was earning a basic of £20,000 per week - although he was not eligible for win or scoring bonuses because boss John Gregory refused to play him. His more modest £12,000 per week contract at Leicester is based on performances - and so Collymore now literally has to play for his money. His overall value remains unchanged since last year.

29 Chris Sutton, 27

Footballer, Chelsea & occasionally England. £4 million.

Having celebrated birthday number 27 last Friday, Sutton will be hoping that it brings better fortune. He was a near inclusion on last year's Young Rich list but fell just short. But his £10m transfer from Blackburn to Chelsea in the summer and £35,000 per week wages changes that. Unfortunately the improvement in his bank balance has not been matched by any on-field success and he has not been topping up his earnings via scoring bonuses - just one goal in the Premiership by the end of February. He was once the most expensive footballer in Britain when Blackburn paid Norwich £5m for his services in 1994, and in true football style he celebrated by spending a night in the cells of a Norwich police station. Last summer he became Chelsea's most expensive English recruit and arguably its biggest flop - at the time of going to press there is speculation that Sutton could be an £8m target for Celtic.

It would further swell his bank balance but do little for his reputation. Having refused to turn out for the England B team under Glenn Hoddle, there is talk that he could return to the England fold - but only if he starts scoring. His main commercial off-field activity is with Umbro - a deal which pays an annual retainer of £250,000 until 2002.

30. Jude Law, 28

Actor. £4 million.

With the exception of 1997's Gattaca, Law has only recently moved away from the low-budget British productions in which he made his name. eXistenZ, David Cronenberg's sci-fi epic, launched him into the Hollywood mainstream. But four years of relatively big cheques do start to add up. His Oscar nomination for The Talented Mr Ripley for which he was paid £500,000 - will catapult him further. Its high-profile has already led to his agents now asking for a reported £3.1m per film. He didn't get that for his next big role - alongside Ed Harris, Joseph Fiennes and Rachel Weisz in Jean-Jacques Annaud's Enemy at the Gates - for which he received between £1.5m and £2m. Law also has a 30 per cent stake in the production company Natural Nylon Entertainment, in which Ewan McGregor and Jonny Lee Miller also hold 5 per cent stakes. Natural Nylon has yet to make any money, but its first major production begins this year.

fields.headline: The young rich enertainers 1-10
fields.standfirst: They are very rich and very famous but the UK's wealthiest stars want more. The Observer reveals where the business minded celebrities invest and spend their money
fields.trailText: Victoria and David Beckham | Melanie Chisholm | Melanie Brown | Emma Bunton | Gary Barlow | Geri Halliwell | Jay Kay | Alan Shearer | Prince Naseem Hamed
fields.body:
1 and 2. Victoria Beckham, 25 Singer, aka 'Posh Spice'. £25.5 million.

David Beckham, 24 Footballer, Manchester United and England. £7 million.

Combined value £32.5 million

Already famous, David Beckham gained worldwide notoriety the night he kicked an Argentine while playing for England in the 1998 World Cup finals. An audience of millions watched the glamour boy of English football march off the pitch in disgrace and on to the cover of virtually every magazine in the world.

Just 13 days later, back in the UK, a company called Yandella was created with two directors Victoria 'Posh Spice' Adams and her mum Jackie. It is described as a 'general commercial company' and has until April to produce its first set of accounts. But on 1 March 1999 came the clearest signal yet of the true purpose of the company when Beckham became Yandella's third director.

The company has been created to maximise earnings from the future joint business activities of the new king and queen of celebrity. Among the first monies should be the £2.5m paid by television production company Planet 24 to film the run-up to their wedding last year.

This is the family business. Of more interest to Posh and Beckham watchers will be the role of her mother, Jackie, as company secretary and director. In theory that gives the Adams family a two-to-one majority at board meetings.

The name Yandella has no significance. It was an existing company bought 'off-the-shelf' but a source close to the couple says: 'The company was created for the service of these two individuals and their role together. Whatever that role may prove to be.' It provides the foundation for future ventures selling the 'Beckham' brand name. He has a string of contracts which more than treble his £1.3m annual on-field earnings - the most lucrative and long-term being with Adidas.

But he is a long way from fully exploiting his worldwide celebrity. Significantly he is expected to have both a longer career and greater worldwide earning potential than his wife. Yandella has been created to ensure that no deal is overlooked or opportunity spurned. And all of this is happening at a time when he looks like leaving Manchester United before his contract ends in May 2002.

Beckham is under pressure from his wife to move south - and under even greater pressure from United manager Sir Alex Ferguson to spend more time in Manchester. She has been quoted as saying Beckham is not paid enough - not a view shared by Ferguson. Beckham has already been linked with a £20m transfer to Arsenal, complete with a £3m signing-on fee and wages of £60,000 per week. But a host of Italian and Spanish clubs would be willing to break the world transfer record of £32m to sign him.

Underlining his potential earning power, one City analyst suggests that in the future some of the world's top footballers will be floated on the stock market. 'It is a radical idea but one that people are tentatively discussing,' says the analyst, 'not with the players but as an academic exercise.'

Such a move for Beckham would dwarf previous earnings and again Yandella could provide the basis for such a floated company. The Manchester Utd star has a separate business, David Beckham Ltd. Its most recent figures - those to the end of April 1998 - show assets of almost £400,000.

Like many big earners, Beckham will have offshore accounts and other investments. This valuation is based on his on-field earnings of £1.3m last year plus his existing commercial deals. It also takes into account his shopaholic tendencies -he spent almost £800,000 last year. But then if you are being groomed by your in-laws to be the 21st-century's first icon you can afford it.

3. Melanie Chisholm, 26

Singer, aka 'Sporty Spice'. £22.5 million.

Her private company, Red Girl Productions Limited, is the vehicle she uses to filter her Spice Girl wages from the central pot and, along with the others, to last autumn she had seen £21m. Given the time it takes revenue from touring and record sales to reach the artist, she can expect to make much more for the last financial year on account of the band's US tour and the 1997 £100m film, Spice World.

Industry sources suggest Virgin is unlikely to make any money from her debut LP, but the solo projects do allow Virgin (which handles all the solo projects) to make money out of the girls without relentlessly flogging the Spice Girls as a product. Chisholm joined the nest-building phase of the rest of the band when she purchased a flat in Mount Vernon, Hampstead for £1.5m.

4. Melanie Brown, 24

Singer, aka 'Scary Spice'. £22 million.

The first to get married, the first to give birth and now the first to be tripping the light fantastic to the divorce courts, Scary has had a bad 12 months on a personal front, which has provided priceless tabloid fodder.

Her brief marriage to Jimmy Gulzar seems to be coming to an end, with divorce lawyers queuing up to suggest that the dancer will be looking for a £1.5m settlement to accept the divorce. It seems likely that someone with Scary's advisers would have drawn up a watertight pre-nuptial agreement restricting any settlement to much less than £1.5m but love can do funny things to people.

Other than her stint as presenter on BBC2's Pure Naughty, her anchoring of the MOBO awards and a single with hip hop's Missy Elliott, this has been a quiet year financially for Mel B - which is reflected in the fact that her valuation has remained unchanged. Instead she has had to sit at home and count her Spice Girl money rolling in from previous tours, records and merchandising contracts.

And roll in it has. Along with the other four, she picked up wages of £6.2m to August 1998. That annual figure, swelled to at least £10m by monies from merchandising, film rights and other commercial spin-offs, has earned her £21m in Spice Girl earnings so far.

5. Emma Bunton, 24

Singer, aka 'Baby Spice'. £22 million.

Bunton has perhaps had the least success in establishing a solo identity. Her only solo record to date, 'What I Am', reached number two in the charts. She was at the centre of the recent court case with Aprilia Scooters - the company alleged breach of contract claiming that the Spices knew Geri Halliwell was leaving before signing a sponsorship agreement that involved all five of them - and demanded £1.4m in compensation.

Spice Girls Limited counter-sued for £212,500 - and lost. In evidence Bunton was forced to admit to 'a bad memory', extending to the fact she couldn't remember if Halliwell had told her she was leaving the then biggest band in the world. Hopefully, she can remember where she has put her fortune. If she is in any doubt, much of it is in Monsta Productions, her wholly owned private company. The purchase of a £2.5m penthouse in a converted Victorian workhouse in Hampstead will have soaked up some of her earnings.

6. Gary Barlow, 29

Musician. £20 million.

Barlow's revenues and royalties from Take That remain his main source of wealth despite the fact the band split up four years ago. He has done superbly from the band's 15m worldwide album sales and his first solo LP, Open Road, which he both wrote and co-produced, sold 3.5m copies in its first year.

But he has been relatively quiet in the past 12 months and, in a move which suggests he believes his future may lie in a different direction, Barlow has recently filmed a cameo performance for ITV's Heartbeat. But along with so many other first-time actors, Barlow, who considers himself worth £19m, can be content in the knowledge that even if the acting career doesn't take off he can always go back to the day job.

6. Geri Halliwell, 27

Singer, formerly 'Ginger Spice'. £19.6 million.

A trawl through Companies House records reveals that although she quit the Spice Girls in May 1998 - comparing it to 'leaving a marriage' - Geraldine Estelle Halliwell remained a director of six Spice Girls companies until 30 November 1999. She also retained a 20 per cent holding in Spice Girl Limited - the umbrella company for the entire group's other activities.

This is not just a technical oversight but a sign that while she left the Spice Girls with a £15m 'farewell' cheque, it was not full and final settlement. The deal also involved ongoing royalties for merchandising, tours and the Spice World movie. So although she claimed not to be a party to the recent legal case involving Aprilia Scooters (see above) she could be said to have had a direct financial interest as a shareholder of the company when the case was first brought against Spice Girls Limited.

On leaving the Spice Girls she signed a solo recording deal worth £3.2m which was soon followed by a £550,000 deal with publisher Transworld for her book If Only - the US rights were picked up by Dell which added a further £500,000 to her coffers. Her solo LP, Schizophonic, went platinum: these 300,000 copies barely approach the three million copies that Spiceworld sold - but then she doesn't have to split the proceeds five ways either.

Halliwell's profile, thanks to the ruthless exploitation of her personal life in the tabloid media, is second only to Posh - she turned up to give evidence at the Aprilia high court case brandishing an ad for her latest single.

Her valuation has risen over the past year in recognition of the advance from her record deal finally hitting her bank balance and in recognition of the extra 18 months of Spice Girl money, which has only just come to light.

8. Jay Kay, 30

Musician. £19 million.

Lead singer of Jamiroquai and fiance to the inexhaustible Denise Van Outen, Jay Kay has been one of the big sellers of the past decade. Confidence and magnitude have followed him since his signing to Sony on an eight-album deal in 1993. He scooped a £100,000 advance on the strength of one song. His second album, Travelling Without Moving, sold seven million copies worldwide, while the current LP, Synchronised, has been number one in most European countries and exceeded sales of four million. Extensive touring has earned him £2m, while his net wealth is augmented by Horsenden Manor in Buckinghamshire, valued at close to £2m, and a fleet of cars worth £1.5m.

9. Alan Shearer, 29

Footballer, Newcastle United & England. £17 million.

If his value was measured in charisma, Shearer wouldn't be on this list. Fortunately for the England captain, who retires from international football this summer, his career is based on goal scoring rather than wisecracking. He was one of the first players to appreciate the commercial opportunities football offered in the early Nineties and he has exploited it fully.

His Newcastle contract guarantees that he will always be the top paid player at the club - the arrival of Duncan Ferguson last season moved both players on to £40,000 per week. But it's off the field where he has proved even more shrewd, doubling his on-field earnings with a string of sponsorship and advertising contracts with the likes of Umbro, McDonald's, BT and Lucozade. Shearer, whose combined career transfer fees come in at just under £19m, signed an unprecedented 15 year boots and clothing deal with Umbro in 1997 that has so far netted him almost £2m. The Umbro deal could be worth a total of £20m over the 15 years. The Geordie has even started to take himself less seriously. A recent McDonald's advert included a young employee commenting that 'he is a bit boring' - but then he does earn a minimum £500,000 for each ad.

10. Prince Naseem Hamed, 26

Boxer and self-proclaimed 'king of the ring'. £17 million.

fields.bodyText: 1 and 2. Victoria Beckham, 25 Singer, aka 'Posh Spice'. £25.5 million. David Beckham, 24 Footballer, Manchester United and England. £7 million. Combined value £32.5 million Already famous, David Beckham gained worldwide notoriety the night he kicked an Argentine while playing for England in the 1998 World Cup finals. An audience of millions watched the glamour boy of English football march off the pitch in disgrace and on to the cover of virtually every magazine in the world. Just 13 days later, back in the UK, a company called Yandella was created with two directors Victoria 'Posh Spice' Adams and her mum Jackie. It is described as a 'general commercial company' and has until April to produce its first set of accounts. But on 1 March 1999 came the clearest signal yet of the true purpose of the company when Beckham became Yandella's third director. The company has been created to maximise earnings from the future joint business activities of the new king and queen of celebrity. Among the first monies should be the £2.5m paid by television production company Planet 24 to film the run-up to their wedding last year. This is the family business. Of more interest to Posh and Beckham watchers will be the role of her mother, Jackie, as company secretary and director. In theory that gives the Adams family a two-to-one majority at board meetings. The name Yandella has no significance. It was an existing company bought 'off-the-shelf' but a source close to the couple says: 'The company was created for the service of these two individuals and their role together. Whatever that role may prove to be.' It provides the foundation for future ventures selling the 'Beckham' brand name. He has a string of contracts which more than treble his £1.3m annual on-field earnings - the most lucrative and long-term being with Adidas. But he is a long way from fully exploiting his worldwide celebrity. Significantly he is expected to have both a longer career and greater worldwide earning potential than his wife. Yandella has been created to ensure that no deal is overlooked or opportunity spurned. And all of this is happening at a time when he looks like leaving Manchester United before his contract ends in May 2002. Beckham is under pressure from his wife to move south - and under even greater pressure from United manager Sir Alex Ferguson to spend more time in Manchester. She has been quoted as saying Beckham is not paid enough - not a view shared by Ferguson. Beckham has already been linked with a £20m transfer to Arsenal, complete with a £3m signing-on fee and wages of £60,000 per week. But a host of Italian and Spanish clubs would be willing to break the world transfer record of £32m to sign him. Underlining his potential earning power, one City analyst suggests that in the future some of the world's top footballers will be floated on the stock market. 'It is a radical idea but one that people are tentatively discussing,' says the analyst, 'not with the players but as an academic exercise.' Such a move for Beckham would dwarf previous earnings and again Yandella could provide the basis for such a floated company. The Manchester Utd star has a separate business, David Beckham Ltd. Its most recent figures - those to the end of April 1998 - show assets of almost £400,000. Like many big earners, Beckham will have offshore accounts and other investments. This valuation is based on his on-field earnings of £1.3m last year plus his existing commercial deals. It also takes into account his shopaholic tendencies -he spent almost £800,000 last year. But then if you are being groomed by your in-laws to be the 21st-century's first icon you can afford it. 3. Melanie Chisholm, 26 Singer, aka 'Sporty Spice'. £22.5 million. Her private company, Red Girl Productions Limited, is the vehicle she uses to filter her Spice Girl wages from the central pot and, along with the others, to last autumn she had seen £21m. Given the time it takes revenue from touring and record sales to reach the artist, she can expect to make much more for the last financial year on account of the band's US tour and the 1997 £100m film, Spice World. Industry sources suggest Virgin is unlikely to make any money from her debut LP, but the solo projects do allow Virgin (which handles all the solo projects) to make money out of the girls without relentlessly flogging the Spice Girls as a product. Chisholm joined the nest-building phase of the rest of the band when she purchased a flat in Mount Vernon, Hampstead for £1.5m. 4. Melanie Brown, 24 Singer, aka 'Scary Spice'. £22 million. The first to get married, the first to give birth and now the first to be tripping the light fantastic to the divorce courts, Scary has had a bad 12 months on a personal front, which has provided priceless tabloid fodder. Her brief marriage to Jimmy Gulzar seems to be coming to an end, with divorce lawyers queuing up to suggest that the dancer will be looking for a £1.5m settlement to accept the divorce. It seems likely that someone with Scary's advisers would have drawn up a watertight pre-nuptial agreement restricting any settlement to much less than £1.5m but love can do funny things to people. Other than her stint as presenter on BBC2's Pure Naughty, her anchoring of the MOBO awards and a single with hip hop's Missy Elliott, this has been a quiet year financially for Mel B - which is reflected in the fact that her valuation has remained unchanged. Instead she has had to sit at home and count her Spice Girl money rolling in from previous tours, records and merchandising contracts. And roll in it has. Along with the other four, she picked up wages of £6.2m to August 1998. That annual figure, swelled to at least £10m by monies from merchandising, film rights and other commercial spin-offs, has earned her £21m in Spice Girl earnings so far. 5. Emma Bunton, 24 Singer, aka 'Baby Spice'. £22 million. Bunton has perhaps had the least success in establishing a solo identity. Her only solo record to date, 'What I Am', reached number two in the charts. She was at the centre of the recent court case with Aprilia Scooters - the company alleged breach of contract claiming that the Spices knew Geri Halliwell was leaving before signing a sponsorship agreement that involved all five of them - and demanded £1.4m in compensation. Spice Girls Limited counter-sued for £212,500 - and lost. In evidence Bunton was forced to admit to 'a bad memory', extending to the fact she couldn't remember if Halliwell had told her she was leaving the then biggest band in the world. Hopefully, she can remember where she has put her fortune. If she is in any doubt, much of it is in Monsta Productions, her wholly owned private company. The purchase of a £2.5m penthouse in a converted Victorian workhouse in Hampstead will have soaked up some of her earnings. 6. Gary Barlow, 29 Musician. £20 million. Barlow's revenues and royalties from Take That remain his main source of wealth despite the fact the band split up four years ago. He has done superbly from the band's 15m worldwide album sales and his first solo LP, Open Road, which he both wrote and co-produced, sold 3.5m copies in its first year. But he has been relatively quiet in the past 12 months and, in a move which suggests he believes his future may lie in a different direction, Barlow has recently filmed a cameo performance for ITV's Heartbeat. webTitle: Unlimited access starts the real race to carve up cyberspace

fields.headline: Unlimited access starts the real race to carve up cyberspace
fields.standfirst: An end to metering is the first step to a bloody revolution, reports  Jamie Doward
fields.trailText: An end to metering is the first step to a bloody revolution, reports Jamie Doward
fields.body:
You wait ages for one to come and then three arrive at once. Last week's news that three Internet companies are to offer unlimited online access made front-page headlines and met with a warm welcome from Downing Street as a big step in its drive to ensure we are all online within five years.

The reactions seemed justified: unlimited or 'unmetered' access is seen as tremendously important by UK Internet companies. For years they have looked longingly at the US, where users have been able to surf with abandon in return for a one-off charge. Experts argue that UK Internet usage suffers by comparison. Online users here are conscious that they are paying by the minute, and thus limit their use of the Internet. US users spend twice as much time online as their UK counterparts.

But the decisions by US Internet search engine Alta Vista, cable company NTL and BT to offer unlimited access will have repercussions beyond turning us into a generation of Netheads. The moves can be compared to seismic shifts in the ocean floor, creating choppy waters above. The question now is how many will stay afloat?

The answer lies in which companies can make the 'free' model pay. Until now big Internet success stories such as Freeserve, the Internet service provider (ISP) that last week entered the FTSE 100, have generated a significant proportion of their revenue from connection charges. Each time you access the Internet through Freeserve, the ISP makes a few pence. Freeserve believes it makes 40p per user per month from this. At the last set of interim results, Freeserve had a turnover of just over £7 million, and roughly half of this came from connection charges.

Unmetered Internet access means this business model becomes difficult to justify. Surfers will opt to pay the likes of Alta Vista relatively small one-off fees for unlimited use, leading to what is known as 'bill shock' in the trade. As a result, Freeserve's shares fell by nearly 20 per cent at the start of this week as analysts speculated that it would have to subsidise the cost of unlimited access if it was to retain its market leading position.

This may have been a knee-jerk reaction. Freeserve has been wise to the notion that the ISP cash cow could not be milked forever, and has been desperately attempting to turn itself into a 'portal' - a must-visit Internet destination that users go to on a regular basis. To do this the company has teamed up with a raft of content providers and e-tailers: now whatever you are looking for, a visit to Freeserve will help you find it. The intention is to make money by exploiting this position through selling online advertising and e-commerce.

Since Freeserve has approaching 1.7 million users - outstripping its nearest rival, AOL Europe, by around 100,000 - it should be in a strong position to make the most of this intention, even when it succumbs to the inevitable and offers its own unlimited-access version. But Freeserve's problem - and ultimately that facing all those who intend to offer unlimited access in the future - is how to stop surfers straying away from the portal. There is nothing to stop you using an ISP's unlimited service to access the Internet and then, having passed through its gateway, leaving it to go elsewhere on the world wide web.

Until now, the ISPs could console themselves that they were making money from the connection side of things. Now this seems doomed to disappear. Continuing to charge significant amounts for access would result in users simply switching to an ISP that offers an unmetered service. 'If companies charge high tolls, they're going to get run over,' said Harris Miller, president of the Information Technology Association of America.

Figures show how serious the threat of wandering users is to even the Internet's biggest players. Miles Saltiel, Internet analyst at WestLB Panmure, said in a recent report: 'In January, Freeserve had 35 per cent of the access market ,but under 15 per cent of total site visits: in other words, users are logging on to Freeserve then going elsewhere.'

The challenge for the major players now is to stop their flock straying, so that e- commerce and online advertising revenues are sufficiently high to compensate for subsidising users' surfing time.

Two things are clear: content and connectivity are the new kings. Sounds familiar? Strangely enough these are also the key drivers that bring in the bucks for conventional television broadcasters. Just as viewers remain loyal to BBC1, Channel 4 or Sky Sports 1 - because they like their programmes, which can be watched easily and cheaply - so the online portals reckon the same must be true for their business strategies. 'What you're now seeing over here is the Internet equivalent of the TV licence. Just like TV, people are paying a certain amount of money upfront in return for unlimited access,' said Alex Birch, a director of Internet specialist OC&C Strategy Consulting.

Birch argues that some of the big US Internet portals are even starting to look like conventional broadcasters. 'It's the model the portals are trying to drive towards in the US. Look at what MSN (Microsoft's portal) is doing with its channels,' Birch said.

The most obvious example of this convergence of television and Internet business models came with the recent ground-breaking merger between America Online and Time Warner. Analysts now speculate about just how long it will be before a raft of Time Warner companies make their services available solely over the AOL network - anathema to all those who argue the Web's raison d' tre should be as a completely open system.

Alta Vista's strategy is similar to the AOL-Time deal in that its intention is to turn the search engine into a mega portal that directs users to content and services provided by its sister companies. The search engine is 83 per cent owned by US venture capital giant CMGi, which holds, or has stakes in, more than 60 other Internet firms. So when you use the Alta Vista search engine, the chances are you will see ads for sites and online services which, not surprisingly, are offered by companies owned by CMGi.

Likewise, NTL has ulterior motives for ensuring it encourages more people to sign up for its unlimited services. NTL plans to use the new service, called ntlworld, as a means to develop its wider ambitions.

NTL will soon launch its digital cable television package, and is currently bidding for a third-generation mobile licence. The plan is to heavily promote its unlimited Internet access to attract a critical mass of users who can then be migrated on to its other new services.

'It's a great opportunity to own customers,' said Janice Hughes of new media consultancy Spectrum. 'NTL is using the Internet as a marketing tool.'

And, of course, NTL has its own set of partners and content providers, who will be promoted on ntlworld, a 'world' the company hopes you won't want to leave. 'The service will be fresh, hugely broad and hugely deep,' a spokesman said. 'It won't just sell you a holiday; it'll tell you when the pool's open.'

So where does this leave BT? Playing a waiting game for now, seems the likely answer. BT is banned from entering the broadcast market until next year, so opportunities for building its own series of channels to rein users in are limited. Significantly, BT last week signed a deal with Yes TV, a company whose technology will one day see BT stream movies over its network.

The worry in the industry, however, is that such new developments will place unprecedented pressure on the telecoms infrastructure. As unlimited access explodes - Birch foresees at least four more ISPs opting for the unmetered model within the next six months - so some of the networks will struggle to cope with the extra traffic.

'It will be just like the National Grid. Everyone's watching the World Cup. You get to half-time and everyone goes to make a cup of tea,' said Internet analyst Simon Moores of consultancy The Research Group. 'In order to make unlimited Internet access available, a broadband infrastructure has to be in place. There's no such thing as a free lunch.'

Pundits have already been quick to predict that a new subscription model will emerge as a rival to the unmetered service. Users would pay for access to high- quality bandwidth, allowing them to access the Internet at much faster speeds.

All these pressures - the need for content, broadband and the ability to change business models almost overnight, not to mention the huge offline costs of promoting the online brand and subsidising free access - suggest that only the biggest players will survive in the Internet world of the future.

Consolidation between media, Internet and telecoms companies looks inevitable as the race to carve up the Web begins in earnest. And the free-thinking pioneers of the Internet can only stand by and mutter that it was never meant to be like this.

Riding this wave of generosity
The explosion in unlimited Internet access is bound to create confusion among consumers.

Basically, there will be at least three unlimited products, with their own pricing structures ,on the market in the next few months. Other, perhaps less heavily advertised products, will also come on to the market.

Alta Vista's package is based on a one-off, upfront fee of between £30 and £50 and then an annual fee of between £10 and £20. The company has not finalised the exact pricing structure or set a launch date, which at the moment could be any time within the next three months.

BT's SurfTime package, to be launched on 1 June, offers unmetered access for £29.25 a month for residential customers. Some users might prefer a different package costing £15.25 a month and offering unmetered access in the evenings and at weekends.

NTL , which will be the first to launch an unmetered Internet access package - on 17 April - has two deals, one for those who live in areas that take its cables, another for those who don't. If you live in a cabled area, you pay £9.25 a month for the phone line. Otherwise you pay a one-off charge of £10 for a telephone adaptor that connects to your BT line. Customers have to agree to pay a minimum of £10 a month on normal telephone calls.

Andrew Boswell, chief technology officer at ICL, says: 'Read the small print. People may well be confused by a complex choice of bundled Internet and voice tariffs, in much the same way as prospective buyers of mobile phones can be faced with a bewildering array of tariff choices.'

fields.headline: Mugabe slips deeper intoquicksands
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Robert Mugabe was in a fury. He had flown to Kuwait to borrow $100 million to buy the oil Zimbabwe desperately needs. Its roads are clogged with drivers waiting for petrol and in the townships residents queue for paraffin, widely used for cooking.
fields.byline: Andrew Meldrum  in Harare and Patrick Wintour  in London
fields.body:
Robert Mugabe was in a fury. He had flown to Kuwait to borrow $100 million to buy the oil Zimbabwe desperately needs. Its roads are clogged with drivers waiting for petrol and in the townships residents queue for paraffin, widely used for cooking.

Mugabe knows his Zanu-PF party will not do well in the forthcoming parliamentary elections in April and promised to sort things out personally.

But the Kuwaitis turned him down and Mugabe returned empty-handed and livid. He was convinced Britain and the United States had advised Kuwait not to help him out.

Back in Harare on Wednesday night, he seized on a way to get even. On 4 March a 7-tonne consignment Britain was trying to bring into Zimbabwe using diplomatic immunity had been impounded by Customs. The state media had already whipped up a furore, saying the shipment was suspiciously large.

So certain was Mugabe that it contained compromising material that he ordered Customs officials to break international protocol and search the shipment.

It was a major media event. Camera crews and reporters from the state press gathered to cover the coup. First they were treated to a demonstration by war veterans, Mugabe's most avid supporters. Singing and shouting, they demanded to be allowed to rip open the diplomatic bags themselves. They said they would find weapons or, even more dangerous, campaign material for Zimbabwe's opposition.

As Customs officials broke open the containers, sniffer dogs were trotted in. But all they found was some innocuous electronic equipment and tools, which was exactly what British officials had declared to Zimbabwe's Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The goods were soon released to British officials. The media were left without a story, but a new one quickly emerged.

Foreign Office Minister Peter Hain, outraged at Zimbabwe's blatant breach of the Vienna Convention, reacted immediately. He denounced the Mugabe government for acting 'increasingly like a rogue state', for leading Zimbabwe into 'economic chaos and increasing social instability and political isolation', and for its 'paranoia'. Hain recalled the British High Commissioner to Harare, Peter Longworth, for consultations. Zimbabwe has refused to apologise.

This worsening of diplomatic relations with Britain adds to Mugabe's already daunting list of crises. As well as the fuel shortages, there is the widespread invasions of white-owned farms, inflation of 60 per cent and runaway public debt.

According to a Gallup poll on Friday, 63 per cent of Zimbabweans believe 'it is time for a change' in government and 65 per cent would like to see Mugabe step down as President.

But as the week ended, Mugabe showed no sign of slowing down. He said on Friday that the war veterans could remain on the more than 400 commercial farms they have invaded over the past two weeks.

In a broadcast he accused the international community, particularly Britain, of giving him problems because he was getting land back from the whites.

He also told all local chiefs to persuade the people in the countryside, where a majority of the population lives, to vote for Zanu-PF in the parliamentary elections.

Morgan Tsvangirai, leader of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change, said: 'It's as if we were being driven along by a crazy bus driver at 150 kilometres an hour and we're being held hostage to his mad driving.'
