fields.headline: The patter of Tiny's feet
fields.standfirst: Donald Trelford was on the brink of being sacked as Observer editor by tycoon Tiny Rowland after he exposed atrocities in Zimbabwe. Now, 16 years later, he reveals the full story of the scandal that may yet end Robert Mugabe's presidencyZimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Donald Trelford was on the brink of being sacked as  Observer editor by tycoon Tiny Rowland after he exposed atrocities in Zimbabwe. Now, 16 years later, he reveals the full story of the scandal that may yet end Robert Mugabe's presidency
fields.body:
It began in the parched earth of Matabeleland, among the cactus and the baobab trees, and ended over lunch in a Park Lane casino, served by long-legged girls in fishnet tights. For two hectic weeks the battle was monitored in every news bulletin, causing anguished debates about press freedom in Parliament and the media - and almost led to the The Observer being sold to Robert Maxwell.

The public row between me, as editor of The Observer, and Tiny Rowland, then chief executive of Lonrho, the international conglomerate which had bought the newspaper three years before, grew into a Fleet Street soap opera that overshadowed the tragic human story that provoked it - the suffering of the minority Ndebele people at the hands of the North Korean-trained Fifth Brigade of the Zimbabwe Army.

This story may now finally emerge, for the Supreme Court has ordered President Mugabe to publish an official report into the atrocities which he has suppressed for 16 years. These revelations, if they come on the eve of the general election, set for the end of the month, could even hasten his overthrow.

After two decades, during which the economy has been ruined and corruption rife, Mugabe is looking vulnerable. He lost a referendum designed to entrench his constitutional position. In crude moves to boost his popularity, he has been encouraging Africans to take over white farms and has stoked up an international incident with Britain by opening our diplomatic bags in breach of the Vienna Convention.

For the first time since independence, however, the opposition has teeth and observers believe he can survive only by moving the electoral goalposts. Mugabe ruled supreme when I met him in April 1984. I went to interview him for the country's fourth anniversary of independence for a current affairs series on Channel 4. I also planned to write a piece for The Observer. I told Rowland about the visit as a courtesy, since his company had started in the former Rhodesia (hence 'Lonrho') and had major business interests there.

That was a mistake, since it gave Rowland an opportunity to ingratiate himself with Mugabe ('I have arranged for my editor to publish an interview in The Observer ') and repair relations that had been damaged by Lonrho's long support for the opposition leader, Joshua Nkomo. (I heard later that Lonrho had also supported Mugabe's Zanu party, but Mugabe never heard about this, because the cash had stuck to the fingers of an emissary who had used it to buy himself a house in Hampstead.)

When I arrived in Harare, I was met by Rowland's Zimbabwe 'fixer', Godwin Matatu, who whisked me off for lunch with Lonrho's local board. The interview was clearly to be a Lonrho production and Matatu, a gregarious, alcoholic journalist who died in 1989, was to be my minder.

The Mugabe interview was disastrously dull, unusable for television, of interest only to a specialist African magazine (where, in fact, it subsequently appeared). When I asked him if he would consider a political rather than a military solution in Matabeleland, where a curfew had been in force since February, he replied bluntly: 'The solution is a military one. Their grievances are unfounded. The verdict of the voters was cast in 1980. They should have accepted defeat then.' Then he added chillingly: 'The situation in Matabeleland is one that requires a change. The people must be reoriented.'

After I had appeared as guest of the week on ZBC, I was recognised by a group of Africans in the lobby of Meikles Hotel. One took me aside conspiratorially: 'You should go to Matabeleland to see what is happening to our people there. There are terrible things.' He hurried away, as if afraid to be overheard.

No media had been allowed inside the curfew area for 10 weeks, but there were rumours about brutal treatment of the population by Mugabe's soldiers, ostensibly searching for 'dissidents' from across the Botswana border. I said to Matatu: 'Let's go to Bulawayo in the morning.'

We found little sign there of military activity, just the odd 'hippo' armoured personnel carrier trundling along a dirt road with mounted guns, or a truck-load of troops with rocket-propelled grenades on their AK-47 rifles. Rain had made the Lowveld roads almost unpassable.

Schoolgirls were marching quietly in green check dresses or lying in the shade; old men scratching with hoes; cattle standing in the dry river beds; goats, donkeys, marmosets, even a kudu bull, dashing across the road.

We knew we weren't allowed officially into the curfew area, but asked our driver to brave the roadblocks anyway. We passed three without bother, all manned cheerily by policemen in brown boots, then Matatu did some name-dropping to persuade a tough-looking soldier to let us through. We were able to drive through the no-go areas, past Kezi, Antelope Mine, Bhalagwe Camp - all names, I learned later, that filled the Ndebele with dread. We saw nothing unusual.

Around 10pm, there was a call from the hotel reception to say that a man wanted to deliver a letter. An African tapped on the door and handed it over. It read simply: 'Please accompany this friend.' Moving quietly to avoid disturbing Matatu next door, I followed the man to the car park, where a headlight beamed in recognition.

I had no idea where I was going, or who with; and nobody knew where I'd gone. I knew instinctively that I couldn't take Matatu with me. Apart from the Lonrho connection, he was a Shona and close to the government and his presence would have deterred people from speaking honestly.

I climbed nervously into the car and was taken in silence for several miles out of town into the curfew area. There - after a semi-comic interlude in which we gave a lift to a policeman - we stopped at a remote house, pipped horns for ages, and finally changed cars with another man.

He took us for another long ride to a religious mission where, for much of the night, I was given a series of eyewitness accounts, sworn affidavits and signed statements from victims of the Matabeleland atrocities. These were graphic, horrific and profoundly moving.

One name kept recurring, as in a nightmare. Brigadier Shiri, known as Black Jesus, was head of the Fifth Brigade. And there was one recurring story, about a major who held up a dead baby and told villagers: 'This is what will happen to your babies if you help dissidents.' He then dropped the tiny corpse in the dust.

Back in the car again, I met a man from Esigodoni village who had been beaten close to death by agents of the Central Intelligence Organisation (CIO) in front of his family. They were warned they would be shot if they uttered a sound. 'They began beating us with sticks and guns, bayoneting us, burning plastic against our skin while our hands and mouths were secured. They tore curtains, put cushions into our mouths. We were tortured for about four hours.'

A man called Jason was brought to the house. He had been chopping trees at Welonke when two soldiers turned up with fixed bayonets and whips on their belts. They asked if he and his wife had seen any dissidents and grew increasingly angry when they said they hadn't. They beat his wife and grandmother and took him away.

Neighbours were collected and they all marched on, their progress broken by periodic beatings and a fight they were forced to stage for the soldiers' entertainment. At the village school they shot two children who had tried to run away. Eventually nine of them were forced to dig a hole to a depth of two or three feet and ordered to jump into it.

Jason told me: 'The commander leaned against a tree, opened his radio cassette and shot five men. On the grave we put branches. I also saw a big grave which had stones in it. There are 16 buried in this grave.'

Earlier I had come across Peter Godwin, of the Sunday Times, who said bodies had been thrown down a nearby mineshaft owned by Lonrho. (Later, Roy Hattersley was sued by Rowland for making this claim in a speech - what Rowland never knew was that I had helped draft Hattersley's speech.)

Godwin had already got some atrocity stories into print, but he was inhibited by the fact that he couldn't betray his presence in the curfew area for fear of being expelled or, as a Zimbabwean himself, suffering even worse retribution. Once he understood that I hadn't been sent by Rowland to put a Mugabe spin on the situation, we exchanged useful information.

I returned to the hotel at dawn, checked out without waking Matatu, then flew to London via Harare, arriving on Saturday morning with my story written. While in Harare I had two conversations. One was with a military attaché at the British High Commission, who wasn't at all surprised by the news from Matabeleland.

The other was with a South African director of Lonrho, Nick Kruger, who wasn't surprised either. 'What you have discovered, Donald,' he said, 'is the eternal truth of Africa. Stuff them, then they stuff you. For centuries we stuffed the blacks; now it's their turn to stuff us. The Ndebele stuffed the Shona; now it's the Shonas' turn. '

My dilemma on returning - should I publish an anodyne interview with Mugabe or tell the truth about Matabeleland, thereby damaging the interests of my proprietor? - has since been written up as a classic case by the Institute of Global Ethics. For me, there was no choice.

I decided to ring Tiny around 5pm on Saturday, too late for him to do anything to stop publication, but before he could hear the news from anyone else. He slammed the telephone down after threatening the direst revenge.

Next morning I turned on the BBC eight o'clock news to hear my story condemned as lies in an official statement by Mugabe, supported by a letter of apology from Rowland: 'I take full responsibility for what in my view was discourteous, disingenuous and wrong in the editor of a serious newspaper widely read in Africa'. He described me as 'an incompetent reporter' and announced that I would be dismissed.

I went ahead with a planned holiday to Guernsey, but quickly returned on the advice of Lord Goodman, the former Observer chairman, who said I must be seen on the bridge of my ship. The story was front-page news for a fortnight, 'the most entertaining hullabaloo', as one writer put it, 'since Harry Evans fell out with Rupert Murdoch'.

Rowland wrote me an open letter, which he distributed to all papers before I could see it, saying Lonrho would not go on supporting a failing editor who showed no concern for their commercial interests. I replied in kind, pointing out that the circulation had actually gone up by 22 per cent in the eight years I had been editor. The Daily Mail published both letters in full under the headlines 'Dear Donald' and 'Dear Tiny'.

Rowland insisted that I should go back to Zimbabwe for a longer investigation. I refused, on the grounds that I had already established the truth of my story and that to do so would endanger the lives of my sources.

The Foreign Office, more concerned about relations with Mugabe than with human rights and doubtless sensitive that Britain had provided some training for the Fifth Brigade, was briefing against me. I learnt this from Prince Charles, with whom I happened to have lunch at that time. 'The Foreign Office tell me you were wrong about Matabeleland,' he said airily. I ate my soup in silence.

Not all the papers were on my side. Paul Johnson said editors had no business trying to be reporters. John Junor wrote: 'If Mr Trelford truly feels that way about Mr Rowland, wouldn't it be more honourable for him to stop accepting Mr Rowland's money?' The Times suggested I had forced a showdown deliberately. The Daily Telegraph said: 'Those who pay the piper must be expected to demand some influence over the choice of tunes he plays.'

The Guardian said the paper should 'find its salvation where the people who write the cheques and the people who write the words can work together'. This proved difficult at The Observer when Lonrho announced it was withdrawing financial support. Provoked by a ruling from The Observer 's independent directors that Rowland had interfered improperly, it put a hard-faced accountant in the office to stop me spending money.

This brought questions in Parliament. When Peter Shore for Labour asked Norman Tebbit what he planned to do to protect the editorial independence of the editor of The Observer, the Secretary for Trade and Industry clearly enjoyed saying 'Nothing'. This was soon after the paper's revelations about Mark Thatcher's business connections with Oman.

The Observer 's journalists were highly supportive of their editor - until Rowland let it be known he was planning to sell the paper to Maxwell. A meeting at Claridges was announced for the next day. I knew Rowland would never sell to Maxwell and this was just a bluff to frighten the journalists. If so, it certainly worked.

I was interested to hear an interview with Maxwell about The Observer on my car radio. He 'greatly admired' me, he said, and would retain me as editor. Then, asked what he would have done about the Mark Thatcher stories, he paused and replied in his deepest tones: 'I'd have stamped on him.'

By now I felt the paper was being damaged and something had to be done to break the deadlock. So I wrote to Rowland offering my resignation - 'I could not allow the paper's future and the prospects of its staff to be jeopardised by my personal position, which sadly seems to be all that stands in the way of the paper's development.'

Rowland seized the olive branch and we made up over an edgy lunch in the incongruous ambience of one of Lonrho's London casinos. Undeterred by the pop music and scantily dressed females, we concocted a priceless statement that we shared an affection for three things - Africa, The Observer and each other.

For us and for the paper, that was the end of a remarkable and in some ways entertaining episode. For the people of Matabeleland, however, it provided only brief illumination before the darkness came again.

 Donald Trelford was editor of The Observer from 1975 to 1993 and is now Professor of Journalism Studies at Sheffield University

fields.headline: Newspaper dot.coms vs BBC brandwagon?
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: On the press
fields.body:
It was another wonderful week on the Net. Free this, free that and even free promises of universal surfage from Tony Blair. Who cares about the fine print when everyone's scenting zillions? But maybe Fleet Street and the BBC should start to care: they'll be going to war soon over this uniquely rich greenfield site.

The warning figures are there for the Beeb, buried in another of the reports they love to commission from McKinsey. Net usage in America is growing almost exponentially, and it's beginning to hurt TV viewing figures. Now such hurt is coming to a living room nearer home. You can't surf and cook couch potatoes at the same time. You have to have a huge stake in the new media, because it will be a huge part of your future.

And, of course, top newspaper executives have identical research forebodings shivering the timbers on their office desks. Here the warnings are starker yet. Five or 10 years on, will there even be a market place for printed words on paper?

Migration to the Net is not some optional extra: you neglect defensive action at your peril. You have to be a player - which, in the torrent of mergers and takeovers, means being a big player. Watch this cyberspace.

The BBC has certainly been doing that, and the news from its briefings is euphoric as well as highly convenient. Put together the Corporation's existing online services, add many more around the world, make strategic liaisons - and you're talking amazing wealth. If revenues hit their estimated £1.4 billion by 2006 (with the usual Internet premium added) the worth of the Corporation's commercial arm could turn Rupert Murdoch green.

At the moment, all the commercial stuff contributes around 4 per cent of BBC revenue: shrimp statistics against the annual £2bn-plus from the licence fee. But that balance is changing with bewildering rapidity. Who, Greg Dyke may shortly ask, needs a fat licence increase to feed our digital ambitions? The £1.5bn of imposed 'savings' over five years may be easy pickings.

Rosy scenarios to make almost everyone happy. The Beeb finds a crock of gold and becomes a true world force; the politicians don't have to keep on taking nasty licence fee decisions; the viewer gets more money spent on programmes and channels while paying (absolutely or relatively) less. Where's the catch?

It is, of course, in what happens all around - to a competition out-gunned. BBC Worldwide, the aforementioned commercial arm, already has trouble on that count. When Gavyn Davies looked at Corporation funding last year, he found ITV, independent radio, the Advertising Association and many more queuing to complain about unfairness; and Davies wasn't unsympathetic. 'Very real issues arise when a public service broadcaster enters the commercial arena and, as usual, the devil is in the detail.'

Thus far the BBC has sought to silence such devilry through an elaborate code of practice ensuring 'clear separation between publicly-funded and commercial activities', but the Net is a Hellfire club of complications.

Take BBC Online, already Europe's most significant portal, boasting more than 100 million hits a month (half of them outside Britain). A service without advertising to you or me, sitting at home in the UK, because we're licence fee payers - but not necessarily so, as it's run out across the world in related sites such as BBCAmerica - and vestigially 'separated' from Beeb.com, Worldwide's existing commercial shop window.

You can't put BBC Online down. It's a lush package of news and information. But then it should be. Even last year it cost £23 million to run (11 times the cost of BBC Parliament) - which, give or take the odd bob, is the editorial cost of producing a national paper such as the Independent. The marketing is vast and constant, but cheap. Almost every TV and radio programme automatically cross-refers to the website. BBC branding naturally dominates. We pay for it. We can't, in the nicest sense, get away from it.

For the user, though, this isn't like ordering a different cable channel. A single key stroke takes you from Online to Beeb.com; they're two peas in the same electronic pod. But the overwhelming reason for logging on to them is Online's commodious news service which, unlike that of every other competitor, real or potential, doesn't even have to think about making a profit because the licence fee covers all that.

Newspapers don't have the luxury of throwing up their hands and retreating. They, too, are having to pour millions into the Net, putting their own news online and swimming in red ink as a result.

There are sites that will reap big dividends. (The FT pounds on). There are sites that win prizes and may, in time, produce a good revenue stream (such as Guardian Unlimited , with 12 million hits a month). Yet the BBC already sits in the middle of the essential battlefield, replete and vastly strong.

Like anything else as the Net balloon heads into the stratosphere, today's prediction may be tomorrow's small print apology.

BBC Worldwide management isn't universally beloved by those who work with it. Post-tax profits of £12m last year on a turnover of £420m wouldn't set any normal business world alight.

But make no mistake: Mr Dyke's Beeb is parked right in the firing line - and newspapers, when they look around them, are bound to start shooting.

webTitle: Bulger killers to be free by 2003

fields.headline: Bulger killers to be free by 2003
fields.standfirst: Bulger case: special report
fields.trailText: Jack Straw will tomorrow announce that Jamie Bulger's killers will walk free in three years time. Straw is expected to make a statement to the Commons that he has decided Robert Thompson and Jon Venables could be freed in 2003, when both will be 20. It is thought that experts have deemed neither to be any longer a threat to the public.
fields.body:
Jack Straw will tomorrow announce that Jamie Bulger's killers will walk free in three years time. Straw is expected to make a statement to the Commons that he has decided Robert Thompson and Jon Venables could be freed in 2003, when both will be 20. It is thought that experts have deemed neither to be any longer a threat to the public.

Straw's decision has been expected since December, when the European Court of Human Rights decreed that Michael Howard, Home Secretary in 1993 when the boys were jailed, acted illegally when fixing a 15-year sentence for them.

The Home Secretary had the option of referring the case to the Lord Chief Justice, Lord Bingham, for a full review, given the long-standing confusion over serious child crimes and the open-ended sentences imposed.

His other two options were to accept the original sentence of eight years set by the trial judge, Mr Justice Morland, which would have meant the boys walking free next year, or the 10-year tariff imposed later by the then Lord Chief Justice after a campaign by James Bulger's parents. He opted for the latter.

His statement comes as The Observer learns that in future such cases will not be tried in the adult courts. Straw will admit he accepts the European ruling that the trial of Thompson and Venables breached their human rights. The announcement will come in the week when James Bulger would have celebrated his 10th birthday - the age Thompson and Venables were when they killed him with a 22lb railway fishplate in Bootle, Merseyside.

The announcement will be made as part of sweeping reforms of the criminal justice system, including a huge expansion of tagging and drug testing by the police.

The European Court of Human Rights decided an adult court was not the appropriate place to try Thompson and Venables. It is thought a new tribunal will be set up for children accused of serious crimes. It is likely these tribunals will adopt the inquisitorial system that operates in Scotland and many European countries, rather than the adversarial approach.

At the heart of a new Criminal Justice Bill to be introduced this week will be a root-and-branch reform of the penal system, opening the way to the eventual merging of the prison and probation services in a US-style Department of Corrections.

A National Correctional Strategy Board will be set up to co-ordinate the punishment of criminals in jail and in the community. The board will be chaired by Home Office minister Paul Boateng and will include the director of the Prison Service and a new national director of the Probation Service, to be appointed later this year.

Party sources said the Government wanted a shake-up of the social work image of the Probation Service in the run-up to the election campaign, during which they will emphasise New Labour's law and order credentials. Ministers want the Probation Service to find a new role as a punishment agency alongside the police and the Prison Service.

Boateng said last night: 'This is a new beginning for the Probation Service as a law-enforcement agency. We are ensuring that it is equipped to play its part alongside the Prison Service in developing corrections.'

The moves are likely to cause fury in the Probation Service, whose officers traditionally identify with the caring professions. National Association of Probation Officers spokesman Harry Fletcher said last night: 'It is clear that the long-term aim is a unified corrections service and that will appall many probation staff. We fear that the counselling role will be completely overwhelmed by prison warehouse culture.'

Ministers also hope the changes will lead to the reform of the Prison Service. They have been concerned by recent reports into Wormwood Scrubs and Wandsworth which described militaristic, brutal regimes.

Straw warned this weekend that the prison population would continue to rise for the foreseeable future. He said it was the duty of the Home Secretary to provide extra prison places.

The prison population has increased by 25,000 since 1990 to 65,000, and is the second highest per head of population in Europe, behind Portugal.

webTitle: Take care Tony, that man has blood on his hands

fields.headline: Take care Tony, that man has blood on his hands
fields.standfirst: Evidence shows secret police were behind 'terrorist' bomb
fields.trailText: The photograph below of a detonator pre-set to explode a bomb calls into question Russian leader Vladimir Putin's line - endorsed by Tony Blair during his visit to Russia yesterday - that Chechen terrorists were responsible for the explosions that killed more than 200 Russians last year.
fields.body:
The photograph below of a detonator pre-set to explode a bomb calls into question Russian leader Vladimir Putin's line - endorsed by Tony Blair during his visit to Russia yesterday - that Chechen terrorists were responsible for the explosions that killed more than 200 Russians last year.

Two bombs went off in Moscow, but a third bomb planted in Ryazan, 100 miles south, was defused by bomb squad officer Yuri Tkachenko who said: 'It was a live bomb.' It was made of the same explosive, Hexagen, and planted in a similar target - a working-class block of flats.

The third bomb did not go off because the bombers were caught red-handed. They were Russian, not Chechen, and when they were arrested by local police they flashed identity cards from the FSB - the new styling for the KGB, the secret police Putin headed before he became Russia's acting President. Two days later the FSB announced that the third bomb had only been 'a training exercise'.

The Kremlin's evidence that Chechen terrorists bombed Moscow is extremely thin. After the bomb outrages, secret police in the FSB handed out Photofit pictures of unnamed Chechens. No suspects were arrested and no convincing explanation was given to the public.

The third bomb was found in the basement of the flats on the night of 22 September at around 9pm. Tkachenko said: 'It was a live bomb. I was in a combat situation.' He tested the three sugar sacks in the basement with his MO-2 portable gas analyser, and got a positive reading for Hexagen, the explosive used in the Moscow bombs.

The timer of the detonator was set for 5.30am, which would have killed many of the 250 tenants of the 13-storey block of flats. The sacks were taken out of the basement at around 1.30 am and driven away by the FSB. But the secret police forgot to take away the detonator, which was left in the hands of the bomb squad. They photographed it the next day.

The bombers were discovered by the people they meant to kill. Vladimir Vasiliev, an engineer com ing home for the night, noticed three strangers acting suspiciously by the basement of his block of flats at 14/16 Novosyolov Street, literally New Settlers Street.

Vasiliev noticed that the number plate at the front of the car had been covered up with a piece of paper, on it '62', the Ryazan regional code. At the back of the car the plate had the Moscow regional code.

Vasiliev, puzzled, decided to call the police. 'As we were waiting for the lift, one of the young guys got out of the car and the girl asked: "Have you done everything?" '

Vasiliev observed the three in the car: 'They were Russian, absolutely, not Asiatic. The girl was a blonde.'

The local police arrested two men that night, according to Boris Kagarlitsky, a member of the Russian Institute of Comparative Politics. 'FSB officers were caught red-handed while planting the bomb. They were arrested by the police and they tried to save themselves by showing FSB identity cards.'

Then, when the headquarters of the FSB in Moscow intervened, the two men were quietly let go.

Police Inspector Andrei Chernyshev was the first to enter the basement. He said: 'It was about 10 in the evening. There were some strangers who were seen leaving the basement. We were told about the men who came out from the basement and left with the car with a licence number which was covered with paper. I went down to the basement.

'This block of flats had a very deep basement which was completely covered with water. We could see sacks of sugar and in them some electronic device, a few wires and a clock. We were shocked.

'We ran out of the basement and I stayed on watch by the entrance and my officers went to evacuate the people.'

The following day, on 24 September, the FSB in Moscow announced that there had never been a bomb, only a training exercise. Vasiliev said: 'I heard the official version on the radio, when the press secretary of the FSB announced it was a training exercise. It felt extremely unpleasant.'

webTitle: Putin plays hardball in summit with Blair

fields.headline: Putin plays hardball in summit with Blair
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday risked the wrath of human rights groups by giving Russian acting President Vladimir Putin, who has led a brutal military onslaught on Chechnya, his broad seal of approval.
fields.byline: Andy McSmith and Ian Traynor in St Petersburg
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday risked the wrath of human rights groups by giving Russian acting President Vladimir Putin, who has led a brutal military onslaught on Chechnya, his broad seal of approval.

Putin, who has just announced his intention to impose direct presidential rule on Chechnya, robustly defended the policies which have reduced Grozny to rubble and made it plain that he had no intention of bowing to Western pressure to halt the onslaught.

He surprised observers by asking for Western support to combat terrorism in his country, citing the British experience in Northern Ireland as an example his security forces could learn from. Britain has declined his request.

Blair's visit and the cordial tone of his meetings with Putin, is being seen as a major coup for the Russian leader who will almost certainly be elected President later this month.

When Blair and Putin emerged after two hours of talks in the Petrodvorets Palace, the Russian President appeared to make a significant concession to Western outrage over the slaughter in Chechnya.

He claimed that Russia was ready to listen and 'make adjustments' and would consider whether to allow international observers from the Red Cross and other organisations into the war zone.

But the British delegation warned afterwards that no new concrete concessions had emerged from the talks.

While Blair told Putin that there should be 'objective' investigations of human rights violations in Chechnya and complained that Russia's response to Chechen secessionism was 'disproportionate', British officials appeared to accept much of Putin's argument.

A Downing Street official said: 'There is a terrorist insurrection there on their [Russia's] territory.'

Such a view of the Chechen conflict will delight the Russian leadership. The Blair visit was the first time a Western head of government has met Putin since he succeeded Boris Yeltsin.

Putin, 47 to Blair's 46, made much of the things he said he had in common with the Prime Minister.

Heading off with his wife Lyudmila to spend an evening at the opera with Blair and his wife, Cherie, Putin described the Prime Minister as 'a very pleasant and a very appropriate partner. We're both law graduates and of the same generation ... We consider the Prime Minister's visit very significant ... Our countries are natural partners and at critical periods in world history they always stood together'.

Blair said it was 'a privilege' to be in St Petersburg and refuted suggestions that he was sending the wrong signal by meeting Putin only two weeks before Russia's presidential election and against the background of atrocities in Chechnya.

'It is in the interests of the whole world that Russia is a successful and engaged nation,' said Blair. 'We've had a very good and full discussion ... I want to say how much I have enjoyed that dialogue.'

Putin signalled on Friday that he intended to impose direct presidential rule on Chechnya 'for a couple of years' after the election on 26 March and stressed that any political talks on Chechnya's future would not countenance secession.

webTitle: Sharif team call for trial move after lawyer's killing

fields.headline: Sharif team call for trial move after lawyer's killing
fields.standfirst: Pakistan coup: special report
fields.trailText: Lawyers for Pakistan's deposed Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif insisted yesterday his trial should be moved away from Karachi after one of his defence team was shot dead. The demand is likely to further delay the drawn-out case, which was due to resume tomorrow.
fields.body:
Lawyers for Pakistan's deposed Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif insisted yesterday his trial should be moved away from Karachi after one of his defence team was shot dead. The demand is likely to further delay the drawn-out case, which was due to resume tomorrow.

Iqbal Raad was killed with two other men as he sat at his desk on Friday. Three gunmen, one carrying a Kalashnikov rifle and the others pistols, ran from the building into a waiting car. Police have made no arrests and no one has claimed responsibility for the murders.

Hundreds of lawyers gathered for Raad's funeral. Sharif himself asked to leave jail to attend the burial but permission was refused.

Sharif's defence team said they would not attend tomorrow's hearing. 'We want a change of venue to Islam abad or Lahore,' said Khwaja Sultan, the leading defence counsel. 'We will not be going to Karachi. It is not safe.'

fields.headline: Take a risk: buy beer and fags
fields.trailText: Put £10,000 into a building society and you will be lucky to get 5.5 per cent interest, after basic-rate tax is deducted. Put the same amount into the shares of household names such as British American Tobacco, Thames Water or Abbey National and you could get annual income, or yields, of 7 per cent or more, plus the prospect of a growing investment.
fields.body:
Put £10,000 into a building society and you will be lucky to get 5.5 per cent interest, after basic-rate tax is deducted. Put the same amount into the shares of household names such as British American Tobacco, Thames Water or Abbey National and you could get annual income, or yields, of 7 per cent or more, plus the prospect of a growing investment.

The generous yields are a side-effect of the City's obsession with technology, telecom and media stocks. Anything without an Internet connection is being ditched as investors queue to buy into the growth stories of the new. The result is that some of the old-fashioned stocks now offer outstanding value. When the obsession with growth ends, that value will be appreciated once again.

But it is essential to choose your investments carefully. Often a high yield is a danger sign. It may mean that the company is about to cut its dividend - or, worse, get into financial difficulty. Thus Somerfield, the food retailer, seems to offer a 21.5 per cent yield. But that is based on last year's 12.9p dividend payment: it has already warned it will be slashed to 4.5p - and some analysts wonder whether that is sustainable.

Likewise, some water companies appear to offer generous levels of income. But they are struggling under increasingly severe regulation, which has already led two companies to cut dividends.

Elsewhere, a high yield is the compensation investors demand for the risk that shares will fall. Royal & Sun Alliance has a yield of 8 per cent because the City dislikes its reliance on car and household insurance.

That said, a number of companies seem to offer the prospect of increases in both dividend and share price - although, for the latter, you may have to wait for technology fever to die down. Most are in old-fashioned sectors such as brewing, food, or housebuilding.

Abbey National shares plunged on fears that it will lose market share to Internet banks and nimbler rivals. But the shares, on a yield of nearly 8 per cent, are now discounting too much disaster.

Thames Water, which offers a 7 per cent yield, is one of the few utilities expected to survive the regulatory crackdown relatively unscathed and its shares are due for a re-rating. Builders such as George Wimpey and brewers such as Scottish & Newcastle, all on yields of 6 per cent or more, should eventually be back in favour.

Food companies such as Northern and Unigate are shunned because their businesses, supplying supermarkets with ready meals, milk and yoghurt, are seen as mature and susceptible to margin pressure. But both now look too cheap, and it is worth buying shares before their sell-by date passes. The final recommendation offers the highest yield but also the greatest risk. British American Tobacco has nearly halved from 650p on fears over US litigation. But to date the industry has fought off every challenge. For those willing to take a risk, a 10 per cent yield is attractive.

fields.headline: Arise, the city state
fields.standfirst:
Labour can only thrive now by taking devolution all the way to create a powerful system of local politics

The London mayor: special report

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Labour can only thrive now by taking devolution all the way to create a powerful system of local politics
fields.body:
After a while, most Great Ones stop thinking. They become the prisoners of their own past words, hypnotised by their past successes. Flattered and distracted, in a world where everything else is changing, they become unwilling - or simply too busy - to change themselves. You see it in newspapers, in big companies, in politics. Only a very few, very good leaders have the deep self-confidence, the inner lack of vanity, to keep learning lessons.

Whether Tony Blair is among them, we will find out soon. New Labour's spring crisis should provoke some long, intensely reflective walks round the grounds of Chequers. I say 'a crisis'. Perhaps that's overdoing it. Composed of Ken, weakening polling, devolutionary problems in Scotland and Wales, likely bad results in the local elections and the Ayr by-election, this is not enough yet to threaten Blair's chances of a second term. But if the story of this spring is ignored, it is enough to make that second term a miserable experience.

Consider, first, the London comedy. Blair is against Livingstone because Ken will scare off the voters and horrify the middle classes. Ken, meanwhile, is currently scaring off the voters so effectively that he is the runaway favourite to become London's directly-elected mayor. As to the middle classes, he is scooping up every merchant banker with monogrammed shirts and half the gels who lunch at Peter Jones en route.

And why is Ken so popular? Because he will make Tony cross. Tee hee. Ho, ho. Let's fart at the Emperor. That's about it. In terms of left-right politics, Ken's campaign seems to be a clinical, brightly-coloured, postmodern vacuity. Not only has he no party, he has no discernible leftist agenda, no labels. This is personality politics, as pure as they come, almost a caricature of Blairite strategy.

Many commentators have pointed to the similarities between Blair's cross-party and over-party appeal in 1997 and the Livingstone appeal today. But the difference is this: Blair made it safe to vote for Ken. Without Blair's tight grip on Labour's national agenda - the same tight grip which produced the grotesque fixing of the London electoral college and gave Ken his chance to stand 'for democracy' - middle-ground voters would be far less ready to support Livingstone now. And, piling paradox on irony in a tottery tower, many of those who will elect Ken purely to offend Blair will happily vote Blair again next time.

For the voters are ahead of Downing Street. Devolution makes it possible to balance different layers of authority, to hedge your bets, to heckle the Great. This is so in every mature, dispersed democracy; none of them are monocultures and they are the better for it. At some level, Blair knows that very well: defending devolution, he told the Edinburgh Parliament last week that 'you do not judge these changes in days or months or even a short space of years. You judge them in the broad sweep of history'.

Wise words. New Labour promised a New Britain and it's getting one, with all the pain and mess that surrounds any birth. Blair himself is - I guess - learning along with everyone else. Has Rhodri Morgan in Cardiff been such a terrible embarrassment since he took over? Indeed, has anyone much noticed? And does Blair now think he was right to put such effort into blocking him in the first place? Of course not.

So there is no question of New Labour trying to reverse devolution, despite Ken, Ayr, Morgan and the rest. The second term may take this a stage further: I gather that the great task of reviving Britain's cities and towns may be Number 10's 'big idea' for the next election. It is a noble idea and meets a rising mood in many towns and cities, from Liverpool, where the commission on the city's democratic future has come up with some fascinating and radical thoughts, to smaller towns across England, such as Brighton with its civic forum.

Revival would require an end to the amateurism and weakened powers of today' s local authorities. But it would also force Downing Street to confront one of the root causes of its current embarrassments, its relationship with the Labour Party. For activists in many places other than London are asking: are we still wanted on voyage?

There is no mystery about why the Labour activists were sidelined in the first place. Throughout Blair's formative years in politics they gave a good impression of loathing the British in general. It is hard to explain to people who weren't there at its rancorous Eighties worst just how awful things were - all I can say is that a lot of memories were brought back for me by John O'Farrell's brilliant memoir, Things Can Only Get Better , and the character who decided that smiling was right-wing and pretended to be miserable throughout the Eighties as a political statement.

But that was then. And Ken the Restaurant Critic isn't going to bring it back. So the question is a real one: what would New Labour want to do with a mass movement, even if it had one? As the Livingstone campaign will demonstrate, activists are less important than ever when it comes to electioneering. Most of us get so much highly-coloured garbage through the front door that the impact of another leaflet, as compared to TV, radio and newspaper coverage, is negligible. 'Getting the vote out' matters a bit; but that is a once-in-four-years job. What about the rest of the time?

Policy is made by professionals in London, behind closed doors; sold and attacked through the national media and debated on chat shows. A whole tradition of political participation, based around direct argument in school halls, trade union offices or front rooms, plus annual pilgrimages to seaside resorts to vote on policies, is dying away. People throughout the Labour Party feel badly hurt by this. They feel demeaned and ignored. They know there is a residual role left for the 'active supporter' as distinct from the activist - do the donkey-work, go along to Conference and clap at the right moment, or merely pay money and hold a card as a reminder to your wallet that you're on the winning side. But this is more like adult membership of the Tufty Club than politics: driven, intelligent people with a conscience want more than that.

Part of the answer is given by Blair and Gordon Brown when they talk of voluntarism and the need for a stronger civic society. Whatever you think about New Labour, it is committed to public good works, to people getting off their sofas and doing something for their communities. It is anything but fatalistic. But the mechanism for political activism, the lever, has been oddly lacking. And here, I think, is where the revival of cities and towns comes in.

For it simply cannot happen without local politics. Labour, like the others, was once rooted in local initiative. In the middle of the twentieth century, half of the great Labour figures had learned their radicalism and optimism on local councils. The glaringly obvious job for tomorrow's political activist is the restoration of confident, well-run and ambitious cities and towns. This is what links the party's past with its future. And this is the ground on which Blair can rebuild his relationship with the sane, community-minded and somewhat disappointed people who make up the majority of Labour's local army.

But it means - it must mean - that Labour is not identical everywhere. As Blair has discovered over the past few weeks, you cannot successfully dictate your party choices from the centre in a system tailored to local choice. You end up fixing, arm-twisting and bullying _ and then you fail anyway. New Blair is going to have to live the pluralism Old Blair has created. He's going to have to watch, and approve, many Labour people - and Libs - and Tories - exercising power across the country and doing things he wouldn't have done. He's going to have to realise that he can't have an exclusive relationship with the British people; we are not monogamous. Can he change himself enough? I hope so.

Throughout my lifetime we have been local people run by a decayed imperial machine. And at long last that is breaking up and giving way to something that is beginning to look suspiciously like a democracy. And whose achievement is that? Not Ken's.

fields.headline: Whitehall farce over IMF job
fields.trailText: The managing directorship of the International Monetary Fund is one of the most important jobs in the world. Countries such as France are desperate to secure the post for one of their own; and they usually manage it.
fields.body:
The managing directorship of the International Monetary Fund is one of the most important jobs in the world. Countries such as France are desperate to secure the post for one of their own; and they usually manage it.

On this occasion, however, having provided three out of the last four IMF managing directors, even the French thought it would be diplomatic to lie low. You can nevertheless bet a few euros that, if the next head of the IMF proves to be Horst Köhler, the German president of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the French will be in there with a candidate for the vacancy this would create.

On this occasion, the British had one of their best ever chances to secure the IMF post - and bogged it. Indeed, we have not even tried. Once Gordon Brown decided he would prefer to be the new Walpole, first as Chancellor and then as Prime Minister, the British 'effort' to find a candidate simply died.

No British candidate? Given that the Americans and others want somebody of ministerial weight, someone like Kenneth Clarke would be formidable. If the ministerial search collapsed, Andrew Crockett, our man at the Bank for International Settlements; Mervyn King, deputy governor of the Bank of England; or Sir Tim Lankester, one of the most distinguished Treasury men of his generation (with IMF experience); all would have been good candidates.

But no, I tell a lie. There is a British candidate: he is called Giuliano Amato, and he is an Italian minister. No, wait a minute, German Chancellor Gerhard Schröder has been talking to Tony Blair on the phone, and the British candidate has become Horst Köhler of the EBRD.

What a classic Whitehall farce! What a characteristically New Labour, Third Way farce: a British candidate who is not British!

There is a history to this. We nearly got the IMF job in 1973. A Conservative Chancellor, Anthony Barber, proposed former Labour Chancellor Jim Callaghan to succeed Frenchman Pierre-Paul Schweitzer for the IMF job. Helmut Schmidt, West Germany's heavyweight Chancellor, backed his friend Jim. But the French vetoed the proposal.

Roy Jenkins was then approached, but declined. As Callaghan's biographer Kenneth O'Morgan has written, it is fascinating to speculate what role he might have played as IMF boss in 1976 when 'Britain had to engage in life-saving negotiations with the IMF'. As it turned out, Callaghan was Prime Minister by 1976, and it fell to him and the 1974-79 Labour Chancellor, Denis Healey, to negotiate with the IMF. It also fell to Callaghan to make a speech, to please the IMF and financial markets, which was widely taken as disavowing Keynesian economic policies but was essentially tactical.

The IMF boss during that episode was Dutchman Johannes Witteveen. By 1977 the financial markets had noticed that Britain possessed North Sea oil, and the pound became the flavour of the year. Later, when Witteveen decided to retire early, he approached Healey and asked him to nominate Sir Kit McMahon, of the Bank of England, whom he regarded as one of the few British officials not to have sullied his reputation in 1976. Healey shared Witteveen's admiration for McMahon, and refused.

Britain's recourse to the IMF in 1976 was a traumatic event for Old Labour, and memories of it played an important part in New Labour's policies. That kind of thing was simply never going to be allowed to happen again.

The 1976 episode was an important staging post en route to New Labour's economic orthodoxy; but so was what they observed - from the Opposition benches - of the Black Wednesday black comedy of 1992.

David Lipsey tells us in his new book The Secret Treasury (Viking) that Treasury officials thought exit from the exchange rate mechanism would be a serious setback, and that the pound should re-enter as soon as possible. But, as Lipsey notes, 'a core Treasury skill is to explain after an event why the way it turned out was in fact for the best in the best of all possible worlds'. Recently, in a lecture to the Royal Society of Arts, one such (former) Treasury official, Sir Alan Budd, pronounced: 'The breakthrough to sustainably lower inflation was achieved through membership of the ERM. I shall one day seek to establish that that episode, politically disastrous though it proved to be, involved brilliant [if accidental] timing in terms of both joining and leaving.'

The necessary rebalancing of monetary and fiscal policy was achieved under what was left, after 1992, of Norman Lamont's chancellorship, and by Kenneth Clarke, Chancellor from 1993 until 1997.

Clarke was a very good Chancellor and there was no poison in the macro-economic chalice he handed over to Brown. But for New Labour, economic history began on 1 May 1997. Clarke gets no credit - and no nomination for the IMF.

Brown may well turn out to be the greatest Chancellor since Walpole. But one is reminded of eighteenth-century events in another way. The key to understanding New Labour is to think of the politics of faction and patronage. Things have reverted since the Tories tried to get the IMF job for Callaghan.

But, as Lipsey notes, 'a core Treasury skill is to explain after an event why the way it turned out was in fact for the best in the best of all possible worlds'. Recently, in a lecture to the Royal Society of Arts, one such (former) Treasury official, Sir Alan Budd, pronounced: 'The breakthrough to sustainably lower inflation was achieved through membership of the ERM. I shall one day seek to establish that that episode, politically disastrous though it proved to be, involved brilliant [if accidental] timing in terms of both joining and leaving.' The necessary rebalancing of monetary and fiscal policy was achieved under what was left, after 1992, of Norman Lamont's chancellorship, and by Kenneth Clarke, Chancellor from 1993 until 1997. Clarke was a very good Chancellor and there was no poison in the macro-economic chalice he handed over to Brown. But for New Labour, economic history began on 1 May 1997. Clarke gets no credit - and no nomination for the IMF. Brown may well turn out to be the greatest Chancellor since Walpole. But one is reminded of eighteenth-century events in another way. The key to understanding New Labour is to think of the politics of faction and patronage. Things have reverted since the Tories tried to get the IMF job for Callaghan.

webTitle: Lords are to face full sleaze inquiry

fields.headline: Lords are to face full sleaze inquiry
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: The reformed House of Lords is to be the subject of a full-scale sleaze inquiry by the Neill Committee on Standards in Public Life.
fields.body:
The reformed House of Lords is to be the subject of a full-scale sleaze inquiry by the Neill Committee on Standards in Public Life.

A new code of conduct for peers, many of whom have substantial outside interests, is likely to lead to transgressing peers being suspended for the first time.

Neill has justified the inquiry on the ground that the Upper House, now stripped of its hereditary element, can more frequently overturn legislation coming from the Commons.

In recent months, the peers have thrown out legislation covering the ban on teaching about homosexuality in schools, the right to trial by jury, and local government reform. Now Neill has written to leaders of political parties, including cross benchers, revealing that he intends to make the Upper House the subject of his next full scale inquiry.

Rules in the Lords are more lax than in the Commons. Peers are not required by the Register of Peers' Interests to declare shareholdings or chairmanships, nor are they required to register visits or gifts related to parliamentary activities. They are only required to register a parliamentary consultancy or shareholdings in a parliamentary lobbying firm. Only 12 peers have registered a consultancy and a further seven a shareholding.

Although peers are expected to declare an interest when speaking, there is nothing to test whether they are complying with guidelines.

The rules, introduced in 1997, have been left more lax largely because peers are thought to act 'on their honour' and because, unlike MPs, they are largely unpaid.

The Nolan Committee which preceded Neill had intended an inquiry more than five years ago, but relented when the peers mounted their own internal inquiry leading to the establishment of the register in November 1995. No peer has been the subject of a complaint since the register was set up, in contrast to the Commons where complaints are filed regularly on a sometimes openly party political basis.

Critics claim that, if Neill's proposed rules prove too tight, it will discourage businessmen, lawyers and other professionals from sitting as working peers.

The inquiry, however, has been welcomed by Lady Jay, the Labour Leader of the Lords, who has made no secret of her desire to modernise the chamber. A Government member said: 'We have always welcomed transparency. Ministers who are also peers such as Sainsbury, the Science Minister, are already covered by the Code of Conduct for Ministers.'

Neill will publish an issues paper on the Lords, before taking oral evidence and producing a report probably later this year.

The proposed reforms come at the time of an increasingly bitter row between the Labour and Liberal Democrat front benches over the refusal of Labour to appoint more Liberal Democrat working peers.

The leader of Liberal Democrat peers, Rodgers, says he has written evidence the Government is witholding the appointment of more Liberal Democrat peers unless his party agrees to back more Government legislation. Tony Blair has appointed 83 new Labour peers and only 59 from opposition parties. Blair claims he is redressing the imbalance caused by the appointment of 173 Conservative peers, and only 123 opposition peers during the 18 years of Conservative government.

fields.headline: Lessons yet to be learnt
fields.standfirst: Iraq: special report
fields.trailText: Ten years after the brutal execution in Baghdad of  Observer journalist Farzad Bazoft, we know enough about Saddam Hussein to be entirely unsurprised that he could have murdered a British reporter in the face of every international objection. A decade after that appalling event, we, who were his colleagues, know all too well why Farzad took the chance he did in Baghdad to go in search of a story that was to lead to his arrest with a British nurse, Daphne Parish, his drugged confession, a spurious trial on spying charges and his eventual hanging.
fields.body:
Ten years after the brutal execution in Baghdad of Observer journalist Farzad Bazoft, we know enough about Saddam Hussein to be entirely unsurprised that he could have murdered a British reporter in the face of every international objection. A decade after that appalling event, we, who were his colleagues, know all too well why Farzad took the chance he did in Baghdad to go in search of a story that was to lead to his arrest with a British nurse, Daphne Parish, his drugged confession, a spurious trial on spying charges and his eventual hanging.

He was a journalist, eager, over-eager perhaps (if over-enthusiasm can ever be thought a failing in a reporter), to get the facts behind an explosion in an Iraqi weapons plant that had aroused international interest. In doing so he slipped from the hands of his 'civilised' Iraqi Foreign Ministry minders into the clutches of the internal security forces that kept Saddam in power then and still do today, despite all the predictions of his imminent downfall and a policy of sanctions that have served only to starve his people and increase his own authority.

Not that Farzad would have wanted the war or the sanctions. Despite being an Iranian, he liked the Iraqis, and particularly some of the Iraqi embassy staff in London. Which is one reason why the embassy invited him as a guest of the Baghdad government on several trips to Iraq before that last fateful invitation in September 1989. He was a man difficult to refuse anything, most especially when it concerned a story. His enthusiasm was so complete, his desire to like, and be liked, so endearing that the initial instinct of saying no to him all too easily slipped to yes.

He came to The Observer - after a chequered (as we were later to find out) student life in Luton - as a freelance helping on stories about immigrants and the rising force of Middle East protest groups in London. He continued providing information and stories on the Iran-Iraq war, then largely ignored by a press.

When the war finished, Farzad, like Saddam himself, turned his attention to the dictator's policy inside Iraq, and in doing so became the victim of the tyranny he had chosen to examine. It was a terrible irony that his last trip was organised to cover new elections among a Kurdish community that Saddam was gassing to death. It was the more painful that the first public protest The Observer made about Farzad's arrest was at a meeting organised by the Royal Institute of International Affairs, and backed by the British Foreign Office, to proclaim Iraq's 'move to democracy'.

And therein lies the simple lesson of Farzad's brutal murder if we are ever to understand the nature of authoritarian rule and to challenge it with any kind of 'ethical' foreign policy. Regimes such as Saddam Hussein's - and it is valid as much for today's China, Syria, Burma, and potentially Russia and some of the Caucasian states as it is for Iraq - work through multiple levels. The face they present to the outside world - the face they present to foreign diplomats, the international press and even the business and other communities - is one of accommodation and pragmatism. If you never go beyond that level there is no reason to feel there is anything else. Actual power, however, is exercised through a network of security forces held severally, and competitively, at the centre. These are more than just an instrument of oppression. The generals and the agents are held by favours and obligations, as well as fear.

The trouble with any policy of punishment through isolation is that you merely tighten the control of the regime. The fewer the goods, the more Saddam can use such as there are to reward his acolytes - and equally to punish his enemies, or even friends, by depriving them. The only way you can bring down, or help undermine, such regimes, is opening up their countries as much as possible to ideas and trade and make available goods and opportunities to those who would otherwise be dependent on the regime to get them. To do that you have to support the free flow of ideas, journalistic inquiry included.

In the end Farzad was lucky in that the British embassy did support him (partly because he was arrested with a British-born nurse) and had the comfort of visits from a British Consul of exceptional individual humanity. He (and Britain as it turned out) was less lucky in a British ambassador and a Foreign Office that looked to his intrusion as an unnecessary nuisance, who saw the future as getting on better with Saddam and controlling him through persuasion rather than a realistic assessment of his ambitions and a determined pursuit of our own ideals.

It is the same argument being used this weekend as Tony Blair rushes to be the first head of state to kiss the cheek of the President-to-be Vladimir Putin in St Petersburg. We have followed the same line in China, even to the extent of suppressing in Britain the very right of democratic protest - the very right we are supposed to be promoting abroad. Far from helping to speed change abroad it will set it back by enabling the outer face of pragmatism to disguise the inner core of internal suppression, the core it took Farzad's death to help expose in Iraq.

And yet, looking back, what remains the most powerful of all feelings is not anger, which his colleagues feel, responsibility, which I feel myself, or even grief, which all who knew him experienced, but an overwhelming sense of fondness for the man and the journalist. There he'd be, clutching an obscure item from the Middle East press. 'I can find out more about this,' he would say, as one's eyes rolled up at the thought of one's foreign correspondents demanding to know what he was doing on their patch and staff reporters complaining that their stories were being spiked for a freelancer. 'I know someone who will help me on this,' he'd persist. 'It's a good story, I know it.' He did and it was.

 Adrian Hamilton was deputy editor of The Observer from 1989-1993. He is now Comment Editor of the Independent .

webTitle: Revealed: UN-backed unit's reign of terror

fields.headline: Revealed: UN-backed unit's reign of terror
fields.standfirst: Kosovo 'disaster response service' stands accused of murder and torture
fields.trailText: Murder, torture and extortion: these are the extraordinary charges made against the UN's own Kosovo Protection Corps in a confidential United Nations report written for Secretary-General Kofi Annan.
fields.body:
Murder, torture and extortion: these are the extraordinary charges made against the UN's own Kosovo Protection Corps in a confidential United Nations report written for Secretary-General Kofi Annan.

The KPC stands accused in the document, drawn up on 29 February, of 'criminal activities _ killings, ill-treatment/torture, illegal policing, abuse of authority, intimidation, breaches of political neutrality and hate-speech'.

The 5,000-strong corps, funded by UN members including Britain, has a £30 million aid budget for Kosovo. It was set up to provide 'disaster response services'; instead, says the UN, it has been murdering and torturing people.

The UN's own damning verdict on its newly created civil defence force is fresh evidence of the failure of Special Representative Bernard Kouchner to establish the rule of law in Kosovo. Many of the corps's recruits came straight from the Kosovo Liberation Army, set up to meet the violence of Slobodan Milosevic's police with violence.

Nato's intervention last June saw the departure of armed Serbs from Kosovo, but violence and gangsterism by Albanian extremists has not stopped. The report's grim message is that the UN is paying the salaries of many of the gangsters.

The report covers the period from 21 January, when the corps formally came into being. Under the heading 'killings', the UN says: 'Dragash: two members of the KPC and three others were arrested by UN police in connection with the killing of an ethnic Gorani (11 February).'

There are three charges of ill-treatment and torture: in Pec, a man was beaten senseless in the KPC's headquarters, suffering head injuries and severe bruising from a rifle butt. The victim had been attacked in a newspaper article, written by a former fighter in the KLA. In Prizren, a man from the Torbesh minority - a group of Muslim Turks suspected by the Albanians of collaborating with the Serbs - was kidnapped and beaten up by a KPC member and three other men.

Also in Prizren, the KPC stands accused of using torture to obtain confessions. After two men arrested on suspicion of stealing cars were handed over to UN police, they 'complained they had been severely ill-treated. Subsequent medical examinations corroborated the victims' allegations'. Troops from K-For, the multi-national force, suspended the two alleged torturers from the KPC on 4 February.

The KPC is not a police force, and yet one of the grave concerns raised by the UN report, drawn up by Kouchner's own office, is that mem bers of the KPC are behaving as if they were above the law. The report lists complaints from UN police working for its mission in Kosovo, Unmik.

The KPC has been running protection rackets across Kosovo - in Pristina, Suva Reka, Dragash, Istok and Prizren - demanding 'contributions' from shopkeepers, businessmen and contractors. In Suva Reka, KPC members are alleged to have forced petrol stations to accept coupons rather than money for fuel.

In Vucitrn, the KPC reportedly demanded protection money from members of an ethnic minority, the Ashkali, originally from India. One family member had previously been kidnapped and the family had been bombed.

The KPC has a nice line in death threats, says the UN. Two members threatened to kill K-For interpreters after being arrested by Nato troops in Kosovo. Following the arrests, 20 KPC men mobbed the police station and demanded their release. They were freed the next day.

The KPC may be running prostitution rackets, says the UN. A report was received on 14 February that a high-ranking KPC officer may be supervising a forced prostitution racket running out of the Drenica Bar, close to the Srbica KPC training camp.

The KPC is led by General Agim Ceku, who comes in for fierce criticism from the report. His earlier pledges not to tolerate any criminal behaviour by KPC members and to expel anyone who violates the law are mocked by the report, and Ceku, who was formerly a senior commander in the KLA, comes in for personal criticism.

Under the heading 'Activities against minorities, including hate speech', Ceku is criticised for being present at a walk-out staged by Albanian members of the KPC when a speech was translated into Serbo-Croat - the language of the Muslim Slav minority suspected by the Albanians of collaboration with the Serbs.

The report comments: 'It was the clear opinion of those present that this was a premeditated action. The speeches of General Ceku and that of the regional KPC commander were not those agreed upon in advance. The men spoke of the war and loyalty to the "country" - 10 February.' Such a speech would contradict the policy of the UN, the general's paymaster.

webTitle: Great Right Hope pitches for the centre

fields.headline: Great Right Hope pitches for the centre
fields.standfirst: George W. Bush tells Ed Vulliamy that he is now looking beyond his core Republican vote
fields.trailText: 'It is,' said the triumphant Governor of the Lone Star State, 'up to Al Gore to explain what happened in that administration, the Clinton administration.'
fields.body:
'It is,' said the triumphant Governor of the Lone Star State, 'up to Al Gore to explain what happened in that administration, the Clinton administration.'

George Bush looked edgier than he does on television, and more nervous than he was on the podium the previous night before a crowd of screeching jocks and more quietly contented businessmen. The smirk had gone - in its place a pinched reserve, with presidential sheen.

'I'm not talking about the President in particular,' Bush told The Observer , 'I'm talking about a whole administration, Clinton-Gore. It's up to Al Gore to explain.'

With these words last Wednesday, Bush spelled out how the already turbulent election campaign will now become the most vitriolic, the longest and hardest fought within living memory. Bush plans to play nasty, and to hit Al Gore where it hurts; in the family. It is simple: blame the son for the sins of the father.

Bush's remarks came as he went to register his absentee vote in what is now the cosmetic last round of primaries in the 'Bush Brothers' states of Florida and Texas. Mardi Gras had been a sweet day for the crucial 'Super Tuesday' vote, the first warm wind carrying the delectable scents of the Texan spring.

But in that sweetness, Bush made it clear that when it comes to the aggressive, 'negative' campaigning that saw off John McCain, 'you ain't seen nothing yet'. He signalled clearly that he will return to the Calvary America has already spent a year walking: the torture of what he calls 'the exiled honour of the White House' and the legacy of the Lewinsky scandal.

Bush invoked President Clinton in almost his opening breath of the discussion, with a scathing attack on Gore's pledge to reform campaign finance (something Bush himself was pushed into doing by McCain).

'Al Gore says he wants to ban soft money, but his President is out there raising soft money hard as he can, and it was the Vice-President who went to a Buddhist temple to raise soft money - raising soft money from monks! How low can you get?' He gave that boyish half-smile with half of his mouth - Bush is going to enjoy this.

The battle is now to be fought between the two men who had felt themselves anointed to the presidency, the party puppets who in each instance represent a triumph for motorcades over battle buses, of party machines and the power of money over the audacity and spontaneity of the challengers. Both Bush and Gore have changed, been damaged to a degree but each has also become, as Bush himself said, 'a better campaigner'. It will now be a more straightforward, uncomplicated duel, the way the system wanted it. It will also be, we are assured, an unrelenting one - there will be no pause for breath between now and the party conventions in summer.

After ensuring that the Lewinsky-Ken Starr hangover will feature large, the Texan Governor's remarks to The Observer took a curious turn - an apparent rush to the political centre with a volte-face on the harsh conservative vocabulary that hallmarked the course he had plotted since the pivotal victory in South Carolina. Then, his conservatism had been as compassionate as a scalpel blade, but now it is 'compassionate' again. Or so he says.

Then, his battleground was the Republican core; now it is floating Democrats and McCain supporters - not all of whom are showing much interest in switching to ' w , pronounced dubya '. Slightly less than half McCain's primary base says that it will now vote for Gore.

'I'm going to be talking about a child health insurance programme; I'm going to be talking about the working uninsured,' said Bush, albeit short on specifics. He even failed to dismiss the notion of increasing the minimum wage, words that make the Republican Right shudder. 'I'm interested in talking about the minimum wage,' he said, as though he always had been, adding 'if there can be protection for small business. Without that, one of the things about a minimum wage is that it does people out of a job.' Again, no promises.

On taxes, we have specifics. About one-third of the billions from the surplus he will spend on cuts will sponsor the top one per cent of earners, those netting over $300,000 a year. But taxation is at least one of the elements that delineates clear party lines, for all the scramble for the middle ground. And this is not a coincidence; this battle is the result of painstaking backroom calculation on both sides.

In their defiance of the doomsayers, Al Gore's staff look back with satisfied disbelief at last year's slough of despondency - that quagmire of Russian embezzlement, terrible speeches and image problems, with Bill Bradley stealing a fundraising march.

Today's motorcade Gore is even immune to the fact that one of his fundraisers was convicted in a criminal court the other day for doing so illegally, and - as Bush pointed out - Gore is able to raise 'soft money' while promising to make reform of campaign finance a 'priority'.

But whatever happened to 'Gore spelled with a B'? The Al Gore we behold in victory this weekend is a genetically modified product. As they weigh in this weekend, the contenders are dead even.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Train kills man who was trying to rescue dogs from line
fields.body:
Train kills man who was trying to rescue dogs from line

A 61-year-old man was killed when he was struck by a passenger train while trying to rescue two dogs from the track at an unmanned Sergeant's Crossing, near Bramshall, west of Uttoxeter, Staffordshire.

'Stinger' ends M-way chase

A police helicopter directed patrols chasing a bus stolen from a depot in Blackpool for nearly 20 miles along the M55 and then the M6. A 'Stinger' device punctured its tyres near Leyland and a man was later questioned by police.

999 call-out to amorous frogs

Durham County Fire Brigade helped hundreds of amorous frogs whose mating pond in the village of Pity Me was dry by pumping water into it.

George Best improving, say hospital doctors

Doctors treating George Best for a liver disorder in Cromwell Hospital, Kensington, said his condition had improved. The Sixties soccer genius has promised to stop drinking.

Officer beaten by hunt fans

A police inspector was kicked and beaten by hunt supporters as protesters tried to disrupt the South Down and Eridge Hunt at Halland, East Sussex. Roy Apps suffered broken ribs and severe bruising.

Classic fetches £5.5m

A copy of Audubon's Birds of America , found on the isle of Bute, fetched a record £5.5m at Christie's in New York.

£1m divine intervention

Bryce and Dorothy Thomas, who used a divining rod to find an 'exceptionally pure' spring near their farm at Swiss Valley, Llanelli, hope to sell it for £1 million to a French company.

Power drive

Golfer Terry Evans sliced his shot so badly that it hit an 11,000-volt, 60ft electricity cable, snapping it in two, at Caersws, North Wales. Charles farms sold for £8m

Charles farms sold for £8m

Thirteen Scottish tenant farmers have failed in a bid to buy their Angus farms from Prince Charles. Under an ancient law banning heirs to the English crown owning land in Scotland, it was sold to the highest bidder for £8 million.
