webTitle: Labour on red alert  as Ken works his charm

fields.headline: Labour on red alert  as Ken works his charm
fields.standfirst:
As the party gears up to fight Livingstone, some Ministers fear the crisis threatens a second term.

New Labour in power: special report

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: As the party gears up to fight Livingstone, some Ministers fear the crisis threatens a second term.
fields.body:
Labour's director of communications, Phil Murphy, had just left the 8.30am Monday strategy meeting in Downing Street when he was 'throbbed' - Millbank slang for being paged. The message on his machine read: 'Reports that Livingstone is standing'.

The five words on the tiny machine, Murphy knew, spelt a crisis for the leadership's attempts to shoehorn its favoured candidate, Frank Dobson, into the London mayoralty. And some very senior party figures fear they might have even greater import. They believe the extraordinary figure of Ken Livingstone, the 56-year-old MP for Brent East many had written off as a relic of the discredited leftist politics of the early Eighties, could yet prove to be Tony Blair's nemesis.

Murphy suspected something was afoot the night before when he tried to brief Charles Reiss, political editor of the Evening Standard , on the launch of Dobson's campaign the next morning. Reiss seemed strangely disengaged, which is not surprising since by then Livingstone had given him the exclusive for the next morning's edition that he would indeed take on the Labour establishment and stand for the mayoralty, ending his turbulent 30-year relationship with the party

When he heard the news the next morning, Murphy set off immediately to help adjust the Dobson launch. Ever since it has been a case of the the mighty Millbank machine rushing to catch up with what Downing Street derisively calls 'poor unspun Ken'.

Livingstone's challenge has unleashed a latent anti-establishment, anti-politics mood in metropolitan London and raised fears that New Labour is losing touch with its own party and heartland support. A runaway Livingstone victory, heralded by a Guardian poll last week, would be symbolic of a deep malaise at the heart of the Government. One depressed Labour official said: 'Cutting back a 55-point lead in six weeks seems a bit steep - 45 points maybe, but this ...'

The chances of such a turn-around are not helped by continuing tensions between Millbank and the Dobson camp. Dobson has made little effort to disguise his anger with Millbank and insists he could have won the party ballot, even if the vote had been confined to London party members.

Since then he has been displaying his independence, in matters of image as well as policy: he has apparently refused blandishments from party image consultants to shave off his beard. He has also told the Treasury he thinks Gordon Brown is wrong not to allow the Mayor to borrow against the income expected from congestion charging to improve bus services. He has refused requests from party officials to put the plan for a public-private partnership to a group of independent experts when in office, an issue on which he differs from the official party line.

Dobson's aides have decided he has to go hard on policy and play up the importance of the mayoralty. They see this as the only way of persuading Liberal Democrats and Conservatives not to risk their second preference votes on Livingstone. 'We have got to make Liberals and Tories think this election and this job matters and not to throw their vote away on Ken.'

Party officials know they have a massive damage repair job to undertake with their own activists. Last week party officials called in over 80 London constituency and union activists to let off steam over the gerrymander ing of the mayoralty election. 'Some pretty brutal things were said, but we hope everyone will now move on,' said one official.

Margaret McDonagh, the party general secretary, took the drubbing on the chin and said future party ballots for devolved bodies would probably be by one member, one vote. Further similar bloodletting sessions are planned in the hope that angry activists will agree to knock on doors for Dobson, once one of the most popular figures in the London party.

Some in Millbank have even privately raised the question of whether its image is so bad they should leave the building, or change its name. Once feted as an effective election-winning machine, the Millbank brand is now synonymous with control freaks and ruthlessness.

Party officials are now agonising over the level of discipline they will impose on party members who back Livingstone. Respected party figures such as Ian McCartney and London party chairman Jim Fitzpatrick had opposed banning Livingstone from standing for the party nomination on the ground that it would lead to a mass exodus from the party. Both now want to ensure the party emerges from these elections intact, if bruised. They are cautioning against a witch-hunt against Labour members supporting Livingstone.

Signing Livingstone's nomination papers or acting as his agent would mean automatic expulsion, but open support, such as putting up one of his posters or raising cash for his campaign, could also lead to disciplinary action. One branch party chairman from south London said: 'The people who really believe in Ken, who are in the Labour Party not outside it, have now been disenfranchised. They can either get themselves kicked out of the party and end their political lives or they can send him wads of cash in brown envelopes and vote for him in the secrecy of the polling booth and no one will ever know.'

Millbank, desperate to get the media's attention on to Dobson's policies, cannot afford more time taken up with the agenda dominated by party wrangling. 'We have got to get Livingstone nailed on policy. It is our only hope,' saId one official.

But Downing Street seems to be quietly preparing for defeat. Officials openly acknowledge that there will be a Livingstone effect, not only in the elections for seats for the Greater London Assembly on 6 May, but also in the nationwide local elections on the same date.

Labour has even privately admitted that veteran left-wing journalist Paul Foot is likely to be elected to the new GLA in the Livingstone backwash. It will be the first time a Trotskyist has been elected to a public body since Tommy Sheridan won a seat in the Scottish Assembly last year. The polls even suggest that Darren Johnson, 33-year-old leader of the Green Party, is assured a seat in the new Assembly.

In the wider local elections across the country, Labour is also bracing itself for horrible headlines in its true heart lands. It is defending over 1,550 of the 3,337 seats last contested in 1996, a high water mark for Blair as the public prepared to throw John Major out in a landslide the following year. One Cabinet Minister said: 'It is frightening. We are going to take a terrible beating.'

The Tories will make 200 gains, even if they just equal their 34 per cent share of the vote achieved in last year's round of elections. If they make over 400 gains, they will be doing well enough to claim they are on course for victory in a general election.

In local government by-elections since Christmas there are already signs Labour is falling back in the wake of the health service crisis and now the splits over Livingstone. Labour's share of the vote went up in only two of the 30 council by-elections contested.

Many Cabinet Ministers admit to frustration in the heartland seats, despite the plethora of initiatives, action zones and social exclusion policies targeted at the poor. It is no longer heresy for Cabinet Ministers such as Foreign Secretary Robin Cook to admit openly, as he will today to the Scottish conference, that the Government's message is not getting through to its core support. Education Secretary David Blunkett admits there 'are very, very deep seated problems in disadvantaged areas'.

Some Ministers, such as Cook's deputy in the Foreign Office, Peter Hain, are even willing to warn in public that the next election hangs in the balance if the Government does not concentrate on getting its message across.

His argument follows closely the analysis revealed last week from Greg Cook, the party's own pollster. Labour's 171-seat majority might be threatened if Labour's vote stayed at home and Hague's euro-sceptic platform galvanised his core supporters, taking the Conservative vote share into the mid-30s.

Hain, who previously warned of disenchantment in the heartlands following the Welsh Assembly elections, told The Observer : 'Labour's official research showing up to one in five Labour supporters may stay at home at the next general election bears out exactly my own feel for the situation, not just in a heartland constituency like Neath - where certainly that is the mood - but generally across the country among our traditional supporters.

'The problem is not just confined to our heartland seats. If 10,000 came off my majority in Neath, it could be argued that Labour would be re-elected comfortably. But that misses the key point. There is a core vote - a traditional Labour support - in every constituency in the land. It might be only a few hundred in a marginal seat in the South-East, but we need that core vote to turn out to win those marginal seats. We cannot just rely on the New Labour vote which Tony Blair has so brilliantly swung behind the party. So this is an issue that does not just affect traditional areas, it affects the whole country.

'I think what we need to do is focus laser-like on getting our message across and make it a real priority. It is amazing to me how few people know that we have brought in the minimum wage or the working families tax credit or the other measures driven through by the Chancellor to benefit the poorest in society. It's as if it has been done, but no one knows about it. We need to start preaching the gospel.

'We have also got to start maximising our opportunities. For example, in the case of the minimum wage we managed to snatch defeat from the jaws of victory. A great message to our traditional supporters that the minimum wage is going up to over £4 an hour turns into a row within government over whether 10p extra is enough or not. We just cannot keep doing that.

'Some people think there is a contradiction in appealing to the Mirror and the Daily Mail vote. I have never said that. We have to appeal to Middle Britain and the Daily Mail , but we seem to have lost the knack of communicating with the Mirror readership and it is time we rediscovered it.'

fields.headline: World hunt for doctors
fields.standfirst:
New 'heart tsar' Dr Roger Boyle (left) issues a global cry for assistance as our sick health system struggles

The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Britain's new 'heart tsar' is to launch a global recruitment drive for heart surgeons in a bid to improve Britain's appalling track record in treating heart disease.
fields.body:
Britain's new 'heart tsar' is to launch a global recruitment drive for heart surgeons in a bid to improve Britain's appalling track record in treating heart disease.

Dr Roger Boyle, appointed last week as National Heart Director, wants to start immediately recruiting doctors from countries such as the US and India as the quickest way to tackle the huge backlog of operations.

Patients with heart disease are having to wait up to 18 months for an operation, and many die waiting. Britain has nearly the highest rate of heart disease of any developed country, but has one of the lowest number of heart surgeons, and performs around half as many operations as the European average.

Last week Health Secretary Alan Milburn pledged to cut the maximum waiting time to three months over a 10-year period as part of a range of proposals aimed at cutting deaths from heart disease by 40 per cent by 2010.

The Government allocated £50 million to do an extra 3,000 operations, but in his first interview since his appointment, Boyle told The Observer that doing any more would be difficult because 'we do not have the staff to undertake the work'.

Britain has only 170 heart surgeons, and although there are now 80 in training, it will take six years for them to qualify. As well as placing adverts, he will next week ask heart surgeons to approach their contacts overseas.

He wants to recruit an extra 30 consultants, each of whom could perform 200 operations a year.

Other plans to cut waiting times include abandoning the taboo about private hospitals, and paying them to do NHS heart operations for the first time. Boyle reckons that they have the capacity to do another 250 operations a month.

'The Prime Minister says he has no ideological objection to it,' said Boyle. But he admitted: 'It is a minefield.'

Despite these plans, Boyle confessed that waiting times are likely to get longer before they get shorter.

The package of measures announced last week is aimed at identifying everyone with heart disease, and making sure they receive appropriate treatment.

'In the day in question we only found one bed available, which was in Oxford, and there's no way he would have survived to get that far,' he said. 'Somehow we coped.'

He will oversee a whole range of schemes to encourage people to cut down on smoking, eat more fruit and vegetables, and to take more exercise. 'You don't need to do a great deal of exercise to get the fitness effect.

'You have to make yourself breathless four or five times a week, it doesn't need to be a five-mile run.

'Doing what I do, walking the dogs for two or three miles every morning is quite enough. It gets me out of breath, particularly if my dog runs after a bitch on heat,' he said.

But if Boyle is successful, there will be no need for his son to follow him into cardiology. 'Heart diseases is preventable,' he says. 'Ideally, I would like to see the disease peter out just about the day I retire.'

fields.headline: Beggars to be swept away
fields.trailText: Sir John Stevens, the Metropolitan Police Commissioner, plans to launch a 'zero tolerance' policy to sweep homeless people and beggars off London streets.
fields.body:
Sir John Stevens, the Metropolitan Police Commissioner, plans to launch a 'zero tolerance' policy to sweep homeless people and beggars off London streets.

The crackdown, which follows controversy about the presence of violent and persistent beggars, has been drawn up by Stevens to tackle 'quality of life' crimes against the public. He will announce next month a task force to tackle street crime and rid pavements of beggars and rough sleepers. Burglary from vehicles and vandalism will also be targeted.

'He is very serious about this,' one senior police source said. 'He sees it as his duty to try to deliver the sort of city the public wants and this is how he thinks it can be done.'

Police sources say Stevens, appointed in January, is an admirer of the tough policing introduced by Mayor Rudolph Giuliani in New York. Stevens is consulting senior officers and advisers to select a task force chief. It would include representatives of social services and agencies for the welfare of refugees, care in the community patients and the homeless.

Stevens's initiative should find favour with Home Secretary Jack Straw. But some police officers are not happy with extra demands the scheme will make.

'Begging may be out of control and be a real problem but criminalisation is not necessarily the way to deal with it,' said Glen Smyth, Police Federation representative for the Met. 'The police should not be used to clear up the mess left by the failure of social policies of successive governments.'

fields.headline: Blair faces poll crisis - ministers
fields.standfirst:
Hain and Blunkett alert on Labour heartlands

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Hain and Blunkett alert on Labour heartlands
fields.body:
Leading members of Tony Blair's Government last night sounded an ominous warning for the Prime Minister, saying he faces a damning rebellion among voters unless the Government does more for its disillusioned traditional electorate.

The comments raise the spectre of Labour being unable to command an overall majority after the next General Election if it continues to ignore its core voters from impoverished areas.

The warnings, which underline the battle between modernisers in the party and those increasingly alarmed by the Government's determination to appeal to former Conservative voters, were made by Peter Hain, the Foreign Office Minister, David Blunkett, the Education Secretary and Foreign Secretary Robin Cook.

Hain told The Observer last night: 'For famed communicators, we have made a very bad fist at communicating not just to our own party, but also to many of our supporters.'

Citing the example of last month's row over raising the minimum wage, Hain added: 'We managed to snatch defeat from the jaws of victory. A great message to our traditional supporters that the minimum wage was going up to nearly £4 an hour turns into a row within government over whether 10p extra is enough or not. We just cannot keep doing that. We have got to start maximising our opportunities.

'The problem is not just confined to our heartland seats. There is a core vote - a traditional solid Labour support - in every constituency in the land, including marginal seats. We need that core vote to turn out to win those seats. We cannot just rely on the New Labour vote which Tony Blair has so brilliantly swung behind the party.'

Ministers are warning that the Budget later this month, and the three-year Spending Review in the Summer, must see resources redirected towards its traditional vote, or face the danger of swathes of support staying away at the next election.

They acknowledge they are reaping the whirlwind of the first two years when they felt forced to stick to tight Conservative spending plans. The impact of the relaxation of the spending reins is only beginning to be felt, they claim.

However, a number are pressing for a switch in the emphasis of public spending in next week's Budget. They want Chancellor Gordon Brown to shift the spending from social security benefits and tax credits towards more 'politically visible' targets , such as public services and infrastructure, especially housing.

Labour officials have calculated that, if one in five of its supporters in the 1997 election stay away next time, turn-out would fall to 65 per cent and Labour's majority will fall below 60.

Blunkett echoed the concerns, saying: 'We face a big challenge. Our policies have not only got to make a difference, but be seen and felt to be making a difference. If our supporters walk out of their house and nothing has changed, they don't believe anything is being done for them by this Government.'

In a speech to the Scottish Labour conference today, the Foreign Secretary Robin Cook will acknowledge the discontent within the party, but couch his concerns in more coded terms. He will say: 'If we want to get across what we have done for the people who most need a Labour government then we are going to have to tell them ourselves.'

Media attention has been focused on Labour's political crisis in London, but Ministers fear severe reverses in the May council elections in Labour's northern heartlands. One Minister said: 'We are going to take a horrible beating.'

webTitle: Winning lashed as bishop bows out

fields.headline: Winning lashed as bishop bows out
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The controversial Episcopal bishop Richard Holloway yesterday combined the announcement of his retirement with a renewed attack on Cardinal Thomas Winning. Holloway, 66, announced he was standing down at a meeting of the diocesan synod.
fields.body:
The controversial Episcopal bishop Richard Holloway yesterday combined the announcement of his retirement with a renewed attack on Cardinal Thomas Winning. Holloway, 66, announced he was standing down at a meeting of the diocesan synod.

He said he wanted to devote more time to writing and lecturing. His resignation will come as a surprise to many impressed by his energy and commitment. Holloway is thought to be weary of the treatment meted out to him by sections of the press where he has been dubbed 'Dotty Dick' for his public support of gay rights, women priests, asylum seekers and the legalisation of drugs.

But he courted further controversy yesterday in his formal address to the synod by launching a broadside at Winning's campaign against the repeal of Section 28, forbidding the promotion of homosexuality in schools.

'One of the disquieting consequences of our new parliament has been the way some of the Christian regiments in the country have been training their guns on it,' he said.

'Most Scots do not go to church and many of them are alarmed by the tone of harsh intolerance that comes from the mouth of Cardinal Winning, who has become the voice of traditionalist Christianity in the new Scotland.

Holloway used the address to state his theological position. 'I am haunted by the strangeness of the universe, by its sacredness as well as by its obviousness,' he said. 'From time to time I have crossed invisible thresholds into other dimensions of reality. Another way to put this is to say that I believe in God.'

webTitle: Tories seek inquiry into free trip for Blairs' nanny

fields.headline: Tories seek inquiry into free trip for Blairs' nanny
fields.trailText: Conservative members of Parliament yesterday demanded an investigation into whether Tony Blair, the Prime Minister, should have declared hospitality provided to his nanny and her family by Geoffrey Robinson, the disgraced former Paymaster- General.
fields.body:
Conservative members of Parliament yesterday demanded an investigation into whether Tony Blair, the Prime Minister, should have declared hospitality provided to his nanny and her family by Geoffrey Robinson, the disgraced former Paymaster- General.

The Blairs sent nanny Rosalind Mark as well as her mother and brother on a holiday to the south of France to thank them for helping with their move into Downing Street after Labour's election victory in 1997.

Although Cherie Blair, the Prime Minister's wife, paid for first-class flights for the trio, Robinson is believed to have allowed them to stay in his luxury apartment in Cannes for nothing. At market rates, the trip would be worth several thousand pounds.

David Heathcoat-Amory, Conservative MP for Wells, said that he would be complaining to the Parliamentary Commissioner for Standards about the Blairs' failure to disclose Robinson's hospitality as a 'benefit in kind'.

'There comes a point where this becomes a pretty unhealthy relationship,' Heathcoat-Amory said. 'Given all this Government's waffle about openness and accountability, you have to ask why this wasn't registered.'

Usually only business interests have to be declared in the Register of Members' Interests. In this case, Conservative MPs say, there are concerns following Robinson's departure from office and the collapse of his company, Transtec, with substantial debts. The Tories claim the Prime Minister would have considerable influence over the investigation into Robinson's affairs.

Yesterday Number 10 said that 'any complaint about any trips will be dealt with in answer to questions from the Parliamentary Commissioner for Standards'.

The Blairs have taken advantage of the hospitality of Robinson, MP for Coventry North-West, on a number of occasions. They stayed at his villa in northern Italy during summer breaks in 1996 and 1997. Although neither trip was listed in the Register of Members' Interests, complaints by Conservative MPs were rejected. Gordon Brown, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, and members of his staff have also spent time in the Cannes apartment.

The 'Nannygate' affair broke last week when a Sunday newspaper published extracts from a 180,000-word memoir written by Mark detailing her life with the Blairs. Although considered not sufficiently 'explosive' by publishers, her revelations about life in Islington and then in Number 10 - tentatively titled 'The Downing Street Tears' - provoked an injunction ordering the Mail on Sunday to retrieve and pulp early editions. The Blairs sued Mark, her literary agent and the newspaper for damages.

On Friday, the Blair family and Mark settled their differences at the doors of the High Court in London. In return for legal proceedings against her being dropped, Mark agreed to hand over all copies of her manuscript and to keep private any information about domestic life with the Blairs. Lawyers for Mark said she was relieved the Blairs were no longer suing her.

However, proceedings are still continuing against the Mail on Sunday and Jonathan Harris, Mark's literary agent. Harris has denied passing the manuscript to the newspaper, which is contesting the injunction against publishing the nanny's material.

Labour Party spin-doctors have kept a tight grip on the affair. That control broke down on Tuesday when a reporter managed to gain access to the Mark family and was told by the nanny's mother about their anger at the way they felt they had been treated by the Blairs and Number 10.

webTitle: Keep the whiskers, Frank, smoothies are just sell-outs

fields.headline: Keep the whiskers, Frank, smoothies are just sell-outs
fields.standfirst:
The short cut to success

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: The short cut to success
fields.body:
It could be the final sell-out. Millbank advisers' request to Frank Dobson to shave off his luxuriant facial growth may drive the final nail into the coffin of true socialism. It would also be a major blow to freedom of expression in Britain.

That is the bald truth as far as the Beard Liberation Front, one of Britain's newest fringe groups, is concerned. Pledged to fight the ugly spectre of beardism wherever it is found, the organisation believes this country's hirsute classes are now being persecuted with unprecedented vigour.

The message - that 'beardies mean weirdies' - has already been taken up by the BBC, with the result that facial hair is an increasing rarity on television. In addition, delivery companies such as UPS encourage daily shaving among male staff, while the Swedish furniture chain Ikea has adopted a 'no bearded customer' policy at one of its stores (news that should make most men drop their razors like hot potatoes).

However, it is the creeping beardism of modern politics that groups luch as the BLF find most sinister, for New Labour's growing antipathy to hairy faces precisely mirrors the party's drift away from socialism, it is argued.

'Bearded candidates at elections have found that Millbank men make computer pictures of them with and without their face hair,' said Keith Flett, the BLF's founder. 'Then they tout these pictures round focus groups asking who they would be most likely to vote for: Mr Smooth or Mr Hairy.'

And if voters say they prefer them shiny-faced, the candidate is asked to shave, though they don't always agree to do so.

'I certainly hope Frank doesn't,' said Flett. 'We were going to give him our Beard 2000 award later this month. Keeping his facial hair was the only one of his principles that he has kept. Without his face hair he would have nothing left.'

Not everyone is convinced that being hirsute is automatically a good thing, however. The writer Keith Waterhouse recently launched a tirade against beard growers. As he said: 'The beard-wearer has clearly something to hide, even if it is only his weak chin and blubbery lips. A beard is a mask, by donning which the dimwit hopes to look like an intellectual, the penny-a-liner tries to look like a poet, the pavement artist seeks to look like a painter, and the bearded publican strives to pass himself off as a Merrie England Mine Host. Would you buy a used car from a bearded dealer or a house through a bearded estate agent? And if you remain unconvinced, would you sell a railway company to a bearded millionaire?'

But why is it possible for men to have beards in the first place? Why can they grow facial hair but not women? Answers are to be found in our evolutionary past with the disappearance of the thick pelts that covered the flesh of our ape-like ancestors, say scientists.

As we began to walk out on to the hot African savannah, we developed smooth skins to help keep cool. But men maintained hairy faces because beards made their faces look larger, perhaps to scare off enemies or even to impress women.

However, some races are hairier than others, as anthropologist Jonathan Kingdon points out in his book, Self-Made Man and his Undoing (Simon & Schuster, 1993). 'This suggests that selection in favour of male beards was mainly the result of prehistoric cultural preferences.'

'Today sophisticated cultures seeking a sense of order in crisp, trim images are embarrassed by this reminder of prehistoric unruliness: the answer is to shave. Cultures that seek to appear civilised but also to maintain a firm distinction between men and women compromise - the men grow moustaches.'

webTitle: Shave your beard or lose, Dobson told

fields.headline: Shave your beard or lose, Dobson told
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Faced with the prospect of humiliating defeat at the hands of the clean-shaven Ken Livingstone in London's mayoral race, Labour's highly-vaunted strategists have come up with a masterplan: tell Frank Dobson to shave his beard off.
fields.body:
Faced with the prospect of humiliating defeat at the hands of the clean-shaven Ken Livingstone in London's mayoral race, Labour's highly-vaunted strategists have come up with a masterplan: tell Frank Dobson to shave his beard off.

Drawing on evidence from psychologists that men with beards are regarded as untrustworthy, Phillip Gould, Labour's senior pollster and interpreter of focus groups, told grey-haired Dobson the beard should go, saying it would reveal the party's candidate as a reinvigorated figure ready and willing to beat Livingstone.

The shave, it was suggested, would also subliminally draw a line across the row over 'the fixing' of the election for party candidate. In addition, party officials believe that it would also make him more appealing to women and younger voters, some of Livingstone's strongest supporters.

But there was one flaw in the plan: a furious Dobson - due to be anointed as Beard 2000 at the annual awards ceremony of the Beard Liberation Front later this month - told Gould to forget it.

At a meeting last week with party officials to discuss how to improve his image, Dobson rejected the idea as 'ridiculous' and said he was not prepared to be the Identikit Labour candidate.

However, Westminster cynics were last night suggesting the disclosure of the exchanges between the Old Labour Dobson and New Labour strategists may be an attempt to show the degree to which Dobson is not going to be a pliant creature of Millbank, Labour's HQ.

Not that facial hair has harmed the chances of some of his former colleagues in the Cabinet: three modernising Ministers have shaved off moustaches - Peter Mandelson, Geoff Hoon and Stephen Byers - but David Blunkett and Robin Cook remain hirsute. Both Blunkett and Cook are said to be out of favour in the party.

webTitle: Peers set to rebel over elderly care

fields.headline: Peers set to rebel over elderly care
fields.trailText: An alliance of peers led by former Permanent Secretary at the Treasury Lord Burns is set to inflict a humiliating defeat on the Government over its refusal to regulate the multi-billion pound long-term care insurance industry. The industry, capable of preying on some of the country's most vulnerable people, is expected to boom over the next few years.
fields.body:
An alliance of peers led by former Permanent Secretary at the Treasury Lord Burns is set to inflict a humiliating defeat on the Government over its refusal to regulate the multi-billion pound long-term care insurance industry. The industry, capable of preying on some of the country's most vulnerable people, is expected to boom over the next few years.

The revolt includes some some normally loyal Labour peers including Lord Borrie, the former head of the Office of Fair Trading, and Lord Lipsey, a member of the Royal Commission whose report on long-term care of the elderly, completed last March, has as yet received no official Government response.

Health Secretary Alan Milburn has tried to head off the peers' revolt - which would be the fourth major defeat inflicted on the Government in as many months - by revealing that the Treasury has set up a Whitehall-wide working party on whether long-term care insurance scheme products should be regulated. But the working party is not due to report until the summer, and has met only once since it was set up in December.

Peers are not prepared to wait and want statutory regulation included immediately in the current Financial Services and Markets Bill. They fear that increasing numbers of elderly people will fall prey to pressure-selling of unsuitable insurance policies which purport to cover their future needs for residential care.

Following scandals over pensions mis-selling and poor mortgage advice, Ministers have already been forced to regulate pension marketing as well as some aspects of mortgage sales.

The ex-Treasury chief, formerly Terry Burns, said he would press his demand either at report or committee stage of the Financial Services and Marketing Bill, currently being examined by peers. Lipsey said that unless the Treasury moved on the issue, the Government would be heavily defeated.

The rebels believe there will be wide scope for high-pressure selling to people who are elderly and vulnerable and that many financial advisers will not have sufficient knowledge of the benefit system to give full advice. At present only 23,000 policies have been taken out, but many companies are planning to enter the field.

Both the Personal Investment Authority and Royal Commission support regulation, as does the Financial Services Authority.

Burns said yesterday: 'I have been very puzzled by the Government's attitude. Long-term insurance for the elderly seems to bear all the characteristics of a product that needs to be regulated.

'It seems the Government is very reluctant to move on this with any speed, but the case for action is urgent.'

webTitle: Cruelty was a way of life - and death

fields.headline: Cruelty was a way of life - and death
fields.standfirst: It is a story that will chill parents to the bone - a sickening case of neglect. But, asks  Jay Rayner , how does the law allow parents to remain in charge of five children despite 230 visits by the social services - and after three others had died in their care?
fields.trailText: It is a story that will chill parents to the bone - a sickening case of neglect. But, asks  Jay Rayner , how does the law allow parents to remain in charge of five children despite 230 visits by the social services - and after three others had died in their care?
fields.body:
She left them to lie on bedding so soaked in urine and caked in faeces that blowflies took up residence in the house. She changed nappies so irregularly they hung heavy down her children's legs with the weight of their contents. When the nappies leaked, as inevitably they would, she left their legs wet until they became red and sore. Their hair became infested with lice and their feet turned hard and calloused because they had so rarely known shoes.

At night, in the darkest hours, the babies were left crying out in hunger because their parents could not be bothered to get out of bed. And when they were fed it was with blended roast dinners and stews, weeks before they were ready even to begin weaning. Hospital appointments to monitor what eventually became life-threatening weight loss in some of the children were never kept and health visitors who tried to intervene were threatened and abused.

Last week at Lewes Crown Court the mother of seven from Brighton who, along with her common-law husband, was responsible for this litany of abuse was found guilty of cruelty and neglect. All the police officers, medical experts and social workers involved in the case describe it as among the worst they have ever come across. The husband, already in prison for raping a relativewhen he was a teenager, pleaded guilty at the start of the trial. They will both be sentenced for these offences on 20 March.

Those of us who sat through even a portion of the horrendous evidence could take little satisfaction from the guilty verdict. What many of us in the courtroom knew - and the jury did not know - was that the two defendants, who escape being named under injunctions designed to protect the identity of their children, who are now in care, had stood trial together at this court once before. Last July they were both charged with the murders of three children, two of their sons and a nephew. The first died in April 1994, the second and third in March 1997, just 19 days apart. All three died at home when there were no other adults present.

At first each was judged a cot death, but after the third a series of leading paediatric pathologists called in by the police found all of them had died by smothering. The couple were arrested and their surviving children placed with foster parents. In police interviews the mother blamed the husband. He said nothing. In court, however, the judge, Mr Justice Moses, directed the jury to acquit.

The mother's statements were purely self-serving, he said. What's more, he went on, 'The Crown cannot prove which of the two defendants smothered one or more of these children.' As it was therefore impossible to be certain who was responsible for the killings, or if they acted together, both had to be freed. Children who had been failed first by their parents and then by social services were failed again, this time by the justice system.

Now senior police officers are calling for a change in the law. 'There needs to be some way of dealing with joint enterprise,' said Paul Whitehouse, Chief Constable of Sussex, this week. 'We have three people in a room. Two adults come out alive and the child is dead. How can it be right that you cannot convict either of them if they stay silent or blame each other?'

Detective Inspector Malcolm Bacon, the chief investigating officer in the case, agrees: 'When the judge at the murder trial made his judgment I think the whole court was flabbergasted,' he said. 'I think there was sufficient evidence that should have been put before the jury.'

Some involved with this case have made comparisons with the Fred and Rose West case in Gloucester: a family on the tattered fringes of urban society, abusing their children unhindered by the law. But that is to diminish it. All caring parents are caring in the same ways. They know how to offer love and comfort, how to minister to an infant's needs. All abusive parents are uniquely so. These two, whom we can refer to only as Ms X and Mr Y, took neglect of children to new lows.

Both came from deprived backgrounds and had themselves spent periods in care as children. Together, from 1992 to 1998, they would have seven children, the last was born after they were arrested, and was taken into care at birth.

Concern for the children would emerge soon after birth as each in turn appeared underfed and was clearly failing to thrive. Becky Chalker, a health visitor with Southdown Health Trust in Brighton, spent five years trying to get them to improve conditions which she described to the court as 'absolutely dreadful'. She recalled kneeling down on the floor to examine a urine- soaked child and finding the carpet soaking wet. There were overflowing ashtrays and full cat-litter trays in reach of the children.

Displays of affection were so rare that Chalker noted them when they occurred. 'Toys were non-existent apart from a few soft ones,' she told the court. 'There was nothing appropriate for children who were developing and exploring.' She described one little boy as being fixed in a state of 'frozen watchfulness' by his treatment.

In the summer of 1993 their second child, a boy, suffered what would was described to the jury in the cruelty and neglect case as 'an acute life-threatening event', an ambiguous phrase which could as easily describe a car crash as an assault. Starved of oxygen, he suffered brain damage, leaving him blind, deaf and unable to swallow. Despite concerns over the family's living conditions he was allowed to return home from hospital with his parents. There he lay on a beanbag, face turned to the wall, to be fed through a nasal gastric tube.

In April 1994 the boy died. After their arrest, Ms X blamed her husband for the initial brain damage. That day their son had been crying and she had asked her husband to deal with him. He went into the room and the crying stopped. She said she passed her husband coming out of the room. 'My son had a pillow over his face,' she told police. 'My husband told me he would not stop crying and that he deserved all he got.'

In 1995 police raided the flat, looking for stolen property. The father, their prime suspect, was in the lounge with friends. 'The adults were sat round the sides of the room, all wearing coats. It was very cold in there,' Detective Sergeant Amanda Hinchcliffe told the court. 'There was a baby lying on the floor in the middle of the room wearing just his nappy. He appeared very cold and was blue. Flies were landing on him.'

The raid led to a visit by the Child Protection Unit who found similar conditions: a baby was asleep in a cot without a mattress, flies buzzing about it, faeces smeared on its stomach.

The children - an ever-growing number because Ms X went from one pregnancy to the next - were put on the Child Protection Register and the parents were given 24 hours to clean up the flat, which they did. In a police interview Ms X admitted the state of the flat was 'not very clever' but that if it meant holding on to her children, she'd keep it clean. A file was passed to the Crown Prosecution Service but they ruled there was insufficient evidence to proceed with charges of cruelty and neglect.

The couple had got away with it, for now.

The situation would repeat itself time and again throughout 230 visits by health and social work professionals, many of whom were subject to violent threats and abuse from Mr Y. The couple would do just enough to stop social services removing the children. The 1989 Children Act, passed in the wake of perceived over-zealousness by social workers in the Cleveland child abuse case of 1987, places emphasis on keeping families together rather than taking children into care. The social services felt they had to abide by its principles.

What emerges from the police interviews from these periods and later is that Ms Y understood what it took to care for a child: she knew about the need to wash clothes and to keep sufficient food in the house. She understood the language of caring. They 'tried to be' a good mum and dad, she said. 'Read 'em stories. I done everything.' But her everything was very little.

The deaths of their five-week-old nephew, followed by that of their six-week-old son 19 days apart in March 1997, were both ruled by a local pathologist to be by natural causes. However in April 1997 the Brighton coroner Veronica Hamilton-Deeley attended a lecture by paediatric pathologist Professor Mike Green, then of Sheffield University, on sudden unexplained infant deaths and when to be suspicious.

Green has regularly been criticised by British Cot Death support groups who argue that he overstates the number of sudden infant deaths which are actually homicides. In an article last year in the British Medical Journal , Green said that up to 40 per cent of such deaths may be as a result of adult intervention. The Foun dation for the Study of Infant Deaths relies on a Department of Health inquiry figure of 6 per cent. Nevertheless Green's advice to 'think dirty' rang bells with the coroner. Green was asked to study all the reports surrounding the case.

'If Miss Hamilton-Deeley hadn't attended my lecture it's possible I suppose that this couple could have continued for longer,' Green says now. 'The whole thing was just not right. I had little doubt that all three of these children had been smothered.'

Working with paediatric pathologists Sir Roy Meadow at Leeds and Professor Jeremy Berry at Bristol, the police charged the couple with murder. Only at that point, in June 1997, were their children taken into care. In his report, read to the court in the cruelty and neglect case, Meadow described the abuse the surviving children suffered as some of the worst he had come across in his 30-year career. It was, he said '10 out of 10 neglect'.

Finally in July 1999, the murder prosecution failed. At least 10 similar prosecutions have failed in the past 13 years, from that for the death of 16-month-old Doreen Mason in 1987 right up to that for the killing of 10-week-old Kate Carman last year, whose parents both blamed each other for the 35 broken bones and the ruptured liver she suffered. It is probable there are many more similar cases which never even get to court because the Crown Prosecution Service knows a successful outcome is unlikely.

DI Malcolm Bacon, who led the Brighton inquiry, would like to see a change in the law to deal with such cases. 'What I'm saying is that if the prosecution can prove that two people were there when a child was murdered the burden of proof should fall to them to say we were not responsible,' he says. 'It's not as if we're talking about the complete breakdown of the principles of law. Similar requirements apply in handling stolen goods cases where it falls to the defendant to explain how they came by the items.' Others, including Brighton MP Des Turner and the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, agree.

However, legal experts say any proposed change to deal with the problem is unlikely to succeed. Allan Levy, QC, is a leading child protection barrister and acted for the surviving children in the Brighton case. 'There are grave difficulties with the change being proposed,' he said. 'And I think it will fall foul of the European Convention on Human Rights which emphasises the right of defendants to be presumed innocent until proven guilty and which becomes part of British law in October. Obviously the death of any child is horrendous but you can't alter the principles of criminal justice to deal with specific cases.'

A spokesman for the Home Office said: 'All legislation is constantly under review. However, there are no plans to alter this particular aspect of law.'

Today Brighton Social Services is trying to learn lessons from an inter-agency review of the entire case. It accepted that health professionals had been working with violent individuals and had tried very hard in the circumstances. However, the review said, opportunities to intervene had been missed in an attempt to abide by the spirit of the Children Act, and that there had been a failure of record-keeping.

Allan Bowman, chairman of the local Area Child Protection Committee, who was not in post when the incidents occurred, accepts the findings. 'Opportunities were missed,' he says. But he adds, the Children Act that they have to work with does not help.

'Legislation never quite keeps up with the reality on the ground,' says Bowman. 'It never reflects the need for flexibility.Here we have a family who do enough to get by and, as a result, we can't be certain that we can justify taking the children into care. If you act too soon and lose and then try again you'll be accused of harassment.' Finally though, in the face of the evidence, the bureaucratic mask slips. 'How the hell did these kids die?' Bowman asks. 'Just what was done to them? What bloody motivation results in this outcome?'

It is a good question which no one can answer for certain. Under police questioning Ms X eventually admitted that Mr Y had beaten her repeatedly and stopped her from going to the authorities for help. She also blamed all three smotherings on him. DI Bacon reacted with surprise to this. 'Smothering is quite a subtle method of killing,' he says. 'He was a brutal, fists type of man. Smothering is the sort of method you more readily associate with the female.'

There is at least one ray of hope in this story. The five surviving children are said to be thriving in foster care. 'I have never seen children in that condition before in my life,' said one foster mother of their state on arrival at her home. 'They were very hungry and looked at food as though they had not seen it before. They ate with their hands.' Now, says health visitor Betty Chalker, they are all starting to find a kind of happiness. She recalled coming across one of the girls playing with beads and a dressing up box. 'She was given the opportunity to be a little girl and she loved it,' said Chalker. 'She was a different little child.'

One morning before the recent cruelty and neglect trial began, the barristers for the prosecution stood around discussing the linguistic problems in the phrase 'wilful neglect': the active process of being inactive. It didn't seem such a difficult concept to me, not where infants are concerned. Seven months ago I became a parent for the first time and, like every other parent, I know how hard it is not to respond to your child's cry. The couple in this case did it as a matter of course until the children simply lost the will to call out at all.

What chills the bone is that the abuse these children endured was not just a sequence of isolated incidents picked out in police reports. It was not about pools of darkness in a childhood filled mostly with light. It was a way of life. These kids woke with it in the morning and they fell asleep to it at night. I can type the last word and go home. You can turn the page. They lived with it every day of their wretched lives.

How couples slip past the law

As the law currently stands the prosecution in a murder trial must not merely prove that the defendant committed the act that resulted in death, but that they did so with the intent to kill or cause 'really serious harm'.

Where the scenario involves a couple in a house in which a baby or babies die, unseen by any other witnesses - as occurred in the Brighton case we report upon today - it is not enough for the forensic evidence to show that the action which resulted in death was one that required intent. Signs of internal haemorrhage, combined with bruising around the mouth and nose from sustained pressure, may prove that someone actively set about smothering the child. But that doesn't tell you who did it.

And for a murder conviction to stick you must know exactly who did what.

In a case involving a couple and a baby there are three possibilities: he did it, she did, or they both did it together in what is known as 'joint enterprise'. Common sense may suggest to us that in a situation where a baby is murdered at least one person in the couple committed the act and at least one person stood by and let it happen, making them equally culpable.

The law does not see it that way. You cannot guess what went on behind closed doors. And if both adults refuse to say anything then it cannot be ascertained who did what and they must both be acquitted.

It makes little difference if one or both blame the other, as happened in the Brighton case, when the wife blamed her common-law husband for the crime. The statements will be taken as 'self-serving' and the jury will be advised to treat them with such caution that they prove worthless.

It is probable there are many more similar cases which never even get to court because the Crown Prosecution Service knows a successful outcome is unlikely. DI Malcolm Bacon, who led the Brighton inquiry, would like to see a change in the law to deal with such cases. 'What I'm saying is that if the prosecution can prove that two people were there when a child was murdered the burden of proof should fall to them to say we were not responsible,' he says. 'It's not as if we're talking about the complete breakdown of the principles of law. Similar requirements apply in handling stolen goods cases where it falls to the defendant to explain how they came by the items.' Others, including Brighton MP Des Turner and the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, agree. However, legal experts say any proposed change to deal with the problem is unlikely to succeed. Allan Levy, QC, is a leading child protection barrister and acted for the surviving children in the Brighton case. 'There are grave difficulties with the change being proposed,' he said. 'And I think it will fall foul of the European Convention on Human Rights which emphasises the right of defendants to be presumed innocent until proven guilty and which becomes part of British law in October. Obviously the death of any child is horrendous but you can't alter the principles of criminal justice to deal with specific cases.' A spokesman for the Home Office said: 'All legislation is constantly under review. However, there are no plans to alter this particular aspect of law.' Today Brighton Social Services is trying to learn lessons from an inter-agency review of the entire case. It accepted that health professionals had been working with violent individuals and had tried very hard in the circumstances. However, the review said, opportunities to intervene had been missed in an attempt to abide by the spirit of the Children Act, and that there had been a failure of record-keeping. Allan Bowman, chairman of the local Area Child Protection Committee, who was not in post when the incidents occurred, accepts the findings. 'Opportunities were missed,' he says. But he adds, the Children Act that they have to work with does not help. 'Legislation never quite keeps up with the reality on the ground,' says Bowman. 'It never reflects the need for flexibility.Here we have a family who do enough to get by and, as a result, we can't be certain that we can justify taking the children into care. If you act too soon and lose and then try again you'll be accused of harassment.' Finally though, in the face of the evidence, the bureaucratic mask slips. 'How the hell did these kids die?' Bowman asks. 'Just what was done to them? What bloody motivation results in this outcome?' It is a good question which no one can answer for certain. Under police questioning Ms X eventually admitted that Mr Y had beaten her repeatedly and stopped her from going to the authorities for help. She also blamed all three smotherings on him. DI Bacon reacted with surprise to this. 'Smothering is quite a subtle method of killing,' he says. 'He was a brutal, fists type of man. Smothering is the sort of method you more readily associate with the female.' There is at least one ray of hope in this story. The five surviving children are said to be thriving in foster care. 'I have never seen children in that condition before in my life,' said one foster mother of their state on arrival at her home. 'They were very hungry and looked at food as though they had not seen it before. They ate with their hands.' Now, says health visitor Betty Chalker, they are all starting to find a kind of happiness. She recalled coming across one of the girls playing with beads and a dressing up box. 'She was given the opportunity to be a little girl and she loved it,' said Chalker. 'She was a different little child.' One morning before the recent cruelty and neglect trial began, the barristers for the prosecution stood around discussing the linguistic problems in the phrase 'wilful neglect': the active process of being inactive. It didn't seem such a difficult concept to me, not where infants are concerned. Seven months ago I became a parent for the first time and, like every other parent, I know how hard it is not to respond to your child's cry. The couple in this case did it as a matter of course until the children simply lost the will to call out at all. What chills the bone is that the abuse these children endured was not just a sequence of isolated incidents picked out in police reports. It was not about pools of darkness in a childhood filled mostly with light. It was a way of life. These kids woke with it in the morning and they fell asleep to it at night. I can type the last word and go home. You can turn the page. They lived with it every day of their wretched lives. How couples slip past the law As the law currently stands the prosecution in a murder trial must not merely prove that the defendant committed the act that resulted in death, but that they did so with the intent to kill or cause 'really serious harm'. Where the scenario involves a couple in a house in which a baby or babies die, unseen by any other witnesses - as occurred in the Brighton case we report upon today - it is not enough for the forensic evidence to show that the action which resulted in death was one that required intent. Signs of internal haemorrhage, combined with bruising around the mouth and nose from sustained pressure, may prove that someone actively set about smothering the child. But that doesn't tell you who did it. And for a murder conviction to stick you must know exactly who did what. In a case involving a couple and a baby there are three possibilities: he did it, she did, or they both did it together in what is known as 'joint enterprise'. Common sense may suggest to us that in a situation where a baby is murdered at least one person in the couple committed the act and at least one person stood by and let it happen, making them equally culpable. The law does not see it that way. You cannot guess what went on behind closed doors. And if both adults refuse to say anything then it cannot be ascertained who did what and they must both be acquitted. It makes little difference if one or both blame the other, as happened in the Brighton case, when the wife blamed her common-law husband for the crime. The statements will be taken as 'self-serving' and the jury will be advised to treat them with such caution that they prove worthless.

webTitle: Winter is mild but more old people die

fields.headline: Winter is mild but more old people die
fields.trailText: The winter death toll of old people is on course to be the highest for more than 20 years, the result of poor housing, disease and neglect. The rise in deaths is particularly shocking because this winter has been unusually mild.
fields.body:
The winter death toll of old people is on course to be the highest for more than 20 years, the result of poor housing, disease and neglect. The rise in deaths is particularly shocking because this winter has been unusually mild.

The bulge in deaths during winter - officially 'excess winter deaths' - soared last year to around 49,000, the highest level for a decade.

Preliminary figures for this winter suggest the toll will be higher still. Five thousand more people had died from December to February than the same period a year ago, according to the Office for National Statistics.

The figures are particularly embarrassing for the Government, which has pledged to put an end to fuel poverty and the spectre of old people dying in their homes of cold. They suggest virtually no progress has been made over the past two years.

Mervyn Kohler, Head of Public Affairs at Help the Aged, said: 'It's a scandal that so many more pensioners die in a British winter compared to older people living in much colder countries like Sweden and Canada.' In the UK, death rates rise by 31 per cent in the winter, whereas in Germany they rise by just 12 per cent and in Norway by just 10 per cent.

Official figures show a relatively small proportion of deaths this winter were due to flu or its complications, such as pneumonia. Far more elderly people are likely to have died from freezing at home. 'Pensioners live in some of the worst housing in the country - many of their homes are cold, damp and badly insulated,' said Kohler.

webTitle: Sarnies give way to sushi at lunchtime

fields.headline: Sarnies give way to sushi at lunchtime
fields.trailText: After the Walkman, the small car and the Playstation, sushi is the latest triumph of Japanese culture in the UK.
fields.body:
After the Walkman, the small car and the Playstation, sushi is the latest triumph of Japanese culture in the UK.

The Japanese dish has replaced possibly the most British tradition of all: the lunchtime buttie. From London to Glasgow, we are choosing sushi, not sandwiches, to see us through the day.

The mix of rice and fish, vegetables or fruit is so popular that Sainsbury's is selling 10 times as much sushi as its best-selling prawn mayonnaise sandwich in London's West End.

Other parts of the UK famous for fatty treats such as deep-fried Mars bars have also embraced the low-cholesterol, protein-rich food, according to research.

'This is not just a London-based trend,' said a Sainsbury's spokeswoman. 'Sushi is incredibly popular in Scotland. Sales have doubled in the past year and in our Glasgow store sushi outsells the top four selling sandwiches put together. Sushi is being requested in stores from Cheadle to Cambridge and Aberdeen to Bath.'

Nutritionists say Japan ese food is among the healthiest on the planet: high in protein and minerals but low in cholesterol, unlike red meat and dairy goods, the fatty staples of the Western diet.

The Japanese have a longer lifespan than any other nation, according to recent research. The average life expectancy is 80.1 years compared with 77.4 in the UK.

Their diet is thought to explain why heart disease and cancer have historically been lower than in the West.

Now - with the help of Britain's first Japanese-style chain of cafés Yo! Sushi - shoppers will find the whole Japanese eating experience alongside the the deli counters and aisles of ready-made salads in supermarkets.

From tomorrow, a new range of sushi meals will be prepared at a £1 million factory off the M25 motorway. The project is masterminded by a publicity-shy Japanese chef who claims to be on a mission to change British tastes.

He has recruited chefs who specialise in rice, the most important sushi ingredient.

webTitle: Sex: it's all in the mind

fields.headline: Sex: it's all in the mind
fields.standfirst: Brain scanners will map the differences between love and lust by peering into the male skull
fields.trailText: Brain scanners will map the differences between love and lust by peering into the male skull
fields.body:
They're the questions that have puzzled poets and singers since time began: what is love and how do you know it's more than just lust? Tomorrow scientists - armed with millions of pounds worth of brain scanners - will start a unique series of tests to find their own answer. They will identify which bit of the brain is fired by feelings of romance and which by feelings of sexual attraction.

Eighty heterosexual male volunteers at the Institute of Psychiatry in London will be strapped into a brain scanner while being shown pictures depicting romantic, erotic, neutral or distressing scenes. Using a technique known as functional MRI, Dr Tonmoy Sharma and his team will work out which part of the brain is being turned on: 'We want to try and isolate the emotions and see what circuits are involved. We are mapping the emotions, which are what makes us human.'

He makes no apology for using male volunteers: 'We believe that male sexual arousal is simpler and more linked to image, whereas in women it's more diverse.'

The study is part of a series of unique investigations to work out for the first time what different parts of the brain do.

Using functional MRI they can see in which part of the brain blood is flowing most rapidly - and so which part is working hardest - when people are thinking about certain subjects or undertaking certain tasks.

Sharma said: 'Until now the skull has prevented us from literally peering into the brain. With open heart surgery, you can take out the heart and look at it working - but you can't do that with the brain.'

Previous knowledge of the workings of the brain have been based on studies of people who have suffered brain injuries and lost some of their abilities. However, because of the damage, their brains may be working differently from healthy brains and the conclusions are thought to be inaccurate.

Sharma and his team have already identified which parts of the brain deal with language processing, by scanning the minds of volunteers while giving them verbal tasks. By giving people joy-sticks to play with they have worked out which part deals with motion control of the hands.

Future tests will try to identify which parts of the brain are fired up by fear, by giving volunteers electric shocks while they are in the scanner. Another study will try to map the parts of the brain that feel pleasure by 'testing people with pleasurable slides which raise the mood'.

The investigations are aimed at more than simply satisfying curiosity. For example, by identifying which part of the brain is triggered by lust, Sharma hopes to develop the first objective test of whether treatment of sex offenders has worked.

'The only test now is whether people get erections under certain stimuli, but that is to some extent under voluntary control,' said Sharma. 'But changes on blood flow in the brain are not under voluntary control.'

The study of pleasure should help to treat depression, where people are incapable of being happy.

'Looking at which part of the brain deals with anticipatory fear will help us understand psychopaths,' said Sharma.

By working out which part of the brain deals with memory tasks in people over the age of 55, Sharma hopes to be able to develop a technique to diagnose Alzheimer's disease before it occurs. New methods of treating the disease depend on early diagnosis, but at present it can only be identified once degeneration of the brain is so advanced it affects behaviour or memory.

The team is also scanning the brains of people with mental illness such as schizophrenia - the first time that anyone has seen any of the structural causes of the illness. Sharma hopes this will help reduce the stigma of the illness.

'We can show that there is really no difference from suffering these brain illnesses and breaking your hand,' said Sharma.

fields.headline: Top horses endure 'barbaric' branding
fields.trailText: Some of Britain's leading racehorse trainers are using a form of 'branding' that campaigners say is barbaric and unnecessarily cruel. The treatment allegedly prolongs their animals' racing careers but opponents accuse it of causing excruciating pain.
fields.body:
Some of Britain's leading racehorse trainers are using a form of 'branding' that campaigners say is barbaric and unnecessarily cruel. The treatment allegedly prolongs their animals' racing careers but opponents accuse it of causing excruciating pain.

As thousands gather for one of the country's premier race meetings at Cheltenham this week, The Observer can reveal that many of the horses running have been subjected to a treatment described as 'medieval' and 'barbaric' by vets.

The procedure involves inserting red-hot needles through the skin to burn tendons in the belief that the practice, known as 'firing', will prolong the careers of top National Hunt horses.

Both the RSPCA and the Royal College of Veterinary Surgeons have condemned the practice as causing animals unnecessary harm because there is no scientific evidence that it helps the horses. The RSPCA has threatened to prosecute any vets who can be proved to have fired horses.

A number of trainers gathering for the Cheltenham Festival routinely fire their horses. They include Paul Nicholls, who trains Call Equiname, the winner of last year's Champion Chase.

Yet despite complaints being made against a number of vets for having carried out the procedure, none has so far been charged or disciplined by their professional body.

According to David McDowell, the RSPCA's chief equine veterinary officer, there are few more disturbing operations which are performed on a horse.

'It's quite horrendous,' he said. 'The needle is inserted through the skin of the leg to burn the tendon. Alternatively, electrically-heated metal plates are placed on the outside of the leg to burn the skin. The belief is that creating scar tissue tightens the skin around the tendon and so gives it some support, and that would make future, similar injuries less likely.

'There is a significant body of research to suggest that not only does firing not work but it actually may aggravate whatever problems were there. It is all about keeping a horse racing; it's a financial decision.'

Many famous horses have been subjected to firing. They include Aldaniti, ridden by Bob Champion to victory in the 1981 Grand National, and Rough Quest, which won the same race 15 years later. Suny Bay, twice a runner-up in the National, underwent the procedure instead of being run at Cheltenham in 1995.

Television racing commentator Jim McGrath says that firing is common. 'There's hardly a trainer in this country in whose yard there will not be a horse which has been fired,' he says.

'Racehorses, particularly those that go over the jumps, have to bear up to all sorts of stresses and strains. They are the ones who are most likely to suffer tendon injuries and therefore are most likely to be fired. The whole process from the operation through to the end of recuperation will take some time. Many of the horses who have been out for up to a year after a tendon injury will have been fired.'

In the last two years, The Observer has learnt, two separate complaints about British vets firing horses have been forwarded to the Royal College of Veterinary Surgeons for action. But the College inquiries failed to result in any disciplinary action. A spokeswoman for the RCVS refused to comment on either case but claimed that the College was still trying to ban firing completely.

The RSPCA is frustrated by its inability to take more decisive action.

McDowell said: 'I believe firing is a criminal procedure. If we felt we could prove a vet had fired a horse we could bring a prosecution under the Protection of Animals Act. All that we would have to do to get a conviction is to show that an animal was caused unnecessary suffering and there is no doubt that firing does that. Unfortunately, because vets are not too keen to admit what they're doing, hard evidence has been difficult to come by.'

So sensitive is the subject that a number of trainers refused to comment. But David Elsworth, one of the most senior and outspoken figures in National Hunt racing, said: 'I don't think it's cruel.' He argued: 'Sure, horses are left sore for a couple of days after the operation but then humans are sore, after operations.If it prolongs their racing careers, then it's a small price to pay.

'There have been many horses who have won major races after being fired.'

One vet working at a major equine practice in Newmarket agreed to talk anony mously. He said: 'You've got to understand the nature of the racing industry. Tradition is all. Some, a small minority, will meet the changes but a large majority will not.

'They will prefer to stick to old methods which they believe are tried and tested, no matter if those methods run counter to good scientific sense.'

webTitle: Wales claims Guinness as its invention

fields.headline: Wales claims Guinness as its invention
fields.trailText: It will be enough to drive the Irish to drink: Guinness, favoured by generations of poets, thinkers and romantics from the Emerald Isle, was invented by the Welsh.
fields.body:
It will be enough to drive the Irish to drink: Guinness, favoured by generations of poets, thinkers and romantics from the Emerald Isle, was invented by the Welsh.

As people around the world prepare to sink thousands of gallons of the country's most famous export on St Patrick's Day this week, the startling claim that we should be tracing leeks rather than shamrocks on our pints has been made by the inhabitants of a Welsh town.

Locals from Llanfairfechan, near Bangor, claim to have identified the site of a tavern from where they claim Arthur Guinness stole the recipe for his famous stout in the 1750s. The Guinness company was this weekend unable to discount the theory.

In a twist straight from the firm's advertising campaign - 'Not everything in black and white makes sense' - the Welsh claim suggests that Guinness should be rechristened Gynwys. The drink is made from hops, barley and its secret ingredient - a special yeast. The Irish were once able to claim the drink derived its magical, life-enhancing properties from the addition of water from the River Liffey rather than its 4.1% alcohol content, but today Guinness is a global brand brewed in 50 countries.

The company's official history says Arthur Guinness developed his taste for dark ales on visits to London where he drank a brew called porter, named after the porters of Covent Garden and Billingsgate with whom it was especially popular. At the time, porter was almost certainly dark brown rather than black.

It has been suggested that before Guinness established his brewery in Dublin in 1759 he may have converted the Irish to porter by importing it from London. But Welsh local historian Deiniol ap Dafydd says it would not have made commercial sense for Arthur Guinness to transport porter all the way from London: the costs would have put the drink beyond most people's pockets.

And, he adds, it would have been a risky undertaking. In the eighteenth century the two-day crossing to Dublin was made from Holyhead on Anglesey. But before the construction of bridges at Conwy and the Menai Strait, Holyhead could only be reached by traversing the mountains of Snowdonia - a superhuman feat with a cargo of drink.

The claim has been given added weight by the identification of the site where Arthur Guinness is believed to have stopped on the last leg of his journeys to Holyhead. Two cottages are still standing - one known as Llety, the Welsh word for place of rest, was where the mail coach stopped overnight, and the other was then a tavern where a local black ale was brewed. That building is still known by its original name - Gwyn du, or 'black wine'.

Ap Dafydd said: 'The ale was renowned for being much darker, smoother and deeper than porter - much more like what we know today as Guinness.

'My view is that Mr Guinness tasted a whole range of local brews on his journey between London and Holyhead, but it was the black wine that took his fancy. It is what was to become Guinness.'

Peter Edmondson, who runs the garden centre in Llanfairfechan, adds that old maps of the town show three malting sites used by the pub. 'They would have produced far more malt than could ever have been needed in what was then a village of a few hundred people.' The surplus could have been going to Ireland.

A spokesman at the Irish Embassy in London, which will be serving Guinness at an official St Patrick's Day reception on Friday, was sanguine about the Welsh claim. 'I don't think anyone will be worrying about its origins come Friday.'
fields.bodyText: It will be enough to drive the Irish to drink: Guinness, favoured by generations of poets, thinkers and romantics from the Emerald Isle, was invented by the Welsh. As people around the world prepare to sink thousands of gallons of the country's most famous export on St Patrick's Day this week, the startling claim that we should be tracing leeks rather than shamrocks on our pints has been made by the inhabitants of a Welsh town. Locals from Llanfairfechan, near Bangor, claim to have identified the site of a tavern from where they claim Arthur Guinness stole the recipe for his famous stout in the 1750s. The Guinness company was this weekend unable to discount the theory. In a twist straight from the firm's advertising campaign - 'Not everything in black and white makes sense' - the Welsh claim suggests that Guinness should be rechristened Gynwys. The drink is made from hops, barley and its secret ingredient - a special yeast. The Irish were once able to claim the drink derived its magical, life-enhancing properties from the addition of water from the River Liffey rather than its 4.1% alcohol content, but today Guinness is a global brand brewed in 50 countries. The company's official history says Arthur Guinness developed his taste for dark ales on visits to London where he drank a brew called porter, named after the porters of Covent Garden and Billingsgate with whom it was especially popular. At the time, porter was almost certainly dark brown rather than black. It has been suggested that before Guinness established his brewery in Dublin in 1759 he may have converted the Irish to porter by importing it from London. But Welsh local historian Deiniol ap Dafydd says it would not have made commercial sense for Arthur Guinness to transport porter all the way from London: the costs would have put the drink beyond most people's pockets. And, he adds, it would have been a risky undertaking. In the eighteenth century the two-day crossing to Dublin was made from Holyhead on Anglesey. But before the construction of bridges at Conwy and the Menai Strait, Holyhead could only be reached by traversing the mountains of Snowdonia - a superhuman feat with a cargo of drink. The claim has been given added weight by the identification of the site where Arthur Guinness is believed to have stopped on the last leg of his journeys to Holyhead. Two cottages are still standing - one known as Llety, the Welsh word for place of rest, was where the mail coach stopped overnight, and the other was then a tavern where a local black ale was brewed. That building is still known by its original name - Gwyn du, or 'black wine'. Ap Dafydd said: 'The ale was renowned for being much darker, smoother and deeper than porter - much more like what we know today as Guinness. 'My view is that Mr Guinness tasted a whole range of local brews on his journey between London and Holyhead, but it was the black wine that took his fancy. It is what was to become Guinness.' Peter Edmondson, who runs the garden centre in Llanfairfechan, adds that old maps of the town show three malting sites used by the pub. 'They would have produced far more malt than could ever have been needed in what was then a village of a few hundred people.' The surplus could have been going to Ireland. A spokesman at the Irish Embassy in London, which will be serving Guinness at an official St Patrick's Day reception on Friday, was sanguine about the Welsh claim. 'I don't think anyone will be worrying about its origins come Friday.'
