fields.headline: Dewar barrage on Section 28
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: Donald Dewar made a strong case for the repeal of Section 28 in his speech to the Scottish Labour conference in Edinburgh yesterday.
fields.body:
Donald Dewar made a strong case for the repeal of Section 28 in his speech to the Scottish Labour conference in Edinburgh yesterday.

It echoed the defence of the policy in Tony Blair's speech the day before. The First Minister said there was "no way, no chance" that repeal would put children at risk.

He said the serious argument over Section 28 could not be 'reduced to irresponsible scaremongering on advertising hoardings'. He said the argument should be conducted on 'facts, not on nameless fears'. Speaking with vigour, Dewar said: 'Section 28 is discriminatory. It is seen as offensive. It is not a necessary safeguard and that is why it should go.'

He said Labour was delivering a 'progressive policy, not random concessions', and that 'steady improvement is preferable to boom and bust'.

He called the Liberal Democrat partners in the coalition 'not everyone's cup of tea' but said the Executive was 'working well at a practical level'. He hoped 'both parties can be proud' of the programme of the Executive.

Dewar said education and the health service were keys to the future plans of the party. The country needed to provide the skills for the e-commerce revolution and the health service needed to undergo reforms if it was to meet patient needs.

The First Minister criti cised the Scottish National Party for making uncosted promises, a mistake Labour had made 20 years ago. He dismissed critics of the new Holyrood building and said a parliament fit for the 21st century 'must be met and can be met on the Holyrood site'.

Earlier, the Minister for Communities, Wendy Alexander, who first announced the plans to scrap Section 28 last year, took her revenge on the backlash mounted by stagecoach entrepreneur Brian Souter. The poster campaign funded by Souter against repeal of the anti-gay law has done much to damage Alexander's standing in the Executive. She said: 'Our concerns are not a celebrity millionaire's misguided campaign, but our campaign to lift millions of children out of poverty.'

Alexander said Labour was defeating child poverty, describing it as the party's 'true moral cause'. She announced £13 million worth of initiatives targeted at improving communities, with some of this money going towards creating a loan fund for local projects. Finance Minister Jack McConnell voiced the only words of criticism at a fringe meeting, when he called for the conference to return to debating motions of principle. The remarks sounded like an appeal to older members who may have grown dissatisfied with the New Labour style.

webTitle: Rival steps up to take on Trimble

fields.headline: Rival steps up to take on Trimble
fields.standfirst:
Anti-Agreement plot to capture party

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: David Trimble will face a 'stalking-horse' challenger to his leadership of the Ulster Unionist Party later this month.
fields.body:
David Trimble will face a 'stalking-horse' challenger to his leadership of the Ulster Unionist Party later this month.

The most likely candidate is Jonathan Bell, a UUP councillor and anti-Agreement activist from Portadown. Bell told The Observer yesterday that he was not ruling out standing against Trimble when the party's ruling body, the Ulster Unionist Council, holds its annual meeting on 25 March.

Bell's supporters in the anti-Agreement camp will hope that history repeats itself and that he will do as well as the last 'stalking-horse' candidate four years ago. Lee Reynolds, an unknown Young Unionist, audaciously challenged the then UUP leader, Jim Molyneaux, at the 1995 Ulster Unionist Council AGM and won 15 per cent of the 860 votes cast.

The result was an embarrassment for Molyneaux and precipitated his retirement as party leader. Ironically, Reynolds, a hardliner opposed to compromise with republicans, paved the way for Trimble to take over the UUP in the same year.

Speaking from his home in Portadown yesterday, Bell said: 'I will be more clear about this in the forthcoming week. It's very fluid at the minute. But I am not ruling myself out. I have to be convinced that the challenge is for the greater good of Northern Ireland.'

Bell, who last year co-organised the Long March, a demonstration by unionist victims of the Troubles throughout Northern Ireland, said he was wary of falling into a trap by standing against Trimble.

'I could get double the vote Lee Reynolds received in 1995 but the result could end up being spun in Trimble's favour,' he said. 'In November, when he persuaded the party to set up a government with Sinn Fein, he received 58 per cent of the Ulster Unionist Council's support. If I were to get even 20 or 30 per cent, Trimble's people could still turn the whole thing around and say that David now commanded the loyalty of more people on the UUC than in November. So we have to be very careful.'

Bell said he was thinking of standing because of Trimble's failure to win any concessions over the Patten report into the RUC. He said assurances from Tony Blair and Peter Mandelson to Trimble were 'as useless as a chocolate fireguard'.

Trimble's allies say the UUP leader and former First Minister is expecting a 'stalking horse' challenge at the AGM. However, they are confident they can see off the challenge and avoid a potentially more difficult second leadership battle later this year.

They point to the fact that Molyneaux's leadership was already under question from senior members of the UUP hierarchy before Reynolds decided to stand against him. Reynolds simply acted as a catalyst for those who had made up their mind to persuade Molyneaux to step down.

The forthcoming AGM is set to become a showdown between the pro- and anti-Agreement factions of Ulster Unionism.

fields.headline: Straw to end Bulger-style trials
fields.trailText: Children suspected of serious crimes, such as the killers of toddler Jamie Bulger, will not be tried in the adult courts in future. Home Secretary Jack Straw is set to issue a statement this week that he accepts the European ruling that the trial of Robert Thompson and John Venables in 1993 breached their human rights.
fields.body:
Children suspected of serious crimes, such as the killers of toddler Jamie Bulger, will not be tried in the adult courts in future. Home Secretary Jack Straw is set to issue a statement this week that he accepts the European ruling that the trial of Robert Thompson and John Venables in 1993 breached their human rights.

The announcement will be made as part of sweeping reforms of the criminal jus tice system including a huge expansion of tagging and drug testing by the police.

The European Court of Human Rights decided that an adult court was not the appropriate place to try Thompson and Venables. It is thought that a new tribunal will be set up for children accused of serious crimes.

It is likely that these tribunals will adopt the inquisitorial system that operates in Scotland and many European countries rather than the adversarial approach of the English courts.

At the heart of a new criminal justice Bill to be introduced this week will be a root-and-branch reform of the penal system, which will open the way to the eventual merging of the prison and probation services in a US-style Department of Corrections.

A National Correctional Strategy Board will be set up to coordinate the punishment of criminals in jail and in the community. The board will be chaired by Deputy Home Secretary Paul Boateng and will include the director of the Prison Service and a new national director of the Probation Service to be appointed later this year.

Party sources said that the Government wanted a complete shake-up of the social work image of the Probation Service in the run-up to the election campaign, during which they will emphasise New Labour's law and order credentials. Ministers want the Probation Service to find a new role for itself as a punishment agency alongside the police and the Prison Service.

Boateng said last night: 'This is a new beginning for the Probation Service as a law-enforcement agency. We are ensuring that it is equipped to play its part alongside the Prison Service in developing corrections.'

The moves are likely to cause fury in the Probation Service, whose officers traditionally identify with the caring professions. National Association of Probation Officers spokesman Harry Fletcher said last night: 'It is clear that the long-term aim is a unified corrections service and that will appall many probation staff. We fear that the counselling role will be completely overwhelmed by prison warehouse culture.'

Ministers also hope the changes will lead to the reform of the Prison Service. They have been concerned by recent reports into Wormwood Scrubs and Wandsworth which described militaristic, brutal regimes.

Ahead of this week's announcements, Home Secretary Jack Straw warned this weekend that the prison population will continue to rise for the 'foreseeable future'. He said it was the duty of the Home Secretary to provide extra prison places.

Straw said that the prison population had increased by 25,000 over the last 10 years to its present level of 65,000. Since Labour came to power in 1997, prison numbers have increased by 6,000. The number of those in jail per head of population is the highest in Europe apart from Portugal.

Straw said: 'Prison is the answer for people committing crimes who have not got the message.'

fields.headline: Meet Scottish Majority Plc
fields.standfirst:
The firm, sorry, the Labour conference, seems ready to trade defeat in Ayr for the big prize of a second UK term

Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: The firm, sorry, the Labour conference, seems ready to trade defeat in Ayr for the big prize of a second UK term
fields.body:
Delegates at Labour's Scottish conference left the briefing with Douglas Alexander energised. They had been shown the path to glory, and liked what they saw. Alexander, the MP for Paisley South, was telling them about Operation Turnout, the war plan designed to secure Labour's second term in Westminster.

Everywhere a delegate turned in Edinburgh's International Conference centre there was a reminder that New Labour holds electoral success to be its Holy Grail. Every speech hit the themes that the next general election will be fought on. Every policy session was geared towards producing the next manifesto.

Alexander told the closed session on Operation Turnout that the Tories were the main enemy. Labour thinks blue ranks are being massed in the Pennines, which will be hotly contested in the next UK general election. In Scotland, virtually all Labour's marginal seats are against the Conservatives.

But according to Labour another enemy is gathering its forces of conservatism to stand in the way of Blair's dream: the media. The Prime Minister referred to its 'corrosive cynicism' in his speech to Holyrood, and mocked the Daily Record in his conference speech. This wasn't the pique of a once hugely popular leader discovering his mortality. It was the opening of the election campaign.

Alexander said papers such as the Express and Daily Mail might turn on Labour by the time the country went to the polls. Party strategists want to weaken the credibility of the media, so that a distrustful public may be less ready to swallow negative commentary on the Government's performance.

Operation Turnout also focuses on voter apathy. The problem for Labour, according to its own analysis, is that voters aren't fully aware of the party's record in government. If told of its achievement, they will feel enthused to vote, the party thinks.

It believes the young are increasingly not voting, possibly because they too have developed a 'corrosive cynicism' about politics. Local, Labour parties are being trained in ways of encouraging them to turn out.

Party managers can look back on a well-run conference. This is largely because under the new policy formation rules, it's virtually impossible for delegates to argue and create bad headlines. Where once they voted on motions and amendments on specific issues, now they discuss general documents. The conference can vote for, or against, a document, but cannot amend it line by line. Next year these documents will have become policy statements, which conference can either reject or accept in their entirety.

It means the party's policy is no longer derived from a mass of separate conference votes, but is geared specifically to the next election. Managers say it allows many more people to contribute, and ensures that the Scottish party will write its own manifesto for the next UK election. Another element of Operation Turnout is for Labour in Scotland to play up its Scottishness.

It's no accident that the Secretary of State for Scotland John Reid aimed his fire at the SNP in his conference speech. The party is concerned it is losing ground on the question of representing Scots, as opposed to the UK electorate. Reid's quip that 1966 was the year 'Germany nearly won the World Cup' is the kind of line normally rounded on if uttered at an SNP conference, but touches the same nerve of identity.

The conference felt like the gathering of 'Scotland's Majority Plc' - a company which has long dominated the political market and was preparing for a new sales drive. Nowhere on the PowerPoint overhead projectors was the one word that might have reminded delegates that real life is different. That word is Ayr.

The refrain of 'social justice' which rang through the conference like an incessant Tannoy announcement rings hollow in the by-election. Voters look set to hand the seat back to the Tories, after returning a Labour MSP last year. They understand Labour's achievements in government, but dislike its achievements on their local council.

South Ayrshire has made swingeing cuts in services. The Labour-run council is trying to cope with a financial settlement bequeathed them by a Labour Minister in Holyrood. A day centre for the over-60s is to be closed, provoking great anger among traditional Labour voters.

The SNP claims it is picking up so many Labour votes it may win. 'We can scent something very significant' is how Alex Salmond put it. The Tories think this is 'absolute nonsense' and a bluff.

Tory candidate John Scott still looks the likeliest winner, but an SNP win would be an astonishing triumph for the Deputy Leader John Swinney, who has run the campaign. Party strategists are already delighted at the way Swinney announced a key policy change last week.

He has recommended to his party's National Council that the SNP should hold a referendum on independence after any general election victory but before independence negotiations begin.

The SNP had long held that a simple majority at a general election would deliver the mandate for independence negotiations. In 1992 the idea of a referendum after the negotiations was adopted. However party leaders believed the policy still made independence seem a 'leap in the dark' to voters.

On last week's evidence, however, Labour has got ahead of its rivals, and will accept a bloody nose in Ayr if it wins the general election.

webTitle: Republican glee misplaced as Titanic shipyard goes under

fields.headline: Republican glee misplaced as Titanic shipyard goes under
fields.standfirst:
The sinking of Harland and Wolff will harm the whole community

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The sinking of Harland and Wolff will harm the whole community
fields.body:
On 21 July 1920 a mass meeting of Protestant workers was held in the yard of Workman, Clark and Co. in Belfast. After the meeting, during which 'speeches were made about not allowing Sinn Fein and Roman Catholics to work in the shipyards any longer', bodies of men carrying sticks and clubs descended on Harland and Wolff - the site of the third most important shipbuilding centre in the British Empire. A police report described the subsequent violence as a 'general hunt' for Catholic workers, some of whom were beaten and thrown into the water.

Thus began, in the middle of the IRA's war against British rule and the establishment of a separate Northern/Unionist state, the mass expulsion of Catholic workers from the shipyard, which built the Titanic.

The expulsions sparked off an orgy of sectarian violence in east Belfast which continued sporadically for two years after partition. In May 1922 my great-uncle, Hugh McDonald, was taken off a tram crossing Queen's Bridge - one of the main routes to the shipyard in east Belfast - and beaten to death by a loyalist mob in nearby Memel Street.

The expulsion of thousands of Catholic workers left a deep psychological scar on nationalists who found themselves living inside the new partitioned Northern Ireland state two years later. It is hardly surprising therefore that when news broke last week that the shipyard, whose twin giant yellow cranes dominate the Belfast skyline, was on the verge of closure, there was a certain amount of schadenfreude within the republican community in the city.

In republican eyes at least, an exclusively Protestant working-class institution was coming to an end, another death knell for the Victorian-Unionist version of old Belfast.

They point to the fact that the yard's workforce continued to provide the shock troops for loyalist street protests right up until the 1970s and 1980s. During the 1974 Ulster workers' strike, which brought down the last power-sharing government in Northern Ireland, the shipyard was closed down, thanks to a combination of loyalist militancy and outright intimidation.

But the delight shared by republicans over the shipyard's imminent closure is both short-sighted and as sectarian as the bigotry which kept Catholics excluded from the yard's gates for decades. The loss of shipbuilding in Belfast will have a negative spin-off for the entire Northern Ireland economy; everyone will be a loser.

Tom Gillen, from the Irish Congress of Trade Unions, has been at the forefront of confronting sectarian discrimination in the workplace. But he warned yesterday that nationalists, like everyone else, had nothing to gain from the yard's closure.

'Those who are gloating about this are very, very short-sighted. Support for the union in the tightly knit terraced working- class streets of loyalist east Belfast in the shadow of the shipyard is as strong as the time when the workers who built the Titanic and its sister ships, the Olympic and the Britannic, vigorously opposed Home Rule.

Yet less than a quarter of a mile from its 300-acre site, there is a new belt of luxury apartments, the Hilton hotel, the Waterfront Hall and offices for companies such as British Telecom. Some of the apartments cost up to a quarter of a million pounds and are situated close to the very spot where my great-uncle Hugh was battered to death. Dublin-based consortiums have moved their newly-earned money from the Celtic Tiger in the south into property in Northern Ireland.

The prospect of closure at Harland and Wolff impacts politically on the loyalist psy che and fuels paranoia about a British economic withdrawal from Northern Ireland. Those who engage in reverse triumphalism over the yard's closure are in danger of backing the Unionist population into a corner, especially the Protestant working class. In an age of uncertainty, that can only drive them into the arms of extreme rejectionist unionism rather than the new unionism of David Trimble.

And those nationalists who are gloating today about the forthcoming end of shipbuilding in east Belfast should remember what the future could hold. It might be the Protestant-dominated workforce of Harland and Wolf today who suffers, but tomorrow it could be the shirt factories of Catholic-dominated Derry facing closure.

Most politicians and commentators from both sides of the border recognise the eco nomic and political dangers in allowing shipbuilding to die in Belfast.

Yesterday the Irish Times devoted a page to the Harland and Wolff crisis. Ironically, in the bottom left corner space was set aside for two advertisements for retraining in 'Internet marketing' and 'effective website design'. The wealth generators in the 19th and 20th centuries set beside the new engines of e-commerce in the 21st.

webTitle: DIY Britons break free of package holiday hell

fields.headline: DIY Britons break free of package holiday hell
fields.trailText: Most Britons seeking their place in the summer sun have had to endure package holiday hell: a patronising tour rep, lukewarm sangría at the welcoming party and dawn trips to be at the airport five hours before the flight.
fields.body:
Most Britons seeking their place in the summer sun have had to endure package holiday hell: a patronising tour rep, lukewarm sangría at the welcoming party and dawn trips to be at the airport five hours before the flight.

But the current generation has had enough. Fed up with foreign trips regimented by reps with irritating patter, record numbers of holidaymakers are turning their backs on the packages that promised nothing abroadwould be 'too foreign'.

A new survey shows that, for the first time since mass tourism began in the Sixties, more Brits are now organising their own breaks than taking the packages offered by tour companies.

'British holidaymakers are a lot more sophisticated now,' said leisure consultant Anne Bourgeois. 'The baby-boomers who went travelling a lot when they were young know exactly what they want and where they want to go. They are able to pick their own accommodation and book their flights to achieve the flexibility that they believe packages can't offer.'

Cheaper air travel to a growing list of destinations as well as easier access to popular continental places through the Channel Tunnel have boosted the spirit of independence.

'Low-cost, no-frills airlines have opened up cities to many more people and the consumer is becoming very good at shopping around to find the best bargains,' Bourgeois said.

Media company manager David Greenwood, 30, is typical of the new breed. His parents were among the first generation of package tourists who travelled to one-time favourites such as Rimini, Italy, on propeller-driven planes from Biggin Hill, Kent.

His idea of a break is very different. 'I took a holiday to Goa with a package company on a charter flight because it seemed easy and it was cheap. The flight was a nightmare with everybody crushed in.

'The hotel was okay - it was one of the least package-like. The only activity I got involved with was the welcome drink, but it was just an embarrassing attempt to sell us all the tours they were running. I worked out we could get to the market for the equivalent of 6p on the local bus. They were charging something like £9, and you had to go exactly when it suited them with a whole bunch of people I had no interest in getting to know.'

Independent travel is no longer associated only with back-packing and far -off destinations, the survey by market research firm Mintel shows. Top of the free-thinking traveller's list of destinations is France, followed by Spain - aided by accessibility and the strong pound.

But self-drive holidays in the United States and flight-only bookings to European cities are also soaring in popularity.

Thousands of small hotels now post their details on the Web, so more travellers are e-mailing hotel owners directly.

The language barrier is less frightening in print than over the telephone, researchers found. Jennifer Cox, the Radio 1 travel presenter and spokeswoman for Lonely Planet guides, said the Internet is driving independent travel rapidly forward. 'We get more than three million hits a day on our website. Package holidays were based on the assumption that you didn't know how to do it yourself, but now technology means there is well-packaged information which is readily accessible and interactive.'

Short, city breaks are more popular than ever, and these also tend to be booked independently. Twice as many people will take a short break to the Continent this year as did in 1994, when the Channel Tunnel opened. There was a further boost when the air industry was opened up to greater competition in 1997.

Domestic holidays are less popular than they were six years ago, and only the taste for weekend breaks is sustaining the UK home market.

Although the statistics show that there are twice as many holidays taken at home than abroad, consumers spend more lavishly on foreign trips. The average spent per UK holiday is £161, compared to e £400 on an overseas trip, not including the travel to and from the destination.

'More people go abroad for their main holiday because we are just too expensive in Britain,' said Robert Unsworth, editor of The Good Guide to Britain .

'We still persist in charging per person instead of per room and offer worse value than probably anywhere else in the world. But short breaks are a different story. People want the minimum hassle, to go somewhere relaxed with something nice to do. Britain is a good place for that.'

Foreign breaks rather than domestic holidays are fuelling the record popularity of getting away. Mintel estimates that 100 million holidays will be taken this year - two million more than in 1999 when the total spending on breaks was £23.5 billion. Spending this year is forecast to reach £24.3 billion.

sarah.ryle@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Danny Boy favourite to oust Queen

fields.headline: Danny Boy favourite to oust Queen
fields.standfirst: The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: 'God Save the Queen', already under heavy attack as a sporting anthem, now faces the axe at Windsor Park, Northern Ireland's cauldron of loyalist football passion. 'Danny Boy', the bittersweet, non-sectarian song of the homesick Irish exile, is favourite to replace it.
fields.body:
'God Save the Queen', already under heavy attack as a sporting anthem, now faces the axe at Windsor Park, Northern Ireland's cauldron of loyalist football passion. 'Danny Boy', the bittersweet, non-sectarian song of the homesick Irish exile, is favourite to replace it.

As disclosed in The Observer last week, the national anthem's use by the English football and rugby teams has come under increasing criticism in the age of devolution because it celebrates the British state.

But it has a special significance for Ulster Protestants and is the unofficial anthem of Glasgow Rangers. Loyalists are expected to resist plans by the Irish Football Association to drop it in an attempt to persuade more Catholics to support the Northern Ireland team.

Most Catholics and nationalists stay away from the Windsor Park either out of fear of attack from loyalist hooligans or because they prefer to support the Republic of Ireland.

John Quinn, the IFA's spokesman, said dropping 'God Save the Queen' was an option if a revived peace process could restore the Assembly and its power to fund the association's community programme.

He explained there were no plans to drop it until after the World Cup in 2002. But he pointed out that the issue would be debated when the association implemented its community relations policy.

Quinn said the IFA was the first sporting organisation in Northern Ireland to adopt an anti-sectarian policy, which in theory urges an end to sectarian chanting at local soccer stadiums.

Norman Boyd, an Assemblyman for the Northern Ireland Unionist Party and life-long fan of the Ulster Protestant's most favoured football side, Linfield, said the issue should not even be discussed by the IFA.

'If the IFA ever attempted to change the national anthem of my country to something else I would lead a boycott campaign of Windsor Park. I have supported Northern Ireland all my life, I have followed them home and away but I would not go to Windsor if they played a different anthem.

'It doesn't surprise me that some elements inside the IFA would consider such a thing but I don't think the issue should even be on the agenda.'

webTitle: If my partner slept with his sister, should I dump him?

fields.headline: If my partner slept with his sister, should I dump him?
fields.trailText: I am engaged to a man who is kind, caring and eager to adopt my two young children from a previous marriage. There is just one thing bugging me - his sister.
fields.body:
I am engaged to a man who is kind, caring and eager to adopt my two young children from a previous marriage. There is just one thing bugging me - his sister. Until the age of 15, they shared the same bed. They are obviously close, but at Christmas she gave him a variety of presents with messages that said: 'I love you.' She once told me that their father sexually abused her and she had a termination at 14. My partner says this is not true.

I hate to think it, but I can't help wondering if my partner has had an incestuous relationship. Although she seems a rational human being, his sister says the most bizarre things and cries when my partner doesn't pay her enough attention.
J.O. of Swansea

This complex situation is difficult to unravel on the basis of such a tiny piece of information. The sister claims abuse by the father, which her brother denies. But how does he know? It would be more rational to claim ignorance. A vehement negative may conceal doubts, or he may be echoing his parents' response. There may be such a condition as 'false memory syndrome' in women but I suspect it's a great deal rarer than 'false denial syndrome' in men.

On the other hand, sibling incest is said to be very unusual. Very little research has been undertaken. There may usually be an age gap and a power gradient, with coercion of the female by the male rather than mutual consent. This would not fit with the strong, affectionate ties between them.

Sleeping arrangements in families may well be more varied than is commonly supposed. In some modern houses, with cupboard-sized bedrooms, ideal arrangements may not be possible. Also, there does exist an innate barrier whereby potential sexual attraction between siblings is downplayed, if not eliminated.

My feeling is that a sexual relationship between the brother and sister in the past is unlikely, but that there could have been parental abuse of the sister, which may account for her abnormal behaviour. If I were you, I should try to gain her confidence and hear her full story. Maybe you haven't yet laid bare your anxieties to your fiancé, but your suspicions must be absolutely dissolved before you marry him.

In view of the sensitivity, guilt, secrecy and denial involved in unnatural sex, you may never feel you are completely in possession of the truth. Faced with such an uphill task, you won't accomplish it without 'seeming mistrustful'. He may be angry, hostile, hurt, but if he is a genuinely decent man, he will see that you have a right to answers. Don't try to be tactful. There's no way you can approach this topic in a subtle, inoffensive way.

Without wishing to damage your relationship any further, I should point out that abusive behaviour by parents (whether by inheritance or imitation) is often repeated in the next generation. Statistically, there is greater likelihood of abuse by a step-parent than by a natural parent. Your children are the most compelling reason for being 100 per cent sure before you link up with this family.

Reader's responses

I think you know what to believe and, understandably, it terrifies you. If you ask your fiancé for a truthful account of his relationship with his sister you may not like the result. My advice would be to run for your life.
L.S. of Hove

 Run like the wind from this abuser. Your lover fathered his sister's baby, not their father. He is grooming you and your children for future sex. He has succeeded in infantilising his sister to the extent that she depends utterly on him.

Get your children away and tell him any old rubbish. He'll know you've rumbled him anyway. As for seeming distrustful, you've every right to. I wouldn't trust him as far as I could chuck him, having worked for social services with abused children.
C.R. of Cheshire

Next week's problem is from J.D. of London

My son is 15. I am divorced from his father but we are on reasonably friendly terms. Our son divides his time between us. We have just heard from a teacher that it is rumoured he has been smoking marijuana and, more seriously, bringing the stuff into school.

He is a bright boy who suddenly seems lacklustre and insecure. We do not want to confront him without more evidence, but if the rumour is true, we are not sure how hard we should be on him. I am worried that our son is releasing stressful feelings about his divided life by smoking dope.

 Write to Observer Review or e-mail margaret.cook@observer.co.uk. Views on next week's dilemma to reach us by Wednesday. Margaret Cook writes for Woman's Journal.

webTitle: Where did you find that voice?

fields.headline: Where did you find that voice?
fields.standfirst: Madonna's English boyfriend sounds like he's invented his own accent. And he's not the only one, says Andrew Smith
fields.trailText: Madonna's English boyfriend sounds like he's invented his own accent. And he's not the only one.
fields.body:
Guy Ritchie first appeared two years ago as the unknown writer and director of Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels, one of the smartest British feature films of the past decade. Then he started dating the biggest pop star in the world. Then he spoke on TV and made the film industry's previous most militant proletarian, Alan Parker, sound like the Queen.

Predictably, the media was most tickled by the second of these achievements and if Bafta decides to go with the flow this year, an award for best British boyfriend of Madonna is already in the can. That accent, though, is intriguing. Even more so than his choice of girlfriend. Especially when it transpires that Ritchie's father was the affluent ad man behind the Hamlet TV commercials, and that the boy spent some unhappy years at private schools, where he certainly didn't learn to talk like that.

The tyro director seems to provide an excellent demonstration of the way that young Britons feel newly free to choose accents from among an available range, as if selecting a suit from Paul Smith, rather than simply accepting the one they were born with.

The things we read into accents have changed remarkably little over the decades. Even on TV, presenters with 'regional' accents, such as Sara Cox (Manc? Yorkshire?) and Jayne Middlemiss (Geordie?), tend to be packaged as rough-hewn, pint-swilling ladettes. The stereotypes endure. Dr Bernice Mahoney, a lecturer at Worcester College of Higher Education, did some research into the effect different accents have on juries' willingness or unwillingness to trust defendants. There are many conclusions to be drawn from her report, one of which is that, if you're from Birmingham, you might as well just plead guilty.

I arrived in this country from the US at the age of 13. It quickly became apparent to me that a would-be Englishman needed two things to survive: a football team and an accent. The latter was a problem. Almost no one at my school in Hastings spoke with the Sussex drawl of my grandparents - in fact, the few boys who did were ribbed far more remorselessly than I was for my Starsky and Hutch drawl. Varying strengths of cockney dominated, with a few quasi-RP speakers dotted around the edge. My response was to find something in between, and I suppose I wasn't the only one doing it.

Ten years later, in 1984, an English teacher called Rose Warne would find a name for this hybrid southern speak: 'Estuary English', after the Thames Estuary. The most distinctive feature of this mutant accent is the 'glottal stop', which involves failing to sound the 't' in words like 'little'. Others include 'l-vocalisation', where an 'l' is pronounced more like a 'w', and 'th-fronting', where 'th' becomes 'f' or 'v'.

Examples of these speech patterns may be found in most southern-raised TV personalities (Zoë Ball, Jonathan Ross) and musicians (Damon Albarn, Nigel Kennedy), in politicians like Ken Livingstone and Chris Smith, and many sports personalities. Not long ago, the Daily Telegraph, referring to England cricket captain Nasser Hussain, thundered that 'somebody who went to a good university has no business speaking in that ghastly estuary sludge'.

So, if Estuary English was unconsciously designed to provide a safe middle ground, free of judgment, it has failed. Alarm has been sparked in the more excitable sections of the media by research suggesting that it is also colonising Liverpool, Manchester, Newcastle and Glasgow. With the BBC and the RSC now embracing non-standard English, the actress Prunella Scales has reportedly assembled a library of posh accents at the National Sound Archive, so future generations will have some idea how to speak Wilde, Coward and Shaw. The implication is that, before long, there will be no posh accents in real life. Even Prince Edward has been chastised for speaking Estuary. The cumulative impression is that our beloved tongue is under attack from this new linguistic virus.

But it's not. Professor John Wells of University College, London, is one of our most distinguished linguists. From his office in the Department of Phonetics and Linguistics, he views things differently. 'As often happens in language matters,' he says, 'the English have got into a muddle.' His thesis rests on the assertion that 'the tendency of features of popular London speech to spread out geographically and socially has been going on for 500 years or more - London has always been the chief source of new trends in English.'

He thus prefers the (admittedly unwieldy) term 'standard English spoken with the accent of the south-east of England' to the more catchy Estuary, adding that there is now a 'new acceptance of speech patterns associated with the working class, and a disinclination to accept RP as the self-evident norm of pronunciation'.

But this is only part of the story. The thing about Estuary is that it provides a good base from which to speak to anyone. Many people's accent seems to change, depending on who they are talking to. Linguists call this process 'accommodation' and we learn to do it from an early age. According to James Crinson, a headmaster on Tyneside who attained his PhD on the strength of a study of the speaking habits of local children, there is no point in trying to correct the language of seven-year-olds, 'because they separate out what's appropriate for certain circumstances'.

In his region, he contends, there is a bigger difference between the idioms used by boys and girls than between social classes. He found boys tending to use the Tyneside glottal stop, for instance, with girls preferring either the southern English version, or none at all. It is a range of accents. Where past generations might have changed or adapted theirs in order to announce their place in the social order, we - unconsciously, for the most part - use ours in order to neutralise our backgrounds, confound attempts to place or pre-judge us. What we have is a mobile, malleable template, which we customise to suit ourselves and our circumstances.

webTitle: Let's all move to Milton Keynes...

fields.headline: Let's all move to Milton Keynes...
fields.standfirst: John Prescott says the future is high-density housing. Architects must rise to the challenge, writes  Deyan Sudjic
fields.trailText: John Prescott says the future is high-density housing. Architects must rise to the challenge.
fields.body:
This is turning out to be a government with a quite remarkable interest in architecture. First it was Tony Blair, with his determined embrace of the Dome, in a self-conscious echo of François Mitterrand and the Parisian grand projets. Then there was the appointment of the developer Stuart Lipton to lead the new Commission for Architecture and the Built Environment, charged with improving the quality of architecture both public and private. Now there is John Prescott, who may yet have the greatest impact of all, with his vision for the future of house building.

With an extra 43,000 Prescott houses likely to be built every year in the South East alone, it's certainly going to be the most visible of the Government's architectural initiatives. And it suggests that after a couple of decades in the doldrums, houses are going to be the next big thing for architects. Back in the 1960s, housing was at the epicentre of architectural debate. But that was before Margaret Thatcher axed council house building from a peak of 300,000 a year, down to a mere 15,000.

Like everything else, house building was to be left to the private sector. The results have, if anything, been even more dismal than the failings of council housing. Most of Britain's house builders are still trapped in what the architect and developer Roger Zogolovitch once called the pre-Habitat era. 'They assume that the British public is sophisticated enough to buy smart German cars and Japanese stereos, but that they check their taste buds at the door when it comes to buying a house.'

Richard Rogers's urban task force was set up to look at ways of filling the policy vacuum on housing. He went to Holland and declared Britain's housing policy to be lagging 20 years behind.

The Deputy Prime Minister might have sounded as if he was playing one interest group off against another when he announced last week that the Government would push through all those additional new homes. But what he was really doing was putting forward a very particular vision of the city. Let's save precious countryside by building on land that has already been contaminated. And by building a little more densely, let's not waste land on suburban sprawl.

The response to Prescott's plans revealed all the ancient feuds that have shaped British attitudes to urban life ever since William Morris declared the industrial city to be an abomination and preached for a return to the decentralised rural ideal. Britain is still divided between those who see the city as a monstrous blot on the landscape, and those who regard the city as the greatest of all mankind's inventions. The monstrous-blot camp were the people who pushed Britain into building the new towns in the 1950s and 1960s. And they are supported by the private house builders who regard building on brownfield land as too much trouble, but keep it to themselves. Publicly they will say that their customers won't stand for the high densities that Rogers and Prescott are demanding. The British will not put up with being squashed like sardines; they want semi-detached houses, not terraces, they claim.

Piers Gough, one of Britain's more innovative housing architects, is supportive of Prescott's plans. 'Its not to do with preventing the invasion of the countryside, its about shitting on the land and not putting it right afterwards. Bloody well clear it up, and don't just move on to a more convenient place. What everybody wants is not what the country can sustain.'

But in truth, it's not the land that is the real issue. It's an idea of what cities could be like. When architects talk about high-density urban living, they have in their heads a picture of Nash's glorious cream stucco terraced houses in Regents Park rising from romantic greenery. Or of Parisian boulevards and pavement cafes. And no wonder - it's a lot more interesting designing housing areas like this than it is churning out the repetitive little boxes of suburbia. But what it really means, in the context of Prescott's attempts to wean us off our addiction to the Brookside cul-de-sac, is more like Milton Keynes. Quite literally so, since Prescott wants new housing concentrated in two areas; north-west of London along the M1, at Milton Keynes, and south-east of it around the Eurostar station at Ashford. And that is hardly the same thing. The real challenge is to come up with a genuine contemporary version of a Nash terrace.

webTitle: The Holy Grail is in Scotland (not for long)

fields.headline: The Holy Grail is in Scotland (not for long)
fields.standfirst: Parsifal Festival Theatre, Edinburgh I was looking at the ceiling... Linbury Studio, Royal Opera House, London WC2; touring Hear Now Royal Festival Hall, London SE1
fields.trailText: Parsifal |  I was looking at the ceiling and I saw the sky | Hear Now
fields.body:
Angy light shed on the inscrutable and primeval drama of Parsifal deserves our thanks and praise. However thoroughly one apprehends Wagner's over-arching preoccupation with sin, suffering and redemption, it can be difficult, moment by moment, to tell exactly what's going on. I confess to being struck down by total bafflement afresh each time, usually about halfway through the first act (and again at the same point in the third). That the binding force of the music makes its own compelling sense has too often been an excuse for muddy stagings. Not at Scottish Opera. Constrained by lack of money, inspired to offer clarity for an audience new to the work, its first Parsifal is little short of a miracle. Musical values are admirable, with a remarkable performance from Anne-Marie Owens as Kundry, good orchestral playing, a well-drilled if small chorus and strong soloists.

For a company under fire, financially and administratively, artistic standards are better than ever, erasing the memory of a few recent flops and provoking the troublesome observation that, in the arts, funding and success are not necessarily mutually dependent.

For once, the single vision of a director who is also the designer works triumphantly. The Romanian-born Silviu Purcarete uses simple ideas to powerful effect. The Grail and Christianity are played down. Sets consist of three movable flats and various curtain-like drapes. The strength is in the detail. Its directness often shocks. Parsifal's shooting of the swanl, which alerts us to his arrival, is announced by a spatter of blood dripping down from on high and staining a white cloth, followed by a dazzle of snowy feathers. Klingor's magic castle is a dressing room lit with mirror lights. When Kundry appears, transformed into a temptress, she upstages the fawning, sexless flower maidens in breathtaking style, gliding in 10 feet tall, swathed in yards of red velvet like a crimson sphere. The flower maidens disperse like a shoal of tiddlers in the wake of a tidal wave.

Richard Armstrong galvanises every musical force at his disposal, drawing a richer than usual gloss from strings and woodwind and exposing the compelling contours of the orchestral preludes. Matthew Best's Amfortas is pitiful and intelligent, David Pittman-Jennings a sleek Klingsor and Manfred Hemm a refreshingly young, unwoolly and lucid Gurnemanz. In the title role American John Murray struggled vocally with what may have been first-night nerves, but he acted with a touching mix of gormless innocence and growing self-awareness. This is too good to miss but with only two performances left in this frustratingly short run (in Glasgow on Wednesday and Saturday), most of us will have to.

If Glasgow cannot lure at such short notice, another essential production beckons. John Adams's I was looking at the ceiling and then I saw the sky, a short, punchy, tough and poetic theatre piece, is now on tour in an outstanding staging by Southwark Playhouse and the Modern Music Theatre Troupe. Adams names Leonard Bernstein and George Gershwin as his models. He shares their street-life subject matter with an affect ing tale (libretto by June Jordan) of seven young people in downtown LA whose lives are changed by an earthquake. Provocative issues of police brutality, birth control, gay politics and racism underpin three separate love stories. Adams's loud yet subtle and engaging score has a predominantly jazzy, non-operatic feel, excellently played by an ensemble of keyboard, guitars, clarinet, saxophone and percussion conducted by John Jansson. Two memorable chorus numbers and several soulful but trenchant ballads, sung by a superb cast from various musical theatre backgrounds, make this a work to hear again immediately. Catch it now (in Newcastle, Oxford, Basingstoke, Mansfield or Brighton).

Jazz, and the saxophone in particular, have sparked some of Mark-Anthony Turnage's best music. His 65-minute uncompromising elegy Blood on the Floor , taking its title from Francis Bacon, uses three jazz soloists and a large ensemble. Improvisation and fully scored music rub shoulders excitingly in a tight sequence of opposing yet empathetic styles. The work formed the focus of the CBSO's first Hear Now concert, billed as 'the culmination of the 10-year Towards the Millennium' and conducted by Simon Rattle. Despite the Rattle factor, and the success of Turnage's new opera The Silver Tassie , the Festival Hall was disappointingly empty.

London doesn't have much chance to hear the likes of guitarist John Scofield or drummer Peter Erskine, for whom, with saxophonist Martin Robertson, Turnage wrote this brazenly eclectic piece. Their virtuosity was matched by the CBSO's own players, who also gave the premiere of Magnus Lindberg's Gran Duo. In this gleaming 20-minute piece, for 13 wind and 11 brass instruments, the Finnish composer spun his textures and timbres with clean precision. The cycle of different harmonic and rhythmic moods flickers from skittering to sombre, airy to dense. He teases the instrumental lines apart then presses them back together as if opening and closing a beautifully agile squeeze-box. It is no sin for the listener, freed from an obligation to unearth hidden meaning, to relish Lindberg's power to charm. Sometimes the Grail can be pleasure, and redemption simple enjoyment.

fields.headline: Audiobook: On The Road
fields.standfirst: David Carradine gives Jack Kerouac's On The Road the perfect smoky, lazy delivery
fields.trailText:
On The Road
by Jack Kerouac
read by David Carradine
running time 2 hrs, 30mins
Penguin, £8.99
Buy it from BOL
fields.body:
On The Road
by Jack Kerouac
read by David Carradine
running time 2 hrs, 30mins
Penguin, £8.99
Buy it from BOL

It is 1947. Sal Paradise is drawing his GI pension and living a hand-to-mouth existence in New York, posing as a would-be author. His friend, Dean Moriarty, is a wayward spirit, a man who divides his time between his wife at home and his mistress in a hotel. But he is Sal's hero. Together, and sometimes alone, they travel the roads of America with no care for geography or the reader's sense of direction.

From New York to Denver to California, where "everyone looked like a broken-down movie extra", to Chicago "C Jam Blues played by sad-eyed negroes" and back to "the sad red earth" of Denver. They smoke "T" (marijuana), they have sex, they treat all women like whores: one is a "great man's woman", another lets Dean do what he wants with "a minimum of trouble". Women are like horses, with "beautiful flanks".

Written in 1957, this classic story can do no wrong. Kerouac created a dream and will remain a hero of American literature for having done so.

David Carradine has remained in my memory for his role in the TV series Kung Fu. It is off-putting to have this image in mind as he evokes the Beat Generation. His smoky, lazy American tongue sounds too big for his mouth. In the middle of the story he is so laid back he is almost asleep. As our heroes reach the hedonism of Mexico he can be heard licking his lips and swallowing as if salivating with excitement. And drawing to the end of their final journey to Mexico City he sounds weary, his voice dry and old. It must be all that pollution.

webTitle: Paperback of the week: The Whole Woman

fields.headline: Paperback of the week: The Whole Woman
fields.standfirst: In this 'sequel' to The Female Eunuch, Germaine Greer's opinions shimmer between madness and terrifing sense
fields.trailText:
The Whole Woman

by Germaine Greer
Anchor, £7.99, pp452
Buy it from BOL
fields.body:
The Whole Woman

by Germaine Greer
Anchor, £7.99, pp452
Buy it from BOL

In Germaine Greer's sequel to The Female Eunuch, she considers every class of woman and spares no man. She really does want to take on 'the whole woman' - I found I could only cope with the equivalent of a fingernail at a time.

Greer's opinions shimmer between madness and terrifying sense. She believes that women should be proud to own their bodies, but she does not seem to entertain the possibility that women might ever regard dressing up as a minor freedom.

She writes admirably - and movingly - about motherhood (as burden and joy). She suggests that mothers be paid by the state for their work (I wish I could see this as more than delectable pie in the sky).

She is dismissive about the tyranny of housework and stress of shopping. But her view of marriage is Strindbergian, with not a happy couple in sight. She is an emphatic pacifist and writes, in a most bellicose style, about peace. She notes that road rage is at its worst when young male drivers are "outdriven by a middle-aged woman in a more powerful car than their own".

Greer is driving that car and going through red lights with abandon. She is bitterly hostile towards transsexuals (her dislike is puzzling) and her views in favour of female circumcision - on the grounds of respecting the culture that condones it - are a disgrace.

Throughout, the reader is diverted by the well-chosen quotations in the text. Nina Simone moodily intervenes to wonder:"'Do you think that men are good for anything? It seems to me that men are ruining the world."

fields.headline: Classicwatch: The Necklace; The Pearls
fields.standfirst: Two short stories on the theme of precious stones by Guy de Maupassant and Isak Dinesen are beautifully presented introductions to great writers
fields.trailText: This beautifully presented little book, containing two contrasting stories by Guy de Maupassant and Isak Dinesen, forms part of Pushkin Press's new Jewel Quartet - four classic stories by European writers all turning on the theme of precious stones.
fields.body:
The Necklace; The Pearls
by Guy de Maupassant and Isak Dinesen
Pushkin Press, £5, pp60
Buy it from BOL

This beautifully presented little book, containing two contrasting stories by Guy de Maupassant and Isak Dinesen, forms part of Pushkin Press's new Jewel Quartet - four classic stories by European writers all turning on the theme of precious stones.

Both stories consider how a jewel may affect the course of a woman's life. 'The Necklace' is the story of a young woman, dissatisfied with her station, who borrows a diamond necklace from a wealthy friend to wear to a grand ball. The necklace is lost, and the lesson learnt by the young woman a cruel reminder of life's ironies.

Dinesen's 'The Pearls' is the tale of Jensine, a restless young heiress who inherits a string of pearls which becomes for her a symbol of endurance and continuity in the midst of her uncertainty and tempestuous feelings.

Both stories are carefully crafted and compassionate; along with the others in the series, they are an ideal introduction to two great writers.

fields.headline: Fast forward
fields.standfirst:
The loafer's guide to popular culture We consume it, so you don't have to.
This week: Tyler Brûlé
fields.trailText: What's that? An ironic, 70s-retro dessert? Get with it. The bearer of this unlikely name is the dishy, dapper French-Canadian founder of publishing phenomenon wallpaper*, the stylish interiors/travel magazine. Brûlé launched it from his living room four years ago, and it now sells 120,000 copies monthly worldwide. Time Inc bought it for £1 million and Brûlé now edits it from a penthouse office in Time's building overlooking the Thames. Style boffins will tell you its success is down to its rediscovery of highly polished 60s and 70s modernist interiors - think white shagpile and teak-veneer coffee tables.
fields.body:
What's that? An ironic, 70s-retro dessert? Get with it. The bearer of this unlikely name is the dishy, dapper French-Canadian founder of publishing phenomenon wallpaper*, the stylish interiors/travel magazine. Brûlé launched it from his living room four years ago, and it now sells 120,000 copies monthly worldwide. Time Inc bought it for £1 million and Brûlé now edits it from a penthouse office in Time's building overlooking the Thames. Style boffins will tell you its success is down to its rediscovery of highly polished 60s and 70s modernist interiors - think white shagpile and teak-veneer coffee tables.

Marvellously frivolous. And? And Brûlé is about to launch his next venture - currently named Project Tart. The idea is that it will do for sports what wallpaper* has done for interiors.

But is it likely that Tart will become a serious player? No sweat: Tart will be dedicated to 'rich sports', such as skiing. Readers will have '10 days and want to know which is the most fantastic resort. Tart will be as relevant in the south Pacific as the south of France.' Brûlé cites wallpaper* as the 'first truly international publication', with identical copies selling in 43 countries. He is against local editions, believing they often have lower-quality journalism.

'Developing countries' unsophisticated? How un-PC. No, just a perfectionist. He's a well-travelled sophisticate. Moving to Britain aged 20, he got a job on the BBC's Reportage, and then became a frontline reporter. In Kabul, he received three bullet wounds, which turned out to be a blessing. While recovering, he conceived of the idea for wallpaper* with the backing of his then boyfriend, shoe designer Patrick Cox.

How jolly enterprising! Yes, he is. Tart aside, he's busy putting wallpaper* online and he's just signed a deal with Puma for custom-made wallpaper* sneakers. The smart money is on Brûlé scoring again.

fields.headline: Raised highbrows
fields.standfirst: If you are perplexed by the question 'What is culture'? and flummoxed by the notion of 'dumbing down', varying degrees of help are at hand in Terry Eagleton's The Idea of Culture, John Seabrook's Nobrow and Ivo Mosley's Dumbing Down
fields.trailText: If you are perplexed by the question 'What is culture'? and flummoxed by the notion of 'dumbing down', help is at hand
fields.body:
The Idea of Culture
by Terry Eagleton
Blackwell, £12.99, pp156
Buy it from BOL

Nobrow
by John Seabrook
Methuen, £9.99, pp221

Dumbing Down: Culture, Politics and the Mass Media
ed Ivo Mosley
Imprint Academic, £12.95, pp324

On the vexed culture question - the subject that links the books under review - Anne Fadiman, author of Ex-Libris, one of the most delightful and most neglected books published last year, tells the following story. Writing in the American Scholar, Fadiman recalls the illuminating case of Vice-Admiral James Stockdale, Ross Perot's 1992 running mate, whose favourite book is the Enchiridion of Epictetus, a first-century Greek Stoic philosopher.

According to Fadiman, Stockdale first read the Enchiridion at the age of 38 when the US navy sent him to Stanford to study international relations. In the course of his studies, he discovered that whenever Frederick the Great went on his campaigns he took with him a copy of Enchiridion for relaxation. Stockdale, apparently, decided to emulate the great Prussian general.

When, in 1966, Stockdale's plane was disabled by flak over North Vietnam, he baled out with a copy of Enchiridion in his back pocket. As he floated down towards certain captivity, Fadiman reports that Stockdale said to himself: "I am leaving the world of technology and entering the world of Epictetus."

This is as stark an example of what Matthew Arnold called "the powerful and beautiful application of ideas to life" as one could hope to find in a day's flying. Never mind. The Stoic teaching of Enchiridion enabled Stockdale to survive repeated torture and to emerge from his ordeal with his sense of himself more or less intact. As Fadiman herself wryly puts it: "I can think of worse ways to use literature."

The role of literature, its place in our lives and the proper response, if any, to its lessons is one that troubles many of us in this business. It certainly exercises the authors of all these books. Each comes up with his own kind of answer. Terry Eagleton's essay, The Idea of Culture , is, as one might expect, both the most elegant, the most comprehensive and the most demanding. From the outset, he identifies 'culture' as "one of the two or three most complex words in the English language".

After a dazzling examination of the etymological and epistemological roots of 'culture', he advances to his central "contention". This is that "we are trapped at the moment between disablingly wide and discomfortingly rigid notions of culture". On the one hand, there is the word's "anthropological" deployment to encompass "everything from hairstyles and drinking habits to how to address your husband's second cousin". On the other, there's its "aesthetic" usage as "perfection, sweetness and light, the best that has been thought and said".

Neither of these, as Eagleton wittily demonstrates, will do. He is, famously, a Marxist critic and much of his purpose in this self-styled 'manifesto' is to revisit the work of that hero of the cultural Left, Raymond Williams, and especially those books that inspired a generation of students - Culture and Society, Keywords and The Long Revolution. At its best, this volume is as inspiring, incisive and enthralling as I remember Williams to have been. In a better and a more enlightened world, a copy of The Idea of Culture would be sent to every arts student in Britain.

So much for appearances. If there is a hidden agenda to Eagleton's essay - and I think there is - it is to upstage a book he does not cite, and to challenge an Oxford colleague he does not name. The book is The Intellectuals and the Masses, the colleague is Professor John Carey. In 1992, Carey set the literary world alight with his eloquent and persuasive analysis of the literary intelligentsia's disdain for the emerging mass culture of late-Victorian England.

Part of his book's appeal, at a time when the appropriate response to popular culture was exercising the critics and the commentariat alike, was that it provided a trenchant narrative of the state literary culture was in, a ready and authoritative explanation for the dichotomy between high and low - between, as it were, Milton and Madonna, Flaubert and Friends, Spinoza and the Spice Girls.

Implicitly, Eagleton is appalled at Carey's assault on the demigods of modernism - Joyce, Woolf, Lawrence et al - but his mind is too subtle and too feline to say so. Instead, he proposes a model of 'culture' with a capital 'C' that might not stand up to North Vietnamese water torture, but which has the virtue of transcending the banal stupidities of the usual debate about 'dumbing down'.

This is not to say that The Idea of Culture is a dry or difficult read. Far from it. Eagleton's pages crackle with aphorism and aperçus , viz: "For every waft of Parisian perfume in Tokyo, one can find a young Nazi thug or a middle-aged communitarian philosopher."

Having explored the idea of "culture in crisis", Eagleton moves to the issue which will, I suspect, most interest Observer readers, the question of "culture wars". Once again, Eagleton is concerned to explain that, from his perspective, this is "not just a tussle between Stendhal and Seinfeld, or between those churls on the English department corridor who study line-endings in Milton and the bright young things who write books on masturbation. It is," he goes on, "part of the shape of the world politics of the new millennium." Thus, to Eagleton, "The culture wars which matter concern such questions as ethnic cleansing, not the relative merits of Racine and soap operas."

All of which suggests that Vice-Admiral Stockdale might have gleaned rather more comfort from Eagleton's brief, brilliant and passionate essay than he could ever have deduced from John Seabrook's Nobrow, a prolix and puzzling volume maddeningly subtitled 'The Culture of Marketing and the Marketing of Culture'.

Much is explained by the author's painful experiences in the world of New York's magazine jungle, notably at the New Yorker. Once again, the part I imagine that Observer readers will most enjoy is the part that describes the heaven-and-hell experience of working for Tina Brown. But here and there, amid the tortuous flux of Seabrook's youthful reminiscences, occasional sentences fight their way to the surface, alluding to issues that Eagleton himself would not disdain. "By the 1990s," Seabrook writes, "the notion that high culture constituted some sort of superior reality, and that the people who made it were superior beings, was pretty much in the toilet. The old meaning of the word culture - something orthodox, dominant and singular - had yielded to the more anthropological Levi-Straussian sense of culture: the characteristic practices of any group."

If Seabrook, who has coined the term 'nobrow' to cope with his numerous and unresolved worries about the high- and low-brow question in its crudest form, about dumbing down and braining up, is going to get any help in the matter, he would be advised to steer well clear of Dumbing Down, a ragbag of essays on "culture, politics and the mass media".

This oddly published volume declares, riskily, on its first page that: "Never in human history has so much cleverness been used to such stupid ends." Not content with this opening salvo, Ivo Mosley announces that what he calls 'dumbocracy' is little more than "the rule of cleverness without wisdom".

The editor has certainly rounded up a quite impressive list of clever contributors, from Philip Rieff and Nicholas Mosley to Michael Oakeshott and Michael Polanyi. There is, sadly, no disguising the fact that, as contributors to a vital contemporary debate, the latter share one distinct disqualification - they are both dead.

Vice-Admiral Stockdale, however, is very much alive and still, one hopes, digesting the lessons of Stoicism. Epictetus, it turns out, has apt things to say to those who fear for our culture in the age of the Internet and the video-link: "Work, therefore, to be able to say to every harsh appearance, 'You are but an appearance, and not absolutely the thing you appear to be.'"

fields.headline: Cornish encounters
fields.standfirst:
Part five of a photographic series capturing the Britain of today. This week, we visit Cornwall

View the photographs at www.gb2k.com.
fields.trailText: Part five of a photographic series capturing the Britain of today. This week, we visit Cornwal
fields.body:
'If I were to say to you "Millennium Dome", you would probably move on to the next reader's suggestion with a long sigh,' wrote Louise Grant from Padstow. But the dome she had in mind was not Greenwich's great white elephant, but the rather different Eden Project in Cornwall. Louise's idea for Derek Hudson's series of portraits of turn-of-the-century Britain immediately caught our photographer's imagination and before you could say 'three-hour queue for the Body Zone', Derek was on his way to St Austell.

While we've all been entertained by the real-life soap opera that is the Millennium Dome project, some 300 people have been hard at work in a disused clay pit in Cornwall. The 14-hectare site, which had been dug for clay for over a century, is - thanks to £37.15 million from the Millennium Commission - soon to be a 'global garden'. The 60-metre-deep central crater will form a natural amphitheatre the size of 30 football pitches, and by this time next year it will be home to thousands of plants. Three of the world's climate zones - Humid Tropics, Warm Temperate and Temperate (which, if you're wondering, is what we have here) - are also going to be created in the dome-like 'biomes'.

And it'll all last a lot longer than 1999's solar eclipse.

Email suggestions to derek@gb2k.com, or write to Derek Hudson c/o Life Magazine, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER

webTitle: The long and short of it

fields.headline: The long and short of it
fields.standfirst: If our attention spans are becomingly increasingly gnat-like, why are films, CDs and books all getting longer? Stuart Husband drags it out
fields.trailText: If our attention spans are becomingly increasingly gnat-like, why are films, CDs and books all getting longer? Stuart Husband drags it out
fields.body:
There's a button-badge currently doing the rounds in the States that reads: 'I survived The Green Mile.' This doesn't refer to a miraculous liberation from the eponymous route between a death cell and an execution chamber but, rather, to something really worth bragging about; the ability to sit through the three-hours-plus of Tom Hanks-starring, Oscar-nominated corn that's currently clogging up the multiplexes. Moviegoers' posterior muscles and bladder retention will be further tested with the imminent release of fellow nominee Magnolia, a 188-minute epic on the lives of Los Angelenos that's like Short Cuts in everything but the fact that nothing about it is short.

Of course, Oscar-friendliness has always increased in direct proportion to extent; just ask James Cameron (Titanic, 194 minutes), Kevin Costner (Dances With Wolves, 185 minutes), or Steven Spielberg (Schindler's List, 185 minutes). What's remarkable this year is the sheer volume of films busting the two-and-a-quarter-hour mark, including The Insider, Topsy-Turvy and The Talented Mr Ripley. As far as Hollywood is concerned, brevity is, well, 195 minutes ago's thing. Long gives you gravitas. Long gives you cred. Long, to paraphrase Michael Douglas in Wall Street (a mere 125 minutes), is good. As writer Larry Gelbart said: 'I haven't seen The Green Mile yet, so don't give away the middle.'

What's even more remarkable is that this trend is occurring at a time when our attention spans have, allegedly, reached parity with those of gnats; books like James Gleick's Faster blame the dizzying fragmentation of our psyches on the blizzards of images and information pumped out by cable TV, the internet and video games. Corresponding blizzards of statistics are wielded in support of this theory: the average man changes TV channels with the remote control every 19 minutes; a typical camera shot lasted 35-50 seconds in the 50s, whereas it had shrunk to five seconds in the 90s; web design companies say that child-targeted websites are obliged to post as many windows and links as possible, because their audience's boredom thresholds are so low; record numbers of children are being diagnosed with attention-deficit disorder (ADD), and Ritalin, the pill that treats this malady, is flying off the shelves faster than Viagra; the average MTV viewer absorbs around 750 images an hour.

While there are numerous counter-arguments to the above - ADD's considerable genetic component means it could be as much about nature as nurture, while MTV's 750 images are basically the same three or four, endlessly recycled - the simple truth is that we are now faced with a greater density of information and more demands on our attention than ever before, and in response to this multiplicity, numerous chill-out rooms have sprung up in which solace can be sought in the interminable and unvarying. Art galleries, as well as cinemas, are discovering that virtue and duration go hand in hand. Three recent Turner prize-winners, Gillian Wearing, Steve McQueen and Douglas Gordon, won respectively for 60 Minutes Silence, in which a group of policemen posed perfectly still, group-photo style, for an hour; Prey, a film in which a balloon very gradually filled with air and gently lifted a tape recorder into the air; and 24-Hour Psycho, in which Gordon slowed down Hitchcock's film to a frame a second (a large crowd reclined on beanbags for a day-and-night session when the work was shown at the Hayward Gallery). The grand-daddy of nothing-happening-incessantly video art was, of course, Andy Warhol; crazed casualties still stalk Manhattan, buttonholing passers-by with tales of how they endured the likes of Chelsea Girls (drag queens and shrill women shriek at each other, 195 minutes), and Empire (a view of the Empire State Building, um, that's about it, eight hours).

A trawl round any bookshop proves that verbosity is also on the increase. Weighty doorstop volumes lovingly detailing the minutiae of the preceding century are still clogging up aisles; no biography worth its salt clocks in at under 500 pages; the more cuboid a thriller's shape, the higher its place on the bestseller lists; and two recent novelistic hits, David Foster Wallace's Infinite Jest and Neal Stephenson's Cryptonomicon, tipped the scales at a Hugo-esque 1,200 and 900 pages, respectively. CDs have also given musicians a licence to lengthen; an old LP (which, lest we forget, quaintly stood for 'long player'), petered out after 40 minutes, whereas fans now feel short-changed if the muse has failed to descend long enough to provide twice that much material (what this usually means, in practice, is the listener being treated to the ineffectual noodlings and doodlings that would once have been relegated to bootlegs and obscure b-sides; The Artist is surely the biggest offender in this department). Fiona Apple's new CD bears a title worthy of The New Protractedness; it runs to 90 words.

The arts' willingness to embrace lengthiness is finding an echo in wider society. Politicians are rushing to deny 'soundbite culture' (and employing their choicest soundbites to do so). Recently, US Vice President Al Gore suggested that old-style, exhaustive, real-time debates replace 30-second ads; perhaps he should look across the Florida Straits to Cuba, where Fidel Castro has always gone in for live seven-hour on-camera speeches - with no bathroom breaks - like boundlessness never went out of fashion. Meanwhile, the ultimate in long - the perpetual TV docu-soap, as envisaged by The Truman Show - is already here in the form of live webcams, though the jerky time-lapse quality of their pictures leaves them resembling doped-out versions of those Eadweard Muybridge anatomy studies.

The average lifespan at the beginning of the 20th century was 47 years; it's now 76, and scientists say that, with ongoing health improvements, it could reach 150 by the end of this century. That's an awful lot of real time - approximately 3,066,000 sittings of The Green Mile - to fill. Long may not just be good - it may be essential. Forget Ritalin - anyone currently working on a pill for Attention Surplus Anxiety can expect to clean up.
