fields.headline: Savaged messiah
fields.standfirst: A new book has reignited one of the fiercest artistic debates of the twentieth century - was Dmitri Shostakovich a Soviet stooge or a passionate critic of communism?
fields.trailText: A new book has reignited one of the fiercest artistic debates of the twentieth century - was Dmitri Shostakovich a Soviet stooge or a passionate critic of communism?
fields.body:
Dmitri Shostakovich, the greatest composer of the twentieth century, was a football fanatic. He was, said Maxim Gorky, 'a rabid fan. He comported himself like a little boy, leapt up, screamed and gesticulated' at matches. Shostakovich supported Leningrad Zenith; he would cut short his composing retreats in some rural idyll and return to the city for home games.

He exchanged detailed analyses of these matches with friends and kept notebooks of scores and championship league tables, arranged in pyramids. He wanted to come to London to see the 1966 World Cup but was thwarted in his plans. He did, however, make sure to go to Disneyland when in Los Angeles - he loved rollercoaster rides.

These vernacular delicacies emerge in a new book about a passionate, tortured man who wrote music about the kernel of what it means to be a human in a violent political society. But in the case of Shostakovich, any biographical fact, however absurd it may seem, is a statement of sorts, since its publication becomes part of the most unforgiving war in the world of music, or probably any of the arts, for that matter - the so-called 'Shostakovich controversy'. Such is the hurricane into which Laurel Fay's Shostakovich: a Life now steps.

Fay is quickly finding that it is impossible to write about him without fanning the flames of controversy. No composer's work, not even Wagner's, has been subject to such acrimony. The debate centres on Shostakovich's jagged relationship with the Soviet authorities and with communism, its party and its tyrant, Stalin.

At crucial times in his life, Shostakovich was denounced and persecuted, but he also made sure to survive, dedicating much of his work to the cause of the revolution and tardily joining the Communist Party in 1960, having resisted for decades.

The claim of the Soviets, their post-Soviet Russian successors and many in the West is that Shostakovich was a believer in the revolution and in the final hour, loyal to the USSR. Not quite that his work is literally party music, but that he could not and did not want to break with the faith or leave the country in the way that Prokofiev, Solzhenitsyn and others did.

Against this is pitched a passionate counter-argument by leading musicologists and some of Russia's most illustrious dissidents - that Shostakovich was himself a bitter and brave dissident against communism, whose entire oeuvre was a vast, inner rebellion. One of the principals in the 'dissident' camp, Ian MacDonald, writes: 'The persistent misinterpretation of Shostakovich's music is arguably the most grotesque cultural scandal of our time.'

The 'Shostakovich controversy' exploded shortly after the composer's death in 1975, at which time the USSR still claimed his creative soul and ideo- logical loyalty, for all the friction between Shostakovich and the authorities during his life. But in 1979, a memoir called Testimony appeared, purporting to have been narrated by the dying Shostakovich to an acquaintance, Solomon Volkov.

Here, the composer lambasts communism and the totalitarian, anti-Semitic state in which 'a man has no significance'. Whether Testimony was genuine or not, no one could have predicted how vituperative the ensuing debate would be.

The doomed Soviet authorities, their post-Soviet successors and the composer's family launched a counter-offensive (although Shostakovich's defector son, Maxim, was equivocal). Laurel Fay, joined with Russian scholar Serge Karlinsky to do some detective work, and found Testimony to be, for the most part, spurious and full of plagiarisms. MacDonald then set out to decipher Shostakovich's entire oeuvre , finding it to constitute a coherent and passionate cry of dissent against communism, in musical code.

The musicologist Christopher Norris retorted with a conference on 'Shostakovich: the Man and His Music', stating that Volkov had written 'a thoroughly mischievous ideological primer'. The debate was joined by distinguished exiled musicians, Vladimir Ashkenazy and Mstislav Rostropovich, whose lives had been defined by their leaving Russia while Shostakovich had stayed on.

Fra from stilling the debate, the collapse of the USSR brought about only a temporary lull. Two years ago came a rabid defence of Volkov in Dmitry Feofanev's Shostakovich Reconsidered, which savaged the claims made in Moscow, and in Fay's research. At a conference in New York shortly after publication, Volkov appeared to deliver what he called his 'first and last' defence of the veracity of his memoir.

Meanwhile, the war has been waged on the Net. MacDonald has his own, intelligent website, arguing with ever-greater passion for his theory of Shostakovich's great coded weave. He and his supporters accuse Norris of 'Stalinism' for defending the composer's apparent loyalty to Marxism.

Norris has, in turn, mocked MacDonald and 'Western liberals' for thinking themselves 'too shrewd' for the Russian version. 'Redrick' is another Internet regular taking the Russian line and assailing the dissidents as inhabiting 'cultish Internet backwaters where neither evidence or logic carry much weight'. Each side accuses the other of 'fraud', 'deceit' and 'revisionism'.

Amidst the acrimony Fay continues to takes the Staten Island ferry to work at the music publisher G. Shirmer's on Park Avenue.

'This isn't the book I wanted to write,' she confesses; that was intended to be about Shostakovich's music. But then she was admitted, after some years of studying music in Leningrad, into 'a library-like room, and there was his life; it was quite a moment' - the moment at which Fay became the first Western writer ever to gain access to the Shostakovich archive.

The result is a deliberately dry book which will infuriate many, if only because of its refusal to discuss either the music or the controversy. Rather, it tries to cut a neutral, biographical, factual furrow through both. It is what Fay calls 'a platform, a factual record upon which other work can build'. It is both minimalist and crammed with detail, devoid of interpretation and built upon what Shostakovich himself can be proven to have said and done, rather than 'all those people who speak for Shostakovich'. Fay constructs a life story which, she says, accounts for the fact that 'people change with time and age. And that Shostakovich was damaged psychologically by what happened to him'.

She follows the life charted by a passionate, tormented, often isolated man in a society where synergy between art and politics was unavoidable. But such is the intensity of the debate that by avoiding it, Fay is seen by the 'dissident' camp as endorsing the Soviet view (which she does not) simply by recording Shostakovich's own public endorsements of communism (as well as his digressions and hostility) without comment, rather than presuming them to be ironic. The negative reviews have begun - cold criticism in the New York Times, a savaging in the Washington Post - and will certainly continue.

'They're already calling me a Soviet stooge,' she sighs. In Britain, Norman Lebrecht has called Fay a 'revisionist' and compares what he calls her account of Shostakovich 'coming to terms with communism' with David Irving's alleged denial of the Holocaust.

Shostakovich had been famously rebuked and shamed during the Stalinist purges of 1936. He was assailed by Pravda for composing 'muddle instead of music'. And yet while Prokofiev fled the tyranny, Shostakovich found a way to live and survive under it.

War against Hitler created a complex set of circumstances which legitimised Stalin's rule. Shostakovich's dedication of his Seventh Symphony, Leningrad, to 'our struggle against fascism' is wholehearted. And yet, with the war over, Shostakovich crossed the party again, to be denounced by Stalin's dreaded commissar Andrey Zhdanov for 'formalism' and compromise with decadent Western modernism.

Shostakovich seems to have greeted Stalin's death with relief, but then wrote his Twelfth Symphony of 1961 as a eulogy to the 1917 Revolution, its final movement entitled 'The Dawn of Humanity'. The following year, however he delivered his most overt rebellion - the epic Thirteenth Symphony, Babi Yar , a setting of Yevgeny Yevtushenko's poem about the Nazi massacre of Jews that was only a thinly veiled and bitter, enraged indictment of the crime and shame of Soviet anti-Semitism.

What was Shostakovich doing? Fay remembers from her time living in Leningrad the way in which 'people are forced to live on so many different levels'. Shostakovich, she says, 'lived his life very publicly', and was, therefore, constrained to exist on different and often contradictory planes. 'It is not as though things just happened to him - he made choices, and I am inter ested in those choices.' Shostakovich's conductor friend Kyril Kondrashin called him 'the moral conscience of music in Russia'. Maxim, the composer's son, said: 'My father was a patriot for his people, which is not the same as being a party apparatchik.' For a younger generation of artists such as Rostropovich and Ashkenazy, loyalty to Russia entailed heroic dissent against communism and defection.

But clearly not for the older Shostakovich, who had lived through the revolution, witnessed the Lenin years and seems to have felt at least some reluctant connection between a love of nation and this antithetic but Janus-like cohabitation with those who terrorised it. 'The demons Shostakovich wrestled with were his own,' writes Fay. 'He crossed his own line in the sand. He was neither the first nor the last to realise, too late, that the path of accommodation of the Soviet system was one of no return.'

fields.headline: Paperbacks, 12 March
fields.standfirst: A delightful short-story collection in Hafid Bouazza's Abdullah's Feet, plus Prozac Highway by Persimmon Blackbridge, Antonia White: A Life by Jane Dunn, The Photographer's Wife by Robert Solé and Pushkin's Button by Serena Vitale
fields.trailText: A delightful short-story collection in Hafid Bouazza's Abdullah's Feet, plus Prozac Highway by Persimmon Blackbridge, Antonia White: A Life by Jane Dunn, The Photographer's Wife by Robert Solé and Pushkin's Button by Serena Vitale
fields.body:
Abdullah's Feet
by Hafid Bouazza
Review, £7.99, pp123
Buy it from BOL

This slim collection of interconnected stories, intricately wrought, suffused with bawdy humour, is a delight. Spiced with sexual and scatological incident, informed by Bouazza's irreverent imagination, these tales set in a generic Moroccan village - a "wonderland" of djinns, debauchery and Arcadian landscapes - touch on the surreal and satiric.

Here, before the eyes of a fanciful young boy, are buxom females with posteriors welcoming as"'ostrich-down cushions for the spasmodic euphoria of manly release"; lascivious boys sharing intimacies with goats; lusty women satisfying their passions with aubergines and cucumbers. Amid these caricatures, the feet of Abdullah (freshly severed, yet still animated) guide the reader from one highly entertaining scenario to another.

Prozac Highway
by Persimmon Blackbridge
Marion Boyars, £8.99, pp268
Buy it from BOL

Jam - gay, middle-aged, with "nothing on my résumé but 'housework' and 'lesbian sex art'" - is depressed. Unable to function in the "meat world", she roams the virtual universe of the internet conversing, courtesy of the inexpressive typeface of e-mail, with faceless strangers at the 'ThisIsCrazy' website on, among other things, the benefits of Prozac.

Reality intrudes minimally: Jam leaves her squalid basement to clean the houses of other people, consumes canned gourmet chilli, cuts herself with a razor. A 'virtual' affair affords all too brief relief from her misery. "How do you write about the erotic bonding possibilities of unpleasant psych-drug experiences?" Jam asks at one point. With cynical wit, sexually explicit imagery and a pinch of pessimism, it would seem, from Blackbridge's downbeat novel.

Antonia White: A Life
by Jane Dunn
Virago, £9.99, pp484
Buy it from BOL

White, best known perhaps for Frost in May, a barely fictionalised account of her convent school experiences, is a good subject for dramatic biography: insanity, family feuds, sexual repression and Catholic guilt all jostle for position. Central to her troubled life was the dilemma "between being both an artist and a woman - the one intrinsically untamed and the other domesticated, defused, made safe".

Committed to Bedlam in her early 20s, plagued by writer's block, demonised by some for the neglect of her daughters, White penned several critically successful works, left more than one million words in diary form and spent her life fighting the demon of depression. Dunn's eloquent prose, eye for humorous anecdote and sympathy make this an excellent biography.

The Photographer's Wife
by Robert Solé
Harvill, £6.99, pp312
Buy it from BOL

Modern, defiant Dora Touta will not be checked in her photographic aspirations by the social mores of nineteenth-century Egypt, a country in social and political ferment. Gradually usurping her husband Milo as head of the Touta studio, Dora favours realism over the posed, retouched portraits characteristic of the age. Milo, no longer the waggish bohemian of his youth, resents being defined as Dora's husband and enjoys an affair with a mutual friend. by Serena Vitale
Fourth Estate, £6.99, pp398
Buy it from BOL

In 1837, Pushkin died following an illegal duel with Baron George D'Anthés, a French cavalry officer and "amiable ladies' man". Anonymous letters had been circulated in St Petersburg prior to the event labelling Pushkin a cuckold as a result of his wife's alleged affair with D'Anthés, Pushkin's brother-in-law. Such is the context for Vitale's literary investigation, which is thorough, but also speculative and fanciful.

Though rich with detail - diary entries, letters, newspaper articles, literary criticism - this book lacks a coherent and persuasive argument. Instead, the tiniest detail is impregnated with great significance (Pushkin's missing button, for example). Overall, however, this piece of detective work is spirited and captivating, due to the reputation of its subject and Vitale's obvious enthusiasm.

Spiced with sexual and scatological incident, informed by Bouazza's irreverent imagination, these tales set in a generic Moroccan village - a "wonderland" of djinns, debauchery and Arcadian landscapes - touch on the surreal and satiric. Here, before the eyes of a fanciful young boy, are buxom females with posteriors welcoming as"'ostrich-down cushions for the spasmodic euphoria of manly release"; lascivious boys sharing intimacies with goats; lusty women satisfying their passions with aubergines and cucumbers. Amid these caricatures, the feet of Abdullah (freshly severed, yet still animated) guide the reader from one highly entertaining scenario to another. Unable to function in the "meat world", she roams the virtual universe of the internet conversing, courtesy of the inexpressive typeface of e-mail, with faceless strangers at the 'ThisIsCrazy' website on, among other things, the benefits of Prozac. Reality intrudes minimally: Jam leaves her squalid basement to clean the houses of other people, consumes canned gourmet chilli, cuts herself with a razor. fields.headline: Living with Parkinson's
fields.standfirst: The debilitating effects of Parkinson's disease are upsetting and disturbing for both patient and carer alike. Making substantial life changes and sticking to a careful diet, however, can help you manage the illness
fields.trailText: The debilitating effects of Parkinson's disease are upsetting and disturbing for both patient and carer alike. Making substantial life changes and sticking to a careful diet, however, can help you manage the illness
fields.body:
Sadly, Parkinson's disease has been at the forefront of my mind twice in the past few months: Michael J Fox recently announced that he is giving up work to devote more time to fighting the disease and, closer to home, the sister of a treasured friend has just discovered that it is responsible for her muscle weakness and tremor.

Parkinson's affects approximately one per cent of people over the age of 50 and can also hit people in their twenties and thirties. We still don't know what exactly causes this disease, but it's a chronic, progressive disorder of the nervous system, resulting from the degeneration of certain brain cells. These brain cells produce a substance called dopamine, which is a neurotransmitter; in other words it helps the nerves communicate messages to one another. Without dopamine the nervous system falters.

Parkinson's commonly starts with a tremor in one arm that occurs when the arm is at rest. As the disease progresses, movements gradually become more rigid, walking and balancing become difficult, the face can become frozen (speech and swallowing can become problematical), and there is progressive difficulty in performing simple tasks we take for granted, such as dressing ourselves - which can become impossible. The time that elapses between the first symptoms (typically a tremor or weakness) and when the more debilitating scenarios kick in varies greatly, but the degenerative path this disease follows means that Parkinson's affects not only the individual but also everyone around them - as time goes by, the sufferer frequently has to rely heavily on others for help. In Britain, there are only about two people with Parkinson's under each GP; many practitioners don't know the best ways of dealing with the disease, so it's essential to find a neurologist who has an interest in it.

No one can deny that Parkinson's disease is a distressing condition, but since the discovery of drugs such as Levodopa, the prognosis has changed dramatically. Levodopa restores the deficiency of dopamine within the brain by providing the brain with the amino acid L-Dopa (L dihydroxy-phenylalanine) from which the dopamine is derived. Levodopa remains the 'gold standard' of Parkinson's therapy as it's the most potent anti-Parkinson's drug available (although a few people fail to respond to this therapy). Long-term use of Levodopa often leads to complications later in this disease, most importantly dyskinesia, (uncontrolled movements) and in the short term, side effects such as depression and extreme tiredness (which usually occur when you first start taking the drug), both of which can make this medication route far from ideal. Thus many specialists now like to consider the use of other drugs, and the trend in treatment is toward combination therapy - the substitution or addition of other drugs at different times in the disease's progression. Some specialists may also consider surgery - either the removal or electronic stimulation of certain cells in the brain which control tremor and balance, or more recently and controversially, scientists are looking at the implantation of (pig) foetal tissue to restore the brain's ability to produce dopamine. Currently, surgery remains a less common option - for the majority of people, drugs provide the core of their conventional therapy.

But it's not just the drugs that need attention, food has a major role to play; it not only helps the body remain as fit and healthy as possible, which is vital in this degenerative disease, but more specifically what we eat has a relationship with L-Dopa. Before exploring this specific drug-food relationship, there are a couple of other wider issues. First, the importance of having a well-balanced, antioxidant-rich diet (fruits, vegetables, etc), since there is some evidence to suggest that free radical damage can be involved in the progression of Parkinson's - and boosting antioxidants counteracts this damage. Your diet also needs to include plenty of calcium and vitamin D-rich foods (dairy products, oily fish, etc) to ensure the bones remain as sturdy as possible. You may become unbalanced and/or weak, as the disease progresses - if you fall over, brittle bones are more likely to fracture. If you suspect that your intake of calcium and vitamin D is low, discuss taking supplements with your specialist. Constipation can also be a significant problem, not only because it causes discomfort, but because it interferes with the absorption of Levodopa - so try to keep your intake of fibre (wholegrain breads, pulses, cereals, fruits and vegetables, etc) and water high.

The major food issue to address, however, is what to eat when you're taking Levodopa. This drug is taken orally and is absorbed most effectively through the upper part of the small intestine, the part encountered by food as it leaves the stomach. It's best taken on an empty stomach, as there are nutritional factors which in some people can interfere with the metabolism and ultimately the efficacy of the drug. In some individuals, certain amino acids (molecules within protein) interfere with the metabolism of L-Dopa; if these protein-sensitive people eat protein foods and take the drug at the same time, L-Dopa will not be able to work efficiently in the body.

You might think that the simplest thing to do would be to cut out protein, but this would lead to other malnutrition problems. Protein is essential in maintaining a healthy muscle system and is also needed to keep the immune system feisty. In fact, all you need to do is separate concentrated sources of protein from the drug doses, so that your body can glean the protein and respond well to the treatment. Your specialist will be able to advise you as to the time you should leave between taking your medication and eating protein-rich foods (meat, poultry, fish and eggs - the slower absorption of protein from pulses such as dried beans, peas and lentils makes them less of a problem). However, leaving an hour before you eat seems to be commonly advised. I cannot give an exact time, because everyone's metabolism is different.

Other foods such as cereal-based carbohydrates (pasta, rice, bread, potatoes, etc) and dairy products also contain protein, but in a less concentrated form, so these, and of course vegetables and fruits, will not interfere with the actions of the drug. So if you take Levodopa and want something to eat before your curfew time, these are the foods to choose. Base breakfast and lunch on carbohydrates (porridge, honey on toast with banana, cereals, etc, for breakfast; risotto, pasta or a simple non-protein sandwich - jam or peanut butter etc, for lunch) and save the protein (roast chicken, fish casseroles, meat, eggs, etc) until the evening meal, eating it an hour after you have taken your last dose of medication. It's important to stick to this sort of structure, in meal quantity, quality and timing - if you vary things too much, the action of the drugs may be compromised.

As the disease progresses, a vicious circle can develop: the disease can weaken and depress you, and it can be so physically difficult to prepare and eat meals that the desire to eat can disappear. Lack of nutrients leads to more depression, chronic fatigue, weight loss and reduced physical strength, all of which compound the problems of dealing with Parkinson's. The best way to tackle these problems is to eat small meals often. Simple meals such as egg on toast or a rich soup are generally better managed than a whole roast lunch. Fruit fools, egg custard, soufflés and omelettes slip down easily, if swallowing is difficult. Keep ahead of the game, by having simple-to-prepare foods such as cheese, sliced meats, individual portions of home-made soups and vegetable flans in stock. Having cake tins stocked with nutritious bakes such as fruity maltloaf, flapjacks or biscuits can help you satisfy hungry moments and keep on top of the disease.

You can contact the Parkinson's Society on 020 7931 8080; or call the national freephone helpline on 0808 800 0303

fields.headline: You and whose army?
fields.standfirst: The 1998 uprising of the KLA surprised almost everyone - not least the people in it. But how did the West fail to see what would happen next? Tim Judah's War and Revenge and Virtual War: Kosovo and Beyond by Michael Ignatieff ask some difficult questions
fields.trailText: The 1998 uprising of the KLA surprised almost everyone - not least the people in it. But how did the West fail to see what would happen next?
fields.body:
Kosovo: War and Revenge
by Tim Judah
Yale University Press, £25/£12.95; pp288

Virtual War: Kosovo and Beyond
by Michael Ignatieff
Chatto & Windus, £12.99, pp249

Buy it from BOL

A year on, it is curious how the revision of history over the war in Kosovo is already in full flood, driven largely by journalists and commentators who managed to avoid covering the build-up to Nato's first ever conflict. Wilfully ignoring the causes of the war, and the international community's part in those causes, their themes are these. That the West was conned by the Kosovo Liberation Army into joining a secessionist conflict on their side. That the Nato conflict was designed to punish Milosevic for the failures of the international community over Bosnia. And, most strange of all, the lingering suggestion that we did it because we could, hypnotised by the possibility of an allied casualty-free war, and by the ability to put on a demonstration of the supremacy of our technology.

It is all very nice and neat. But there is something deeply unsatisfactory about this account of why Nato went to war in Kosovo. Unsatisfactory because - as ever - it is about us, not them; because it is an account that is only interested in the neat transposition of European and American ideological arguments on to the Balkans. In the past seven years or so, the Balkan wars have thrown up two kinds of book. First, there are the glib volumes that place the writer's (often puzzled, sometimes horrified) experience at the centre of the examination of the Balkan mystery. But the Balkan wars have also produced tours de force of popular and serious history that for the first time, almost in a century, have placed the liminal territory of Balkan experience back at the centre of the European story.

This second kind has thrown up a trio of writers - Misha Glenny, Noel Malcolm and Tim Judah - who, while not necessarily in agreement in their analysis, have dared to treat the Balkans seriously. Tim Judah's first book, The Serbs: History, Myth and the Destruction of Yugoslavia, took the wars of Slovenia, Croatia and Bosnia from the most unfashionable of angles, examining the causes of the war from within the Serbian mind-set. Now he has turned his attention to an equally intractable problem - trying to extract a sense of meaning from how the contradictions and vagaries of Albanian nationalism within the ethnic Albanian Kosovar community, both in Kosovo and abroad, grew into a 'liberation army' and started a war.

The truth of the matter, as Judah makes clear in his new book, Kosovo: War and Revenge, is that the rapid acceleration towards the KLA spring uprising - that began after Serb forces wiped out the compounds of two secessionist clans in the Drenica mountains in March 1998 - was unexpected by almost everyone, including the vast majority who would within months be wearing the black doubled-headed eagle of the UCK (the KLA). The difficulty with revisionary accounts of what happened in Kosovo in the lead-up to the war and after is that they operate on the assumption that the nascent KLA (around 150 strong as the civil war began) was cohesive in its strategy, philosophy or aims; that tying Nato into the conflict was always intended, rather than a cry of help as the full weight of the Serb forces was unleashed against the mountain villages that summer.

One of those who repeats this claim is Michael Ignatieff. His Virtual War is a patchy and rather unsatisfactory book, including (at rather too great length) his correspondence with Robert Skidelsky on whether Nato was right to intervene. Ignatieff never seems to get below the surface detail or beyond what Ignatieff is feeling. Worryingly, the most interesting section (previously published in the US), which deals with the efforts of the US envoy Richard Holbrooke to negotiate a peaceful settlement, comes across as rather gauche - as if Ignatieff cannot quite credit that he is travelling with such important people.

Instead it is left to Tim Judah to interpret Ignatieff's material and to illuminate it. For where Judah is skilful is in his mastery of both primary and secondary sources, to lay bare how Kosovo, Serbia and the international community stumbled into a crisis where all felt bound by dangerous obligations. At the heart of Judah's argument is that despite the warnings of the diplomats and moderate ethnic Albanians, no one wanted to believe that the ground was being laid for confrontation. As one diplomat tells Judah: "There was no sense of critical mass. You could not say that it was going to erupt."

The point, as Judah demonstrates, is that there should have been. The failure of the international community to try and settle the Kosovo issue at the Dayton peace conference (and before), and the subsequent collapse of faith in the struggling policies of pacifist Kosovar leader Ibrahim Rugova, created the circumstances in which a disparate group of extremists could flourish and coalesce into the KLA. That failure, and the weaknesses of international resolve as the Serbs began the killing, made war inevitable.

fields.headline: Health report The eternal optimist
fields.standfirst: Alternative medicine has long championed the healing powers of positive thinking. Now, thankfully, the mainstream is catching on, says Richard Lawrence
fields.trailText: Alternative medicine has long championed the healing powers of positive thinking. Now, thankfully, the mainstream is catching on, says Richard Lawrence
fields.body:
Researchers at the distinguished Mayo Clinic in Minnesota have just released the results of a long-term study into the relationship between a person's state of mind and how long they live. A sample group of 839 people were interviewed between 1962 and 1965, and graded according to their degree of optimism or pessimism. The same group was surveyed 30 years later, and it was found that the pessimists had a 19 per cent greater likelihood of premature death than the optimists. 'The survey tells us that mind and body are linked,' says Dr Toshihiko Maruta, a Mayo Clinic psychiatrist, 'and that attitude has an impact on the final outcome, death.' In other words, academics have now confirmed what many of us have long believed: that positive thinking leads to a longer and healthier life.

Researchers have known for more than 20 years that the health of animals suffers when they feel helpless about negative events beyond their control, and more recent studies have indicated that humans who feel similarly are more likely to experience not only depression, but physical illness and premature death. The Mayo study draws conclusive parallels between modes of thinking and health. After reading the report, Professor Martin Seligman of the University of Pennsylvania Psychology Department advocates using programmes for pessimistic people to 'change their thinking and so lower their risk of physical illness and even death'. The authors of the Mayo report came to the same conclusion. At last, the traditionally sceptical academic community is starting to accept that positive thinking should be used in health care.

Anecdotal evidence has existed for years. Cures for anything from headaches to cancer have been attributed, wholly or partially, to a positive mental approach. This makes sense when you consider that the part of the brain relating to subconscious activity is a purely functional aspect of the mind. It knows exactly how to direct the nervous and physical human structure, to cause us to walk, talk or perform any other physical action. It also responds to instruction. When your conscious mind decides to walk, the subconscious will respond by causing the necessary nervous interactions. Neuroscientists do not yet know exactly how this happens - but they know that it does. In the same way, the subconscious mind will respond to positive or negative suggestions. So if you consciously think you are getting better during an illness, the subconscious mind will work with that suggestion and you will tend to improve (and vice versa for negative feelings).

This basic principle has been proved by the so-called 'placebo effect'. Researchers have given patients neutral pills which should have no effect whatsoever on them, but because the patient has been told it is a beneficial medicine, they get better. Their subconscious mind has been programmed with the idea that they are going to get better and so they do. Colin Rose published the details of a survey in 1985, which was conducted at Travis Air Force Base in California. Doctors rated 152 cancer patients at the base as to whether they had a positive or negative expectation of recovery. Without exception, the patients with positive expectations had more successful remission rates. Only two of the patients with negative expectations showed any response to treatment at all. The physician at the base stated that: 'A positive attitude towards treatment was a better predictor of treatment than was the severity of the disease.' This shows just how potent subconscious programming can be - in this case through expectation.

Hypochondria is on the opposite side of the coin to the placebo effect. Believing you are ill can cause you to become so. A study conducted at the Ottawa General Hospital Department of Medicine in Canada, and published in 1987 by Dr Herbert Benson, illustrates this well. It looked at 63 women and 43 men who had experienced pain and attributed it to a heart condition. X-rays showed that none of these patients was at any significant risk from coronary illness or death, and the patients were informed accordingly. A year later it was found that those who held on to this belief were still experiencing pain, while most of the others were either free of pain, or experienced it at a reduced level.

Now that academic evidence exists, establishing attitude and belief as a potent force in programming the subconscious mind - either positively or negatively - it is to be hoped it will be incorporated into the treatment of patients. It would be wonderful to think that a visit to a GP might soon include patients being instructed on the benefits of positive thought. On the basis of this report, it will certainly improve their health.

 If you tell yourself that you are better when you are not, the subconscious will react against this and prove you wrong. The suggestion should always be that you will improve, not that you have already done so.

fields.headline: Second opinion
fields.standfirst: This week: is electroconvulsive therapy - ECT - a barbaric treatment for mental illness?
fields.trailText: YES Tom Keen, senior lecturer in mental health at Plymouth University
fields.body:
YES Tom Keen, senior lecturer in mental health at Plymouth University

ECT is ineffective, unsafe, cruel and crude and causes patients to experience severe and disabling psychological side effects - anything from social unease to memory loss. We have absolutely no idea how shock treatment works, yet it is being administered in this country in a way that is, at times, completely cavalier. Still, cracks are beginning to show in psychiatry's armour of arrogance and some professionals are starting to think twice about using it.

In simple terms, ECT makes people have convulsions, which makes you wonder when you consider that we try to stop epileptics having convulsions because we think they're bad for them. Fits are bad for the brain, and while there is no question that ECT does jolt the patient out of a state of mind, is this benefit worth the cost? The evidence is that this effect doesn't last long and offers only temporary relief, and an awful lot of people who have ECT once do not want to go through it again. Yes, surveys have offered evidence of patients who believe that the benefits outweigh the costs, but I do think that when people have ECT and say they would choose it again, it might well say more about their psychological state than how effective the treatment is. They are often motivated by guilt, masochism or self-loathing.

There really should be a full debate around the whole issue of ECT now. I think in 20 years' time we will look back and think, 'What the hell were we doing?'

NO Dr Mark Salter, psychiatrist

ECT is saving the lives of some of my patients. These are people who are suffering from a depression so severe that they think they are responsible for all the pain and suffering in the whole world. They want to die because they don't think they deserve to be released from their pain.

All experienced and responsible psychiatrists who work in this country today will recognise that people suffering from this sort of psychotic depression will almost certainly benefit from ECT. There is no doubt in my mind of that at all.

At any one time, 5 per cent of the human population are suffering from a depression that we should recognise as an illness. These are the people that we used to shove in asylums to be force-fed and force-watered. The mentally ill still face stigma today which precludes people who have benefited from ECT coming out and talking about it. A history of mental illness means you aren't going to get life insurance and you can forget about having a mortgage.

There are 12,000 ECT treatments being administered in England and Wales each year, which is probably a sign that it is being used too much, but the evidence is overwhelmingly that it works.

Yes, the effects of ECT often don't last very long, but I would rather have six or seven weeks relief from a psychiatric illness than none at all. Also, at least two people I have given ECT in the past five years are still well now.

webTitle: If feminism really is up the creek, don't blame the Messenger

fields.headline: If feminism really is up the creek, don't blame the Messenger
fields.standfirst: Imelda Whelehan's Overloaded: Popular Culture and the Future of Feminism is concerned with equality but cavalier about free speech
fields.trailText: In a culture overloaded with the idea that women's liberation can be equated with the freedom to appear semi-naked in FHM magazine, anything which questions this seems welcome. It's an obvious point - but more feminists feel they have to say it these days - that lifestyle choice is not the same as economic or reproductive choice.
fields.body:
Overloaded: Popular Culture and the Future of Feminism

by Imelda Whelehan

The Women's Press, £11.99, pp202

If you agree that lewd remarks made by television personalities such as Denise Van Outen are offensive, politically incorrect irony, then this book is for you.

Imelda Whelehan, a lecturer in English and women's studies at De Montfort University, puts on her 'old' feminist boots to give 'new' feminists who trivialise women's inequality a kick up the arse. In her book, she advises people to stop pretending that "retro-sexism" - naked images of women and laughing at sexist jokes in a "I know it's offensive but I'm not sexist" way - don't undermine women's equality. Her message to women everywhere is: burn your ironic bras!

Overloaded is a compact description of how feminism has become an f-word as a result of the popularity of Girl Power language. Whelehan explains how feminists have been accused, unfairly, of encouraging women to have it all when the reality of being a career and baby-juggling superwoman is burn-out and disappointment.

She's scornful of feminist contemporaries who feel sorry for male victims instead of prioritising women victims, and she opposes the fashion industry for explaining macho behaviour and sexual cultural divisions as the product of the male psyche rather than patriarchy.

In a culture overloaded with the idea that women's liberation can be equated with the freedom to appear semi-naked in FHM magazine, anything which questions this seems welcome. It's an obvious point - but more feminists feel they have to say it these days - that lifestyle choice is not the same as economic or reproductive choice. Yet although women such as Posh Spice or Zoë Ball, who symbolise 'new' feminism, may well agree with her, it doesn't mean that young women are more inclined to become Whelehan-style feminists either.

As a solution to political apathy, she appeals to women to view themselves as victims of a postmodernist culture which makes them believe that sexist images are meaningless. In fact, she urges, there is still a need for a revitalised feminist critique of a world where popular manifestations of gender inequality inform and reflect society. "When cast in this light, no individual image is trivial," she argues.

Few people would deny that culture has some influence on perception. However, if women are seen as so downtrodden by sexist language and imagery, how can they escape their victimhood in order to change anything in the first place?

Women cannot start political campaigns if they really are spending all their time sobbing about Melinda Messenger's voluptuous breasts on television or staying at home in case they're offended by wolfwhistles from drunk football fans.

Whelehan offers no answers to this. She attacks such views as the product of anti-feminists who deny the complexities of reality and cultural influences. The idea that all Whelehan wants to do is consider the plethora of ways in which culture influences our world sounds open-minded. She rejects the notion that all feminists hate porn but says its influence on our lives needs to be considered.

However, her instinct is to protect women from patriarchal influences by curbing everybody's rights. She supports positive discrimination and censorship because "total freedom of speech allows for the abuse and harassment of the disempowered". So, although she hates the lifestyle correctness imposed on women by a global consumer-obsessed culture, Whelehan is in favour of political correctness which dictates what people can say. It seems that she's ready to give up on the right to say what you want and replace it with the right to consume what you want. So much for the idea that only 'new' feminists were into consumerism.

No doubt, Whelehan will accuse me of being on the side of the 'anti-feminists', yet I wish I was wrong about her ideas. If only she had retained the progressive elements of radical politics from the 70s and ended up supporting the right to exercise freedom of speech as well as the freedom to have equal pay.

Instead, Whelehan takes the worst aspects of 'second-wave' feminism. She demands intervention by the authorities at every opportunity in the name of helping women victims. Yet what kind of a world will we end up living in if people become more anxious and less free to conduct personal relationships in the way they want because of new codes of conduct?

At the end of the book, she wonders whether young women will "feel nostalgic for the heady days of the women's movement". Yet they weren't there and - forgive me if this sounds offensive - if Whelehan's memory of what can be learnt from the feminist movement is anything to go by, it's just as well they weren't.

fields.headline: First catch your spit-roasted servant
fields.standfirst: Ian Rankin's eleventh Rebus novel, Set in Darkness, shows a writer at the height of his powers, while George P Pelecanos's Shame the Devil is a hardboiled delight and Joseph Glass's Blood a clunky disappointment
fields.trailText: Ian Rankin's eleventh Rebus novel, Set in Darkness, shows a writer at the height of his powers, while George P Pelecanos's Shame the Devil is a hardboiled delight and Joseph Glass's Blood a clunky disappointment
fields.body:
Set in Darkness
by Ian Rankin
Orion, £16.99, pp415
Buy it from BOL

Shame the Devil
by George P Pelecanos
Victor Gollancz, £9.99, pp299
Buy it from BOL

Blood
by Joseph Glass
Macmillan, £16.99, pp499
Buy it from BOL

From Conan Doyle to Colin Dexter, crimewriters have chafed against the limitations a long-running mystery series imposes on them. Set in Darkness is Ian Rankin's eleventh novel featuring the choleric, compassionate loner, Detective Inspector John Rebus, but if the author is feeling constrained, there's no sign of it here.

The starting point for Set in Darkness is the establishment of the new Scottish Parliament. The novel opens with Rebus, appointed police liaison to the Parliament, on a tour of Queensberry House, the ancient building being refurbished to provide the new institution's residence. Much guff has been talked about the sense of place in crime fiction, but Edinburgh is the shaping force for the Rebus series. Rebus is drawn to the city's bloody past and you can't get much bloodier than an act of cannibalism in Queensberry House around the time of the Act of Union in 1707, when a madman killed a young servant and roasted him on a spit.

In the course of his tour, archaeologists uncover the fireplace where the youth died and a recent murder victim comes to light. When the body of Roddy Grieve, a prospective MSP from a well-known Edinburgh family, is discovered in the gardens of Queensberry House, the scene is set for an immensely satisfying police procedural.

Under pressure from above to solve the murder of Grieve as quickly as possible, Rebus is not surprised to find there are people willing to do anything to capitalise on Scottish independence, especially when it comes to profiting from Edinburgh's booming land values. His survival becomes questionable when he finds himself up against an old enemy, a powerful villain he hoped he'd put away for years to come.

Rebus is a masterful creation (one shortly to be incarnated by John Hannah in the television adaptation of Black and Blue and The Hanging Garden). At the beginning of the series, Rankin kitted him out with a junkie brother, a past life in the SAS, a stage hypnotist father and a "smart-arse, postgraduate joke name" (author's words).

Over the years, Rankin has modified him - his musical taste changed abruptly from jazz to rock when John Harvey's jazz-loving Resnick came on the scene; his SAS background has been fondly debunked. In deepening the characterisation with each novel, Rankin has made Rebus into the most interesting crime protagonist around. In consequence, over the past three years, Rankin has taken his well-earned place among the top echelon of crime writers.

American writer George P Pelecanos, meanwhile, is heavily tipped to be the Next Big Thing. Shame the Devil is the sixth of his hip, hardboiled thrillers to be published in Britain. Born, raised and still living in Washington DC, Pelecanos writes with passion and commitment about the plight of the working classes in the American capital's crime-ridden inner city.

His 'DC Quartet', of which Shame the Devil is the final part, looks at the impact of drugs and the crime they bring over three decades in the ethnically mixed inner urban areas. It opens with a pizza-parlour robbery which turns into a bloodbath - staff shot in cold blood; the gunman's brother killed by a cop; a young boy run over by a getaway car.

Three years later, the gunman heads back to Washington to even the score over his brother's death by killing everyone involved. This story is set against the background of a police department in disarray, a former general parachuted in to run the capital's school system and Congress appointing a control board with a white Texan city manager to oversee a city, 80% of whose residents are black.

The DC Quartet has been likened to James Ellroy's LA Quartet but the books have little in common. Pelecanos doesn't go in for Ellroy's stylistic pyrotechnics, convoluted plots and complex narratives. He prefers to focus on a single incident and let a story develop from its consequences. Music plays an important part in the feel of the quartet: it has a soundtrack of the coolest music of the different periods embedded in it, as do his other novels.

Shame the Devil shows once again that Pelecanos is a powerful writer, a deft stylist with a good ear for the nuances and rhythms of street speech. He deserves to be listed among the best - the fluency of his dialogue alone matches that of the masters, Leonard and McBain.

Joseph Glass's Blood would be much improved if he (or she? The name is a pseudonym for "a New York Times bestselling author") weren't so clunky with both internal and external dialogue. The sequel to Eyes, in which we first met psychic psychiatrist Dr Susan Shader, has the requisite number of thrills and an overabundance of spills (of the red stuff, naturally, given the title) but is little more than formulaic. It's the psychic in pursuit of the psychotic.

There's a serial killer on the loose called the Undertaker, who is obsessed with women's blood and virginity. Shader is the only one who can stop him because when there are no more clues to work from, she has psychic insights to move the plot along. The problem is she likes to explain her insights at length, and she always talks as if she has just swallowed a textbook.

The psychology lectures masquerading as conversation are bad and the brief chitchat between her and a cop on blood symbolism in Romeo and Juliet excruciating, but my favourite moment is when she's pondering the cop's gunshot wound. "In Gold's case empyema of the damaged lung was also to be feared. If it happened, the doctors would have to insert a drainage tube in the area, in order to get rid of the purulent exudate."

The purulent exudate? Who said words are puny things?

The DC Quartet has been likened to James Ellroy's LA Quartet but the books have little in common. Pelecanos doesn't go in for Ellroy's stylistic pyrotechnics, convoluted plots and complex narratives. He prefers to focus on a single incident and let a story develop from its consequences. Music plays an important part in the feel of the quartet: it has a soundtrack of the coolest music of the different periods embedded in it, as do his other novels. Shame the Devil shows once again that Pelecanos is a powerful writer, a deft stylist with a good ear for the nuances and rhythms of street speech. He deserves to be listed among the best - the fluency of his dialogue alone matches that of the masters, Leonard and McBain. Joseph Glass's Blood would be much improved if he (or she? The name is a pseudonym for "a New York Times bestselling author") weren't so clunky with both internal and external dialogue. The sequel to Eyes, in which we first met psychic psychiatrist Dr Susan Shader, has the requisite number of thrills and an overabundance of spills (of the red stuff, naturally, given the title) but is little more than formulaic. It's the psychic in pursuit of the psychotic. There's a serial killer on the loose called the Undertaker, who is obsessed with women's blood and virginity. Shader is the only one who can stop him because when there are no more clues to work from, she has psychic insights to move the plot along. The problem is she likes to explain her insights at length, and she always talks as if she has just swallowed a textbook. The psychology lectures masquerading as conversation are bad and the brief chitchat between her and a cop on blood symbolism in Romeo and Juliet excruciating, but my favourite moment is when she's pondering the cop's gunshot wound. "In Gold's case empyema of the damaged lung was also to be feared. If it happened, the doctors would have to insert a drainage tube in the area, in order to get rid of the purulent exudate." The purulent exudate? Who said words are puny things?

fields.headline: Four of the best...
fields.standfirst: ...places to eat and buy quality organic cabbages, sprouting broccoli and other greens. By Jim Ainsworth
fields.trailText: ...places to eat and buy quality organic cabbages, sprouting broccoli and other greens. By Jim Ainsworth
fields.body:
Adam Robinson at The Chiswick (131 Chiswick High Road, London W4; 020 8994 6887) is a man who relishes winter greens. 'Why do people rush to buy expensive Italian cima di rape and cavolo nero,' he asks, 'when traditional English greens are cheaper and make much more sense?' He confesses to some embarrassment on behalf of the restaurant trade, noting that half the capital's food is likely to be underlaid with spinach all year round, leaving the great variety of other seasonal greens to go unrecognised by his colleagues and competitors. In the case of purple sprouting broccoli, he starts by blanching the greens, leaves and flowers separately, which he then sautés in butter before adding a Provençale anchovy dressing to make a tasty first course. His current favourite vegetables are sprout tops, which are gentler in flavour, don't smell as much as sprouts themselves, and are less iron-rich than kale. Simply stewed in butter for five minutes, they make a fine accompaniment to winter meats, confits, stews and braises.

Purple sprouting broccoli is cooked just as straightforwardly at Blue Print Café (Design Museum, Butlers Wharf, London SE1; 020 7378 7031), although here there is a penchant for Italian greens, too. Chopped cavolo nero is added to sweated onions and garlic and reduced to a 'lovely and rich' purée to accompany rabbit or chicken dishes, while cima di rape (long, broccoli-like turnip tops) are braised with lentils or partner fish. Savoy cabbage, meanwhile, might be braised with onion, bacon, celery and carrot, and given some indulgent shavings of black truffle, to make a prince-and-pauper sideshow for duck or pigeon.

While London restaurants can take their pick of the best market produce, country restaurants have an arguably greater advantage; many can grow, or have grown for them, small quantities of less common vegetables. Tony and Tina Bricknell-Webb of Percy's at Coombeshead (Virginstow, Devon; 01409 211 236) cultivate a mere one-and-a-half of their 130 acres as a kitchen garden, which is en route to becoming organic. But while commercial growers need to supply an established demand, they can afford to experiment. Last year, for example, they grew both purple and white sprouting broccoli side by side, and found that the unusual white (in fact pale green) variety was less prone to disease, didn't bolt as quickly, and produced larger heads with better flavour. Tina boils them briefly (if you call one minute brief) in a splash of water, seasons them, and sends them to the table immediately, alongside main courses of chicken or fish. Resourcefulness appears to be a characteristic of this kitchen. When small Savoy cabbages, for example, are hollowed out and stuffed to make a vegetarian dish, the dark outer leaves are shredded and slowly roasted to crispness, to add to soups or to make a garnish. Some varieties of beetroot also yield usable leaves - de-ribbed and stir-fried they produce 'fantastic flavour' - as did a patch of failed Brussels sprouts this year, whose loose leaves and unformed heads were declared 'better than sprouts' by some customers.

Daphne Lambert at Penrhos Court (Kington, Herefordshire; 01544 230 720) is an organic champion who is 'really keen on green things'. She balances her four-course meals nutritionally, and rates brassicas highly for their calcium contribution. Broccoli is roasted with sesame oil and seeds, becoming soft inside, crisp outside; chopped beet leaves crop up raw in salads, or are juiced to make an aperitif; cabbage leaves are stuffed with rice, currants and pine kernels, just like vine leaves; while sprouts are grated, sautéd in olive oil and seasoned with black pepper and nutmeg.

Jim Ainsworth is editor of The Good Food Guide

fields.headline: Chinese whispers
fields.standfirst: The Orient in London's Piccadilly features two items on its menu which are often missing from Chinatown's restaurants - excellent service and superb food. Jay Rayner spreads the word
fields.trailText: The Orient in London's Piccadilly features two items on its menu which are often missing from Chinatown's restaurants - excellent service and superb food. Jay Rayner spreads the word
fields.body:
A few years ago I was chased from a restaurant in London's Chinatown by a machete-wielding chef for refusing to leave a tip. The service had been appalling and I was hardly moved to reward it. The highlight - or lowlight - was when a sizzling dish was brought to the table sans sizzle, because it had taken so long to leave the kitchen, and the waiter attempted to cover for the absence of noise by making a fizzing noise with his lips. It was a nice bit of improvisation but I didn't think it deserved the extra 10 per cent. And the introduction of the cleaver into discussions did not sway me any.

This, of course, is an extreme example, but it's still fair to say that while Chinatown is renowned for cooking, it is less known for the grace with which it gets it to the table. Any new Chinese restaurant in central London trying to set themselves apart from the competition can therefore start by working on the service. I am happy to say that in this regard The Orient Restaurant at the new China House complex on London's Piccadilly scores highly. None of the staff there would ever dream of threatening you with a large knife.

The Orient costs, but then quality does. I have to admit a certain sense of relief at its success. In recent months I have visited a series of big-ticket openings in London - Asia de Cuba, Between Six and Eight (now renamed Seven), and most recently Twentyfour - and found gross fault with each. None of them delivered anything approaching value for an awful lot of money. I began to fear that the experience of repeatedly crashing the company plastic on your behalf (a dirty job, but somebody's got to do it) had induced in me a certain - and very unreasonable - ennui; as if no amount of subtle downlighting, crisp napery and polished glassware could ever satisfy me. The Orient has restored my faith.

The wide, airy, L-shaped room on the first floor of the corner site overlooking Piccadilly comes with all the subtle downlighting, crisp napery and polished glassware you could wish for. The floors are stripped wood, the chairs are dressed in chocolate shades of leather and the banquettes are a calming caramel suede.

These are the expected incidentals; the reason for going is the food. I always find myself anticipating a certain delicacy and precision with Chinese food which rarely transpires. Here, that's exactly what you get. We were advised by the staff that we would need at least three starters between two. This was not an attempt to up the bill but an accurate representation of their size. A single soft-shell crab came in a light batter and dressed with a fine dice of chilli, garlic and spring onions. The sweetness of the seafood played beautifully against the saltiness of the batter. Smoked, shredded chicken came with intense flavour bombs of roasted garlic. The least successful starter, perhaps because it was the least obviously Chinese, was a salad of rare sliced beef in a honey mustard dressing. The meat was wonderfully tender but a little too cold, clearly having only left the fridge a few seconds before being sliced on to the plate.

For our main courses we chose caramelised prawns with cashew nuts - the nuttiest toasted nuts I have ever tasted. It was presented in a couple of sheaves of fried wonton pastry which, being smeared with the intense sauce, we just had to eat as well, even though the waiter tried to take them away. We literally ate the plate. Tender, succulent pieces of honey-glazed pork came with a tempura of plantain and courgette and crisp green beans were dressed in a light black bean and ginger sauce. I had assumed that a dish called garlic wafer chicken described the cut of the meat - sliced thinly - rather than that of the garlic. I was wrong. Perfectly roasted chicken, the skin rendered to a parchment crispness, came beneath a golden brown heap of deep fried garlic and shallot.

Puddings have never been the main reason for eating Chinese and so here the menu goes resolutely Western. It is mark of The Orient's success that they can pull this off. A rich chocolate cake and a raspberry and ginger crème brûlée were both fine pieces of work. By now our six-month-old son was getting restless. As the restaurant was almost empty, we asked whether we could lay him on a rug by our feet. The good-humoured waiters did not bat an eyelid. Eddie rolled and wriggled about, a massive grin on his face. The way we were feeling after our lunch we were almost inclined to get down there on the floor and join him. I'm sure the staff wouldn't have minded.

The Orient at China House, 160 Piccadilly, London W1 (020 7499 6888). Dinner for two including drinks and service, £100.
Jay Rayner can be contacted at jay.rayner@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Daddy, where did I come from?

fields.headline: Daddy, where did I come from?
fields.standfirst: Sticky love and harsh callousness: Susan Elderkin's first novel, Sunset Over Chocolate Mountains, is excellently written, but not exactly literature
fields.trailText:
Sunset Over Chocolate Mountains
by Susan Elderkin
Fourth Estate, £9.99, pp306
fields.body:
Sunset Over Chocolate Mountains
by Susan Elderkin
Fourth Estate, £9.99, pp306

This novel's first sentence could easily have qualified it for the "novels we never finished reading" list: "When he moved to the mountains of Arizona and set up home amongst the giant saguaros of the Sonoran Desert, Theobald Moon developed the habit of getting up early in the morning, peeing in a glass, and knocking it back in a few quick gulps while it was still warm and fresh."

Amazingly, despite this - as well as reading books such as A Manual for Living Comfortably in the Cosmos and weighing hundreds of pounds, Theobald is strangely taking, as are his eventual adored daughter, Josephine, two passionate Slovakian lovers and even the improbable Jersey, who talks like a cowboy out of an old western, is descended from Polish émigrés (is it a joke that it's not Jerzy?), and helps timid, fat Theobald from sheer goodness.

Somehow, these fanciful misfits curled their little tendrils around my sentiment-resistant heart. The story consists of the gradual revelation of their true relations to each other. We learn about Theobald's arrival from England after the death of his mother, with whom he lived, his self-imposed homesickness (much manifested in the importation and ingestion of British sweets), the setting up of his caravan, cottage garden and cactus garden in the desert and his own blossoming in size, serenity and fatherhood.

How this solitary and profoundly clueless man ever connected with a female, however, remains a mystery. We assume he slept with someone, unimaginable though such an event must be, and hope there is at least a bittersweet memory.

For Josephine, however, as she grows, this holding out on basic information becomes central. All she has of her mother are pairs of mostly elegant but wrong-size shoes, which Theobald begins giving her on her seventh birthday, and from which she tries to deduce the rest of her mother. Theobald won't even tell her so much as her mother's name.

In Slovakia, meanwhile - or, as it emerges, somewhat earlier in time - the beautiful Eva, with her hair in a provincial crimp, works in a shoe factory and sneaks off to the woods for liaisons with the even more beautiful Tibor, who may or may not be Romany but has a gypsy's wandering ways, selling homemade ice-cream from a travelling van. When he vanishes without warning, she is desolate, and when he reappears, she clings to him like a burr.

Tibor, a reader of American classics, a confessed murderer and fugitive, adds her name to his falsified passport and takes her off to America. They end up, surreally but inevitably, in an ice-cream truck broken down in the Arizona desert, where Theobald can focus on the (very pregnant) Eva through binoculars.

Novels that tease you into reading on by withholding information can be little more than irritating. This one, happily, offers pleasures along the way. For the domestically inclined, it is satisfying to follow the setting up of Theobald's housekeeping. Paradoxically, this satisfaction is deepened when Josephine starts seeing her doting father as intolerably weird. (Her revulsion at his drinking urine is a nice little revenge for the reader.) As she grows into adolescence, she scoffs and sneers openly.

Her behaviour is finally so self-destructive that you have to cover your eyes. You think nothing worse can happen, but it is at this stage that we learn how Theobald became Josephine's father. It is an ingeniously horrible episode, with the special horror that comes from seeing a benign and innocent person being crueller than a less kind but more knowing one.

The title of the novel comes from the name Eva gives to an ice-cream flavour that Tibor invents for them to sell in America, and the author, too, at first seems to want to reinvent the world as a pastel place full of golden, high-heeled sandals and men who are strong, brave, and handsome or baby-like in their innocence, a world sticky only with sweetness.

In our greyer world, Eva would have stayed abandoned, and Theo would be alone: the trusty sidekick represented by Jersey is an almost purely literary device. It is Josephine's sour turn that promises reality will edge in, and it does so harshly indeed. If reality is what it is.

The contrast of sticky love and harsh callousness is itself literary, though typical of literature characterised by Somerset Maugham as being "not of the first water", the kind of which he considered himself a first-rate exponent. One thinks especially of Carson McCullers's too-lovable geeks and Lenny in Of Mice and Men.

But those creations have shown popular staying power and still pack a punch (though you may hate yourself in the morning). It is likely that Susan Elderkin will, like Maugham, continue entertaining and moving us, a first-rate writer of literature of not quite the first water.

fields.headline: Best cellars
fields.standfirst: This week: three great reds from Pic St Loup  by Tim Atkin
fields.trailText: 1997 Chteau l'Euzière, Pic St Loup, Cuvée des Escarboucles (£7.99, Fullers). The stunning 1998 will be available in May, but this is enough to be going on with. Marcelle and Michel Causse's reds are some of the most stylish in the area. This peppery, spicy, Syrah-dominated red has delightful oak integration and good grip on the finish. As good as many Cte Rties.
fields.body:
1997 Chteau l'Euzière, Pic St Loup, Cuvée des Escarboucles (£7.99, Fullers). The stunning 1998 will be available in May, but this is enough to be going on with. Marcelle and Michel Causse's reds are some of the most stylish in the area. This peppery, spicy, Syrah-dominated red has delightful oak integration and good grip on the finish. As good as many Cte Rties.

1998 Mas Bruguière, Pic St Loup, Fts de Ch êne (£7.99, Fullers; Swig, 020 7431 4412; Noel Young Wines, 01223 844 744; Adam Bancroft, 020 7627 8700). Along with Domaine de l'Hortus, Mas Brugière is the leading name in Pic St Loup. This richly oaked blend of 60 per cent Syrah and equal amounts of Grenache and Mourvèdre is stunning, with flavours of blackberry, chocolate and vanilla. I've already bought two cases myself.

1998 Chteau de Lascaux, Coteaux du Languedoc (£4.99, Oddbins). Jean Benot Cavalier bottles his basic cuvée as a simple Coteaux du Languedoc, but this aromatic blend of Syrah and Grenache still tastes like a scaled down Pic St Loup - smooth and easy to drink.

webTitle: A worm's eye view of the Big Apple

fields.headline: A worm's eye view of the Big Apple
fields.standfirst: Ted Heller's Slab Rat takes on the seedy media world of New York machinations with blackhearted comedy
fields.trailText: Ted Heller's first novel, Slab Rat, is a coruscating comedy of manners set in a most Manhattan of magazine offices. It magazine is owned by Versailles Publishing, which boasts the most pulp-worthy of lifestyle magazines - Boy, Here, There, Appeal, Ego.
fields.body:
Slab Rat
by Ted Heller
Abacus, £10.99, pp332

Zachary Post, associate editor of an inane cultural rag, It magazine, New York, prepares to shake hands with nervous new recruit Mark Larkin. Senior editors smirk blithely in the background, hair is smoothed, ties are adjusted; the illustrious preen themselves before the trembling initiate. Just as he extends his hand, Post is paralysed by a single, all-consuming thought. "This guy is a really serious asshole and a lot of people are going to hate him."

Unfortunately for Post, not enough people. Vastly overdue for promotion, Post has found himself stuck at 32 on half-ascent, despite the wild fabrications of his CV (a Gatsby childhood, cosmopolitan stint in the UK, a golfing handicap, father a famous architect of skewed post-modernish buildings). Larkin is the nemesis of the editor-in-waiting - a late-twentysomething, English tailored shirt-wearing, transatlantic vowel-intoning man with an unusually honed skill for platonic ingratiation.

Ted Heller's first novel, Slab Rat, is a coruscating comedy of manners set in a most Manhattan of magazine offices. It magazine is owned by Versailles Publishing, which boasts the most pulp-worthy of lifestyle magazines - Boy, Here, There, Appeal, Ego. Post's initially guileless attempts to work his way up lead him into a series of schmooze-dribbling soirées, where female editors clad their ever-diminishing waists in sleek black pantsuits and their male equivalents descend into drunken halitosis.

Heller revels in the seedy lowest rungs of the media ladder: bored interviewees, articles spiked, petulant squabbles over desk arrangements. The feud between Post and Larkin is hardly a clash of Titans - both more closely resemble snuffling ferrets - and its opposed armies are a tatty assortment: doomed-to-the-dustbin Willie Lister, once a gleaming polymath, now sliding further into Willy Loman ramblings and revenge fantasies; maenad sex-queen Marjorie Millet, known for impromptu photocopier fumblings; Ivy, waifish and cloying, the overindulged child of a millionaire; and Leslie, the self-serving Anglo-toff, a vision of floating locks and après-ski health.

Via their frenzied attempts to bag the lead article, Heller smoothly exposes the worst sort of cultural commentary, in which prose becomes a fallacious sputum of Zeitgeist labels. Heller might have made the error of casting Post as a man with a tortured soul. Instead, he makes him a second-rank devil, enthusiastically aiming his best Zeitgeist labels at the prize, constantly unable to snatch it from other hoofed hands.

Unfortunately for Post, Larkin is particularly fluent in the idiolect, turning out reams of "grad-school" pseud-twists: "Ethan Cawley both demythifies and remythifies, deconstructs and reconstructs... informed of its time and place... a crazy quilt concoction of Zane Grey and James Joyce... turning American literature on its head, then standing it back up again."

Heller relishes execrable prose of many hues - the conspiratorial whispers of hedonist gossip columnist Boris Montague are lovingly evoked: "If Armand St. Clair Stringcheese, once one of the finest polo players in Europe, were not such a fantastic drunkard and despicable whoremaster, he might still be a friend of mine, but..."

Post's internal narrative is a virtuoso display of mental footling and pat articulacy. The arch machinations he pulls off to win the acidic English rose and the job he covets send the novel into surprising reaches of farcical blackheartedness.

As his cast of sallow demons circle frantically around each other, Heller delivers a few broadsides to American Dreamism, the jolly call to "Dream, plan, can!!" and the idea that status and wealth are the only demarcations for a life. And there's something about the culture of avid precociousness as well - Post fears the advent of mid-thirties stymie as he fears the final stroke of death. Ultimately, Heller suggests, dribbling ambition is not enough; psychotic stealth is the only way to succeed in this grubby, panmictic, wine-slugging world.

fields.headline: Bedsit genius charms US
fields.standfirst: A reclusive publishing sensation is being hailed as the new William Burroughs, reports  Ed Vulliamy
fields.trailText: A reclusive publishing sensation is being hailed as the new William Burroughs, reports Ed Vulliamy
fields.body:
The American world of letters is feting a new literary sensation, a semi-reclusive and deliberately difficult young author who is being acclaimed as a 'genius' in the mould of Kierkegaard, James Joyce and William Burroughs.

David Eggers's A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius is already in its third imprint in the United States, despite its apparently unpromising subject matter - a memoir on the death of his two parents and his experience of raising his young brother.

The few readings that he has given have been packed out with fans of his previous ventures - not least the hugely obscure McSweeney's magazine which he edits and publishes.

A bidding war for the international rights is rumoured to have seen offers of deals running to several million dollars, while Eggers has turned down a $2 million offer for the film rights on the ground that a film would 'be too painful'.

The book has been greeted with extraordinary reviews.

Michiko Kakutani, the New York Times literary critic with notoriously little patience for the avant-garde, has described Eggers as a 'staggeringly talented new writer', while the author Lawrence Weschler has written that 'when Kierkegaard got in this deep - this endlessly, self-ironisingly, loopily, down-spiralling deep - he had to rely on God to save him. But Eggers somehow manages to save himself.'

'What moved me,' he says, 'is that from this generation supposedly incapable of reading came something so sophisticated, yet so full of undefeated wonder, formed and educated, but which has the ability to marvel.'

The Boston Globe, for its part, said Eggers's book 'defies gravity'; 'a book of infinite jest,' Sara Mosle called it in the New York Times .

All this about a book filled with grim humour and opacity, which takes as its subject matter death and Eggers's love for his young brother.

Born in the Chicago suburb, and now living in a chaotic Brooklyn bedsit, Eggers's life is marked by encounters with tragedy. His parents both died of cancer when he was 21, leaving him to take care of his eight-year-old brother, Toph.

But there are other awful incidents that he deals with with a casual aplomb.

'Jeff called,' writes Eggers in one memorable passage, 'and said we had better go over to Ricky's because something terrible had happened. "What happened?" "Ricky's dad doused himself with gasoline and lit a match and ran around the yard on fire and then stopped running and died" ... we walked to Ricky's. He was in the family room watching TV ... they were showing a video for a Bob Dylan song called "Joker Man". We liked the video.'

His friend John attempts suicide with almost comic regularity but the deaths of Eggers's alcoholic father and stoic mother spare nothing. The physical decomposition of his parents and the stench of death are comfortless and unrelenting.

Eggers leaves Chicago and establishes a doomed satirical magazine called Might as he cares for Toph.

Eggers has not read and cannot, he says, read his own account of the denouement, when he returns to Chicago to stumble upon his mother's 'cremains' and scatter them into Lake Michigan - a moment of ruthless self-parody.

The story of the book, of Eggers's real life and how it was written, has come to be the stuff of instant legend - written between midnight and 4am almost every night for a year. To add to this legend, Eggers has reviewed his own book (of which he claims he has yet to see a copy) in Spin magazine - and panned it. He has also arranged a competition on the website of the Amazon Internet bookshop, offering whoever writes the best review a lifetime subscription to the journal that he edits. The only condition is that the book is be awarded five stars under the site's reviewing system and that the reviewer must be able to prove they have not read it.

Such Dadaist interventions are familiar to Eggers's existing fans. His assault on American letters has not been without some forewarning through the quarterly journal McSweeney's which - now in its fourth issue - has gained cult status.

It is McSweeney's, published by Eggers himself, that lays out his manifesto, and he concedes that it could not be 'weirder'. Weschler says its is about 'love of words and love of being'.

None of this, however, gets to the bottom of a phenomenon that has been selling out with each subsequent issue.

The third issue of McSweeney's - filled with graphical and textual tricks - looked like Granta, the British literary magazine.

It is the content that confounds. There are articles like 'Plausible: Provincial Beginnings for Stories Which Might Never Be Written But Could'. Such as: 'After rubbing his eyes, a man becomes permanently blurred.'

The fourth issue is packaged in a box containing 14 elegant pamphlets, each a single article.

But just as one gets used to the idea that McSweeney's is about playing with words, a rumour reaches The Observer that the next issue will have no text at all.
