fields.headline: The outsiders
fields.standfirst: Sophie Bouniol came to the rugged coast of Cork in search of   a new life. So, too, did Ian Bailey, an English journalist. But when she was bludgeoned to death, Bailey found himself under suspicion and shunned by the close-knit community. John Montague lived nearby and recounts the aftermath of an unsolved murder...
fields.trailText: 'There is a devil somewhere in the hills of southern Ireland,' the film producer Daniel Toscan du Plantier wailed in the pages of Le Figaro. He was speaking of West Cork, the part of Ireland where I live, in a 19th-century farmhouse in the luminous shadow of Mount Gabriel - where, legend has it, the last wolf in Ireland was killed.
fields.body:
‘There is a devil somewhere in the hills of southern Ireland,’ the film producer Daniel Toscan du Plantier wailed in the pages of Le Figaro. He was speaking of West Cork, the part of Ireland where I live, in a 19th-century farmhouse in the luminous shadow of Mount Gabriel - where, legend has it, the last wolf in Ireland was killed.

The devil he was referring to had murdered du Plantier’s 39-year-old wife, Sophie, on a moonlit night just before Christmas 1996. It was the first murder in these remote parts since Civil War days, when Michael Collins was killed in Beal na Blath, the Gap of the Blossoms, a few miles inland.

I had spent the days before that Christmas with my companion, the novelist Elizabeth Wassell - who helped to research and write this article - at the Literary Forum in Okinawa, an elongated, serrated island that regards its larger neighbour with much the same ambivalence as Ireland does England. We had gone there from Tokyo, where I had been granted an audience with the Empress. Irish poets vie for the longest meeting with her, and I had out-talked Seamus Heaney by a good 30 minutes. But my contentment waned on the flight home, when I read news of the murder and realised we were heading back into turbulence.

Cork is the largest county in Ireland, and West Cork, the scene of the crime, is its most ruggedly beautiful part, with its shipwrecking seas and its bony mountains clothed in heather and gorse. Its centre is the town of Skibbereen, beyond which gleam the seaside villages of Schull, Goleen, and Crookhaven. Roaringwater Bay is necklaced with islands, and three finger peninsulas - Mizen Head, Sheep’s Head, and Beara - jut into the often wild Atlantic.

Although this region is historically insular (electricity wasn’t introduced here until 1954), over the past two decades expatriates and artists have begun to pour in. The Heinz and newspaper magnate Tony O’Reilly, Jeremy Irons and Sinead Cusack, and David Puttnam all have summer houses in West Cork. Elizabeth Hurley and Hugh Grant were beaten to the house of their choice by a rock band. Even Tony Blair has spent holidays here, and the region has become known as ‘the Irish Riviera’.

At the other end of the spectrum are the unemployed, an invading army, since, under the terms of the European Union, anyone with a European passport can settle in Ireland and draw the dole. West Cork has become a Mecca for the eccentric, the lost children of Europe. Many - such as the New Age hippies of Coole Mountain, a commune of several hundred families whose pot-smoking disturbs the gardaí - are in flight from over-industrialised European centres. One year, they descended on our village to enact a Dionysiac summer-solstice ceremony, burning a giant effigy and dancing to the beat of tasselled tambourines.

Still, despite a recent slight increase in petty larceny, the savage murder of Sophie Toscan du Plantier was the first incidence of serious violence in the area, and the first crime to have international implications. In the ensuing criminal investigation, two jurisdictions and legal systems have collided, provoking debates in the Irish parliament and creating an uproar in the British and French media.

Sophie Bouniol had met Daniel Toscan du Plantier in 1990, when she was 33 and he was 49. She soon became du Plantier’s third wife. The head of the French Academy of Cinema Arts and a close friend of President Jacques Chirac, du Plantier also ran a film-production company, the projects of which included Peter Greenaway’s The Cook, the Thief, His Wife & Her Lover, and he had been made a Chevalier of the Légion d’Honneur, France’s highest cultural honour, that year.

Sophie had the delicate, slightly unconventional style of a Left Bank Parisienne and the birdlike elegance of Mimou. When du Plantier met her, she wanted to act; he convinced her to try a new career as a documentary producer and scriptwriter, for the cultural Channel Arte, with which he was connected. Sophie also had a romanticised image of the Irish countryside, which she had visited briefly in her youth. In 1993, du Plantier bought a bulky five-bedroom house in Schull, which would serve as Sophie’s refuge from her high-profile life in France. She was often photographed at her husband’s side at media events, but she also slipped away to Ireland four or five times a year. Occasionally she would bring someone with her - her teenage son from her first marriage, or another member of her family - but du Plantier joined her only once, and she was listed in the local telephone directory under her maiden name. Among the locals, she had a reputation as something of a loner. For a while she even feuded with her nearest neighbour over a shared gate that she felt should stay closed.

On Friday, 20 December 1996, Sophie landed at Cork Airport (the security video shows her trundling a surprising amount of luggage) and drove to her house along the winding coast road in a rented Ford Fiesta. She chatted briefly with Denis Quinlan at the Courtyard Bar, in Schull, and with Tom Brosnan, the jovial owner of the Spar supermarket, both of whom she knew well. Over the weekend she visited many of her local haunts, including O’Sullivan’s Pub, on the quayside in Crookhaven, a village that has recently become so popular with visiting French yachtsmen that it’s known as ‘little Saint-Tropez’. She also went for a walk on bleak Three Castle Head and called on some friends, with whom she had a strange, melancholy conversation. She said that, while walking, she had come upon the ruins of Dun Lough - or Black Lake - Castle, and had sensed some kind of menace. According to legend, the lake next to the castle is home to a female ghost who, if glimpsed, is supposed to be a harbinger of death. Afterwards, Sophie decided to return to Paris on 24 December, a few days earlier than she’d originally intended. That Sunday, she called her husband at 11pm and had what he recalls was a ‘convivial’ conversation.

At 10 o’clock the next morning, a neighbour found Sophie’s body in the lane leading to her house. She was wearing a nightshirt, leggings, and high, brown lace-up boots, and had been bludgeoned more than a dozen times with a weapon like a poker or possibly a hatchet. A large stone or concrete building block had been dropped on her head, crushing her skull. There was evidence of a struggle. Sophie was a small woman - only 5ft tall - but she had clearly put up a fight: there was blood under her fingernails and she was clutching a clump of hair. Neighbours reported having heard wild cries in the night, which they had assumed were the yowls of mating foxes.

Yet no murder weapon was found, Sophie’s house seemed untouched, and there was no indication of sexual assault. It was said that there were two rinsed wineglasses by the kitchen sink (a local garda told us later that this was ‘a bit of a myth’) and two chairs drawn up to the radiator. It had been a frosty night and, by the time the state pathologist arrived, 24 hours later - having driven the 230 miles from Dublin - rigor mortis had set in and it was too late to determine the time of Sophie’s death.

The story broke in the Irish papers, with many of the details provided first by a local freelance journalist named Ian Bailey, who was working as a stringer for the Cork Examiner and had been one of the first reporters on the scene. But, days later, a rumour began that a woman who’d been walking home from her lover’s house at dawn on the night of the murder said she had spotted a man who resembled Bailey washing his boots in a stream. Others noticed cuts and scratches on his head and hands (which he said he’d got from killing Christmas turkeys and cutting down an aggressive Christmas tree). There was also a rumour that he’d been seen burning clothes on the morning after the murder. Seven weeks later, the gardaí arrested Bailey and his Welsh girlfriend, Jules Thomas.

We knew Bailey, though he had been living in the area for only five years. Born in 1956, the son of a butcher, Bailey had grown up in Gloucestershire, where he attended the Crypt Grammar School and later played for Gloucester’s Old Cryptians rugby club. His size and strength made him an ideal second-row forward. He started working for the Gloucester & County News Service in 1975. In his reporting, Bailey specialised in espionage stories and gave a lot of ink to GCHQ - the intelligence agency in nearby Cheltenham. A journalist who worked closely with Bailey at the time remembers how ‘he talked big. He was always bursting with ideas for making his fame and fortune.’ In 1980, Bailey married another journalist, but the marriage soon ended in a divorce that he describes as ‘acrimonious’, and that the various newspaper accounts called ‘sordid’ and ‘bitter’. In 1991, after brief stints in London and in the United States, Bailey settled in West Cork.

We first met him one night in the winter of 1994. After a lecture at the West Cork Arts Centre, Elizabeth and I stopped in a Ballydehob pub. Next to us at the bar was a tall, striking man in his late thirties, with long dark hair, black eyebrows, and a snaggle-toothed grin. He introduced himself in a crisp English accent and gave us his card, which identified him as ‘Eoin Bailey’. He mentioned his interest in gardening, and we phoned him soon afterwards to ask whether we could hire him to take care of our garden, as we were often travelling and unable to do it ourselves. He agreed.

Frequently, as he bustled around in the garden (and what a peculiar historical satisfaction it was for an Irishman to gaze out the window at his English servant), we would notice that he had hurt himself with a scythe or a sickle - a clumsiness we found surprising in someone who was otherwise so athletic. (Elizabeth speculated that he might have an übermensch complex. I thought he was just awkward.) Once, we had to find Mercurochrome and bandages to staunch the blood. Bailey also smoked heavily, and I can hardly think of him without seeing his eyes narrowed against the smoke of his hand-rolled cigarette.

After he had been working for us for almost a year, Bailey showed me his collected works - scraps of songs and poem-ballads - and I encouraged him in his writing. There was a glimmer of talent there, but it needed a level of discipline which he seemed unprepared to give. He had made a minor reputation for himself, reciting poetry and banging the bodhran - an Irish goatskin drum - at O’Sullivan’s Pub, in Ballydehob, and he seemed to prefer the gratifications of the pub’s indulgent audience to the tedious, concentrated work of a serious writer. At the annual Irish Seanachie - a storytelling festival - on Cape Clear Island, Ian Bailey transformed himself into Eoin Bailey or, sometimes, O’Baille. As he described it in one poem, ‘The tall Eoin Bailey, he chipped in his bit,/with his poems on life he proved a big hit.’

On one occasion, he borrowed a typewriter that had been gathering dust in our house since we’d switched to computers. I worried later that I might have lent my typewriter to Raskolnikov, but I felt a vaguely paternal affection for Bailey back then, and saw him as an older version of the troubled young men I had dealt with as a teacher. Above all, I saw him as a victim of the English class system, a butcher’s son educated at a ‘good’ grammar school where he learned to read Latin but lost his social moorings, who craved acceptance in the more bohemian society of West Cork.

My Collected Poems were published in the autumn of 1995, and Bailey came to a reading in Cork, an occasion that was somewhat eclipsed by torrential rain. After the reading, there was a launch party, where Bailey mingled easily with the assembled literati in a round room overlooking the River Lee, the setting of Spenser’s ‘Epithalamion’.

That Christmas, Bailey and Jules Thomas invited us to dinner in their remote farmhouse, which stands on an expanse of rugged land called Lioscaha (‘the Fairy Fort’), in a region affectionately known as the Prairie. It was a cold night, the sky black and starless, but they welcomed us enthusiastically. Jules put a homemade pâté on their big wooden dining table, alongside chunks of toasted and buttered home-baked bread. A handsome woman in her late forties, Jules is a painter of land- and seascapes, which are conventional but skillful in their composition. She has lived in West Cork for more than 20 years and her love life has been mildly untraditional, but eccentric behaviour is generally tolerated here, at least among the expatriates.

Her three daughters joined us at dinner. The middle daughter is a fledgling artist and she showed us her portfolio. The 18-year-old was warm and courteous, but we sensed an unease between her and Bailey. During dinner, the youngest daughter complained that the Christmas tree had not yet been brought into the house. At first, Bailey placated her with an indulgent smile and continued eating, but when she persisted he got up abruptly, left the house, then lumbered back in with a large tree shivering under his arm, scattering needles across the floor.

Bailey continued to work for us through that winter and the following spring. He started leaving us little notes, addressed with whimsical grandiloquence, ‘To the Bard, John, and the Lady, Elizabeth,’ usually on the subject of our lush garden: ‘I came up on Thursday, the only dry day of the week - I gave the grass a thrashing.’ When we were away in March, we received a St Patrick’s Day card in which he reported: ‘You lost a couple of branches in the storms - but nothing you would notice.’

It was obvious, though, when we returned a few weeks later, that the garden had been neglected - the grass was tangled and knee-high, the boughs unpruned, weeds encroaching on herbs and flowers. We learned from our former housekeeper that Bailey and Jules had broken up. Then he wrote us a different kind of letter, still grandiloquent, but painfully vulnerable as well: ‘Dear John, A chara’ - Gaelic for ‘friend’ - ‘It is under very sad and tragic circumstances I write to you and it is difficult to know where to start. On 2 May, Jules and myself were coming back from a party - I was driving and an argument broke out. It ended in a fight - we had both been drinking and were very tired. I unintentional [sic] hurt Jules, and her daughter called the guards... [I]t’s all quite awful - Jules is deeply upset - neither of us in spite of what has happened want to part and I love her stronger than ever... Please don’t think to [sic] badly of me. I never intended to hurt hurt [sic] - it was the drink and I am now resolved to abstinence.’

fields.bodyText: ‘There is a devil somewhere in the hills of southern Ireland,’ the film producer Daniel Toscan du Plantier wailed in the pages of Le Figaro. He was speaking of West Cork, the part of Ireland where I live, in a 19th-century farmhouse in the luminous shadow of Mount Gabriel - where, legend has it, the last wolf in Ireland was killed. The devil he was referring to had murdered du Plantier’s 39-year-old wife, Sophie, on a moonlit night just before Christmas 1996. It was the first murder in these remote parts since Civil War days, when Michael Collins was killed in Beal na Blath, the Gap of the Blossoms, a few miles inland. I had spent the days before that Christmas with my companion, the novelist Elizabeth Wassell - who helped to research and write this article - at the Literary Forum in Okinawa, an elongated, serrated island that regards its larger neighbour with much the same ambivalence as Ireland does England. We had gone there from Tokyo, where I had been granted an audience with the Empress. Irish poets vie for the longest meeting with her, and I had out-talked Seamus Heaney by a good 30 minutes. But my contentment waned on the flight home, when I read news of the murder and realised we were heading back into turbulence. Cork is the largest county in Ireland, and West Cork, the scene of the crime, is its most ruggedly beautiful part, with its shipwrecking seas and its bony mountains clothed in heather and gorse. Its centre is the town of Skibbereen, beyond which gleam the seaside villages of Schull, Goleen, and Crookhaven. Roaringwater Bay is necklaced with islands, and three finger peninsulas - Mizen Head, Sheep’s Head, and Beara - jut into the often wild Atlantic. Although this region is historically insular (electricity wasn’t introduced here until 1954), over the past two decades expatriates and artists have begun to pour in. The Heinz and newspaper magnate Tony O’Reilly, Jeremy Irons and Sinead Cusack, and David Puttnam all have summer houses in West Cork. Elizabeth Hurley and Hugh Grant were beaten to the house of their choice by a rock band. Even Tony Blair has spent holidays here, and the region has become known as ‘the Irish Riviera’. At the other end of the spectrum are the unemployed, an invading army, since, under the terms of the European Union, anyone with a European passport can settle in Ireland and draw the dole. West Cork has become a Mecca for the eccentric, the lost children of Europe. Many - such as the New Age hippies of Coole Mountain, a commune of several hundred families whose pot-smoking disturbs the gardaí - are in flight from over-industrialised European centres. One year, they descended on our village to enact a Dionysiac summer-solstice ceremony, burning a giant effigy and dancing to the beat of tasselled tambourines. Still, despite a recent slight increase in petty larceny, the savage murder of Sophie Toscan du Plantier was the first incidence of serious violence in the area, and the first crime to have international implications. In the ensuing criminal investigation, two jurisdictions and legal systems have collided, provoking debates in the Irish parliament and creating an uproar in the British and French media. Sophie Bouniol had met Daniel Toscan du Plantier in 1990, when she was 33 and he was 49. She soon became du Plantier’s third wife. The head of the French Academy of Cinema Arts and a close friend of President Jacques Chirac, du Plantier also ran a film-production company, the projects of which included Peter Greenaway’s The Cook, the Thief, His Wife & Her Lover, and he had been made a Chevalier of the Légion d’Honneur, France’s highest cultural honour, that year. Sophie had the delicate, slightly unconventional style of a Left Bank Parisienne and the birdlike elegance of Mimou. When du Plantier met her, she wanted to act; he convinced her to try a new career as a documentary producer and scriptwriter, for the cultural Channel Arte, with which he was connected. Sophie also had a romanticised image of the Irish countryside, which she had visited briefly in her youth. In 1993, du Plantier bought a bulky five-bedroom house in Schull, which would serve as Sophie’s refuge from her high-profile life in France. She was often photographed at her husband’s side at media events, but she also slipped away to Ireland four or five times a year. Occasionally she would bring someone with her - her teenage son from her first marriage, or another member of her family - but du Plantier joined her only once, and she was listed in the local telephone directory under her maiden name. Among the locals, she had a reputation as something of a loner. For a while she even feuded with her nearest neighbour over a shared gate that she felt should stay closed. On Friday, 20 December 1996, Sophie landed at Cork Airport (the security video shows her trundling a surprising amount of luggage) and drove to her house along the winding coast road in a rented Ford Fiesta. She chatted briefly with Denis Quinlan at the Courtyard Bar, in Schull, and with Tom Brosnan, the jovial owner of the Spar supermarket, both of whom she knew well. Over the weekend she visited many of her local haunts, including O’Sullivan’s Pub, on the quayside in Crookhaven, a village that has recently become so popular with visiting French yachtsmen that it’s known as ‘little Saint-Tropez’. She also went for a walk on bleak Three Castle Head and called on some friends, with whom she had a strange, melancholy conversation. She said that, while walking, she had come upon the ruins of Dun Lough - or Black Lake - Castle, and had sensed some kind of menace. According to legend, the lake next to the castle is home to a female ghost who, if glimpsed, is supposed to be a harbinger of death. Afterwards, Sophie decided to return to Paris on 24 December, a few days earlier than she’d originally intended. That Sunday, she called her husband at 11pm and had what he recalls was a ‘convivial’ conversation. At 10 o’clock the next morning, a neighbour found Sophie’s body in the lane leading to her house. She was wearing a nightshirt, leggings, and high, brown lace-up boots, and had been bludgeoned more than a dozen times with a weapon like a poker or possibly a hatchet. A large stone or concrete building block had been dropped on her head, crushing her skull. There was evidence of a struggle. Sophie was a small woman - only 5ft tall - but she had clearly put up a fight: there was blood under her fingernails and she was clutching a clump of hair. Neighbours reported having heard wild cries in the night, which they had assumed were the yowls of mating foxes. Yet no murder weapon was found, Sophie’s house seemed untouched, and there was no indication of sexual assault. It was said that there were two rinsed wineglasses by the kitchen sink (a local garda told us later that this was ‘a bit of a myth’) and two chairs drawn up to the radiator. It had been a frosty night and, by the time the state pathologist arrived, 24 hours later - having driven the 230 miles from Dublin - rigor mortis had set in and it was too late to determine the time of Sophie’s death. The story broke in the Irish papers, with many of the details provided first by a local freelance journalist named Ian Bailey, who was working as a stringer for the Cork Examiner and had been one of the first reporters on the scene. But, days later, a rumour began that a woman who’d been walking home from her lover’s house at dawn on the night of the murder said she had spotted a man who resembled Bailey washing his boots in a stream. Others noticed cuts and scratches on his head and hands (which he said he’d got from killing Christmas turkeys and cutting down an aggressive Christmas tree). There was also a rumour that he’d been seen burning clothes on the morning after the murder. Seven weeks later, the gardaí arrested Bailey and his Welsh girlfriend, Jules Thomas. We knew Bailey, though he had been living in the area for only five years. Born in 1956, the son of a butcher, Bailey had grown up in Gloucestershire, where he attended the Crypt Grammar School and later played for Gloucester’s Old Cryptians rugby club. His size and strength made him an ideal second-row forward. He started working for the Gloucester & County News Service in 1975. In his reporting, Bailey specialised in espionage stories and gave a lot of ink to GCHQ - the intelligence agency in nearby Cheltenham. A journalist who worked closely with Bailey at the time remembers how ‘he talked big. He was always bursting with ideas for making his fame and fortune.’ In 1980, Bailey married another journalist, but the marriage soon ended in a divorce that he describes as ‘acrimonious’, and that the various newspaper accounts called ‘sordid’ and ‘bitter’. In 1991, after brief stints in London and in the United States, Bailey settled in West Cork. We first met him one night in the winter of 1994. After a lecture at the West Cork Arts Centre, Elizabeth and I stopped in a Ballydehob pub. Next to us at the bar was a tall, striking man in his late thirties, with long dark hair, black eyebrows, and a snaggle-toothed grin. He introduced himself in a crisp English accent and gave us his card, which identified him as ‘Eoin Bailey’. He mentioned his interest in gardening, and we phoned him soon afterwards to ask whether we could hire him to take care of our garden, as we were often travelling and unable to do it ourselves. He agreed. Frequently, as he bustled around in the garden (and what a peculiar historical satisfaction it was for an Irishman to gaze out the window at his English servant), we would notice that he had hurt himself with a scythe or a sickle - a clumsiness we found surprising in someone who was otherwise so athletic. (Elizabeth speculated that he might have an übermensch complex. I thought he was just awkward.) Once, we had to find Mercurochrome and bandages to staunch the blood. Bailey also smoked heavily, and I can hardly think of him without seeing his eyes narrowed against the smoke of his hand-rolled cigarette. After he had been working for us for almost a year, Bailey showed me his collected works - scraps of songs and poem-ballads - and I encouraged him in his writing. There was a glimmer of talent there, but it needed a level of discipline which he seemed unprepared to give. He had made a minor reputation for himself, reciting poetry and banging the bodhran - an Irish goatskin drum - at O’Sullivan’s Pub, in Ballydehob, and he seemed to prefer the gratifications of the pub’s indulgent audience to the tedious, concentrated work of a serious writer. At the annual Irish Seanachie - a storytelling festival - on Cape Clear Island, Ian Bailey transformed himself into Eoin Bailey or, sometimes, O’Baille. As he described it in one poem, ‘The tall Eoin Bailey, he chipped in his bit,/with his poems on life he proved a big hit.’ On one occasion, he borrowed a typewriter that had been gathering dust in our house since we’d switched to computers. I worried later that I might have lent my typewriter to Raskolnikov, but I felt a vaguely paternal affection for Bailey back then, and saw him as an older version of the troubled young men I had dealt with as a teacher. Above all, I saw him as a victim of the English class system, a butcher’s son educated at a ‘good’ grammar school where he learned to read Latin but lost his social moorings, who craved acceptance in the more bohemian society of West Cork. My Collected Poems were published in the autumn of 1995, and Bailey came to a reading in Cork, an occasion that was somewhat eclipsed by torrential rain. After the reading, there was a launch party, where Bailey mingled easily with the assembled literati in a round room overlooking the River Lee, the setting of Spenser’s ‘Epithalamion’. That Christmas, Bailey and Jules Thomas invited us to dinner in their remote farmhouse, which stands on an expanse of rugged land called Lioscaha (‘the Fairy Fort’), in a region affectionately known as the Prairie. It was a cold night, the sky black and starless, but they welcomed us enthusiastically. Jules put a homemade pâté on their big wooden dining table, alongside chunks of toasted and buttered home-baked bread. A handsome woman in her late forties, Jules is a painter of land- and seascapes, which are conventional but skillful in their composition. She has lived in West Cork for more than 20 years and her love life has been mildly untraditional, but eccentric behaviour is generally tolerated here, at least among the expatriates. Her three daughters joined us at dinner. The middle daughter is a fledgling artist and she showed us her portfolio. The 18-year-old was warm and courteous, but we sensed an unease between her and Bailey. During dinner, the youngest daughter complained that the Christmas tree had not yet been brought into the house. At first, Bailey placated her with an indulgent smile and continued eating, but when she persisted he got up abruptly, left the house, then lumbered back in with a large tree shivering under his arm, scattering needles across the floor. Bailey continued to work for us through that winter and the following spring. He started leaving us little notes, addressed with whimsical grandiloquence, ‘To the Bard, John, and the Lady, Elizabeth,’ usually on the subject of our lush garden: ‘I came up on Thursday, the only dry day of the week - I gave the grass a thrashing.’ When we were away in March, we received a St Patrick’s Day card in which he reported: ‘You lost a couple of branches in the storms - but nothing you would notice.’ It was obvious, though, when we returned a few weeks later, that the garden had been neglected - the grass was tangled and knee-high, the boughs unpruned, weeds encroaching on herbs and flowers. We learned from our former housekeeper that Bailey and Jules had broken up. Then he wrote us a different kind of letter, still grandiloquent, but painfully vulnerable as well: ‘Dear John, A chara’ - Gaelic for ‘friend’ - ‘It is under very sad and tragic circumstances I write to you and it is difficult to know where to start. On 2 May, Jules and myself were coming back from a party - I was driving and an argument broke out. It ended in a fight - we had both been drinking and were very tired. I unintentional [sic] hurt Jules, and her daughter called the guards... [I]t’s all quite awful - Jules is deeply upset - neither of us in spite of what has happened want to part and I love her stronger than ever... Please don’t think to [sic] badly of me. I never intended to hurt hurt [sic] - it was the drink and I am now resolved to abstinence.’ Jules was indeed hurt. fields.headline: Heal thyself
fields.standfirst: Chang-Rae Lee's A Gesture Life is a beautiful, sad and gently hopeful novel, entwining the horrors of war with the blandness of the everyday
fields.trailText: The novel is punctuated by death and loss, the inevitable experiences of those who have lived long and watched their worlds changing around them. Chang Rae Lee, Korean-born, mentions in his acknowledgements that he has interviewed surviving "comfort women", and there is a painful accuracy in these wartime accounts that bears the stamp of experience.
fields.body:
A Gesture Life

by Chang-Rae Lee

Granta, £16.99, pp356

The title is a charge levelled at the novel's narrator by his daughter: "You make a whole life out of gestures and politeness," she tells him. Franklin Hata, known as "Doc", is respected and liked by everyone in Bedley Run, the small, affluent suburban town where he has lived since leaving his native Japan as a young man.

Doc is in his 70s when his narrative begins, and has recently retired from running the town's medical supply store. His time is taken up now with swimming, walking and taking a keen, if not altogether welcome, interest in the way the young city couple who have taken over the shop are managing it. Sunny, his adopted Korean daughter, has left home long before; her palpable absence, and the fresh memories Doc carries of her, haunt the slow tread of his retirement days. "It was during Sunny's absence," he says, "that I finally awoke to this notion that I was perfectly suited to my town, that I had steadily become, oddly and unofficially, its primary citizen, the living, breathing expression of what people here wanted - privacy and decorum and the quietude of hard-earned privilege."

After an accidental fire at his home, Doc finds himself in hospital, left to turn his thoughts in on themselves, first to Sunny's arrival and her sullen and rebellious youth, and then to his memories of his time in Burma during the Second World War. As these images of war begin to resurface, Doc's reserve and protective shell of courtesy and civic decorum becomes easier to understand. As a medical officer in the Japanese army, Doc, or Jiro Kurohata as his name then was, took responsibility for the welfare and health of the "comfort women" sent over to serve the troops.

The girls were young and frequently brutalised; Doc, with characteristic self-restraint, did not himself visit the comfort house, but there is one girl who stands out to him, not only for her beauty but also for her quiet dignity. She is a high-born Korean, named K, and discerns that Doc, too, is Korean by birth. He falls in love with her, believing that they will marry after the war, but his love is naive and she sees, as he does not, that her life was over the moment she arrived at the outpost.

Gradually, Sunny and K begin to parallel one another in Doc's memories - both Korean orphans, both beautiful, proud and unwilling to accept his guardianship. Entangled with them are thoughts of another woman, Mary Burns, a widow with whom Doc had a tentative relationship when Sunny was a child. Released from hospital, he is troubled by a growing awareness of his age and a sense of restlessness. Beneath the quiet, measured prose, there is a keenly felt yearning for something that was never quite achieved with any of the women in his life.

The novel is punctuated by death and loss, the inevitable experiences of those who have lived long and watched their worlds changing around them. Chang Rae Lee, Korean-born, mentions in his acknowledgements that he has interviewed surviving comfort women, and there is a painful accuracy in these wartime accounts that bears the stamp of experience. Most affecting is his portrait of a complex family relationship: a man's craving for another chance to protect an innocent young girl, having failed the first time; the tension of affection and resistance in a girl's feelings for her adoptive father.

This is a beautiful, sad and gently hopeful novel, carefully exploring the range of human emotion between the depths of suffering and the blandest normality of the everyday.

webTitle: The West is not necessarily best

fields.headline: The West is not necessarily best
fields.trailText: I sympathise with much of what Polly Toynbee says about the need to fight for progressive liberal values globally and to avoid reactionary romanticisation of non-Western cultures (Comment, last week).
fields.body:
I sympathise with much of what Polly Toynbee says about the need to fight for progressive liberal values globally and to avoid reactionary romanticisation of non-Western cultures (Comment, last week). She is guilty, however, of creating a false impression that Western culture uniformly matches her liberal picture and of unnecessarily polarising the debate in terms of the West vs. the Rest.

There is an unfinished battle in 'the West' between progressive liberalism and traditionalist conservatism. Some liberal features of 'the West' are relatively recent achievements, secured often against much opposition: basic women's and gay rights - even the universal franchise.

And there are features of 'the West' whose export we are right to oppose. They include (to offer just a few examples) the gun culture, prison regime and plutocratic politics of the US, overproduction of greenhouse gases, nuclear weapons and unaccountable corporate power.
Dr Daryl Glaser
Department of Government
University of Strathclyde

 The West's persistent argument that its version of human rights are better than other cultures is weak. The West has appalling social problems and many of these can be attributed to the high divorce rate. Ms Toynbee advocates the virtues of divorce while ignoring the adverse consequences. Ms Toynbee is also expressing the virtues of selfishness with no concern for social cohesion. That is a typical Western vice. If the debate on human rights is to progress at all, and it should, then the West must listen to the views of Asian leaders and others, and not assume that the West should hold a monopoly of opinions on this important issue.
Gavin Staples
Cambridge

fields.headline: We're not 'guilty' for not fighting
fields.trailText: Americans of my generation who reached adulthood in the 1960s may feel guilty about not 'serving' in Vietnam, but Geoffrey Wheatcroft (Comment, last week) gets the reasons wrong.
fields.body:
Americans of my generation who reached adulthood in the 1960s may feel guilty about not 'serving' in Vietnam, but Geoffrey Wheatcroft (Comment, last week) gets the reasons wrong.

Our guilt is not that we did not go, but that others did, to fight an unjust, immoral, dirty war on behalf of a predatory dictatorship, against a people fighting for many decades for national liberation against first French imperialism and then American Cold War interventionism.

The very refusal to participate helped undermine the Cold War mentality in the United States and shaped the so-called 'Vietnam Syndrome' or 'body-bag effect' which still today acts as a serious constraint on the misuse of American power in many parts of the world.
Philip G. Cerny
Professor of International Politics
University of Leeds

 Geoffrey Wheatcroft says McCain 'served and suffered' in Vietnam! What was he doing there in the first place? Killing children, burning villages, torturing an ancient and proud people who had dared to defy the American way. Let us be thankful for every draft-dodger. They dodged their draft for their own selfish ends but for every single dodger there were fewer Vietnamese children killed.
Dr A Chatterjee
London E9

fields.headline: Wyner answers harrassing Keiller
fields.trailText: I feel dreadfully misrepresented by Dr D.H. Keiller (Letters, last week) who has been manning a hate campaign against me since I submitted plans for Wintercomfort to set up a housing and rehabilitation project for homeless people in Cambridge, not far from where he lives.
fields.body:
I feel dreadfully misrepresented by Dr D.H. Keiller (Letters, last week) who has been manning a hate campaign against me since I submitted plans for Wintercomfort to set up a housing and rehabilitation project for homeless people in Cambridge, not far from where he lives. Police objected to this project but were over-ruled by Cambridge's planning committee.

Drug dealers were never given 'carte blanche' at our day centre in Cambridge and that was not stated at my trial. Some people did come from 'miles around', but it is the only homelessness day centre for miles around. One of the eight convicted drug dealers apparently had an old BMW but we never saw it.

It is not true that I 'did nothing'. When heroin became more apparent in the homeless population I strengthened our drugs policies, liaised (so I thought) with the police, banned drug use on site and suspected dealing, and I spoke in the local press, at meetings and at local and national conferences about the problem.

In 1993 I did lose my job as deputy director of St Martin's Housing Trust in Norwich (the pay was £17,000 a year, not £20,000). So did many others: the chair resigned, and the director, four managers and around six staff were forced out.

I was accused of allowing one person to smoke cannabis in her room. I've always denied this and there were no police charges. Subsequently I was employed as co-ordinator of the Herring House Trust in Great Yarmouth, whose trustees were aware of the Norwich situation, as were the Charity Commissioners. In one year, I set up a hostel and move-on housing for the homeless in Yarmouth. In 1995 I went to Cambridge.

My defence team were keen for the trial to be held in Cambridge. It was the prosecutor who chose King's Lynn, which, I'm told, has the highest conviction rate of any Crown court in the country. As for confidentiality, this policy was approved by the Wintercomfort trustees. I was asked by police for the names in the day centre banned book, for drug use as well as dealing. I and others refused. We were not told keeping to confidentiality was a crime.
Ruth Wyner, Prisoner EH6524
HMP Highpoint
Newmarket
Suffolk

Keiller (Letters, last week) who has been manning a hate campaign against me since I submitted plans for Wintercomfort to set up a housing and rehabilitation project for homeless people in Cambridge, not far from where he lives. Police objected to this project but were over-ruled by Cambridge's planning committee. Drug dealers were never given 'carte blanche' at our day centre in Cambridge and that was not stated at my trial. Some people did come from 'miles around', but it is the only homelessness day centre for miles around. One of the eight convicted drug dealers apparently had an old BMW but we never saw it. It is not true that I 'did nothing'. When heroin became more apparent in the homeless population I strengthened our drugs policies, liaised (so I thought) with the police, banned drug use on site and suspected dealing, and I spoke in the local press, at meetings and at local and national conferences about the problem. In 1993 I did lose my job as deputy director of St Martin's Housing Trust in Norwich (the pay was £17,000 a year, not £20,000). So did many others: the chair resigned, and the director, four managers and around six staff were forced out. I was accused of allowing one person to smoke cannabis in her room. I've always denied this and there were no police charges. Subsequently I was employed as co-ordinator of the Herring House Trust in Great Yarmouth, whose trustees were aware of the Norwich situation, as were the Charity Commissioners. In one year, I set up a hostel and move-on housing for the homeless in Yarmouth. In 1995 I went to Cambridge. My defence team were keen for the trial to be held in Cambridge. It was the prosecutor who chose King's Lynn, which, I'm told, has the highest conviction rate of any Crown court in the country. As for confidentiality, this policy was approved by the Wintercomfort trustees. I was asked by police for the names in the day centre banned book, for drug use as well as dealing. I and others refused. We were not told keeping to confidentiality was a crime. Ruth Wyner, Prisoner EH6524 HMP Highpoint Newmarket Suffolk

fields.headline: Drugs alert
fields.trailText: While it is true, as Nigella Lawson writes (Comment, last week) that the chemical and biological laws which determine how our bodies deal with prescription drugs   are precisely the same as those applying to herbal medicine, there are important differences.
fields.body:
While it is true, as Nigella Lawson writes (Comment, last week) that the chemical and biological laws which determine how our bodies deal with prescription drugs are precisely the same as those applying to herbal medicine, there are important differences.

The most important is that there is a huge difference between a chemical, single molecule delivered by a drug and the complex of active ingredients delivered by a whole plant.

Ms Lawson is being disingenuous with her blind faith in the 'scientific' testing of drugs: if it is so, how come there are some 106,000 deaths from adverse drug reactions in the US alone?
Giovanni Maciocia
Amersham
Bucks

fields.headline: Class conscience
fields.trailText: Kate Hoey's remarks about teachers in state-maintained schools following the example of colleagues in fee-paying schools (Sport, last week) are outrageous.
fields.body:
Kate Hoey's remarks about teachers in state-maintained schools following the example of colleagues in fee-paying schools (Sport, last week) are outrageous.

It is simply not true that commitment by teachers in state schools to extra-curricular activities has 'gone'. There are countless examples of schools where sport, music, drama, visits and so forth thrive because of this commitment. It is insulting to thousands of dedicated teachers to imply they no longer provide this service.

It is inappropriate for a Labour Minister to berate teachers providing a public service with examples from exclusive private schools which, if nothing else, pay their staff more and have facilities and resources most state schools can only dream about.
Alan Manasseh
Professional Association of Teachers
Derby

fields.headline: Prime crime
fields.trailText: George Steiner, in his review of  Uncle Petros and Goldbach's Conjecture  (Books, last week), speaks of 'the luminous insight that all numbers of the form 2 2 n +1 are prime numbers'. This conjecture of Fermat's was disproved more than 300 years ago.
fields.body:
George Steiner, in his review of Uncle Petros and Goldbach's Conjecture (Books, last week), speaks of 'the luminous insight that all numbers of the form 2 2 n +1 are prime numbers'. This conjecture of Fermat's was disproved more than 300 years ago. In fact it is true only for values of n between 0 and 4. Mr Steiner also states: '4 is indeed the sum of 1+3'. While this is true, it unfortunately has no bearing on Goldbach's conjecture, since 1 is not a prime number.
Peter Bendall
Cambridge

fields.headline: Pinochet shame
fields.trailText: The conspiracy, coming to light (Focus, last week), that brought about the freedom of Pinochet denigrates the status of the three governments who took part in it. Where are the wheelchair, the trembling hands, the absence of memory and difficulty to acknowledge what is being said and done?

Baltasar Garzon, the Spanish judge who prosecuted the case, although his government impeded him in every conceivable way, will be remembered for as long as justice is sought to be brought to the world. For the first time in my life, although a Socialist for 50 years, I am ashamed of being British.
Ernest Fraser-Finnie
Alicante
Spain

fields.headline: Chin and bare it
fields.trailText: Millbank spin doctors are right. Of course, Frank Dobson should shave off his beard. The white whiskers, even in their latest Versailles-trimmed manifestation, are an electoral disaster. Women hate beards and always have done - whether pointy and fey, sculpted and urbane, or Ruskinian freestyle. When women look at Frank Dobson or Robin Cook, they see a man hiding behind fuzz, concealing not just a weak chin and a timorous mouth but probably the remains of dinner as well. Above all, they wince and feel sorry for Gaynor and Janet and agree with Shakespeare's Beatrice that they would rather 'lie in the woollen' than endure a husband with a beard.

Hairy faces make babies cry at hustings. They irritate other men by revealing more than they wish to know about the wearer's testosterone levels. At the eleventh hour, Labour's spin doctors have come to recognise that victory will never be theirs while Frank holds resolutely to beard and principles. Both must go. Ken Livingstone has done excellently without either and will have been laughing into his shaving mirror every morning. Our only hesitation in pressing the case for a close shave any further is a strange foreboding that the beard might be concealing something far worse.

webTitle: A child's interests must come first

fields.headline: A child's interests must come first
fields.trailText: Aiming to shock and startle, the poet Philip Larkin wrote memorably in 1974: 'They fuck you up, your mum and dad./ They may not mean to, but they do.' And he finished: 'Man hands on misery to man./ It deepens like a coastal shelf./ Get out as early as you can,/ And don't have any kids yourself.'
fields.body:
Aiming to shock and startle, the poet Philip Larkin wrote memorably in 1974: 'They fuck you up, your mum and dad./ They may not mean to, but they do.' And he finished: 'Man hands on misery to man./ It deepens like a coastal shelf./ Get out as early as you can,/ And don't have any kids yourself.'

In the trial we report today, three Brighton children were more than psychologically scarred by their parents. They died while in their custody, even though the necessary operation of the law means that it has been impossible to prove that the parents were the murderers. It is a salutary reminder that the conventional family is not always a place of love and nurture.

However, the wisdom of the last 20 years has been to promote the sanctity of the natural family in every circumstance. The 1989 Children Act moved the emphasis away from intervention in families to working with them, to keeping children with their natural parents whenever possible. Family is best. Family is sovereign. But families can also be dark, constricting institutions, as much a source of pain as joy.

In the case we report today, there is no doubt that Brighton social services recognised that there were severe problems. More than 230 visits were made in five years. A prosecution was attempted but blocked by the Crown Prosecution Service. They tried hard to work with the family, as the Children Act said they should. But in this case, the Act created as many problems as it solved. As Allan Bowman, chairman of the local Area Child Protection Committee said, sometimes the law does not reflect realities on the ground.

The Children Act cannot be the last word on the issue. However much we might deplore the intervention of the state into the family, the ultimate symbol of the private in our society, we must enter into a debate about where the balance lies between privacy and child safety. It cannot be assumed that natural parents will naturally want the best, or be the best, for their child.

The Government is showing some signs in recognising that over adoption, for instance, the interests of the natural parents wrongfully and sometimes harmfully take precedence over the interests of the child. Even in cases of wilful neglect and abuse, when a child has had to be taken into care, social services are unable to make long-term fostering and adoption arrangements for a child if the natural mother refuses consent. The result is that at a critical time in a young child's life, he or she is refused the security and love of potential long-term adopters, with possibly disastrous consequences.

The Government wants to remedy this defect in adoption law, but the approach needs to be more generalised. We need to recognise that while long-term care institutions have had a disastrous record, it does not follow that natural families are sources of harmony and love. They can be abusive, even murderous, as well.

fields.headline: Blunkett's crisis
fields.trailText: It has been a disastrous week for the education policies of New Labour. On Wednesday, the  Guardian, revealed how this administration's much vaunted extra £19 billion was a piece of false accounting. Then came the news that Torsten Friedag, the first of Education Secretary David Blunkett's corps of new 'superheads' designed to take on failing schools, had resigned. Last night Mr Blunkett's humiliation was complete. Following accusations that the Government had fixed Ripon's parental ballot on whether to keep its grammar school and 11-plus selection, a spokesmen for Mr Blunkett let it be known that, when he had promised 'read my lips: no selection either by examination or by interview', he was confused. What he really meant was 'no further selection'. He said he meant it as a joke.
fields.body:
It has been a disastrous week for the education policies of New Labour. On Wednesday, the Guardian, revealed how this administration's much vaunted extra £19 billion was a piece of false accounting. Then came the news that Torsten Friedag, the first of Education Secretary David Blunkett's corps of new 'superheads' designed to take on failing schools, had resigned. Last night Mr Blunkett's humiliation was complete. Following accusations that the Government had fixed Ripon's parental ballot on whether to keep its grammar school and 11-plus selection, a spokesmen for Mr Blunkett let it be known that, when he had promised 'read my lips: no selection either by examination or by interview', he was confused. What he really meant was 'no further selection'. He said he meant it as a joke.

The present chaos over education is doubly embarrassing for a Prime Minister who promised that his three priorities were 'education, education, education'. Few now will be prepared to buy Mr Blunkett's excuses or explanations. Instead they will judge rightly what little regard this Government appears to attach to either those who voted for it or to whatever principles that it still lays claim to.

It is time for New Labour to deliver on its promises. What is needed is not slick explanations, excuses and funny accounting, but a real mobilisation of financial resources and commitment. The per-capita spend in education has barely risen under Labour. Numbers of teachers need to be doubled to bring the staff/pupil ratio in line with that in private education. The Government too must accept that its key education policies, like that of introducing superheads such as Mr Friedag, are out of step with economic and social realities. Even the best head can make little impact in areas with deep social problems. Mr Blunkett must realise no one is laughing.

fields.headline: Class warfare
fields.trailText: The remedy for state education, runs the New Labour mantra, is to end selection and to empower a cadre of highly-paid super-headteachers to turn round failing schools. Money, says Labour, is not the issue; nor private schools; nor socio-economic conditions of the catchment areas from which schools draw their pupils. Inequality, poverty and underfunding do not excuse failure; good headmasters are what is needed.
fields.body:
The remedy for state education, runs the New Labour mantra, is to end selection and to empower a cadre of highly-paid super-headteachers to turn round failing schools. Money, says Labour, is not the issue; nor private schools; nor socio-economic conditions of the catchment areas from which schools draw their pupils. Inequality, poverty and underfunding do not excuse failure; good headmasters are what is needed.

The resignation of Torsten Friedag as the superhead of the troubled George Orwell school in Islington is a salutary reminder of just how far removed the Government's education policies are from economic and social reality. Superheads cannot alone around turn the tide of pupil delinquency when it is rooted in dysfunctional families and abysmal social conditions. Middle-class parents know that very well - hence their growing preference for educating their children privately or at the handful of state selective schools.

We need a mobilisation of financial resources, which is precisely what is not happening. Per-capita spend has scarcely risen under New Labour; numbers of teachers need to be doubled to bring the staff/pupil ratio in line with private schools. For progress in a school such as George Orwell, staff-pupil ratios need to be lower than private counterparts, and the per-student spend higher.

Conservative Ministers educated their children privately so had little interest in addressing the disenchantment of the British middle class with state schools. New Labour is different, although Chancellor Gordon Brown has no children and thus no direct experience of the chronic neglect of British schools. Is this the reason he has colluded in the duplicitous presentation of underfunding as a gigantic spending increase? There are those at Number 10 who think so. We begin to agree.

webTitle: Hunt on for missing gas blast boss

fields.headline: Hunt on for missing gas blast boss
fields.standfirst: Union Carbide's boss cannot be found as victims of the 1984 Bhopal disaster continue their fight for justice
fields.trailText: Union Carbide's boss cannot be found as victims of the 1984 Bhopal disaster continue their fight for justice
fields.body:
It has been a slow news week at the Vero Beach Press Journal. It usually is. Little troubles the thousands of retired couples who have chosen to spend their golden years walking along the east Florida resort's palm-lined beaches or enjoying the famous Champagne Brunch at P.V. Martin's Elegant Oceanside Restaurant.

One story the journal hasn't covered is the recent mys terious disappearance of one local resident: Warren S. Anderson, of 1111 South Catalina Court. Though his absence has gone largely unnoticed in Vero Beach, it has provoked fury in a steaming, stinking city in India. Anderson was chief executive officer of the Union Carbide chemicals factory in Bhopal which exploded in 1984, killing up to 13,000 people.

When, earlier this month, lawyers arrived at the Florida address where Anderson has lived since retiring from Union Carbide 12 years ago they found the house empty. And New York's finest private investigators have so far been unable to track him down.

The lawyers, who hoped to serve a summons on Anderson to appear in a Manhattan courtroom, were acting on behalf of a coalition of Bhopal victims' groups who have launched a new legal action against the former chief executive and a host of senior Union Carbide executives. In a suit brought in a Manhattan court at the end of last year they claim that Anderson ought to be punished for his role in the Bhopal disaster.

'We want to get him before he dies,' said Satinath Sarangi of the Bhopal Group for Information and Action, one of those who is behind the new legal action. Sarangi and a dozen others have put their names to an 85-page complaint that alleges that Anderson and Union Carbide 'demonstrated a reckless and depraved indifference to human life' in violation of international law.

The complaint describes how at around midnight on 2 December 1984 a massive leak of lethal methyl isocyanate and other toxic chemicals, used for making insecticides, spilt out from storage tank number 610 of the Union Carbide plant and blanketed the city for miles around with a deadly white fog. Thousands were killed instantly from exposure to the gas as they slept or fled through the narrow alleys of the residential areas surrounding the plant. Hundreds of thousands more were maimed and have been badly disabled ever since.

Mass burials and cremations following the incident mean the estimates of the number of dead vary widely, but official Indian government figures suggest that at least 1,700 died in the 48 hours following the leak. Unofficial estimates indicate at least 6,000 fatalities in the days immediately after the disaster and an Indian court has accepted claims that the final death toll exceeded 13,000.

One of the victims listed on the complaint, Sajjida Bano, describes how, having lost her husband to a previous gas leak at the plant in 1981, she watched her son drowning in his own bodily fluids after the disaster three years later. Bano herself was affected by the leak and is still badly disabled. Another victim de-scribes watching his parents and five brothers and sisters choke to death. Several eyewitnesses, quoted in the complaint, described scenes of terror and confusion as Bhopal residents tried to flee the lethal gas. 'The railway station was a charnel house,' said one victim last week.

Union Carbide, which had sales of $5.9 billion last year, says that all claims were settled with a $420 million payment made to victims or their relatives and the Bhopal city government in 1989. Campaigners say that this merely settled Union Carbide's civil liability and that Anderson and his fellow officers are all also guilty of 'culpable homicide' or manslaughter.

Sarangi, and other campaigners, claim that much of the compensation was funded by insurance companies and that the 'real culprits' have never been made to pay. 'If the people who do this don't suffer themselves, there is no reason for them - or other big companies - to make sure it doesn't happen again.'

Union Carbide has claimed that the gas leak was caused by a saboteur. However, the complaint claims that sloppy management was responsible. The campaigners say that Union Carbide enforced different 'racially discriminatory' standards of safety on their US and Indian plants respectively.

Though a computerised safety system was installed on the company's plants in the US, there was none in Bhopal and, the complaint alleges, new safety procedures implemented at plants in West Virginia were ignored. Also, it says, sirens in the Bhopal plant were turned off to avoid causing 'undue panic' among the local population over 'routine minor leaks'.

Abdul Jabbar, who heads a gas victims' women organisation, has written an open letter to US President Bill Clinton, who will be visiting in ten days, demanding Anderson's extradition. He will be leading a series of rallies in New Delhi in the days before Clinton's arrival.

The Indian government is still pursuing a criminal case against Indian staff of the plant and nine locally recruited executives are currently in custody.'

Sarangi and a dozen others have put their names to an 85-page complaint that alleges that Anderson and Union Carbide 'demonstrated a reckless and depraved indifference to human life' in violation of international law. The complaint describes how at around midnight on 2 December 1984 a massive leak of lethal methyl isocyanate and other toxic chemicals, used for making insecticides, spilt out from storage tank number 610 of the Union Carbide plant and blanketed the city for miles around with a deadly white fog. Thousands were killed instantly from exposure to the gas as they slept or fled through the narrow alleys of the residential areas surrounding the plant. Hundreds of thousands more were maimed and have been badly disabled ever since. Mass burials and cremations following the incident mean the estimates of the number of dead vary widely, but official Indian government figures suggest that at least 1,700 died in the 48 hours following the leak. Unofficial estimates indicate at least 6,000 fatalities in the days immediately after the disaster and an Indian court has accepted claims that the final death toll exceeded 13,000. One of the victims listed on the complaint, Sajjida Bano, describes how, having lost her husband to a previous gas leak at the plant in 1981, she watched her son drowning in his own bodily fluids after the disaster three years later. Bano herself was affected by the leak and is still badly disabled. Another victim de-scribes watching his parents and five brothers and sisters choke to death. Several eyewitnesses, quoted in the complaint, described scenes of terror and confusion as Bhopal residents tried to flee the lethal gas. 'The railway station was a charnel house,' said one victim last week. Union Carbide, which had sales of $5.9 billion last year, says that all claims were settled with a $420 million payment made to victims or their relatives and the Bhopal city government in 1989. Campaigners say that this merely settled Union Carbide's civil liability and that Anderson and his fellow officers are all also guilty of 'culpable homicide' or manslaughter. Sarangi, and other campaigners, claim that much of the compensation was funded by insurance companies and that the 'real culprits' have never been made to pay. 'If the people who do this don't suffer themselves, there is no reason for them - or other big companies - to make sure it doesn't happen again.' Union Carbide has claimed that the gas leak was caused by a saboteur. However, the complaint claims that sloppy management was responsible. The campaigners say that Union Carbide enforced different 'racially discriminatory' standards of safety on their US and Indian plants respectively. Though a computerised safety system was installed on the company's plants in the US, there was none in Bhopal and, the complaint alleges, new safety procedures implemented at plants in West Virginia were ignored. Also, it says, sirens in the Bhopal plant were turned off to avoid causing 'undue panic' among the local population over 'routine minor leaks'. Abdul Jabbar, who heads a gas victims' women organisation, has written an open letter to US President Bill Clinton, who will be visiting in ten days, demanding Anderson's extradition. He will be leading a series of rallies in New Delhi in the days before Clinton's arrival. The Indian government is still pursuing a criminal case against Indian staff of the plant and nine locally recruited executives are currently in custody.'

webTitle: Neo-Nazis to invade Chile for world rally

fields.headline: Neo-Nazis to invade Chile for world rally
fields.trailText: Fresh on the  heels of Augusto Pinochet's return, Chile is bracing itself for another PR disaster when a world Nazi congress takes place in Santiago in April. The meeting is to run from 17-22 April, including Hit-ler's birthday on 20 April.
fields.body:
Fresh on the heels of Augusto Pinochet's return, Chile is bracing itself for another PR disaster when a world Nazi congress takes place in Santiago in April. The meeting is to run from 17-22 April, including Hit-ler's birthday on 20 April.

The people who think that the Second World War was won by the wrong side are gathering in Chile's capital to plot the comeback of the neo-Nazi movement. Far-right fanatics from as far apart as Spain and Mexico and 10 South American countries have accepted invitations to the First International Ideological Meeting of the National Socialists. Outraged Jewish, human rights and youth groups are campaigning to outlaw the meeting.

The Chilean government is exploring ways to ban the event - to accusations of discrimination from the organisers, Patria Nueva Sociedad (PNS), or New Fatherland Society. The 300-strong 'helpers' of the PNS are taking pains to present themselves as decent, thoughtful and clean-cut, to no avail.

They complain they are misunderstood, but there is nothing ambiguous about the 'Sieg Heil' on their website. These slick modernisers eschew the jackboot and are at pains to be seen as nice guys looking for a new way in politics. But their bible is Mein Kampf and they have paid attention to Hitler's advice that the way to power is the path of legality. The leader of PNS, Alexis López, 31, an entomologist and journalist, stresses that 'everything we do is legal. We will never do anything outside the law'.

The PNS has been planning the congress for almost two years, and López vows the congress will go ahead despite government disapproval. 'If we can't have it publicly, we'll have it in private.' He confirmed last week that representatives from 10 Latin American countries are coming, among them the anti-Semitic Brazilian Integralist Movement and neo-Nazi New Triumph Party of Argentina.

López denies that the PNS is an ultra-right movement. When asked if the PNS follows neo-Nazi principles and asked to explain the 'Sieg Heils' and Nazi insignia in the organisation's literature, he concedes it adheres to Nazi economic and labour principles, but says 'we have changed the ideology from the original. We are against xenophobia, racism and discrimination'.

Yoram Rovner, editor of the Jewish magazine Der Ruf , begs to differ. He says the PNS is racist and anti-Semitic but uses words cunningly to appeal to a greater audience. He believes the PNS will use the congress as a platform to lay foundations for a new National Socialist Party. Der Ruf is campaigning to gather 1.5 million signatures (one for every child killed in the Holocaust) to oppose the congress. 'We're going to have a meeting with the government and make a lot of noise in Chile,' Rovner said.

webTitle: Mum jailed as sons run riot

fields.headline: Mum jailed as sons run riot
fields.trailText: France has found a new and controversial weapon in its war against youth violence: for the first time, a court has jailed a parent of delinquent children for failing in her parental duties.
fields.body:
France has found a new and controversial weapon in its war against youth violence: for the first time, a court has jailed a parent of delinquent children for failing in her parental duties.

Simone Ignalzak, 35, was jailed for one month after a court in Mulhouse, eastern France, heard the criminal records accumulated by her four sons, aged 12 to 17, while in her care.

Their mother was accused of egging them on, ignoring frequent truancy, refusing the recommendations of the juvenile court, allowing a 'climate of violence' at home, and leaving the flat in a 'filthy, repulsive, cockroach-infested and grease-covered' state.

It was enough to make the presiding judge, Fernand Kalo, invoke Article 227-17 of the French criminal code, which permits a court to punish by up to two years in prison any father or mother who 'without legitimate reason shirks the obligations of parenthood ... where health, safety, morals or education of their child are endangered'.

The report from childcare experts was damning. Ignalzak, it said, was 'well acquainted with the social services, which she manipulates cleverly ... using her children for personal ends'. It said she joined in her sons' crimes, and saw them 'purely as a source of income'. She said she could not supervise 24 hours a day. 'I go to sleep,' she told the court. 'The boys go out the window. I don't hear them. But I do all I can to put them to bed.'

Article 217-17 is one of the weapons being wielded by French authorities alarmed by a rising tide of youth crime. The Prime Minister, Lionel Jospin, last year promised a traditional solution: 7,000 new policemen on the streets and 50 new high-security detention centres for serious and multiple offenders aged between 13 and 16.

The move came after police figures showed that reported incidents of juvenile crime in France, from graffiti to murder, rose by over 11 per cent last year, with more than 155,000 minors involved against 138,000 in 1998. The numbers doubled since 1992. Juvenile crime makes up 25 per cent of all police cases. The Justice Ministry has told magistrates to use Article 217-7 more.

But some cases seem dubious. In Seine Saint-Denis, a father and a mother who spoke little French were fined for the crimes of their teenage sons and, said their lawyer, 'understood not a jot of what was going on'.

A father in Versailles is appealing against a fine and suspended sentence given because he 'failed to take the necessary educational measures' to moderate the behaviour of his son. Even one author of the government report, Christine Lazerges, says the law 'can only be the last resort'.

fields.headline: World in brief
fields.trailText: US ambassador gunned down in Cameroon
fields.body:
US ambassador gunned down in Cameroon

Unidentified gunmen shot and seriously wounded the United States ambassador to Cameroon, Melvin Yates, outside his residence in the capital, Yaounde. He is the latest and the most senior diplomat there to be targeted by criminals seeking money or vehicles.

Thaw floods 1,000 homes

Heavy rains and melting snow have flooded 1,000 homes and large areas of farmland in the Transylvanian counties of Romania.

Arabs turn heat on Israel

Arab foreign ministers meeting in Beirut endorsed Syrian demands that Israel must make its withdrawal from Lebanon part of a broader Middle East peace settlement, including leaving the Golan Heights and a Palestinian state capital in Jerusalem, they said.

Labour bids to lead Norway

The Norwegian Labour Party leader Jens Stoltenberg agreed to form a government after centrist Prime Kjell Magne Bondevik resigned.

Earthquake shakes Rome

An earthquake measuring 4.1 on the Richter scale shook Rome and the surrounding areas, but no casualties or damage were reported. The epicentre was believed to be in mountains east of the city, the Ansa news agency said.

webTitle: Battle of the ice hots up as activists are charged

fields.headline: Battle of the ice hots up as activists are charged
fields.trailText: In one of the most inhospitable corners of the world, what is being billed as a battle for the future of the planet escalated dramatically yesterday. Three Greenpeace activists who had spent the last month camped out on an ice shelf in the Arctic Ocean in temperatures of -20C (-2F) were arrested by Alaskan state troopers, charged with criminal trespass and banned from the region.
fields.body:
In one of the most inhospitable corners of the world, what is being billed as a battle for the future of the planet escalated dramatically yesterday. Three Greenpeace activists who had spent the last month camped out on an ice shelf in the Arctic Ocean in temperatures of -20C (-2F) were arrested by Alaskan state troopers, charged with criminal trespass and banned from the region.

The campaigners - an Englishman, an American and a Dutchman - were part of a group of eight Greenpeace activists who have been protesting against BP Amoco for opening up a new oilfield six miles off the north coast of Alaska. Greenpeace claims that by building an artificial island and drilling below the melting Arctic ice, BP is promoting global warming and taking a one-in-four risk of a major oil spill. BP insists that there need not be an unacceptable risk just because a practice is unprecedented.

Greenpeace spokesman Peter Morris said that photographer Steve Martin, from Somerset, Hank Haazen, from Holland, and Dan Ritzman, from Alaska, have been charged with criminal trespass in the first degree.

The protesters have been living in two insulated canvas tents, pitched on the rough pack-ice just over a mile from BP's $500 million (£316 million) Northstar project. The wilderness is probably the region of the world most affected by climate change, with temperatures rising up to five times faster than the global average. In the last 20 years, pack ice three times the size of the UK has melted. Polar bears, deprived of their habitat, have been starving to death because they cannot find food.

The protesters who were arrested had been standing by their fibreglass shelter on the edge of the no-trespass zone around Northstar, examining an anonymous note saying that if the shelter was not occupied, it would be destroyed. When six state-troopers marched toward them, the protesters thought they were coming to explain the note. Instead, the activists were arrested and their film and video footage confiscated. They have been banned from coming within 100 miles of the site until the trial in May.

Tanya Popp, one of the five campaigners left in the camp, told The Observer over a satellite phone: 'We were totally shocked. They weren't even doing anything.'

The protesters insist they are innocent of trespass, and allege collusion between the state troopers and the oil company. 'BP have a lot of money, and a lot of control in Alaska. I am sure they have a big say in what happens,' said Popp.

The Northstar production island will have 22 oil wells and is expected to produce 65,000 barrels of oil a day. To get the oil back on shore across the pack ice, BP is burying a pipeline for hot oil six feet below the Arctic sea floor, a technique that has never been used before.

The environmentalists say that the extreme conditions and the immensely powerful and shifting Arctic ice-pack mean that production will be extremely risky, with one academic study showing a one- in-four chance of an oil spill.

A BP spokesman said the study was outdated, adding: 'This has been approved by the Alaskan authorities - and they wouldn't allow us to embark on it if there was a real environment risk.'

But Greenpeace climate campaigner Stephanie Tunmore said: 'Neither BP Amoco nor the Alaskan state government will prevent Greenpeace revealing the appalling truth about oil exploration in the Arctic. The Northstar project is a real threat to this fragile Arctic environment and will only make global warming worse. BP Amoco must halt construction immediately'.

BP Amoco would not comment last night, its spokesman saying only: 'It is a matter for the police.'
