fields.headline: Why is beauty so bland?
fields.standfirst: Perfection is a game of averages which strips the ideal face of personality.
fields.trailText: Perfection is a game of averages which strips the ideal face of personality.
fields.body:
Every spring, in the run-up to the Oscars, Vanity Fair reports on the young actors it deems most likely to become the future gods and goddesses of Hollywood. It is not always right, but because it was right about Cate Blanchett, Leonardo DiCaprio, Cameron Diaz and Nicole Kidman, the industry takes its predictions very seriously. When it published its predictions for the 'class of 2000' earlier this week, the story ran in almost every national daily. But there was something very odd about the nine new faces in the accompanying photo.

Six of them are female and three of them are male. Five have dark hair and four are blond. Two have names that suggest not entirely WASP origins. And there you have it, the sum total of distinctive features. That said, the overall effect is very pleasing. All nine faces are symmetrical and oval in shape, all nine pairs of eyes large and moist. The lips are full, the bodies are perfect. It's impossible to tell them apart.

You could almost imagine them exchanging roles in a film without anyone noticing. But according to many people in the entertainment industries, their identikit good looks are just not a problem. They are what everyone is looking for these days. Nothing sells better than a perfectly symmetrical 17-year-old blank slate.

Unless it's a 16-year-old blank slate. According to Sandra Halliday, news editor of the Internet fashion site WGSM, it is important to keep one's sense of proportion about this. There are sound practical reasons for using young models. Cameras are kinder to slips of girls. Slips of girls cut better figures on the catwalk. Ours is hardly the only culture to glorify youth, she says.

In her book, Survival of the Prettiest , Harvard psychologist Nancy Etcoff cites research suggesting that it pays to be beautiful at any age: the closer you are to the classical ideal, the more likely you are to get jobs, salary rises and promotions. She believes that our standards of beauty are to a large degree genetically determined. 'We are born with lookism programmed into us,' she says. There are studies showing that babies as young as three months old respond more favourably to a classically beautiful face that they do to a classically plain one. Long before we ever see our first issue of Vogue , she says, we all have 'biological radar for healthy, fertile bodies'. If this is so, it would be wrong to blame the showbiz world for making our wildest dreams come true.

But in so doing, has it perhaps changed our idea of what is normal or possible? One of Etcoff's pet theories is that human beauty is based on 'facial averageness'. 'Since the average of a population is likely to reflect the optimal design of physical traits, evolution has given us brains wired to calculate mean averages and prefer them.'

Those who first proposed this theory likened it to a 'face-averaging device', and suggested that it might work like 'composite portraiture'. 'It collects impressions of faces and turns them into composites that become our standards of attractiveness.'

The standards you end up with, she suggests, depend very much on the sum total of faces you see. Thus, in an age when the Chelsea Set only ever saw the other members of the Chelsea Set, the standards of beauty would have been rather narrow and perhaps a little racist. But now, with so many non-white ethnic groups gaining prominence in the Western world, the pool of facial data is much larger and beauty standards have become broader. You see a shift away from Caucasian norms. We are moving, she says, to an 'internal average where Asian, African and Hispanic features are helping to recalibrate norms and re-envision beauty'.

That view is far too optimistic, according to Halliday. She still sees a great deal of 'covert racism' right across the media. Naomi Campbell has done well, she thinks, because her beauty is closer to the Western norm than it is to the African norm. It's the same for Jennifer Lopez and Salma Hayek, she says, and for almost all of the handsome new generation of not-Caucasian Hollywood men. You cannot expect to do well, she thinks, unless you can appeal to white consumers.

This may explain why our new beauty standards are such halting, timid recalibrations of the old ones.

The pool of facial images coming to us from the media is not just disproportionately good-looking, but disproportionately youthful. During the 15 years that Annie Shepherd has worked as a New York music video producer, she's seen the ages of the stars go down so far and so fast that people are talking about themselves as has-beens by the time they've turned 18. The internal norms of the music industry, she says, have never been more rigid. 'Even if you're young and talented, they won't sign you if you're ugly.' She is worried about the effect this is having on her own pre-teen daughter's self-image.

But at least her daughter is drawing her standards of beauty from real people. As technology improves, real beauties are going to have to compete with cyberbabes. It's happening as we speak: Lara Croft has already appeared on the covers of The Face and Loaded . Games magazines routinely feature a 'virtual babe'. This allows ideal types to exert an even more powerful influence.

Last year, psychologist Vic tor Johnson surveyed 10,000 men about their criteria for an ideal woman. He then processed their views to come up with the ideal cyberbabe. When the Daily Mirror ran a picture of the final product, it asked readers to send in photos of real people who resembled her. There followed a reader's poll to find out which of the top five closest matches was the most beautiful. It turned out to be an 18-year-old girl from Warrington. When the Daily Mirror ran her winning picture, the headline was, 'Face it - I'm Perfect'.

And let's face it. She was. But she was also very embarrassed by the whole thing. It is right to query media trends, as Halliday puts it, and it is wrong to assume that they have the same terrible effect on everyone. Normal, balanced people are not as gullible or malleable as the media assume. They adjust their appearances to fit cultural norms, but only up to a point.

When she looks at the young people in the fashion industry, and contrasts them with the people she worked with when she was their age, she sees what she can only call a big improvement. They have better teeth, skin and hair. They're taller and fitter and have a much more sophisticated sense of style.

But they don't all look alike, and neither do they want to. 'There's a general look, but within that look there's lots of room for manoeuvre.' They are much better at expressing a distinct identity, she thinks, than she and her peers were.

The only reason the New Hollywood Nine look uniform, she says, is that we haven't seen enough of them yet. An unknown Sharon Stone would have looked anonymous, too, if you had photographed her with a comparable group earlier in her career. But now that we know so much about her, we can't look at her face without her personality coming through. If any of the new class becomes as famous as she is, we'll look back at this picture and see it differently.

With their personalities airbrushed out, the photograph of the class of 2000 takes on the aura of a boardroom. The images these people project are opaque but soothing, careful but confidence-inspiring. They suggest people who know how to play the game, who can be counted to get to work on time. As such, they are very much in keeping with the Zeitgeist as the sociologist Richard Sennett describes it in his little masterpiece about life in the new flexible economy, The Corrosion of Character .

The new world order as he describes it is in many ways Hollywood writ large. It is not a place where you can expect long-term security, and so smart people stay on their toes, hold back and hedge their bets. Young people fare better because experience counts for little and energy counts for a lot. And because they have fewer responsibilities to carry, it is easier for them to move on if things don't work out. These are the values I see reflected in the New Hollywood Nine. What disturbs me is not how they look but how neatly they blend in with the corporate façade.

Cameras are kinder to slips of girls. Slips of girls cut better figures on the catwalk. Ours is hardly the only culture to glorify youth, she says. In her book, Survival of the Prettiest , Harvard psychologist Nancy Etcoff cites research suggesting that it pays to be beautiful at any age: the closer you are to the classical ideal, the more likely you are to get jobs, salary rises and promotions. She believes that our standards of beauty are to a large degree genetically determined. 'We are born with lookism programmed into us,' she says. There are studies showing that babies as young as three months old respond more favourably to a classically beautiful face that they do to a classically plain one. Long before we ever see our first issue of Vogue , she says, we all have 'biological radar for healthy, fertile bodies'. If this is so, it would be wrong to blame the showbiz world for making our wildest dreams come true. But in so doing, has it perhaps changed our idea of what is normal or possible? One of Etcoff's pet theories is that human beauty is based on 'facial averageness'. 'Since the average of a population is likely to reflect the optimal design of physical traits, evolution has given us brains wired to calculate mean averages and prefer them.' Those who first proposed this theory likened it to a 'face-averaging device', and suggested that it might work like 'composite portraiture'. 'It collects impressions of faces and turns them into composites that become our standards of attractiveness.' The standards you end up with, she suggests, depend very much on the sum total of faces you see. Thus, in an age when the Chelsea Set only ever saw the other members of the Chelsea Set, the standards of beauty would have been rather narrow and perhaps a little racist. But now, with so many non-white ethnic groups gaining prominence in the Western world, the pool of facial data is much larger and beauty standards have become broader. You see a shift away from Caucasian norms. We are moving, she says, to an 'internal average where Asian, African and Hispanic features are helping to recalibrate norms and re-envision beauty'. That view is far too optimistic, according to Halliday. She still sees a great deal of 'covert racism' right across the media. Naomi Campbell has done well, she thinks, because her beauty is closer to the Western norm than it is to the African norm. It's the same for Jennifer Lopez and Salma Hayek, she says, and for almost all of the handsome new generation of not-Caucasian Hollywood men. You cannot expect to do well, she thinks, unless you can appeal to white consumers. This may explain why our new beauty standards are such halting, timid recalibrations of the old ones. The pool of facial images coming to us from the media is not just disproportionately good-looking, but disproportionately youthful. During the 15 years that Annie Shepherd has worked as a New York music video producer, she's seen the ages of the stars go down so far and so fast that people are talking about themselves as has-beens by the time they've turned 18. The internal norms of the music industry, she says, have never been more rigid. 'Even if you're young and talented, they won't sign you if you're ugly.' She is worried about the effect this is having on her own pre-teen daughter's self-image. But at least her daughter is drawing her standards of beauty from real people. As technology improves, real beauties are going to have to compete with cyberbabes. It's happening as we speak: Lara Croft has already appeared on the covers of The Face and Loaded . Games magazines routinely feature a 'virtual babe'. This allows ideal types to exert an even more powerful influence. Last year, psychologist Vic tor Johnson surveyed 10,000 men about their criteria for an ideal woman. He then processed their views to come up with the ideal cyberbabe. When the Daily Mirror ran a picture of the final product, it asked readers to send in photos of real people who resembled her. There followed a reader's poll to find out which of the top five closest matches was the most beautiful. It turned out to be an 18-year-old girl from Warrington. When the Daily Mirror ran her winning picture, the headline was, 'Face it - I'm Perfect'. And let's face it. She was. But she was also very embarrassed by the whole thing. It is right to query media trends, as Halliday puts it, and it is wrong to assume that they have the same terrible effect on everyone. Normal, balanced people are not as gullible or malleable as the media assume. They adjust their appearances to fit cultural norms, but only up to a point. When she looks at the young people in the fashion industry, and contrasts them with the people she worked with when she was their age, she sees what she can only call a big improvement. They have better teeth, skin and hair. They're taller and fitter and have a much more sophisticated sense of style. But they don't all look alike, and neither do they want to. 'There's a general look, but within that look there's lots of room for manoeuvre.' They are much better at expressing a distinct identity, she thinks, than she and her peers were. The only reason the New Hollywood Nine look uniform, she says, is that we haven't seen enough of them yet. An unknown Sharon Stone would have looked anonymous, too, if you had photographed her with a comparable group earlier in her career. But now that we know so much about her, we can't look at her face without her personality coming through. If any of the new class becomes as famous as she is, we'll look back at this picture and see it differently. With their personalities airbrushed out, the photograph of the class of 2000 takes on the aura of a boardroom. The images these people project are opaque but soothing, careful but confidence-inspiring. They suggest people who know how to play the game, who can be counted to get to work on time. As such, they are very much in keeping with the Zeitgeist as the sociologist Richard Sennett describes it in his little masterpiece about life in the new flexible economy, The Corrosion of Character . The new world order as he describes it is in many ways Hollywood writ large. It is not a place where you can expect long-term security, and so smart people stay on their toes, hold back and hedge their bets. Young people fare better because experience counts for little and energy counts for a lot. And because they have fewer responsibilities to carry, it is easier for them to move on if things don't work out. These are the values I see reflected in the New Hollywood Nine. What disturbs me is not how they look but how neatly they blend in with the corporate façade.

webTitle: On tour with the politician formerly known as Red Ken

fields.headline: On tour with the politician formerly known as Red Ken
fields.standfirst:
Andrew Rawnsley finds a pinstripe audience in the City grunting in approval and lapping up Livingstone's artful line in self-deprecation

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Andrew Rawnsley finds a pinstripe audience in the City grunting in approval and lapping up Livingstone's artful line in self-deprecation
fields.body:
Ken flashes his salamander smile and oozes a charm that would beguile a reptile house of snakes. 'I can't remember why I agreed to do this nine months ago,' he tells his hosts. 'I was turning everything else down, because I didn't know whether I'd be a candidate.'

What an outrageous fraud he is. Champagne? 'Yeah,' he's gasping. 'That would be lovely. If we'd thought about it a bit,' he goes on, 'we could have got some TV cameras here - got you a bit of publicity.' Brazen Ken, utterly shameless schmoozing. And absolutely brilliant, too. They are already scoffing from his hand. We are in the gilded splendour of the Draper's Livery Hall, opposite the Stock Exchange, just downwind of the Bank of England, in the heart of the City that New Labour says will be ruined if the newt-fancier is elected Mayor of London. That morning, in the rather less glitteringly-appointed home of the Local Government Association, Frank Dobson had been predicting that Livingstone would be the greatest calamity to hit the capital since the Black Death.

When the politician formerly known as Red Ken rises to speak - having been introduced as 'the hottest ticket in town' - the marble columns of this temple of capitalism certainly shudder. With laughter. 'I suppose you're not a representative audience of Londoners - but there must be some bugger out there who supports me,' he begins. Livingstone's artful line in self-deprecation is designed to defuse the accusation that he is using the mayoralty as a vehicle for his own out-sized ego.

He muses that Tony Blair had wanted the mayor's parlour occupied by a captain of industry. 'But they're not paying enough for you to take that sort of cut in your income. So you're left with the same old clapped-out party hacks.' More warm chuckling. He speaks for 50 minutes, without notes. The pinstripe crowd are in stitches over an anecdote about a corrupt American mayor. He asks them to share his pain at having to leave the Labour Party - 'more difficult than deciding whether to continue with my marriage' - and actually claims credit for not pretending that he hasn't broken his word about running as an independent. The pitch is: at least I honestly admit lying. They grunt approvingly as he lays into 'those ghastly dullards' responsible for London Underground. He has an excellent riff about why getting rid of conductors was such a disaster for buses.

Ken switches into nostalgia mode: 'I remember when I first started work, seeing City gents on the bus reading their Financial Times . You don't see that any more.' Having laid on the sugar, to his credit, he is not afraid to give some tarter messages. The levels of poverty in London 'disfigure' the City. He will introduce a congestion tax, which is unlikely to be popular with the company motors in the audience. Questions are smoothed over or avoided deftly. The Government says he'll inflict chaos on the capital. 'I hear myself echoing Tony Blair,' retorts Livingstone's mischevious adenoidal twang. 'The work of the mayor will take more than one term. I won't be re-elected if I screw it up.' When he's finished, they give him a standing ovation.

All those former Labour colleagues who brand him a manipulative, self-centred, traitor may be right. But Livingstone is still a fantastically accomplished performer. On a political stage hardly crowded with charisma, here's a star. He is as skilled a communicator as Blair. The irony - perhaps this is why he so confounds New Labour - is that Livingstone and Blair share a chameleonesque ability to appeal to wildly different audiences. He gets pop star treatment, whether he's joining a demonstration by firefighters (wearing 'Vote Ken' badges almost to a man and woman) on the Embankment, or whether he's paying respects to the Saatchi Synagogue. That it was built with the money of the Tory ad men brothers is no obstacle to the ecumenical Livingstone. When he visited the London School of Economics the day after his declaration, students offered plastered bits of their bodies for his autograph. A great roar greeted Livingstone's arrival; Frank Dobson was welcomed with a sympathetic 'aaah' as if to confirm Alastair Campbell's contention that the Prime Minister's man, the official candidate of the great machine, is 'the underdog'.

They are doing their best to groom up doggo Dobbo. The candidates are brought together one evening at the Soho Theatre to record a debate for the BBC's First Sight programme. Frank is quite resplendent - well, as resplendent as Frank can be - in an immaculate mid-blue suit, toned tie, and dazzling white shirt. Beard and hair look freshly trimmed and plucked. Ken toils up in his usual wardrobe: battered brown shoes and an unseasonably beige, not quite matching jacket-and-trouser combo which is in desperate need of visiting the dry cleaners. There's another paradox of this campaign.

It is Frank, desperate to prove he is not the New Labour stooge, who dresses to the Left. He makes an extravagant promise that 'all the existing Tube lines will be rebuilt' and untold sums will be spent on an outer circle line for the capital. Ken, sounding just like Jack Straw when Labour was in Opposition, says he wants more bobbies on the beat. 'When I was a kid, you didn't get into trouble, because you never knew when a policeman might come round the corner,' he says.

Livingstone's minder for tonight is Neil Pearson, the actor whose next big TV drama is aptly entitled Dirty Work . He is leading the fund-raising effort to put together a Livingstone machine. At the moment it operates from two rooms belonging to a friend in advertising over an empty shop near Goodge Street. Phones to the office are permanently engaged. 'This two men and a dog business, it's all very folksy, but it's got a limited shelf life, quite frankly,' says one of the Livingstone team. 'People are going to start asking: if he can't run a proper campaign, how the fuck can he run London?'

Dobbo should have the advantage here, at least. I ask Frank's charming assistant - 'Alice, as in Wonderland', she introduces herself - about his schedule. There's a meeting with meningitis charities - he is especially proud of what he achieved in this area as Health Secretary - at the Commons. 'But that's private,' says Alice. Private! It is a commentary on Dobbo's decency - and also on the deficiencies of his campaign - that the doors are closed on an event that might flatter him.

Dobbo's next big photo-opportunity is at HMS Belfast. By the gangplank, he poses with Labour candidates for the London Assembly. The usual thinking behind such picture events is for followers to bask in the glory reflecting off the leader. Here, the blood-soaked champ is hoping for resuscitation from his seconds. The idea is to contrast Labour's happy family with lone wolf Livingstone. Trouble is that solo Ken against the machine is so much part of his appeal.

At the Drapers' Hall, I fell into conversation with the City swells. 'My taxi driver is voting for him, and so am I,' declares an insolvency accountant. 'He's intelligent, thoughtful. He's of the far Left. So what? We could do with a bit of variety. I quite like Blair, but he can't have it all his own way.' His friend, in pensions, is a Livingstonite, too. 'He's very impressive.' What about some of his fellow travellers, I wonder. Neither of these liverymen sound like natural bedfellows of the Socialist Alliance. 'It's only four years. And, anyway, he won't be able to do too much,' says Mr Insolvency Accountant. Mr Pensions agrees: 'If he goes too far, the Government will rein him in. He's a character. It'll be fun. Why not?' From the City to student halls and hangouts, they say the same: Why not? Tony Blair has less than eight weeks to find an answer.

webTitle: Why nobody gets my vote this time

fields.headline: Why nobody gets my vote this time
fields.standfirst:
John Diamond , a lifelong Labour supporter, on why he is disillusioned now

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: John Diamond , a lifelong Labour supporter, on why he is disillusioned now
fields.body:
The claim I'm about to make isn't, I imagine, a rare one, but it is this: I've voted in every election since I was 18, council, national, European, rain, shine, snow, the lot. It wouldn't occur to me not to; one of the first political saws I learned from my father was that if you don't vote you give up the right to complain.

In every election, except for one in the Eighties where I recklessly gave one of my three local council votes to the Green Party, I have voted Labour. I voted Labour when the local party was run by brain-dead Trots, and in the Callaghan days when the party was run by tired old geezers who made Tony Blair look like Watt Tyler's radical kid brother. I couldn't vote Tory because - well I just couldn't - and no other party has ever got nearer to where I wanted to be than Labour, in any of its guises.

Having come through all that, suddenly I find myself in danger of not voting at an election. As a Labour member I should, of course, have voted in the Ken v Frank fight at party level but couldn't bring myself to put my mark against either name. And when the day comes to vote in May, I think I might find myself in the same position again.

By temperament, I'm inclined to go for Livingstone for all the reasons that many London voters will go for him. I can still remember what the GLC was like under the late Horace Cutler, the clownish Bernard Matthews of local politics. And I remember the relief when Labour got in and Livingstone executed the dodgy coup against Andrew Macintosh on his first day in the chamber after the election. Yes, I thought Fare's Fare was wonderful; no, I had no problem with the GLC raising a supplementary rate when the money started running out; no, I could never get too upset about the comparatively small amounts of money handed to gay and ethnic groups. And, almost regardless of Livingstone's policies, under his rule London felt like a place of its own, with a special identity.

Then, in 1991, I interviewed Livingstone for the London Evening Standard . I thought he was going a tad far when he predicted with relish that with the coming of the true Brussels spirit, national government would wither and die, and all power would devolve to the EC and the regions - but even that would suggest to me that he'd be safer working at local rather than national level.

The one thing that almost certainly will stop me voting for him is that he was happy to admit that when he got into Parliament just four years earlier he had given up on London as his specialist subject. 'I did not come here as Mr London I came here to do something else,' he told me.

The something else was to develop some new sort of economic model for Britain. Or Europe. Or the World. Who knows? Whatever, he was ploughing the money he made from writing and broadcasting into leased time on some sort of supercomputer into which he'd spend hours downloading the numbers he needed to find whatever magic formula it was he was looking for.

I was appalled. Here was the man once proclaimed as London's saviour telling me London wasn't his business any more. London was dying on its feet. The roads were stuffed with traffic, the Tubes and buses expensive and smelly, decent people who had once been a shoe-in for a council house place were living on the streets. And without a GLC we needed more than ever an MP who would stand up for the capital in the Commons.

Other Labour MPs were doing it, after all. Tony Banks quickly became a professional Londoner, almost on the level of Fred Housego or the Pearly Kings: if something nasty was happening in London then Banks was at the microphone complaining. Or if not him, then David Mellor or even Steven Norris. But not Ken. Ken was now an economist, and it wasn't until the mayoralty became a paying proposition that he resurfaced as a born-again Londoner.

But the alternative? Frank Dobson? I'm not sure I can bring myself to vote for him either. Don't get me wrong - I'm just the sort of mealy-mouthed Blair-supporting anal retentive that Ken's people hate. But I recognise that the only value of having a Mayor with such truncated powers is that he or she can give a personality to the city in the way American mayors do. The way Ken Livingstone did, come to that. We need a mayor of sufficient charisma that the microphone and the camera will always be in his face. And Frank isn't that man.

It's not that I mind him being Blair's poodle: even the most radical elected official is a party's poodle if he wants to keep the party whip. It's just that voting for Dobson as Mayor of London is a little like voting for the head of the University Geology Society to book the bands for the weekend Student Union concerts.

My Ken-supporting friends say the worst that can happen if Ken gets in, screws up, gets bad press in the Mail , and gets deselected next time round, is that we'll get a Labour Mayor who is neither Livingstone nor Dobson. But that isn't how it will work. Voters disenchanted with Livingstone won't vote for the new Labour candidate - but for the new Tory.

The ridiculous thing for me, and, I imagine, thousands of Labour supporters like me, is that if Ken had stuck to his computer and not risen again as the saviour of London, there would have been no problem. We may have grimaced while we placed the cross against Dobson's name, but we would have voted Dobson for the reason we always vote Labour.

Now we have two Labours to vote for and, spoilt for choice, my temptation is not to vote at all.

I probably will, in the end, because I seem to be genetically determined so to do. But it really wouldn't surprise me if whoever wins the election does it on a turnout of rather less than 50 per cent. And that's no win at all.

The ridiculous thing for me, and, I imagine, thousands of Labour supporters like me, is that if Ken had stuck to his computer and not risen again as the saviour of London, there would have been no problem. We may have grimaced while we placed the cross against Dobson's name, but we would have voted Dobson for the reason we always vote Labour. Now we have two Labours to vote for and, spoilt for choice, my temptation is not to vote at all. I probably will, in the end, because I seem to be genetically determined so to do. But it really wouldn't surprise me if whoever wins the election does it on a turnout of rather less than 50 per cent. And that's no win at all.

webTitle: Odd allies in search of peace

fields.headline: Odd allies in search of peace
fields.standfirst:
Henry McDonald 's new biography of the Ulster Unionist leader and suspended First Minister of Northern Ireland charts the relationship between Trimble and Blair from the Prime Minister's days as a new frontbencher

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Henry McDonald 's new biography of the Ulster Unionist leader and suspended First Minister of Northern Ireland charts the relationship between Trimble and Blair from the Prime Minister's days as a new frontbencher
fields.body:
David Trimble's hostility towards the Tories was bolstered by the revelations that the Conservatives had maintained a 'back channel' to the IRA since 1990. He now saw an opportunity to cultivate new links with senior figures in John Smith's Labour Party, including a young MP who had just been promoted to the front bench: Tony Blair.

Trimble first came across Blair in March 1994 when the MP for Sedgefield was appointed Shadow Home Secretary. According to Trimble, Blair spoke frankly about the need to change the Labour Party's pro-nationalist policies on Northern Ireland towards a more balanced position that addressed Unionist concerns. Trimble recalls that Blair told him prophetically that changing Labour's Ulster policy would mean sacking Kevin McNamara, the party's avowedly pro-nationalist Northern Ireland spokesman. The first meeting between Blair and Trimble was at the former's request.

'I got this message from Blair to come and have a discussion with him about the Prevention of Terrorism Act. I checked with Molyneaux and he said, "Go ahead." So I arranged to see him and it became quite clear what he wanted.

'He said very openly that he wanted to change the Labour Party's stance on the PTA. He couldn't do it immediately but he would focus opposition to the PTA on specific items and ask the Government to review them

'He told me he had noticed that I had spoken the previous year on the PTA and had criticised some aspects of it such as exclusion orders and the lack of proper judicial procedures. Blair said he had noted these criticisms, which were exactly what he wanted to focus on.

'He asked me would I support him if he called for a review of the legislation on those matters I had criticised. I told him I would need to check with Jim Molyneaux, and then we chatted a bit. His obvious disapproval of Kevin McNamara came out in that conversation. When I went back to check, Molyneaux said yes.

'That led to a meeting with John Smith, Tony Blair, Molyneaux and myself in the Labour leader's office, which was astonishing. Molyneaux was engaged in one of these elliptical conversations in which he alluded to the Callaghan years, sending out the broad message to Smith that Molyneaux might do for Smith what he did for Jim Callaghan.

'Smith then sent a coded message back, emphasising his position as someone from the West Coast of Scotland who understood Ulster Unionists. The thing that fascinated me most about sitting there listening to this was that Molyneaux had never actually spoken to John Smith before! That established a reasonable relation ship between Blair and myself.'

Trimble and other Ulster Unionists had a growing belief that the Tories would eventually be voted out of power, and that it was wise to forge closer ties to Labour now. Within a year Kevin McNamara was dumped and Labour's oppositional stance to the PTA moderated; for Trimble these were clear signals that Smith and eventually Blair were men the UUP should cultivate.

Trimble was trying desperately to sell the Good Friday peace agreement to a sceptical and nervous unionist population. He had brought over one of the grandees of the Tory Party, Lord Cranborne, one of the co-founders of Friends of the Union in Britain, to support his call for a Yes vote on 22 May.

Behind the scenes, Sean O'Callaghan, the former IRA killer turned garda agent, acted as an adviser to Trimble's campaign team. But one issue almost destroyed Trimble's project to persuade Unionists about the benefits of the Agreement - Drumcree.

The Parades Commission, the body set up by Blair's Government to adjudicate on controversial Orange Order marches, was due to publish its report on the 1998 Drumcree parade a week before voting took place.

The report which recommended the march down Portadown's Garvaghy Road should be banned, was a political time bomb for Trimble. Had it been published in the week running up to the end of the referendum campaign Trimble's opponents in the No camp, Ian Paisley et al , would have made enormous political capital out of the decision. But Blair intervened on his behalf and compromised the independence of the institution the Prime Minister had established to take decisions over parades out of political control.

The critical moves in the final days of the Trimble campaign were made by four players. They were Glen Barr, the singer Bono, Blair and the former RUC Chief Constable, Sir Jack Hermon.

Although Barr opposed the Good Friday Agreement he still held some residual loyalty to Trimble. The former UWC spokesman and old Vanguard comrade had been appointed to the Parades Commission as one of two loyalist representatives on the body, the other being Tommy Cheevers from the UVF-aligned Progressive Unionist Party.

In the middle of the referendum campaign the commission was scheduled to deliver its preliminary verdict on whether the Drumcree 1998 parade would be allowed to pass through the Garvaghy Road. (As it turned out, the commission recommended - despite opposition from both Barr and Cheever - that the Orange march be rerouted away from the Garvaghy Road. The verdict, however, did not make the light of day until after the referendum.)

Barr realised that during the campaign Trimble's Unionist opponents would exploit the ban and dress it up as just one more sop to violent republicanism. He contacted Trimble and informed him that the Parades Commission was about to ban the Drumcree march. Trimble then relayed to Downing Street his concern about the impact this would have on the Yes campaign. Blair agreed with Trimble's analysis and intervened to delay the commission's report.

Barr, a faithful adherent to Ulster independence who disagreed with the agreement, had saved his former Vanguard colleague. The commission had a remit to take controversial decisions on Orange marches out of the hands of politicians and police officers. And yet Trimble was able, via Barr and ultimately Blair, to compromise its political independence in the wider interests of saving the Good Friday Agreement.

 ' Trimble', by Henry McDonald, is published by Bloomsbury at £16.99

fields.headline: Ken Livingstone, mutant hero
fields.standfirst:
The more they abuse him, the stronger Ken Livingstone becomes. Perhaps the way to kill him is with kindness

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: The more they abuse him, the stronger Ken Livingstone becomes. Perhaps the way to kill him is with kindness
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone is the Rasputin of British politics - except that they got Rasputin in the end. They've bludgeoned him. They've shot him. They've stabbed him. They've poisoned him. They've tried chucking him into the river. Damn it, swears Tony Blair, as the newt-fancier just bubbles up to the surface, smiling that infuriatingly smug salamander smile.

The moment Livingstone unfurled himself as an independent, the big howitzers of the Cabinet and the popguns of the backbenches swivelled in the direction of the Cricklewood chancer. Were you and I on the receiving end of such a brutal barrage, we would be lying in a darkened room with a bag of ice on our foreheads. From Number 10 downwards, they've been thumbing Campbell's Thesaurus of Abuse. He's a liar, a traitor, an egotist. Should the people be so recklessly stupid as to elect him, he will be a more cataclysmic disaster for the capital city than the Plague of London rolled into the Great Fire.

Tony Blair and his cohorts may turn out to be right that he will be a bad mayor. Frank Dobson is not wrong when he says of Livingstone: 'Those who know him best trust him least.' Livingstone simply doesn't care. He can afford not to. It isn't honest Frank who commands the massive poll ratings and the audiences that explode in cheers before he has even opened his mouth. The punters don't mind that he lied. He's a politician, isn't he? So he's treacherous. He's a politician, isn't he? So he's an egotist. He's a politician, isn't he?

The lesson for New Labour - a lesson that should have been learnt many months ago - is that these attacks, even when grounded in the truth, have no traction against Livingstone. Worse, it's counter-destructive. He thrives when the battalions mass against him. He gorges and grows fat on their abuse. In the Eighties, he turned himself into the Cockney Rebel by confronting the judges and the Tories. Now his popularity with the voters draws on his unpopularity with Downing Street and the New Labour machine. Livingstone is a mutant form of politician. Like the coprophagous beetle, the more crap that is thrown in his direction, the stronger he becomes.

The man himself claims to expect his lead to shrivel during the course of the campaign. 'Of course I can be beaten,' Livingstone tells me. 'I could do something stupid. Frank could hire a contract killer.' He shouldn't put ideas like that into Downing Street's head. Or maybe he should. Given how atrociously they've fouled this up, a Millbank contracted killer would be certain to blow away Dobbo.

People in a rage never make good decisions. This has been Tony Blair's problem with Livingstone from the very beginning. No one in the inner courts of New Labour has been able to clear the red mist from their eyes for long enough to think coolly about how to deal with him. New Labour has been utterly confounded by Newt Labour, a label on which I believe I own the copyright but am delighted to see others taking up.

New Labour's thrashing incomprehension of Livingstone's popularity reminds me of nothing so much as the Tories' stunned bewilderment when first faced with the appeal of New Labour. This is a lovely irony. Before the last election, John Major simply couldn't fathom Tony Blair. Surely, Major reasoned, the people would see through this unprincipled opportunist who once sub scribed to so many things that made Labour unelectable. Equally, Tony Blair cannot handle the popularity of Livingstone. Surely, he says to himself, the people will see through this unprincipled opportunist who was once responsible for so much that made Labour unelectable.

To grasp Livingstone's appeal, Tony Blair only has to look in the mirror to see much of the answer staring him in the face. Just as he reinvented the party as New Labour, so Livingstone has reconfigured himself from Red Ken into Cuddly Ken. Just as New Labour has accommodated itself to capitalism, so has Newt Livingstone. I watched him last week stroke an audience of City pinstripes to a standing ovation. Just as Blair won his landslide by inviting the national electorate to stuff the sleazy Tories, so Livingstone campaigns for a landslide by offering himself as the device to stiff the control-freakists of New Labour.

Blair represented change - but nothing too disturbingly radical. Livingstone says he is different - but not dangerously so. Just as Blair assembled an extraordinary coalition of support, spanning the classes and the ages, so has Livingstone. Following his campaign over the last seven days - you can read my report elsewhere in the paper - I found him being embraced with equal enthusiasm by students at the LSE and slickers from the Square Mile.

This rainbow of support can be sustained until election day. It can't be expected to last forever after. Tony Blair's vote at the last general election was wide but shallow. The longer he has been in office, the trickier he has found the balancing act required to keep content all the constituent parts of his coalition. Livingstone, the candidate, is the beneficiary of the mid-term antagonism towards the Government. Livingstone, the mayor, will be a victim of the same process himself.

Ken's bound to be a disappointment to some people, probably a huge number of them, when they discover that the Tube does not miraculously start to move faster and it doesn't stop raining on the bus queue the day after they've voted for him. One of two things is likely to happen. The Prime Minister will be proved right. Off will be ripped the rubber mask of cheeky chappie Ken, and all those merchant bankers who voted for him just because he's a bit of a card will have a shock when he reveals himself to be an unreconstructed hard Leftist. Alternatively, Mayor Livingstone will be the acme of commonsense he now claims to be. This will come as a bitter betrayal to his fellow travellers when they discover he is not the revolutionary instrument for creating a workers' paradise on Earth in the London Commune as a first step towards supplanting the Blair Government with the People's Socialist Republic of Britain.

The implausibility of Livingstone satisfying every component of his coalition is not an argument anyone's hearing - because it's been drowned out by the counterproductive gnashing and howling that he's a lying shyster. I offer this suggestion to Tony Blair. Turn down the volume. A light touch with Labour and union activists who help Livingstone would also be well-judged. A wave of mass expulsions will make a terrible tear in the Prime Minister's Big Tent. The purge - rather than what Livingstone stands for and what he would do - will be the story of the campaign. Best, too, to cease suggesting that the Government will use the London Assembly to castrate him. The more powerless they suggest Mayor Livingstone will be, the more voters will regard him as a fun-filled, risk-free ride.

A smarter way to contest with Livingstone is to start taking him seriously. Invite him to join a searching argument about what he really believes in. Names will never hurt him. Tony Blair might instead try to kill Ken with kindness. To be honest, he's that far ahead, I suspect there's no way of stopping him. But, hey, they've tried everything else.

fields.headline: The harsh reality of PR
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: When Tony Blair addressed the Parliament on the Mound last week he was defiant in the face of adversity. But he also looked a touch hurt and baffled, as if to say, 'Look, I fathered this creature and now Scotland bites me on the foot at every turn. It's just not fair.'
fields.body:
When Tony Blair addressed the Parliament on the Mound last week he was defiant in the face of adversity. But he also looked a touch hurt and baffled, as if to say, 'Look, I fathered this creature and now Scotland bites me on the foot at every turn. It's just not fair.'

Welcome to the new political culture, Prime Minister. For many comfortable years Scotland was able to blame its ills, from the big potatoes of industrial change to the small beer of potholed roads, on Westminster in general and the Tories in particular.

This week, in the first by-election of the devolution era, the Tories are expected to win Ayr. This is watershed of considerable significance. The party has not had a straight victory in any parliamentary contest north of the Border since 1992 but, in a ripe political irony, proportional representation, which it reviles intellectually, has allowed it to enter parliament via the list system, to regroup and rebrand itself, after the long Thatcher night, as a Scottish party.

It has now latched on to the populist campaign against the repeal of Section 28. But this issue alone will not explain victory this week. The Tories were traditionally strong in Ayr. What drove them out, here and elsewhere, was the Scottish political culture which blamed Thatcherism for everything.

Now the rhetoric is completely changed. The Executive is the new whipping boy. Every night on the news a spokesman, a councillor or plain Joe Public will blame it for any deficiency, perceived or real, in any Scottish public service, even if it has been responsible for its delivery only since the summer and, in some cases, may not be responsible for it at all.

The psychological effect of this shift of focus is profound. Scotland is now looking to Holyrood as its main domestic arena and the Scottish MPs at Westminster are feeling the cruel wind of neglect. Last month Brian Wilson launched an intemperate attack on Newsnight Scotland because it had the gall to ask what did the Scotland Office do these days, by the way. Last week a couple of Donald Dewar's enemies raised their heads out of the Westminster undergrowth to attack his leadership of the Executive; George Galloway went on television to say he had 'lost the plot'.

But these are the least of the First Minister's troubles. Last week the budget settlement with local government gave a striking illustration of the new political landscape. In the past this was a ritual dance in which councils blamed the London government for its parsimony. Now the source of the troubles - a settlement which will produce above-inflation rises in council tax and service cuts - may be the same: No 11 Downing Street where the subtle Mr Brown gives loudly with one hand but takes away quietly with the other.

Yet the screams of pain were directed at Finance Minister Jack McConnell; and rather ominously for the coalition one of the louder cries came from deputy First Minister Jim Wallace. His complaint was that the rural areas, the Lib Dem heartlands in other words, were scurvily treated. Similar problems are expected to arise when the distribution of funds to the NHS is recalibrated to reflect the greatest need, which of course arises in the old industrial conurbations.

Labour will almost certainly lose Ayr; they may even be beaten into third place. Dewar may privately have begun to reconcile himself to the prospect of an SNP administration, perhaps even after the next Scottish parliamentary elections. It is an inevitable result of devolution; it might even be a healthy development, testing the quality of the SNP and maturing it in the realities of power. Alex Salmond was surely right last week to reformulate his view that an electoral majority would not of itself be a mandate for independence but would trigger a referendum, even though it would be merely advisory and have no formal constitutional weight unless Westminster endorsed it.

Yet the rise of the SNP, at Holyrood though not at Westminster, looks inevitable. The same may be said for the decline of the Lib Dems. They may turn out to be the real victims of the new political culture which tars them with a share of the blame for ills foisted on them by a Labour machine which wants the appearance of devolution but not its reality.

But these are the least of the First Minister's troubles. Last week the budget settlement with local government gave a striking illustration of the new political landscape. In the past this was a ritual dance in which councils blamed the London government for its parsimony. Now the source of the troubles - a settlement which will produce above-inflation rises in council tax and service cuts - may be the same: No 11 Downing Street where the subtle Mr Brown gives loudly with one hand but takes away quietly with the other. Yet the screams of pain were directed at Finance Minister Jack McConnell; and rather ominously for the coalition one of the louder cries came from deputy First Minister Jim Wallace. His complaint was that the rural areas, the Lib Dem heartlands in other words, were scurvily treated. Similar problems are expected to arise when the distribution of funds to the NHS is recalibrated to reflect the greatest need, which of course arises in the old industrial conurbations. Labour will almost certainly lose Ayr; they may even be beaten into third place. Dewar may privately have begun to reconcile himself to the prospect of an SNP administration, perhaps even after the next Scottish parliamentary elections. It is an inevitable result of devolution; it might even be a healthy development, testing the quality of the SNP and maturing it in the realities of power. Alex Salmond was surely right last week to reformulate his view that an electoral majority would not of itself be a mandate for independence but would trigger a referendum, even though it would be merely advisory and have no formal constitutional weight unless Westminster endorsed it. Yet the rise of the SNP, at Holyrood though not at Westminster, looks inevitable. The same may be said for the decline of the Lib Dems. They may turn out to be the real victims of the new political culture which tars them with a share of the blame for ills foisted on them by a Labour machine which wants the appearance of devolution but not its reality.

fields.headline: Careless talk costs lives
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: One of the most striking things about the abduction of Mark Kelly is the silence of human-rights groups and international watchdogs.
fields.body:
As I write this, somewhere in a barn, a house or in an isolated farm, in a quiet corner of the south Armagh/north Louth border, someone is pleading for his life. He is probably blindfolded, possibly tied to a chair; his guards are armed and will kill him if the order comes through.

We hope that the man abducted from his girlfriend's home outside Armagh city earlier last week can convince his captors to release him without harm. History, however, is not on his side. The usual fate for someone kidnapped and taken for interrogation by republicans is a bullet in the back of the head, the body dumped on an unapproved road.

One of the most striking things about the abduction of Mark Kelly is the silence of human-rights groups and international watchdogs. Rosemary Nelson was barely dead in her car when the human-rights lobby was accusing the RUC of collusion and, quite correctly, demanding an international inquiry.

Yet this same lobby is curiously quiet when loyalists continue to torture and maim in their own communities and when republicans resume their shootings and abductions.

More disturbing still is the silence of the Catholic church's national leaders. Archbishop Sean Brady should be leading the appeals for Kelly's return rather than leaving it to other lone, brave voices, like the SDLP's John Fee.

The inaction of the hierarchy is reminiscent of their attitude following the IRA's murder of Andrew Kearney, when the Bishop of Down and Conor Patrick Walsh told mourners via a written statement at his funeral that what was needed was a period of silence and reflection.

The overwhelming majority of those taken to the border never came back. They were without exception labelled as informers who supposedly provided the British or Irish security services with information on terrorist organisations.

The word 'informer' demonises the victim, reducing sympathy for him or her in the eyes of the community they come from. Yet that is a narrow definition of the 'informer'. One of the most consistent defenders of human rights is the Dungannon priest Fr Denis Faul. It was Fr. Faul, following the murder of the last alleged informer Charles Bennett, who reminded people that the label 'informer' could be applied to thousands of citizens living in both states.

What else is the person who provides the personal details on the life of the police officer about to be assassinated but an 'informer'? What other word is there for someone who offers intelligence on the daily routine of the prison officer but 'informer'?

Irish society, particularly in the north, contains a vast network of amateur spies and informants who have been gathering information on their neighbours for decades, not just for the state, but also for all the main terror groups.

A former UVF leader once told me that there are hundreds of people in the north walking the streets today who don't realise how lucky they are to be alive. These people, he explained, were the subjects of prolonged intelligence gathering by his organisation and who escaped death because the 'operation' had to be called off or was compromised at the last minute.

It is a chilling thought. How many of us have been blissfully unaware that our movements were being tracked and that at any time those building up a pattern about our lives could eliminate us?

If the RUC had arrested someone on Wednesday night in a republican area, every concerned lawyer and cleric would be screaming for habeas corpus - that the police had to declare that a person was in custody.

It is a measure of the double-standards applied to the peace process by its greatest supporters that no such demands are made when it comes to those spirited away by masked men.

 Henry McDonald's new biography of David Trimble is published this month by Bloomsbury at £16.99

webTitle: Food on the table, money in the bank

fields.headline: Food on the table, money in the bank
fields.standfirst: The aisles are spanking clean, the trolleys huge, the staff cheery. And those Thai-style chicken wings are so tasty. But do you spend too much on your supermarket shop?  Rachel Fixsen looks at serious savings on grocery costs
fields.trailText: The aisles are spanking clean, the trolleys huge, the staff cheery. And those Thai-style chicken wings are so tasty. But do you spend too much on your supermarket shop?
fields.body:
Next to your rent or mortgage, your food bill may well be your largest monthly expense. But unlike the price you pay for your accommodation, it is not a fixed cost. So if you want to find some room for manoeuvre in your budget, the grocery bill could well be the place to start.

But is it possible to pare down your supermarket bill without serious self-sacrifice? Certainly: changing the way you shop could enable you to maintain the quality of your groceries, but at the same time save more than £100 a month.

As a population, we have stepped up the proportion of our income we spend on food. According to research from Mintel, food retailers did better in the five years from 1993 in terms of rising sales than the retail sector as a whole, with sales increasing by 23 per cent over the period.

'This implies that people are spending a greater proportion of their income on food,' the report's authors said. However they acknowledged that the fact that larger food retailers were widening their range of products beyond traditional core areas was an influential factor.

Rather than shopping at different shops and comparing prices, many people now restrict their shopping to one supermarket. And that supermarket has changed. Its product ranges has broadened way beyond groceries and household items: larger outlets now stock books, magazines, CDs, clothes, flowers, videos. Some have dry-cleaning facilities and banking services. 'Essentially, they've become the traditional high street under one roof,' the Consumers' Association points out in a report on supermarkets.

While we may like the choice and service offered, it is now so time consuming simply to push a trolley round the numerous aisles of a large supermarket that shoppers are reluctant to make any additional trips elsewhere. And publicity from the large chains aims to give the impression of low prices.

Asda says that thanks to its 'Rollback' price-cutting campaign, its price for an average basket of goods has come down by 18 per cent over the past year. But the jury is still out on whether the large chains do actually offer value for money.

The UK Competition Commission is conducting a monopoly inquiry into the supermarket industry, and has said it will consider measures as drastic as forcing companies to sell stores if it discovered competition problems. The hearings are taking place this month.

However, many basic products are now offered at far lower prices by discount supermarkets such as Aldi, Lidl and Netto. These are supermarket chains, often with outlets Europe-wide or even worldwide, which claim to discount prices. They can do so, they say, because of economies of scale and their bare-bones approach to the retail business. According to Consumers' Association research, prices for own-brand products at Aldi and Netto were nearly half the price of own-brand products in the most expensive main supermarket chain it looked at - Waitrose.

A spokesman for Aldi says the large chains have grown further away from what grocery shopping used to be about. 'They've made the shopping experience very complicated,' he says. 'Our basic principle is to keep our operating costs at a fraction of those of the larger chains, and have a focused range.'

Aldi and Lidl both say it is a misconception that the products they offer are poorer quality in any way than own-brand products offered by the large chains. Food retail analyst Caroline Tatham of Goldman Sachs says the larger chains reacted to the arrival of discount supermarkets seven years ago by introducing their own 'value' and 'economy' lines of basic foods to compete on price.

But the discounters say these 'economy' ranges are of much poorer quality than the products they offer. Which product actually tastes better can only be judged by the individual. But at least from a nutrition point of view, experts say there is nothing to lose by buying the cheapest brand of many basic products.

'Usually, they are almost exactly the same as the others,' says Sarah Stanner, nutrition scientist at the British Nutrition Foundation. For example, all sunflower margarines and wholemeal breads will have the same nutritional value whatever the price, unless the product actually specifies that it is trying to be healthier. Perhaps it has decreased the salt content.

'People on low incomes do tend to eat less well than other people, but the reason for that is they select different foods,' she says. 'They shy away from fresh vegetables because they perceive them to be more expensive.'

Organic foods are out of range for those on a tight budget, but at the moment, Stanner says, there is not much evidence that those consuming organic foods are better off nutritionally.

But since the discounters stock a limited range - often 500 lines compared with Tesco's 20,000 - most shoppers would have to top up with a visit to a larger supermarket or local shops.

Phil Evans of the Consumers' Association says many of the discounters appear to have entered the market before it was ready for them. Now many of the discount supermarkets are stuck in backwaters and run-down areas, effectively out of reach for more affluent shoppers.

But why are we drawn to more expensive brands when we know there is little or no difference between those products and ones with far lower price tickets?

Dr Paul Webley, professor of economic psychology at Exeter University, says that people do not choose particular brands and products for themselves, but for the way those products define them to other people.

'The brands matter because you are not just buying the taste,' he says. When you have a bottle of top-price extra virgin olive oil on your shelf next to pots of fresh herbs, these are important in terms of the message you want to give others.'

The shopper who displays such items is not simply saying they are wealthy enough to afford them, they are showing their connoisseurship, says Webley. It is like showing that you can tell the difference between Colombian and Kenyan Coffee.

Hubertus Rick, managing director of Lidl UK, agrees snobbishness is a big reason why some people steer clear of discounters. 'We had the same situation in Europe,' he says. 'People worried all their neighbours would think they were not able to afford good things.'

But customers weakened after a independent consumer tests on its products gave the discounter top marks. 'Today it's already chic to show you shop with a discounter,' says Rick.

It may not be chic here - yet. But if the savings are enough to pay for an annual skiing holiday, you could always be chic on the slopes.

webTitle: 'The Lidl mayo was a bad mistake'

fields.headline: 'The Lidl mayo was a bad mistake'
fields.standfirst: But  Rachel Fixsen is saving enough to make a difference to her pension
fields.trailText: Finding ourselves blighted by the usual cash crisis that accompanies the new year, we looked at ways we could save money. Our biggest monthly expense was food shopping. At nearly £400 a month, it was slightly more than our mortgage. But how could we reduce it?
fields.body:
Finding ourselves blighted by the usual cash crisis that accompanies the new year, we looked at ways we could save money generally. Our biggest monthly expense by far was food shopping. At nearly £400 a month, it was slightly more than our mortgage.

But how could we possibly reduce it? Since our eldest child, Jack, was born, five years ago, we had started shopping sensibly, giving up those dinky staples of expensive takeaway meals - even fresh pasta and pasta sauce were luxuries consigned to the past.

And, as we both worked from home, we were no longer stuck having to pay cafe prices for lunch.

One thing we felt we might still be paying a premium for was convenience. We were in the habit of doing a fortnightly shop at Sainsbury's. Although we suspected many items would be cheaper at a discount supermarket, we avoided shopping there because many items would be unavailable, so we would have to make two trips.

We had also grown rather used to the bright, shiny Sainsbury's stores with the friendly service and willing bag packers at the checkout. But when we thought about it, we realised we didn't like those extras so much that we wanted to pay for them.

After two friends sang the praises of nearby discount supermarket Lidl, I decided to give it a go. In comparison to shopping at Tesco or Sainsbury's it certainly was a more eastern European experience. There was only one brand - usually Lidl's own - of each type of product, and there were only four aisles.

I was suspicious of some products, which I thought would taste revolting in a cheap version - orange squash, tea and coffee. I also steered clear of meat and chicken, which conjured up hideous images of intensive farming. But how could I go wrong with orange and apple juice from concentrate, plain crisps, fruit and vegetables, butter and flour?

I got to the checkout with my loaded trolley and was ready to huff and puff about there being no one to help me pack, when the man at the till told me I had £27.30 to pay. I would have expected the same volume of groceries to cost at least £70 in a larger supermarket.

Still, I withheld judgment until I had actually tried some of the products. Standard items - orange juice and sunflower spread - were identical in taste and appearance to Sainsbury's own-brand products.

The wholemeal bread tasted the same, and though its appearance and texture were different, they were no worse.

Comparing prices later, I discovered low-fat sunflower spread had cost just 35p at Lidl, compared with 59p in Tesco; sliced wholemeal bread was 31p, compared with 55p in Sainsbury's. Orange juice was 59p for 1.5 litres, compared with Tesco's own-label price of 69p a litre.

The next time I went, I was more adventurous, buying tissues, washing-up liquid, mayonnaise, even wine. The mayonnaise was a mistake - too much vinegar - but the other products were fine. The washing-up liquid even seems more effective.

We still need to do extra shopping for meat, free-range eggs, bread, flour, tea and coffee, but for this we now make more use of our local shop. In the process I discovered its prices are, in many cases, no higher than at the large supermarket chains.

By using a discounter for most of our shopping, by becoming more aware of the prices I pay and by avoiding some excessively expensive products, we managed to cut our monthly grocery bill from £400 to £250.

At my age, these savings are enough to finance a decent pension.

webTitle: No fertilisers, pesticides or antibiotics - and no exorbitant prices

fields.headline: No fertilisers, pesticides or antibiotics - and no exorbitant prices
fields.trailText: The demand for organic food has grown rapidly in recent years, with sales rising by 40 per cent a year. The trouble is that suppliers are having a hard time keeping up, and this has kept prices in the clouds.
fields.body:
The demand for organic food has grown rapidly in recent years, with sales rising by 40 per cent a year. Worries about the dangers of pesticides and the consequences of intensive farming for animals and the entire food chain have prompted many people to choose organic produce.

The trouble is that suppliers are having a hard time keeping up, and this has kept prices in the clouds. Although the Soil Association now receives about 100 new applications every month from farmers wanting to convert, just 1.5 per cent of total UK farmland is dedicated to organic methods.

Most supermarkets now stock organic food, but the prices are still extremely high. 'Supermarkets are charging a price premium on organic foods of an average 62 per cent,' says Anna Ross, lecturer at the University of the West of England. 'At least part of this is justified by the higher production costs of organic food, but for the price-conscious consumer, alternative retail outlets can offer more competitive prices.'

Emma Parkin of the Soil Association adds: 'Organic food is seen as being more expensive, but in organic farming the costs are, we estimate, about 30 per cent higher.'

The association set up the vegetable box scheme a few years ago: here local producers or companies deliver regular boxes of organic produce to customers. There are now between 400 and 500 such schemes, says Parkin.

London-based Farm-a-Round is one such scheme. A standard vegetable box, which includes 3lb of potatoes, 1lb of carrots,onions and six other vegetable items, costs £9.20 including delivery.

'We are cheaper than the supermarkets,' says Matthew Morgan of Farm-a-Round. 'People are generally reluctant to go into the supermarkets because you hear so many conflicting stories about prices - especially with organic products.'

Old MacDonald had a market...

Already well-established in the US and Germany, farmers' markets are now taking off in the UK. They are also backed by the Soil Association, which aims to make organic food available to everyone.

The idea is that farmers sell their own fresh, local seasonal produce directly to the public - a family member must be present at the stall. The first farmers' market was started in Bath in 1997, and now there are about 200 around the country.

The main aims of farmers' markets are to achieve freshness and quality in products as well as a better deal for farmers. But Emma Parkin of the Soil Association says the produce should also be cheaper than at the supermarket, because there is no middleman. The farmers themselves decide on the prices, which are supply-driven.

But Emma Parkin of the Soil Association says the produce should also be cheaper than at the supermarket, because there is no middleman. The farmers themselves decide on the prices, which are supply-driven.

fields.headline: The watercolour of money
fields.standfirst: John Windsor  on growing demand for once-ignored English paintings
fields.trailText: Victorian landscape watercolours, once lucky to find refuge on the dusty walls of vicarages, are likely to become hot property at two major sales this week.
fields.body:
Victorian landscape watercolours, once lucky to find refuge on the dusty walls of vicarages, are likely to become hot property at two major sales this week.

The biggest private collection of them to come under the hammer for more than 20 years will be sold at Christie's next month, with 141 lots expected to be snapped up for between £500,000 and £800,000.

And the Spink-Leger gallery also launches a selling exhibition this week that hails lesser-known early 19th century watercolourists as pioneers of the Romantic revival and forerunners of Impressionism.

Victorian pictures led the art market out of the slump of the late eighties. Prices fell at the start of the next decade but reached a new peak in 1994. They did falter again, but have been rising steadily for the past four years.

In recent years the best of the watercolour landscapes have been disappearing rapidly into museums and private collections. Quality works are now in short supply and dealers and auctioneers have responded by casting their net wider.

The list of blue-chip names has now swelled from a handful - Turner, Constable, Cozens, Girtin, Cotman - to include lesser-knowns such as Cox, Hunt, De Wint, Linnell, and John Varley.

In the next few weeks, London's starved, but increasingly educated and discriminating, market for Victorian landscape watercolours is likely to put its money on two lesser- knowns artists - Cornelius Varley, 1781-1873 (at Spink-Leger) and James Watts, 1853-1930 (at Christie's).

Price tags and auction estimates indicate pictures by both artists could be bought for as little as £2,500, but if you'd hesitate to part with even the price of a second-hand family saloon for a painting, at least view what is on offer in order to get an inkling of what has lit up the trained eyes of dealers and collectors.

It has taken Lowell Libson of Spink-Leger six years to put together his selling exhibition, The Feeling Eye: The 'New' Landscape in Britain 1800-1830 . Libson began making waves in the Victorian watercolours market when he bid a whopping £51,000 at Sotheby's, way above the £12,000-£18,000 estimate, for William Hunt's watercolour The Interior of a Barn, a price record for the artists that still stands.

That was three years ago, after Spink and Leger had merged and their owner, Christie's, had entrusted Libson with a huge buying kitty. He bought the Hunt for stock, such is his confidence in his own eye.

In Hunt's early 19th century landscapes, Libson detects a breaking away from the artificial 'picturesque' style with its theatrical scenery, tasteful classical ruins and occasional nymph or shepherd. The artists in his exhibition, notably a group that congregated at the feet of John Varley, went into the open air with their paints and pencils and confronted nature in the raw - in much the way of the Lake poets.

'These landscapes struck me as personal, exciting and rewarding,' says Libson. 'They have hitherto occupied a critical backwater, dismissed as parochial, but in my opinion British landscape, especially of the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries, is the greatest contribution the British have made to Western painting. My aim was to produce a strong show to combat the prejudice that British art of the period is secondary to European.'

He leads me towards a pencil sketch of 1803 by the lesser-known Cornelius Varley, who studied under his elder brother, John. It is of the weir at Machynlleth, Wales, priced at £7,000.

Then there is Cornelius's watercolour of a cottage near Brampton, Huntingdon - price £18,000. 'See how he's got to grips with his subject,' Libson says. 'He's understood its dynamics, done all he wants to do with it.'

He props John Varley's spirited and technically accomplished watercolour of Conway Castle in front of me (£36,000). John taught a generation of maturing artists between 1803 and 1810, including Linnell, Hunt and Turner of Oxford. 'Almost spiritual,' Libson says of it.

And then I bridle at Thomas Tudor's meringue-like clouds at sunset, painted in 1810 (£2,400).'Clouds were a nineteenth-century preoccupation,' Libson says. More cloud paintings appear before me, by Cox, Linnell, James Ward and Cornelius Varley. All are Romantic, Impressionistic.

The star turn of David Fuller's collection of Victorian landscape watercolours at Christie's is the only known group of work by the late Victorian James Watts (1853-1930). There are 20 of them, mostly the shaded interiors of woodland. One, on its own, could be considered subdued, even dull. But the educated eye of Fuller, a 58 year old American-born naturalised Brit, homed in on their subtle twilight tones, atmosphere and sheer technical accomplishment.

Fuller, who is a director of EFM Technical Research, publisher of an investment newsletter, Fullermoney, began his collection in 1973.

He rescued Watts from obscurity, having briefed dealers and country auctioneers in Wales and the North of England to be on the lookout for his work.

The Watts watercolours carry estimates of between £2,000 and £6,000, but prices could be driven up.

Ominous note for would-be investors: Fuller is selling his Victorian collection in order to invest in the work of living artists. 'They're my heroes,' he says.

Victorian landscape watercolours are also for sale in Sotheby's 'The British Sale: Victorian Paintings and Watercolours', 22 March (10.30am), 34-35 New Bond Street, London W1 - inquiries (020-7293 5000); and in Agnew's annual selling exhibition of English Watercolours and Drawings, until 24 March at 43 Old Bond Street, London W1 (020-7629 6176).

'Feeling Through the Eye' is at Spink-Leger, 13 Old Bond Street, London W1, 14 March-19 April (020-7629-3538). The Fuller Collection is at Christie's, 8 King Street, London SW1, 7 April (11am), inquiries (020-7839 9060).

webTitle: A dozen tins of beans and 78 toilet rolls, please

fields.headline: A dozen tins of beans and 78 toilet rolls, please
fields.trailText: In theory, buying products in bulk should save you money. But supermarkets do not appear to encourage bulk buying: their prices for multiple products are on the whole not appreciably cheaper than buying the products individually.
fields.body:
In theory, buying products in bulk should save you money. But supermarkets do not appear to encourage bulk buying: their prices for multiple products are on the whole not appreciably cheaper than buying the products individually.

'Our customers don't really bulk buy,' says Emma Mason of Safeway. 'People probably save more money by choosing our special deals.'

The real problem with buying in bulk is storage space, which is usually at a premium in homes.

Two-for-one and three-for-two offers may be worth taking advantage of if they apply to products that you would usually buy, but all too often they can draw you into a buying a more expensive brand that you would otherwise have ignored.

At the other end of the scale, shopping economically when you live on your own can be difficult.

For a start, the amount of groceries you need is likely to be too small to warrant a trip to an out-of-town discount supermarket.

But also, it is easy to waste food, because packaged products are simply too large for one person.

Phil Evans of the Consumers Association says: 'This problem is increasingly being addressed. With the growth of the singleton, whichever retailer cracks this is going to enjoy quite a large market.'

Spending less

 Take a list

 Avoid convenience foods

 Don't go food shopping when you're hungry

 Be flexible - substitute your usual product for a similar one if that is on special offer

 Look at the price: don't assume it will be reasonable

 Learn when certain vegetables are in season - and don't buy them out of season

 Plan your meals, to avoid wasting food
