webTitle: Live the high life - above the shop

fields.headline: Live the high life - above the shop
fields.standfirst: A flat over commercial premises is no longer a no-no, writes Anne Caborn
fields.trailText: Living above the shop was common in the days when medicine came in apothecaries' jars and tea in paper twists. But the demise of traditional family businesses and the surge of modern commerce have changed that. However, things are changing.
fields.body:
Living above the shop was common in the days when medicine came in apothecaries' jars and tea in paper twists. But the demise of traditional family businesses and the surge of modern commerce have changed that.

While businesses in the high street carried on, the flats above them fell into disrepair: occasionally used for storage; rarely as a home. But things are changing.

Urban living has new fans, who can find an awful lot of space at competitive prices simply by looking upwards.

'It's a very good idea and well worth encouraging,' said Jeremy Leaf, housing market spokesman for the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors.

The return of residents can benefit the business below commercially, provide potential staff, and repopulate urban 'twilight zones': people will be interested in a local area, its upkeep and amenities. And not driving to the shops, or to work, is good for the environment.

But living above the shop has a downside. A desirable home may lose its allure if the florist downstairs closes and a fried food emporium opens in its place. You may need to talk to the local planning department about what uses are allowed in the business premises, and what has been allowed in the past.

The flat will probably be leasehold, and the lease will need checking in detail.

'I would be looking for some control in the flat lease over what is going on downstairs,' said solicitor Edward Nally of Fieldings Porter in Bolton. And it is not just a question of what type of business is below, but the shop's opening hours and any noise, smell or potentially hazardous materials.

Business premises with residential space above are generally classed as 'mixed hereditaments', and this could mean different rules covering security of tenure and your ability to renew your lease, says Nally.

The business below may also have certain rights, which could include access to the flat above to effect repairs or renovations, such as fitting a new shop sign.

'Commercial properties tend to be more responsive to change, so you will see disruption downstairs.'

Other issues that need to be looked at include security, fire precautions, separate from the shop, the probability of high traffic noise and access. You need a separate entrance, but ideally not one in a poorly lit rear service road next to the bins.

More adventurous buyers may want to purchase the entire property, including the shop, in order to provide income as well as a home. But landlord status needs to be considered carefully. And a commercial mortgage may be needed, which could be dearer and less flexible.

Traditional high street lenders are more willing to consider flats above shops than they were even a few years ago, but they will look at such properties on their merits, value and resaleability. Environmentally and politically, getting people back into empty property above shops is a good thing. Philip Venning, secretary of the Society for the Protection of Ancient Buildings, says: 'Our view is that if the property is lived in it is more likely to be looked after, and people living there are going to be more aware of problems such as leaks than the trader below.' Venning's own home is above a beauty parlour.

And the Government is keen to see these spaces come back into use. 'Towards An Urban Renaissance', a Government task force report published last year, mentioned the 'upper rooms', and took a broader view than simply the reoccupation of the estimated 26,000 empty flats above shops.

This would involve utilising vacant and underused space, even if it is not currently designated as residential. The report cited a model for bringing this about, with freeholders and commercial leaseholders dealing with housing associations which would undertake repairs and oversee occupancy.

Ann Petherick, whose Living Over the Shop project, based in York, came up with this model, believes this empty space could create, conservatively, half a million flats. But she is concerned that the Government may fail to appreciate the project's scope, along with the need for a separate organisation to mastermind it and deal with commercial landlords using 30-year commercial leases.

Ian and Charlotte Cameron and their contractors and architects recently won awards from the Surrey Historic Buildings Trust for their home and shop renovation in Dorking.

The judges said: 'The result is a project where the maximum historic fabric has been retained but the building has been revitalised.'

The Camerons originally bought the entire property next door to their current house - both the business and the derelict floors above. They created a self-contained shop and flats above.

Two-and-a-half years ago the adjoining property came on the market, and they bought that, too. Both buildings are Grade II Listed.

Ian Cameron said the second shop was in complete disarray but lettable.

'We immediately found a tenant to go straight in. The upstairs probably hadn't been lived in for 80 to 90 years. There was no electricity, no water. It was a dark, dingy and horrible mess, but there was so much character to it.'

This has now been turned into a family home for the Camerons and their daughters Alice, aged three, and six-month-old Olivia.

While not everyone may want to purchase an entire property, including the business space below, the Camerons believe the rental income obtainable can be invaluable when undertaking a major renovation.

'The rental income means the property pays its own mortgage. That's one reason for living above the shop,' said Ian Cameron. 'The second is that we don't have to get in the car to go shopping; we just fall out of the front door.'

fields.headline: What's the catch?
fields.trailText: International Special Offers has contacted Observer readers claiming that they have been chosen to receive a generous award.
fields.body:
International Special Offers has contacted Observer readers claiming that they have been chosen to receive a generous award.

'Congratulations!' says the Florida-based firm. 'You have been selected from hundreds of people in your country as one of a lucky group who will receive a brand new 1999 Vauxhall Corsa... up to £3,500 in cash... a Toshiba colour TV... a Genuine Diamond Studded Wristwatch or a Goodmans Hi-Fi/CD player in our latest special offer promotion aimed at introducing carefully chosen people to our company. Please understand that this is neither a game nor a contest. You are guaranteed to receive one or more of these valuable awards if you simply follow the instructions on your Express Award Notice and return your Award Claim Certificate to us promptly.'

Small print on the back of the letter indicates that participants stand a one in 250,000 chance of getting a TV or £1,100 in cash, a one in 750,000 chance of winning the Corsa or £3,500 in cash, and a one in 187,000 chance of getting the Mini Hi-Fi/CD player. However, if all else fails, they have a one in one chance of receiving the watch.

One reader decided the promotion was worth trying out and sent off a cheque for £20 with a completed application form. He says: 'I thought that at least I would receive the watch, a gamble as you might say. That was several weeks ago and I have not heard anything yet.'

International Special Offers (IOS) is a familiar name to the Advertising Standards Authority. In January, the ASA upheld several complaints against the firm, which included failure to state the advertiser's full address in the mailing, failure to prove that the firm's signatory in its mailing - Charles A Robertson - was a genuine employee of the firm, and the impression given to recipients from the use of his initials, CAR, in the approval code, that they had won a car.

IOS promised the ASA that the mailing would no longer appear in its original form and that changes had been made to accommodate all of the upheld complaints. It also sent the ASA a list of people who had won prizes.

However, although the new mailing received by readers is signed by a different signatory - Dennis R. Turner - the initials CAR appear in a code printed at the top of the letter, which could still mislead some recipients into believing they had been awarded the car. The firm also fails to print its address on the part of the letter kept by recipients after sending the application form back.

Chris Reed of the ASA says: 'We closed our file, but if the same claims are being made, we may well have to look into it again.'

 Seen an advertisement or mailshot that looks too good to be true? Write to What's the Catch?, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1 3ER.

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.standfirst: Farewell Miras
fields.trailText: Mortgage payments are set to rise by about £19 a month from April when Mortgage Interest Tax Relief (Miras) is abolished.
fields.body:
Mortgage payments are set to rise by about £19 a month from April when Mortgage Interest Tax Relief (Miras) is abolished. Its abolition will add more than £230 a year to payments for homeowners with standard variable rate mortgages of £30,000 or more - equivalent to a 0.3 per cent rise in mortgage rates.

The Halifax, the UK's biggest mortgage lender, does not expect the axing of Miras to have much effect on spiralling house prices, but adds: 'Regions where house prices are lowest and where tax relief therefore makes up a larger proportion of the mortgage will bear the brunt of the change.

'The housing markets in Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland and most northerly English regions will be most affected, with the greatest impact on first-time buyers.'

The tax relief is applied to interest charged on the first £30,000 of any homeloan, effectively reducing the amount of interest a mortgage borrower has to pay.

Rumours on duty

With a rise in mortgage costs on the way from the axing of mortgage interest tax relief, homeowners will be relieved that the Bank of England held interest rates last week.

Speculation continues to build, however, that stamp duty on house purchases will rise in the Budget, to take some of the heat out of the housing market. People in the throes of buying may be advised to try to exchange contracts before Budget day, Tuesday 21 March.

Stamp duty starts at 1 per cent on properties worth £60,000 to £250,000 and then rises to 3.5 per cent on homes worth more than £500,000, so any increases could add thousands to the cost of a purchase.

Endowment help

A NEW valuation and information service has been set up to help people who have unwanted endowment policies. The Endowment Price Research Agency has a leaflet outlining the options for offloading an endowment, including assigning the policy to a partner if the policy is owned by a divorcing couple.

The agency will also obtain valuations from dealers to obtain higher prices than available from insurers for surrender. Tel: 01788 510311/510011 or visit: www.endowmentsales.co.uk

Techs fancied

Private investors' fascination with technology stocks has been confirmed by the latest new business figures from discount broker Torquil Clark. Six of the top 10 selling funds over the past year were technology funds. Jupiter Global Technology comprised 21 per cent of Isas sold by Torquil Clark, while technology funds generally accounted for 40 per cent.

Tom McPhail of Torquil Clark points out that most equity-based growth funds contain a reasonable proportion of technology stocks, and that investment in pure funds could be unbalancing investors' portfolios: 'People are losing sight of risk management. They should try to remember their overall risk strategy and not get too carried away by the current craze for technology stocks.

'People who have been in technology funds for the past year may want to think about taking profits now.'

Its abolition will add more than £230 a year to payments for homeowners with standard variable rate mortgages of £30,000 or more - equivalent to a 0.3 per cent rise in mortgage rates. fields.body:
Prizes have now been awarded in the first round of our Investor of the Year 2000 competition, sponsored by Fleming Asset Management and run in conjunction with our sister publication Money Observer.

The first prize fund covers the performance of the 30 shares in the competition over both January and February. The correct combination of top-performing shares was: Reuters Group (number 23 on your original entry coupon); WPP Group (30); Blue Circle Industries (5); Vodafone AirTouch (29) and EMI Group (12). The five produced an average gain of 26.2 per cent - not bad given that overall, only eight of the 30 shares managed to record a gain during January and February.

As so often seems to happen with our first prize of the year, many people managed to select all five correct shares. However, only seven of them managed to select the correct tie-breaker - that eight shares would end January and February in positive territory from their 4 January starting prices.

As stated in the rules to the competition, the editor has decided to split the entire monthly prize fund of £1,000 between all seven winners. This means each individual will pocket a cheque for £142.

The seven winners are John Byrne from London; Mr I. Pujara from Eastbourne; Robert Kidd from Stockton-on-Tees; Matt Evans from Somerset; Martin Morrison from Southend-on-Sea; Mrs P. Fahy from Essex and Sean Kavanagh from Kent.

Sharing the prize fund is a rare occurrence and usually only happens in the first month as entrants had so long to watch the market before entering the contest.

Finally, Investor of the Year 2000 competitors should note that we had hundreds of claims for the prizes last week but there is actually no need to do so this year. Our computer now selects the winners automatically and we will then notify them of their success.

The next prizes will be awarded for the best share price performance in March and details will appear in Cash on 2 April.

fields.headline: New scientist in old dilemma
fields.standfirst: Should I pay off my student loan or buy a car, Mike Lovelady asks  Helen Pridham
fields.trailText: Some people may be making their fortunes from the Internet, but backroom scientist Mike Lovelady is still working out the best way to make ends meet. His dilemma is whether he should pay off his debts or take out another loan and buy a decent car.
fields.body:
Name: Mike Lovelady

Age: 26

Lives in: Loughton, Essex

Occupation: Research and development scientist

Earns: £21,500

Mortgage: None

Debts: £3,000 student loan

Investments: Contributes 3% of earnings (around £50 a month) to company share save scheme

Pension: Member of company scheme

Aims: Pay off debts and buy new car

Some people may be making their fortunes from the Internet, but backroom scientist Mike Lovelady is still working out the best way to make ends meet. His dilemma is whether he should pay off his debts or take out another loan and buy a decent car.

He studied opto-electronics and laser systems at Hull University and until recently was working on his MPhil, researching next-generation Internet technology, involving optical fibres. His course, while officially at Loughborough University, was done as a work placement. He has now been taken on full time.

Like many, Lovelady has a student loan to repay, and now that he has a reasonable salary he is trying to get his finances straight. He is a member of a final salary pension scheme at work, to which he contributes 5 per cent. He is also saving through the company's share save scheme. He pays 3 per cent of his earnings to this and his employer tops it up with another 1.5 per cent.

He is living in rented accommodation,which costs £370 a month.

He doesn't see himself getting on to the property ladder for a few years - he is hoping to move around with his job at home and abroad. By that time he believes his salary will have risen and the 'stupid house prices at the moment will level off'.

Apart from rent, other regular bills include £60 a month for mobile phone and car insurance and £80 for his student loan. This leaves him with around £800 a month. He received a small inheritance on the death of his father last year, which enabled him to pay off a £3,000 credit card debt, but he still has £4,000 and is thinking of borrowing another £5,000 to enable him to buy a car for £9,000.

'I need a car to drive to work, and this money would enable me to buy a decent V reg. I cannot buy a small car because of my height [6ft 3in] and I do not really want to get a cheaper one. I did this three years ago and it ended costing me £3,000 in one-off payments.

'My question is this: am I being incredibly stupid getting into more debt rather than paying off my student loan?'

Adviser 1: Charles Levett-Scrivener

The rate of interest on a student loan is equal to the retail price index, so the loan will be charged at 2.1 per cent until 31 August. These loans can be repaid over 60 or 80 months, depending on how many have been arranged.

It is not possible to borrow for any consumer purpose at this rate of interest.

So Mike should take as long as the rules allow to to repay his student loan. Any spare funds he has available as a result can either be put towards buying his new car or, for example, saving for a deposit for whenever he does decide to purchase a home.

When arranging a consumer loan, the only way to get the best deal is to shop around. Sometimes car dealerships offer good rates, but these are possibly linked to above-average car prices. Affinity groups are another possibility. For example, Mike's old university may provide a facility for graduates to obtain personal loans at a reduced rate. Some employers offer such facilities, or Mike may be able to find a competitive deal on the Internet.

I believe Mike is probably wise to wait before buying a home. It is best for buyers to have reasonably clear career prospects for two years ahead before embarking on house purchase. This will also give him a chance to save. It is important for prospective homebuyers to have a deposit of 5 per cent of the purchase price and to be able to pay general expenses such as stamp duty. The better loan deals are usually available to borrowers with a deposit. All first-time buyers should arrange their loan on a 'repayment' basis.

 Charles Levett-Scrivener works for independent financial adviser Towry Law

Adviser 2: Sharon Linnard

Mike's decision to retain the student loan for now seems reasonable, as it is comparatively cheap.

After his unfortunate experience with his existing car, buying one still under warranty would make good sense. The nearly-new car market is in the doldrums, and there are good deals about.

The funding of this vehicle will depend on its cost and what finance arrangements are offered. Some dealers offer nil-interest finance. It would be best to shop around.

If favourable terms are not available from the car dealer, Mike should consider the plentiful loan offers around. Rather than plump for his credit card, which would be convenient but expensive, he should speak to a selection of banks and building societies to find the cheapest personal loan.

Bear in mind any penalties for repaying this type of loan early.

Insurance may be offered with the loan to cover redundancy and sickness or death. People often feel such cover is expensive and unnecessary, but it should not be ignored, especially if salary continuance in the event of disability is not provided by Mike's employer.

In selecting a car, he should consider not only the price, but running costs such as fuel, insurance and servicing. Such aspects are often overlooked in the euphoria of acquiring a new vehicle.

Any surplus funds could be held in a cash Isa. The balance built up could become a house deposit when Mike is clearer on where his career is going.

 Sharon Linnard works for chartered accountant KPMG

Advice is for guidance only.

Write, including daytime and evening telephone numbers, a brief list of circumstances and any investments, to: Wealthcheck, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or e-mail:cash@observer.co.uk You must be prepared to be interviewed and photographed.

webTitle: Banks' u-turn hides charge hike ploy

fields.headline: Banks' u-turn hides charge hike ploy
fields.trailText: Banks garnered a few favourable headlines last week in the cash machine row by magnanimously agreeing to drop 'disloyalty' charges that would have led to swingeing double charging under the new regime planned to maintain the cash machine network.
fields.body:
Banks garnered a few favourable headlines last week in the cash machine row by magnanimously agreeing to drop 'disloyalty' charges that would have led to swingeing double charging under the new regime planned to maintain the cash machine network.

But, with Barclays and others still plumping for sur charges beyond the 30p-a-time that it really costs, there is still a danger banks will overcharge when another organisation's customer wants to use its machines.

The big banking groups are in a prime position to exploit the monopoly they have in areas where there are no other machines. They will be able to use their large networks as a selling point for their current accounts, putting the squeeze on smaller competitors.

The Labour Government is having a shot at the Black Economy and its approach appears serious; it is considering adopting powers to search people's bank accounts for evidence of benefit fraud and tax evasion.

Such a Big Brother-ish approach might unearth evidence of fraud and act as a deterrent, but most people will find it distasteful and determined fraudsters are, anyway, adept at hiding the spoils of their toil. Small-time fiddlers, or people who make mistakes on complex social security or Inland Rev enue forms are more likely to fall foul of Government snooping. A taxation and social security system as complex as ours is a gift to the talented fraudster and a disaster for the financially innocent or inept.

Politicians should look into their own backyards before they start looking over our fences.

fields.headline: Questions
fields.standfirst: Premium bonds
fields.trailText: Premium bonds.
fields.body:
Is there any point hanging on to the £1 bond my grandmother gave me when I was seven?

Unless you want the cash back, you may as well. One patient person with a £1 bond bought in January 1967 won £50,000 in the February draw. Besides, the odds of winning a prize have just got better.

What are the odds?

Since the March draw, every bond has an equal chance of one in 21,000 of winning a prize; from May this year the odds will shorten to one in 20,000.

How many prizes are there?

It depends on the size of the prize fund, which in turn depends on the number of bonds eligible for that month's draw and the prize fund rate (which is set by National Savings). This is currently 3.75 per, cent rising to 4 per cent in May and 4.25 per cent in June. The more bonds there are and the higher the prize fund rate, the greater the number of prizes. But there is always only one prize of £1 million.

What are my chances of becoming a millionaire?

With a £1 holding, one in 13.53 billion, which is a lot worse than the odds of winning the Lottery jackpot. But at least you don't lose your stake if your number doesn't come up.

How can I improve my chances of winning?

Buy more bonds. The minimum amount you can invest in premium bonds, £100, gives you a chance of one in 135.35 million of winning the jackpot. Invest the maximum £20,000 and the odds come down to one in 676,744.

Is it really worth tying up that amount of money just for a gamble?

National Savings prefers to call it 'serious fun' and says someone with a £20,000 holding and average luck could expect to win 12 prizes a year. Assuming you won 10 £50 prizes and a couple worth £100, the rate of return on your £20,000 'investment' would be a tax-free 3.5 per cent - equivalent to 4.38 per cent before tax for a 20 per cent-rate taxpayer, and 5.83 per cent for a higher-rate taxpayer.

What if my luck is worse than average?

You would win fewer than 12 prizes a year and the rate of return would be lower. It is possible that someone with the maximum holding could win nothing, although this has yet to happen. But if you won just one £5,000 prize a year, you would have a rate of return of 25 per cent.

Could I have won a prize and not know about it?

It's possible - there are over 300,000 prizes worth more than £18m waiting to be claimed. You can check at a main post office or by entering your bondholder's number at www.nationalsavings.co.uk. If you change your name or address, fill in Part B of your Bond Holder's card or write to: Premium Bonds, National Savings, Blackpool FY3 9YP.

So I might be an Ernie millionaire?

No, the highest unclaimed prize is £25,000. And anyway, nobody with just a £1 holding has ever won a million - but there's always a first time.

webTitle: Fed up? It could be time to switch

fields.headline: Fed up? It could be time to switch
fields.standfirst: Maria Scott  sets out ground rules
fields.trailText: The row over cash machine charges may be the last straw for people who are dissatisfied with their banks.
fields.body:
The row over cash machine charges may be the last straw for people who are dissatisfied with their banks.

This could be the time to consider switching accounts. While you may feel like biting the bullet now, it could be worth waiting a while to see how the cash machine row shakes down.

Banks agreed last week to scrap disloyalty charges - the fees many charge when a customer uses another bank's machines - to avoid double charging. From January, disloyalty fees will be replaced by surcharges at many machines if you are not a customer of the bank owning them.

The issue that has yet to be resolved, however, is how much the banks will take in surcharges. If you are shopping for a current account, it is still possible to join a bank that charges nothing for cash machine withdrawals, regardless of whether the machine is owned by that bank or another.

Banks that don't charge include Nationwide, Co-op, Royal Bank of Scotland and Bank of Scotland. But the future of their charging structures is uncertain. It could be that, if banks such as Barclays impose charges on machines of more than 30p, these banks will be forced to pass on at least some of the cost to customers.

Note that the banks offering free cash machine access at present are among those participating in a pilot project aimed at making it easier for people to switch accounts. In the pilot, banks agree, on opening new accounts, to transfer all direct debits and standing orders for you. Participating banks are Abbey National; Nationwide, Halifax; Woolwich; Ulster Bank; Virgin One; First Direct; Yorkshire, Clydesdale & Northern Bank.

Brian Capon, spokesman for the British Bankers Association, suggests the following guidelines when choosing a new bank:

 Write a checklist of services you want. 'This could include, for instance, a free overdraft facility or buffer zone in case you go overdrawn, a local bank branch, free access to cash machines, or availability of telephone or Internet access to your account.'

 If you want to use a branch regularly, visit a selection at about the time you would normally use it. Are there long queues? Are sufficient counter positions open?

 If you want to keep your main current account at one bank, savings at another and credit card somewhere else, consider how quickly you can transfer money between accounts.

Also, give your employer details of your new bank account immediately after the last salary payment goes to the old account. It may be worth negotiating an overdraft with the new bank in case money does not arrive in the new account as planned.

Don't close the old account until you know the new account is working smoothly.

 Pub and leisure company Scottish & Newcastle Retail is extending cashback at pubs. By the end of the year, customers spending £2 or more can cash a cheque up to £50. The facility will be available in 80 per cent of S&N's pubs, which include Chef & Brewer, Bar 38 outlets and the Rat & Parrot chain.

'This could include, for instance, a free overdraft facility or buffer zone in case you go overdrawn, a local bank branch, free access to cash machines, or availability of telephone or Internet access to your account.'  If you want to use a branch regularly, visit a selection at about the time you would normally use it. Are there long queues? Are sufficient counter positions open?  If you want to keep your main current account at one bank, savings at another and credit card somewhere else, consider how quickly you can transfer money between accounts. Also, give your employer details of your new bank account immediately after the last salary payment goes to the old account. It may be worth negotiating an overdraft with the new bank in case money does not arrive in the new account as planned. Don't close the old account until you know the new account is working smoothly.  Pub and leisure company Scottish & Newcastle Retail is extending cashback at pubs. By the end of the year, customers spending £2 or more can cash a cheque up to £50. The facility will be available in 80 per cent of S&N's pubs, which include Chef & Brewer, Bar 38 outlets and the Rat & Parrot chain.

webTitle: Taxing times indeed for us as the rules they are a'changing

fields.headline: Taxing times indeed for us as the rules they are a'changing
fields.standfirst: In the first part of our end-of-tax-year special,  David Hunt  suggests we give our finances a 'clean-out' ahead of any Budget changes
fields.trailText: With a Budget just nine days away and the end of the tax year approaching, savers and investors should think seriously about giving their financial affairs a spring clean. If you do nothing, certain tax exemptions could be lost forever.
fields.body:
With a Budget just nine days away and the end of the tax year approaching, savers and investors should think seriously about giving their financial affairs a spring clean. If you do nothing, certain tax exemptions could be lost forever.

Some changes have already been announced.

From 6 April, Miras (Mortgage Interest Relief at Source) disappears; there will also be another 1 per cent cut in the basic rate of income tax. The married couple's allowance and the married couple's age allowance for couples who are not yet 65 also disappear.

On the investment front, the Isa regime will be pruned back. Until 5 April a maximum £7,000 can be invested in stocks and shares within a maxi Isa, but this will be cut to £5,000 for the next tax year, starting on April 6. Likewise the cash limit will drop from £3,000 to £1,000.

These are changes we already know about. But what about those the Chancellor may impose on 21 March?

Despite rumblings of discontent about the complexity of the Isa rules, and the rumoured 50,000 people who have broken them, the chances of Gordon Brown tinkering in this area are slim. 'We don't envisage changes to the Isa rules before the first full year has been completed,' says Anne McMeehan, director of communications at the Association of Unit Trusts and Investment Funds (Autif).

'It will take time for the Treasury to analyse the investment data, so we wouldn't expect changes before October at the earliest. It's just possible they might do something about the investment levels in the second year - after all £5,000 is not easily divisible by 12 for regular savers - but the only things we have been talking to the authorities about are some technical issues concerning stamp duty and Cat standards.'

Martin Sherwood of stockbroker Teather & Greenwood agrees that things are unlikely to change on the Isa front, but he has heard rumours of CGT changes. 'I've heard the level could be reduced from 40 per cent to the basic 20 per cent.' He hastens to add however, that at this time of year, all sources of information are 'equally unreliable'.

Sherwood gives more weight to rumours about a tightening on the pensions front. 'People are expecting crackdowns on the tax relief on pension contributions - along with the disappearance of current carry-forward provisions.'

At present, if you had relevant earnings in all, or any, of the past six years and did not pay maximum contributions, you can 'carry forward' this unused relief. Similarly, if you did not pay the maximum permissible contribution in the previous year, you can pay a contribution in the current tax year and elect to have it 'carried back'. But, with the introduction of stakeholder pensions from April 2001, the carry-forward provisions will go, although people will still be able to carry back one year.

The abolition of higher-rate tax-relief on pension contributions has been predicted every year for at least a decade, and many believe it is just the pensions companies trying to drum up business. The rumour has emerged again this year: now the stakeholder being used as the excuse. Martyn Laverick of independent financial adviser Chartwell suggests the £3,600 stakeholder allowance 'may just become the benchmark for the maximum allowance anyone gets for tax-relief purposes'.

Another area where the Chancellor may make a move is in Inheritance Tax. 'The tax-free ceiling (currently £231,000) will proba bly be raised again in line with inflation,' suggests Sherwood, 'but Brown may be more radical this year.'

Clive Scott Hopkins, of retirement specialist Towry Law, says his best guess is that IHT reform will be postponed until the next parliament, because Brown does not want to upset Middle England. 'But he may just raise the nil rate band to £300,000, and then offset this by extending the gift period from seven to 10 years and abolish potentially exempt transfers [Pets],' he says.

Most of the experts believe rumours about a rise in stamp duty from 0.5 per cent to 1.0 per cent to counter the rise in house prices, but overall they are predicting a fairly quiet Budget on the savings and investment front.

All agree, however, on the basic message: take advantage of existing tax breaks because they are unlikely to get any more generous.

fields.headline: A pension, too? Thank you
fields.standfirst: Some people think they will get a raw deal with company schemes but that is far from the truth.  Helen Pridham  details their benefits
fields.trailText: If you are offered the opportunity to join a company pension scheme, the many advantages involved mean you should nearly always accept.
fields.body:
If you are offered the opportunity to join a company pension scheme, the many advantages involved mean you should nearly always accept.

Your employer will usually foot the costs of running the scheme, and in most cases will be contributing on your behalf as well.

Also, you qualify for tax-relief on your main scheme contributions, and also on any extra savings you make in the form of additional voluntary contributions (AVCs).

Yet many people still fail to appreciate what a good deal they are getting when they are offered membership of a company pension scheme. They sometimes even resent being asked to contribute 4 or 5 per cent of their salary to it. This is usually because they have not taken into account the value of their employer's payment towards their pension. This contribution will usually be at least as much as theirs, and can be more than double the amount. It means an employee who is being asked to contribute, say, £1,000 of his salary to a company scheme will find the total amount being paid into his pension, including his employer's contribution, could be as much as £3,000, at a net cost to him after basic rate tax relief of 23 per cent of just £770.

Despite this advantage, recent figures from the National Association of Pension Funds (NAPF) show about 15 per cent of eligible employees are turning down membership of company pension schemes. Even though, as Anne Robinson, director-general of the NAPF, says: 'Employees who don't join are effectively voting themselves a pay decrease.'

However, becoming a member of a company scheme does not necessarily mean all your pension worries are over.

Unless you stay with the same employer throughout your working life, you are unlikely to end up with the maximum occupational pension of two-thirds of final salary. And most people, unless they work in the public sector such as the NHS or the teaching profession, change jobs about five times during their working lives, often moving between pensionable and non-pensionable employment.

This is why making extra savings to boost your pension through additional voluntary contributions (AVCs) is usually a good idea. There is plenty of scope for making these contributions, as you are allowed to put a total of 15 per cent of your annual earnings towards your pension. So if your main scheme contribution is, say, 4 per cent, you can save a further 11 per cent in an AVC.

Your main scheme contribution may not count all your income either. For example, overtime or bonuses may not be taken into account for the main scheme, nor the value of fringe benefits such as company cars or medical expenses cover. However, these can be included when you are calculating how much you can put into an AVC.

All pension schemes must offer an AVC facility. These are usually run by outside organisations such as insurance companies and building societies. Although it is also possible to take out freestanding AVCs (FSAVCs) independently, it is usually most cost-effective to use your in-house scheme for regular savings, because the admin and running costs are covered by your employer.

However, if you want to make a one-off lump sum contribution, there are also some low-cost FSAVCs available, such as those offered by Fleming, Marks & Spencer and Professional Life.

webTitle: Grab a bigger Isa while it's  still on offer

fields.headline: Grab a bigger Isa while it's  still on offer
fields.standfirst: Rachel Fixsen gives a guide to the current tax-free savings rules - and how they'll change
fields.trailText: This is the first and last tax year in which you can invest up to £7,000 in a tax-efficient individual savings account (Isa).
fields.body:
This is the first and last tax year in which you can invest up to £7,000 in a tax-efficient individual savings account (Isa). Isas can hold three different types of asset -- cash, insurance and stocks and shares. Up to £3,000 (£1,000 from 6 April) can be invested in cash, up to £1,000 in insur ance and the balance in stocks and shares. Alternatively, the whole £7,000 allowance can be invested in stocks and shares (£5,000 from 6 April). You can invest all your allowance in a maxi Isa, managed by just one provider, or split the different investment components between different providers by taking out separate mini Isas. In addition, you can transfer the capital - up to a maximum of £9,000 - from a maturing Tessa to a Tessa-only Isa.

Returns earned within the Isa tax shelter are free from income and capital gains tax, which makes it a valuable tool for tax planning. Below, we explain how each type of Isa works and which providers offer the best value:

Cash Isas

If you have cash savings, it is worth having them in a cash Isa. All interest earned is free of tax, and some accounts pay 7 per cent or more.

It may seem sensible to choose the account paying the highest rate of interest, but some of these accounts operate notice periods, requiring 30 or 90 days' warning before you withdraw cash, while some limit the number of withdrawals you can make each year.

The account currently paying the highest rate of interest is available only to people with access to the Internet. Smile, the Internet banking division owned by Co-op Bank, is paying 7.25 per cent on its instant access Cat-marked mini cash Isa. However, the Leeds & Holbeck instant access Isa pays 7.05 per cent gross and has no penalties for withdrawing money. It also offers a fixed- rate version, also paying 7.05 per cent for three years. However, your money is tied in for the full three years, and you will incur 90 days' loss of interest if you demand access earlier.

Insurance Isas

This is the most ignored element of the Isa package. An insurance Isa is similar to a with-profits bond - an investment stake in a with-profits fund run by a life assurance company - except returns earned are free of income and capital gains tax.

The annual investment limit is just £1,000, and the choice is limited, with only 11 providers offering insurance Isas. However, some advisers believe this is a viable option for someone who wants exposure to stock market investment without too much risk.

Norwich Union offers a mini insurance Isa, with a minimum of £500 for single premiums, and a monthly savings limit of £25. You can choose between four funds - with profits, UK ordinary share, European and Managed.

The Druids Sheffield Friendly Society Insurance Isa, which has a minimum monthly investment of £5, meets the standard required for a Cat-marked insurance Isa. To qualify as a Cat-marked product, an insurance Isa must have annual charges of less than 3 per cent, and no other charges.

The minimum premium must be no more than £250 a year or £25 a month, its surrender values should reflect the value of the underlying assets, and after three years the surrender value must be at least equal to the premiums paid.

Sixty per cent of the money invested in the Druids Sheffield Friendly Society Insurance Isa goes into a British Government Securities fund, with the rest in property and a little in UK equities.

Tessa-only Isas

Up to £9,000 capital - no interest - from a maturing Tessa (Tax Exempt Special Savings Account) can be transferred to a Tessa-only Isa.

Money can be held in a Tessa-only account indefinitely, enabling you to keep earning interest on your capital free of tax. It pays to shop around as rates vary.

On an investment of £3,000, according to Moneyfacts, the Newcastle Building Society pays 5.05 per cent, while the Mercantile Building Society is paying 7.25 per cent on the same balance.

Stocks and shares Isas

If you can afford to invest money for a long period of time, most financial advisers would advocate using your full £7,000 Isa allowance to invest in stocks and shares.

Over the long term, they have produced far higher returns than cash.Returns earned with the Isa are free from income and capital gains tax, and until April 2004, investors can reclaim a tax credit worth 10 per cent on dividends.

The investment rules for equity-based Isas are relaxed - you can shelter shares, bonds, unit trusts, investment trusts and Oeics - and you can invest almost anywhere in the world. This presents investors with a major problem - how to choose an investment for inclusion.

Patrick Connolly of Bath independent financial adviser Chartwell recommends the Save & Prosper Premier Equity Growth fund, which invests in UK blue chip stocks. 'It is the only fund that has beaten the FTSE All-Share Index in each of the past seven years,' he says.

For investors seeking income, he points to the Mercury High Income Bond fund, which yields 8.2 per cent gross. The fund is run by Merrill Lynch, which is one of world's biggest investors in high-yield stocks.

For very cautious investors, Kim North recommends an equity Isa with a capital guarantee, such as the Scottish Widows Sheltered Growth unit trust within its Safety Plus Isa. Investors prepared to tolerate some risk could choose Legal & General's UK Index Tracking Isa, which emulates the performance of the FTSE Allshare index.

And for those who want to spread their money around the world's stock markets, she suggests the Invesco Global Dynamic Theme fund. In the past three months, a £1,000 investment in this fund would have grown to £1,193, according to Moneyfacts.

For further information contact: Smile: www.smile.co.uk

webTitle: Plot your retirement - or pay for it

fields.headline: Plot your retirement - or pay for it
fields.standfirst: By acting quickly on pension contributions, writes  Helen Pridham,  you can save a lot of money - and stress
fields.trailText: Contributing to a pension is one of the most tax-efficient forms of saving. Yet few people use their pension allowances to the full; some don't use them at all.
fields.body:
Personal pensions

Age at start of maximum contributions

Tax year % of earnings*

up to 35 17.5 per cent

36-45 20 per cent

46-50 25 per cent

51-55 30 per cent

56-60 35 per cent

over 60 40 per cent

*The maximum income on which contributions can be based in the current tax year is £90,600 a year.

Contributing to a pension is one of the most tax-efficient forms of saving. Yet few people use their pension allowances to the full; some don't use them at all.

Pension experts warn that delaying the start of your retirement could be costly. Just a year's wait before starting a pension can reduce the value of your fund at retirement by thousands of pounds because of the loss of the compounded investment returns on your pre miums. It also means you pay more tax than you need to because when you make pension contributions the tax man hands you back some income tax. At the current basic rate of 23 per cent, the taxman adds nearly £1 to every £3 you save, while for higher-rate taxpayers, the boost is even greater.

Other tax advantages of pensions are that your savings are invested in virtually tax-free funds and, at retirement, you can take part of your benefits as a tax-free lump sum.

The Government hopes people will start using their contribution allowances to the full when it introduces low-cost stakeholder pensions in April 2001. Stakeholder pension schemes will be very similar to existing personal pensions. Both are designed for the self-employed and for employees who are not members of company pension schemes. In each case, savings build up into a pension 'pot' which can be converted into a regular pension at retirement through the purchase of an annuity.

The problem with personal pensions in the past has been their lack of flexibility and high charges, but many companies have pruned costs and introduced 'stakeholder-friendly' schemes. These will enable savers to switch to a stake holder scheme next year at no penalty if they wish. Among the cheapest and most flexible are those offered by Marks & Spencer, Virgin Direct, Eagle Star Direct, Friends Provident and Tesco Life.

This has not stopped a 3 per cent fall in the number of personal pensions sold over the past year, which the Association of British Insurers (ABI) blames on the uncertainty about stakeholder schemes. But Margaret Craig, pensions expert at Standard Life, says: 'Our research has shown there is always a tendency for people to put off starting their pension, even though they know they need one. It is unfortunate, as any delay can cost them dearly in the long run and means they will miss out on valuable tax relief.'

The amount you can save each year in a personal pension varies according to your age and earnings, as shown in the table. Up to age 35, for example, you can contribute a maximum of 17.5 per cent of your pay. In other words, if you are 30 and on average earnings of around £20,000 a year, you could contribute £3,500 to your pension or just under £300 a month. This is approximately what you would need to save to build up a pension of three quarters of your current earnings, and most people are contributing much less than this. According to the ABI, the average new contribution is only £78 a month.

Although many people can afford to save more than they do, a pension may not be suitable for everybody. If you are on a low income you could unnecessarily disqualify yourself from receiving valuable means-tested pension benefits when you get to retirement if you build up your own pension. In this situation it is important that you seek professional advice.

In each case, savings build up into a pension 'pot' which can be converted into a regular pension at retirement through the purchase of an annuity. The problem with personal pensions in the past has been their lack of flexibility and high charges, but many companies have pruned costs and introduced 'stakeholder-friendly' schemes. These will enable savers to switch to a stake holder scheme next year at no penalty if they wish. Among the cheapest and most flexible are those offered by Marks & Spencer, Virgin Direct, Eagle Star Direct, Friends Provident and Tesco Life. This has not stopped a 3 per cent fall in the number of personal pensions sold over the past year, which the Association of British Insurers (ABI) blames on the uncertainty about stakeholder schemes. But Margaret Craig, pensions expert at Standard Life, says: 'Our research has shown there is always a tendency for people to put off starting their pension, even though they know they need one. It is unfortunate, as any delay can cost them dearly in the long run and means they will miss out on valuable tax relief.' The amount you can save each year in a personal pension varies according to your age and earnings, as shown in the table. Up to age 35, for example, you can contribute a maximum of 17.5 per cent of your pay. In other words, if you are 30 and on average earnings of around £20,000 a year, you could contribute £3,500 to your pension or just under £300 a month. This is approximately what you would need to save to build up a pension of three quarters of your current earnings, and most people are contributing much less than this. According to the ABI, the average new contribution is only £78 a month. Although many people can afford to save more than they do, a pension may not be suitable for everybody. If you are on a low income you could unnecessarily disqualify yourself from receiving valuable means-tested pension benefits when you get to retirement if you build up your own pension. In this situation it is important that you seek professional advice.

webTitle: For these reliefs, much thanks  - and how to avoid new traps

fields.headline: For these reliefs, much thanks  - and how to avoid new traps
fields.standfirst: Rachel Fixsen  checks out the many ways you can go about legally reducing your income tax bill this year
fields.trailText: Rachel Fixsen checks out the many ways you can go about legally reducing your income tax bill this year.
fields.body:
How far would you go to avoid paying tax?

You may well disapprove of disguising your assets as an offshore trust or claiming the cost of your family's Christmas celebrations as a business expense but many people pay tax they do not owe simply because they do not understand the rules. Research by IFA Promotion indicates that eight out of every 10 adults in the UK will pay too much tax this year. This equates to unnecessary tax payments totalling £5.8 billion or an average of £160 per person.

By taking the simple steps suggested in the following sections, you can make the most of your annual tax allowances and save hundreds, perhaps thousands, of pounds.

Bed and breakfasting

Bed and breakfasting is the name given to a method of minimising your capital gains tax liability. You make a capital gain when you sell an investment which has increased in value since you bought it. Capital gains tax is payable to the Inland Revenue at a rate of either 20 per cent for basic-rate taxpayers or 40 per cent for higher-rate payers on capital gains over a certain threshold each year. Every adult has a capital gains tax allowance, and this year it is £7,100.

In the past, 'bed and breakfasting' an investment involved selling it to crys tallise any gain and almost immediately buying the same investment back again. The idea was to make the most of each year's CGT allowance by realising capital gains annually, rather than allowing them to build up and therefore incurring tax when they exceed the annual allowance.

However, the Labour government outlawed this form of bed and breakfasting from April 1998. Now investors have to wait 30 days to reinvest, otherwise it is assumed by the Inland Revenue that the investment was not sold at all. With fast moving investments - such as technology stocks - this can mean you miss out on a lot of growth while waiting to buy back in.

But there is a legal alternative - sell the investment to realise the capital gain, but reinvest the money in a different investment. Or, alternatively, a married person can sell an investment and the spouse can reinvest the proceeds in the same investment. 'This is one of the few remaining fiscal advantages of being married,' says John Battersby, tax partner at accountant KPMG.

For most smaller investors, capital gains fall within their annual CGT allowance, so it is only when an investor has a portfolio of £50,000 or more that bed and breakfasting may be worth considering. It is unnecessary for investments held within personal equity plans and Individual Savings Accounts, as they are free of capital gains tax anyway.

Registering to receive your interest gross

More than 8 million people in the UK could save an average of £60 in tax on their bank and building society accounts by simply filling in a form.

Income tax at the rate of 20 per cent is deducted from all bank and building society accounts, but if you are a non-taxpayer, you are entitled to receive your interest gross. Ask for form R85 at your savings institution and fill it in.

Many housewives and children do not realise this option is open to them and end up paying tax unnecessarily, says Julie Lord of Cardiff adviser Cavendish Financial Management.

However, if you have forgotten to register for gross interest, all is not lost. 'You can still reclaim up to six years' worth of tax - it's very straightforward,' says Lord. Savers should request a tax reclaim form from the Inland Revenue.

Within families, people can save themselves tax by making sure that savings are in the name of non-taxpayers, such as a non-earning spouse. In that situation there can be quite a lot of tax to be saved, with the rate falling from a maximum of 40 per cent to zero.

Retrospective claims of personal allowance

People often miss out on the benefits of tax-free allowances because they have been given the wrong tax code by the Inland Revenue.

Allowances are deducted from your income, along with reliefs, to make your taxable income - and therefore your tax bill - smaller. For example, the married couple's allowance entitles you to a reduction of 10 per cent off your normal rate of tax on £1,970 of your income.

But John Battersby says: 'If someone fails to send in their tax return, the Inland Revenue may give them a notice of coding that fails to take account of their personal allowance, as an incentive for them to do their tax return.'

In this situation, you can claim tax back for up to six previous tax years. You get tax relief at the rate of tax that would have applied if you claimed the deduction at the right time. Allowances to which you may be entitled include:

 Age-related personal allowances. People aged 65 or more can claim a higher personal allowance, worth £5,720 this tax year for those aged 65 to 74, or £5,980 if you are aged 75 or more. Relief is at the claimant's full rate of income tax.

 The married couple's allowance. This is being axed from 6 April for people under 65, but this tax year it is still worth having, at £1,970. However, tax relief is only available on this allowance at 10 per cent, rather than the full 23 per cent for basic-rate taxpayers, or 40 per cent for those on the higher rate. Couples where one spouse is already over the age of 65 can continue claiming the allowance - £5,125 for couples where one or both partners are aged 65 to 74, and £5,195 for those aged 75 or more.

 Additional personal allow-ance. If you are a single parent, you may be able to claim this allowance if your child lives with you. The amount of the allowance is £1,970, and the relief for the current tax year is 10 per cent.

 Blind person's allowance. Anyone registered as blind with a local authority can claim this allowance, worth £1,380 a year (relief at the claimant's full rate of tax).

 Widow's bereavement allowance. This is also being axed in the new tax year, starting 6 April, but for the time being, widows can claim this allowance, which is worth £1,970, in the year they lost their spouse, or the following year.

The relief applied to the allowance is 10 per cent.

webTitle: Prepare for the 'rich man's tax' - or suffer

fields.headline: Prepare for the 'rich man's tax' - or suffer
fields.standfirst: David Hunt  reveals how to prepare yourself so you can avoid the sting of inheritance tax
fields.trailText: Inheritance Tax (IHT) is often referred to as 'the voluntary tax', because there are lots of ways of avoiding it. If this is the case, there are an awful lot of volunteers, because the Inland Revenue reckons it will collect £2 billion in the current tax year from this source.
fields.body:
Inheritance Tax (IHT) is often referred to as 'the voluntary tax', because there are lots of ways of avoiding it. If this is the case, there are an awful lot of volunteers, because the Inland Revenue reckons it will collect £2 billion in the current tax year from this source.

Inheritance tax is levied at the punishing rate of 40 per cent. It is payable on a person's death, on the value of their estate above £231,000 (called the nil rate band). So a taxable estate valued at £250,000 would pay £7,500 in tax (40 per cent of £19,000) while an estate valued at £1 million would pay £307,600 (40 per cent of £769,000).

So why, if it is avoidable, do people still get clobbered by IHT? Some, like Princess Diana, die unexpectedly without having made any provisions (Princess Diana's estate is believed to have been hit with an IHT bill for £8m). Others mistakenly believe it is a 'rich person's tax'.

What they forget however, is that if they bought a house in the 1950s or 1960s, their property alone could easily be worth quite a lot now. Then there is that inheritance from Great Aunt Bertha, the business they own, or those life insurance policies they have been paying into for years. Pretty soon, £231,000 doesn't look quite so much.

There are basically two methods of IHT planning. You can build up a fund with which to pay the bill when it arrives, or try to reduce the eventual bill. Reducing the bill is made easier by a range of exemptions allowed under the IHT legislation.

The most important is that assets passing between spouses, during their lifetime or on death, are exempt from the tax. Less important, but also exempt, are gifts to charities, political parties or national bodies. Other exempt gifts include regular transfers out of income that do not affect the donor's nor mal standard of living. In addition you can make a gift of £3,000 every year, small gifts of up to £250, and marriage gifts (up to £5,000 from parents, £2,500 from grandparents and £1,000 from others) all without incurring a tax liability.

Outside of the above, outright gifts made during lifetime come under the heading of a 'potentially exempt transfer (Pet)'. If you remain alive for seven years after making a Pet, the gift falls out of the estate for tax purposes. Should you die within the seven-year period, the transfer is taxed on a sliding scale basis You can't, however, give your home to your children on the condition you remain living in it, as this is considered a 'gift with reservation' and would still form part of your estate.

Giving away assets during lifetime may cheat the taxman, but could be impracticable. So, having a will that spells out clearly where assets should go on death is essential, particularly from an IHT viewpoint.

Both husband and wife have the nil rate band allowance of £231,000, so it makes sense to use both where possible. On the death of the first partner, assets could be passed to the children up to the nil rate band, with the balance passing to the survivor. When the second partner dies, another nil rate band is available for use. Even after death, if nothing has been done, a spouse can execute a deed of variation redirecting some of the assets.

Investments can be put in a discretionary trust written into the will, with the spouse and children as beneficiaries. By this method the spouse can still get income or capital from the investments, but on death the assets will not incur tax.

Where the main asset is the family home, it may well be difficult to reduce the IHT bill by much, if at all. Here it makes sense to find a tax-efficient method of building up enough cash to meet the bill when it comes.

Usually, in tax planning circles, this will mean the use of a whole life insurance policy. For a married couple, a policy is taken out on both their lives, paying out on the second death.

This policy is written in trust, so the proceeds do not count as part of the estate. The beneficiaries will normally be the children, who can use the proceeds to pay off the tax bill.Measures to avoid or reduce IHT can become complex, so this is probably one area where the 'go it alone' approach is not advisable.

Professional help should be taken, and with rumours that Pets may be abolished in the upcoming Budget, this should be done sooner rather than later.

webTitle: Take the chance to pump up your pension

fields.headline: Take the chance to pump up your pension
fields.standfirst: 'Carry forward' or 'carry back' ... confused?  Helen Pridham explains all
fields.trailText: Want to pump up your personal pension? If you have some extra cash available, investing it in your pension will not only help to boost your retirement income prospects, it may also be your last chance to mop up unused tax relief from previous tax years.
fields.body:
Want to pump up your personal pension? If you have some extra cash available, investing it in your pension will not only help to boost your retirement income prospects, it may also be your last chance to mop up unused tax relief from previous tax years.

Under current rules for personal pensions, it is possible to catch up on contributions you have failed to make over the past seven years. However, as part of its proposals for stakeholder pensions, the Government has now announced it is limiting this concession.

At present, there are two ways of backdating your contributions - known as 'carry back' and 'carry forward'. With 'carry back' you can opt to have the pension contribution you are paying in this tax year treated as though it had been made last year. This way you can claim the tax reliefs which would have applied last year. This is particularly useful if you were a higher-rate taxpayer the previous year but are now paying basic-rate tax or if tax rates generally were higher in that year than in the current year.

The 'carry forward' rule allows unused tax relief from up to six years ago to be carried forward to the current year. In this case, tax-relief is given on the basis of the tax rates applying in the year in which the contribution is paid, or deemed to be paid, not the rates for the years from which the unused relief originated. So if you were a basic-rate taxpayer and are now paying higher-rate tax, it could be especially beneficial.

However, to be able to take advantage of 'carry forward', you must pay the maximum contribution for the current year first. You can then make up unused allowances from as long ago as 1993/94 or, if you are able to combine 'carry forward' and 'carry back', you could go back a further year to 1992/93. You will need to obtain special forms from the Inland Revenue for this purpose, unless you are self-employed, in which case you can make a claim for tax-relief on your tax return. A professional adviser can guide you through the process.

With the introduction of stakeholder pensions in 2001, the Government has decided it will abolish the 'carry forward' rule. This has left pension experts such as Steve Bee, head of pensions strategy at Scottish Life, puzzled. He says: 'If anything, people's earnings are becoming more variable, so the need for flexibility is increasing, not decreasing. This is why products such as flexible mortgages are becoming more popular.

'It seems a step backwards. The rule has always been particularly useful for the self-employed, who often have uneven earnings. Yet this is a group the Government seems to want to encourage.

'It has also benefited employees, who have left company pension schemes within two years, got their contributions back and then had up to two years of non-pensionable earnings. Such groups will lose out.'

Some people will still retain the benefit - according to Bee, people with retirement annuities (which preceded personal pensions) will not be hit by the 2001 abolition of the 'carry forward' rule.

fields.headline: Taking a big financial plunge
fields.standfirst: Alistair McArthur  looks at a mixed approach to planning for later life
fields.trailText: Alistair McArthur looks at a mixed approach to planning for later life.
fields.body:
Jim Poole is 38 and a service engineer for a security company. At present, the company does not offer Mr Poole access to a company pension scheme, and he thinks now is the time to make provision for his retirement.

Mr Poole can afford to invest a regular sum each month into a suitable plan, and two main options are open to him. He could invest in a personal pension plan or opt for an individual savings account (Isa).

A personal pension plan would allow Mr Poole to invest regularly until he retires. He could also add lump sums as and when they become available. His age entitles him to invest up to 20 per cent of his salary each year in a personal pension plan, and he would receive tax-relief on this money. At his retirement, he could take a tax-free cash sum of 25 per cent of the value of the fund.

However, the balance of the fund must be used to buy an annuity income, payable for the rest of his life. Annuities are paying unattractively low incomes at the moment, and this situation is not expected to improve in the foreseeable future. In addition, Mr Poole will not be able to get at his money until he reaches the age of 50 at the earliest.

The alternative is to invest the regular contributions in an Isa. This is a tax-efficient savings scheme that can be designed to produce capital growth or income. Mr Poole could invest for capital growth until his retirement, when he would have the whole of the fund available to spend as he wishes - or he could alter the investment content to draw an income. He could also get at the funds at any time. Unlike with a personal pension, Mr Poole would not receive tax relief on his investments, but any returns earned by his investments would be free of income and capital gains tax.

Mr Poole decided to read up on both personal pensions and Isas and to obtain independent advice on the best course of action in his circumstances.

'The idea of having a pension did not appeal, but they are a fact of life,' he says. 'I have been used to living for today but now I have got to put money away for my retirement.'

He likes the idea of the flexibility of an Isa. 'If I had an Isa and needed the money in the future, it is there,' he says. 'I would be able to get at it in an emergency, which I would not be able to do with a personal pension.'

Mr Poole decided to enlist the help of Robert Reid, a director at independent financial adviser Syndaxi. On Reid's advice, Mr Poole has decided to split his investment by putting part into a personal pension and part into an Isa.

'The recommendation is to invest in a stocks and shares Isa - so the money is accessible but still getting the benefit of growth on the stock market - as well as a personal pension, such as Legal & General, whose scheme follows closely the Government's guidelines for stakeholder pensions,' says Reid.

His age entitles him to invest up to 20 per cent of his salary each year in a personal pension plan, and he would receive tax-relief on this money. At his retirement, he could take a tax-free cash sum of 25 per cent of the value of the fund. However, the balance of the fund must be used to buy an annuity income, payable for the rest of his life. Annuities are paying unattractively low incomes at the moment, and this situation is not expected to improve in the foreseeable future. In addition, Mr Poole will not be able to get at his money until he reaches the age of 50 at the earliest. The alternative is to invest the regular contributions in an Isa. This is a tax-efficient savings scheme that can be designed to produce capital growth or income. Mr Poole could invest for capital growth until his retirement, when he would have the whole of the fund available to spend as he wishes - or he could alter the investment content to draw an income. He could also get at the funds at any time. Unlike with a personal pension, Mr Poole would not receive tax relief on his investments, but any returns earned by his investments would be free of income and capital gains tax. Mr Poole decided to read up on both personal pensions and Isas and to obtain independent advice on the best course of action in his circumstances. 'The idea of having a pension did not appeal, but they are a fact of life,' he says. 'I have been used to living for today but now I have got to put money away for my retirement.' He likes the idea of the flexibility of an Isa. 'If I had an Isa and needed the money in the future, it is there,' he says. 'I would be able to get at it in an emergency, which I would not be able to do with a personal pension.' Mr Poole decided to enlist the help of Robert Reid, a director at independent financial adviser Syndaxi. On Reid's advice, Mr Poole has decided to split his investment by putting part into a personal pension and part into an Isa. 'The recommendation is to invest in a stocks and shares Isa - so the money is accessible but still getting the benefit of growth on the stock market - as well as a personal pension, such as Legal & General, whose scheme follows closely the Government's guidelines for stakeholder pensions,' says Reid.

webTitle: Establishing a better bond with your children's future

fields.headline: Establishing a better bond with your children's future
fields.standfirst: Are friendly society bonds 'investor-friendly'?  Alistair McArthur  reports
fields.trailText: Friendly society bonds are often recommended as a suitable investment for grandparents wanting to save tax-efficiently on behalf of their grandchildren. But the returns generated by some friendly societies also attract the attention of any taxpaying investor.
fields.body:
Friendly society bonds are often recommended as a suitable investment for grandparents wanting to save tax-efficiently on behalf of their grandchildren. But the returns generated by some friendly societies also attract the attention of any taxpaying investor.

Friendly society bonds are tax-exempt life insurance savings policies that run for a minimum term of 10 years. Returns roll up tax-free within the friendly society's insurance fund, and at the end of the term, the payout is free of all taxes.

Unfortunately, as with all tax-efficient investments, the Government puts a limit on the amount invested. Every person, even a one-day-old child, has an allowance of £25 a month or £270 a year.

To qualify for special treatment, policies must run for at least 10 years and can be set up so they pay out at a specific date, such as 18th or 21st birthdays.

David White, chief executive of Tunbridge Wells Equitable Friendly Society (Twefs), says the society's biggest seller is its Baby Bond. 'This is a children's version of the adult bond,' he says. 'The policy is written in the child's name and only a friendly society can do this.'

So where do friendly society bonds invest policyholders' money? Most of the funds are directed to with-profits funds.

White says: 'Many people like the idea of with profits. If somebody is going to invest in equities, they have three key concerns. The first is to decide which stock to invest in, the second is to know when is a good or bad time to invest, and the third is to consolidate gains. A with-profits fund manages all three objectives.'

Some potential problems with friendly society bonds are the charges societies levy. A Twefs bond investing in with profits fund, for example, has a policy charge of 80p a month. This equates to about 3.2 per cent a year on a policy of £25 a month.

Scottish Friendly Assurance offers only a traditional with-profits option. Calum Bennie, direct marketing manager of the company, says: 'For a male aged 30 taking out a plan for 10 years, paying £25 a month, the total charges amount to £343. This equates to a reduction in the yield over the term of 2.5 per cent a year.'

And the performance of the bonds needs to also be scrutinised, Bennie adds.

So, considering the charges and the small investment limits, are friendly society bonds worth investing in? Andy Cowan, director of Edinburgh independent financial adviser Aitchison & Colegrave, warns: 'You have to ask "Are the tax benefits worthwhile when you look at the charges?". Charges could be relatively high when you look at the amount being invested. But, over the long term, they are still a good investment.'

White says people should look at past performance before writing bonds off: 'People who have saved £9 a month over the past 10 years will have received a return of 9 per cent a year - after charges.'

Cowan also believes friendly society bonds have a part to play for investors who can afford only a small amount each month.

Friendly society bonds are suitable for all investors, but some companies have aimed their products at specific markets. Plans such as Twefs' Baby Bond and Scottish Friendly Assurance's Child Bond, are aimed at providing investment opportunities for children.

Bennie believes friendly society bonds are used increasingly to fund further education. 'One of the main reasons for investing in these bonds is to pay something towards university,' he says.

Twefs has introduced the University Bond, aimed at providing funds to help students cope with college life. The bond is designed to pay out in each year the child is at college or university. 'It costs a lot of money to get through university,' White says. 'But with this bond, parents can work out how much it may cost and fund a bond to get their children through.'

For further information telephone:

Scottish Friendly Assurance 0845 6021065

Tunbridge Wells Friendly Society 01892 515353

Atchison & Colegrave 0131 557 5757
