webTitle: Investing offshore does not mean you're off the hook

fields.headline: Investing offshore does not mean you're off the hook
fields.standfirst: Looking to tax havens is not necessarily a way of cutting your liability.  Helen Pridham  reports
fields.trailText: Investing offshore may sound like an easy way of dodging the taxman - but it is not. However, it can be a useful and legitimate way of controlling when you pay tax and, in some cases, minimising your tax bill.
fields.body:
Investing offshore may sound like an easy way of dodging the taxman - but it is not.

However, it can be a useful and legitimate way of controlling when you pay tax and, in some cases, minimising your tax bill. For expatriates, in particular, it has clear advantages, and it may also be worthwhile if you are a UK resident - so long as the extra costs involved are not excessive.

Many UK banks, building societies, fund managers and insurance companies have subsidiaries in the Channel Islands or the Isle of Man. For UK expats working overseas, they offer the best of both worlds - familiar UK-type products but in a tax-sheltered environment. Malcolm Corrigan of Cater Allen Bank in Jersey, part of the Abbey National Group, argues that an offshore interest-bearing bank account would be useful for anyone working or retiring abroad.

Most offshore bank and building society deposit accounts are also open to UK residents, and their interest rates can be found in publications such as Moneyfacts. They do not necessarily pay better rates than onshore accounts, but they do pay it without tax deducted. However, if you are an ordinary UK resident, this does not mean you escape paying UK tax - not declaring this interest on your annual tax return constitutes tax eva sion.

Charles Levett-Scrivener of Slough-based independent financial adviser Towry Law, says: 'People often think that when they put their money offshore it is free of UK tax. But they are wrong. If you are resident and domiciled in the UK, you are liable to tax on all your worldwide income and capital gains - wherever they arise.'

However, there are offshore products, such as roll-up funds and investment bonds, which allow you to postpone the payment of tax. According to Patrick Connolly of independent financial adviser Chartwell Investment Management in Bath, who has recently compiled an Offshore With-Profits Bond Guide , tax deferral is a major reason for people using offshore investment bonds.

He says: 'By deferring tax liability, an investor may be able to reduce or completely avoid UK tax.'

For example, an investor who is paying higher-rate tax can invest in a bond and defer encashment until retirement, when he becomes a basic-rate taxpayer. Or he could gift it to a non-taxpaying spouse or to his children to support them when they are students, and they could cash in the bond in stages, using their personal allowances to ensure no tax is paid. Alternatively, investors planning to retire abroad could defer tax liability until they are non UK taxpayers.

Offshore investment bonds are offered by a variety of insurance companies with UK parents: among them Clerical Medical International, Norwich Union International, Royal & SunAlliance International and Scottish Life International.

They work in the same way as onshore insurance bonds, offering investors access to a range of investment funds including with-profits, unit-linked and capital-protected funds, or acting as a 'wrapper' and allowing you to choose from other managers' unit trusts and offshore funds.

The major difference between offshore and onshore bonds is that the offshore insurance companies are not subject to tax on investment income or capital gains, so returns roll up free of tax. This gross roll-up can enable bonds to grow faster than an onshore bond with similar returns.

Their tax-efficiency makes offshore bonds especially useful for inheritance tax planning, says Adrian Sacco, trust and tax manager for Scottish Life International. 'With a loan trust, investors can make capital withdrawals from their bond to supplement their income, while the gross roll-up of the investment returns occurs outside their estate,' he says.

While such a tax planning exercise is mainly of interest to the wealthy, Sacco points out that an offshore bond may appeal to the less well off because returns are paid without the deduction of tax. He says: 'The disadvantage of insurance bonds onshore is non-taxpayers cannot reclaim the tax paid by the insurance company. Offshore this is not a problem.'

However, Patrick Connelly of Chartwell warns that offshore products often have higher charges than their onshore equivalents. He says: 'It is important that investors weigh up tax benefits against higher cost.'

Another potential disadvantage when you invest offshore is that you are outside the protection of UK compensation schemes, such as the Policyholders Protection Board, which guarantees 90 per cent of a UK life assurance company's liabilities should it go bust. Although the Isle of Man has its own compensation schemes for depositors and insurance policyholders which are on a par with the UK, the Channel Islands do not. They insist all organisations are thoroughly vetted before they can operate there.

If you are considering investing offshore, it is best to seek the help of an authorised UK financial adviser. This will also give you extra protection, as the adviser will be covered by UK's Investor Compensation Scheme.

webTitle: Brotherly love may stop the taxman taking a slice of £48,000 gift

fields.headline: Brotherly love may stop the taxman taking a slice of £48,000 gift
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers.
fields.body:
One of my sons lent his brother £37,000 six years ago to buy a house. The borrower is now thinking of moving, and can repay the loan. The price of the property has risen so much that he intends to repay his brother £85,000.

I admire his fair-mindedness, but I am concerned about the tax position.
JP, London

 This depends on what the boys agreed at the outset. If, as it sounds, brother A gave brother B a loan with no strings attached and no interest payable, brother B is now returning brother A's money and, on top, making him a gift of £48,000.

Potentially, this £48,000 is subject to inheritance tax, but none will be payable if brother B survives for another seven years, or if he dies sooner and his entire estate is worth less than the inheritance tax nil-rate band, which this year is £231,000.

But if brother B had agreed to pay interest on the loan, and the £48,000 is regarded as interest, the Inland Revenue could demand income tax from brother A. Or, if the loan was treated as an investment for brother A, entitling him to share of any profit when the house is sold, brother A has made a capital gain on a home which is not his main residence, so capital gains tax is payable on all gains above this year's £7,100 capital gains tax allowance.

Assuming the first scenario, neither brother has to record the payment on a tax return, as the question of tax arises only if brother B dies early. But if brother A buys, say, unit trusts with the money and declares the dividends on his tax return, the Revenue may ask where the £85,000 came from. If the two were unrelated, it would be hard to convince the taxman that the original loan was an act of generosity. But between brothers it is harder for the Revenue to prove otherwise.

Internet error: Bad Egg

I paid off the balance of £1,200 on my Egg credit card account by cheque, but Egg took the amount again by direct debit from my current account, sending me overdrawn by £1,000. The money was returned when I complained. I closed the credit card account, but a month later, Egg debited another £1,200 from my bank plus charges, sending me overdrawn again.

I want compensation, an explanation and an apology that I can present to my bank to explain the unauthorised overdrafts. I have written several times to Egg, by post and email, but so far they have ignored me.
RK, Reading

 Internet banking gives customers instant access to their accounts, but it takes three days for Egg to activate direct debits. These three days were critical because the direct debit process started before the money was due and before your payment arrived by cheque. This is why you overpaid the first time. But then Egg took out £1,200 again 'due to an administrative error'.

There is no explanation for this, nor for why it failed to answer your letters. Egg says it will compensate you for any overdraft charges and other expenses you incurred - let them know how much this is - and is sending you a letter which proves to your bank that it was not your fault you went overdrawn.

AA windfall: No pay, no excuse

I was an associate member of the AA for several years on my father's membership, until my twenty-first birthday last June, when I wanted to become a full member. Not having a bank account myself, and not wanting to send cash by post, I gave my father my subscription in cash, and he either sent a cheque or paid by credit card for me. The AA says I am not eligible for a share payout, but will not explain why.
CH, Ilford

 Here is yet another case of the AA rejecting a member's entitlement to a windfall following its takeover by Centrica and ignoring appeals for information. The motoring organisation has now taken a closer look at your case and agrees that, as you did not have a bank account, you could not have paid directly, but that you are still a fully paid-up member.

A cheque for £248 is on the way to you.

 Many other AA members have contacted Money Writes to complain that it has failed to pay windfalls or investigate further. I have passed their letters to the AA, though not all of them qualify.

Inheritance at 18: Appeal of wheels

On her eighteenth birthday, my eldest daughter will take control of £2,500 held in a National Savings Investment Account. I know that she will be tempted to spend this money, but I would like her to invest some for a few years, perhaps to buy a car or start buying a home of her own. What is the best investment for her?
PH, Manchester

Your daughter is more likely to stick with a savings scheme if she has an incentive. A car may be attractive enough, but having fun could outweigh any desire to buy a home at this time in her life.

Let her spend a little of the money straight away. The balance should stay in a bank or building society deposit account unless it will be there for more than five years. Ideally, the account should be difficult to cash in, although most banks emphasise how easily you can get hold of your money these days. An account needing 90 days' notice may deter her from cashing in on a whim; one- and two-year bonds make it harder still.

Internet accounts could appeal; some include cash cards, but, to get cash in some cases, you have to transfer money to an ordinary bank account first. Decide the terms you want and then look for the best rate of interest.

Shares transfer: Grandparents' gift

My parents bought shares in BT and British Gas/Centrica which they now wish to transfer to my two children. What do my parents need to do, and would any significant costs be involved?
PT, Ashby de la Zouch

They need to complete a share transfer form, available from the companies' shareholder relations departments. There is no fee, no stockbroker's commission nor stamp duty to pay. Giving away shares counts as a disposal, so they may face capital gains tax.

 Write to Margaret Dibben, Money Writes, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Please include a telephone number, but not SAEs or original documents. Letters are selected for publication and we cannot give personal replies. The newspaper accepts no legal responsibility for advice.

fields.headline: Harland & Wolff: who's to blame?
fields.trailText: A row broke out this weekend over who was to blame for shipbuilder Harland & Wolff's failure to win the £450 million contract for Cunard's new liner, Queen Mary II.
fields.body:
A row broke out this weekend over who was to blame for shipbuilder Harland & Wolff's failure to win the £450 million contract for Cunard's new liner, Queen Mary II.

The Department of Trade and Industry indicated that the Belfast yard had approached it for aid too late. The company praised the DTI for acting quickly to secure a £400 million aid package, but said its bid had been thwarted by lack of support from Northern Ireland's Industrial Development Board (IDB).

Up to 1,700 jobs at H&W are threatened, plus 1,500 more in supporting industries. The contract is almost certain to go to French yard Chantiers d'Atlantique. H&W asked the IDB, which arranged a £38m grant as part of the aid, to pay it in advance because Cunard wanted to keep 85 per cent of the price until the 1,100ft ship was delivered. The IDB refused.

The Department says aid was not requested until 29 February, when Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers met H&W chief executive Brynjulv Mugaas and Ulster MPs including Peter Robinson, whose East Belfast seat includes the yard, and David Trimble. A DTI official said it was Byers who urged H&W to put in a request. The £400m aid package was offered by the department only six days later.

A DTI source said: 'The company came to us very late, and only put in a bid when we encouraged them to do so.'
fields.bodyText: A row broke out this weekend over who was to blame for shipbuilder Harland & Wolff's failure to win the £450 million contract for Cunard's new liner, Queen Mary II. The Department of Trade and Industry indicated that the Belfast yard had approached it for aid too late. The company praised the DTI for acting quickly to secure a £400 million aid package, but said its bid had been thwarted by lack of support from Northern Ireland's Industrial Development Board (IDB). Up to 1,700 jobs at H&W are threatened, plus 1,500 more in supporting industries. The contract is almost certain to go to French yard Chantiers d'Atlantique. H&W asked the IDB, which arranged a £38m grant as part of the aid, to pay it in advance because Cunard wanted to keep 85 per cent of the price until the 1,100ft ship was delivered. The IDB refused. A DTI official said it was Byers who urged H&W to put in a request. The £400m aid package was offered by the department only six days later. A DTI source said: 'The company came to us very late, and only put in a bid when we encouraged them to do so.'

webTitle: US deals fatal blow to BA tie-up

fields.headline: US deals fatal blow to BA tie-up
fields.trailText: British Airways planned partnership with American Airlines will suffer a crushing blow within days - the final setback in a catalogue of bad news that destroyed the career of chief executive Bob Ayling last week.
fields.byline: by Joanna Walters, Transport Business Editor
fields.body:
British Airways' planned partnership with American Airlines will suffer a crushing blow within days - the final setback in a catalogue of bad news that destroyed the career of chief executive Bob Ayling last week.

The Observer has learned that the US authorities are poised to refuse BA permission to 'code-share' with American - sharing flight numbers in order to market jointly each other's networks.

This will reduce the BA-AA relationship from the centrepiece of the global 'Oneworld' alliance to little more than a goodwill pact involving frequent flyer schemes.

The move will be seen as retaliation by the US authorities because BA successfully lobbied the UK government not to open up Heathrow airport to more US rivals. BA chairman Lord Marshall said this weekend: 'Given their [the US authorities'] track record it would not be surprising.'

In the wake of Ayling's sudden, forced resignation at BA, Marshall said the struggling airline was not seeking a buyer nor did he regard it as a takeover target - because of its hefty debt.

The airline vehemently denied The Observer's exclusive story last weekend that Ayling was set to depart, but one day later he was asked to resign and did so on Friday.

The airline is expected to reach or even exceed the City's most pessimistic forecasts of £280m pre-tax losses for the year ending 31 March, with one-off redundancy charges on top.

Ayling cut £1 billion from the cost base in his four years as chief executive, while fuel prices soared and capacity flooded on to the Atlantic.

But he failed to stem burgeoning losses and a plummeting share price. His confrontational style with the powerful trade unions soured employee relations early on while only partially achieving the wholesale restructuring of the company that he had made his mission.

Staff morale and customer service never fully recovered from the badly-handled cabin crew strike of 1997. And he abandoned a three-year fight for a full-blown joint venture with American Airlines citing prohibitive conditions imposed by the competition authorities.

Ayling had only recently initiated a recovery strategy of using smaller aircraft and concentrating on high-paying business passengers, while planning redundancies.

Marshall is to continue this strategy and act as chief executive, trying to improve employee relations and customer service while seeking Ayling's successor - probably someone from outside the company.

Ayling is still negotiating his pay-off. The value of his share options is negligible because of the poor share price performance. He is likely to receive two years' salary, worth almost £1m, and an unspecified pension package.

Meanwhile, it has emerged that BA has been secretly lobbying Downing Street to break up the London monopoly of privatised airports giant BAA, which owns Heathrow, Gatwick and Stansted. It believes that BAA has effectively blocked its expansion by failing to apply to build another runway in the South-east and that competition between airports would change that.

BAA has since 1991 been trying to win permission to build a fifth terminal (T5) at Heathrow - which is now not expected to get approval until 2002 and open in 2008 - six years late.

webTitle: Post union threatens to cut cash for Labour

fields.headline: Post union threatens to cut cash for Labour
fields.trailText: The head of the Communication Workers' Union is threatening to cut or freeze its cash contributions to the Labour Party unless the Government changes a key part of plans for commercialising the Post Office.
fields.body:
The head of the Communication Workers' Union is threatening to cut or freeze its cash contributions to the Labour Party unless the Government changes a key part of plans for commercialising the Post Office.

General secretary Derek Hodgson told The Observer that his postal worker members would reject any increase in the political levy paid to Labour, and may demand a cut at a special conference next month.

The news will worry the party's fund raisers because Hodgson - a member of Labour's National Executive Committee - has until now been helping to driving forward plans for unions to pay more to Labour ahead of the general election.

Hodgson said the CWU paid the party £500,000 a year in fees for members affiliated to the party. He had proposed an increase that would boost this by at least £100,000. This will be discussed next month.

Now even the current funding is under threat because the CWU is furious about plans to allow the Post Office to swap equity with partners in joint ventures to secure deals once it gains plc status and shares are created.

While the Government guaranteed that it would not sell shares in the Post Office without primary legislation, the same protection does not apply to share swaps.

A Department of Trade and Industry spokesman said there was still strong protection because any equity swap would have to pass through Parliament and be agreed by the Government.

But Hodgson says this still allows 'privatisation by the back door' - and undermines government guarantees that the Post Office would stay publicly owned. He wants any swaps to be limited to 5 per cent of the total equity.

Hodgson, who had a heated argument with Byers on the issue last week, said: 'Share swaps could lead to privatisation by the back door, which is a U-turn and shows the Government has broken its promises. Our affiliation to the party and our members' participation in that affiliation is based on the party keeping its promises.

'We will ask why we should pay any more into Labour Party funds, and question current levels. I may need the money to fight the Government on the issue.'

A DTI source said a 5 per cent limit would be arbitrary and would not make sense: 'What would happen if there was a good proposition which took it to 6.5 per cent?'

fields.headline: Briefcase
fields.trailText: Company futures: BA sets a new course
fields.body:
Company futures: BA sets a new course

With British Airways' share price at an eight-year low, and depressing Saturn adding to Bob Ayling's woes since February, his departure now is no surprise. Ayling was a good man but he was in the wrong job.

His birthchart (3/8/46) shows top talent and the brusque leadership style of the Leo Lion. Global Jupiter teams up in the air signs with Uranus, symbolising flight and a love of bold strategies. His 'small is beautiful' policy plugged his Venus into BA's Virgo ascendant (13/12/83), but most of his other connections were striking planetary oppositions which showed him flying BA against its grain.

BA is essentially a long-distance Sagittarian with giant Jupiter dominant at both its incorporation and its first trade (11/2/87). It used to thrive on jumbo philosophy. Downmarket Pisces in its horoscopes points to the cheap-and-cheerful economy holiday market, but Ayling courted the premium business traveller. His strategy of slimming down the aircraft and the airline, his outsourcing and his ethnic logo fiasco, proved antithetical to BA's expansive, empire-building spirit.

Another change of flight path sounds like thinking the unthinkable, but a big Jupiter movement beginning this June looks like BA beefing up its capacity, probably through a jumbo alliance. With a change in the cockpit, and a major reversal of policy in late November, this giant has a lot more mileage to go. By 2002 its profits should fly high again.

Buy...

Hit Entertainment, owners of children's TV and book character Bob the Builder. The company is doing very well as a key content provider for the world's burgeoning TV channels, many of them aimed at tiny tots and crammed with hard-sell advertising. Interims this week showed total revenues up by 31 per cent in the six months to 31 January. There is significant growth in merchandising, following the trend established by Toy Story for charging people to watch a feature-length advert and then charging them again when they buy the toy figures. A new Bob the Builder TV series is to start in the US soon, linked to the launch of Bob the Builder 'consumer products'. But it is the home market which offers the most exciting prospects for growth. First, there is the survey news that children in relatively well-off families (ie: Hit's target consumers) have no idea about budgets and believe that banks provide grown-ups with endless cash which arrives from holes in the wall as though by magic.This can only bode well for the company's merchandising efforts. Then there is John Prescott's plan to build 860,000 more houses in London and the Southeast - in an area equivalent to Southampton, or 50 million new Toy Towns. The development is certain to keep Bob busy with his hammer for many years to come.

Sell...

Storehouse. Actually, there is nothing wrong with the company, other than subsidiary Mothercare's failure to move fast enough in exploiting the top end of the baby product market. Last week the Beckhams reportedly spent up to £35,000 on baby Brooklyn's first birthday party. But you will search in vain in Mothercare for Gucci booties. According to reports, the 'baby-luxe' markets is one of the fastest growing consumer niches in the United States. Ostrich feather cribs, designer nappy-changing tables and cashmere blankets are now standard kit for even the most moderately go-getter parent. But by restricting itself to practical baby bouncers and sensible non-toxic wooden objects, Mothercare is turning its back on these opportunities. In the US, the seriously bonkers pay specialist decorators up to £30,000 to set up a nursery. Over here it is still mostly a matter of two tins of Dulux and a mobile. A few weeks ago this paper reported that due to medical advances many babies born today can expect to live to 120. It is Mothercare's solemn duty to get parents of newborns used to shelling out straight away.

Watch out for: Trafficmaster

THE COMPANY that aims to take the Hartley's out of traffic jams, unveils full-year figures on Tuesday. Analysts predict pre-tax profits rising to £4 million, from £3.2m. A strong rise, but whether this is enough to justify Trafficmaster's future price/earnings ratio of 377 is open to question.

The shares have been bolstered over the past 12 months by a whirlwind of activity. Trafficmaster, established in 1988 and initially launched as a pilot project on the M25, has been busy developing new ways to help us get around safely and more efficiently.

Recently it unveiled Fleetstar, a product that allows vehicles to be tracked via global satellite positioning technology - handy for bosses keeping tabs on dawdling employees. It has also teamed up with Motorola and Blaupunkt to develop a new 'smarter' navigation system that is aware of traffic conditions and can plot the quickest route accordingly.

A range of alliances with the likes of the AA and the RAC, not to mention a host of vehicle manufacturers, has also done much to strengthen the company's position.

But it is the technology side of things that attracts the City. As much of the company's systems work via wireless and fixed-line Internet protocols, Trafficmaster is now enjoying the lucrative reputation that comes with being an online player.

webTitle: Too slick for a new oil crisis?

fields.headline: Too slick for a new oil crisis?
fields.standfirst: As Opec's prices treble, Oliver Morgan looks at the lesson we could have learned from the Seventies
fields.trailText: The front page headline read: '3p increase in petrol feared.' It was 19 October 1973 and the Daily Telegraph was reporting the possibility of petrol at 50p a gallon. Twenty-seven years later - on 3 March 2000 - the paper roared again: 'Fears of petrol at £4 a gallon.'
fields.body:
The front page headline read: '3p increase in petrol feared.' It was 19 October 1973 and the Daily Telegraph was reporting the possibility of petrol at 50p a gallon. Twenty-seven years later - on 3 March 2000 - the paper roared again: 'Fears of petrol at £4 a gallon.'

Take out inflation, and this is a chance for those with a taste for history repeating itself to say that some things never change. It may be more accurate to say that things do change but not enough to prove we have learnt from our mistakes.

The industrialised West has spent recent months worrying over the trebling of oil prices, from around $10 a barrel a year ago to touch $32 last week, fuelled by a 2-million-barrel-a-day shortage. Leo Drollas of the Centre for Global Energy Studies says this 168 per cent increase is the second-biggest since 1973.

The West is upset with the 11-nation Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec), which is due to decide on 27 March whether to produce more, thereby easing prices.

US Energy Secretary Bill Richardson has been touring the world's oil capitals, trying to avoid US petrol prices rising from $1.40 a US gallon to between $1.80 and $2 in election year.

Parallels have quickly been drawn with the Seventies oil crisis. And just as quickly, they have been dismissed.

The world, after all, has changed. For one thing, says Stephen Turner, oil analyst at HSBC investment bank, 'there is no Arab-Israeli war'.

Today's problems have been triggered by economics, not politics. Opec has simply acted to raise the price of oil from its trough last February. The Vienna-based body now accounts for only 44 per cent of world production, compared with 56 per cent in the Seventies.

Also, the world economy is not so dependent on oil. Services have replaced traditional industries, and other forms of energy have been found.

Inflation is now around 2 per cent across the 30 industrialised nations belonging to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development - well below the double-digit levels of 30 years ago, which were themselves fuelled by rising oil prices.

The weight of oil in the UK Retail Prices Index, for example, is 3.6 per cent; it was 10 per cent then. North Sea oil has given us a £4 billion trade surplus in oil, replacing a deficit. And the effect on UK petrol prices is less than in the US because so much of our petrol price is tax.

In short, the West is not threatened this time by balance-of-payments shocks.

But one thing does not seem to have changed: the ability of the West and Opec to blunder and worsen the crisis. As events unfolded in 1973 it became clear that although, in the West's eyes, Opec was behaving outrageously, the western governments were acting incompetently.

That crisis grew from the decline in co-operation between the oil-rich Arab world and the West through events such as Libya's Islamic revolution, and growing hostility to America's support for Israel.

Middle-eastern and north African countries were at the time nationalising their oil industries, making western oil firms mere contractors.

King Faisal of Saudi Arabia feared his country would be isolated within Opec because it had good relations with the US. Faisal warned the four US oil giants in the Saudi-based Aramco consortium that they would 'lose everything' unless US support for Israel cooled. But warnings from Aramco were ignored by President Richard Nixon.

In April Opec called for talks with major oil companies. Spurred on by Libya, Algeria and Venezuela, it wanted price rises to compensate for the fall in the value of the dollar, the currency in which oil is valued, which had cut its members' earnings.

BP's then chairman, Sir Eric Drake, said: 'The era of cheap energy ... is, I believe, behind us.'

In August, Faisal and Egyptian President Anwar Sadat agreed to cut oil supplies if US policy did not change. Opec called more talks, saying the 1971 Tehran Agreement with the oil companies, intended to set prices until 1975, was giving the firms 'high unearned profits'.

Then, on 6 October, Egypt and Syria invaded Israel. Ten days later, the Gulf states triggered the energy crisis by raising the price of crude oil by 66 per cent to $5 a barrel.

The implications were appalling. The Financial Times economics correspondent at the time, William Keegan, wrote that the UK balance of payments would be hit by between £600m and £1bn - huge amounts then.

Worse was to come. In November the OECD warned that an industrial world trade surplus of $10bn in 1974 could be cut to zero, and in December an Opec meeting in Tehran indicated higher prices still for the coming year. By late January 1974, the benchmark Arabian light crude was $11.65 per barrel.

In Britain, industry's raw materials and fuel bills rose by 17 per cent in one month because of the oil price, provoking a panic worsened by a wave of industrial action. Electricity workers, railwaymen and miners banned overtime. There were selective power cuts, followed at the end of December by the three-day working week.

Parliament was recalled early for a two-day debate on the energy crisis. When a strike ballot by the miners showed 81 per cent in favour of walking out, the Tory Prime Minister, Ted Heath, called a general election. He lost and was replaced by Labour's Harold Wilson.

In March, the UK balance of payments deficit fell from £429m the previous month to £453m. The oil deficit was a staggering £294m.

However, Opec's unity was cracking. On 27 January, Saudi Arabia's Oil Minister, Sheikh Yamani, said King Faisal wanted price cuts to help the world economy.

But Iran, still led by the Shah, pushed for a price rise to $14 a barrel. In May, Kuwait cut production, which again saw prices leap.

The Saudis, however, continued in their attempts to moderate Opec's squeeze, and in December Yamani offered to undercut the cartel's $10.12-a-barrel basic price, although this held up into 1975.

In January that year US Secretary of State Henry Kissinger warned that American military action over the high oil prices could not be ruled out. He introduced a plan for a floor price on oil to encourage investment outside the Gulf, in areas such as the North Sea. At the same time western governments boosted their nuclear power programmes to counter their dependence on oil.

The oil price wavered throughout 1975 and 1976, before falling as the unity of Opec cracked further.

In Britain, the energy problem had created a disastrous economic inheritance for the Labour government. International investors took fright, and sterling tumbled.

Ironically, it was oil that rescued the pound when, in 1977, the world realised that Britain, by opening up the North Sea fields, was becoming an oil exporter.

Circumstances today are different, but the West's capacity for misjudging the Middle East remains.

Paul Hornsell of the Oxford Institute for Energy Studies says: 'The West is again playing a poor hand. There has been a growing clamour to do something. Bill Richardson has been trying to get the oil nations to release more oil, but all he has done is to stoke up the oil price. These things are best not left in the hands of western politicians.'

Drollas, of the Centre for Global Energy Studies, believes there are more fundamental problems. The failure of the West so far to broker a lasting peace between the Arab states and Israel, together with instability around Iraq means, that military spending in the region - which underpins the need for oil revenues - dwarfs that of the West.

Compared with US defence spending of 5 per cent of its gross domestic product and the UK proportion of 3.5 per cent, Saudi Arabia spends 16 per cent, Oman 14 per cent and Kuwait 13 per cent. With Saddam Hussein still there as a neighbour, despite US intervention, who can blame them?

Now, as then, Opec has its own problems. Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and Mexico want to increase supply. Others, such as Iran, Libya and Algeria, want the present production limits to remain through the summer. A suggested compromise, pumping out an extra 1.2 million barrels a day, is 800,000 too few, and has made the price rise still steeper.

And once again, says Drollas, Opec has misjudged things: 'In the autumn it needed to increase supply because stocks were falling, but it said inventories were healthy. They were using outdated figures. It now has to cope with a very difficult position - judging how to release oil onto the market without losing control of prices.'

The Opec nations have their economic problems, which should not be written off. Hawkish states remain hawkish because they have smaller oil reserves.

Drollas adds: 'Inflation may be lower than in 1973. But it has still doubled in the OECD from 1 per cent to 2, largely thanks to the oil price.'

And oil is still the primary source of 40 per cent of the world's energy. In some sectors, such as transport, it is still almost the only fuel in town.

fields.bodyText: The front page headline read: '3p increase in petrol feared.' It was 19 October 1973 and the Daily Telegraph was reporting the possibility of petrol at 50p a gallon. Twenty-seven years later - on 3 March 2000 - the paper roared again: 'Fears of petrol at £4 a gallon.' Take out inflation, and this is a chance for those with a taste for history repeating itself to say that some things never change. It may be more accurate to say that things do change but not enough to prove we have learnt from our mistakes. The industrialised West has spent recent months worrying over the trebling of oil prices, from around $10 a barrel a year ago to touch $32 last week, fuelled by a 2-million-barrel-a-day shortage. Leo Drollas of the Centre for Global Energy Studies says this 168 per cent increase is the second-biggest since 1973. The West is upset with the 11-nation Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec), which is due to decide on 27 March whether to produce more, thereby easing prices. US Energy Secretary Bill Richardson has been touring the world's oil capitals, trying to avoid US petrol prices rising from $1.40 a US gallon to between $1.80 and $2 in election year. Parallels have quickly been drawn with the Seventies oil crisis. And just as quickly, they have been dismissed. The world, after all, has changed. For one thing, says Stephen Turner, oil analyst at HSBC investment bank, 'there is no Arab-Israeli war'. Today's problems have been triggered by economics, not politics. Opec has simply acted to raise the price of oil from its trough last February. The Vienna-based body now accounts for only 44 per cent of world production, compared with 56 per cent in the Seventies. Also, the world economy is not so dependent on oil. Services have replaced traditional industries, and other forms of energy have been found. Inflation is now around 2 per cent across the 30 industrialised nations belonging to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development - well below the double-digit levels of 30 years ago, which were themselves fuelled by rising oil prices. The weight of oil in the UK Retail Prices Index, for example, is 3.6 per cent; it was 10 per cent then. North Sea oil has given us a £4 billion trade surplus in oil, replacing a deficit. And the effect on UK petrol prices is less than in the US because so much of our petrol price is tax. In short, the West is not threatened this time by balance-of-payments shocks. But one thing does not seem to have changed: the ability of the West and Opec to blunder and worsen the crisis. As events unfolded in 1973 it became clear that although, in the West's eyes, Opec was behaving outrageously, the western governments were acting incompetently. That crisis grew from the decline in co-operation between the oil-rich Arab world and the West through events such as Libya's Islamic revolution, and growing hostility to America's support for Israel. Middle-eastern and north African countries were at the time nationalising their oil industries, making western oil firms mere contractors. King Faisal of Saudi Arabia feared his country would be isolated within Opec because it had good relations with the US. Faisal warned the four US oil giants in the Saudi-based Aramco consortium that they would 'lose everything' unless US support for Israel cooled. But warnings from Aramco were ignored by President Richard Nixon. In April Opec called for talks with major oil companies. Spurred on by Libya, Algeria and Venezuela, it wanted price rises to compensate for the fall in the value of the dollar, the currency in which oil is valued, which had cut its members' earnings. BP's then chairman, Sir Eric Drake, said: 'The era of cheap energy ... is, I believe, behind us.' In August, Faisal and Egyptian President Anwar Sadat agreed to cut oil supplies if US policy did not change. Opec called more talks, saying the 1971 Tehran Agreement with the oil companies, intended to set prices until 1975, was giving the firms 'high unearned profits'. The implications were appalling. The Financial Times economics correspondent at the time, William Keegan, wrote that the UK balance of payments would be hit by between £600m and £1bn - huge amounts then. Worse was to come. In November the OECD warned that an industrial world trade surplus of $10bn in 1974 could be cut to zero, and in December an Opec meeting in Tehran indicated higher prices still for the coming year. By late January 1974, the benchmark Arabian light crude was $11.65 per barrel. In Britain, industry's raw materials and fuel bills rose by 17 per cent in one month because of the oil price, provoking a panic worsened by a wave of industrial action. Electricity workers, railwaymen and miners banned overtime. There were selective power cuts, followed at the end of December by the three-day working week. Parliament was recalled early for a two-day debate on the energy crisis. In May, Kuwait cut production, which again saw prices leap. The Saudis, however, continued in their attempts to moderate Opec's squeeze, and in December Yamani offered to undercut the cartel's $10.12-a-barrel basic price, although this held up into 1975. In January that year US Secretary of State Henry Kissinger warned that American military action over the high oil prices could not be ruled out. He introduced a plan for a floor price on oil to encourage investment outside the Gulf, in areas such as the North Sea. At the same time western governments boosted their nuclear power programmes to counter their dependence on oil. The oil price wavered throughout 1975 and 1976, before falling as the unity of Opec cracked further. In Britain, the energy problem had created a disastrous economic inheritance for the Labour government. International investors took fright, and sterling tumbled. Ironically, it was oil that rescued the pound when, in 1977, the world realised that Britain, by opening up the North Sea fields, was becoming an oil exporter. Circumstances today are different, but the West's capacity for misjudging the Middle East remains. Paul Hornsell of the Oxford Institute for Energy Studies says: 'The West is again playing a poor hand. There has been a growing clamour to do something. Bill Richardson has been trying to get the oil nations to release more oil, but all he has done is to stoke up the oil price. These things are best not left in the hands of western politicians.' fields.headline: Stockwatch
fields.trailText: dot.com danger | Backward rolls
fields.body:
dot.com danger

Reading this column will not, we hope, seriously damage your wealth, but it could rob you of immediate riches galore. Because, taking a medium-term view in the main, we refuse to chase the runaway dot.com bandwagon indiscriminately.

Thursday's pricing of the lastminute.com flotation, upping the shares - at the last minute, appropriately - by two thirds, makes the mind boggle. The valuation of start-ups like this throws every yardstick out of the window. To cognoscenti of crashes of yore, when the market mispriced risk - or forgot about it altogether - investors sooner or later can only get burnt.

For at prices like this, people are blindly assuming that these first companies to float will be as successful as their wildest dreams. Last week's jolt to Freeserve's shares, however, following Alta Vista's news of free Internet calls, should warn how quickly this market moves.

In the meantime, dot.com fever ignores boom times in some of our most basic industries, which will never go away. Take mining and oil stocks, where profits are at a record. It is only a matter of time before 'value stocks' are back in vogue. So don't be last-minute about taking a look at the sectors techno-mania has clobbered.

Food for thought

The equity strategists at broker Charterhouse, old fogeys the lot, seem to have been thinking along similar lines. They say that while the high-tech New York Nasdaq market, in particular, continues to power ahead, there's no point calling a turn in the market.

But Gordon Brown's dear friend, prudence, suggests you should selectively build up a list of undervalued shares in the meantime. And goodness knows, there is no shortage of sound-looking stocks where today's valuations are unprecedented.

Strategist Tony Jackson points to the food and drink sector, where a series of firms have a dividend yield in excess of the earnings multiple. Pubs group Wolverhampton & Dudley, he points out, has raised its dividend by double digits over 20 years, but now yields 7.2 per cent on a multiple of just 6.8 times at today's 340p price.

Other such stocks worth a look are Northern Foods (92p), Tate & Lyle (220p) and Greene King (382p).

Backward rolls

It is time for a change of view, however, on one of our best-known, 'old economy' stocks, aero-engine maker Rolls-Royce. So says Nick Cunningham, respected engineering analyst at broker Salomon Smith Barney. Rolls didn't quite join last week's FTSE-100 cull, but it is on the cusp of joining the slaughter next time.

Only a few months after Rolls's £600 million takeover of Vickers, the group is more indebted than ever, and still not generating any cash. In the long-term, Rolls has been successful in gaining market share in aero-engines, and a US merger may be on the cards in the future.

But the point when all those benefits start rolling in is, Salomon says, indefinable and you should pursue growth elsewhere. The broker has cut its share price target to 160p from 190p, against Rolls's current 186p value.

Had its day

Like Somerfield (until chief executive David Simons walks the plank, at least), Alldays is another retail nightmare to avoid. The convenience store operator's shares may, at 50p, be near their all-time low. But following the firm's results last month, the full extent of its trading and debt problems are clear.

At the current price, with its £175m of borrowings, Alldays is trading on a multiple of 13 times its total debt plus equity divided by operating earnings. That's higher than Tesco, Sainsbury and Morrisons, suggesting little upside from here. Avoid.

webTitle: Winning is not enough if you're just Williams

fields.headline: Winning is not enough if you're just Williams
fields.standfirst: Throg Street
fields.trailText: Investors seem to have no problem discerning value in companies such as QXL or lastminute.com, despite business plans which seem to depend on years of exponential growth. When it comes to working out the worth of two companies which actually make money from keeping our homes and offices secure, however, they seem to be completely stuck.
fields.body:
Investors seem to have no problem discerning value in companies such as QXL or lastminute.com, despite business plans which seem to depend on years of exponential growth. When it comes to working out the worth of two companies which actually make money from keeping our homes and offices secure, however, they seem to be completely stuck.

Williams, owner of security businesses Chubb, Kidde and, for the moment, Yale, saw its shares surge by a third last week after it announced that it was to split Chubb Security Services from Kidde Yale.

The rise was ostensibly because investors will find it easier to work out what the businesses are worth when they are separate. Chairman Sir Nigel Rudd and his longstanding partner Roger Carr, the chief executive, make the usual claims that demerger will free the businesses to 'pursue their own strategic development' and realise their 'greatest potential and value'.

In truth, however, the only thing that was stopping them realising their potential in their traditional form was the fact that the City refuses to forgive Williams for having once been a conglomerate, and has rated its shares accordingly.

Rudd and Carr have spent the past five years shedding businesses and increasing the group's 'focus'. Its three companies, which supply locks, burglar alarms and security services, can hardly be described as unrelated.

But it seems the only way to persuade investors that Williams has changed is to waste at least £20 million in fees on breaking it up into its constituent parts.

Rudd points to the proposed sale of one of the parts, the Yale locks business, as evidence of how much value there is in the business. It is the slowest-growing part of the empire, yet Sweden's Assa Abloy is prepared to pay more than 20 times last year's earnings for it.

That partly reflects the fact that Yale not only adds a valuable piece to Assa's international locks business; but it also demonstrates that companies with leading market positions are worth paying good money for.

Last week's leap in the value of Williams shares accounts for much of that value. The shares are high enough for the present, although buyers looking for long-term growth should be rewarded.

Brewers bottle out

The exit of Scottish & Newcastle and Whitbread from the FTSE-100 leaves just one brewer, Bass, in the premier index. And after much dithering and dropping of hints, Bass has finally conceded that it is likely to pull out of brewing.

So, as long as Bass fulfils its ambitions to convert itself into a hotels, retailing and leisure company, there is a real possibility that by the end of this year, there will not be a single brewer in the FTSE-100.

Furthermore, Whitbread now seems certain to pull out of brewing. The company has already admitted that brewing is not central to its plans for the future shape of the business: it is much more interested in developing its pubs, restaurants, hotels, sports clubs and the like.

It has become accepted wisdom that Whitbread will wait until the auction of Bass's breweries has been completed before marketing its own more actively.

Carlsberg, Heineken and South African Breweries are all looking hard at Bass's breweries. And whichever two fail to clinch a deal with Bass would be interested in going for the Whitbread operation. Carlsberg is a particular favourite, as it already has good relations with Interbrew of Belgium which licenses its Stella brand to Whitbread for production in the UK.

Of the big, UK-quoted players, only Scottish & Newcastle is committed to remaining in the business of producing beer. And it would like to expand overseas - particularly by buying Kronenbourg from Danone of France. (S&N will shortly be topping up its coffers with the sale of Center Parcs and Pontins, which it hopes will yield around £950m.)

What should investors holding shares in Whitbread, Bass or S&N make of all this?

Whitbread and S&N are both on extraordinarily low ratings: even taking a pessimistic view of earnings this year and next, they are on price/earnings ratios of less than 10, and they offer yields better than anything you would get by putting your money in a bank or building society. Bass's rating is scarcely more demanding.

By just about any conventional measure, shares in all three look cheap. Buy.

Running too fast

Holmes Place is a classic example of a company that has to run fast simply to stand still. Health clubs are a very fashionable business, as is demonstrated by the number of companies queuing up to build them: Cannons, Fitness First, and First Leisure as well as Holmes Place.

They are doing well out of them. Holmes Place's sales jumped almost two-thirds last year to £61.4m, and its pre-tax profits by 48 per cent to £10.7m. That owed a lot to its breakneck expansion - the number of clubs doubled to 53 last year - but like-for-like sales, based on 13 clubs that have been open for more than two years, rose 10 per cent.

Such growth will become harder to achieve. Even chief executive Allan Fisher admits that some of the new openings - in Islington, north London, for example, or the new City clubs - risk cannibalising existing ones. There is no guarantee that it can achieve the same returns in provincial cities such as Manchester or Birmingham, its next targets.

Extending into Europe is a sensible strategy but again it will have to battle for territory with rivals Cannons and Fitness First. Holmes Place is sensibly seeking local partners to help with its continental expansion, but even so, the risks of doing business overseas are high.

The shares have recently lost some of last year's spectacular gains but they still do not look cheap. Holders should take some profits.

webTitle: Headless BA in shock at Ayling's swift demise

fields.headline: Headless BA in shock at Ayling's swift demise
fields.standfirst: 'It was clear that Bob had to go.' Joanna Walters reports on a cruel end for the high flier
fields.trailText: 'It was clear that Bob had to go.' Joanna Walters reports on a cruel end for the high flier
fields.body:
The execution was planned with discretion and stealth. Some time over the past three weeks, Lord Marshall decided that British Airways would finally have to jettison Bob Ayling, his protégé and annointed successor. With a tenacity bordering on stubbornness, Ayling had survived the 'dirty tricks' scandal with Virgin Atlantic, the bitter cabin crew strike, the failure to seal a comprehensive partnership with American Airlines and a plunge from profit into disastrous loss.

Just as he thought he had turned the airline around and was about to steer it back to good times, the board was secretly nailing together the gibbet. There was no gathering, no formal meeting. Marshall fixed up quiet, one-to-one conversations with each of his seven non-executive colleagues. He started with deputy chairman Sir Michael Angus, veteran of Unilever, Boots, Whitbread and the CBI, and then worked his way down the list.

'By the time he had spoken to all of us, we were unani mous,' said one this weekend. 'It was clear that Bob had to go. Of course there is considerable sadness. He was a friend of ours.' By the time Marshall denied The Observer's story last weekend, the die was cast, although Ayling did not yet know it. Last Monday evening the chairman beckoned his 53-year-old colleague into the inner sanctum of the airline's anonymous Berkeley Square offices in central London and told him that after 15 years it was all over.

An ashen Ayling retreated to his large townhouse in Stockwell, south London, to seek solace with his wife Julia. There were sporadic phone calls between Ayling and Marshall over the next three days. On Thursday, Ayling officially opened his beloved London Eye, the giant ferris wheel on the South Bank of the Thames, sponsored by the airline. That evening he phoned his chairman and agreed to hang. His resignation was tendered in writing to the board of directors on Friday morning, by which time Ayling and his family had already left the country to avoid the inevitable media storm. Having released the news to the City, Marshall then briefed BA's top 100 managers at the airline's futuristic glass-and-steel Heathrow headquarters. He praised Ayling but emphasised that it was time for a new face at the top to deliver the real recovery programme.

One manager who attended said the mood was a mixture of relief and shock - the kind of weird shock you experience when you expect a sick relative to die but they linger on, and on and then pass away unexpectedly.

Marshall was given a two-minute ovation, and then managers huddled to discussed the leadership hole now gaping wide at the top of the airline.

Despite the chaos and clear lack of a succession plan, Marshall said that Ayling had understandably not been expected to stay on as a lame-duck boss while the globe was scoured for his replacement.

Ayling had been intent on dragging the airline back to profitability with a lean, mean cost base while doing 'a Marshall' and grooming a bright young thing to take over when he was ready to step off the corporate roller- coaster into some sort of Government role. He is very close to New Labour and has the Prime Minister's ear.

But it was not to be and the end, when it came for Ayling, was swift.

Marshall told The Observer this weekend: 'When you come to a conclusion that that's what you need to do, you get on and talk to the person affected.'

It is a cruel end for a high flying executive. Ayling's expected £1m compensation package will provide material comfort for the family he has, in time-honoured fashion, now pledged to see more of now that he has not got a job any more.

But his pride will probably never recover, and the coveted knighthood - so cruelly awarded to arch rival Richard Branson in the Millennium Honours - looks more elusive than ever.

An industry source said: 'BA is not recovering this year, and that is the usual reason company chief executives go, even though some of the passenger numbers are looking better.

'The airline is suffering huge losses in Germany and on domestic routes; long haul is still looking pretty sick on the North Atlantic; and the turnaround may not come until 2001 or 2002/3 - it is definitely not coming in 2000.'

What he said...

January 1996: On becoming chief executive: 'I will make this the best managed company in Britain by 2000.'
June 1996: Letter to staff on eve of cabin crew strike threatens to sack strikers and sue them for loss of business.
July 1997: 'Soon I won't have a desk.'
June 1999: As BA halts psychedelic tailfin programme: 'The people of Britain believe their community is not represented as well as it should be. UK passengers want the Union Jack given greater prominence.'
November 1999: 'We are never going back to that price again' (a share price of 275p). Feb 2000, shares hit eight-year low of 261p.
9 March 2000: On opening the London Eye: 'What goes around comes around.'

fields.bodyText: The execution was planned with discretion and stealth. Some time over the past three weeks, Lord Marshall decided that British Airways would finally have to jettison Bob Ayling, his protégé and annointed successor. With a tenacity bordering on stubbornness, Ayling had survived the 'dirty tricks' scandal with Virgin Atlantic, the bitter cabin crew strike, the failure to seal a comprehensive partnership with American Airlines and a plunge from profit into disastrous loss. Just as he thought he had turned the airline around and was about to steer it back to good times, the board was secretly nailing together the gibbet. There was no gathering, no formal meeting. Marshall fixed up quiet, one-to-one conversations with each of his seven non-executive colleagues. He started with deputy chairman Sir Michael Angus, veteran of Unilever, Boots, Whitbread and the CBI, and then worked his way down the list. 'By the time he had spoken to all of us, we were unani mous,' said one this weekend. 'It was clear that Bob had to go. Of course there is considerable sadness. He was a friend of ours.' By the time Marshall denied The Observer's story last weekend, the die was cast, although Ayling did not yet know it. Last Monday evening the chairman beckoned his 53-year-old colleague into the inner sanctum of the airline's anonymous Berkeley Square offices in central London and told him that after 15 years it was all over. An ashen Ayling retreated to his large townhouse in Stockwell, south London, to seek solace with his wife Julia. There were sporadic phone calls between Ayling and Marshall over the next three days. On Thursday, Ayling officially opened his beloved London Eye, the giant ferris wheel on the South Bank of the Thames, sponsored by the airline. That evening he phoned his chairman and agreed to hang. His resignation was tendered in writing to the board of directors on Friday morning, by which time Ayling and his family had already left the country to avoid the inevitable media storm. Having released the news to the City, Marshall then briefed BA's top 100 managers at the airline's futuristic glass-and-steel Heathrow headquarters. He praised Ayling but emphasised that it was time for a new face at the top to deliver the real recovery programme. One manager who attended said the mood was a mixture of relief and shock - the kind of weird shock you experience when you expect a sick relative to die but they linger on, and on and then pass away unexpectedly. Marshall was given a two-minute ovation, and then managers huddled to discussed the leadership hole now gaping wide at the top of the airline. Despite the chaos and clear lack of a succession plan, Marshall said that Ayling had understandably not been expected to stay on as a lame-duck boss while the globe was scoured for his replacement. Ayling had been intent on dragging the airline back to profitability with a lean, mean cost base while doing 'a Marshall' and grooming a bright young thing to take over when he was ready to step off the corporate roller- coaster into some sort of Government role. He is very close to New Labour and has the Prime Minister's ear. But it was not to be and the end, when it came for Ayling, was swift. Marshall told The Observer this weekend: 'When you come to a conclusion that that's what you need to do, you get on and talk to the person affected.' It is a cruel end for a high flying executive. Ayling's expected £1m compensation package will provide material comfort for the family he has, in time-honoured fashion, now pledged to see more of now that he has not got a job any more. But his pride will probably never recover, and the coveted knighthood - so cruelly awarded to arch rival Richard Branson in the Millennium Honours - looks more elusive than ever. An industry source said: 'BA is not recovering this year, and that is the usual reason company chief executives go, even though some of the passenger numbers are looking better. 'The airline is suffering huge losses in Germany and on domestic routes; long haul is still looking pretty sick on the North Atlantic; and the turnaround may not come until 2001 or 2002/3 - it is definitely not coming in 2000.' What he said... January 1996: On becoming chief executive: 'I will make this the best managed company in Britain by 2000.' June 1996: Letter to staff on eve of cabin crew strike threatens to sack strikers and sue them for loss of business. July 1997: 'Soon I won't have a desk.' June 1999: As BA halts psychedelic tailfin programme: 'The people of Britain believe their community is not represented as well as it should be. UK passengers want the Union Jack given greater prominence.' November 1999: 'We are never going back to that price again' (a share price of 275p). fields.headline: Media Diary
fields.trailText: Cricket pitch battles | Single White Anchor
fields.body:
A losing bid that just wasn't cricket
For those who missed the full fun of Kelvin MacKenzie's talkSport Radio losing its bid for radio Test Cricket rights against the BBC - who incidentally offered to pay less - here are the edited highlights.

In a statement pondering why his money wasn't good enough, MacKenzie said: 'Is it because we don't talk like a peer of the realm? Lord McLaurin, who earned his peerage by selling Brussels sprouts [at Tesco], refused in the end to sell us the rights. It's a disgrace, and we will be using this case as a further illustration of why we need to go to the Competition Commission to see the BBC broken up.'

Losing his composure on R4 Kelvin ranted about the Corporation being 'up shit creek without a paddle' at 8.30am, which would have caused a spillage of Lord McLaurin's Earl Grey. An entire fresh pot would have been needed when Mackenzie went on to claim that, as his failed bid had involved free helmets for schools, the next child who died playing cricket would have effectively been killed by the satanic Beeb. Not surprisingly, the normally matey R4 presenter suddenly discovered there was no more time to listen to Kelvin's reasonable views and he was faded out.

The story, albeit unconfirmed, is that Greg Dyke and the BBC bruisers threatened to pull out of TV rights bidding against C4 unless they got the radio rights - a course of action sadly not open to the audio-only MacKenzie.

A bitchy tale of two Jeremys
Because Jeremy 'Paxo' Paxman is the most talented male broadcaster in Britain, by a country mile, we would prefer to think of him as having no taint on his character.

So, can it be true that Sian Kevill, editor of Newsnight, has had to slap Jeremy's wrists for being beastly to the new boy? The allegations, false we are sure, are that Mr Paxman has been referring to the other Jeremy, Jeremy Vine as 'mini-me' and holding up his little finger, no doubt to indicate the junior stature.

Tsk, tsk, except, of course, that it may be a bit disconcerting to be followed around by someone mirroring your mannerisms and appearance.

A case of SWA: Single White Anchor

Beeb's T-Rex? Too lowbrow by miles We hear Walking With Dinosaurs is to be remodelled for the US market. Could it be that they wish to Disney-fy it, turn it into a Jurassic Park? Make the dinosaurs more cutesy, cuddly? Er, no actually. Apparently, Discovery Channel feels that the version shown in the UK was a bit, er, basic in scientific terms. So, a few palaeontologists and Professor Pointy Heads are being inter-cut in the Velociraptor action sequences to give the programme a bit more intellectual bottom.

fields.headline: Coming soon: Bespoke TV
fields.standfirst: Hard disk recorders mean headaches for broadcasters, says  Jamie Doward
fields.trailText: Hard disk recorders mean headaches for broadcasters, says Jamie Doward
fields.body:
It's late on a Tuesday night. You have arrived home from work three hours after the Queen Vic closed. TV land is shut for the night. A horrifying realisation dawns: you will have to wait until Sunday to watch the Eastenders' omnibus - a long time in which to wonder whether Phil is going to get back with Lisa, or whether Pauline is ever going to smile again.

But fear not. Such anxieties will soon be a thing of the past. The big broadcasters and electronics firms are rushing to equip us with new, clever TV sets, capable of recording programmes that the devices think we'll like. And that's just the start. The new machines can play around with time in ways that video recorders cannot. The new ones will allow you to watch a taped programme from the start while it is still being broadcast. This new form of 'non-linear' television - shorthand for TV that allows us to watch programmes whenever we want - is about to become big business, and has major implications for the industry.

The announcement made earlier this month that broadcaster BSkyB is teaming up with US electronics firm TiVo was the clearest indication yet that this technology is about to become a reality over here. TiVo makes the technology behind a new generation of videos which, unlike VCRs, record on hard disk rather than video tape.

The disks can store up to 30 hours' broadcasting which, because it is stored digitally, can be replayed instantaneously. And because it uses hard disk formats, viewers can watch a recorded programme while videoing another. Or they can watch the recorded programme from the start while it is still videoing the rest of the broadcast. This has obvious appeal to sports fans, who would enjoy instant replays on demand.

Of more concern to advertisers is the new devices' ability to cut out commercials. Broadcasters are considering innovative solutions to this.

Chris Tant, an analyst at market research firm Datamonitor, says: 'One suggestion is that people use a credit system, where they get rewarded for watching the ads. If they do, they get a credit off their next month's subscription.'

UK advertisers may find succour in the knowledge that the new devices, which will be on sale by the end of this year, will cost around £500 to buy. This will limit their early appeal. However, as with all new technology, the prices are predicted to fall dramatically if the machines are popular. In the US, a TiVo device with a 14-hour disk sold for $700 nine months ago. A sister 30-hour device cost $1,200. Today both devices are $500 cheaper.

But advocates of the new technology offered by TiVo and its rivals, which include US firm ReplayTV, believe the devices will take off because they offer something that conventional VCRs cannot provide, and this goes beyond simply allowing viewers more flexibility in how and when they watch recorded programmes.

The new systems allow viewers to 'teach' their recorders the sorts of programme they like, so that the devices automatically capture favourite programmes without having to be instructed. You need never miss another trip to Coronation Street. In TiVo's case, users hit 'thumbs up' and 'thumbs down' buttons on control pads. The device learns from this and, because it interacts with the broadcaster, it can trawl the media company's database for similar programmes that may appeal.

Admittedly, the new recording technology's ability to personalise in this way is limited so far. 'There's a lot of development to be done in terms of the software,' one industry observer said.

But this is not to say the VCR is dead once the software's teething problems are resolved. 'You've only got so much space on your hard disk,' Tant said. 'There will still be a need for a permanent storage medium if you want to archive things. It's not going to kill off VHS.'

Equally, the solutions being offered by the likes of TiVo may themselves be usurped by other forms of emerging technology before long. NDS Broadcasting Solutions, a UK company listed on the US Nasdaq shares index and 80 per cent-owned by Rupert Murdoch's News Corp, will by the end of this year have launched what it describes as the world's first truly integrated digital TV service. One, as yet unnamed, UK broadcaster has already signed up for it.

Unlike the TiVo system, the new service, called XTV, uses a computer code known as XML - this is the multi-media version of HTML, the language that powers the World Wide Web. Several other companies are looking to introduce similar solutions, and the idea is to make XML an industry-wide set of protocols so that it can work across all platforms.

Because the system uses its own language, users will be able to 'communicate' with the programmes stored on the hard disks of the new recording devices.

'When I sit down and watch the news at the moment, I have to watch a standard bulletin. But with the new system, I can see a list of topics featured in the bulletin. I can then choose which ones I want to watch in detail and which I just want to glance at,' said Andrew Wallace, marketing director at Pace, the company which will build a new generation of digital recorders to integrate with XTV.

This will move the new generation of black boxes from recording programmes you like into offering truly personalised interactive digital services. Tant says this could end up working to the advertisers' advantage: 'The new systems could streamline the ads to your television and pick out the ones that are the most relevant to you.'

David Richardson, director of business development at NDS, says: 'It's a much more efficient system. It generates more revenue for the broadcaster, and it gives much more value to the consumer.'

NDS was given a boost last week when Microsoft announced a strategic alliance with the company that will see the two partners develop software and applications for interactive television. While Microsoft takes over the new technology's operating system, NDS will concentrate on writing the code for the broadcasts that will allow viewers to interact with programmes.

Pacific Century Cyberworks, the Internet company owned by Asian tycoon Richard Li, is developing its own form of interactive television: this will see broadcasts intertwined with Internet technology, so viewers can watch a programme and then explore websites related to it. The development of broadband telecoms networks means these sites will soon be able to carry video-quality footage.From the competing claims made for these different systems it is clear that the fragmented UK television market is about to splinter again. After the platform wars, the new recording war ... It's coming soon to a television near you.
