webTitle: Still crazes after all these years

fields.headline: Still crazes after all these years
fields.standfirst: Is Whitbread really worth less than the latest dot.com? Throughout history super soaraway shares have defied gravity - for a while, says  Ben Laurance . And as for the p/e ratio - it could just as well stand for preposterous expectations :   The share price of anything, but the value of nothing
fields.trailText: Is Whitbread really worth less than the latest dot.com? Throughout history super soaraway shares have defied gravity - for a while, says Ben Laurance . And as for the p/e ratio - it could just as well stand for preposterous expectations : The share price of anything, but the value of nothing
fields.body:
With the benefit of hindsight, the grass skirt should have been a giveaway. It was the mid-Eighties and the investors' love affair with biotechnology companies was at its most passionate. Robert Swanson, a venture capitalist by training, was chief executive officer of Genentech - one of the few biotech groups that had managed to bring some products to market.

Swanson was riding the wave of biotech fever with great enthusiasm. His company had developed a product, t-PA, which was hailed (largely by Genentech itself) as the greatest advance to date in the treatment of life-threatening blood clots. The company's share price had rocketed. Employees were encouraged to don T-shirts bearing the words 'Clot Buster'. And Swanson missed no opportunity to celebrate Genentech's success. He regularly organised Friday afternoon parties at the head office. These gatherings were enlivened with pie-throwing and water pistol fights and, on occasion, Swanson would bring the event to a hilarious climax by donning a grass skirt to dance the hula.

Investors were not concerned. They would let nothing qualify their affection for Genentech. Biotech was the sector to invest in and Genentech was the biotech company.

At least, that is what they believed in 1987. Then, some more cautious souls began to subject Genentech to some of the more conventional tests of investment analysis. Was its share price really justified by even the most optimistic of earnings forecasts? Should investors not worry that there was no hope - even in the medium-term - of the company giving its shareholders even modest income from dividends?

Genentech's share price, which had touched $65, fell to $18 within 12 months. Swanson hung up his grass skirt.

The Genentech episode was just one example of a share price gaining a momentum that defied the conventional rules of stock market pricing. And now, more than a decade later, analysts are struggling to find a new set of rules by which the soaring share prices of a new group of companies - 'dot.com' stocks - can be explained.

The 'conventional' tools of valuation seem to have been abandoned. How else could a company such as Baltimore Technology, with monthly sales of £2 million and losses of £3m be deemed worthy of inclusion in the FTSE-100 when Whitbread, with monthly sales of £250m and profits of nearly £30m is not?.

But even the 'conventional' measures are relatively young. At the start of the twentieth century, there were some rough-and-ready rules for estimating how much a company should be worth. The world had moved on from the days of the South Sea Company, whose success in the early eighteenth century had spawned scores of imitators whose only aim was to part gullible investors from their money.

Money was raised to extract silver from lead, build a wheel of perpetual motion and trade in human hair, among many other things. Most strikingly of all, one unidentified soul launched 'a company for carrying on an undertaking of great advantage, but nobody is to know what it is'. Dozens of people subscribed funds for this project. The promoter closed his doors after five hours, took the money and vanished.

But it was only after the First World War that a generally accepted system for valuing shares was devised. It was outlined by American John Williams in The Theory of Investment Value. The basis of his ideas was simple: that every investment has an 'intrinsic value', and that value is determined by the dividend income it yields now and the likely rate of increase in the future. Add up all that future income, apply a 'discount rate' according to the difference one attributes to money this year as opposed to money in the future, and bingo: you can work out the current intrinsic value.

In theory, the idea seems fine. If a share's price is less than its intrinsic value, it should be bought; if its price is higher than its intrinsic value, it should be sold.

But there are two clear snags: first, over what period does the investor assume a particular growth rate for the income an investment will yield? Second, what if the discount rate were to change? This would throw out comparisons between a share currently giving a high yield but with low growth prospects and a second stock with low yield but better growth prospects.

Nevertheless, the notion of intrinsic value - helped by the publication of Benjamin Graham and David Dodd's seminal work Security Analysis - provided the underpinning of valuations for a generation of investors. Dividend yields were the crucial measure of a share's value. Arguably, the more modern approach - of comparing a share's price with the net earnings attributable to that share - is merely a variation on the well-established theme. After all, no company can pay dividends for very long unless it has the earnings from which to pay them.

The main intellectual challenge to the idea came from the eminent economist John Maynard Keynes, whose 1936 General Theory pointed out that no one really knows what is going to influence future earnings and dividends. So investors spend their time trying to anticipate how the view held by the rest of the market will change. Every other investor is trying to do the same. So the market is trying to guess what the market guesses the market will guess.

Keynes wrote: 'It is not sensible to pay 25 for an investment of which you believe the prospective yield to justify a value of 30 if you also believe that the market will value it at 20 in three months' time.'

Keynes used the famous example of a beauty contest in a newspaper. The reader's aim is to select the six prettiest faces from 100. The winner is the person whose choice conforms most closely to the average of all those who enter the contest. The sensible strategy is not to choose the six which you individually find most pleasing, but to choose those which you believe the readership will select. But every other canny reader will be doing the same. So, you have to guess what other readers guess other readers will guess.

If you apply this to invest ments, prices of shares can sustain a level well above what their intrinsic value would suggest. They stay there not because the shares' holders believe that this is the 'right' price, but because they believe other investors will soon believe that the market will believe them to be worth more.

Nevertheless, since the Sixties, the main plank of share valuation has been that of price/earnings ratios: a share priced at 120p in a company which will give earnings per share this year of 10p has a p/e ratio of 12, for example. And since the mid-Nineties, a variation of this has appeared under the acronym of EV/EBITDA, standing for Enterprise Value divided by Earnings Before Interest, Tax, Depreciation and Amortisation. Enterprise value equates to a company's stock market value plus its debts: in other words, the enterprise value of a company with a market capitalisation of £6m and debts of £4m has an enterprise value of £10m.

A further measure which has its supporters is economic value added: this is a fiendishly complicated varia tion on an old favourite of discounted cash flow - taking the flow of cash a company is likely to produce over coming years and attributing a current value to that flow.

But - particularly in the current environment, where huge values are being put on companies which are making losses and will do so for years to come - measures such as yields and book value are looking quaint but unloved.

The essential point is this: conventional valuation mea sures have been abandoned at regular intervals over most of the twentieth century. In the 18 months between March 1928 and September 1929, share prices on Wall Street increased by more than they had in the previous five years. Exactly as Keynes was later to explain, people bought shares because - whether or not they thought the prices were already too high - they believed that they would go higher. In those 18 months, the price of shares in Radio Corporation of America increased fivefold. (After the Great Crash, they fell by 97 per cent from their September 1929 peak.)

Between 1959 and 1962, there was a fashion for what were then considered high-tech stocks, the 'tronics boom'. To be highly rated, a company had to have a name which suggested that it was a 'tron' - Astron, Vulcatron, Transitron, Circuitronics and Videotronics, for example.

The American Music Guild, whose business consisted of selling records and record players door-to-door, caught the Zeitgeist. It changed its name to Space-Tone, and its share price rose sevenfold within a few weeks.

As with all crazes, it died out - and investors suffered. Take one example - Hydro-Space Technology. It was floated at $3 a share in July 1960. The price hit $7 on their first day of trading. Their low in 1962 was $1.

In the mid-Sixties, conglomerates became fashionable. Many of their shares were selling on price/earnings multiples of 40 and 50. By 1969, their prices had tumbled and p/e ratios were down to a less giddy 10-15.

Also in the mid-Sixties, there was a boom in 'concept stocks' where a company was highly-rated because it had a smart idea even if it was unclear how this would ever be translated into income. (This may sound eerily familiar to observers looking at dot.com stocks today.) P/e ratios commonly topped 100.

'Why?' asked the fund manager. 'Because, because... because everybody else is.' Very scientific.

It was the mid-Eighties and the investors' love affair with biotechnology companies was at its most passionate. Robert Swanson, a venture capitalist by training, was chief executive officer of Genentech - one of the few biotech groups that had managed to bring some products to market. Swanson was riding the wave of biotech fever with great enthusiasm. His company had developed a product, t-PA, which was hailed (largely by Genentech itself) as the greatest advance to date in the treatment of life-threatening blood clots. The company's share price had rocketed. Employees were encouraged to don T-shirts bearing the words 'Clot Buster'. And Swanson missed no opportunity to celebrate Genentech's success. He regularly organised Friday afternoon parties at the head office. These gatherings were enlivened with pie-throwing and water pistol fights and, on occasion, Swanson would bring the event to a hilarious climax by donning a grass skirt to dance the hula. Investors were not concerned. They would let nothing qualify their affection for Genentech. Biotech was the sector to invest in and Genentech was the biotech company. At least, that is what they believed in 1987. Then, some more cautious souls began to subject Genentech to some of the more conventional tests of investment analysis. Was its share price really justified by even the most optimistic of earnings forecasts? Should investors not worry that there was no hope - even in the medium-term - of the company giving its shareholders even modest income from dividends? Genentech's share price, which had touched $65, fell to $18 within 12 months. Swanson hung up his grass skirt. The Genentech episode was just one example of a share price gaining a momentum that defied the conventional rules of stock market pricing. And now, more than a decade later, analysts are struggling to find a new set of rules by which the soaring share prices of a new group of companies - 'dot.com' stocks - can be explained. The 'conventional' tools of valuation seem to have been abandoned. How else could a company such as Baltimore Technology, with monthly sales of £2 million and losses of £3m be deemed worthy of inclusion in the FTSE-100 when Whitbread, with monthly sales of £250m and profits of nearly £30m is not?. But even the 'conventional' measures are relatively young. At the start of the twentieth century, there were some rough-and-ready rules for estimating how much a company should be worth. The world had moved on from the days of the South Sea Company, whose success in the early eighteenth century had spawned scores of imitators whose only aim was to part gullible investors from their money. Money was raised to extract silver from lead, build a wheel of perpetual motion and trade in human hair, among many other things. Most strikingly of all, one unidentified soul launched 'a company for carrying on an undertaking of great advantage, but nobody is to know what it is'. Dozens of people subscribed funds for this project. The promoter closed his doors after five hours, took the money and vanished. But it was only after the First World War that a generally accepted system for valuing shares was devised. It was outlined by American John Williams in The Theory of Investment Value. The basis of his ideas was simple: that every investment has an 'intrinsic value', and that value is determined by the dividend income it yields now and the likely rate of increase in the future. Add up all that future income, apply a 'discount rate' according to the difference one attributes to money this year as opposed to money in the future, and bingo: you can work out the current intrinsic value. In theory, the idea seems fine. If a share's price is less than its intrinsic value, it should be bought; if its price is higher than its intrinsic value, it should be sold. But there are two clear snags: first, over what period does the investor assume a particular growth rate for the income an investment will yield? Second, what if the discount rate were to change? This would throw out comparisons between a share currently giving a high yield but with low growth prospects and a second stock with low yield but better growth prospects. Nevertheless, the notion of intrinsic value - helped by the publication of Benjamin Graham and David Dodd's seminal work Security Analysis - provided the underpinning of valuations for a generation of investors. Dividend yields were the crucial measure of a share's value. Arguably, the more modern approach - of comparing a share's price with the net earnings attributable to that share - is merely a variation on the well-established theme. After all, no company can pay dividends for very long unless it has the earnings from which to pay them. The main intellectual challenge to the idea came from the eminent economist John Maynard Keynes, whose 1936 General Theory pointed out that no one really knows what is going to influence future earnings and dividends. So investors spend their time trying to anticipate how the view held by the rest of the market will change. Every other investor is trying to do the same. So the market is trying to guess what the market guesses the market will guess. Keynes wrote: 'It is not sensible to pay 25 for an investment of which you believe the prospective yield to justify a value of 30 if you also believe that the market will value it at 20 in three months' time.' Keynes used the famous example of a beauty contest in a newspaper. The reader's aim is to select the six prettiest faces from 100. The winner is the person whose choice conforms most closely to the average of all those who enter the contest. The sensible strategy is not to choose the six which you individually find most pleasing, but to choose those which you believe the readership will select. But every other canny reader will be doing the same. So, you have to guess what other readers guess other readers will guess. If you apply this to invest ments, prices of shares can sustain a level well above what their intrinsic value would suggest. They stay there not because the shares' holders believe that this is the 'right' price, but because they believe other investors will soon believe that the market will believe them to be worth more. Nevertheless, since the Sixties, the main plank of share valuation has been that of price/earnings ratios: a share priced at 120p in a company which will give earnings per share this year of 10p has a p/e ratio of 12, for example. fields.headline: Lottery movies: 9 hits, 121 misses
fields.standfirst:
Vanessa Thorpe and Antony Barnett examine why lottery-funded films have become a byword for mediocrity

Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Vanessa Thorpe and Antony Barnett examine why lottery-funded films have become a byword for mediocrity
fields.body:
It sounded promising. Colin Firth was on board. The screenplay had a glamorous location in the south of France and the central plot had all the right credentials, concerning, as it did, an imperilled and steamy love affair across the racial divide.

But if you have not yet seen the feature film The Secret Laughter of Women , if you have not even heard of it, then you are not alone. Although the film won a lottery grant of just under £1m, its box-office takings last year came to only £2,832 in this country. The critics were not ecstatic either. A typical review in the British magazine Total Film commented: 'The fairytale relationship follows a disappointingly predictable trajectory, with Firth giving an anaemic performance in a poorly written role.'

Government figures released to The Observer this weekend reveal that this unpleasant twist to the end of what should have been a lovely story is not an isolated incident. A lottery grant is starting to look more like a blight on a film's chances of audience popularity than a boost.

Of around 130 feature films that have received backing since lottery money came on stream in 1996, only nine could be counted as any sort of success. Many have faltered at the final hurdle and are still awaiting distribution deals, others are permanently on hold.

Perhaps the most painful figures to read, though, are the large sums that went into films that have won big cinema releases and which were far from enjoyable to watch: this year's critically panned Fanny and Elvis , for example, with a grant of more than £1m, or the upcoming Kevin Spacey film, Ordinary Decent Criminal , which also had a £1m grant.

For many within the industry the sad roll call of silver screen turkeys is directly attributable to the cosy clique of producers and financiers who are in charge of handing out the grant money in Britain. They may well have been keen to support the constantly threatened, home grown production business with a windfall of lottery money, but in doing this, it sometimes seems large amounts have gone to projects on little more than the recommendation of a friend.

Rupert Preston of the independent film distributor Metrodome sees lottery funding as a force for mediocrity, not excellence. He also thinks it is ultimately a business irrelevance.

'Good films, like our own Human Traffic , for example, tend to emerge anyway, without any lottery help. We did ask for a grant for that one but we were told, no, because it was all about nasty drugs.'

Even the more obviously commercial bets, such as last spring's romantic comedy This Year's Love , can make it through without calling upon public funds.

'It is a scandal, to be frank. Many of the lottery-funded films don't even get a distributor,' says Preston.

'All this money is spent and then no one actually sees them, whether they are any good or not. A vast amount of money has been spent; I would say around £30m for each of the three big film franchises that were set up to hand out production cash, and then another £70m at least which has gone direct into production itself.'

Most lottery money was granted through the film panel at the Arts Council, a now disbanded collection of appointed producers and film finance experts who inevitably had connections with several of the production deals that they funded.

Colin Levanthal of Hal Productions, for example, was a member of the Arts Council panel and his film Mansfield Park , a joint BBC Films venture with US giant Miramax, was one of those to benefit. It received a £1m grant and, while it has been welcomed by some critics, it is hard to see why a commercial project with such big backers should receive public funds.

Premila Hoon, the doyenne of British film finance, was also an Arts Council panelist at the time she was orchestrating the film investments made by Guinness Mahon. This company put money into two fairly successful recent projects, Wilde and Shooting Fish , which had also received big lottery grants. Both Leventhal and Hoon declared their financial interests at the time.

The producer of the Oscar-nominated documentary film One Day in September , John Battsek, is critical of the funding structure. He believes it is helping from the wrong end.

'It is first-time, independent producers who have the hardest time breaking through. These are the people that would like to keep the British business going and who are prepared to risk money on a good script. The scripts themselves, to be honest, will always come through if they are good enough - although it might also be worth making grants to young screenwriters,' he said.

Battsek, whose brother Daniel runs British distribution for Disney, believes the common complaint about distribution is a red herring. The wider deals, he argues, will come to the best movies.

'On the other hand, it is hellish becoming a producer unless you already have a private income. If you are in the established producers' loop you can just continue to make films without any of them being any good. I don't actually like to think about that.'

Yet it may all be about to change. The British public film funding bureaucracy is on the brink of the biggest reshuffle ever. Following the report of the government advisory committee, The Bigger Picture, the various commercial and public funding routes for films are to be combined in the Film Council.

Rather less radically, many of the personnel will remain the same. The body will be chaired by Alan Parker, the film director who chaired the government advisory panel, and Stewart Till, his vice chair and former business associate, will be a council member.

Other council members, including Colin Leventhal, will transfer directly from the dissolved Arts Council film panel.

Tina MacFarling of the Film Council emphasises that many of the strategies for organising funding may be changed, but she defended the history of the lottery awards.

'When this money was given to the industry it was not thought it should be given direct to film projects, it was just for capital projects. This was because they wanted to create some sort of continuity, so that producers did not have to keep starting afresh,' MacFarling says.

The industry analyst, Mark Smith of Film Digest , sees the problem with inter-connecting deals as intractable.

'It is a very, very small industry in this country,' he says. 'The companies making these films employ four or five people only, so everyone always knows everyone else. Having said that, there is no shortage of people who want to break into it and can't.'

The low takings in British cinemas for many of these films do not reflect the total income since, as Smith points out, recently British films have made more in France than they have here. The sums also exclude eventual returns for TV screenings and video and DVD sales.

The low taking figures simply show that British audiences did not come to see these lottery-funded films. Why? Well, Smith suspects that the old industry rule of thumb that if you made 10 films, one of them would pay for the other nine has now been distorted. Public money has brought dodgy projects forward and lengthened the odds still further in a risky business.

Smith's colleague, David Hancock, adds that across Europe, public film funding is being withdrawn.

'I would like to see the method of repaying public investors improved here, too. The problem is that they are often the last in the chain to recoup when a film goes into profit.'

And of course there have been relative box-office successes. The acclaimed Mike Leigh film Topsy Turvy had a grant, so did The Ideal Husband , Hilary and Jackie , Hideous Kinky , The Land Girls and Plunkett and Macleane. There have been true critical successes too. Films like Sara Sugarman's Ratcatcher of last year, which would not have been made without the lottery. But Ratcatcher is the exception. It might have been better if The Secret Laughter of Women had remained a secret -and the same can be said for many others on the lottery funding list.

Remember these?

The Lost Son
Starring Daniel Auteuil and Katrin Cartlidge, 1999
Summary: A French detective (Daniel Auteuil) working in London is hired to find the missing 30-year-old son of a wealthy couple. The film was based on Eric Leclere's 1995 original screenplay written in collaboration with his wife, Margaret.Directed by: Chris Menges, Scala Productions.
Review: The Observer Peter Preston: 'This, in essence, is a stylish French film noir translated to NW5.'
The Guardian Peter Bradshaw: 'It ends with absurd violence and melodrama, and the paedophilia motif looks tacky and dubious.'
Lottery grant: £2,300,000
UK takings: £49,302

Downtime
Starring Paul McGann, 1998
Summary: A thriller set in a lift shaft in rain-lashed tower block in Newcastle. While the cops and crowds congregate below, former police psychologist Rob tries to coax a potential suicide in from the ledge. Directed by Bharat Nalluri, in his second feature
Review: Variety 'If the script had remained centred on the apartment block through to the end -- and developed loose ends like the roaming gang members, the character of Kevin and the poorly written Jimmy (which squanders Georgeson's talents) -- the movie could have laid claim to being a successful genre-bender. As it is, it's a game try...'
Lottery grant: £768, 898
UK takings: £28,135

Amy Foster
Starring Rachel Weisz and Ian McKellen, 1998
Summary: Set amid the craggy cliffs of nineteenth-century Cornwall, Amy Foster charts the passionate affair of a young servant girl (Rachel Weisz) and her immigrant lover, Yanko (Vincent Perez), the sole survivor of a capsized ship bound for America. Based on the powerful short story by Joseph Conrad, the film is an epic, passionate and tragic tale about courage, individuality and the resiliency of the human heart. Director Beeban Kidron. Writers Tim Willocks.
Review: On the net 'As a love story it has all the ingredients of a girls' dorm fantasy.'
Lottery grant: £2,000,000
UK takings: £48,711

Beautiful people
Starring Charlotte Coleman, 1998
Summary: A manic comedy set in 1993 London as the Bosnian war rages, the film features the entwined lives of a motley assembly of Brits and Bosnian refugees. Trimark Pictures. Directed by Jasmin Dizdar, first-time director and screenwriter
Review: The Observer
Philip French: 'Most of the characters (particularly a Tory backbencher and a band of skinheads) border on caricature, but the picture is cleverly patterned and fairly amusing.'
Lottery grant: £553,823
UK takings: £116,966

'When this money was given to the industry it was not thought it should be given direct to film projects, it was just for capital projects. This was because they wanted to create some sort of continuity, so that producers did not have to keep starting afresh,' MacFarling says. The industry analyst, Mark Smith of Film Digest , sees the problem with inter-connecting deals as intractable. 'It is a very, very small industry in this country,' he says. 'The companies making these films employ four or five people only, so everyone always knows everyone else. Having said that, there is no shortage of people who want to break into it and can't.' The low takings in British cinemas for many of these films do not reflect the total income since, as Smith points out, recently British films have made more in France than they have here. The sums also exclude eventual returns for TV screenings and video and DVD sales. The low taking figures simply show that British audiences did not come to see these lottery-funded films. Why? Well, Smith suspects that the old industry rule of thumb that if you made 10 films, one of them would pay for the other nine has now been distorted. Public money has brought dodgy projects forward and lengthened the odds still further in a risky business. Smith's colleague, David Hancock, adds that across Europe, public film funding is being withdrawn. 'I would like to see the method of repaying public investors improved here, too. The problem is that they are often the last in the chain to recoup when a film goes into profit.' And of course there have been relative box-office successes. The acclaimed Mike Leigh film Topsy Turvy had a grant, so did The Ideal Husband , Hilary and Jackie , Hideous Kinky , The Land Girls and Plunkett and Macleane. There have been true critical successes too. Films like Sara Sugarman's Ratcatcher of last year, which would not have been made without the lottery. But Ratcatcher is the exception. It might have been better if The Secret Laughter of Women had remained a secret -and the same can be said for many others on the lottery funding list. Remember these? The Lost Son Starring Daniel Auteuil and Katrin Cartlidge, 1999 Summary: A French detective (Daniel Auteuil) working in London is hired to find the missing 30-year-old son of a wealthy couple. The film was based on Eric Leclere's 1995 original screenplay written in collaboration with his wife, Margaret.Directed by: Chris Menges, Scala Productions. Review: The Observer Peter Preston: 'This, in essence, is a stylish French film noir translated to NW5.' The Guardian Peter Bradshaw: 'It ends with absurd violence and melodrama, and the paedophilia motif looks tacky and dubious.' Lottery grant: £2,300,000 UK takings: £49,302 Downtime Starring Paul McGann, 1998 Summary: A thriller set in a lift shaft in rain-lashed tower block in Newcastle. While the cops and crowds congregate below, former police psychologist Rob tries to coax a potential suicide in from the ledge. Directed by Bharat Nalluri, in his second feature Review: Variety 'If the script had remained centred on the apartment block through to the end -- and developed loose ends like the roaming gang members, the character of Kevin and the poorly written Jimmy (which squanders Georgeson's talents) -- the movie could have laid claim to being a successful genre-bender. As it is, it's a game try...' Lottery grant: £768, 898 UK takings: £28,135 Amy Foster Starring Rachel Weisz and Ian McKellen, 1998 Summary: Set amid the craggy cliffs of nineteenth-century Cornwall, Amy Foster charts the passionate affair of a young servant girl (Rachel Weisz) and her immigrant lover, Yanko (Vincent Perez), the sole survivor of a capsized ship bound for America. Based on the powerful short story by Joseph Conrad, the film is an epic, passionate and tragic tale about courage, individuality and the resiliency of the human heart. Director Beeban Kidron. Writers Tim Willocks. Review: On the net 'As a love story it has all the ingredients of a girls' dorm fantasy.' Lottery grant: £2,000,000 UK takings: £48,711 Beautiful people Starring Charlotte Coleman, 1998 Summary: A manic comedy set in 1993 London as the Bosnian war rages, the film features the entwined lives of a motley assembly of Brits and Bosnian refugees. Trimark Pictures. Directed by Jasmin Dizdar, first-time director and screenwriter Review: The Observer Philip French: 'Most of the characters (particularly a Tory backbencher and a band of skinheads) border on caricature, but the picture is cleverly patterned and fairly amusing.' Lottery grant: £553,823 UK takings: £116,966

webTitle: Ants' eggs: how many will hatch?

fields.headline: Ants' eggs: how many will hatch?
fields.standfirst: European companies have been quicker off the e-commerce mark than US ones, but antfactory says they need help, writes  Simon Caulkin
fields.trailText: European companies have been quicker off the e-commerce mark than US ones, but antfactory says they need help.
fields.body:
'You have to experience it - Internet time really is so much faster it's incredible,' says Rob Bier, charging out of his office in Victoria.

'Lead times for doing a business plan are down to days and, for launching a company, to weeks - nothing' As the e-commerce technology infrastructure is perfected, the pace will become even hotter, he promises.

Bier, a 39-year-old American, is group managing director of antfactory, a London-based 'incubator' ('for lack of a better word') which aims to turn that speed to business advantage.

However, it is not just quickness off the mark that is of the essence. Antfactory, which has raised just shy of $50 million so far, was founded on the premise that once hatched, its quick-fire fledglings must also be able to compete in real markets at Internet speed.

Accordingly, to the seed capital and services other incubators provide, antfactory aims to add a strong management capability. Also contributing to the party are powerful partners with existing assets to pitch in - whether brands, distribution, manufacturing or management talent. In other words, big corporates.

'We're not just an investor but an operating company,' Bier insists. 'So we could start with an entrepreneur with an idea, like any venture capitalist or incubator. But the starting point could equally be a corporate with an idea, or a corporate with assets but no idea, or a group of talented executives who want to play this game. We think there are bigger value-creating opportunities in combining all the elements.'

The eggs that antfactory aims to sit on are correspondingly large, more ostrich than quail: companies targeting markets of $1 billion plus in which they can be No 1 or 2 -and where they can make equally serious financial returns.

Internet incubators are now two a penny, but Antfactory argues that it differs from the herd by virtue of its deliberate corporate and European focus.

The analysis goes like this. There's a $1 trillion value grab going on as the economy changes under the impact of the Internet, 'and we want to be among the people who create the companies that capture that value', says Bier.

But while in the US much of the potential value has been claimed by the dot.coms, in Europe a different e-business ecology is emerging.

While large US companies took two to three years to wake up to the new economy, European firms have been quicker. That means Internet start-ups haven't been able to get such a head start.

European companies are also beginning to believe that the Old Continent's consumers may be more loyal to old brands - and less open to new ones - than Americans. The net result, says Bier, is that 'we think big European corporations could have a major influence on shaping the whole Internet economy'.

But they can do this only if they can overcome some tricky management problems. One issue is cultural: many big firms are risk-averse, bewildered by fast-forward new business models and entirely lacking the entrepreneurial talent to execute them.

Worse are the structural impediments. The reason big companies find it so difficult to adapt to disruptive technology shifts is that the optimal new business almost always cannibalises the old (this is why BT seems paralysed by the Internet). The result, says Bier, is 'the bright guys are hindered at every turn, and the invariable outcome is compromise'.

Existing pay systems are also hostile to internal enterprise - and so, sometimes, is the shareholder base. 'If you're a steady, boring old company and you want to pour £50 million into an Internet venture, that changes the risk profile, which doesn't suit some shareholders,' Bier says.

So the best, or only, way for most big companies to get into the e-speed economy is to do it via separate and autonomous start-ups, in partnership with companies that do have experience of the new conditions. Even old-economy companies such as retailers, oil companies and car manufacturers are getting in on the the act in this way.

Which is where antfactory comes in. 'We think we can help corporations overcome these kinds of problems, exploit the value of their position and their knowledge assets and invest in new platforms as joint-venture partners,' explains Bier. He points to figures from the US Small Business Administration which suggest that 'incubated' start-ups have a much greater chance of survival than those that go it alone.

But how many eggs can one management team nurture into fully fledged companies in such hands-on style? Antfactory has a dozen or so projects on the go, in which it has invested $15m. Among them are a joint venture with coffee retailer Whittard's; Inmoclick, a Spanish residential ISP; eShipping, an online shipping exchange; and ace-quote.com, a B2B marketplace for information technology.

Antfactory, which also has a presence in Paris, Munich, Amsterdam and Madrid, is targeting 40 deals this year, says Bier, many of them for corporations. A key success factor will be its ability to staff its ventures as quickly as it does everything else. The traditional headhunting cycle -three months to draw up a shortlist, another three months to make a choice and draw up contracts -is yet another casualty of galloping Internet time.

So what happens to antfactory if there's a stock market crash? 'There'll be a traumatic effect on the bottom third of the start-up proposals we see,' predicts Bier. 'The top third will still go ahead but at lower values, which is no bad thing. And corporations will still want to go ahead because their ventures are strategic and essential.' In other words, the quantity may slacken off -but not the speed.

 simon.caulkin@observer.co.uk

webTitle: I can't get my job terms in writing

fields.headline: I can't get my job terms in writing
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: I have moved from being part-time to full-time, and from being on a contract to being employed on an indefinite basis since my fixed-period contract expired two years ago. But I do not have a contract of employment covering my present position. My boss suggests I should not rattle the cage. What can I do?
fields.body:
I have moved from being part-time to full-time, and from being on a contract to being employed on an indefinite basis since my fixed-period contract expired two years ago. But I do not have a contract of employment covering my present position. My boss suggests I should not rattle the cage. What can I do?

 You have a legal right to a written copy of certain of your terms and conditions - your hours, your pay and the date your 'continuous service' started. Your right is to receive these within a month of starting employment. You can pursue these rights in an employment tribunal, but this route is a difficult one.

There are other starting points. Your terms would be judged by a tribunal to be 'reasonable' ones when considering your previous contract, the practices you and your colleagues follow and terms thought fair in the industry.

You could also drop a line to personnel, saying you are sure they would want to fulfil their legal duties and logging the fact that veiled comments have been made about the adverse affects of asking for a written contract. This would be useful in a tribunal if they did end up firing you after you asked for a written contract.

 Legal advice from Lewis Silkin's 'Employment Case Law - the impact on HR managers' available on customer.services@gee.co.uk

 Problem at work? Write to Neasa MacErlean, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1 3ER. Answers are for guidance only.

webTitle: Hitting that deadline may be the last thing you do

fields.headline: Hitting that deadline may be the last thing you do
fields.standfirst:
Rush, rush, can't stop, gotta hurry... Will the pace of our jobs break us? Peter Baker investigates
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: It is not only working long hours that can damage your health. Employees who usually have to work at speed, or who are always rushing to meet tight deadlines, are about twice as likely to fall ill because of their work as those who work at a more leisurely pace.
fields.body:
It is not only working long hours that can damage your health. Employees who usually have to work at speed, or who are always rushing to meet tight deadlines, are about twice as likely to fall ill because of their work as those who work at a more leisurely pace, according to new Cambridge University research released exclusively to The Observer.

This startling statistic is based on an analysis of data from the European Survey on Working Conditions, an ongoing study of 1,000 employees in each European Union country by Dr Brendan Burchell, lecturer in social and political sciences at Cambridge University.

Take backache, for example. Dr Burchell's figures show that 40 per cent of staff working at speed for all or almost all of their time suffer from work-related back pain, compared with just 23 per cent of those who work at speed for a quarter of their time or less.

Staff who regularly face tight deadlines are also more likely to be affected. Burchell calculates that 37 per cent of those who work to tight deadlines all or most of the time are affected by backache caused by their job, compared with 25 per cent of those who work to tight deadlines for a quarter of their time or less.

The same pattern is repeated across 14 other physical and mental health problems, including headaches, stomach pains, sleeping difficulties, fatigue, allergies, ear and eye disorders and skin complaints.

And the illnesses linked to hard work are by no means trivial: heart disease is also twice as common among those regularly working at high speed or to tight deadlines.

'Continual pressure on employees takes its toll,' says Burchell. 'We used to think that work kept us healthy and that the unemployed were the ones with problems. Now this situation seems to be reversing, and overwork is a major cause of sickness. Even if people enjoy working intensively, it can still be depleting them physically and can affect their health.'

What is especially worrying about this data is that more and more employees are now expected to work harder and harder. This problem extends way beyond call centres, now notorious for their intensive working practices.

Two-thirds of UK employees say that, over the past five years, they have experienced an increase in the speed of work and the effort they put into their jobs, according to Joseph Rowntree Foundation research published last year.

In a survey of over 800 managers at all levels published last month by the Institute of Management (IM), 69 per cent of respondents reported an increased workload over the past 12 months. The research found that the prime cause of stress for managers was time pressure and deadlines.

The European Survey on Working Conditions data also shows that British workers now top the EU list ranking the proportion having to work to tight deadlines all or most of the time.

'The single greatest cause of this work intensification is that employers are downsizing but expecting the remaining workforce to do as much work as before,' says Dr Burchell. 'In the public sector this has been caused by governments trying to reduce expenditure. In the private sector it has been driven by global competition, mergers and takeovers.'

Not everyone agrees that downsizing automatically results in heavier workloads, however. Diane Sinclair, policy adviser at the Institute of Personnel and Development, believes 'an increase in intensity where employees are trained to cope isn't necessarily going to be detrimental'.

Sinclair also remains sceptical about the argument that work is generally becoming increasingly intensive because 'there's little evidence to show that we're becoming more dissatisfied at work'.

However widespread it might be, work intensification can be a difficult problem to tackle because, unlike working hours, it is difficult to quantify. But organisations that fail to act could face expensive compensation claims, as in the case of social worker John Walker. In 1996, Walker was paid £175,000 in an out-of-court settlement by his employer, Northumberland County Council, after he claimed he suffered a nervous breakdown caused by the stress of an unmanageable workload.

Although the problem of long working hours is far from solved, the Working Time Regulations have at least set some limits.

If the Cambridge analysis is correct, work intensification could be the next big workplace problem requiring government action.

Don't let the bosses grind you down

Sue Carr, 39, was an IT team leader for a leading insurance company.

'The trouble started when the company reorganised and I was effectively given three-and-a-quarter jobs. I told my manager this was ridiculous but he said I had to get on with it. I tried, but it was unmanageable.

There were always deadlines to meet and I felt pressurised the whole time. I was also working long days, often up to 12 hours.

After a month, I was exhausted. I had sleep problems, and started to get colds and flu and tension headaches. I took three weeks off work because of the stress, and then another-six-and-a-half weeks. Two years later, I was diagnosed as having ME, which I'm still suffering from.

I eventually got another job, but sued the company for damage to my health. With the help of my union, UNIFI, I received an out-of-court settlement of £17,000 plus costs.

 Jennifer Hall, 37, is a freelance TV producer.

'I've had to work harder over the years as production budgets have been cut.

I have less time to do the job and fewer people to help me with it. As a freelancer, I am also always under continual pressure to look out for the next job. I feel as if I am constantly working.

I sometimes get stomach cramps after a stressful day and I have found it hard to sleep when I've been over-tired and thinking about how to get round a problem. I cannot prove it scientifically, but I always seem to fall ill whenever I have some time off.

Sometimes it will be a cold or flu, but last Christmas I came down with a nasty case of gastro-enteritis. I ended up in bed with a very high temperature - and spent the time worrying about when I would be able to get back to work.'

webTitle: Maybe you can fool the people  but science is on your trail

fields.headline: Maybe you can fool the people  but science is on your trail
fields.standfirst: Big business is sniffing out the little ways we always betray ourselves when we lie
fields.trailText: Big business is sniffing out the little ways we always betray ourselves when we lie
fields.body:
It is one of mankind's most common pursuits, practised 200 times a day by each of us. We claim to loathe it, but build our lives around it - for telling lies is in our genes.

Every day we slither round the truth, claiming to like our loved one's hairstyles, praising our bosses' decisions, and promising to return calls. Such is human nature.

But some individuals go much further and deceive for a living, or at least attempt to gain an unfair advantage over others. And the practice is worsening.

Indeed, the trend to deceive now alarms employers so much that they are turning, more and more, to psychologists and communication experts for help in pinpointing the worst, most dangerous liars in our midst.

'Companies are becoming increasingly interested in spotting deceivers who apply to work for them. They want to make sure their vetting is the best and most professional,' said psychologist Dr Richard Wiseman of Hertfordshire University. 'Spotting liars is becoming big business.'

The increasingly deceptive nature of society was recently revealed by the Association of Search and Selection Consultants (ASSC), which warned companies that a quarter of job seekers now tell straightforward falsehoods on their CVs, lies that include non-existent or exaggerated qualifications, hidden career gaps and inflated past pay levels.

And these are not examples of people who are merely boosting their achievements in some mild way, by claiming dubious sporting abilities or slightly overstated dedication to various charities. These are individuals who slice years, sometimes decades, from their ages, claim non-existent degrees, and cover up bankruptcies and prison sentences.

The practice is becoming more and more serious because people believe that 'everyone else is doing it', say psychologists Liz Walley and Mike Smith in their book, Deception in Selection . As a result, employers are setting up more and more stringent checks on applicants while those seeking jobs are resorting to increasingly complex and devious ways of falsifying CVs.

In an attempt to short-circuit this problem, companies are beginning to screen potential employees' entire demeanour, based on speech patterns and deportment.

'There are some ways in which a person just cannot help but give themselves away,' added Wiseman. 'Very often they betray themselves with a squelched expression on their face, a fleeting glimpse that betrays their real emotion - fear or anger - which is then covered with a false smile that only covers the lower half of the face. It is a good sign that someone is trying to deceive you.'

Such vetting is now being adopted by employers in all walks of life, from the military and civil service to political parties, which are screening potential candidates with mounting intensity. 'The problem is not that politicians lie,' said communications consultant Guy Fielding. 'The issue is whether we can trust them or not. Certainly, telling lies is not abnormal. It is common practice. We praise things we dislike simply to avoid causing our friends offence, for example. And politicians are no different from anyone else in that respect.

'The real problem is that a person who tells too many lies is clearly untrustworthy. We have no confidence that we can have a relationship, no matter how distant, with that person. There are no trustworthy rules or guidelines for dealing with them. That is what brought down Archer. He didn't even tell a lie, in the end. He was actually caught trying to line up a friend to lie on his behalf.'

There were many who warned Tory leaders that Archer was an unpredictable deceiver, of course. Nevertheless, spotting major liars in our midst is an extremely tricky business, for the practice of dissembling is so deeply entrenched in our psy ches and our pasts. As Oscar Wilde pointed out, the first liar was probably the caveman who claimed to have 'slain the mammoth in single combat'.

In fact, human deception predates the Stone Age. Even apes deceive. They will hide food and then pretend they have nothing to eat in the hope they can con the rest of their troop into sharing their goodies with them.

This sort of behaviour has been studied by Andy Whiten and Richard Byrne at St. Andrews University. They have not only recorded examples of solitary apes and monkeys hiding food, but have noted cases in which other animals in their troop - realising that some form of deception was going on - began to spy on these deceivers. Then as these hapless individuals dig up their carefully secreted morsels, the rest of their troop will burst on the scene, and attack them.

In other words, strategies for deception and counter-deception are deeply ingrained in our genes and the subsequent evolution of spoken language by evolving apemen only increased our capacity to lie, causing problems for the rest of the species. 'One reason we developed big brains was to work out which members of our species were lying to us and which were not,' said anthropologist Professor Leslie Aiello, of University College London.

By the time modern humans appeared on the scene, about 150,000 years ago, some sort of equilibrium between deceit and the ability to spot liars had been reached. 'When we look at hunter-gatherer tribes today, we can see they live very fair, egalitarian lives, in which food and possessions are shared,' said Professor Whiten. 'Nevertheless, you will always find examples of individuals hiding the odd bit of food. But if they go too far, they generally get caught.'

In other words, we owe our evolutionary success - at least in part - to our need to pinpoint the lies we were being told by our fellow human beings.

It is a point made by Karl Popper: 'Lying has made the human language what it is: an instrument which can be used for misreporting almost as well as for reporting.' Or as Philip Kerr, editor of the Penguin Book of Lies , says: 'Lying is instinctive rather than learned.'

It suggests that, although psychologists may be able to pinpoint bad, indifferent or even modestly effective liars, they will be hard put to spot the really good ones. Deception is too deeply entrenched in the human soul.

Four ways to spot a liar: Masters of deception

Evasive

 Liars avoid giving direct answers when interrogated and respond to embarrassing questions by asking other questions. All politicians adopt such diversionary tactics, but Richard Nixon was the master of this technique.

 Liars reveal themselves in various ways. Their body language - the tapping of their feet or the drumming of their fingers - often exposes their attempts to deceive. Polygraphs (lie detectors) can occasionally achieve success as well. However, these tests work by measuring a person's stress levels - and a stressed individual is not necessarily a liar. As a result, psychologists now look for other, more certain and subtler characteristics that indicate a person is peddling falsehoods. These include:

Blatant

 Liars tend to stare at their interrogators in a bid to overcompensate for a deeper urge to turn away from the gaze of those they are deceiving. Jeffrey Archer is a classic bare-faced, unashamed, 'in-your-face' deceiver.

Shifty

 A fleeting expression - a look of anger or joy or surprise - often passes momentarily over a liar's face, revealing his or her inner feelings, before being quickly replaced by a forced smile or grin. Bill Clinton's startled look, when asked about the cigar and Monica Lewinsky, and his strained demeanour a couple of seconds later provide such an example.

Hesitant

 Short answers to questions, responses riddled with hesitations or rapid blinking: these indicate a man or woman is in the act of dissembling. The nervous, flickering of the eyes of Neil Hamilton during his recent libel case cross-examination is a typical example of the tell-tale behaviour of the liar.

fields.headline: Motivate yourself
fields.trailText: Understand that there are many things you can do to motivate yourself. Sue Knight, workplace trainer and neuro-linguistic programming enthusiast, says: 'We tend to be brought up to think about what we don't want and what could go wrong.' Many parts of the brain function like a computer - if you feed in negative questions like 'Why am I so bored here?', the feedback will be equally negative. If you ask 'How can I become more satisfied at work?', your subconscious will probably supply several ideas.
fields.body:
Understand that there are many things you can do to motivate yourself. Sue Knight, workplace trainer and neuro-linguistic programming enthusiast, says: 'We tend to be brought up to think about what we don't want and what could go wrong.' Many parts of the brain function like a computer - if you feed in negative questions like 'Why am I so bored here?', the feedback will be equally negative. If you ask 'How can I become more satisfied at work?', your subconscious will probably supply several ideas.

Remember the times when you really felt good about work, and recall in detail what happened and the way you felt. You need to recapture some of that optimism and excitement. Workers often get shifted into jobs they do not like. If your satisfaction comes from working in a team, you may need to reorganise your new management job.

Ask yourself what you want others to think of you. 'Think what you'd like people to say about you when you've just left the room,' says Knight. Work out the values you want to espouse, examples you want to set.

Set yourself small tasks, such as tidying your desk or getting out for a walk in the day, suggests freelance writer Ruth. 'If you can't do the difficult thing, do the simple thing, something that gives you a sense of pride.' If you do not achieve anything in the day, you are adding to your problem.

Use the increasingly popular techniques of visualisation, meditation, exercise and affirmations, suggests Jo Bond of Right outplacement consultants: 'If you visualise yourself being successful, you are far more likely to achieve those goals.' Most people are sceptical about affirmations - saying something like 'I am winning these battles at work' 20 times to yourself - but they are surprisingly motivating.

Find a new job if you cannot imagine getting satisfaction from your present one. We all have personal disaster areas where we function extremely badly. Get away from them as fast as possible. If Beethoven had become an accountant, he would probably have been far less motivated.
